HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Black-Held Businesses In Sales Gain

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
The nation's largest black-owned companies, despite weakness in the economy, said they had a 5.2 increase in sales last year from the previous year, according to an annual survey being released today by Black Enterprise magazine. By contrast, the top 500 American companies listed by Fortune magazine showed a 1990 sales increase of 6.4 percent.
Gross sales for the largest black-owned industrial and service companies and automobile dealerships increased to $7.16 billion in 1990 from $6.81 billion in 1989. 
 But the recession took its toll on the work force of the black-owned companies, which cut their staffs by 4.5 percent last year.
"Black businesses have done nothing different than what other businesses are doing," said Earl G. Graves, editor and publisher of Black Enterprise. "They have been cutting costs and delaying capital expenditures. They have cut staffs, delayed buying new equipment and new vehicles."
Mr. Graves added that the chief executives of the nation's largest black-owned companies "reacted to the recession, the retrenchment of government set-aside programs and diminished private procurement opportunities by showing just how good, smart and tough they could be when the chips were down."
 
One Publicly Traded
 Except for the Johnson Products Company, which is traded on the American Stock Exchange, the companies on the Black Enterprise list are privately held and do not report earnings. The sales figures were given to the magazine by the companies. Mr. Graves speculated that there had been a decline in profitablility in the last year among black-owned companies. "My sense is that profitability has followed the general trend of American corporations," Mr. Graves said.
Heading the list for the fourth consecutive year is TLC Beatrice International Holdings Inc., which includes the international operations of the Beatrice Companies. The holdings were purchased four years ago by the investor Reginald F. Lewis. The company, based in New York, reported sales of $1.49 billion in 1990, accounting for about a quarter of the sales on the list of industrial and service companies.
In second place was the Johnson Publishing Company, the magazine, broadcasting and cosmetics company based in Chicago. Johnson Publishing's sales totaled $252.1 million, up from $241.3 million in 1989. The company, whose magazines include Ebony and Jet, led the ranking four years ago.
In the No. 3 spot again this year was the Philadelphia Coca-Cola Bottling Company, which reported sales of $251.3 million, up from $240 million in the previous year's survey.

HEADLINE: Borrowing by Consumers Down for 4th Month in a Row

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 7

 BODY:
Consumers cut back on borrowing for the fourth straight month in March, a degree of spending restraint not seen since 1980, when credit controls were in place, the Federal Reserve Board said today.
The amount of outstanding consumer installment credit -- loans on cars, furniture and other items that are paid off in monthly chunks -- fell by $931 million after declining a revised $201 million in February. 
 Consumer credit debt fell $2.14 billion in January and $342 million in December, adding up to a four-month shrinkage of $3.61 billion in the amount consumers owed.
The Fed, the nation's central bank, said the last time credit debt fell for four straight months was in 1980, when the Carter Administration imposed stiff controls on lenders as part of its war on inflation. Before that, there had not been a four-month period in which consumer credit contracted since the 1958 recession.
Most of the March drop was accounted for by lower demand for new-car loans, while so-called revolving or credit-card loans were the only category of credit that grew.
Analysts said rising credit-card debt was unhealthy in the long term because it reflected consumers' attempt to maintain living standards amid recession by taking on more debt. Credit cards typically carry extremely high interest rates.
"Any increases in spending that we're seeing seem to be those that are put on credit cards," said Jean Sundrla, an economist at Evans Economics Inc. in Washington.
Credit-card debt grew by $3.25 billion in March, compared with expansion of $1.97 billion in March. But auto loans contracted by $2.29 billion after falling $1.12 billion in February and $839 million in January, as consumers put off buying new cars.
Spending in the first quarter was also dampened by the Persian Gulf war, which depressed consumer sentiment. Spending by consumers fuels two-thirds of economic activity.
Loans to buy mobile homes, another measure of credit activity used by the Fed, fell $95 million in March after dropping $258 million in February. Other loans, which include any bank borrowing other than home mortgages, dropped $1.79 billion after falling $791 million in February.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Magazine Publishers Toast A TBWA Ad for Absolut

BYLINE: By STUART ELLIOTT

 BODY:
WHEN the nation's magazine publishers gathered last night in New York to salute the best print advertising of 1990, the winner wore a familiar, though welcome, face.
Receiving the 10th annual Stephen E. Kelly Award from the Magazine Publishers of America was TBWA Advertising Inc., New York, for its Absolut vodka ads. It was the second time in three years that TBWA has been honored for its unusually creative and innovative ads for the pricey imported liquor. Singled out this time was "Absolut First Class," an ad that appeared in New York magazine in July, showing a sheet of perforated stickers mimicking postage stamps. The sheet was tucked into a glassine envelope that was bound into the magazine. 
 The award, named for the late president of the magazine publishers group, bestows a cash prize of $100,000 on the executives responsible for producing the winning ad, making it the most lucrative of the many ad awards presented each year by various organizations and assocations.
The difficulty of convincing agencies and advertisers of the efficacy of print in an age of video spurred the group to create the Kelly award in 1982, then to increase the prize five years later to $100,000, from $25,000. The strategy behind the award is to treat the agencies' creative staff people as a target market, encouraging them to think print.
"The more we could focus the attention of creative directors, copywriters and art directors on great magazine advertising, the more we could get agencies and clients that haven't been using magazine advertising to consider it," said James R. Guthrie, the group's executive vice president for marketing development.
Still, such an effort -- even when the usual incentive of a prestigious award is sweetened with 100,000 extra reasons to ponder print -- is clearly a daunting task.
"The agencies that have been winning are the small ones that do a lot of print," said Ted Bell, president and director of creative services of Leo Burnett USA in Chicago.
"I would love for Leo Burnett to win the Kelly Award," Mr. Bell added, and indeed Burnett does produce print ads for giant clients like McDonald's and Oldsmobile. But most of the agency's efforts are directed at television.
This suggests there are limits to what any award can achieve.
"I don't think that an award enters into the media choice, that anyone says, 'Hey, let's do print instead of TV because we can win $100,000,' " said Arnold Arlow, executive vice president and co-creative director of TBWA. (Mr. Arlow, one of six people at the agency and at Carillon Importers Ltd., the importer of Absolut, who are sharing the Kelly wealth, was interviewed before the award announcement.)
Peter Eldredge, the United States publisher of Newsweek magazine, said he hoped the Kelly award "does make some difference." But he added: "What the Kelly award is doing is just one step. We should be doing more." Mr. Eldredge wants additional efforts aimed at young media planners and buyers who were "raised on video."
"They read magazines," he said, "but they don't love magazines."
"Love" is probably the right word to describe the affair between Absolut and the magazine industry. Since 1980, Carillon's strategy to stimulate sales of the Swedish vodka has been to drown readers in a sea of Absolut ads, all different and unusual. There have been talking ads, singing ads, ads resembling jigsaw puzzles and ads in 3-D. The result: Absolut has become the No. 1 imported vodka.
Absolut has also become a sort of patron of the arts, not only in the choice of cutting-edge artists to illustrate its ads, but also in its decision to advertise in the initial issues of magazines like the now-defunct Wigwag, as well as in "downtown" magazines aimed at young, hip readers, like the revamped Details. And Absolut has begun to buy space in publications directed at homosexuals, making Carillon one of the few mainstream marketers addressing those consumers through their own media.
Absolut is important to the continued health of many magazines. Although Carillon does not appear to be joining the advertisers cutting back on print during the recession, some magazine executives say the company and TBWA seem to be driving harder bargains when buying space.

GRAPHIC: Photo: TBWA Advertising Inc. was honored last night by the Magazine Publishers of America for its Absolut vodka ads. The ad above, which was singled out for praise, mimicked a sheet of postage stamps within a glassine envelope. The envelope was bound into New York magazine. (TBWA Advertising)

HEADLINE: Laissez-Faire Legacy on Jersey Shore: How Not to Do It

BYLINE: By PETER KERR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SEA BRIGHT, N.J., May 6

 BODY:
So intense and so haphazard is development along the Jersey Shore that it has become an example to other coastal states of what not to do.
For 18 years, builders have taken advantage of a loophole in state law that exempts any development of fewer than 25 units from state regulation. As a result, the 137-mile shoreline is dotted with 24-unit complexes, often shoe-horned in between the beach houses, motels, restaurants, and arcades that make New Jersey's coast one of the most heavily used in the nation. 
 The overbuilding threatens water wildlife and the ecosystems of fragile wetlands.
 
Bill Before Senate
 "In other states they are now saying they want to avoid the New Jerseyization of their shores," said John Weingart, an assistant commissioner in the State Department of Environmental Protection. "We have beautiful beaches, but a huge population that uses them."
As New Jersey again begins its summer campaign to attract visitors to its beaches, environmentalists are pointing to mile after mile of chock-a-block development and are asking the Legislature to restrict overbuilding on the shore.
Next week, a State Senate committee is to hold hearings on a bill that would make developments of 25 or fewer units within 1,000 feet of the ocean subject to state approval. The bill would also require the state to develop a comprehensive plan for future growth in areas near the shore.
But a number of environmentalists say that even if such restrictions are passed into law, the state is going to pay a price for the feverish development of the 1980's. Its legacy, they say, ranges from the traffic jams on the state's highways to the effect of storm water pollution on the fish that swim in coastal waters.
"People who come down to the shore now don't even know what it was once like," said Derickson W. Bennett, the executive director of the American Littoral Society, an environmental group that specializes in coastal issues. "It's just difficult at the shore now to find a place where there isn't somebody else."
Mr. Bennett spoke as he drove his pickup truck down the shoreline road in Sea Bright, a town built on a sliver of sand, a barrier island where several 24-unit condominium complexes were built in recent years. He pointed to the storm drains in parking lots, through which rain washes the oil and other residue from the street out to sea.
Attempts to control development along the shore go back to 1973, when the Coastal Area Facilities Review Act, a bill sponsored by Assemblyman Thomas H. Kean, was enacted. Under the law, developers intending to build along the coastal areas were required to receive approval from the state.
 
1,232 Applications
 But Mr. Kean, who was governor from 1982 to 1990, recalls that under pressure from the state's builders, the Legislature agreed to exempt residential projects of fewer than 25 homes.
Since 1973 the state received 1,232 applications for construction in coastal areas, most of which were large housing projects averaging about 100 units, according to the Department of Environmental Protection. But the state kept no record of the developments of 24 units or less, requiring only the approval of local governments, which often were eager to encourage building that would increase their tax bases.
One count of construction in coastal areas, by The Press of Atlantic City, identified 190 24-unit developments in Ocean, Cape May and Atlantic Counties between 1986 and 1989. The 24-unit complex became so common in coastal areas that shore planners often quip that some day archeologists will try to discern the religious significance of the number 24 in 20th century New Jersey.
In areas like Barnegat Bay, Mr. Bennett said, the water has turned cloudy from sediment washed from the land, blocking the growth of vegetation on the shallow bottom. The runoff of fertilizers from lawns, as well as other nutrients, has often spurred algae growth, which, in turn, has upset the ecological balance of coastal areas. In extreme cases, public beaches have been closed because of high levels of coliform bacteria from storm water and sewage.
 
State Testing of Water
 Questions of how to regulate commercial development in shore areas have become a major subject of debate in many of the nation's coastal states, including Florida, the Carolinas, Georgia and California. Orrin Pilkey, a professor of geology at Duke University who has written extensively about shoreline preservation, said conservation experts in many of those states look to New Jersey as a textbook case of overbuilding.
Despite such problems, some critics of environmental groups in New Jersey say, with rare exceptions the water at public beaches in the state has been clean and safe and the state closely monitors the water during the summer months.
"I'm not sure what horrendous impact we are talking about," said Michael Gross, a lawyer who represents builders along the shore. "The D.E.P. has said the water was never cleaner. The statement that development has been uncontrolled, that is an exaggeration."
As a result of the extensive development of housing projects with fewer than 25 units, Governor Kean enacted an emergency order in October 1988 extending state review to most of those projects within 1,000 feet of the ocean. Gov. Jim Florio adopted a similar policy, but it was struck down by an appeals court last December.
 
Developers' Proposal
 Senator Paul J. Contillo of Hackensack, a Democrat who is chairman of the Senate Committee on Land Use and Regional Affairs, said builders were willing to support the bill that would extend state regulation of developments with fewer than 25 units. But, Senator Contillo said, the builders want any master plan for coastal development to be subject to an economic impact study and a vote of the Legislature. The committee is to vote on the bill on Monday.
In an interview today, Mr. Kean said he would urge the Legislature to adopt stricter regulation of development on the coast, in part to protect the state's tourism industry.
"You can kill the goose that lays the golden egg," Mr. Kean said. "You can make the Jersey Shore the type of place where people would not want to go."

GRAPHIC: Photo: New Jersey exempts from regulation developments with fewer than 25 units, so the shoreline is dotted with 24-unit complexes. In Sea Bright, Derickson W. Bennett said, "It's just difficult at the shore now to find a place where there isn't somebody else." (Harvey L. Bilker for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Housing Plan In New York Taps Banks From Abroad

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
Several large foreign banks, concerned that their lack of local lending in New York City could hurt their standing with banking regulators, are joining a lending program to finance construction of new low- and moderate-income housing.
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo is expected to announce the program today as part of an effort to attract more foreign capital and business to New York. 
 It comes as American banks are making stronger efforts to comply with the Community Reinvestment Act passed by Congress in 1977. The act does not specify how much banks should lend within their local community, but requires that they provide satisfactory service locally if they want approval for other projects, like acquisitions of other banks or expansion into new businesses.
"There is increasing interest among foreign banks in how they can participate in community-reinvestment kinds of lending," said Lyndon Comstock, president of Community Capital Bank, a new Brooklyn bank specializing in loans to areas of the city that many banks have shunned.
 
$10 Million Committed
 Cathy Wilde, director of the New York City Housing Partnership, which will channel the foreign banks' funds to developers of low- and moderate-income housing, said investment from foreign banks in local real estate is increasingly important because American banks have grown more cautious about real-estate lending since suffering large losses on loans. "Without investments by foreign banks in areas outside Wall Street and midtown Manhattan, we are going to come up short," she said.
As of late yesterday, banks had committed at least $10 million to the program. The goal is $100 million, officials said.
To encourage the cash-rich foreign banks, many of whom have little knowledge of city neighborhoods or small real-estate developers, the State of New York Mortgage Agency will insure 75 percent of the bank loans against loss.
The housing developments to be financed by the foreign banks will be selected by the Housing Partnership, a nonprofit organization that has completed about 6,000 owner-occupied housing units since it was founded in 1982. The group now has about 1,500 units under construction. "We are not a consumer or retail lender, so the Housing Partnership can help us by providing expertise for lending we could not do on our own," said Allyn W. Keiser, general manager of the Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce.
"This combines good citizenship with good credit quality," he added.
The Canadian bank is one of half a dozen expected to join the effort. Others considering the program include the American branches or affiliates of Barclay's Bank of London; Banco Popular of Puerto Rico; and four Japanese banks, Sumitomo Bank, Fuji Bank, Bank of Tokyo and the Industrial Bank of Japan.
Masahiro Nagayasu, vice president at Fuji Bank, said, "We do not have our own staff for lending to the local community, so we have to trust somebody to do the credit decision-making for us."
Bankers Trust Company, a New York bank, is also participating in the program as a lender and to coordinate the collection and disbursement of funds from other banks.
Kenneth H. Thomas, a banking consultant in Miami, noted that foreign banks in the New York area have received lower ratings under the Community Reinvestment Act than domestic banks "because the foreign banks have not done much local lending."
The program grew out of discussions between the partnership, the banks and the state's director of economic development, Vincent Tese. As a condition of their participation, the banks insisted that the state insure their loans and assist low-income applicants in obtaining mortgages.

HEADLINE: WORLDWIDE EFFORT TO AID BANGLADESH CALLED TOO LITTLE

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 7

 BODY:
The world has failed to mount an adequate relief effort to help survivors of last week's deadly cyclone in Bangladesh, international relief agency and United Nations officials said today.
At a meeting in Dhaka attended by representatives from the United Nations Disaster Relief Organization and the United States, Japan, Britain, France, Germany, the World Bank and nongovernmental aid agencies, the Bangladeshi Government appealed for $1.4 billion for relief and reconstruction, of which $670 million would be for immediate relief and $740 million for help in rebuilding the country. 
 Speakers at the meeting said tighter organization of relief efforts was needed. Officials there said that the United Nations Disaster Relief Organization was expected to lead coordination with the Bangladeshi Government and that Hamed Essafi, director of the United Nations agency, had spent the last five days in Bangladesh and was drawing up a plan of action.
 
Copters and Medicines Needed
 The United Nations Disaster Relief Organization said on Sunday that Bangladesh urgently needs helicopters, 10 million water purification tablets, tents, plastic sheeting, emergency medical kits, drugs, particularly anti-diarrheal medications, and milk powder.
Other urgently needed items, like rice, beans, shallow-draft boats, cooking oil and utensils, are available in Bangladesh, but the means to transport them to the affected areas are lacking, the report said.
Although the official death toll in Bangladesh stands at just over 125,000, relief officials estimate that as many as 200,000 people have died and up to 10 million others remain homeless. Of the 10 million, 4 million are classified as "in immediate risk," that is, in urgent need of food, medicine and clean water, said Philippe Boulle, the New York director of the United Nations Disaster Relief Organziation.
United Nations and relief agency officials argue that without a large and immediate infusion of aid as well as helicopters to transport it to remote areas, another 100,000 or more Bangladeshis could die.
 
Comparable to '70 Disaster
 "This crisis compares closely with the 1970 cyclone in Bangladesh that claimed half a million lives," said John Hammock, executive director of Oxfam America. "Recovery is going to cost hundreds of millions of dollars."
Saudi Arabia, the leading international donor, has given $100 million to the Bangladeshi Government for the relief effort. Other aid donors include the European Community, which has given $12 million; Britain, $7 million; India, $5 million; Pakistan, $4.3 million; Japan, $2.5 million, and Canada, $1.5 million.
But so far, the relief effort has been organized in a haphazard fashion. The United Nations has not had access to the funds and does not know how the Bangladeshi authorities will disburse the aid. United Nations officials emphasize that the relief effort requires extraordinary organization so that well-meaning donors do not send goods that may be available in the country.
The officials at the Dhaka meeting asserted that the problems in Bangladesh were far more serious than the refugee crisis in Iraq and appealed to governments in general to commit more funds to Bangladesh and to the United States in particular to divert some of the helicopters currently being used to help Iraqi Kurds.
 
Worse Than Kurdish Situation
 Between 20,000 and 30,000 Kurds have died, and an estimated two million Kurds are either refugees in Turkey and Iraq or displaced inside Iraq.
"The Kurdish crisis is just a blip on the screen compared to what we're facing in Bangladesh," said Tom Getman, director of government relations at World Vision, a private relief organization.
In Washington, the deputy State Department spokesman, Richard A. Boucher, announced today that the Administration was authorizing an additional $5 million in grants to nongovernmental organizations for the Bangladesh relief effort and would reprogram $2 million in funds already in Bangladesh for the effort. The Administration has already authorized $2.1 million in grants, medical supplies and equipment and water purification equipment.
The Administration has allocated more than $200 million to help the estimated two million Kurdish refugees and displaced persons who have fled their homes and has asked Congress to approve another $150 million in supplemental aid. The Administration estimates that the Kurdish relief effort will cost the United States and its allies between $500 million and $700 million in the first six months.
United Nations officials said today that the United States, as well as other governments they did not name, had thus far turned down their requests for helicopters, and that they lacked the funds to rent private helicopters.
 
No Decision on Helicopters
 Mr. Boucher said no decision had been made on sending American helicopters to Bangladesh. "The substantial transportation assets do exist in the country," he said. "There are boats that can be mobilized, and part of the $5 million that I announced will be available for logistic support to distribute the relief to the victims and disaster by truck and boat."
Bangladesh, which has been hit by 55 cyclones since 1900 and 8 of the world's 10 worst floods of the last decade, has enough food in warehouses inside the country to feed the survivors of last week's storm. But it is still raining in the areas where the homeless are located, and overland transporation is impossible.
What complicates the Bangladesh relief effort is that tragedy struck on the heels of other emergency relief crises: that of the Iraqi Kurds and a worsening famine in the Sudan. "If Bangladesh had happened at any other time, there would be a much more massive outpouring of support," said Lisa Mullins, program officer for foreign disaster assitance at Interaction, an umbrella group of more than 100 relief organizations. "But then again, there's no geopolitical interest in Bangladesh."
Even some private benefactors are reluctant to transfer to Bangladesh money intended for other causes. Sponsors of an international celebrity concert that will be staged Sunday on behalf of Kurdish refugees said there was no current intention to divert any of their receipts to Bangladesh.

HEADLINE: G.A.O. Job Study Expected To Fuel Trade-Pact Debate

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 7

 BODY:
A study by the General Accounting Office has found that employment in the Los Angeles furniture industry has dropped by as much as one-tenth in the last three years as companies have moved to Mexico in pursuit of lower wages and less stringent environmental laws.
The study, scheduled for release on Wednesday, is likely to provide further ammunition for members of Congress who have contended that a proposed free-trade agreement with Mexico would prompt many American companies to move their factories there, depriving the United States of jobs and despoiling the Mexican environment. Organized labor and some environmental groups have opposed granting the Administration the negotiating authority it seeks for the proposed pacts. 
 Administration officials have testified repeatedly that American companies with any interest in moving to Mexico have already done so. The Administration and some economists also maintain that economic development in Mexico offers the best hope for protecting the environment there.
The Administration is seeking so-called fast-track authority to negotiate trade agreements for the next two years, including one with Mexico, and submit them to a single yes or no vote in Congress with no amendments allowed. Resolutions have been introduced in both houses of Congress to cancel this authority, and if either house passes such a resolution by the end of this month, the fast-track authority would be canceled.
The G.A.O. study estimated that up to 28 wood furniture manufacturers moved from Los Angeles to Mexico in the last three years. A survey of some of these companies found that 83 percent of them identified high wages in Southern California as a reason for the move and 78 percent "cited stringent air pollution emission control standards for paint coatings and solvents" in Los Angeles.
The study also said that Mexico had not established air pollution standards for paint coatings and solvents in the region near its northern border.
Representative John D. Dingell, Democrat of Michigan, commissioned the study for the House Subcommittee on Commerce, Consumer Protection and Competitiveness.
In a statement prepared for delivery on Wednesday, Representative Cardiss Collins, Democrat of Illinois and head of the House panel, said the G.A.O. report was "the first documentation that manufacturers do, in fact, relocate to avoid environmental regulation."
President Bush is scheduled to meet Wednesday morning at the White House with several environmental leaders in a bid to win their support for the fast-track authority.
The plan was submitted to Congress last Wednesday.
Mr. Dingell sent letters today to the United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, and Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher seeking reactions to the study, said Victoria Clarke, a spokeswoman for Mrs. Hills.

HEADLINE: More Woe for Dinkins: Income-Tax Revenue Is Off

BYLINE: By JOSH BARBANEL

 BODY:
The Dinkins administration said yesterday that income-tax collections from April were running significantly below the city's already shrunken expectations in the crucial final weeks of the fiscal year.
A city lawyer disclosed the problem yesterday at the closing of a sale of $1.2 billion in short-term notes, saying that income-tax payments made around the April 15 tax deadline were $80 million below expectations. The trend raised new concerns about the city's ability to balance its budget before the fiscal year ends on June 30. 
 But Dinkins administration officials tried to discount the significance of the revenue problems. They said that much of the shortfall was likely to be offset by $30 million in increases in other tax revenues and $40 million in revenue from stepped-up city audits.
 
Holtzman's Concerns
 However, with the city already struggling to close a $465 million budget gap this year and a $3.4 billion gap for next year, City Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman said the lower tax collections were a real concern, indicating that the situation "is not even stabilizing."
City officials have repeatedly reduced their estimates of income-tax and sales-tax collections during the last year in response to the worsening local economy.
City officials also disclosed yesterday that they were counting on as much as $77 million in new aid from the state to help close this year's budget gap. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo has promised to help make sure the city ends the fiscal year with a balanced budget, but this is the first time details of the state's plan have become known.
City officials said state tax officials had agreed to provide $50 million this year by speeding up the final reconciliation of city income taxes collected by the state, a process that in the past was completed in November. The state has also agreed to restore $27 million in funds for the city that Albany had proposed cutting. The money is a payment that the state has made each year to cover the city's losses from the elimination of a state tax on the transfer of stock.

HEADLINE: Latin Immigrants in Capital Find Unrest a Sad Tie to Past

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 7

 BODY:
With the smell of tear gas lingering in the air, Central American immigrants said today that the unrest in their neighborhoods was rooted in what they saw as brutality and discrimination by the Washington police and was an unwelcome reminder of the strife they thought they had left in their native lands.
After two nights of disturbances that prompted the imposition of a 7 P.M. curfew today, the Mount Pleasant district and part of the Adams-Morgan area in the Northwest section of Washington are reminiscent of battle zones, with storefronts and vehicles left smoldering and police officers in riot gear patrolling in groups of half a dozen or more. 
 The damage shows that the demonstrators were discriminating about what they attacked: amid the looted drug stores and supermarkets, Salvadoran restaurants and Guatemalan artisans' shops were untouched.
"We left El Salvador to find peace," said Mario Pineda, a 22-year-old construction worker. "But what did we find here? No jobs and bad police."
Roberto Flores, a 21-year-old Salvadoran bricklayer who was loitering on an Adams-Morgan street corner today with Mr. Pineda, nodded his head in agreement.
"The problem is racial discrimination," he said. "Everyone looks down on us. Fifteen days ago when I was assaulted by some blacks, I asked the police for help and they told me to put my hands up like I was the criminal."
The street violence began Sunday night, shortly after the police wounded a Salvadoran man who they said was wielding a knife. The incident ignited long-held resentments in the densely populated streets about two miles north of the White House where most of Washington's Central Americans live.
For many of them the incident recalled the role of the police in their home countries and the sense of injustice they felt when they left. In street-corner interviews in their neighborhoods today, many residents expressed anger toward the police here, and complained of abuse and disrespect by American institutions.
Comparisons by Central Americans of the police in Washington to the police in their own countries reflected their frustrations more than the facts of the alleged brutality. Tens of thousands of people have disappeared in El Salvador and Guatemala at the hands of security forces in the last 15 years.
 
'It's the Same Repression'
 Jose Mendez, 23, a Salvadoran carpenter, said, "It's the same repression, though in El Salvador it's about politics. Here it's about discrimination."
A 48-year-old Salvadoran house painter who would only identify himself as Jose, said: "The problem is the police shot a Salvadoran man who was handcuffed. They could have arrested him and taken him to jail -- that is supposed to be the American way to do things."
Instead, he suggested, the authorities here are not much different from the Salvadoran security forces.
Mayor Sharon Pratt Dixon announced the new curfew this afternoon. The 7 o'clock starting time was five hours earlier than on Monday night. The curfew ends at 5 A.M.
Tonight, in sharp contrast to the tear gas, rock throwing and fires of the previous two nights, it was relatively quiet.
The police started enforcing the curfew at 7 P.M., and by 8 o'clock there was only a trickle of pedestrians on the street. Those who could not identify themselves or persuade the police that they were on their way home from work were usually arrested.
By late tonight the police had arrested 23 adults and 10 youths on charges of violating the curfew, disorderly conduct or disturbing the peace. The police also said there had been two stabbings and a shooting in the general area of the disturbances, but were unable to connect them to the street disorders of the last two nights.
"We feel that the community is in support of what the city government is trying to do," said Lieut. Reginald Smith, the chief spokesman for the police department.
 
Mayor at Command Center
 At about 10:15 P.M. Mayor Dixon came out of the command center that the police have set up on the outskirts of the Mount Pleasant area and said, "So far we have nothing to report, which I'm very happy about."
At least 1,000 of the city's 4,800 police officers have been assigned to the troubled district.
More than 40 people were arrested Monday night for curfew violations. They were taken to a night court, and most decided to pay a $300 fine rather than go through a trial.
None of dozens of people interviewed today would admit that they had participated in the disturbances, and many refused to speak at all. But several descriptions of the violence indicate that most of the participants were Salvadorans, Guatemalans, Nicaraguans, Panamanians and Colombians.
Young blacks and teen-age gang members took advantage of the mayhem, especially on the second night, to steal money and food.
"It's just like Guatemala except what happens back home during the day happens here at night," said Armando Marroquin, a 29-year-old restaurant waiter who arrived in Washington from the Guatemalan city of Esquintla seven months ago. Referring to the Salvadoran man shot by the police, he spoke like a man seeking revenge for a death squad slaying: "The people took reprisals for the Latino brother."
On a couple of looted stores, red graffitti scrawled on the wooden siding covering the broken windows called for "justicia," the Spanish word for justice. Also scrawled on the panels were the acronyms of three revolutionary groups fighting the Government in El Salvador.
"The same oppression that there is in my country, there is here, too," said Juan Perez, 38, an unemployed Salvadoran. "The police are the same as in El Salvador. For the simple pleasure of it, they harass people. The rioting is the response to years of oppression."
The disturbances also appeared to unleash tensions between Hispanic and black residents, with each group blaming the other for the violence.
 
Blacks Accused of Stealing
 Andrea Blanco, 25, a waitress at the El Tazumal Salvadoran Restaurant, said Hispanic youths threw rocks through store windows but it was the blacks who stole. "They've taken advantage of the situation and we take the blame," she said of the blacks.
Jacqueline Grooms, a 43-year-old black housewife, said that because of the misbehavior of Hispanic residents she and her neighbors were choked by tear gas fumes even though they stayed in their houses. "They came over here with malice in their hearts," she said. "They trash the neighborhoods."
But another black woman, Janet Poteat, 33, a supermarket worker, compared the unrest to past disturbances involving blacks. "The Spanish people are going to have to be heard the way we were in 1968," she said. "They are in the streets with no hope."

HEADLINE: Human Threat Ruled Out in Drug for Cows

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 7

 BODY:
A new Congressional report concludes that genetically engineered bovine growth hormone, which is being used to increase milk production in cows, poses no safety hazards to humans or to the animals in which it is injected.
The report, prepared by the Congressional Office of Technology Assessment, agrees with the Food and Drug Administration that the hormone does not pose the fundamental danger that some scientists, consumer groups and state regulators have contended it does. 
 But the Congressional agency also said widespread commercial use of the hormone was likely to put greater economic stress on many small dairy farmers, because it was likely to push milk prices downward.
The report, to be issued on Friday, is likely to strengthen the position of companies now pressing the Federal Government for commercial marketing approval. It gives members of Congress an independent technical basis for refusing to override attempts by the Food and Drug Administration to approve such growth hormones for widespread commercial use. Until now, the drug agency has allowed their use in dairy herds only on an experimental basis.
 
Safety in Humans
 In its report, the Congressional office agrees with the drug agency and says the hormone is very unlikely to turn up in milk consumed by humans, and that even if that happens, it would have no effect on humans.
The agency reiterated the opinion of most scientists in the field, saying that bovine growth hormone's effects were specific to cows and that the drug "does not elicit any of its normal biological actions in humans, even if injected." The report notes that bovine growth hormone has a unique three-dimensional shape that can only attach to cells in dairy cows.
Genetically engineered versions of the natural hormone, although having slightly different molecular structures, would be equally unlikely to affect humans.
The use of the hormone, technically known as bovine somatotropin, has been a source of heated debate among groups worried about its safety as well as its economic effects on farmers. Supporters of the drug contend that it can increase a cow's milk production by 10 to 25 percent. But some consumer groups have argued that important safety issues have not been addressed, and many smaller farmers have been alarmed about the hormone's effect on their livelihoods.
Four companies have developed genetically engineered versions of the drug and have applied for Federal approval to begin marketing it. They are the Monsanto Company, the Upjohn Company, the American Cyanamid Corporation and Eli Lilly & Company.
Industry representatives said the report provided further vindication of their views. Richard D. Godown, president of the Industrial Biotechnology Association, a trade association in Washington, said the Congressional agency "is verifying what the industry has been saying all along: that bovine growth hormone is a safe product and one which will benefit society."
 
Consumer Group's Concerns
 But the Consumers Union, the publisher of Consumer Reports magazine, said the report was only based on a review of published literature and had failed to delve into issues raised by unpublished documents within the Food and Drug Administration. Dr. Michael K. Hansen, a biologist at the Consumer Policy Institute, the research division of Consumers Union, said, "Our concerns are not from what has been published, but by what's not been published -- what the F.D.A. has and is not releasing."
Mr. Hansen said the drug agency raised concerns to Monsanto in l988 about evidence that cows treated with the hormone were affected by inflammation of the udder and reproductive problems. If valid, he said, the result could be that cows would need more treatment by antibiotics, which might then make their way into humans.
But the Congressional report dismissed those concerns. It confirmed that cows showed a decreased pregnancy rate and a slightly altered fertility cycle, but said the changes were associated with high milk yields and not the effects of growth hormone.
The report noted the concerns about a growing incidence of inflammation of the udder and other ailments, but said that "no such effects have been observed" and "nor have subtler health effects been in evidence."
Milk and meat both appear to be essentially unaffected by the hormone, the report continued. Milk showed slight variations in fat content in the first few weeks of hormone treatment, the report said, but the changes were temporary and smaller than those that occurred in a cow's natural lactation cycle. It said the meat from treated cows had a lower fat content but was otherwise identical.
But the agency did warn that use of growth hormones could speed the trend toward larger, technology-driven farms and a smaller total number of cows in use. "Such changes inherently put increased pressure on traditional dairy farms," the report concluded. "The trend will no doubt accelerate in the 1990's as the result of the combination of BST and other cost-reducing technologies."

HEADLINE: EATING WELL;
Are Cattlemen Now Guarding The Henhouse?

BYLINE: By MARIAN BURROS

 BODY:
ON April 24, after three years of study, research, consultations and discussions with consumers, the Agriculture Department sent its Eating Right Pyramid to the printer. This new chart was to have replaced the food wheel used since the 1950's to provide information about a healthy diet.
The next day Agriculture Secretary Edward R. Madigan announced that he was indefinitely delaying the chart's publication. Through a spokeswoman, Kelly Shipp, Mr. Madigan said many groups had complained that it was confusing and that it had not been tested on children. 
 But other Federal officials and health professionals, outraged by the Secretary's decision, said the pyramid was withdrawn because meat and dairy producers objected to what they felt was the pyramid's negative depiction of their products.
"It's very clear this is the effect of pressure from the cattlemen," said one Agriculture Department official who spoke only on the condition of anonymity. The official was referring to a meeting the Secretary held with board members of the National Cattlemen's Association, a producers' group, on April 15. "Up until the cattlemen came to their meeting with the Secretary, the Eating Right Pyramid was being released," the official said.
 Mr. Madigan has denied succumbing to pressure from commodity groups. But the reversal on the pyramid highlights the dual role of the Agriculture Department, the Federal agency in charge of educating the public about nutrition as well as the agency representing the food industry. Critics say that if the department surrenders to producer interests on matters of nutrition education and withdraws a well-researched teaching tool like the pyramid, why should the public believe anything it says about nutrition?
Even agency officials fear a loss of credibility.
"No one is going to believe us," the Agriculture Department official said, adding that cancellation of the pyramid "is tainting everything the department is doing."
"You don't need nutrition education from U.S.D.A. if it's going to be controlled by special-interest groups," the official said.
Gerald Combs, who retired last Friday from the department as deputy administrator for human nutrition, said: "For almost eight years, until this release came out, I had had no surprises and no pressures. Issues were dealt with on the basis of scientific fact and objectivity. I was terribly upset by this announcement. I don't know of any valid reason for the decision made so abruptly and handled so badly. One can only jump to all sorts of conclusions. My concern is that people will think the department has no integrity or objectivity."
Health professionals outside the agency were less surprised.
"There's a long history, going way back, of U.S.D.A. changing dietary policy because of the food industry," said Dr. Marion Nestle, chairwoman of the nutrition department at New York University. "I saw this all the time during the preparation of the Surgeon General's report on nutrition and health." Dr. Nestle was the editor of that report.
At the center of the controversy is the four-level pyramid, which has grains and cereals as its base. The next three levels, in ascending order, are fruits and vegetables, meat and dairy products and at the tip, fats, oils and sweets (with the advice "use sparingly").
The pyramid recommends 6 to 11 servings a day of grains and cereals, 2 to 4 of fruit, 3 to 5 of vegetables and 2 or 3 each of meat and dairy products. The number of servings called for by the chart are the same as on the old food wheel; the only difference is the way the information is presented.
"The Eating Right Pyramid emphasizes foods from the five food groups shown in the three lower sections of the pyramid," says the text that was to have been published with it. "Each of these food groups provides some, but not all, of the nutrients you need. Foods in one group can't replace those in another. No one food group is more important than another; for good health, you need them all."
At the April 15 meeting with Mr. Madigan, the cattlemen said the pyramid, which they had seen without the text, gave the impression that some foods were good and some, specifically meat, were bad.
On April 19 the American Meat Institute weighed in with its complaints. In a letter to the Secretary, the trade association said it had "neither seen the pyramid nor been consulted about it," but that to clear up confusion the Agriculture Department should "reject adoption of the 'Eating Right Pyramid.' "
The National Milk Producers Federation joined the chorus with complaints that dairy products were stigmatized by being next to the fats and oils on the pyramid.
The pyramid had not been kept secret. It was presented at a Public Voice for Food and Health Policy conference in Washington in March. It was talked about at the American Dietetics Association conference last year.
"It kind of makes you wonder where the cattlemen were for the last year," said the Agriculture Department official.
Despite the outcry, there is no unanimity about the pyramid in the meat and dairy businesses. The National Livestock and Meat Board and the National Dairy Council, trade associations that have more contact with consumers than the producer groups, have been aware of the pyramid for quite a while and have not protested. In fact, the National Dairy Council uses a similar illustration in its publication "Healthy Dividends."
Mr. Madigan said the pyramid was being withdrawn because it had not been tested on children, but on Friday Steve Abrams, the department's deputy assistant secretary for food and consumer services, added a new wrinkle.
In a telephone interview, he said the Secretary also wanted the pyramid tested to see if low-income families could understand it. He said Mr. Madigan wanted other symbols tested, too, though he could not provide a date for the new testing.
The pyramid was created as an illustration for a food guide intended to provide practical information to the public on how to use United States Dietary Guidelines, the Federal Government's advice for healthful eating. The food guide and the dietary guidelines are both geared to people with a high school education.
"The pyramid was never specifically targeted to children," said Dr. Rachel Ballard-Barbash, director of the nutrition policy staff in the Office of Disease Prevention and Health Promotion at the Department of Health and Human Services. The office worked closely with the Agriculture Department on the pyramid.
"Dietary guidelines were never intended to be read by children," Dr. Ballard-Barbash said. "Nutrition guidance is a particularly complex area. In my view it is naive to think it should be understood by children." Mr. Combs, the newly retired Agriculture Department official, concurred.
Research on the pyramid, which included work with two "focus" groups, made up of ordinary consumers, as well as interviews in a shopping mall, showed that people understood the purpose of the pyramid.
"No one came away with the feeling of good foods, bad foods," Dr. Ballard-Barbash said.
The pyramid and its text were reviewed by outside professionals who work with nutrition information and by the Agriculture Department's interdepartmental committee that includes a liaison from Health and Human Services.
 Dr. Ballard-Barbash said her agency was concerned about the turn of events at the Agriculture Department, as are many people who worked for three years on the pyramid.
Before Mr. Combs retired he proposed a compromise in a letter to Charles Hess, an Assistant Secretary of Agriculture. "I suggested the blocks of the pyramid be modified to be directly in proportion to the median serving size," he explained.
Letters urging Mr. Madigan to reconsider have been sent by the American Cancer Society, the Society for Nutrition Education, the American Dietetic Association, the United Fresh Fruit and Vegetable Association and the Center for Science in the Public Interest.
The Center for Science, a nutrition advocacy group, urged the Secretary "to demonstrate that your department has not put agricultural industry needs ahead of the public's health by resuming plans to publish the pyramid now."
Mr. Abrams, the deputy assistant secretary for food and consumer services, said he thought Congress "will believe Ed Madigan on these matters."
"He spent 18 years in Congress and is credible on health and nutrition issues," Mr. Abrams said.
But Representative Ted Weiss, a Manhattan Democrat who heads the Human Resources and Intergovernmental Relations Subcommittee of the Committee on Government Operations, has asked for all of the Agriculture Department's records on the Eating Right Pyramid.
"We are not surprised by allegations that U.S.D.A. succumbed to industry pressure to abandon the Eating Right Pyramid," Mr. Weiss said. "This provides the committee with the opportunity to review the capacity of U.S.D.A. to deal objectively with the conflicting duties of protecting the public's health while also promoting the economic well-being of the meat and poultry industry."

HEADLINE: Food Notes

BYLINE: By Florence Fabricant

 BODY:

Award for Greenmarket
The New York City Greenmarket program has been honored for its contribution to city life, winning the Rudy Bruner Award for Excellence in the Urban Environment. 
 The annual award, named for a business executive and friend of Frank Lloyd Wright who died in 1967, has been given annually since 1987 by the Rudy Bruner Foundation to the project that best combines the successful interaction of social, economic and esthetic elements to demonstrate the reaffirmation of urban areas.
The Greenmarket program, sponsored by the City Council for the Environment, has established markets in the five boroughs where farmers sell food they produce.
The Bruner award is more than mere honor. It includes a prize of $25,000. Program officials said they would use some of the money to match a state grant for making improvements at the markets, including building portable market shelters. The winnings will also be used to help complete a study on local farm survival.
 
Gravlax, Homemade
A new product, Mar-Seche, is a blend of salt, sugar, dill and spices for making gravlax at home. The process, consisting of rubbing a boneless piece of raw fish with the dry marinade, covering it, weighing it down and refrigerating it from eight hours to two days, could not be simpler.
Salmon is the fish typically used for making gravlax. For best results, it is important to run your hand over the fillet and remove any tiny bones with a tweezer. After the fish has been cured, slice it thin and hold each slice up to the light to check it again.
Before making the gravlax, take the precaution of freezing the raw salmon for 72 hours at 0 degrees Fahrenheit to destroy any parasites that may be lurking.
Fresh sea bass and fluke can also be used to make gravlax, and the marinade can also cure scallops and tuna. Do not use it for freshwater fish, which should never be consumed raw.
Mar-Seche, a formula devised by Richard G. Sanders, owner of Grace Tea Company, is available by mail from the company, 50 West 17th Street, New York, N.Y. 10011. Two 6 3/4-ounce jars, enough for about 12 pounds of boneless fish, are $10.95 including postage.
 
Downtown Pies
Bubby's, at 120 Hudson Street (North Moore) in Manhattan, is a cozy cafe with a menu of hefty sandwiches and simple, homestyle food available to eat in or take out. When it comes to dessert, Bubby's can stand in for a bakery. The homemade pies in cookielike crusts are especially good.
Cherry, caramel apple, banana cream, cranberry and cranberry-pear are some of the flavors usually on hand. The pies are sold by the slice for $3. A whole 10-inch pie is $18.50 to $20.50, depending on the flavor. Miniature pies, enough for two people, are $4.50.
Bubby's also has a chocolate cake, a single intense, yet light, layer dusted with powdered sugar, for $3 a slice.
 
Cookbook Contest
There is a special competition for community cookbooks, those books published as fund-raisers by nonprofit organizations. Created by the McIlhenny Company of Avery Island, La., the makers of Tabasco, the competition is open to books published in 1990 and 1991 that have not been previous winners.
The deadline for submitting books for consideration by a panel of judges is Oct. 1. Winners receive a donation of as much as $1,000 to the charity benefiting from the book.
Previously published community cookbooks that have sold more than 100,000 copies are also eligible to be named to the Walter S. McIlhenny Hall of Fame.
Entry forms and contest rules are available from Tabasco Community Cookbook Awards, c/o Hunter MacKenzie Cooper, 41 Madison Avenue, New York N.Y. 10010; (212) 679-6600.
In 1990, the first year of the competition, "From a Lighthouse Window," published by the Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum, won first prize.
Runners-up were "Gracious Goodness: A Taste of Memphis" published by the Memphis Symphony League and "Spice and Spirit: The Complete Kosher Jewish Cookbook" published by the Lubavitch Women's Club of Brooklyn.
Regional prizes were awarded to six other books. One, "The $2 Billion Cookbook" was published by volunteers in Anchorage, Alaska, who were working to clean up the Exxon Valdez oil spill in Prince William Sound.
 
KING OF THE WINE FRONTIER
THE label on the bottle of California wine says Parker, not as in Robert, the wine critic, but as in Fess, the actor who played Davy Crockett and Daniel Boone on television. The gold label has a tiny coonskin cap on it. Fess Parker has gone into wine making with his son Eli.
The first of the wines from their ranch in Santa Barbara County, a supple 1989 chardonnay for about $15 and a 1989 Johannisberg riesling in a lush Spatlese style for about $9, are now available in the East. Mr. Parker is also preparing to play Rhone Ranger, planting Rhone Valley-style grapes like viognier, marsanne, syrah and mourvedre.
The wines are sold at Park Avenue Liquor Shop, 292 Madison Avenue (40th Street); Sherry-Lehmann, 679 Madison Avenue (61st Street); Heights Chateau, 131 Atlantic Avenue (Henry Street), Brooklyn; Zachy's, 16 East Parkway, Scarsdale, N.Y.; Young's Liquor Store, 505 Plandome Road, Manhasset, L.I., and Murphy's Liquors, 106 Closter Plaza, Closter, N.J.

HEADLINE: The Pop Life

BYLINE: By Stephen Holden

 BODY:

Back in New York
Harry Belafonte is an optimist. Though America is mired in recession, the country's civil rights agenda has faltered and its cities are in turmoil, the 67-year-old singer and human rights advocate says he finds hope in the patterns of history.
"It's not the first time we've entered a dark age," he said in a telephone interview in Manhattan last week. "The antebellum period, which gave rise to the Ku Klux Klan and segregation, was also a dark age that ended the short-lived euphoria of blacks who believed they would be able to participate in this new union. We had to go through that period before the civil rights period came and took things to another level. I have to hope that history will continue to repeat itself." 
 This evening, Mr. Belafonte, who lives in Manhattan, is to give his first concert in the city in more than 30 years. It is to be at Avery Fisher Hall, to benefit the Ensemble Studio Theater. Although he has continued to perform all over the world and in the suburbs of New York, he said he decided years ago that it would be unwise to wear out his welcome in the city where he was born and became famous.
"Being born in New York and having got my start here, I had painted myself into a corner," he said. "One day I woke up and realized that there was nothing I hadn't done here. I decided I would only come back at those moments when I had something significant to do or say."
Mr. Belafonte is to perform what he called "the old, the new and the unimagined" in a program that will include music from Brazil, the Caribbean and Africa. Some songs are to be taken from his 1988 album, "Paradise in Gazankulu" (EMI-America), a record of African-oriented music that drew little attention when it was released. Mr. Belafonte said he paid close attention to the world-music movement, especially to African music. He hopes, he said, to work one day with the Senegalese singer Youssou N'Dour.
Musically, Mr. Belafonte is still best remembered for igniting the calypso craze in the mid-1950's with songs like "Jamaica Farewell" and "Banana Boat (Day-O)," and with the album "Calypso" (RCA), one of the first long-playing records to sell more than a million copies.
"I was absolutely amazed at the response to the music, especially that of white America," he said. "I can't think of another music from an outside source that has impacted on the American popular music world so strongly. The 50's were an apolitical time in America. Singing those songs was as political as one could get while still trying to sell something."
"All my life, I've spent a lot of time wondering how to break stereotypes," he said. "I've often thought that if those who participated in oppression could be made to understand that their humanity was equal to mine that they would be required to challenge their own prejudice. If you sing my song and enjoy it, you're going to want to know a little about who I am."
These days, music is only one of many facets of Mr. Belafonte's career. He recently signed a production agreement with New Line Cinema to develop seven movies and has bought the rights to August Wilson's play "Joe Turner's Come and Gone." Denzel Washington, Sidney Poitier, Morgan Freeman and Danny Glover have all agreed to appear in the film, for which Mr. Wilson will write the screenplay, Mr. Belafonte said.
 
Color Me Badd
 Hip-hop doo-wop is the catchy term that the pop group Color Me Badd has invented to describe its sound, which combines four-part pop-soul harmonies with electronic hip-hop beats and occasional short raps.
One variant of that sound has already propelled the group's first single, "I Wanna Sex You Up," to No. 12 on Billboard's pop-singles chart in just six weeks. The biggest hit from the sound track album of "New Jack City" (Giant/Reprise), "I Wanna Sex You Up" has a loping pop Latin beat that is similar to the Young Rascals' "Groovin' " and Laura Nyro's "Stoned Soul Picnic," and a piercing lead vocal by Bryan Abrams, whose voice resembles that of the late-1960's Stevie Wonder.
The four members of Color Me Badd, who come from Oklahoma City and who have been living in the New York area for nearly two years, are all 21 years old and have been working together for six years. Besides Mr. Abrams, the group includes two second tenors, Sam Watters and Mark Calderon, and Kevin Thornton, a baritone.
They said they first heard doo-wop a cappella singing in a jeans television commercial, which they taught themselves and performed in a school talent show. "Confucius said that the best prophet for the future is the past," Mr. Abrams said in a group interview last week when asked to explain why the group has delved so far in the past for its sound.
Mr. Watters added: "We don't try to make pop music, and we don't try to make R-and-B music. The name Color Me Badd means that we ignore all boundaries."
It was through sheer persistence that the quartet got itself a record contract. When big-name acts would play Oklahoma City, the group would follow them around and perform spontaneous auditions. One afternoon, Mr. Thornton spotted Jon Bon Jovi in a movie theater; he telephoned the other band members, who came to the theater, waited for Mr. Bon Jovi to leave, and insisted on singing the 1961 doo-wop hit "Daddy's Home." Mr. Bon Jovi promptly invited the group to be his band's opening act for an audience of 15,000 the next night.
It was Robert (Kool) Bell of the pop-funk group Kool and the Gang who helped the group find management and a record deal.
Color Me Badd recently completed its first album, which is to be released in early July.

LENGTH: 1837 words

HEADLINE: Educator's Legacy: Success, and Shaky Finances, in Several Districts

BYLINE: By WILLIAM CELIS 3d

 BODY:
Long before Walter L. Marks was blamed for the bankruptcy last month of the Richmond, Calif., school district, his reputation had been cast: An innovative administrator and educator whose concept of budgets was elastic at best.
In 20 years, Mr. Marks served five school districts, was ousted from two of them and left a third under mutual agreement with the board. As superintendent in four of the districts -- Richmond; Lake Travis, Tex.; Wake County, N.C., and Montclair, N.J. -- he introduced magnet school programs acclaimed for integrating racially polarized districts and improving curriculums and students' performances. 
 But he left the Wake County and Richmond districts in fiscal chaos -- a grand jury is investigating what happened to Richmond's finances -- and during his tenure in Montclair a state audit took the district to task for accounting lapses.
"He's one of the sharpest curriculum and instructional minds I've ever known," said James A. Adams, superintendent of the Fort Myers, Fla., schools, who as superintendent in Montclair in 1972 hired Mr. Marks as a curriculum director. "But sometimes his vision to get things done doesn't match reality."
Most education experts agree that magnet school programs and other improvements like those created by Mr. Marks would be expensive in any district. But he has been criticized for playing down the true costs and forging ahead with his innovations.
"When you talk about adding programs, you are talking about adding cost," said Thomas A. Shannon, executive director of the National Association of School Boards. "That can sometimes lead to disaster."
In Richmond and his previous positions Mr. Marks proceeded with his grand plans largely unchecked, according to many current and former school officials in those districts. He skillfully sold his plans to board members, who rarely quizzed him because they so wanted and needed the changes he promised -- and delivered.
He has charisma, too, these former associates said, so that when they challenged him, and he gave his stock answer -- "It's in the budget" -- they were inclined to believe him. Most board members said they did not know how to analyze a budget, or lacked the time.
When officials of a new school system came to court him, they were always so impressed by the educational achievements he had fostered that they tended to overlook questions about his handling of budgets.
Mr. Marks, who started his new job as superintendent of the Kansas City, Mo., schools on March 1, declined repeated requests for interviews about the Richmond bankruptcy and his experiences elsewhere. In several articles in The Kansas City Star after his arrival in Missouri, Mr. Marks said Richmond's financial difficulties reflected the souring California economy and grants that had failed to come through.
Members of the Kansas City board said they believed his assessment. But when California officials approved a court-ordered $19 million bailout of the Richmond system last week, they castigated Mr. Marks for his management there.
 
Making a Name in Cleveland
 After receiving a bachelor's degree in elementary education from Glenville State College in West Virginia in 1960, Mr. Marks worked in small Ohio schools. In his spare time, he earned master's and doctoral degrees in education from Kent State University and Ohio State University, respectively.
By 1971, he caught the notice of Robert Holloway, the superintendent of the Beachwood Public Schools in suburban Cleveland, who hired him as an assistant high school principal. There, Mr. Marks began a program that allowed gifted students to pursue an independent course of study and receive one-on-one instruction.
"It worked real well in the beginning because he picked the cream of the crop," said Walter McMahon, a retired Beachwood teacher. But the program did not survive Mr. Marks's departure very long, he added, largely because it required too many teachers.
Even before the program's demise, however, Mr. Marks encountered criticism. Some teachers said that he introduced a radical idea too quickly and that he hired acquaintances or friends as consultants.
Less than a year he began work, he was threatened with a school board inquiry into the hirings and was dismissed, Mr. Holloway said.
"I couldn't find it in my heart to be too vindictive under the circumstances," Mr. Holloway said. "I brought in Walter Marks to do a job, and he did it."
Mr. Holloway gave Mr. Marks a good recommendation when school officials from the Montclair Public Schools in New Jersey called.
 
Suspicions in Montclair
 After two years as curriculum director at Montclair, Mr. Marks succeeded Mr. Adams as superintendent in 1974 and catapulted to national prominence with his magnet school program. It was intended to desegregate the schools without mandatory busing, using upgraded, specialized curriculums to lure white students into predominantly black schools, and vice versa.
The plan worked, but within months questions arose over how the improvements were being financed. Eventually, the Montclair League of Women Voters asked to see district financial records and requested a state audit.
"We had strong suspicions that our school budget was being overspent," said Patricia Koechlin, chairwoman of the league's education committee in 1978 when the group sought the audit. For example, she said, the district would ask for 20 lawn mowers in one budget year and then ask for the same number the next year.
The audit uncovered accounting lapses, and the state recommended tighter controls on finance. These were instituted, and the Montclair programs continued running successfully.
In 1981, after he had been at Montclair for 10 years, Mr. Marks went to Wake County, which had recruited him to overcome problems similar to those he had helped solve in Montclair.
Wake County officials traveled to Montclair to assess Mr. Marks's work with the magnet system. They brushed aside questions about the audit, said Charlotte Martin, a Wake County board member who traveled to New Jersey.
In his three years as superintendent in Wake County, Mr. Marks worked his magic once more with magnet schools to desegregate the schools. But again there were skeptics.
"I was very leery from the beginning," said Ann Koonce, a board member during Mr. Marks's tenure. "I didn't think people would come into the inner city. And I didn't think it was possible for him to do everything he wanted to do for how much he said it would cost."
Mrs. Koonce admits being wrong about her first worry; the program was a success in integrating schools in and around Raleigh. But her fears about money were correct. The local newspaper, The News & Observer, began reporting irregularities in the school budget, and as a result the board requested an audit by the state education department.
After months of scrutiny, the state, in 1984, ordered the district to repay $489,000 in Federal grants designated for poor children, saying the money had instead been funneled into Mr. Marks's magnet program, which included students ineligible for Federal aid.
In addition to repaying the money, the district had to raise taxes to keep the magnet program operating.
At the same time, Mr. Marks's personal style -- his Lincoln Continental, his large house and the redecorating of his office with expensive leather furniture -- rankled board officials, who were also perturbed by his demand, which was not met, that his wife, Diane, a teacher he married in Montclair, be hired as an assistant principal.
But it was the misuse of Federal money that ultimately unseated Mr. Marks, as a second audit found an additional $60,000 in misused Federal money. He and the board agreed he should leave.
Mr. Marks taught briefly at Texas A&M University, and then in 1985 returned to school management, as superintendent of the Lake Travis Independent School District outside Austin.
The small district of 1,800 students needed an academic jump start and several new buildings. Dusting off his ideas, Mr. Marks started several programs, including Spanish for kindergarten students and an independent education foundation to award college scholarships to graduates.
Taxpayers groused about the changes, and about the expensive new administration building erected under Mr. Marks's guidance.
"He was changing so many things," said John Burns, a parent. "The biggest negative is he moves too quickly and the community does not have a chance to catch up."
Lake Travis officials said they were told about the fiscal problems in Wake County by school officials there, but Jack Reynolds, a board member at the time, said that over all Mr. Marks was given "a very pleasing recommendation."
Indeed, despite the grumbles, when Richmond officials came to recruit Mr. Marks, Lake Travis board members were so pleased with his work that they debated suing him for breach of contract if he left.
 
A National Reputation
 When he arrived in the sprawling Richmond district northeast of San Francisco in 1987, students' test scores were low and teachers were dispirited. The district, ethnically and economically diverse, was polarized.
Mr. Marks's school-choice program, a variation of his magnet programs, tried to pull white students into minority schools and vice versa. Extra teachers and administrators were hired (including Mr. Marks's wife, who became an elementary school principal), and all teachers and administrators received raises. In time, the program helped improve students' test scores.
"But almost immediately, it became apparent that he was going to implement expensive programs without any input from teachers and parents," said Ernie Ciarrocchi, executive director of the United Teachers of Richmond."People opposed him, but Walter is nothing if not a good salesman."
If the board sensed that the district was overspending, little was said initially. And understandably: Richmond basked in a national spotlight in 1989, when the Education Secretary, Lauro F. Cavazos, visited and pronounced the district a national model for school-choice programs.
But last year, it began unraveling, as expenses grew significantly, partly because extra people were required for the school-choice program.
When, as a condition for a $9 million loan from the state, a state-appointed trustee moved in to oversee the district's finances, he said the district's accounting was so shoddy that nobody knew how many people were actually employed. A head count was undertaken and showed that the district's personnel costs were over budget by $7 million.
Last December Mr. Marks was dismissed.
Now as the Richmond system struggles to regain its financial balance, many blame Mr. Marks. But others are more philosophical.
"I think his tragic flaw was that he wanted to believe in what he was doing," said Pat Howlett, who ran the district's public relations office under Mr. Marks. "He found ways to justify what he was doing. He reached."
