HEADLINE: Violent Impasse in Seoul

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, May 8

 BODY:
One of the more revealing moments in the flare-up of violence between student demonstrators and the South Korean Government over the last two weeks was the hasty retraction of comments by a senior member of the ruling party that the much-feared plainclothes riot police should be disbanded.
 The politician, Kim Chong Hoh, the Democratic Liberal Party's floor leader in the National Assembly, told reporters he had asked the Interior Minister to dissolve these forces, which were notorious for their rough tactics long before they beat a student to death with steel pipes two weeks ago. But the party spokesman later insisted no such request had been made or was planned. 
 Despite most Koreans' growing frustration with the cycle of demonstrations and clashes that poison the air with tear gas this time of year, the reversal was a sign of the immense resistance on both sides to new thinking that might avert the annual ritual of running street battles.
The Government's opponents have, in some ways, only grown fiercer in their determination, taking the most extreme measures in years. There has been a series of suicides to protest the earlier killing of the student.
Today a 24-year-old dissident set himself on fire, then leapt from a building at Sogang University in Seoul. It was the fourth such self-immolation.
The violence, which has spread across the country, also seems increasingly out of step with the more moderate image South Korea is trying to project internationally; Seoul is seeking membership in the United Nations and a greater voice in regional affairs.
The stances of both the Government of President Roh Tae Woo and its opponents seem hardened in another era, while the middle classes appear fed up with unyielding attitudes.
 
Sign of Weakness Feared
 Kim Kyung Won, a former Ambassador to Washington and head of the Social Sciences Institute in South Korea, said both sides are locked in place out of fear any conciliatory steps would be perceived as a sign of weakness, which the other side would exploit with even harsher attacks.
"This has become a structural problem," said Oh Sae Chull, an economics professor at Yonsei University.
That intransigence stands in stark contrast to the bold diplomatic steps President Roh has taken over the last year. South Korea has wooed the Soviet Union and China. It has also won some international support by holding a round of local elections, with plans for another set in June. But the old order of violent dissent and heavy-handed Government responses reigns on.
Part of the problem is the Government's falling credibility. Despite his recent overseas triumphs, Mr. Roh's domestic position has been eroded by recent student deaths, a major industrial pollution scandal and a corruption scandal involving several former Government officials, according to Park Choon Ho, a law professor at Korea University.
"The public will not give the Government credit for its diplomacy if it is not seen as taking the initiative for getting rid of corruption," Mr. Park said.
 
Cabinet Official Dismissed
 Eager to allay the distrust, Mr. Roh was quick to dismiss his Interior Minister after the beating death of the student on April 26. That came a few days after he dismissed his Environment Minister over the pollution scandal. Mr. Roh also issued an apology for the student's killing, and five riot policemen were later arrested.
For the students, the death was an opening to win back some of the public support they have lost in recent years. The public has grown weary of political strife and eager to enjoy this country's increasing wealth.
After the latest suicide, a prosecutor called for an investigation into what he said appeared to be an organized program among dissident leaders to compel young followers to kill themselves to advance the movement.
Indeed, each death has become another focal point for further demonstrations. The funeral of the student killed earlier is set for Thursday, and it is feared there will be violent confrontations around the nation.
The demonstrations have been fiercer and attracted more students than at any time since the presidential election in 1988. Tens of thousands of students have demonstrated at various times in the capital as well as more than a dozen provincial cities.
While many hope for some conciliatory measures to at least halt the suicides, there are few optimistic signs.
Mr. Roh speaks frequently of strengthening the country's three-year-old democracy. Yet the plainclothes riot troops, who are trained in the martial arts and carry truncheons or steel pipes, are a carryover from the years of military rule.
In addition, the Government has yet to ease or amend the National Security Law, a vague ordinance that permits the Government to detain just about anyone it suspects is a threat to order.
The students' short-term goal seems clear: to disrupt the elections slated for June, and thus rob the Government of a chance to improve its credibility. The Government, in turn, has yet to show that it has a broader plan for ending the cycle and building a unified nation in the South before it tackles building a unified peninsula.

HEADLINE: AFTER THE WAR;
Firefighting Pace Quickens in Kuwait Oilfields

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KUWAIT CITY

 BODY:
Slowly, the recovery of Kuwait's oil industry, its only basic industry, is taking shape.
Firefighters can now arrive at a small burning well in the morning, extinguish the fire and cap the flow of oil before dusk, and roll their equipment off toward another well, to be ready for the next day. 
 The continuous application of manpower, proven oilfield methods and tons of equipment airfreighted from Houston are gradually yielding results. More than 10 percent of the 600 dynamited wells have been brought under control, the first step for Kuwait in resuming its role as one of the world's largest exporters.
The Kuwait Oil Company can find the remains of its heavy equipment among the convoys of Iraqi vehicles destroyed by allied aircraft during the retreat, but despite the destruction of war, Kuwait still has infrastructure.
The country lacks tools and spare parts, and blames the Iraqis for stealing everything, right down to the bulbs in the traffic signals. But the amount of heavy civil engineering work now needed is fairly modest. The airport control tower must be rebuilt, but the runways are still there and in service. The ports need new cranes or repairs to existing ones, but they, too, are in operation.
 
Buildings Still Standing
 It will take many square miles of plate glass to restore Kuwait City to its pre-war appearance, but the buildings are still standing. Around the country, the roads need patching but few need rebuilding. Many were under construction at the time of the invasion, and they wait to be finished.
The land here, whether crossed by roads or not, is easily traversed by bulldozers, heavy trucks and the other equipment used in an oilfield. This is far more than can be said of many frontier areas where international oil companies are accustomed to doing business.
Kuwait also has capital. If this is not always evident in the oilfields, where purchasing agents sometimes scrimp, buying used equipment that breaks down, it is evident in the streets and highways here. The streets are crowded with fleets of white 1991 Chevrolet Caprice sedans, ordered by the Government for its own use, and car carriers full of shiny new police cars, with emergency lights on top and Kuwaiti markings painted on the sides, could be seen crossing the border from Saudi Arabia.
 
Bureaucracy Hampers Effort
 Wealth is also evident in the private sector; pickup trucks speed by with refrigerators and freezers, and the markets are stocked with everything from chandeliers to designer sunglasses.
The most important ingredient, the oil, is still there; even if some wells have to be re-drilled, the prospect for success is nearly 100 percent.
Outside the oil sector, other parts of the rebuilding effort are hampered by a choking post-war bureaucracy, the Kuwaitis' inability to do the work themselves, and desire not to let too many non-Kuwaitis in to do the work. Kuwaitis complain that they lack the computers, fax machines and other conveniences to run their country.
But the oil sector, in the hands of foreigners since its inception more than 50 years ago, does not suffer from the same problem. Skilled foreigners fly in daily from Dubai on a chartered flight, without visas.
Kuwait Oil Company is represented at each well, as is customary in the oil business around the world, by a "company man," but most of those company men are Americans. It is possible to spend days at the wells themselves watching Americans and Canadians fight the fires, aided by Indian mechanics, Sri Lankan truck drivers and Banagladeshi laborers, and never see a Kuwaiti.
The goal of the firefighters now working is 50 wells a month, which would mean that wells will still be burning next spring, more than a year after the Iraqis were driven out.
 
Production Being Restored
 But oil exports could resume long before the last fires are out; as the firefighters move from well to well and finally field to field, other oilfield service technicians can move in behind them, repairing the capped wells and putting them back into service. In any given location, firefighting may preclude production, because the pipes that formerly carried oil to the terminals and tankers in the gulf are instead carrying seawater inland, for firefighting.
But Kuwait's oil wealth is spread over hundreds of square miles, tied into 26 separate gathering systems, and then exported through several different terminals, depending on the location of the well. Resumption of their production above the level of gathering station need not be closely synchronized; Ahmadi, southwest of Kuwait City, where firefighting began, will undoubtedly be back in production before some of the wells to the north are even touched.
In addition to the wells, there are other problems; some storage tanks and port installations were hit by allied bombs, and must be repaired.
 
Meeting Domestic Needs
 But plans are to start production in May, by tying 20 surviving wells around Ahmadi into one mostly intact gathering station, to produce 50,000 barrels a day. That amount is small by Kuwait's prewar standards, about 3 percent of the country's OPEC quota of 1.5 million barrels a day, and small even by prewar consumption standards. But with the country's population reduced by about half, it might meet domestic demand, ending the paradox of having to import oil into the country with a tenth of the world's known reserves.
By late this year, the Kuwait Oil Company hopes to be producing 100,000 more barrels a day, with exports resuming on a small scale by year end. Full recovery, the company thinks, will take five years.
This could take longer, as everything in Kuwait seems to these days. But recovery might also be more than full; the country may finish with more capacity than it had when it began. Its prewar capacity was estimated at 2.1 to 2.2 million barrels a day, but it always had more wells than its ports could handle. In rebuilding, it may re-size.
This, however, may depend more on politics than engineering. Iraq has reportedly told customers that it is ready to export 600,000 barrels a day, pending a lifting of the United Nations embargo. It badly needs the revenue to rebuild. Kuwait and Saudi Arabia, which spent heavily on the war, need revenue too, and will not be inclined any time soon to sacrifice market share for Iraq.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Money Fund Yields Lower As Analyst Cites Confusion

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields of money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report fell for the week that ended yesterday.
Walter S. Frank, the chief economist at IBC/Donoghue's, said he saw much confusion in the market. "The Fed has lowered interest rates but as yet gotten no response except from the short end of the market, where it has control," he said. The Government's quarterly refunding this week will temporarily block the way of lower rates, as yields of government securities rise to attract investors.
 
Maturity Days Unchanged
 Tax-exempt money fund yields declined for the week, with the average number of days to maturity of securities held in portfolios unchanged at 45. Fund assets increased by $465 million, to a total of $88.1 billion. 
 For the period that ended yesterday, the average seven-day compounded yield fell by 12 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 4.32 percent, while the seven-day simple yield fell by 11 basis points, to 4.23 percent. The 30-day compounded average yield increased by a basis point, to 4.30 percent, and the 30-day simple yield rose by a similar amount, to 4.21 percent.
The taxable equivalent of the current tax-exempt compounded yield is 6 percent for investors in the 28 percent tax bracket and 6.26 percent in the 31 percent tax bracket.
Of the tax-exempt funds with assets of more than $100 million monitored by IBC/Donoghue's, the General California Municipal Money Market Fund, distributed by the Dreyfus Service Corporation in Garden City, L.I., had the best return for the second straight week, at 5.31 percent.
 
Taxable Assets Higher
 The assets of taxable funds rose by $1.5 billion, for a total of $458.4 billion, with those of institutional funds up by $2.5 billion, to a total of $116.6 billion. Donoghue's analysts think institutionals may be parking money in the money funds while the quarterly refunding is taking place. But the assets of consumer funds were down by $1 billion, to $341.8 billion. The smaller investors may be looking elsewhere for higher returns, the analysts said.
The average seven-day compounded taxable yield fell by 9 basis points in the week, to 5.81 percent, while the 30-day yield fell by 7 basis points, to 5.93 percent. The seven-day simple yield was 5.65 percent and the 30-day one was 5.76 percent, both down, by 9 basis points and 7 basis points, respectively.
The taxable fund with the best return was a Merrill Lynch & Company fund, the Merrill Lynch CBX Money Fund, with a yield of 7.14 percent, including capital gains.

HEADLINE: Licenses for 2 Trump Casinos Are Renewed

BYLINE: By WAYNE KING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, May 8

 BODY:
State regulators conditionally renewed gaming licenses for two of Donald J. Trump's Atlantic City casinos today amid concern about his tottering finances, propped up just last December at one of the casinos by a $3.5 million cash infusion disguised as a chip purchase by his father.
Licenses were renewed at the Trump Castle and the Trump Plaza by a unanimous 5-to-0 vote by the Casino Control Commission in Atlantic City. One requirement for obtaining and holding a casino gaming license is "clear and convincing proof" of financial stability on the part of both the casino and its owner. 
 The commission voted to renew the two licenses, but left open the question of Mr. Trump's financial stability until next month. In the meantime, Mr. Trump and the casinos must file weekly cash flow reports and progress reports on meeting payments to bond holders.
The commission took a similar action last month regarding Mr. Trump's other Atlantic City casino, the Taj Mahal, imposing the same conditions.
 
Cash-Flow Difficulties
 In both instances, the major concern was not about the casinos, although they have experienced cash-flow difficulties amid a weakened economy and the impact of the recent Persian Gulf war on travel, but on Mr. Trump's personal financial stability. He has had to sell off many assets, restructure more than a billion dollars in debt, and plans to declare the Taj Mahal bankrupt in June to protect himself from creditors during restructuring, Mr. Trump and his advisers have told the commission.
Valerie Armstrong, a commission member, voted to renew the casino licenses in all three cases, but said today that she remained concerned not only about overall stability, but also specifically about a chip transaction at the Trump Castle last December that amounted to a sub rosa loan. The casino paid a $30,000 settlement to the state's Division of Gaming Enforcement in the matter, but the commission has yet to approve or reject the settlment.
Mr. Trump's father, Fred, a New York real-estate investor, purchased $3.5 million in gambling chips from the casino, but never used them, leaving the $3.5 million in the casino's coffers. The money was then used to make a bond payment that the casino otherwise did not have enough cash to make.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Up in Quiet Trading; Gold Prices Also Higher

DATELINE: The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar rose yesterday in quiet trading as investors were heartened by the results of the Treasury's bond auction.
Gold prices were mostly higher, rising in all major markets except Zurich. Gold picked up 60 cents on the Commodity Exchange in New York, closing at $357.10 an ounce. The Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $357, up 70 cents.
There were few events to influence domestic currency trading, but the market was reassured by good demand for the $11.96 billion in 10-year notes the Treasury sold yesterday, said Kevin Logan, chief economist for the Swiss Bank Corporation in New York. 
 If United States bonds are attractive to foreign investors, the dollar gets a lift because overseas buyers must purchase dollars to pay for their new securities.
The Government sold the bonds as part of its three-day quarterly refunding auction.
Analysts said the dollar was also helped by news that President Bush suffers not from a heart ailment, but from a treatable thyroid condition.
In earlier European trading, the dollar rose on news that an American warplane came under antiaircraft fire while flying over northern Iraq Tuesday night. The report was subsequently played down by United States officials.
The dollar tends to rise in times of international strife because it is seen as a haven for investors.
Dealers said the United States currency was also helped by unsubstantiated rumors that the president of the German Bundesbank, Karl Otto Pohl, was about to resign. The rumors sent the mark falling.
The dollar rose to 1.7312 marks in New York from late Tuesday's 1.7175. In Europe, the dollar advanced to 1.7330 German marks, from 1.7210 late Tuesday.
The British pound fell against the dollar, dropping to $1.7200 in New York, from $1.7265 late Tuesday. In London, sterling fell to $1.7180 from $1.7205.
The dollar rose against the Japanese yen in New York, closing at 138.30 yen, up from 137.80 late Tuesday. In Tokyo overnight, the dollar fell 0.54 yen, to 137.88 yen, and in London, it was quoted at 138.30 yen.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday's prices, included: 1.4630 Swiss francs, up from 1.4530; 5.8585 French francs, up from 5.8155; 1,281.25 Italian lire, up from 1,270.50, and 1.15245 Canadian dollars, up from 1.15105.
Earlier in London, gold rose to a late bid price of $357.25, from $356 late Tuesday.
In Zurich, gold fell to a closing bid of $356.65, from $356.85 late Tuesday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose $1.19 to close at a bid of $357.55.
Silver closed at $4.047 an ounce on the Commodity Exchange, up 1.1 cents. Earlier in London, silver was unchanged at a late bid of $4.05.

HEADLINE: New Haven Feels Strain Of Increasing Fiscal Blows

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW HAVEN, May 8

 BODY:
For more than three decades, Arnie Brown waited for a redevelopment plan that would revive the last old section of this city's downtown district, an area known as the Ninth Square, just blocks from the town green and the towers of Yale University.
Four years ago, Mr. Brown tired of waiting. He sold his family's shoe store on Chapel Street in the Ninth Square. The storefront's new owners operate an adult book store and a peep-show parlor. 
 "We have had so many promises for the area, it is unbelievable," Mr. Brown said.
Today, most of the Ninth Square remains a motley collection of boarded-up storefronts and soaped windows. It is very likely to remain that way for the foreseeable future because of a decision by the Connecticut Housing Finance Authority not to approve $52 million in bonds needed for the latest plan to revitalize the area with a mix of stores and housing.
 
Austerity Measures Imposed
 The project's scrubbing, though, is just the latest fiscal problem to strike this long-suffering city. And the troubles, which are found in many Northeast cities these days, are weighing particularly heavy on Mayor John C. Daniels, a well-respected former state senator, who was elected this city's first black mayor 18 months ago.
Last month, Mr. Daniels laid off 120 employees, or 5 percent of the city's non-education work force, to avoid a $6.2 million deficit for the current fiscal year. His other austerity measures included delaying the opening of some parks until July 1 and leaving the main library open only 24 1/2 hours a week and its three branches, 15 hours.
More foreboding, perhaps, is the fiscal situation for next year.
The city, which already has the highest property tax rate in the state, has a gap of $40.9 million between projected revenue and departmental budget requests for the fiscal year beginning on July 1. The budget for the current fiscal year is about $255 million.
"There is a lot of hopelessness out there," Mr. Daniels said. New Haven's fiscal problems stem, in part, from a slowing growth in its tax base, which rose by only 0.2 percent for the year ending Oct. 15, 1990.
City officials attribute the stagnation to the regional recession, the continuing commercial and residential flight to the suburbs, a high office vacancy rate, the generous tax abatements awarded to some downtown developers by previous administrations and the tax-exempt status of many properties held by Yale, the city's largest landowner.
The Mayor also attributed the financial problems to a lack of county or regional government, which forces large and poor cities in Connecticut to pay for many of their own social services.
 
Outside Aid Dwindles
 Peter Halsey, the comptroller, said that Federal aid has been sharply curtailed, and state aid, under the 1991-92 budget proposed by Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr., would rise from about $100 million this year to $110 million next year. "The state is not going to be our salvation," he said. "We will be happy to keep what we have got."
What little optimism was left about the city's fiscal future was dashed with the cancellation of the Ninth Square project. Mr. Daniels said he feared it might also dissuade other potential downtown developers like the Taubman Company, which has expressed an interest in building a new shopping mall in the city. "This project may have been the litmus test," he said.
"It is a dead end," said Arthur Horowitz, whose family has owned a yarn shop in the Ninth Square area for more than 50 years. "At this point, I can't see anything happening until the economy starts up again, and that could be another 10 years."
 
Political Payback to Some
 The decision not to approve the bonds was made, housing administration officials said, because of the state's fiscal problems and the level of risk in the project.
Many New Haven officials believe, though, that the demise of the project, which was backed by the previous governor, William A. O'Neill, a Democrat, is a political payback aimed at Mr. Daniels, a Democrat, who actively supported former Representative Bruce A. Morrison of Hamden, a Democrat, for governor over Mr. Weicker, who created the Connecticut Party before leaving the Republican Party.
"I want to believe that it's not politics," said Mr. Daniels, who is seeking re-election this fall but has said he intends to run for governor in 1994, "and I have to take the Governor's word on it that he wants to help cities, that he wants to provide jobs for the cities, that he wants to provide housing for the cities, that he wants to give the cities an economic boost.
"Well, this was the project to do that, and it didn't happen," he said. "And I have yet to this day received a solid reason as to why the state is not going to do this project."
The project had the financial support of Yale, which had pledged $10 million. "We still believe it is a good project, and would like to see it revived and succeed," Shelia W. Wellington, Yale Secretary, said. "It is important for New Haven socially and economically."
As New Haven officials search for a way to revive the Ninth Square project and solve their fiscal problems, they are being pressed to increase social services, particularly in the city's poorer neighborhoods. For example, New Haven, which has a population of about 130,000 and is the third largest city in Connecticut, after Bridgeport and Hartford, has the highest infant mortality rate in the nation.
The city, which was chosen as the site of the nation's first urban-renewal project and later became known as the original model city, has also experienced a rising level of violent crime, much of it prompted by the increased use of illegal drugs and the growing prevalence of gangs.
Nine murders have been committed in New Haven this year. The most publicized, by far, was the slaying of a Yale sophomore, Christian H. Prince, on Feb. 17 a block from the home of the Yale president, Benno C. Schmidt Jr. The slaying has not been solved.
"It did considerable harm to the city in terms of the efforts we are trying to make to try and uplift the image of the city," Mr. Daniels said of the killing of Mr. Prince.
He added, though, that town-gown relations with Yale, had never been more harmonious. Yale is the city's largest employer. New Haven has an unemployment rate of 6.2 percent compared with 5.9 percent statewide.
Mr. Daniels also dismissed widespread criticism that Yale's contributions to the city were not enough. He noted that last October the university had agreed to place its golf course on the city tax roll and to make contributions for Fire Department services.
"What do I say to Yale?" Mr. Daniels said, "I say, 'Thank you.' "

HEADLINE: Washington Talk;
In Clashes, a Hispanic Agenda Enters

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 8

 BODY:
The riots of the 1960's in Watts and Washington helped to push the questions of civil rights, political representation and economic opportunities for blacks to the top of the national political agenda, and this week's disturbances in the capital could focus national attention on the wide array of problems facing Hispanic Americans.
Certainly the spasms of violence on Sunday and Monday night were dramatic enough, with hundreds of youths throwing rocks, bottles and other missiles at police officers, setting fire to cars and trucks and looting more than a dozen stores. 
 And certainly the television cameras caught the fury of the crowd. It was a civil version of the war in the Persian Gulf, with battering rams instead of Scuds. A city watched live as youths bashed in the doors of a fried-chicken restaurant while customers inside huddled in terror and the police, having been withdrawn for the moment, were nowhere to be seen.
An exigent curfew imposed by Mayor Sharon Pratt Dixon calmed the streets on Tuesday night, and she has promised to do a number of things to attack the underlying problems, like recruiting many more Spanish-speaking police officers.
Leading Hispanic officials joined in the effort to steady nerves. Representative Solomon P. Ortiz, a Texas Democrat who is a former sheriff, broadcast messages on Spanish-language radio.
But many Hispanic leaders doubt that there will be a serious national effort to attack the problems affecting the more than 22 million people of Hispanic descent living in the United States. (That figure, which comes from the 1990 census, is almost certainly too low because of systematic undercounting, the Cenusus Bureau concedes; it works out to 9 percent of the national total, whereas Hispanic people probably account for about 10 percent.)
"You can already hear people saying that this is an isolated instance, that things are different in other cities, that we should leave things to local officials and everything will be fine," said Margarita Roque, executive director of the Hispanic caucus on Capitol Hill. "But in cities across the country, our people feel like they do in Washington -- no access, no local elected officials, no recourse."
There are no Hispanic senators or governors at the moment, though there have been some in the past. There are 10 Hispanic members of the House (including 4 from Texas and 3 from California), which is only 2 percent of the total, and Hispanic people account for less than 1 percent of all elected officials in the country, according to the census.
Hispanic people face intractable problems that are significantly different from those of other minorities. If blacks tend to be disenfranchised by their failure in many cases to register to vote, Hispanic Americans often do not even get that far. Rob Paral of the National Association of Latino Elected Officials says that 37 percent of all Hispanic people living in the United States are aliens.
Large numbers of those are in the country illegally, which makes their integration into American life difficult if not all but impossible.
Another difficulty is the reluctance of many Hispanic people to learn English -- a pattern mentioned by many blacks and whites in the Mount Pleasant and Adams-Morgan neighborhoods here as an explanation of ethnic tensions.
But there is more to it than that. For those who remember 1968, this week in Washington has brought eerie and disheartening echoes of that year, when white politicians, merchants and journalists admitted that they had been totally surprised by the explosions in black communities. This time both whites and blacks here, including Mayor Dixon, who is black, have made such confessions.
The problems will not go away now any more than they did then, and they will confront more and more communities as the Hispanic population is diffused through the nation. Ten years ago, for instance, there were few Hispanic residents in Rhode Island, which is now 5 percent Hispanic, or Nevada, which is now 10 percent.
For that matter, few Washingtonians, though vaguely aware of the Salvadoran and Guatemalan refugees who have been settling among them, would have guessed that the District of Columbia is now at least 7 percent Hispanic, with large Hispanic communities in the Virginia and Maryland suburbs, too.

HEADLINE: Productivity Error Fixed

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 8

 BODY:
Correcting an embarrassing mix-up, the Labor Department issued a new report today on the productivity of American workers to officially fix inaccurate figures issued earlier this week.
Today's report confirmed that American workers' productivity rose 1 percent from January through March. 
 On Monday, the Labor Department first reported that productivity fell nine-tenths of a percent during the first quarter of 1991. Eight hours later, the agency caught the mistake, and said productivity actually increased 1 percent. It said there had been a mistake in transmitting data between the Commerce Department and the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The report issued today officially revised the figures.
Productivity, defined as output per hours worked, is considered a key to increasing the nation's standard of living without lifting inflation.
Deborah Klein, a spokeswoman for the Labor Department division that releases the figures, said she could not recall such a mix-up in economic statistics in the 25 years that she had worked with the figures.

GRAPHIC: Graph: 'U.S. Productivity' shows output per hour of all people in nonfarm businesses from '87 to '91 (Source: Bureau of Labor Statistics)

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Income Slides At Woolworth

 BODY:
Citing lower than expected revenues in all but its German operations, the Woolworth Corporation said yesterday that first-quarter net income dropped 65.8 percent, to $13 million, or 10 cents a share, from $38 million, or 29 cents a share, in the comparable quarter last year.
The New York-based retailer said revenues rose 2.4 percent, to $2.12 billion in the period that ended April 27, from $2.07 billion the year before. Domestic revenues rose 2.5 percent, and foreign revenues increased 3.9 percent. Specialty store revenues increased 6.3 percent while general merchandise revenues remained essentially unchanged. 
 "The recession continued to hurt our operations in North America, especially in Canada, where same-store sales of our Woolworth and Kinney subsidiaries were down 15 percent," said Harold E. Sells, Woolworth's chairman and chief executive officer.
Company-wide operating profit declined 46 percent, to $49 million, from $91 million in the 1990 quarter. Specialty store operating profit declined to $24 million from $53 million, mainly because of the weak performance of the company's non-athletic apparel and Kinney shoe stores.

HEADLINE: Excerpts From the Bush News Conference on Foreign and Domestic Issues

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from President Bush's news conference in Washington yesterday as supplied by Reuters:
 
OPENING STATEMENT
It is with a great sense of pride -- genuine pride in his accomplishments -- and long years of dedicated service to his country, that I announce that Bill Webster has informed me of his intention to retire as the Director of Central Intelligence. Bill will be leaving Federal service after 26 years on the Federal bench as Director of the F.B.I. and as Director of the C.I.A. And as a former D.C.I., I know the complex organizations and inter-relationships that comprise our intelligence community. 
 Bill has brought an integrity, an effectiveness, and an insight to the many intelligence-gathering operations of this nation. He has done a superb job. A strong nation requires a strong intelligence organization, and Bill Webster has directed our efforts according to the guidelines that I set down at the beginning of this Administration, that the C.I.A. would have the single mission of providing intelligence to the policy makers of this government. And he's performed admirably. And that is a very important point. Intelligence not trying to shape policy.
There are those who think C.I.A. should have a different role, but I believe Bill Webster has demonstrated the value of an intelligence organization that is professionally directed and purposely committed. It is invaluable in defending the security of America.
I noticed what one of our coalition partners said -- the dependence on United States intelligence in the recent war. In so many ways he has performed with great distinction and the best -- the best -- in the sense of service to his country. And I hate to see him go. This was his choice, but I offer him my thanks, and I offer him the thanks of a very grateful nation, as he finishes this distinguished career in government and considers other avenues. And he can say a few words now, and then I'll be glad to take just a few questions. Director, we're going to miss you, pal, but you're not leaving right now. We're not going to let him go.
WILLIAM H. WEBSTER: Thank you, Mr. President. I have many mixed feelings about this morning. There's never an easy time to go, especially when you are working for an organization that you believe in and for people that you believe in. It's been an extraordinary experience to have worked with you, Mr. President. . . . I think I'm leaving you -- I know I'm leaving you -- a healthy organization, one that has had, during the last four years, I think, a good track record for its accountability, insofar as it's possible to be accountable. We have positioned ourselves for the challenges of the 90's, which are different than the challenges of the 80's, and I'm very proud of the performance that the entire community rendered during the Persian Gulf. . . . You hate to leave, but something tells you that it's a good time to leave. I still have my roots in the law, and this gives me an opportunity to pursue other avenues in the private sector. So there you are.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS
Successor to Webster
Q. Did this come as a surprise? Do you have a successor in mind?
A. We haven't talked successor -- haven't got anyone in mind, but it did come as a surprise when Bill brought this up to me. He told me this several days ago. And it was his decision. I told him that what I've said -- essentially said here publicly -- and he called in yesterday evening and said he thought we ought to go with this announcement.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
Health and Schedule
Q. Mr. President, you were described yesterday as elated when you got the news that it was your thyroid, not your heart that was out of kilter. Do you have any plans to adjust your schedule, which we all know is rather grueling for anyone, let alone a 66-year-old?
A. Almost 67. No. They've said that with the thyroid thing that I might not get into as active an athletic regime as I'd like to, and they told me that this morning when I took this -- did this test. But they're elated that they know what caused this fibrillation and that it's curable, and will be cured very soon. But they've asked me just for the next few days to check it a little bit in terms of athletics, not in terms of my schedule here.
Q. But beyond the next few days -- will you be scaling back?
A. No, I don't think so. That's the good news, is that once the thyroid is corrected, that means there's no problem on the heart -- the thyroid connected to the heart bone, you know, and I think it's going to be all right. And they've assured me that it can be O.K. Yes.
 
Position on Brady Bill
Q. Mr. President, the House will begin voting today on the Brady bill or the Staggers bill. Is there any scenario under which you would find yourself being able to support the Brady bill, if, in fact, it is attached to you comprehensive crime legislation?
A. Well, what we've said is, we will consider it if it is attached to the comprehensive crime bill. The important legislation -- the priority legislation -- should be the comprehensive crime bill. And I'm a little discouraged that it has not moved faster. And so I will just stay with that position, that we're opposed to them alone. We'll consider them as part of the comprehensive crime bill.
Q. What's wrong with waiting seven days, Mr. President?
A. Our position on this is so well known, I don't want to take up your time going into it any more. Yes.
 
Baltics and Aid to Soviets
Q. Yes, Mr. President. You've got the Baltic leaders coming in later this morning. What are you going to tell them about your leanings on providing aid to the Soviet Union?
A. Well, I'm going to tell them that we haven't made a decision on that. I'm going to tell them I must comply with the law as it's written. But I will also tell them that we have a strong and I think good relationship with President Gorbachev, and I will tell them that I will be interested in hearing what their problems are. I will tell them that we have never, and will never recognize the incorporation of the Baltics into the Soviet Union, but I will encourage peaceful resolution of these very difficult questions.
Q. Well, your comment about Gorbachev today and a similar one yesterday seem to indicate that you'd like to help him out -- that you might want to work around the edges of that credit worthiness provision in the law.
A. Look, when you look at the accomplishments of Mikhail Gorbachev, they are enormous. And yes, the Soviet Union is fighting difficult economic times, but I am not about to forget history and what he did in terms of Eastern Europe, what he's done in terms of perestroika and glasnost has my respect. And so we will deal with the facts as they come to us, but I don't want to see a breach in a relationship that is very strong, that has served us extraordinarily well in recent times, during the war itself, where for the first time the Soviet Union and the United States worked in sync on those matters, and I give President Gorbachev great credit for that, because he was under some pressures at home.
Q. Well, that sounds like you're not going to turn down his request for help.
A. Well, we have to, as I said the other day, we have to be sure that we abide by the rules, as established -- I think the Agriculture Department has to make certain representations. But look, I've always felt that when people are hungry or in need of support, as it relates to food and nourishment, that we ought to try to help.
 
Travel Policy and Sununu
Q. Mr. President, could you give us an update on your review of the White House travel policy and are you still absolutely firmly convinced that Governor Sununu did not abuse it in any way?
A. Yes. I am convinced of that, and I'm going to have some changes, and I'll announce them soon -- perhaps in the next 48 hours.
Q. Will the travels that were made -- that he took -- be permitted under the revisions?
A. Well, why don't you wait and see, because I don't want to preview it. . . .
 
Keeping Quayle on Ticket
Q. Mr. President, what do you say to the pundits who have suggested that as a result of your health scare over the weekend, you might reconsider keeping Dan Quayle on the ticket next year?
A. . . . I've expressed my support for Dan Quayle. I think he's getting a bum rap in the press, pounding on him when he's doing a first-class job. And I don't know how many times I have to say it, but I'm not about to change my mind when I see his performance and know what he does. And I think it's probably been quite hurtful to him, but he's a man -- strong one -- and in fact, we talked about it a little bit yesterday. And I said, look, keep your head up. You're talking to a guy that went through something like this for about eight years -- maybe not quite as intense. But that goes with the territory. And it's unfair, and it is piling on, and it is beneath the critics to do that at this time, I think. But anyway, it's a question I can't lay to rest. . . .
 
Deal on Hostages
Q. Mr. President, lately we've been hearing a resurgence of questions and increasing credence to these allegations that the Reagan-Bush campaign in 1980 was involved in a political deal to hold off on hostage releases until after the election. And even President Carter, who hadn't said this before, thinks that there should be at least some investigation. Don't you think that with all of these allegations coming from so many different continents and so many questions being raised that at least an investigation would be warranted to lay some of these issues to rest?
A. I think the Congress -- some Democratic members -- are looking at it right now, and that's fine. I can only say categorically that the allegations about me are grossly untrue -- factually incorrect -- bald-faced lies. And I have my schedule out there. I think it was put in the days in question -- was in detail in the paper. And those critics -- those who continue to pass this little word-of-mouth ugly rumor ought to have the decency and the honor to say, this takes care of this question. I'm talking about myself. And I can categorically deny any contact with the Iranians or anything having to do with it. And to assign -- let me give you a little more lecture on this, Rita -- to assign a motive to a person that he'd want to keep an American in prison one day longer I think is vicious, and I really am turned off by this, and I'm disappointed in this Mr. Sick, whoever he is.
Q. Then Mr. President, you wouldn't object then to Congress, if it ----
A. They can do whatever they want. It's been looked at exhaustively. But all I'm talking about -- all I can speak for is my own participation or lack there of. And I think that the people who are making these insidious insinuations ought to have the honor to say, this takes care of it. But that's not the way the rumor will works. Yes.
 
Altering the Quayle Image
Q. Mr. President, . . . to follow up about the Vice President. The confidence you've expressed in him is buttressed by those around the White House here who say he's very much a player. There's strong evidence, apart from what the media may or not write that that confidence is not widely shared among people in the general public, and I wonder, sir, if you have contemplated altering his role, giving him more of a chance to be seen, or anything that might allow him to shake this image that he seems to have ----
A. I'd love to be helpful to him in any way I could in that regard. In my view, he is doing his assignments very well -- Competitive Council, Space Council. He's done a lot of very important foreign travel for me, particularly as it relates to South America. And so I can think of a lot of things that maybe I could emphasize more, because I want to help. I don't like to see somebody unfairly criticized. With me, it's again a question of honor. I don't like it. I see him in action. I know what he's doing. He has been extraordinarily helpful, and I can't ask any more of him. But Brit, if there was something I could do to help, I'd want very much to do it because I have great respect for him.
 
Involvement in Iraq
Q. Final question -- the Iraqis this morning tried to shoot down an American plane. What [inaudible] the United States in that?
A. Well, we're looking into that. Fortunately it didn't hit anybody, and I gathered from the Pentagon that they're not particularly concerned. But we have to look into that.
Q. It seems that more and more the U.S. is going deeper in northern Iraq. Aren't you [inaudible] try and [inaudible]?
A. Well, as you know, I expressed my concern early on that I did not want to get bogged down. But what we're doing is humanitarian. We're getting enormous credit finally -- not that we're in there for credit -- for saving lives and helping innocent victims of Saddam Hussein's brutality. And so you raise a very good question, because I don't want to see us get into a quagmire, get further militarily involved with some permanent presence required. I will be talking to the Secretary General of the U.N. -- I think it's tomorrow, and I would hope that the U.N. could do in the north that which they are doing in the south. This is the last one, then I really do have to go.
 
Attitude on Middle East
Q. Mr. President, can you tell us your feelings now towards the Middle East? You've got Secretary Baker heading back for yet another trip. The Soviet foreign minister Bessmertnykh is going to be there at the same time. Does this signal some sort of breakthrough in the offing -- something that gives you cause for optimism?
A. I wouldn't say breakthrough. I wouldn't say breakthrough. But cause for optimism -- I think there's reason to be optimistic. I won't go into the details right now, because when you're dealing with a situation of this complexity and of this endurance, you have to use some quiet diplomacy, which Secretary Baker is very effectively using. But I saw after his last trip some very quite negative reports, and I don't think it's negative. I think there's still a real opportunity here and I don't say that just wishfully. I say it after talking to him and talking to some leaders around the world. So, I'd like to say optimism. But I don't want to go overboard on it, because there's still a complex problem.
Q. There are some who think that you may be being mislead and they cite for proof of that that actions such as the Israelis continuing to establish settlements, that people may be telling the Secretary one thing but either unable to deliver or actually not telling the truth about their intentions.
A. As we know, these differences have gone on for a long, long time, and I don't think that's the case, that somebody's saying one thing and then going off and, you know, just doing something behind his back. But -- no, it's complex. But I don't accept that criticism. There's plenty of room to critique this and to wish for more progress from one country or another. But there's a lot going on and I want to stay involved myself. I want to be a part of this, because I think we have an opportunity now. And I think countries that the United States has helped recognize that, and I think Israel understands that. I think the Saudis understand that. I think the Egyptians understand that. And so I want to use that good will to further peace in the Middle East. And so I'm -- put it this way -- moderately optimistic. Thank you all very much.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Newspaper Ads, for Newspapers

BYLINE: By ALEX S. JONES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, May 8

 BODY:
The newspaper industry ended its annual convention here today by announcing a national multimedia advertising campaign to promote a product that has rarely been effectively advertised: newspapers themselves.
"Go on the offensive and holler!" Donald F. Riesett, vice chairman of W. B. Doner & Company, the Baltimore ad agency that created the campaign, exhorted the American Newspaper Publishers Association. The association's 1,400 members include most of the daily newspapers in the United States and Canada. 
 Mr. Riesett said the campaign was intended to reverse the image of newspapers as old-fashioned, and tout the advantages of advertising in newspapers. He pointed to campaigns by television, radio and magazines that try to portray newspapers as out-of-date.
Like true believers at a revival, the publishers cheered such ads as one that read: "Some car dealers love to see themselves on TV. Others love to see a lot of buyers in their showroom," followed by the campaign's tagline: "Newspaper. The best way to close a sale."
The campaign, which will begin this month, includes a $500,000 budget for placing ads in advertising and marketing trade publications and a commitment by 15 major metropolitan papers to bear the cost of repeatedly publishing the ads in their own pages.
In addition, the ads will be distributed by direct mail, and camera-ready newspaper ads, radio spots and videotapes will be provided to all newspapers at a modest cost so they can localize the campaign in their own markets.
The advertising agency had recommended a $5 million campaign that would have included national television and billboards, but that approach was deemed too expensive for an industry looking for every opportunity to trim costs.
The promotion effort comes as newspapers are suffering through what many here say is the worst advertising recession in memory.
The association reported that newspapers accounted for 24.9 percent of the $129 billion spent on advertising in 1990, which meant newspapers retained their longstanding place as the largest advertising medium, followed by television with 22.2 percent.
But the newspaper share of the total advertising pie was down from 26.1 percent in 1989, and the decline has only intensified the anxiety among publishers.
Indeed, this year's convention has been unusually serious. Its theme was "reinventing" the traditional local daily to prosper in a dauntingly competitive world.
"There has been very much less sizzle and much more on operations," said Richard T. Schlosberg 3d, group vice president for newspapers for the Times Mirror Company.
But the nation's 1,611 daily papers, each with its own quirks and procedures, have a history of talking about change without following through.
For instance, retailers like K Mart, which advertise in many markets and are newspapers' most important customers, have long complained that the industry should standardize certain procedures and forms to facilitate buying space.
In 1986, for instance, the association adopted a standard advertising invoice format and loudly predicted its universal use by 1988. But a majority of papers still do not use the format, or use it incorrectly.
 
Symbol in an Invoice
 The failure to adopt the standardized invoice "has become a symbol of newspaper inertia to our best customers," said Ann C. Hunt, a vice president of the Newspaper Advertising Bureau, an industry support organization.
There are signs that this time, the industry will rouse itself, if only because it has no choice.
"We're not alarmist to say that the retail-newspaper partnership may be up for grabs," Ms. Hunt warned.
After years of discussing the need for a mechanism that would allow advertising agencies to buy advertising at many newspapers through a single centralized computer system, such a system now seems a near reality.
A rapt audience of publishers watched wall monitors today as the new system was put through its paces and, in minutes, was used to plan a hypothetical $75,000 advertising campaign in four cities. Under the system, which is still being refined, the entire campaign could be ordered with the push of a button.
But, once again, the success of such a system will depend on whether most of the nation's newspapers will provide data and follow procedures in the standardized fashion that such a computerized system requires.
Jerry Tilis, vice president for marketing at Knight-Ridder Inc., who has headed the project, said that without broad industry support, "we will end up with a technological success and a marketing failure."

HEADLINE: Insurer Pays Price for Risk Strategy

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, May 8

 BODY:
Like its crosstown rival, the First Executive Corporation, the First Capital Holdings Corporation of Los Angeles built itself into a major life insurance company by investing heavily in high-risk "junk bonds," and like First Executive, whose Executive Life insurance subsidiaries were seized by regulators last month, First Capital is now paying the price for that strategy.
Rocked by defaults in its junk bond portfolio, the Los Angeles-based First Capital reported a $24.7 million net loss in the fourth quarter. Its claims-paying ability has been downgraded by ratings services. Its stock price has slid from $26 four years ago to $1.50 at the close on the New York Stock Exchange today. 
 This week, with concern rising among regulators about the company's ability to withstand further junk bond losses, the California insurance comissioner, John Garamendi, has been putting pressure on First Capital's largest shareholder, the American Express Company, to replenish the financial reserves of the First Capital Life Insurance Company, the largest operating subsidiary.
 
Profitable on Operating Basis
 First Capital so far does not appear to be nearly as weakened by its junk bond losses as First Executive and Executive Life were, analysts said, and there is no indication that any move by regulators to seize its operating units is imminent. Aside from the losses it has had to recognize on its junk bonds, the company still seems to be profitable on an operating basis.
Perhaps most important, it has one thing Executive Life did not: a well-financed backer in the form of American Express, whose Shearson Lehman Brothers subsidiary owns 28 percent of First Capital Holdings.
The most immediate threat to First Capital and First Capital Life may be one of consumer confidence. As questions have grown about First Capital Life's finances, there has been an increase in the number of customers cashing in policies or taking out loans against them. A spokesman for First Capital Life said the number of policy surrenders and withdrawals was up, but that it was "certainly at a manageable level." He declined to provide specifics.
 
An Aggressive Founder
 First Capital Holdings is largely the creation of an aggressive investor, Robert I. Weingarten, who saw a carefully selected portfolio of junk bonds as a way to generate high returns that would fund the competitive rates the company would offer consumers on insurance policies and other investments.
Mr. Weingarten, who resigned as chairman and chief executive on March 15, followed a strategy similar to that used by Fred Carr, the former money manager who built Executive Life into one of the nation's largest insurers.
Mr. Weingarten, a former stockbroker, analyst and magazine publisher, founded First Capital Holdings in 1984. The company grew dramatically, reaching $9.7 billion in assets at the end of last year, $4.1 billion of it in the First Capital Life Insurance subsidiary and $4 billion more in another insurance subsidiary, Fidelity Bankers Life Insurance of Virginia. Both companies primarily sell interest-earning life insurance policies and annuities.
 
$500,000-a-Year Pact
 The whereabouts of Mr. Weingarten, who had previously said that his departure from the company was unrelated to its financial problems, could not be determined. Mr. Weingartern, who is 49 years old, will continue to be paid $500,000 a year through 1997 under a consulting agreement with First Capital Holdings. First Capital Holdings executives did not respond to an interview request.
First Capital is now being run by Gerry R. Ginsberg, the president and chief operating officer.
It is unclear how much money Mr. Garamendi wants American Express to inject into First Capital Life. Mr. Garamendi said on Tuesday that the regulators would "continue to closely monitor First Capital, and will take any action necessary to protect the interests of policyholders."

HEADLINE: Bush Is Leaning To Food Credits For the Soviets

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 8

 BODY:
With the United States and the Soviet Union seeming to move toward another summit meeting, President Bush hailed the accomplishments of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev today and indicated that he was inclined to find a way to satisfy the Soviet leader's request for emergency aid to buy American food.
"When you look at the accomplishments of Mikhail Gorbachev, they are enormous," Mr. Bush said at a White House news conference, going out of his way to praise the Soviet leader. "And yes, the Soviet Union is fighting difficult economic times. But I am not about to forget history. And what he did in terms of Eastern Europe, what he's done in terms of perestroika and glasnost, has my respect." 
 In Moscow, Prime Minister Valentin S. Pavlov said that if the West was truly interested in the success of economic reforms in the Soviet Union, it could not take a "wait and see" attitude toward providing aid. [Page A12.]
 
Ties Seems to Improve
 Developments in recent days suggest that Soviet-American relatons are improving again after a period of coolness that began when Eduard A. Shevardnadze resigned as Foreign Minister in December and Moscow cracked down violently against independence movements in the Baltic republics.
An implicit deal seems to be in the making in which Mr. Gorbachev will satisfy American concerns about the conventional arms treaty, Mr. Bush will help him with more economic aid, and they will both agree to hold a summit meeting in June or July, when they will focus on the still uncompleted strategic arms reduction treaty.
Mr. Bush, in a meeting today with Baltic leaders, was quoted by his visitors as speaking freely about his coming meeting with Mr. Gorbachev, although arrangements have not been completed.
In addition, reports from Moscow indicate that Parliament this weekend may pass a law lifting legal barriers against travel abroad, something long demanded by the United States before remaining trade barriers can be removed.
In discussing the Soviet request for additional credits to buy more American grain, Mr. Bush said, "I've always felt that when people are hungry or need support as it relates to food and nourishment that we ought to try to help."
 
Still Undecided on Method
 But Mr. Bush quickly went on to say that he had still not decided how to respond to Mr. Gorbachev's appeal for the United States to guarantee up to $1.5 billion worth of commercial bank loans by the Soviets to purchase American grain -- largely because by law the Administration cannot extend more such guarantees unless the Soviets are deemed a credit-worthy borrower, which they no longer are by the international banking community.
Administration officials said, however, that the President has asked his aides to look for alternative ways to extend food aid or technical assistance to the Soviets and that this was now being explored by a variety of departments.
Mr. Bush's lavish praise for Mr. Gorbachev today, and his strong hint that he would provide some sort of economic help, were in marked contrast to his public position last week. He said then that "regrettably" the Soviets could not meet the requirements of credit-worthiness, and he left the impression that as a result no American help would be forthcoming.
Since then, though, Mr. Shevardnadze met with Mr. Bush on Monday and appealed for help. And Mr. Gorbachev agreed Tuesday to send the Soviet Chief of Staff, Gen. Mikhail A. Moiseyev, to Washington next week to try to resolve the last disputes over the treaty limiting conventional forces in Europe.
 
$1 Billion Used Up
 The Soviets have virtually used up all of the $1 billion in credit guarantees that Mr. Bush granted them through the Commodity Credit Corporation in December to buy grain to get them through the winter. With Washington guaranteeing the loans, the Soviets could not only get them from commercial banks, which would not normally lend them money, but also get a better interest rate.
Mr. Gorbachev's reason for seeking more help and the Administration's inability to give it automatically have to do with several factors that have developed since December.
First, the United States farm bill that went into effect in 1991 tightened up the conditions for agricultural credits by stipulating that the Secretary of Agriculture had to be able to affirm that a country receiving such benefits could service its debts.
Second, with the Soviet foreign debt now $60 billion and rising, Moscow has become less able to repay many of its commercial lenders, and is now in arrears.
Third, last fall, when the Soviet winter grain crop was being planted for harvesting this spring, its economy was experiencing widespread dislocations, with shortages of seed, fertilizer, tractors, fuel and workers prepared to do their jobs properly. Administration experts are predicting not only a poor Soviet harvest this spring, but also a poor spring planting, which will reduce the fall harvest needed to take the Soviets through next winter.
The impulse to help Mr. Gorbachev is not simply motivated by his cooperative behavior in Eastern Europe and in the Persian Gulf, officials say, but also by the feeling in Washington that he is making a real push to complete the conventional and strategic arms control treaties, which the Administration is eager to lock in.
Administration officials say they are also inclined to help Mr. Gorbachev because if they do not, there could be more serious upheavals in the Soviet Union this year, which could spill over into Eastern Europe.
At the same time, extending new food credits to the Soviets is viewed by some in the Administration as the equivalent of giving drugs to an addict, since it is increasingly clear that the Soviet leader is either unable or unwilling to adopt the real free-market economic reforms that might one day make such credits unnecessary.
Among the alternative approaches being considered would be for the President to extend bank loans or food aid under his discretion to meet humanitarian disasters, although this would require declaring a disaster in the Soviet Union, which would be complicated.
Another option is to use the up to $300 million in credits that could be secured through the Export-Import Bank. A third option, already in the works, is to send a team from the Department of Agriculture this month to advise the Soviets on how to reorganize their farm distribution system. Another possibility is to make grain available on concessionary terms through Public Law 480.
After his news conference, Mr. Bush met for 40 minutes in the Oval Office with President Vytautas Landsbergis of Lithuania, Prime Minister Ivars Godmanis of Latvia and Prime Minister Edgar Savisaar of Estonia. This marked the sixth time he has met with Baltic leaders in the last year.
Mr. Godmanis, speaking to reporters after the meeting with Mr. Bush and Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, said Mr. Baker had suggested that the Baltic republics try to establish their independence from Moscow in ways "which also save face for the Soviet Union."

From left were Prime Minister Ivars Godmanis of Latvia; President Vyitautaus Landsbergis of Lithuania, and Prime Minister Edgar Savisaar of Estonia. (George Tames for The New York Times) (pg. A12)

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Toys 'R' Us Sales Results

 BODY:
Toys "R" Us Inc., the nation's largest specialty toy retailer, said yesterday that sales at its domestic stores open at least a year fell 4.7 percent in the first quarter.
The retailer said its overall sales, which include those from newer stores, rose 9 percent, to nearly $1.03 billion, from $944.8 million in 1990's first quarter. 
 Securities analysts and investors consider sales from stores open at least a year, known as same-store sales, to be the best measure of a retailer's performance. Newer stores tend to have extraordinarily strong sales.
Many American retailers have seen their same-store sales fall or remain level because of consumer worry about unemployment and the economy. Toys "R" Us had reported a drop in same-store sales during the Christmas shopping season. The company, based in Paramus, N.J., said it would release first-quarter earnings on May 20.

HEADLINE: C.I.A. in Search of a Role

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 8

 BODY:
With his retirement as the Government's chief spymaster, William H. Webster leaves the Central Intelligence Agency with its image and internal controls on misdeeds visibly stronger, but with its own destiny muddled and its performance in the Persian Gulf crisis under a cloud.
 Charting a new role in a world no longer chilled by the cold war will be the overriding task of his successor, and Mr. Webster's own difficulty in doing so may be one reason that he is leaving. President Bush announced Mr. Webster's decision today but did not name a successor. 
 When Mr. Webster came to the intelligence agency in 1987, on the heels of William J. Casey and the Iran-contra affair, the situation in American intelligence was the opposite. The agency was swamped in scandal over secret arms sales to Iran and the Nicaraguan rebels but nevertheless driven by a single cause: the defeat of America's archenemy, the Soviet Union and its proxies in the third world.
Mr. Webster's greatest accomplishment, Administration experts agree, was his restoration of public trust in American intelligence after the political and policy debacle of the Iran-contra scandal.
"The Agency was perilously close four years ago to sliding back into the public image of the 'rogue elephant,' " Bobby Ray Inman, a former Deputy Director of the C.I.A. and an intelligence adviser to Mr. Bush, said today. "The first and foremost job that Webster did, and at a critical time, was to arrest that and get the presumption back to reality."
Mr. Webster imposed strict controls over secret operations like the Iran-contra arms sales, and he disciplined several lower-ranking agency officials involved in the sales. Those public actions reassured a suspicious Congress and raised morale in the intelligence agencies, where advocates of the C.I.A's involvement in the affair were a minority.
But as morale and direction improved within the intelligence agency, the collapse of the Soviet military and ideological threat in 1989 and 1990 suddenly deprived the agency and its brethren organizations of the purpose that drove them for four decades. And while Mr. Webster made a mark in restoring the heart of American intelligence to its proper place, he leaves it without its old soul.
 
Unprepared to Deal With Peace
 "We set up an intelligence apparatus in the 1940's for a specific purpose, to monitor a military and political challenge from the Soviet Union," said one former intelligence official who spoke on condition of anonymity. "When we were planning to meet this challenge, our assumption was that it would come in the form of war. But it didn't; it came in the form of peace. And we are basically unprepared to deal with it."
Agency officials argue that the organization under Mr. Webster has been planning for years for a world without a preeminent Soviet threat. Although critics such as Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, have argued otherwise, some evidence supports the officials' assertion.
Five months after Mr. Webster took office in 1987, for example, the agency sent President Ronald Reagan a classified report entitled "Eastern Europe: Impact of Gorbachev's Agenda on Stability," which predicted outright that Soviet political and economic reforms taking place under Mikhail S. Gorbachev would infect the old East Bloc, producing a political upheaval within several years.
 
Speed of Change a Surprise
 Similarly, the agency sent Mr. Bush a 1989 classified report that predicted increased economic crisis and political instability within the Soviet Union and its ethnic republics as Mr. Gorbachev's policies unleashed national aspirations and demand for goods that even the Soviet leader's reforms could not accommodate.
Mr. Webster since has acknowledged in interviews that the intelligence agency did not anticipate the speed or sweep of those upheavals, but that he believes its assessments were generally accurate.
In recent months, Mr. Webster has come under fire from some in Congress who have complained that he has not offered a dynamic plan to reshape American intelligence for a post-cold war world. Both the House and Senate intelligence committees are now studying legislation that would impose new orders on the $30 billion-a-year intelligence establishment.
Mr. Webster's supporters say that he sought to outline new roles for the intelligence agency, even before the Soviet Union's difficulties. Mr. Webster set up a Federal counter-terrorism center to coordinate American and foreign intelligence on global terrorism and a second center to integrate intelligence and law-enforcement efforts against narcotics producers and traffickers.
More recently, he has publicly advocated collecting more intelligence on foreign threats to the American economy, such as companies that steal American trade secrets and governments that use espionage to learn about American economic strategies.
But such new roles have been unpopular among some intelligence officials, who question the agency's involvement in law-enforcement missions or the practicality of using economic intelligence on foreign rivals to benefit American companies.
 
Challenge Facing Successor
 Whoever succeeds Mr. Webster must quickly resolve those differences and convince Congress that the agency and other espionage agencies have compelling missions to perform in the absence of a serious threat of global war.
The task is made doubly hard by Congress's own skepticism about the ability of American espionage agencies to provide accurate and farsighted information about either its enemies or its friends.
Congress's faith has been shaken by predictions in such hot spots as Afghanistan, where the C.I.A. and many other agencies forecast in 1989 that the nation's Soviet-backed regime would collapse within weeks after Moscow withdrew its troops. Two years later, the Afghan Army has grown stronger and has battled United States-backed guerrilla forces to a stalemate.
More recently, some legislators have criticized the agency's analysis of intelligence on Iraq and its president, Saddam Hussein.
Less than a year before Iraq invaded Kuwait last August, C.I.A. analysts forecast incorrectly that Mr. Hussein would shy from military adventures in order to rebuild his nation's economy after an eight-year war with Iran.
Analysts in serval intelligence agencies were also slow to conclude that Iraq's buildup of forces at the Kuwait border would lead to an invasion, and virtually no one foresaw that he would seize all of Kuwait and precipitate an international crisis.
Many experts in the estabishment complain that such failures are rooted in the C.I.A.'s 20-year emphasis on satellites and other technical wizardry to collect intelligence rather than on traditional spies who collect information firsthand and up close.
 
Traditional Role Stressed
 "Largely speaking, in broad parts of the world we're interested in, we have no special sources, no particular or unique sources of information," said one former Congressional intelligence expert who spoke on condition of anonymity. "If you expect our clandestine services to have recruited lots of people in the Politburo, then we're a failure."
Mr. Webster's associates say that he has made major efforts within the agency, amid resistance from some officials, to stress the traditional espionage of individual agents abroad. He has also intensified the agency's language training and begun to aggressively recruit ethnic minorities and technical specialists, a departure from the spy of agency lore, who was a white, male, Ivy League-educated expert in the liberal arts.
Because recruiting, training and placing agents takes years, the real fruits of Mr. Webster's effort will not be seen until the next century.

HEADLINE: Mail-Order Sales Tax Upheld in North Dakota

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 8

 BODY:
In a decision that could substantially aid small merchants and state treasuries, the North Dakota Supreme Court decided late Tuesday that out-of-state telemarketers and mail-order houses must start collecting a 5 percent sales tax on purchases by North Dakota citizens and sending it to the state.
The case, believed to be the first in which a state's highest court has ruled directly on this issue, challenged the landmark 1967 National Bellas Hess decision in which the United States Supreme Court barred states from collecting sales and use taxes from out-of-state marketers. It was brought against the Quill Corporation, an Illinois-based seller of office products, by Heidi Heitkamp, North Dakota's tax commisioner. 
 The court, citing technological advances and mail-order growth during the last quarter-century, found that "the economic, social and commercial landscape upon which Bellas Hess was premised no longer exists, save perhaps in the fertile imaginations of attorneys representing mail-order interests."
This is a longstanding controversy, one that has turned on the question of physical presence. Ms. Heitkamp contended that not only does Quill use sophisticated equipment to market its goods in the state but also distributes 24 tons of catalogues and brochures each year that wind up in state landfills.
The decision in Bismarck is thought unlikely to have much practical effect until it is upheld on appeal. But if the United States Supreme Court agrees, "out-of-state direct marketers no longer will enjoy an unfair competitive advantage against Main Street America small businesses through the avoidance of $2.9 billion in state and local tax collections," asserted the Coalition for Fair Collection of Interstate Sales Taxes, a group of business and labor interests allied with North Dakota.
Citizens of North Dakota, the most rural of the states, rely heavily on mail-order houses, which now account for 15 percent of national retail sales.
Duane Benton, tax commissioner of Missouri and chairman of the Multistate Tax Commission, a group of 32 states that have led the legal challenge to the mail-order tax exception, said, "Local businesses in every state with a sales tax will benefit from this decision, which recognize the facts of life about the modern American retail market."
