HEADLINE: Excerpts From Dinkins Speech: 'Our Difficult Journey Ahead'

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from an address last night by Mayor David N. Dinkins, as recorded by The New York Times.
Good evening, everyone. Tonight I want to talk to you about events of the past few days that touch upon the heart of our fiscal health. I want to talk to you about our difficult journey ahead and about the choices facing all of us who care about this city. And I want to reaffirm my staunch and deep belief that despite our problems, for this greatest of all cities the greatest days still lie ahead. 
 Last Saturday an extraordinary meeting took place at Gracie Mansion. I called together a diverse group of New Yorkers -- elected officials, leaders of business, labor, the Municipal Assistance Corporation and the social service community -- all joined in a common bond, believing in our city and wanting to secure the best New York has to offer for all of our people.
I shared with each of them some very painful decisions that I have had to make for the coming fiscal year. And I asked each and every one of them to work with me to ease the pain of this tight budget. They will be responding in weeks to come -- specifically, compassionately and even bravely. . . .
During the past few months I've had to make some of the most difficult decisions of my career, decisions affecting every single New Yorker. . . . While it has not been an easy time for any of us, we have taken the actions required to regain our fiscal health. Since taking office, my administration has had to cut spending in nearly every agency, raise taxes and weigh every service on a new scale of priorities. The conditions we have faced have stretched the imagination and tested the character and soul of our city.
And we have accomplished a great deal.
 
Budget on Friday
Since I took office we have had to close nearly $8 billion in budget gaps. That's a larger deficit than any prior mayor has had to confront in a full four-year term. This Friday we will be releasing our budget for the next fiscal year and our plan for the next four years. The facts are starkly, undeniably clear. We will grapple with nearly $4 billion in shortfalls for the next 14 months -- at the same time that New York State must come to grips with a $6.5 billion shortfall. . . .
Like most cities throughout the region and the nation we are faced with a kind of continuing, grinding financial squeeze and regrettably the only solutions available will be felt in one way or another by everyone of us.
Most New Yorkers, especially older New Yorkers like myself, remember the city's fiscal crisis 15 years ago as though it were yesterday. . . . Let us never lose sight of the fact that there is a fundamental difference between then and now. The fiscal crisis of the mid-70's was precipitated by financial gimmicks and budgetary tricks. The fiscal challenge today is largely the direct result of a failing national economy. The national recession is real in New York, and it has deprived us of both dollars and hope. We simply do not have the resources to pay for what we need, and our city, like every urban center in our country, has been abandoned in the past decade by the Federal Government.
If the Federal Government had maintained the level of aid it gave New York City 10 years ago, our operating budget would have received an additional $1.2 billion. In addition to that, over $2.5 billion in housing money would have enriched our capital construction plan. Now we must solve problems that have jolted our nation. Our Federal Government stopped building housing, and homelessness has swept across our land. We battle crack and crime, a failing infrastructure, an AIDS virus that has killed more people than the Great Plague. Our current situation is not one that we have created. We are paying the price of inequities in state aid and of money not saved during better times. Washington let us down and then left us with the recession. . . . We will achieve nothing by pointing fingers or assigning blame.
 
'Our Future Health'
As New Yorkers we cannot quarrel about the past and the present or we are sure to lose the future. The answers to our problems are clear. We are the participants who must shape the solutions. . . .
It is, however, only a small down payment toward our future health. A budget gap of over $3.5 billion for the next fiscal year remains. Indeed, our shortfall is so large that we have met with the Governor, state legislators, the City Council, municipal labor unions and the Municipal Assistance Corporation to ask them for help. And unless we receive this critical assistance, we will have to cut essential services by almost $1.5 billion in a single year.
To make reductions of this size is a drastic, almost intimidating, undertaking. But to stop short of that goal of insuring a fiscally sound New York would mean a failure of will, a failure of responsibility, a failure of our city itself. And I do not intend to fail.
Let me outline the choices we have made. Not one of them is pleasant, but without the help of the leaders I have mentioned every one of these cuts will be necessary. I'm ordering city agencies to begin moving ahead with our plan to lay off over 20,000 full-time city workers. As I announced in January, I will recommend to the City Council and to the State Legislature that property and personal income taxes be raised. And most painful of all, under our $1.5 billion service reduction plan we will have to begin a broad-based retrenchment in virtually every critical service this city provides.
We will be dealt some hard blows, but I am certain that in this hour of action we will show our greatest courage. . . . Our entire recycling program will have to be suspended for one year. Our children will lose a treasured experience when we shut the Central Park Zoo. Our streets will be darker since we cannot afford to light all of our lampposts. Our street-cleaning program will be drastically curtailed. . . . For me, this has been a time of reflection. I must say that there is personal sorrow in each of these choices for I have fought for many of these initiatives for years and unless we get the relief that I am seeking, we must begin to dismantle them. But the decisions we had to make, the necessary sacrifices we had to confront, were piercingly clear. As we addressed projected shortfalls for the next four years we have not merely reacted to the crisis, we're several steps ahead. We will have balanced the budget not just for this year, but we will be stabilizing our city's finances for years to come.
 
'I Will Assure You'
At each step along the way we've tried to cushion the blow. Until now we've been able to cut expenses without sacrificing the core programs and services that fuel growth in our communities. We're downsizing city government; I'm reducing the mayor's office by 15 percent; we've consolidated six of our economic development agencies into just two; we have slashed our debt service; we've slashed overtime; we've slashed our fleet of automobiles; we've slashed the salaries of our senior city managers. Sometimes our common goals are derived simply from common sense. In total we have saved $550 million through productivity initiatives. . . . In making these very difficult choices I have tried to preserve programs that affect our most precious resource, our children. Sadly that has not always been possible. But I will assure you tonight, that as soon as our fiscal health improves or if I can secure funding from the other sources that I have consulted, programs will be restored.
Since I dedicated my administration to children, I want to assure you personally that this government will do everything it can to keep our children from harm's way.
We will endeavor to restore prenatal care programs, drug treatment for pregnant mothers and school health clinics. I know the children need nourishment for their minds and bodies, and our libraries and recreational facilities will open again, as soon as additional revenues are at hand. We also want our children to be nurtured by the richness of our cultural life, and I hope I will soon be able to restore funding for these very very vital institutions.
We have fought our hearts out to fund a $1.8 billion six-year criminal justice strategy. Safe Streets-Safe City we call it -- subtitled Cops and Kids, and we will keep that program in place. The battle against violence, lawlessness and drugs will not be short or easy, and I am convinced that if this battle is not won, our poorest, most vulnerable citizens will be hurt most of all.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Our labor unions fight tenaciously for their workers, but we're asking them to think about the impact of these cuts not only on their members but on the sons and daughters that they have and the grandsons and granddaughters of those members. . . . Our business leaders must cope with a great national and local recession, but we're asking them to protect the future of the city that nurtured them by bearing an increased tax burden.

 	 	 		. . .	 	The budget that the State Legislature should have passed in April must be passed by May 25.
This delay has already cost us millions of dollars, and once this budget is approved we ask that they give us our fair share of aid. I'm sure that's clear but let me just say it again: We not only need a budget by May 25, we need our fair share out of that budget.

 	 	 		. . .	 	The choices before us are clear. We can act together making sacrifices and sharing the burden for the good of this city. Or we can go forward with some of the most difficult, painful budget cuts our city has ever had to confront. I am convinced that we will act collectively, not selfishly in this alliance for New York's future, for a cause that is greater than any of our separate interests.

GRAPHIC: Photo: "Despite our problems, for this greatest of all cities the greatest days still lie ahead," Mayor Dinkins said last night in his televised speech on the city's fiscal crisis. (Chester Higgins Jr./ The New York Times)

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 1604 words

HEADLINE: Dinkins Urges New Yorkers to Ride Out Fiscal Cuts

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
Mayor David N. Dinkins painted a grim picture of a fiscally flattened New York in a somber speech last night that served as his strongest appeal yet for sacrifices from every corner and constituency of the city.
The Mayor announced that the city could close a $465 million budget gap in the last seven weeks of its current fiscal year. But for the longer term, he said, "we simply do not have the resources to pay for what we need." 
 To resolve that problem, Mr. Dinkins affirmed that he would press ahead in his budget proposal to the City Council tomorrow with harsh cuts, some of the worst the city has seen, he said. But then he said not all of this nightmare vision had to come true if all New Yorkers, from municipal workers to business leaders and state officials, would join in making sacrifices.
In doing so, Mr. Dinkins sought to use his public platform and persuasive powers to move large numbers of New Yorkers to accomplish what his administration has so far been unable to do in private talks: agree to address the problems, one way or the other.
"The choices before us are clear," he said. "We can act, together, making sacrifices and sharing the burden for the good of this city, or we can go forward with some of the most difficult, painful budget cuts that our city has had to confront." [Excerpts, page B2.]
With the speech, Mr. Dinkins fell back on a tactic he has used in other pivotal moments in his 16-month tenure, going directly to the public in an effort to quell criticism of his stewardship by confronting it head on and appealing for understanding of his predicament.
The Mayor's speech -- carried live on five television stations and six radio stations with the solemn trappings of a Presidential event -- offered little new substantive information.
The Mayor's aides said they would be able to close the current year's gap by juggling various reserve funds and one-time revenues. For the fiscal year that starts on July 1, Mr. Dinkins vowed to make more than $2 billion in spending cuts to balance the $29 billion budget if he cannot win concessions or aid from the state and the Municipal Assistance Corporation, a state body that was set up to borrow on the city's behalf in the fiscal crisis of the mid-1970's. He has also called for more than $1 billion in higher taxes.
But the remarks were crafted primarily to elaborate on his plea last weekend to municipal labor unions and state officials for concessions and aid to soften the worst of cuts, which would turn off street lights, drain swimming pools, shut homeless shelters, abandon garbage recycling for a year and lay off more than 20,000 workers.
Mr. Dinkins began the half-hour speech by saying flatly that he would make the cuts, then outlined how others could help and by the end made his own conviction clear. "I am convinced that we will act collectively, not selfishly, in this alliance for New York's future -- for a cause that is greater than any of our separate interests," he said.
Unlike the fiscal crisis of the 1970's, Mr. Dinkins said, the city's current problems were not caused by "financial gimmicks and budget tricks" but by the pressures of recession and Federal cutbacks that have "deprived us of both dollars and hope." But that, he said, would pass.
Speaking hoarsely from the effects of a cold in the calm style that is his trademark and wearing glasses to see a Teleprompter, he asked citizens to volunteer to help clean neighborhood parks and streets and to donate time and money to local community organizations that would be hurt by city budget cuts.
He announced that an anonymous donor had offered $2 million to avoid the closing of all 32 city swimming pools, though he said he realized that not everyone could be so generous.
"If others cannot come to the table because of their own constraints, then we can and we must and we will help ourselves in a way that only New Yorkers can," he said, flanked by 18 flags under the crystal chandeliers of the old Board of Estimate chamber on the second floor of City Hall.
"And we'll do it together. For we are New Yorkers, a people with restless dreams and countless hopes, a people who have derived strength from adversity, a people who have always reached for greatness."
 
'Not Going to Stand By'
 City Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone, whose members must pass a budget by June 30, said after the speech, "We're not going to stand by and see essential services decimated." At the same time, he said, the Council will resist the amount of higher property taxes Mr. Dinkins is seeking.
"We have said clearly a long time ago that the days of taxing and spending are over," Mr. Vallone said.
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's press secretary, Anne W. Crowley, said he had not had a chance to listen to the speech, which was not broadcast in Albany, and could not comment on it.
All day, City Hall had an anticipatory air, with television trucks stationed outside and technicians scurrying about, but there was also some sense of skepticism about just what Mr. Dinkins could say that would be new.
In a reminder that not all departments would shrink under the Mayor's cuts (he is hiring thousands of new police officers) and of the oddities of municipal government, police officers from the Technical Assistance Response Unit of the Chief of Detectives' office -- who more often wield cameras and listening devices to help defuse hostage-takings -- were called to install a television link from the second floor to the Blue Room downstairs, to handle overflow crowds of invited guests of city officials and community leaders.
 
'A Tough Town'
 The televised speech evoked an emotional appeal broadcast just 16 years ago this month by Mayor Abraham D. Beame, at the depth of the city's fiscal crisis, in which Mr. Beame warned of the tens of thousands of layoffs he would have to make, complained of a "whispering campaign to denigrate our fiscal integrity" and pledged that New York "is a tough town and it knows how to deal with adversity."
Weeks later, the city was faced with the prospect of immediate bankruptcy, Gov. Hugh L. Carey stepped in to rescue it and by that fall was overseeing its affairs through a special state body, the Financial Control Board.
The control board, now just a watchdog agency, could resume binding powers over the city's spending if the city ended the year with a deficit of $100 million or more or was unable to borrow money in the bond markets. But Mr. Dinkins has pledged to avoid that at all costs, and Mr. Cuomo says his goal is "cooperation, not control."
Mayoral aides said the city could finish closing the gap in the current budget, which they pinpointed several weeks ago after unexpected falloffs in personal-income and sales tax receipts. They would do so with savings from a freeze in purchasing nonessential supplies and other cuts in spending, $50 million from labor reserves, up to $60 million from the sale of a mortgage the city holds on Mitchell-Lama housing, and higher than expected collections in some other taxes and improved tax audits.
 
'Showing Leadership'
 But they acknowledged that if the state did not pass a budget by the end of this month, giving the city anticipated aid, the city could face severe cash-flow problems.
Mr. Dinkins decided to make the speech last Saturday after meeting with union and business leaders, state and city officials and representatives of social-service, parks and cultural groups at Gracie Mansion to outline his proposed cuts.
"I felt that with all of the buzzing around going on, that the Mayor needed to go directly to the public," said Deputy Mayor Bill Lynch, his chief political aide. The strategy "is one that should be used when you have situations like this where the public is concerned," he said. "I think he's showing leadership as he has in the past and he's gotten people's attention."
It was at least the fourth time Mr. Dinkins had taken to the airwaves in a moment of challenge for his administration. The first was just a year ago, when he appealed for racial tolerance in the midst of a black-led boycott of Korean-American grocery stores in Brooklyn and in the Bensonhurst racial murder trial.
The second was last fall, when Mr. Dinkins announced his plan to hire thousands of new police officers and expand the justice system after spending weeks being criticized for not responding forcefully or vocally enough to a highly publicized spate of late-summer crimes. In January, he outlined an optimistic vision for the future in his State of the City address.
 
Final Revisions
 Last night's speech was drafted by Mr. Dinkins's principal speechwriter, Maria Laurino, and worked over by deputy mayors and other aides. Late yesterday, Mr. Dinkins made final revisions himself and then practiced delivering it using the Teleprompter.
First Deputy Mayor Norman Steisel said the point was to prepare the public for pain but also "to remind people that the city has always turned around and there's no reason it shouldn't now" and that the problems were the result of precipitous declines in the city's tax revenues, "as opposed to the impression that seems to be forming in some people's minds that this is poor management at City Hall."
But the City Council President, Andrew J. Stein, who has said he may challenge Mr. Dinkins for the mayoralty in 1993, said: "If we had confronted these problems eight months ago, and the Mayor hadn't granted raises to unions, the public wouldn't be facing this situation now. This is the 11th hour. This is very late in the game."

HEADLINE: A Moving Call to Arms, Or Too Little, Too Late?

BYLINE: By FELICIA R. LEE

 BODY:
Mayor David N. Dinkins's appeal to New Yorkers last night to make sacrifices in a time of fiscal trouble was praised by many city leaders invited to hear it as an eloquent call to arms. But City Council leaders derided the Mayor's plea as too little, too late, and two key labor leaders, while praising the speech, said they were not ready to give Mr. Dinkins what they would call concessions.
Elected officials as well as civic, religious and labor leaders crowded into the public hearing room at City Hall to hear Mr. Dinkins's televised speech, and most gave him high marks afterward. They said the Mayor did a good job articulating the scope of the city's problems in plain but passionate terms. 
 "I thought the Mayor was somber, eloquent and strong," said the Rev. Herbert Daughtry, the pastor of the House of the Lord Pentecostal Church in Brooklyn and a civil-rights advocate. "It was as though he stepped forward and said, 'I've got a painful job to do and I'm going to do it.' "
The city faces a budget gap of more than $3.5 billion in the fiscal year that begins in July, and city officials have ordered reductions in virtually every critical city service.
 
Another Message
 In a speech that outlined a broad swath of cost-cutting measures, including more than 20,000 layoffs, cuts in cultural programs, and the closing of drug-treatment programs and homeless shelters, the Mayor asked New Yorkers to volunteer their services to save the city. Mr. Dinkins said the resolve of ordinary people, coupled with tax increases and the retrenchments he has ordered, would ensure New York's continued pre-eminence.
But the critics in the audience said resolve alone would do little to ease New York's budget woes. They said the Mayor's speech lacked long-term solutions and was not tough enough on pressing the business community to do its part. They also criticized his failure to discuss the impact of the higher personal and property taxes that his administration has requested.
"The Council has a message for the city also," said Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone, whom the Mayor called on in the speech to enact a property-tax increase to raise additional revenues. "And that is we will not allow the decimation of essential city services and we will not allow a tax rate that will cripple the city's economy. We will begin to reshape the budget after we receive it on Friday."
Those who praised the 30-minute speech said the Mayor had succeeded in giving New Yorkers some idea of how they can help, whether it be volunteering at a clinic or library or just making do with less.
"It was a great speech. Inspirational. Well-done," said Barry Feinstein, president of Local 237 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters. "We'll do what we can in reviewing the budget."
"I think he had real impact with people who watched him on television," said Stanley Hill, executive director of District Council 37 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees. "We must make sure that the children grow up with health clinics, swimming pools, libraries -- all the things I had when I was growing up."
But neither Mr. Hill nor Mr. Feinstein said yesterday that they would ask their memberships to make wage concessions and givebacks previously requested by Mr. Dinkins to reduce the deficit. Mr. Hill said he had a "very productive" three-hour meeting with his membership yesterday, and Mr. Feinstein pledged his help in any way he could.
Some other union officials who campaigned for Mr. Dinkins were left disappointed and upset.
"He's going totally against the entire platform that he won on," said Jimmy Carosella, the president of Local 299 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, which represents Parks and Recreation Department workers, hospital therapists, chaplains and employees at the Department of Cultural Affairs. "He's an embarrassment. I'm really sorry that my local, we backed him, because everything he said he wouldn't do, he's doing."
Geoffrey Canada, executive director of the Rheedlen Foundation, which operates six service centers for children and families in Manhattan, gave Mr. Dinkins's speech a mixed review. He said the Mayor was articulate and compassionate, but failed to conceive a clear role for the unions and for business in sharing the burden.
"I thought the Mayor was truly moved by the pain that the budget cuts were going to bring to the children and families in New York," Mr. Canada said. "But I was disappointed that he was not more explicit in making clear what the other parties who hold the city's future in the palm of their hands could bring to the table."

HEADLINE: U.S. Sees End of Slide In Housing

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 8

 BODY:
The housing slump appears to have bottomed out in much of the nation, the Government reported today.
In the latest sign that sales and values have picked up from a low point at the beginning of the year, a new survey of bank examiners and liquidators shows that residential real estate improved over the last six months in the West, the South and the Midwest. The survey found that even in the Northeast, which is reeling from overexpansion in housing and commercial real estate, more officials saw an improvement than further deterioration. 
 The survey, which will initially be conducted twice a year but may become quarterly, supports anecdotal reports and impressions by real estate developers and brokers that the worst may be over.
 
Other Evidence of Upturn
 It follows other Government and private reports that indicate the markets have begun to improve. On Tuesday the National Association of Realtors reported that home sales picked up for the first quarter of the year by 1.8 percent, to an annual rate of 3.5 million units, although prices continued to stay low compared with those of the 1980's.
And last week the Commerce Department reported that sales of new single-family homes rose in March to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 490,000 from a low of 409,000 in January. Building permits issued for new-home construction, a leading indicator, have also steadily increased since January.
Analysts attributed the increases to the continuing drop in interest rates while prices remain low in many regions.
 
'Turned the Corner'
 "The picture is beginning to become clearer that the housing market has turned the corner," said Mark H. Obrinsky, senior economist at the Federal National Mortgage Association, which provides financing to lenders and did not participate in the survey. "It looks very much like January was the bottom of the residential housing market. We've seen improvements in February and March and although the final numbers have not come in yet, we will probably see an increase in sales in April."
Mr. Obrinsky and other economists predicted that housing prices could begin to increase at the same rate as inflation by the end of the year.
The newly developed index of real estate trends found that more than half the professionals polled across the country said the strongest gains in residential real estate had been in the West, the South and the Midwest. It also found that in the view of the majority of those polled, commercial real estate continued to decline modestly.
The survey was based on questionnaires sent to 500 bank examiners and liquidators from five Federal bank agencies that value and sell real estate. It was created by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, which insures the largest real estate lenders, and the Resolution Trust Corporation, which is supervising the bailout of the nation's savings associations and has become the world's largest holder of commercial and residential property. The results of the survey generally conform to the outlook of many private economists and analysts.
Like the widely followed Purchasing Managers' Index, the survey relies on an index calculated from the responses of those polled. An index of more than 50 indicates an improving economic condition, while one below 50 is a sign of decline.
The composite F.D.I.C. real estate index for the last six months through the middle of last month was 61, which was a weighted average of the commercial market index of 47 and the residential index of 70. The index is expected to become more useful once it is conducted over a period of time that will enable trends to be detected.
At a luncheon with reporters, L. William Seidman, chairman of the F.D.I.C. and the trust corporation, said results and trends gleaned from the survey would be used to set discounts and pricing on property held by the Government and to help devise regulations for lenders.
 
'A Reasonable Improvement'
 "People in the field see a reasonable improvement in the marketplace in residential real estate compared to six months ago," Mr. Seidman said. "They don't see it in commercial real estate.
In recent weeks, Mr. Seidman has attributed the weakened condition of the banking industry to changes in the laws that have permitted institutions to make imprudent loans on construction and development projects.
The survey, conducted in the first few weeks in April, also detected strong evidence of a tightening of credit. Almost four-fifths of those questioned found that financing was a problem for "viable" commercial property.
Opinions were more mixed for residential construction lending. Slightly more than a third of the respondents said banks in their area had cut back, and 22 percent reported that banks had become more active. Almost 7 out of 10 polled also said there was too much commercial and residential property on the market.

HEADLINE: Rent Board Proposes Increases of 3% a Year

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT

 BODY:
In a move that left tenants' groups unhappy but not as unhappy as landlords' representatives, the New York City Rent Guidelines Board proposed last night that apartment rents rise 3 percent for one-year leases and 6 percent for two-year leases in rent-stabilized buildings.
If adopted, the proposal would be less than last year's rent increases, which were 4.5 percent for one-year leases and 7 percent for two-year leases. 
 More than 900,000 apartments with at least two million city residents are covered by rent stabilization. Public hearings on the proposal will be held on June 18 and 20, and the rates could be revised before a final vote by the board on June 24.
As usual in the annual jockeying over the rent increases, both tenant and landlord groups at the board meeting last night expressed dissatisfaction. But landlords were especially vehement.
"This is one of the most irresponsible government acts I've ever seen," said John Gilbert 3d, president of the Rent Stabilization Association, a building owners' organization.
A study by the staff of the Rent Guidelines Board concluded that actual building operating costs in the 12 months ending in April rose by an average of 5.1 percent. Mr. Gilbert's organization came up with a figure of 7.2 percent.
The city agency's study also projected that in the coming year, operating costs would rise 6.1 to 7.7 percent.
Citing steep rises of about 20 percent in property taxes and water and sewer charges, Mr. Gilbert said many building owners could not make ends meet under the proposed rent increases. He predicted that more buildings would be abandoned by owners.
Another owner representative, Dan Margulies, executive director of the Community Housing Improvement Program, said that without adequate rental income, more owners would default on their property taxes, a result that would only compound the city government's fiscal problems.
But tenant advocates called for no change in rent levels, asserting that building owners have profited from excessive increases in past years.
 
Proposal Approved 5 to 4
 The board itself was sharply divided in last night's voting. It has two members representing landlords, two representing tenants and five designated as "public" members.
After a succession of 10 different rent formulas were introduced and voted down, the board took a recess and returned to adopt the compromise proposal by a vote of 5 to 4.
The regulations apply to leases that are renewed between Oct. 1 of this year and Sept. 30, 1992, said Timothy L. Collins, executive director of the rent guidelines agency.
Oda Friedheim, a tenants' representative on the board, said rents needed to be limited in part because of the economy. "Many tenants are suffering tremendously in the recession," she said. But a member of the audience supporting the landlords shouted, "We're not social workers!" There were occasional catcalls and boos from both sides throughout the session.
While the annual rent increases are being decided, the landlord groups are making their most concerted effort in years to win changes in rent control laws from the State Legislature. Tenant organizations are adamantly opposed to them.

HEADLINE: $4.5 Million Matisse Leads in Slow Sales

BYLINE: By CAROL VOGEL

 BODY:
The recession in the art market continues, judging by this week's auctions of Impressionist and modern works at Christie's and Sotheby's . A majority of paintings at both auctions sold either well below or right at low estimates, and private buyers dominated the market.
Of the 57 lots sold at Christie's last night, 17 did not find buyers. The sale totaled $23,144,000, well below the presale estimate of $34 million to $47 million. Sotheby's sale on Tuesday evening fared even worse: of the 49 paintings, sculptures and drawings offered for sale, 20, or 41 percent, found no buyers. Even the best-known painting -- "The Persian Robe" by Matisse, which sold for $4.5 million -- went for significantly less than Sotheby's presale estimate of $5 million to $7 million. 
 As was evident at last week's sales of contemporary art at Sotheby's and Christie's, which opened the spring auction season in New York City, selectivity was the buzzword among buyers, who eagerly packed both sales rooms, hoping to cash in on bargain prices. In this week's sales of Impressionist and modern art, auction houses and buyers appeared to be playing tug of war to see just how low prices have to go to make sales, and just how many risks are worth taking.
"Bidding was slow, so slow at times it was almost in reverse," said John L. Marion, the chairman of Sotheby's North America, at the conclusion of Tuesday's auction, where he served as auctioneer.
While both auction houses said they had put what they considered low estimates on the artworks they were selling, those estimates apparently were not always low enough. Sotheby's had estimated its sale would bring $31 million to $42 million, the Sotheby's auction totaled only $18.2 million. In comparison, last year's spring sale brought a total of $286 million, $78.1 million of which went for a single painting, "At the Moulin de la Galette" by Renoir.
Christie's Impressionist and modern sale last May totaled $268.4 million, $82.5 of which went for Van Gogh's portrait of Dr. Gachet. Last night's top lot at Christie's was Magritte's "The Mysterious Barricades," a chilling Surrealist scene that sold for $2,200,000 after a high estimate of $1,600,000, but that was one of the few works that exceeded the estimate. Another was a pen-and-ink drawing by Picasso that sold for $264,000, or $64,000 more than the high estimate.
Last night, rumors circulated that Christie's had urged consignors to lower their reserves in light of Sotheby's sale. "There was a small degree of fine-tuning," said Michael Findlay, who heads the Impressionist and modern department at Christie's. "But by and large the results reflected accurately the works offered, which has not always been true in recent years."
Clearly, times and tastes have changed. One artist whose works did badly both nights was Chagall, a favorite among Japanese buyers. At Christie's, two of the five Chagall's up for sell did not find buyers, including "The Night of Orgeval, which had the highest estimate in the sale. At Sotheby's, only one out of three Chagalls sold.
Looking at the overall picture, Sotheby's admits that it was not easy to obtain artworks for this week's sale. In addition to the climate of recession in the art market, the sale was put together at the height of the war in the Persian Gulf, when few sellers were inclined to trade actively. "We debated and debated about whether to have a sale at all," said Diana D. Brooks, president of Sotheby's North America.
Fortunately for Sotheby's, one big-name estate was available: seven important paintings and drawings, including the Matisse, which had belonged to Irene Mayer Selznick, the Broadway producer known for "A Streetcar Named Desire" who died last year at age 83. She was the daughter of the film producer Louis B. Mayer and the first wife of the producer David O. Selznick.
To secure the property, the auction house followed the now-common practice of offering a guarantee, or a promise of a minimum amount that Mrs. Selznick's heirs would receive from the sale. While the amount of the guarantee was not disclosed, the consensus among experts is that it was roughly 80 percent of the low estimate. If so, the guarantee was met, but narrowly: the total received for the Selznick property was $7.7 million, just meeting Sotheby's low estimate.
 
$1.3 Million for Seurat Study
 Besides the Matisse, another work from the Selznick estate that drew major attention was a study for Georges Seurat's "Sunday Afternoon on the Island of La Grande Jatte," which is in the Art Institute of Chicago. It sold for $1,375,000, above the $1 million high estimate.
Also offered for sale was a 1905 Matisse, "View of Collioure With Church," which made headlines several months ago when it was removed from the Museum of Modern Art and sent to Sotheby's as the result of a dispute over its ownership. The painting, which was eventually determined to have been the property of Ariana Rodina Calderone Stahmer of Pennington, N.J., a 6-year-old great-granddaughter of the photographer Edward Steichen, did not find a buyer. Nor did two paintings by Jean Dubuffet that were the property of the Pierre Matisse Gallery, whose collection Sotheby's owns in partnership with the art dealer William Acquavella.
Still, many works seemed out of place in a sale of Impressionist and modern art. Among them were the five Latin American paintings that Sotheby's decided to include rather than holding a separate Latin American auction, as it has done in the past. Of these works, only one sold.
 
A Narrower Market
 "There were a lot of lesser works, the type that would have normally been put in a day sale," said Ann Richards Nitze, an art dealer in New York and Washington. "There were also many more 20th-century pictures." Mrs. Nitze said the sale as a whole did not appeal to the Japanese market. "Japanese buyers tend to gravitate more toward pictures of beautiful women and colorful landscapes," she said.
While the Japanese have not been active buyers this spring, many were in attendance, occupying the front rows, as they often have. "The salesroom looked very much the same, with its standing-room-only, glitzy crowd," said the writer Tom Wolfe. "The adrenaline is still pumping. Maybe people are still coming because they think it's all going to collapse." Actual buyers were primarily private European and American collectors, many of them new to the market, others re-entering after years of not buying.
"It's a much narrower market than we've had in the past," said David Nash, who heads Sotheby's Impressionist department. "This season there was no support at all from the trade." The speculators who epitomized the hyperactive market of the 1980's were missing as well.
One buyer very much in evidence at Sotheby'swas a man who refused to give his name but said he was a private collector based in London. He bought steadily all evening, racking up a bill of more than $4.2 million. "The overall sale was disappointing," he said. "But for me it was an opportunity to make some good purchases. Who knows? I might be wrong. Ask me in three years."

HEADLINE: For the Disabled, Products That Help, but Have Style, Too

BYLINE: By EVE M. KAHN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: EDISON, N.J., May 5

 BODY:
Tom Mullen, a wheelchair designer, fears that neon is losing favor with the California beach crowd.
"The surfers are starting to wear shirts that say, 'No to Neon,' " said Mr. Mullen, whose employer, Quickie Designs in Fresno, Calif., builds wheelchairs with high-speed wheels and neon frames that are used for sports. "We're having trouble picking frame colors for next year, because people in wheelchairs are just like everybody else. They want the very latest." 
 Quickie was one of more than 100 companies that participated in the Abilities Expo here last weekend. The exhibit of products for the disabled attracted parents of infants with severe birth defects as well as elderly paraplegics.
"We're looking for anything that makes life a little easier for us," said Laura Reilly of Basking Ridge, N.J., who attended with her son, Erik, a college student who uses a wheelchair.
She had one complaint: the prices. Marc Friedenthal, a graduate student from Albany who uses a wheelchair, agreed. "Everything's so expensive here," he said. Adapting a home, car or workplace for infirmities may now involve highly sophisticated technology, and that costs more.
Among the most innovative and highest-priced products was the Eyegaze Computer System, which is meant for people with virtually no mobility and costs about $25,000. A lens below the computer monitor follows the user's pupil, and half-second glances at segments of the screen act as commands.
"There are 18 of our systems running now," said Nancy Cleveland, a medical and technical coordinator for the manufacturer, LC Technologies . "There's an 11-year-old kid in Florida doing his homework on one."
For less profoundly disabled people, exhibitors like the J. C. Penney Company offered clothes that are easy to put on. All the buttons on Penney's Easy Dressing Fashions are nonfunctional fronts for Velcro strips, and zippers bear oversized pull-up rings. Most items in the line are $20 to $60.
LJM Products showed a line of housewares, including thick-stemmed wine goblets that are difficult to topple ($5.50 each for glass; $14.95 for acrylic) and a plastic cutting board ($62.50) equipped with a vise that can grip bottles. LJM's heavy utilitarian designs could pass for Danish modern.
"We try for products that aren't so rehab-looking," said Linda Schweighardt, the company's president.
The expo was started 12 years ago in California by Richard C. Wooten, who was partially paralyzed by polio as a teen-ager in the 1950's. This was the expo's first venture on the East Coast, and visitors came from all over. Earl and Lisa Vaught drove up from Luray, Va., where they run a steakhouse. The Vaughts attended with their 7-year-old son, Daniel, who has a motor disorder that prevents him from walking.
"We live in a very rural, economically deprived area," said Mrs. Vaught, who watched her son tap hesitantly at a computer keyboard. "His school got a computer because of our advocacy," she said, "and I'm here to learn what it can do, because no one back home understands its potential."
Nearby, Dennis Fitzpatrick, a 5-year-old with cerebral palsy, was trying out a motorized wheelchair painted in primary colors. Adults were cruising the aisles in high-tech wheelchairs. People riding electric scooters that looked like lawnmowers with seats had to swerve to avoid others in three-wheeled exercise chairs powered by hand pedals.
Parked alongside every aisle were sleek minivans. Sales representatives rolled potential customers in wheelchairs inside, pressed buttons that folded up ramps and closed doors, and then locked the chairs into the seatless driver positions.
"I've never seen anything like this," said Inez Allen, principal of Public School 134 in the Hollis section of Queens. Her wheelchair was ensconced in a van manufactured by Independent Mobility Systems , and she was toying with the hand controls. "This would be so much better than my Toyota," she said. "I could get in and out myself."
The salesman told her the vehicle cost $32,000; she frowned and said she doubted she could afford it. "I really came looking for a scooter," she said.
Mark Malone, a financial analyst from South Bound Brook, N.J., came to the expo in search of ideas. Paralyzed eight years ago in a swimming accident, he wore a T-shirt that read, "I'm Not Paralyzed I'm Just Lazy."
"I'm checking out reactions to the shirt, to see if I should sell ones like it, maybe at the next expo," he said. "And I'm seeing what products are out there, what I could use. I've got a big family, and if I see something I like, maybe a relative could make it for me."

HEADLINE: HORSE RACING;
Withers Stakes Won By Subordinated Debt

BYLINE: By JOSEPH DURSO

 BODY:
Belmont Park rang up the curtain on 66 days of racing yesterday with the 116th running of the Withers Stakes and a rousing victory for Subordinated Debt, a 7-to-1 outsider who outran Scan, Kyle's Our Man and half a dozen other colts with varying designs on the Preakness and other 3-year-old classics.
The performance was an upset in more ways than one. Subordinated Debt had a bleeding problem only two months ago plus a three-race losing streak of convincing proportions. But he still ran a dashing race, outdueled the well-connected Scan in the final sixteenth, won by three-quarters of a length. 
 At the finish, with Julie Krone prompting him home, the 3-year-old bay gelding had the best of Scan, the even-money favorite, who in turn had eight lengths on Kyle's Our Man, next in the betting at 5 to 2. And farther up the track in fifth place came Wayne Lukas's Dodge, another failing candidate for Triple Crown action, who had gone off as third choice at 9 to 2.
Not only that, but Subordinated Debt toted his 126 pounds over a fast track in very fast time, indeed: He went the first three-quarters of a mile in 1:09 3/5 and completed the mile in 1:34, which was one-fifth of a second (or one length) slower than Dr. Fager's stakes record of 1967 and only one second slower than Conquistador Cielo's 1982 track record for the mile.
David Monaci, who trains Subordinated Debt for Leslie R. Grimm, immediately said that his horse had opened several doors, including the Preakness. And this was a horse who had run third (and bled) in the Fountain of Youth Stakes in February, run 11th in the Jim Beam in March and sixth in the Arkansas Derby in April.
"I was a little discouraged because of those last two races," Monaci said. "You try to get them ready and then they fall apart. He even had a little virus. But he's fine now. I want to run him in one more race before the Belmont Stakes, probably either the Jersey Derby, the Preakness or the Peter Pan. It depends on how he comes back."
 
Running Out of Candidates
 Scotty Schulhofer, who once was training three prime Kentucky Derby contenders, conceded that he had run out of candidates. Cahill Road suffered a leg injury while winning the Wood Memorial, and will be retired. Fly So Free ran fifth in the Derby, and will skip the Preakness. And now Scan, a three-time winner at Belmont last fall, ran second in the Withers.
"He just got beat," Schulhofer said.
The Preakness? "Never even thought about it," he replied.
But John Veitch, who trains Kyle's Our Man for Daniel Galbreath, said that the Preakness was still a possibility despite the fact that the colt ran third on the same track where he had won the Gotham a month ago.
"It's disappointing," Veitch said. "He may go to the Peter Pan, it's right here at Belmont. The Preakness is still a possibility. But we'll have to let Mr. Galbreath make that decision."
 
FINISH LINE
 The sun was shining and the temperature was climbing, but only 11,549 persons attended the opening of Belmont after four months of New York racing at Aqueduct. The horses will stay at Belmont for 66 days until July 22, when the action moves upstate to Saratoga for five weeks.
Aqueduct reported some losing numbers, too: The daily average attendance over the 107 days dropped 11 percent to 9,117. The betting handle also dropped 11 percent to $260 million.
"Our business," said Gerard J. McKeon, president of the New York Racing Association, "is a reflection of what's going on across the country and in particular in the Northeast, which is that there is a recession."

HEADLINE: In New York's Crisis: Opportunity

 BODY:
New York City will cobble together a solution to its immediate fiscal crisis; it has little choice. By law, it must balance its budget and will do so with a hotly debated assortment of tax increases and harsh service cuts. But unless the city's leaders use this emergency to pursue fundamental reforms, nothing will change.
The city will remain adrift, at the mercy of the economic tides. New Yorkers, now facing such pain that a solemn Mayor David Dinkins felt compelled to deliver a televised pep talk last night, will suffer even more of it the next time the economy sours. 
 There is an alternative. Under the discipline of crisis, City Hall and the state can make dramatic changes in government. Mr. Dinkins has begun downsizing his administration, to his credit, but there are more far-reaching ways to provide better services with fewer employees and less money. There are no surprises or municipal magic bullets. But a number of responsible reforms could make a powerful difference. They will be hard to achieve. As the Mayor noted last night, however, New Yorkers "are the participants who must shape the solutions."
Shift the local share of Medicaid and welfare costs to the state. New York City would save close to $3 billion a year if New York State took over these costs, shifting the burden of caring for the poor to a broader tax base. Ideally, these health and social services should be a Federal obligation, but there's little chance that Washington will soon accept that burden. A state takeover is the next-best solution.
Reform civil service rules so the city can consider merit when it must lay off workers. The city must now consider only seniority. This change would allow retaining the most motivated -- and productive -- employees.
Use more one-officer police cars. The N.Y.P.D. is alone among the largest police forces in permitting only two-officer cars to respond to 911 calls. Using solo cars in low-crime neighborhoods would free officers for community patrol and could save some hiring costs for the Mayor's anti-crime plan.
Negotiate new rules for trash collection. Sanitation workers are paid for eight-hour workdays but more than half put in four hours or less because of a 1981 agreement made to win union acceptance of two-man crews. The agreement made sense then, but needs modifying now. Just one more hour of work would save $7 million.
Restructure health and welfare plans. These can be designed to provide better benefits for municipal workers at less than the current annual cost of $1.25 billion.
Reform the pension laws. Police officers and firefighters can retire on half pay after 20 years. That's a holdover from the days when age 40 was considered over the hill. There's another expensive provision: a police officer who develops a heart problem, or a firefighter who develops a heart or lung problem, can retire immediately on three-quarter pay because the law presumes that the disability was job-related. Former Mayor Edward Koch failed when he tried to get Albany to modify the "heart bill." Another try is long overdue.
Charge tuition at the City University based on ability to pay. That's a much fairer way to support the university system than the present approach, imposing tuition increases across the board.
Those are some of the more obvious reforms. The city needs cuts and taxes of the kind the Mayor described last night; there's no avoiding the loss of billions in municipal income. But New York can do more than bite the bullet; courageous reforms made under the gun of the crisis can save many billions more, permanently.

HEADLINE: Essay;
Landsbergis for Nobel Laureate

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Through an area under curfew where 66 were arrested the night before; past boarded-up shops, recently looted, with shards of glass cluttering the sidewalk; into the very eye of defiance of authority I made my perilous way to breakfast with Vytautas Landsbergis, President of the Republic of Lithuania.
This was in Washington, D.C., of course, capital of the most stable Government in the world. Did President Landsbergis, who made his stand against Mikhail Gorbachev's black-bereted goons in Vilnius four months ago, feel at home? 
 "Certain similarities exist," he allowed, "but I feel at home in a different sense." Later, he said: "This is the home of freedom. Everybody seeking freedom looks to the U.S."
This modest patriot offers no bombast, no heroic poses; he believes the Baltics are of right independent and ought to be treated that way.
"But the Western democracies speak over our shoulders to the face behind us," he says. "They don't look us in the eye."
Yesterday, in a significant symbolic act, President Bush looked the Balts in the eye, greeting the leaders of Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania in the Oval Office.
No longer do we cling to the passive posture of not accepting the Hitler-Stalin conquest. We are step-by-stepping toward outright recognition of the captive states, which infuriates the leftover imperialists in Moscow.
In helping to move Baltic independence from de jure to de facto, Mr. Bush is executing the classic "pushmipullyu maneuver." This involves talking out of heads at both ends of the mythical animal.
Thus from the front head he loudly lauds the "enormous" accomplishments of Mr. Gorbachev, and flashes the signal that $1.5 billion of U.S. taxpayers' money is soon to go down the Soviet command-economy drain to appease the old apparatchiks.
Meanwhile, the back head of Mr. Bush is planning to name Robert Gates (who Mr. Gorbachev thinks is out to get him) as Director of Central Intelligence. That back head also poses for a picture with the Baltic leaders, which helps weaken Moscow's grip on three captive nations.
As further evidence of his back head's iron resolve, Mr. Bush will send Curtis Kamman, a Deputy Assistant Secretary of State (whose protocol seat at a diplomatic dinner is deep in the butlers' pantry) to the Baltic capitals to show the U.S. flag.
Is pushmipullyu diplomacy -- dazzlingly acting against our words -- the best way to achieve our ends? Oval officers love it because historians damnably praise feints. Sometimes two-facedness works, but most of the time it confuses everybody by muddying our purpose.
President Landsbergis, with independence his fixed goal, would prefer us to use our credit guarantees to encourage companies to invest in his country, and to establish a Baltic development bank. Richard Nixon, returning from his Soviet tour, agreed: we should be helping the reforming hands in the republics, not pressing credits into the dead hand of the Gorbocracy.
But the trio of Baltic leaders in the White House yesterday did not presume to advise against our giving billions in baksheesh to a Soviet central Government bankrupted by arms spending; they were grateful for the photo op and eager to develop connective tissue. The steady accretion of foreign recognition is their bloodless road to independence.
Moving beyond symbolism, we should warn the Kremlin that any economic punishment of the Baltics would trigger our counter-coercion. We should also lean on the Soviets to accept the Balts as observers at C.S.C.E. meetings this summer. (Last year the U.S. supinely allowed the Soviets to lock out the Balts.) And next March, at Helsinki II, we should link our attendance to their full participation as European nations.
Momentum is all. Norway's Nobel committee, to make up for its abysmal judgment of the recent past, should restore the luster of the Peace Prize this October by awarding it to Vytautas Landsbergis, symbol of Baltic independence.
That long-overdue return to self-determination by three little nations has always been the key to the relaxation of Soviet internal imperial rule. Keep the heat on; free the Baltics, change the world.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: For Floyd Bennett Field Past Should Be Future

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Contrary to your April 6 article on Floyd Bennett Field in Brooklyn, the abandoned air facility may not need a private developer to make a park of it. In my view, Floyd Bennett should be re-established as an airfield, preferably one that is physically linked to Kennedy International Airport to create a superregional airport. 
 The proximity of Floyd Bennett to Kennedy (five miles) means that they could be connected by a passenger monorail over Jamaica Bay. Floyd Bennett's runways can be used or expanded slightly to accommodate the same kind of aircraft that now use La Guardia, whose runways and land area cannot readily be expanded. The Gateway Park setting could be preserved as part of the overall project. This plan would use Government-owned land, create jobs and help revitalize our local economy, ease traffic congestion on the highways leading to Kennedy, ease air traffic congestion at La Guardia and Kennedy, and promote air traffic safety.
New York City should do everything in its power to restore Floyd Bennett to what it once was: a thriving airfield.
 
STEPHEN I. SILLER
New York, April 25, 1991

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Qualex Chief's Strategy To Beat Photo 'Minilabs'

 BODY:
Although customers of photofinishing labs operated by Qualex Inc. usually wait 24 to 48 hours to get their photos, the company's new president is relatively unconcerned about the proliferation of laboratories that can process film in under an hour.
Peter D. Fitzgerald, who was named Qualex's president and chief executive yesterday, said the company had a strategy that can beat the one-hour laboratories, or "minilabs," at their own game. 
 "We will put our own 'microlab' into a retailer's store at no cost to the retailer," Mr. Fitzgerald said. "They can have 30-minute processing, and the lab takes only one-third of the space of the standard minilab."
Unlike the minilabs, which use on-site machinery, Qualex had used only centralized processing. The company picks up film at an affiliated retail outlet, sends it to one of its 53 laboratories and then returns the finished pictures to the retailer.
The centralized labs are usually cheaper than minilabs. Centralized processing companies also offer a broader range of enlargement and processing services.
Mr. Fitzgerald said Qualex, based in Durham, N.C., controlled about a third of the photofinishing market. "The minilabs have about 25 percent of the market and other laboratories have 75 percent," he said. Qualex, he added, controls nearly half of the centralized laboratory market.
The company was formed in March 1988 from a merger of photofinishing operations owned by the Atlanta-based Fuqua Industries, which owns 51 percent stake in Qualex, and photofinishing operations owned by the Eastman-Kodak Company, which holds a 49 percent share of Qualex.
Mr. Fitzgerald said the company expected to place about 300 of its microlabs into drugstores and grocery stores before the end of the year. Nevertheless, sales should be flat to down. "Volume will be flat this year. And prices are under a little bit of pressure," he said.
Curt Rohrman, an analyst with the First Boston Corporation, said: "We're in a recession, and that is going to affect travel. Anything that affects travel is going to affect photo taking."
Nevertheless, he said, Qualex should not be under increasing pressure from the minilabs. "The minilabs have proliferated to most of the retail outlets where they are likely to go," Mr. Rohrman said. "I don't see much increased growth for them."

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Why Some See A Longer Slump

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
IS the recession bottoming out?
The latest survey by Blue Chip Economic Indicators, to be released today, reports that the consensus forecast of the 50 economists polled is that real gross national product, after dropping at annual rates of 1.6 percent and 2.8 percent in the last two quarters, is flattening and will rise slightly -- by six-tenths of 1 percent -- in the current April-June quarter. And a new survey of 500 bank examiners and bank liquidators indicates that the housing slump is ending. 
 Yet, some economists at major banks and industrial corporations contend that the recession is not only still here but is even widening. Joseph G. Carson, the Chemical Bank's chief economist, told the bank's international advisory board earlier this week: "In my opinion, rather than ending, there are more signs that the recession is broadening domestically, encompassing not only the consumer sector but also capital spending and Government spending." Globally," he added, "recessions continue in Canada and the United Kingdom, and early signs of recession are now present in continental Europe."
Mr. Carson's major concern about the American economy is that as a result of the debt buildup of the 1980's and the big rise in interest costs to a record level of 30 percent of cash flow, many concerns have been starved for cash and, even before the recession began last July, had been suffering "profitless prosperity."
Hungry for cash, they have resorted to selling goods at distress prices, liquidating inventories, cutting capital spending and laying off workers and managers. And Mr. Carson sees more adjustments ahead, as profit margins continue to shrink, manufacturers' inventories remain high and, in some retail sectors, order backlogs continue to decline. Also, he said, "export orders may remain soft for several more months."
Mr. Carson also reported on the views of other business economists at last week's meeting in Washington of the technical advisers to the Business Council. "Without exception," he said, there had been a "significant swing" toward pessimism since the economists' mid-February meeting. Auto industry representatives said business was "very soft" with no "signs of a pickup in sales." There were also pessimistic assessments by representatives of the capital goods sector, chemicals, textiles, primary metals and consumer durables.
Yet, Mr. Carson reported, "industry representatives continue to expect a second-half recovery." He suggested that these representatives were guilty of "calendar analysis," based on the belief that because recessions historically have lasted about one year, this one should be over by midyear. But he held that individual recessions vary widely in duration and do not expire because of old age. Rather, he said, they end as business makes its financial adjustments and Government monetary and fiscal policies kick in to lift the economy out of recession.
"How much worse the recession gets," Mr. Carson said, "will depend on the pace at which we can unwind the financial imbalances which triggered this recession and, importantly, the monetary and fiscal policy responses which follow." Those responses up to this point, he argued, have been "at best neutral."
Last fall's budget agreement between the Administration and Congress raised personal taxes by more than $25 billion for 1991, and 26 states increased taxes by $10.3 billion. The Fed has been moving to bring down interest rates, including last week's half-point cut in the discount rate, to 5 1/2 percent, and a quarter-point cut in the target for the Federal funds rate, to 5 3/4 percent. But Mr. Carson held that real corporate borrowing costs had not come down enough.
His conclusion was that the recession would last another five to six months -- but that during that period the roots of recovery, in the form of lower interest rates, would be taking shape, "setting the stage for a solid recovery in 1992 and beyond." Before the recession is over, he is looking for at least one more cut in the discount rate, to 5 percent, and a Federal funds rate of about 5 1/4 percent. He is far from alone in his view that Fed policy should ease further. Richard A. Debs, advisory director of Morgan Stanley International, and a former official of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, said the Fed "has leeway now to go further."
And David D. Hale, chief economist of Kemper Financial Services Inc., said that while the economy might be stabilizing, the recovery was likely to be so modest as to have no impact on unemployment or industry's rate of using capacity. "The critical issue," he said, "is the economy's growth rate vis-a-vis the potential growth rate of new supply and the slack created by the recession."
If the second-half recovery is too weak, it will still feel like recession, especially to the jobless, the cash-short and debt-laden consumers and businesses threatened with falling profits or bankruptcy. And there will be a danger of a lurch into a secondary recession in 1992 or '93 -- like the double-dip recession of 1979-80 and 1981-82. A stronger Fed push is still needed.

GRAPHIC: Drawing

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Santa Anita Sees Odds in Its Favor

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
CLIFFORD C. GOODRICH says his business drew fewer customers this year than last, and he thinks the number will fall off dramatically next year. And those facts are positive, he says.
Mr. Goodrich runs the annual horse racing meet at Santa Anita, the race track in Arcadia, near Los Angeles. In California, the major horse racing tracks are owned by investors. Santa Anita, like its crosstown competitor, Hollywood Park, and Northern California's Bay Meadows, is publicly traded. 
 As Santa Anita sees it, the general decline in horse racing is likely to result in a shakeout in which the strong do better, and Mr. Goodrich thinks that Santa Anita will make the cut. And, he adds, with fewer people attending the races, some parking lots can be closed and developed for other uses.
While spring is the annual highlight of the racing calendar, as the Triple Crown races draw attention from sports fans who otherwise ignore horse racing, this spring has been a glum one. Attendance and betting are down.
"Racing used to be recession-proof and inflation-proof," Mr. Goodrich said in an interview.
In this year's meet at Santa Anita, which began on Dec. 26 and ended on April 22, there was a 4.5 percent decline in attendance, and, perhaps more significant, a 7 percent drop in the amount wagered.
Santa Anita's problems are not unique. At New York's Aqueduct, whose racing season ended this week, betting handle and attendance were each down 11 percent.
Horse racing in California has not been the same since 1985, when that state's lottery began. Suddenly, there was an easier legal way to gamble than going out to the track. But the tracks have fought back, obtaining passage of laws that allow gamblers to bet at their local track on races at other Southern California tracks, as well as allowing some bettors outside the state to bet on California racing.
Revenue from those gamblers is expected to push up Santa Anita's revenue this year, despite the drop in attendance, and to do the same next year even though Mr. Goodrich, the president and chief operating officer of the Los Angeles Turf Club, expects a further decline in attendance, perhaps as much as 25 percent, as more satellite wagering sites go into operation.
But for investors in Santa Anita, horses are not the only story. And it was real estate, the other part of the story, that caused a big fall last year in the value of shares in the two Santa Anita companies, which trade in a pair. A stock buyer gets shares in two companies: the operating one that owns the Los Angeles Turf Club, which runs the races, and the real estate investment trust, which owns the track and a lot of other property.
The stock price fell from a 1989 high of $35 to a low last fall of $19.375. In this year's market revival, the shares have climbed back to $25.75, despite a drop of 37.5 cents in New York Stock Exchange trading yesterday.
"Everybody was so down on real estate investment trusts," Mr. Goodrich said. "We just got swallowed up in the real estate depression." He argues that that pessimism was unwarranted.
The most important real estate assets are two big shopping centers in which Santa Anita has large interests. The first is adjacent to the track. It plans to expand by adding two more major tenants, and the second is a shopping center, Towson Town Center, near Baltimore, where expansion will be completed later this year and a Nordstrom's is scheduled to open next year.
The dual-share arrangement provides some unusual tax benefits. The profits of the operating company end up being paid as rent to the real estate trust, which passes them, along with income from other properties, through to investors in the form of dividends. The law requires the real estate trust to pay at least 95 percent of its net income to shareholders each year, but in fact it pays out much more than that as it passes along available cash flow as well.
As a result, Santa Anita shareholders got $2.08 a share in dividends last year, although the company only reported earnings of $1.41 a share, down from $1.61 the previous year. The good news for holders is that they must pay tax only on the part of the payout that represents earnings. The rest qualifies as a return of capital, and taxes on that payout are deferred until the shares are sold.
In the first three months of this year, net earnings were down slightly from the year before, with the per-share figure dipping to 61 cents from 63 cents. The company paid 52 cents in dividends.
As a result, the shares now have a dividend yield of 8.1 percent, which makes the shares sound cheap, but a price-earnings ratio of 18.5, which does not.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends Mixed in U.S.; Gold Up After Dip in London

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar ended mixed in quiet domestic dealings yesterday after posting narrow gains overseas.
Gold prices were also mixed. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $358.10 an ounce, up $1. The Republic National Bank later said that gold gained 60 cents an ounce, to $357.60. Gold fell in London to a late bid price of $356.95 an ounce, from $357.25 bid late on Wednesday. 
 Markets in Zurich were closed for a holiday. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold rose 65 cents to close at $358.20.
The dollar got an initial lift from a better-than-expected report from the Labor Department showing initial claims for unemployment insurance fell by 45,000, to 455,000, in the week that ended on April 27. That was down from a peak of 543,000 a month earlier and could be interpreted as an indication the economic recovery might be under way.
But the dollar reversed course on technical factors. Michael Malpede, a senior analyst at the Refco Group Ltd. in Chicago, said traders were squaring their positions before today's report on producer prices for April.
Marc Chandler, an analyst with the financial advisory firm IDEA, said that bidding for the Treasury's $11.75 billion in 30-year bonds in the Government's quarterly refunding auction was inefficient and that demand was "somewhat reluctant." Many traders had expected strong foreign appetite for the bonds, which would have helped the dollar.
Over all, "the dollar remained confined to ranges as the market awaits fresh trading incentives," he said.
Analysts noted that national holidays closed markets throughout most of continental Europe, which kept trading subdued worldwide.
In Tokyo, the dollar rose to close at 138.23 Japanese yen, from 137.88 yen on Wednesday. Later in London, it rose to 139.35 yen. In New York, the dollar settled at 138.10 yen, down from 138.30 yen on Wednesday.
In London, the pound fell to $1.7045, from $1.7180 late on Wednesday. In New York, it cost $1.7175 to buy a pound, less expensive than Wednesday's $1.7200.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with those of late on Wednesday, included: 1.7325 German marks, up from 1.7312; 1.4629 Swiss francs, down from 1.4630; 5.8585 French francs, unchanged; 1,280.25 Italian lire, down from 1,281.25, and 1.5326 Canadian dollars, up from 1.5225.
In Europe, other late dollar rates included: 1.7425 German marks, up from 1.7330; 1.4730 Swiss francs, up from 1.4655; 5.8925 French francs, up from 5.8650; 1.9635 Dutch guilders, up from 1.9523; 1,288.75 Italian lire, up from 1.282.50, and 1.1529 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1519.

HEADLINE: Council Speaker Vows to Avert Steep Cuts by Dinkins

BYLINE: By JOSH BARBANEL

 BODY:
A day after Mayor David N. Dinkins warned New Yorkers to show courage in the face of devastating cuts in city services, the Speaker of the City Council vowed yesterday to head off the worst of the reductions.
In doing so, the Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, appeared to undermine the Mayor's public-relations strategy -- if not his actual fiscal plans -- in which a horror list of service cuts was to be used to wrest crucial concessions from municipal unions and close a huge gap in the city's budget. 
 "The time for games is over," Mr. Vallone said. "It is time to balance the budget."
In an emotional televised address Wednesday evening, Mr. Dinkins presented a somber scenario of service reductions -- from shutting off a quarter of all street lights in the city to closing the Central Park Zoo and a suspension of the city's recycling program.
 
Cool to Concessions
 Mr. Vallone's move raised the possibility that the initiative may be slipping from the Mayor's control, even after he spent much of the last week trying to marshal support from Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, labor leaders and the public in a carefully orchestrated series of meetings and presentations culminating in his televised address. Labor leaders, although praising his speech, have remained cool to any concessions.
Yesterday, Mr. Vallone, in a brief interview a day before the Mayor is to present his budget to the Council, said he was committed to keeping the zoo open and maintaining the operation of all street lights and was seeking to maintain the Council's commitment to continue recycling.
"The zoo is back in," Mr. Vallone declared. Asked about the turning off of street lights, he added, "We are not going to close down portions of the city that we consider essential."
Mayor Dinkins did not respond directly to Mr. Vallone's remarks yesterday. But at a City Hall news conference the Mayor lost his composure, for the second time yesterday, after quoting Mr. Vallone as quoting Fiorello H. La Guardia to the effect that budgets are "conceived in despair and developed in agony." His voice halting, with tears welling in his eyes, Mr. Dinkins told how hard it was to sit across from a city commissioner "telling you about the safety net and how frayed the safety net is."
"So people who think that this is some process that one engages in as an exercise really don't understand," he said. "Not if you care. This administration cares deeply."
The Mayor also appeared to lose his composure in a similar fashion as he defended his service cuts at a meeting at City Hall with representatives of private social-service agencies.
 
Within Its Rights
 First Deputy Mayor Norman Steisel said the Council was within its rights to to restore programs as long as it came up with the money to pay for them. He said he hoped the Council would also come up with funds to restore infant-mortality programs threatened with cuts by the Mayor.
Mr. Dinkins is to present his executive budget today, giving the first detailed account of how he would find $3.4 billion to close a gap in a $29 billion budget for the fiscal year that begins on July 1. His plans include about $1 billion in new taxes, $1.5 billion in service cuts, productivity improvements and increased state aid.
As a preview to this main event, Mr. Dinkins presented a 10-year capital plan, which seeks to reduce city construction plans by $500 million next year, or about 12 percent, and a total of $2.9 billion in cuts over a five-year period as part of city economy moves.
The new plan slashed spending below previous plans, cutting spending by the Parks Department by more than 50 percent over four years. Nevertheless, the plans showed the city planned to spend $4.8 billion on construction next year, the largest construction budget in the city's history.
 
Some Flowery Praise
 Only a day before, in his televised pleas for unity and help, Mr. Dinkins reached out to Mr. Vallone, offering him a bouquet of flowery praise, albeit one wrapped in a suggestion that the Speaker might be beholden to "special interests."
"Our City Council," Mr. Dinkins said, "led by an extraordinary public servant, Speaker Peter Vallone, must act as true representatives of the people, moving beyond any special interests to enact our property tax increase."
The Mayor's tone reflects the distant relation between the Mayor and the Speaker, who have been at odds over the City Council's redistricting plans and who rarely meet to discuss the city's finances or other issues.
Months ago, Mr. Vallone rejected more than half of the nearly $800 million in property tax increases called for by the Mayor, and presented the outline of an alternative plan to cut as many as 30,000 jobs from the city payroll over the next few years.
Administration officials said Mr. Vallone would be under pressure to give up his rejection of the full $1 billion in tax increases as the budget process unfolds, especially since union leaders have conditioned their concessions on the willingness of others to share the pain.
But with the city seeking to put together a credible financial plan before the city returns to the bond market in a matter of weeks, the Mayor will be under pressure to make concessions as well, long before the June 30 deadline for adoption of the budget.
 
Expanding City Jails
 Mr. Dinkins's 10-year capital plan called for deep cuts in spending in some agencies, which were in part offset by sharp increases in others, particularly on expanding city jails and replacing a detention center for youth.
Proposals within the administration to make steep cuts in Mr. Dinkins's housing program were rejected by the Mayor, who restored $247 million in funds for housing development over the next four years. The city now plans to spend $400 million a year on housing, officials said.
The administration also cut $976 million from a $4 billion plan to rebuild many city schools, prompting Board of Education officials to question whether the cuts violated the terms of a state law that set up a School Contruction Authority several months ago.
