HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Long Bond Yield Averages 8.21%

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
The Treasury struggled to complete the final leg of a record $37 billion set of auctions yesterday, as an $11.75 billion auction of new 30-year bonds attracted the smallest amount of bids since early 1977, when the United States began to sell such securities on a regular basis.
Because of their maturity, 30-year bonds are the most speculative security issued by the Government. As the size of outstanding issues has increased over the years, 30-year Treasury bonds have become the financial world's most favored vehicle for placing a bet on the direction of interest rates. 
 The bonds auctioned yesterday were sold at an average yield of 8.21 percent, up from the 7.98 percent average yield produced at the last 30-year bond sale on Feb. 7.
The yield was largely in line with expectations, but analysts nevertheless said the results of the auction were very poor.
The fact that only $17.3 billion worth of bids was placed for the securities was a big reason for that assessment. In relation to the $11.75 billion worth that was sold, it was the lowest amount of bids received since February 1977, the Treasury said.
In addition, the difference, or spread, between high bids and the average bid was 3 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, an unusually large amount. The large size of the "tail" indicated that dealers were far from unanimous in estimating the value of the securities.
 
Secondary Trades
 On other days, such results would have sent the secondary market for Treasury securities into a tailspin. That did not occur yesterday, however, as prices of outstanding notes and bonds actually moved slightly higher.
"The bond auction was far worse than expected, yet the results had no impact on secondary trading," said William V. Sullivan Jr., a senior vice president at Dean Witter Reynolds. "That suggests the distribution of the securities was far better than most expected."
By late in the day, the new bonds were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 8.20 percent.
As on Wednesday, when the Treasury auctioned new 10-year notes, rumors of a strong bid from Japanese firms for the new bonds circulated yesterday.
"The Japanese bid for a good 30 percent of the bonds," said John P. Costas, a managing director in the taxable fixed-income department at the First Boston Corporation. "It's the highest level of participation we have seen from them in the last couple of years."
An executive at one of the four large Japanese investment banks, who asked not to be identified, estimated the big-four firms actually purchased about 20 percent of the issue, or around $2.45 billion worth of bonds.
In searching for an explanation on why bond prices did not tumble after the release of the auction results, analysts and traders said market participants are expecting a good report from the Government today on inflation. Most analysts are estimating that the Producer Price Index, scheduled to be released this morning, was unchanged in April and up a modest two-tenths of a percent excluding food and energy.
Bond investors loathe any hint that inflationary pressures are intensifying because rising prices erode the inflation-adjusted value of their fixed-income investment.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the outstanding benchmark issue, the 7 7/8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021, were offered at a price of 96 7/32 late yesterday, up 2/32, to yield 8.21 percent, down from 8.22 percent late on Wednesday.
Among note issues, the 7 5/8 percent five-year notes were offered at 99 7/8, up 1/32, to yield 7.65 percent. And the 7 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 11/32, unchanged on the day, to yield 6.80 percent.
Prices of securities sold earlier in the week by the Treasury also inched higher.
The 8 percent 10-year notes sold on Wednesday were offered on a when-issued basis at a price of 99 31/32, up 5/32, to yield 8 percent. And the three-year notes sold on Tuesday were offered at a price of 99 3/4, up 1/32, to yield 7.09 percent.
 
Bill Rates Slip
 Short-term Treasury bill rates dipped slightly.
By late in the day, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 5.46 percent, down 1 basis point. Six-month bill rates fell by 4 basis points, to a late offered rate of 5.58 percent.
In deference to the Treasury, corporate and tax-exempt issuers chose not to offer new debt securities yesterday.
In the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds, traders said prices of most issues were unchanged in quiet trading.
In the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds, prices of the most widely quoted issues rose 1/8 to 1/4, according to market participants.
 
New York City Issues
 An address on Wednesday evening by Mayor David N. Dinkins on the fiscal crisis confronting New York City had little impact on prices of New York City securities yesterday. Traders said prices of most New York City bonds were unchanged in light trading.
In other developments, the Federal Reserve reported yesterday that all three measures of the nation's money supply fell during the week ended April 29. The money numbers were largely in line with expectations, and had little impact on prices in the credit markets.

HEADLINE: AFTER THE WAR;
BAGHDAD REJECTS U.N. POLICE FORCE TO PROTECT KURDS

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 9

 BODY:
Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar of the United Nations told President Bush today that Baghdad had turned down an American-supported proposal for a United Nations police force in northern Iraq, raising the possibility that American troops might have to stay there far longer than the Administration had hoped.
Mr. Perez de Cuellar was said by his associates and by American officials to be unwilling to send a United Nations force in the face of Iraqi opposition, unless the Security Council authorized it, which at the moment seems unlikely.
 
No Lifting of Sanctions
 So it appears that President Saddam Hussein of Iraq -- defeated in battle, faced with awesome economic and social problems, struggling to hold his country together -- has found a way to frustrate the United States, at least for the moment. 
 But by blocking a United Nations force, Mr. Hussein in effect invites a continuing occupation of part of his country by American and other allied forces. Moreover, until the Kurdish problem is resolved satisfactorily to Americans, the United States has said it would not agree to relaxation of the economic sanctions against Iraq.
Administration officials conceded that Baghdad's action probably means a considerable delay in United States withdrawal from the area. Although the last American troops left southern Iraq on Wednesday, those in the north cannot depart until some other sizable force arrives to screen the new Kurdish refugee camps in the region.
 
'The Q Word' Is Heard
 Last week, important policy makers began to apply what they called "the Q word," meaning quagmire, to the problem developing in the area along Iraq's border with Turkey. Today, they said Mr. Perez de Cuellar's report, which was delivered to the President at a White House meeting, represented a major setback to American policy.
Mr. Bush promised last month, when he announced that the United States would aid the Kurds, that American troops would pull back quickly, handing over the camps to United Nations administration. But that plan raised the question of who would make the camps at least symbolically secure enough from possible Iraqi attack to persuade large numbers of Kurds to leave their mountain refuges. And that led to the idea of a United Nations police force.
In company with France and Britain, the United States has insisted the international organization could set up a police force in the area -- a less heavily armed force than the peacekeeping force authorized by the United Nations in southern Iraq -- without the passage of a new resolution. But Mr. Perez de Cuellar, aides said, was worried about bypassing the Security Council.
The three nations hoped, according to Western diplomats, that Iraq would not object to the police force if not specifically asked to approve of it.
 
'A Very Clear Rejection'
 But Mr. Perez de Cuellar sent an envoy to Baghdad, where he got the thumbs-down from the Iraqi Government. "Today I have received a very clear rejection from the Iraqi Government," the Secretary General said at the White House. "They do not want a United Nations police force."
John Bolton, the United States Assistant Secretary of State for International Organizations, confirmed that Mr. Perez de Cuellar was still pressing for another resolution. The problem with that is that either the Soviet Union or China or both are likely to block a Security Council authorization because they are reluctant to set precedents for interfering in the internal affairs of other countries, such as that between the Kurds and the Baghdad Government.
 
'Limited in Duration'
 Mr. Bush has been emphasizing for weeks that he would do everything possible to avoid getting bogged down in northern Iraq, with American troops stuck there because no replacements were available. At a news conference on Wednesday, he said again that he opposed any permanent commitment. And today he said that the United States still viewed its role in protecting the Kurdish refugees "as limited in duration."
"I think that is the wish of our American friends as well as the United Nations," Mr. Perez de Cuellar said, to which Mr. Bush responded, "That's for sure." But then the United Nations official took up again the line that has the White House and the State Department seething with irritation.
"I think we have to be patient," he said.
 
'Sanctions Will Remain in Place'
 According to White House aides, Mr. Bush pressed Mr. Perez de Cuellar again today to move faster, as he had done in a telephone call more than two weeks ago.
Richard Haass, Mr. Bush's special adviser on Near Eastern matters, reiterated today the Administration's determination to continue to penalize Iraq until President Hussein is replaced, even though the United Nations resolution setting the terms for ending the war, which was passed April 3, makes no demand for his departure in exchange for relaxing sanctions.
"In our view, Saddam is discredited," Mr. Haass told a group of correspondents. "As a result all possible sanctions will remain in place until he is gone. Iraqis will not participate in the region's post-crisis political, economic and security arrangements until there is a a change in regime."
Eventually, the United States wants private relief agencies and the United Nations to care for the Kurds who have been uprooted by the failed rebellion that followed the Persian Gulf war. But that cannot be done, everyone agrees, until the Kurds' fear of the central government has been overcome, and that may take considerable time.
"The goal is not simply to create a series of camps along the Iraqi border with Turkey and Iran," a senior Administration official said. "The goal is to get the Kurds to return to their place of permanent residence in safety, so the camps are envisioned as a very temporary thing."

HEADLINE: New Claims by Unemployed Fell Sharply in Late April

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 9

 BODY:
The number of Americans filing new claims for unemployment benefits declined significantly at the end of April, the Government reported today. Analysts saw the drop as a possible sign that the worst of the recession was over.
"It's confirmation of the belief that the end of the recession is not too far away," said Irwin Kellner, chief economist at Manufacturers Hanover Trust. 
 "This is further evidence that the labor markets are improving," said Michael K. Evans, a Washington economist and consultant. "It's another straw in the wind to support the view that the recession is over."
 
45,000 Fewer Claims
 The Labor Department said that for the week ended April 27, the number of people filing unemployment claims for the first time fell by 45,000 from the previous week, to 455,000.
The news followed a report last week showing the unemployment rate fell in April for the first improvement in nearly a year. The nation's unemployment rate dropped to 6.6 percent last month, down from March's rate of 6.8 percent.
Some analysts dismissed April's unemployment report as a statistical fluke, but others said it might mean that the nation's economy, mired in recession since July, was bottoming out.
The jobless claims report can be extremely volatile from week to week, but Mr. Evans noted that the four-week average of jobless claims, which many analysts consider a more reliable measure, had also fallen.
For the four weeks ended April 27, the average for weekly jobless claims filings was 476,000, Mr. Evans said, down from the 511,000 average for the similar four-week period in March.
Although the number of people filing for unemployment assistance fell in the last week of April, it was still far above the level for last year. In the similar week of 1990, there were 361,000 new jobless claims, the Labor Department said.
Samuel Kahan, an economist at Fuji Securities, cautioned against making too much of the jobless claims report. He noted that analysts were cheered by back-to-back declines in jobless claims in mid-March, only to see those claims jump by 47,000 a week later.

HEADLINE: New York's Government: Is It Too Big?

BYLINE: By SARAH BARTLETT

 BODY:
As New York City officials struggle to cope with a tide of red ink by turning off street lights and shutting down drug-treatment programs, many are asking a more fundamental question: has the local government simply grown too big for its own good?
Across the political spectrum, business executives, labor leaders and politicians are asking whether New York can afford to maintain its traditional commitment to big government when the money to pay for it is growing scarcer and scarcer. 
 New York City's financial commitment is certainly considerable. According to the latest data available from the Bureau of the Census, it spends more money per capita on its residents than any other city except the District of Columbia. That money helps pay for a $10.5 billion municipal payroll, 10,300 beds in 16 public hospitals and clinics, housing for 900,000 people, seven community colleges, and dozens of agencies that regulate everything from outdoor bootblacks to billiard parlors.
In the past, the city could count on a healthy supply of personal, corporate and real-estate taxes to pay for those services. But today, New York is confronted by what amounts to a triple whammy: the cost of social programs to combat drugs, AIDS and homelessness is soaring at the same time that Federal and state spending has been sharply curtailed and the city's traditional base of tax revenue is shrinking.
As a result, the city's longstanding commitment to provide a social safety net for its residents is under siege. Last week more than 20,000 city workers crowded the streets to protest imminent cuts in public services. And on Wednesday, Mayor David N. Dinkins delivered a somber televised address in which he detailed the painful cuts that would be necessary if substantial aid from municipal unions and the state is not forthcoming.
For the most part, Mr. Dinkins's cutbacks are meant to be temporary, with services to be restored when the economy recovers. "The situation we now face will pass," he said on Monday at City Hall. "Much of our difficulty is the economy." Out of his $3.4 billion package to deal with next year's deficit, only $58 million in savings is expected to come from downsizing the government.
But some municipal experts, and even certain members of the Dinkins administration, think that approach is too accepting of the boundaries of city government as they are currently drawn. They argue that the city needs to rethink entirely the range of services it offers, finding new ways to provide some of them at a lower cost and eliminating others altogether.
Officials in the Dinkins administration "are asking questions like how they can avoid the Financial Control Board, how can they get through 1992," said Stephen Berger, chairman of the Financial Guaranty Insurance Company and former executive director of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. "The real question is: How can they unwind these bureaucratic public institutions and find different ways of assuring service?"
City officials often try to justify the relatively high level of public spending by noting that many of the services New York City offers are normally paid for by county governments, making strict comparisons difficult. That is also true of Washington, which provides services traditionally provided by counties and states.
But as far as New York is concerned, that justification can be somewhat misleading. Consider Los Angeles, the nation's second most populous city. Even if its budget is combined with that for Los Angeles County, which pays for much of the area's social-welfare programs, the two governments still spend a little more than half as much per capita on their residents as New York City.
The City of Los Angeles, for example, offers its residents no public higher education; that is provided by the state. And it has no public hospitals. Los Angeles County has six public hospitals, but they have just 3,020 beds, a third the number available in New York City, which has 1.1 million fewer people than Los Angeles County.
Chicago pays only one-third of the cost of its community colleges and has no city university system. Its only public hospital is run by Cook County, and has one-tenth as many beds as New York despite having three-quarters as many people as New York City.
 
History of Advocacy For Public Relief
 Per capita spending is higher in New York City -- and ambitions greater -- for a variety of reasons. Some of them hark back to an era when the city was a thriving commercial and manufacturing center determined to respond to the influx of immigrants who needed temporary public assistance.
It was the city rather than the state that adopted its own unemployment-relief program during the Depression, and started the first full-scale public-housing program that became a model for Federal programs in the New Deal. That same history explains why New York City pays a larger share of state Medicaid costs than any other city.
"In terms of ideology and thinking about the role of government, New York City was very open to what was going on in Europe -- much more than any place else in this country," observed Dick Netzer, professor of economics at New York University. "Local government here became much more activist, like governments in industrial Europe."
Perhaps as a result of this cultural tradition, New York has also shown itself to be more susceptible to political pressures. When the public outcry over homelessness grew to a crescendo, Mayor Edward I. Koch reversed himself and committed the city to the largest low-income housing program in the country. When Mr. Dinkins tried to close firehouses in low-density areas, the public outcry was so great that he immediately relented.
Over time it became commonly accepted that New York's local government could and should try to protect its residents from all potential sources of harm. The result is that although other cities have also been hurt by cutbacks in Federal and state aid, they have not all rushed to fill the vacuum the way New York City has. Los Angeles, for instance, has a limited commitment to shelter poor people.
"The city is stuck trying to fill the Federal Government's housing role, the state's Medicaid role, and also provide local basic services," said Allen J. Proctor, executive director of the Financial Control Board, which oversees the city's spending.
The question Mr. Proctor and others are now asking is whether and how the local government can continue to deliver services that are considered essential without bankrupting the city or forcing taxes so much higher that more businesses and wage-earners flee, further eroding the tax base.
 
Trap With No Exits: Streamlined Services
The city's Comptroller, Elizabeth Holtzman, said some might liken this problem to a trap with no exits. "This crisis creates opportunities to change the way the city works in a fundamental way," she said. She and others have proposed a frontal assault on waste and bureaucracy, returning some services to the private sector, and getting out of some businesses altogether.
Some politicians would move to eliminate certain government units that have parallels at the state level, like the Human Rights Commission and the Department of Consumer Affairs, transferring the latter's revenue-generating licensing authority to other agencies and eliminating one agency's administrative costs. Others would like to see the city's two computer-service agencies combined, and the Cultural Affairs Department eliminated.
Some former city officials also argue that many mayoral offices -- like the commission on the status of women, and the offices for children and families, health policy, housing coordination, midtown enforcement and people with disabilities -- would be expendable if other city agencies would simply fulfill their mandates. Some who study New York's urban problems have recommended eliminating the borough presidents' offices for a savings of $30.8 million.
While cuts like these might lighten the city administration, the organizations involved are for the most part so small that their elimination would not do much to solve the budget shortfall. That has led some municipal experts to conclude that the Dinkins administration has no choice but to tackle three big areas of city spending: health care, education and housing, even though doing so is most likely to engender fierce political opposition.
The city's costs for Medicaid, the main health program for the poor, have almost tripled in 10 years, to $1.8 billion in the last fiscal year from $650 million in 1980. City officials are quick to point out that New York City pays a higher proportion of state Medicaid than any other urban area. But New York also has a far more liberal eligibility standard and more generous range of benefits, which some politicians now say should be trimmed back.
The Mayor's management advisory task force has emphasized the savings the city would reap if it could assign a Medicaid patient to a particular center. Proponents said such a system would not only reduce duplicative record-keeping, but would also improve preventive health care and reduce the stream of Medicaid patients into expensive emergency rooms.
Some municipal observers like Felix G. Rohatyn, chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, which was created in the 1970's to help finance the city's deficit, have suggested that the city also consider returning hospitals to the private sector, on the theory that it would run them more efficiently. But social-service advocacy groups remain skeptical.
"I'm not against privatization," said David R. Jones, president of the Community Services Society. "But I question whether you'll get the cost savings." He also said that any shift to the private sector would have to be accompanied by more stringent enforcement of the law requiring private hospitals to accept Medicaid patients.
Some former officials and public-policy experts think the city's public education system also needs to be examined. New York now has 86,200 employees devoted to education, a 23 percent increase from 10 years ago. Spending by the Board of Education, meanwhile, has more than doubled.
Despite the commitment of resources, condemnation of the city's public-school system is almost universal, leading a variety of critics to suggest that the problem is not a lack of money but the way the city spends it. They have called for more cuts in the Board of Education's administrative staff and more freedom for individual schools.
 
Relieving the State To Unburden City
Some people, including Mr. Rohatyn, have questioned the need for both a state and a citywide university system. A recent study by the State Comptroller, for instance, found that the state spends about $32 million supporting colleges for the study of forestry and maritime activities, and questioned whether the state could afford to support such efforts in the current climate.
Since the state pays most of the costs of the State University of New York and the City University, merging them would not result in direct savings to the city. But Mr. Rohatyn and others consider the state's and the city's budget troubles intertwined, and say that anything that would reduce the pressure on one would ultimately help the other.
Public housing is the third big area that many who have studied the city's finances believe should be re-examined. Many municipal experts are proud of the city's efforts to fight homelessness, but still question whether the city should try to fill the vacuum caused by the Federal Government's retreat from low-income housing programs.
They feel that the city can no longer afford to be the landlord of last resort, rehabilitating more than 10,000 apartments a year through the Department of Housing Preservation and Development and taking on ancillary services like construction and oversight of fuel deliveries.
Many of these proposals could be expected to generate fierce opposition from a wide variety of constituencies: advocacy groups for the poor, labor unions and voters dismayed by the scaling back of New York City's welfare role.
Mr. Berger, the former Port Authority chief, believes that in a time of economic crisis, ideas previously considered too radical will gain new currency. But others point to the 1970's: As the city's fiscal problems gradually subsided, so too did pressure for fundamental change.

HEADLINE: Worry on Quayle Continues With News of Bush's Health, Poll Says

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER

 BODY:
Thrust into the spotlight because of President Bush's health problems, Vice President Dan Quayle continues to stir deep anxiety among Americans, with 62 percent saying they worry about the prospect of a Quayle Presidency, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll has found.
Nearly three years of careful image-grooming have done little to improve the public's perception of the 44-year-old Mr. Quayle, the poll suggests: Only 19 percent of those who participated in the survey say they have a favorable opinion of the Vice President. Twenty-two percent held that view just after the election in November 1988, three months after Mr. Bush stunned much of the political world by selecting the young Senator from Indiana as his running mate. 
 And 54 percent said Mr. Bush should replace Mr. Quayle in 1992. That possibility is often discussed by commentators and political professionals, but it has been repeatedly ruled out by the President. Just 32 percent in the survey say Mr. Quayle should be kept on the ticket.
 
Doubts Among Republicans
 The survey showed pervasive doubts about Mr. Quayle in his own party: 42 percent of those identifying themselves as Republicans favored keeping Mr. Quayle on the ticket, but 47 percent said he should be replaced. Even those who identify themselves as conservative Republicans, thought to be Mr. Quayle's strongest supporters, are evenly divided on whether he should stay or go.
Less than a third of all those responding to the poll say Mr. Quayle passes a basic test for a Vice President. To the question "If something happens to George Bush, do you think Dan Quayle would be qualified to serve as President, or would you be worried about him?" 30 percent said he would be qualified and 62 percent said they would be worried. This has changed little in the last three years.
The poll, with a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points, was conducted through telephone interviews with 909 adults around the country on Tuesday and Wednesday. That was after Mr. Bush had returned to work and after the announcement that his heart irregularity had been attributed to a treatable thyroid problem, but it was before the White House said he had Graves' disease.
 
Quayle Gains Some Support
 The survey showed that most Americans were rallying around the President. Eighty-one percent said they approved of the way he was doing his job. That was an improvement over his rating in two Gallup Polls in recent weeks that showed him receiving about 75 percent approval. The jump in support was reminiscent of that accorded ailing Presidents in the past, from Dwight D. Eisenhower, who rose in the Gallup Poll after a heart attack in 1955, to Ronald Reagan, whose popularity climbed in polls after he underwent colon surgery in 1985.
Even after Mr. Bush was back on the job, there were signs of lingering anxiety among the public about his health. Twenty-seven percent said they were very or somewhat "concerned" that Mr. Bush might not be able to complete his term as President.
The Times/CBS News Poll did find a few signs of improvement in Mr. Quayle's ratings -- a few indications that some Americans, at least, see him growing in office. Forty-eight percent said they thought he understood the complicated problems a President must deal with, as against 33 percent who said so in mid-October 1988. And a Gallup Poll conducted on Monday and Tuesday suggested some gains for Mr. Quayle since last November, the last time Gallup asked a comparable question about his qualifications to be President.
But The Times/CBS News Poll registered overwhelming and persistent doubts about Mr. Quayle at a time when Ameicans were forced to confront the possibility of his assuming Presidential power. Mr. Quayle would have become acting President, temporarily, if Mr. Bush had undergone the electric shock treatment to his heart that was considered earlier this week, before the President's condition responded to medication.
 
Little Fallout Over Kurds
 The proportion of those who said they held an unfavorable opinion of Mr. Quayle actually rose slightly, to 32 percent, as against 27 percent in March. The proportion of those who said they held a favorable opinion remained at 19 percent. Forty-seven percent said they were undecided or had not heard enough to have formed an opinion.
Asked to explain their disapproval, people most often cited what they viewed as his youth and immaturity, a perceived lack of qualifications and their sense that he simply did not seem like a leader.
One-sixth of those surveyed said they would be more likely to vote for the Republican ticket in 1992 if Mr. Quayle was replaced. For all of that, Mr. Bush is not considered likely to replace Mr. Quayle, and some analysts have suggested that the Republicans will suffer little for it.
In 1988, the voters' doubts over Mr. Quayle did not prevent a Republican landslide, even though Democrats tried hard to build on those fears in a number of television commercials.
The poll's results suggest that the Bush Administration is suffering little political fallout over the Kurds: Just 32 percent say the United States should do more to help the Kurdish refugees in Iraq, while 47 percent say it is doing enough and 12 percent say it is doing too much.
Sixty-one percent approve of Mr. Bush's handling of the Kurdish situation. And 53 percent say American actions are not to blame for the plight of the Kurds, while 32 percent say the United States is partly responsible.
Some Democrats had predicted that the Kurds' situation, along with the recession and other domestic problems, would dim Mr. Bush's post-war glow. But the poll found his overall approval rating to be 81 percent.
However, the poll continued to show a huge gap in approval of Mr. Bush's handling of foreign and domestic policy. Seventy-four percent said they approve of his foreign policy, and 41 percent said they approved of his handling of the economy.
On another issue recently in the news, only 11 percent said they believed reports to be true that people in the 1980 Reagan campaign encouraged the Iranian Government to hold the American hostages in Iran until after the election as a means of weakening President Carter. Forty-four percent said they would not rule out those reports, saying they "might possibly be true." And 32 percent said the reports were "almost certainly not true."

HEADLINE: Treasury's Sale Result Lifts Stocks

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
The stock market came out of a slump late yesterday and moved sharply higher. Traders attributed the upturn to Wall Street relief that in spite of all the concern over the huge three-day Treasury refinancing, the sales came off well.
The Dow Jones industrial average of 30 blue chips, which climbed 30 points early in the day and then gave back half of that gain fairly rapidly, ended the day ahead 40.25 points, or 1.4 percent, to 2,971.15. The Dow is now only slightly more than 33 points from its record close of 3,004.46 established in mid-April. 
 "As soon as the Street realized that the Treasury raised $37 billion without increasing long-term bond yields very much, it released pent-up cash to go into stocks," said Peter G. Grennan, senior vice president of Shearson Lehman Brothers.
 
Overcomes Weakness
 "We got the news about the third leg of the refunding, shortly after 2 P.M.," he noted, "and at that point stocks turned up again." The Dow had been weak for at least an hour before the news.
The bidding in the final leg of the auctions was sluggish, but the Treasury sold $11.75 billion of new 30-year bonds at an average yield of 8.21 percent, which was in the expected range. [Page D14.]
All the major stock market averages quickly moved ahead sharply. The broader-based Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks, gaining almost as much as the Dow, rose 1.3 percent, or 4.74 points, to 383.25. The smaller stocks, as represented by the Nasdaq composite, tacked on 1.1 percent, or 5.30 points, to 497.81. The American Stock Exchange's market value index, another measure of the smaller stocks, also moved ahead but by about half as much.
 
Fairly Strong Volume
Trading volume, while not exactly sizzling, rose to a fairly strong 180.2 million shares, from a slugglish 157.2 million on Wednesday.
The New York Stock Exchange said advances led declines by 1,101 to 516, or a little more than 2 to 1. Three Big Board stocks slid to 52-week lows while an impressive 98 rose to 52-week highs.
Computer-driven program buying, particularly after the favorable results of the Treasury refinancing, lifted the Dow by almost 19 points, Birinyi Associates said.
The Dow slid 24.15 points on Tuesday amid widespread fears that the sheer size of the refunding, coming on top of disquieting economic news, would make investors hesitant. But Wednesday, the Dow climbed 13.41 as many traders realized that the refinancing was going well. And yesterday, in what Mr. Grennan called "a sigh of relief" that the auction was over, the market responsed instantly.
Among the Dow stocks, gains of a point or more were widespread. Walt Disney, a Dow newcomer since Monday, rose 3 1/2, to 123 1/4. I.B.M. rose 2 1/8, to 105 7/8, on 1.5 million shares, and Minnesota Mining and Mannufacturing rose 2 1/8, to 89 7/8.
 
Several Dow Stocks Up 1 or More
 Among the Dow gainers of a point or more were Merck, General Motors, International Paper, Coca-Cola, Exxon, Boeing, Du Pont and Texaco.
Among other movers, Wal-Mart Stores rose 2, to 42, with two million shares changing hands, making the retailer the sixth-most-active Big Board stock. Wal-Mart said sales rose 37 percent in the three months ended April 30.
Other retailing stocks were also strong. Dillard Department Stores climbed 1 3/8, to 121; J. C. Penney 1 1/4, to 54 7/8; Dayton Hudson 1 1/2, to 75 1/2, and Home Depot 1 1/2, to 60. Toys "R" Us tacked on 1 5/8, to 29 1/2; Gap 1 1/2, to 58 1/2; Melville 1, to 49 7/8, and Nordstrom 1 1/4, to 42.
 
'Excellent Opportunities'
 Commenting on the industry in his latest report, Bruce Missett, retailing analyst for Morgan Stanley & Company, said, "Investors' perception of gradual improvement in consumer spending and growing confidence in expense control have helped drive up the share prices of both growth and more mature retailers."
He continued, "While the price movement has been substantial, valuations are still below their historical averages, and excellent investment opportunities remain, in our view." His buy list included Dillard, Dayton Hudson, Limited, Circuit City, Gap, Toys "R" Us and Woolworth.
Technology and health-care stocks were also strong.
Bristol-Myers Squibb rose 2 5/8, to 80 3/4, with 1.2 million shares changing hands. Richard Gelb, the company's chairman, told stockholders at the annual meeting on Tuesday that the Food and Drug Administration would review its AIDS drug, Videx, in July.
 
Pfizer Up 2 1/8
 Pfizer rose 2 1/8, to 58 1/8, in brisk trading, although there did not appear to be any news to account for it.
Amgen, recommended by Michael Sorell, biotechnology analyst at Morgan Stanley, rose 2 1/2, to 129 1/4. Chiron, another Sorell "buy," rose 1, to 56 1/2.
Drug stocks rising a point or more included Schering-Plough, Merck, Johnson & Johnson, Warner-Lambert and Eli Lilly.
In the technology group, Intel gained 3, to 54 1/2; Microsoft 2 3/4, to 105 3/4; Hewlett-Packard 2 1/2, to 49, and Borland International 2 1/2, to 54. Adobe Systems rose 2 3/4, to 54 1/2.
Morgan Stanley told investors in its latest report that "with the equity market uncertain about the direction of interest rates, spooked by first-quarter earnings shortfalls and in a mood to harvest investment gains, our 'fresh money buys list' is concentrated in technology, basic industry and energy stocks, whose long-term prospects remain unusually compelling."
 
Tokyo Stocks Are Lower
TOKYO, Friday, May 10 (Reuters) -- Stock prices declined today in Tokyo. The Nikkei index of 225 stocks ended the week at 26,274.29, off 164.21 points, or about six-tenths of a percent. For a week, it fell 203.57 or about eight-tenths of a percent.

HEADLINE: Bell Units' Rivals Gain At F.C.C.

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 9

 BODY:
In a move that could greatly increase competition for many local telephone companies, the Federal Communications Commission proposed a rule today that would force them to let rivals plug directly into local telephone systems.
The proposal, which officials hope will be adopted within 12 months, will be a big help for the growing number of operators of high-speed fiber optic lines that bypass the traditional telephone system. These companies allow customers to reach their long-distance carriers at prices considerably lower than the access charges imposed by local telephone companies. Access charges account for about 40 percent of the cost of long-distance service. 
 Over the long term, the measure represents an important step in chipping away at the near-total domination of traditional telephone companies in their local markets. Large corporations have begun to consider the newer services in developing local private networks to link their offices.
 
Issues Are Unresolved
 F.C.C. officials said they considered the measure a priority although many issues remained unresolved, particularly those concerning rates that telephone companies would charge for making connections.
The heart of today's proposal is a requirement that telephone companies with revenues greater than $100 million a year let the aspiring rivals set up switching equipment on or very near their premises. This will cover most local phone companies that serve mid-sized and large cities. At the moment, bypass companies account for less than 1 percent of the local telephone market.
The measure will mean that a fiber optic company can run lines directly to the neighborhood switching stations and then use the telephone company lines to reach individual customers.
 
Deeper Market Penetration
 Under the proposal, the telephone companies will have to offer special rates that reflect the narrowed use. As a practical matter, the change will make it economically feasible for the bypass companies to penetrate much more deeply into local markets than they can now.
At the moment, these rivals serve only customers who are connected directly to their fiber optic lines. These lines are analagous to superhighways: They are excellent for relaying heavy volumes of traffic along a busy corridor, but they do not offer the equivalent of backroads that reach throughout a community.
Today's proposal will address this "last mile" problem by allowing new providers to run high-speed lines to the telephone company's neighborhood substations scattered around a city. Customers will use the telephone company only for a tiny segment of their service, and use the bypass company for the rest of the service.
The proposal was greeted enthusiastically by Metropolitan Fiber Systems of Oak Brook, Ill., which operates fiber networks in 11 cities, including New York, and had proposed the new rule. "Over all, we truly do applaud the F.C.C. on the action they have taken," said Royce Holland, chief executive of Metropolitan Fiber. "This is a giant step in opening up this last bastion of monopoly control to competition."
It was also applauded by long-distance carriers, including both A.T. &T. and the MCI Communications Corporation, which stand to benefit from lower access charges. "This will speed the day when there are more choices for consumers at the local level," said John Houser, an MCI spokesman. "This will speed the day when access charges will be lower,"
The regional Bell companies had mixed reactions. Some have long predicted that competition is inevitable, but some expressed concern about being forced to encourage competition when their prices reflect obligations imposed by state utility commissions.
"What we're worried about is that we're still restricted as to what markets we are allowed to expand into, while others are now expanding into our markets," said William F. Adler, executive director of Federal regulatory relations in the Washington office of the Pacific Telesis Corporation.
 
Local Companies Restricted
 Unlike their new competitors, who can choose to provide service only through the most lucrative high-traffic areas, the local telephone companies are obligated by state and Federal governments to make service available to everyone in their jurisdictions and to keep prices for residential customer comparatively low.
The upshot is that prices to residential customers are frequently artificially low, while prices for large corporate customers artificially high.
Metropolitan Fiber Systems is considered the largest player, with plans to add nine operations by the end of 1992. Other significant providers are New York Teleport of New York City and the Institutional Communications Company in McLean, Va.
Thus far, competing providers have tended to push down prices on business lines in the markets they have entered. Mr. Holland, of Metropolitan Fiber, said his company usually charged about 10 percent to 20 percent less than the local telephone company, but those prices were eventually matched.
Mr. Holland said about 18 cities now had a competing provider of local telephone service and that the market would be saturated if his company simply expanded according to its current plan. If the rule is adopted, however, bypass companies would probably be able to generate profits in as many as 50 more cities.
The F.C.C. took another action intended to lower customers' bills, this one for calls made from the United States to foreign countries. The F.C.C. has long contended that state-owned telephone companies in Europe and Latin America charge excessive prices for receiving calls and that these charges currently drain about $3 billion a year from the United States.
In the action today, the F.C.C. ordered American long-distance companies to negotiate rates with foreign telephone companies that reflect the declining cost of new technology. If the negotiations do not result in lower rates, F.C.C. officials said they would consider prohibiting Americans from paying rates higher than those it considered fair.
 In moves concering radio broadcasters, the F.C.C. proposed relaxing rules that currently limit a company from owning more than 12 AM and 12 FM stations, as well as rules that bar a company from owning both an AM and FM station in one market.


GRAPHIC: 
TRADITIONAL PHONE SERVICE
 
Calls must travel over local telephones lines. The local phone company charges for access to its lines and businesses that want to establish private networks must lease lines from the local company.
 
EXISTING FIBER-OPTIC PHONE SERVICES
 
To establish private networks for customers, an independent phone company must lay a fiber-optic network parallel to existing phone lines, lines to branch offices.
 
PROPOSED FIBER-OPTIC PHONE SERVICES
 
The Federal Communications Commission has proposed that private fiber-optic phone companies be allowed to plug into a local phone company's switching stations. The access costs would be smaller because calls would use local lines for a shorter time. (pg.D6)

HEADLINE: Auctions

BYLINE: By Rita Reif

 BODY:
A Frida Kahlo
The second Frida Kahlo self-portrait from the 1940's to be auctioned in New York in a year is the most important work in Christie's Latin American art sale at 7 P.M. on Wednesday. The painting, from 1947, is an intense study of this solemn-faced Mexican artist with her long thick black hair hanging loosely. It was painted after a year of undergoing operations to correct injuries from a bus accident when she was 18 years old.
At 24 by 17 inches, it is twice the size of her self-portrait "Diego and I," from 1949, which brought $1.4 million last May at Sotheby's. This small work, which was the first Latin American artwork to exceed $1 million at auction, shows Kahlo with her hair down and with an image of the artist Diego Rivera, her husband, painted at the center of her forehead. 
 "The loosened hair is one indication of her sadness," said Lisa Palmer, who heads Christie's Latin American art sales. "If she was in despair, she depicted herself this way. When she was happy, she painted herself in braids, her hair piled high on her head.
"Self-portraits were a recurrent theme throughout Kahlo's career. They represent about one-third of her works. She would paint a portrait and would send it to a friend with a bill. Those who were not thrilled with this uninvited gift would return the painting."
Mrs. Palmer said the artist, who was 40 years old when she completed the 1947 painting, wrote in the inscription across the bottom of the painting that she was 37 years old.
Since 1985, Kahlo's works have been part of the national patrimony of Mexico. "This means they cannot be exported and are increasingly difficult to find in the market," Mrs. Palmer said. Since Kahlo's total output was small, her self-portraits are scarce today, even though the record-breaking painting sold at Sotheby's last May is still available at the gallery of the buyer, Mary-Anne Martin of Manhattan.
The value of Kahlo paintings dramatically escalated in the 1980's art boom, Ms. Martin said. In fact, the portrait at Christie's was bought in 1982 for $85,000 at Ms. Martin's gallery by Louise Noun, a collector from Iowa. Ms. Noun is selling the painting to establish a women's archive at the University of Iowa.
Christie's presale estimate is $1 million to $2 million.
Compared with other art sales in November, in which about half the works went unsold, the Latin American art auctions last fall in Manhattan realized healthy totals. Christie's achieved a record total for a Latin American art sale -- $12.4 million -- at an auction in which 228 works of the 317 offered were sold. It was below the low estimate of $13 million.
The Latin American art sales this month are being viewed by auctioneers, dealers and collectors as the first test of this market in the recession. Sotheby's canceled its sales of Latin American art this month and included 32 works by these artists in its contemporary art auctions last week and in this week's sales of Impressionist and modern art. Of the 32 Latin American works in the auctions, which were estimated by the house to bring about $3 million to $4 million, 22 were sold for a total of $1.7 million.
Christie's has no intention of canceling its Latin American art sales, Mrs. Palmer said. The two-day sale, which is to continue at 10 A.M. on Thursday, will offer 213 works estimated by the house to total $13 million to $16 million.
"What's been making prices go up and paintings sell in the specialty sales is the competition between the Latin American buyers, the Americans and the Europeans," said Ms. Martin, who is a former head of Latin American art sales at Sotheby's.
Meanwhile, Sotheby's is reviewing its decision to cancel its Latin American sales. Diana D. Brooks, Sotheby's president in North America, wrote to clients last month asking them to express their opinions about how they wished such art to be presented.
David J. Nash, who heads Sotheby's fine-art sales internationally, had urged that Latin American art be combined with European and postwar American art in sales. But this week, after Tuesday night's unsuccessful Impressionist and modern art auction, in which only two of the five works by Latin American artists were sold, Mr. Nash said, "We are keeping an open mind whether this is the right approach."
 
African Sculpture
 An angular African sculpture of a woman, carved a century ago by a Senufo artisan in the southern part of what is known today as Mali, is the most important work in the tribal-art sale to be held at 10:15 A.M. on Wednesday at Sotheby's in New York. The smoothly sculptured ritual artifact, a three-foot rhythm pounder with a bronzelike patina, was used in ritual dances.
It was shown in 1984 at the Museum of Modern Art exhibition " 'Primitivism' in 20th-Century Art" and was later owned by the show's organizer, William S. Rubin, the former director of the department of painting and sculpture at the Modern.
Bernard de Grunne, who heads Sotheby's tribal-art sales, said this week that Mr. Rubin owned the figure until three or four months ago, when it was acquired by the seller, a European collector who wishes to remain anonymous.
Why is the owner selling the figure?
Mr. de Grunne said: "I don't know. Maybe he doesn't like it, or maybe he needs the money."
Susan Vogel, director of the Center for African Art in Manhattan, described the figure as an "absolutely wonderful piece, one of a tiny group of similar ones all by the same workshop or the same hand."
Mr. de Grunne, who has headed tribal-art sales at Sotheby's since 1987, described the carving as "the best African piece I have ever offered for sale."
Sotheby's presale estimate is $800,000 to $1 million.
 
One Big Sapphire
 Large stones discovered at the turn of the century are among the most discussed items in next week's jewelry sales organized in Geneva by Christie's and Sotheby's. Christie's is to auction a 337.66-carat sapphire, described by the house as the largest ever to be auctioned, in a sale to be held on Thursday night. Squarish with rounded corners, the stone was framed in diamonds weighing 24 carats and mounted as a pendant in 1910 by Cartier of Paris.
Francois Curiel, who heads Christie's European art sales, said on Wednesday that the house's original presale estimate of $1.6 million for the sapphire was recently reduced because of the recession. The estimate is now $850,000 to $1 million.
A pear-shaped 69.68-carat diamond, the weightiest jewel of the 21 cut at the turn of the century from what was then the largest gem-quality diamond in the world, is to be auctioned on Wednesday by Sotheby's in Geneva. It was cut from the loaf-shaped blue-white 995-carat Excelsior, which was discovered in 1893 in Jagersfontein, South Africa, and which was exceeded in size in 1905, when the 3,106-carat Cullinan was discovered. Both were cut by the I. J. Asscher diamond company of Amsterdam.
Sotheby's diamond, called the Excelsior I, is owned by a European client who bought the stone in the last year. Sotheby's presale estimate is $2 million to $3 million.

HEADLINE: Review/Art;
What an Old Scroll Tells About Buddhism in Korea

BYLINE: By MICHAEL BRENSON

 BODY:
"The Story of a Painting: A Korean Buddhist Treasure From the Mary and Jackson Burke Foundation" is the first exhibition at the Asia Society that was conceived under its new director, Dr. Vishakha N. Desai, and it points one of New York's revered institutions of Asian art in a new direction.
This idea-filled yet overanxious and overambitious exhibition, organized by Dr. Hongnam Kim, an Asia Society curator who also wrote the catalogue essay, inaugurates "Objects in Context," a key part of Dr. Desai's curatorial program. 
 "In this series of annual exhibitions," the new director writes in her preface, "we intend to feature a single work of Asian art, generally from the permanent collection, augmented with related loans from public and private collections in the United States, to highlight the multiple layers of meaning -- esthetic, cultural, art historical, functional -- embedded in the work."
The painting whose story is being told is "Sakyamuni Buddha and Attendant Bodhisattvas," a 426-year-old hanging scroll discovered in Japan in 1989 and acquired by the Mary and Jackson Burke Foundation in New York in 1990. It is not large, around 28 inches tall and 13 inches wide, and is easily obscured by the more than 60 paintings and sculptures around it.
This restrained yet expressive work, which has darkened considerably with time, is one of 400 paintings completed in 1565 for the Hoeam-sa temple near Seoul. The temple was reconstructed by the Queen Dowager Munjong, who seems to have been almost single-handedly responsible for reviving Buddhism in her country. The pictorial program at Hoeam-sa was clearly a pillar of her Buddhist revival. When all 400 pieces of this vast religious and cosmological puzzle were in place, the effect must have been both meditative and spectacular.
The painting presents Sakyamuni Buddha, the historical Buddha, on a throne (Sakyamuni was, Dr. Kim writes, the founder of the faith, the "paradigm for the Buddhas who transcend time and space, existing outside of all doctrines and scriptures"). The delicate, frontal, almost feathery figure is flanked by two bodhisattvas (enlightened beings) who carry out the Buddha's word. The triadic composition (each figure is a point of a triangle) was widespread throughout Asia (as it was throughout Renaissance Italy). The most accessible part of the exhibition is devoted to this composition and its many forms in Asian art.
The installation places the work in the context of the Songgwang-sa monastery in Korea (Hoeam-sa temple was destroyed sometime between 1565 and 1825). It places the work in the context of Buddhist "banner" paintings, or t'aenghwa, of which there are two kinds: one small, private and made for indoors (like the Burke painting), one large (some were colossal), public and made for outdoor display.
The exhibition is instructive in many ways. Its variety of work from all over Asia underlines a diversity of Asian art that the public may not expect. It suggests a Korean style of painting that is much flatter (at times almost wafer thin) and, despite its apparent gentleness and self-effacement, is spellbinding and authoritative in intention and emphatically rhythmic in chromatic effect.
The exhibition also reveals that the figures in the Burke painting were part of a type -- oval face, arched eyebrows, almond-shaped eyes -- that essentially developed in Tang Dynasty China (618-907) and became an Asian style. The section on connoisseurship points out that the distinctions between Korean, Japanese and Chinese art are not always as clear as they may seem.
The exhibition provides a good deal of information about Dr. Desai, whose appointment last year as Asia Society director is as important in its own way as the recent selections of David Ross as director of the Whitney Museum of American Art and Robert Storr as a curator at the Museum of Modern Art.
Dr. Desai, a scholar of Indian art who had been a teacher and curator in Boston, Mr. Ross and Mr. Storr are all in their early 40's. She shares with them a far-ranging intellectual curiosity and eagerness to engage the kinds of issues -- including the meaning and formation of an artistic "mainstream" and canon -- that are helping to define the first years of this decade.
What does this exhibition tell us about her curatorial vision? For one thing, it is contextual in a broad sense. It approaches the painting from religious and artistic as well as political and historical perspectives.
For another, the focus of the show is not China, Japan and India, the giants of Asian art, but Korea, whose art is far less known in the United States.
Dr. Desai is clearly interested in opening up the field of Asian art so that the public will consider all its aspects and also question prevailing assumptions about which styles, traditions and approaches are worthy of serious consideration.
In addition, the show is a clear attempt to develop the resources of the Asia Society and to court collectors. Nine works in the show are from the museum's permanent collection. The centerpiece, as well as some of the Japanese paintings in the show, were lent by Mary Burke, a major collector of Japanese art and a member of the Friends of the Asia Society Galleries, a group that provides the museum with advice, economic support and artistic loans.
The exhibition also suggests some of the dangers of a contextual orientation. Although the painting is clearly a historical document of considerable importance, it is not a masterpiece. It is, in fact, considerably less compelling than some of the other paintings around it.
The problem is almost fatal. A show about a single work in context has to choose a work that is, if not demonstrably great, at least an artistic statement with unmistakable visual weight and power. The esthetic stature of this painting is questionable amid all the strong works around it. As a result, the exhibition has no center, and it seems more an attempt to present a new work and communicate a new curatorial approach than a desire to put the public in touch with a work it needs to understand.
In addition, the exhibition attempts too much. There are so many directions to follow that the points the show sets out to make are obscured or lost.
But stay tuned for the next installment in the "Objects in Context" series. The dynamism and scholarship in this show are clear evidence of a curatorial administration with a lot to say. In Chapter 2, many of the problems here may be resolved.
 "The Story of a Painting: A Korean Buddhist Treasure From the Mary and Jackson Burke Foundation" remains at the Asia Society, 725 Park Avenue, at 70th Street, through July 28.
 
Arturo Martini
Philippe Daverio Gallery
41 East 57th Street
Through June 15
This exhibition offers a glimpse at a 20th-century Italian sculptor who is almost entirely unknown in the United States, even through he may be the equal of Marino Marini and Giacomo Manzu. It presents 10 small sculptures and 3 large reclining nudes, all in bronze. It does not include any of Martini's sculptures in plaster, terra cotta or stone (although one reclining figure was cast from stone). If the show cannot suggest the range of Martini's work, it does reveal his talent and the difficulty in pinning his work down.
Martini was born in Treviso in 1889 and died in Milan in 1947. The artists with whom he studied or was affiliated, including the German sculptor Adolf von Hildebrand and the Italian painter Carlo Carra, as well as the group Valori Plastici (Plastic Values), were committed to finding a modern way of working with the human figure. The sculptures in this show fit easily into classical and academic categories, but they are not all that idealized and there is something that saves almost all of them from being academic.
Martini had a real touch. He also had a sense of line and surface and the kind of feeling for void that cannot be taught: the spaces between arms and body, and between legs, can be more convincing than the limbs themselves. He also had a feeling for the odd angle that keeps you turning around a work, and for quirky bumps that disrupt a flowing movement or shift the weight in a surprising direction. In "Woman in the Sun" and "La Pisana," both reclining nudes, the movement through and around the body is extremely active, even though the figures are at rest. It would be nice to be given a larger selection of work so that it would be possible to see how far Martini's talent managed to go.

GRAPHIC: Photo: A detail from "Sakyamuni Buddha and Attendant Bodhisattvas" on exhibit at the Asia Society. (Asia Society)

HEADLINE: BOXING;
Nunn Fight Looks Like an Economic Prize for His Resurgent Hometown

BYLINE: By PHIL BERGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DAVENPORT, Iowa, May 9

 BODY:
In an era when prime-time fights routinely land in Las Vegas and Reno and Atlantic City, where casinos use them to draw high rollers to their gaming tables, a hometown hero has returned here to the banks of the Mississippi to defend his world title.
Here, there are no flashing neon hotel signs or honking horns downtown. Davenport, Iowa, population 100,000, is surely an odd spoke on boxing's big wheel. 
 But on Friday night, in John O'Donnell Stadium, a baseball park that is home to a Class A affiliate of the California Angels, Davenport native Michael Nunn, the International Boxing Federation middleweight champion, will be in action against an undefeated contender named James Toney.
 
Trend in Site-Setting?
 Is the grass-roots setting of the fight a trend? After all, just last weekend Orlando Canizales defended his bantamweight title in Laredo, Tex.
It's doubtful. The Nunn bout is a specific case in which both the fighter and his hometown benefit. For Nunn, it's a rare chance to show off his slick moves to the people he grew up with, and still be awarded in a manner to which he is accustomed. Nunn, who, like Jerry Lewis, is more popular in France than he is on these shores, gets to keep the fight's gate receipts, which could go as high as $750,000. That is as good -- and predictably better -- than any casino would have paid him for this match.
For Davenport, the fight signals ongoing recovery from economic hard times, adding to a sense of progress that the recent launching of riverboat gambling has given the city. And in the days leading to the match, the involvement of Nunn has lent an edge to life in this place, which is generally quiet save for an annual festival dedicated to another of the city's home-grown stars, jazz great Bix Beiderbecke.
 
On the Mound
 Friday night, things don't figure to be quiet for long.
Somewhere around 10:15 P.M., Central time, Nunn will bound up the steps of the stadium's first-base dugout and enter a ring laid out over the pitcher's mound. And if the weather is temperate and ticket sales go as expected, 9,000 to 10,000 fans, paying prices ranging between $25 and $200, will cheer Nunn on while the rest of the country catches the bout on a TVKO pay-per-view telecast that costs $19.95.
The 28-year-old Nunn, who said fighting in his hometown "means the world to me," is undefeated in 36 fights and, if he wins Friday, is expected to fight Nigel Benn next. Toney, a 22-year-old from Ann Arbor, Mich., who has been fighting professionally for only two and a half years, has 24 victories and a draw in 25 bouts. Tonight, Nunn weighed in at 160 pounds, and Toney at 157.
The pairing of this city -- one of the Quad Cities on the Iowa and Illinois sides of the Mississippi River -- and a prime-time fight has not been without complications. To set the match in motion, the advance men of promotor Bob Arum said they first had to knock down the local people's expectations of windfall prices for services rendered and materials delivered.
"They read about all the fancy numbers for Holyfield-Foreman and figured this was a grand chance for them," said Fred Berns, the on-site promotor for Arum.
 
Fight Game's Format
 Besides overcoming those economic preconceptions, Arum's men had to bring Davenport personnel up to speed on boxing logistics. O'Donnell Stadium personnel may know baseball, but as Jay Edson, site coordinator for Arum, discovered, they were fuzzy on staging a fight.
For instance, there was a question of where to house all the fighters for the night. Nunn and the co-featured Michael Carbajal, the I.B.F. light flyweight champion, will use the home-team clubhouse; their opponents, the visitors' clubhouse. Edson wanted two 60-foot trailers for the other preliminary combatants, but had to settle for two 30-foot trailers and a last-minute offer of two motor homes.
 But in Davenport, Edson has discovered adversity is mother to invention. "To get power for the trailers, we'll go through the ball park's scoreboard electric box," he said.
 
Difficult 80's
 If staging the fight in Davenport has meant complications for the promotor, it has been another story for the city. Staging a big-league fight here has primarily been an affirmation of an upturn in its fortunes. Like the other Quad Cities -- Bettendorf on the Iowa side and Moline and Rock Island on the Illinois side -- Davenport has had its share of hard times in the recent past.
"In the late 1970's and early 1980's, the farm economy went bad," said Joe Taylor, director of communications for the Quad Cities Convention and Visitors Bureau. "There were large surpluses and prices plummeted. Farmers were unable to buy farm equipment. And the plants that made that equipment were situated in the Quad Cities. We're talking about J.I. Case. John Deere. International Harvester. Farmall. The plants laid off workers, and some of them closed."
But Davenport is bouncing back, Taylor said. Yes, there are empty storefronts on some of the main streets and in the downtown, and yes, the reconstruction there is hardly finished. But for the civic leaders, Nunn's title defense here is viewed as one of many proofs of a resurgent economy.
The most conspicuous sign of a revitalized city is along River Drive. That's where four times a day the President Riverboat Casino pushes off from dockside and cruises along the Mississippi with a thousand or so customers trying their luck at slot machines and at table games like blackjack, craps and roulette.
Riverboat gambling is new here. On April 1, floating casinos began navigating the Mississippi in Bettendorf, Dubuque and Davenport. There's a $200-per-cruise limit to what a patron can lose, but that may change. Across the river in Illinois, it seems the Legislature has approved riverboat gambling, with no limit to what a consenting adult can lose.
After the Nunn-Toney bout was announced, John Connelly, owner of the President, bought $100,000 worth of tickets. That was in March. By this week, the activity and excitement for the fight was quickening. On Wednesday night, Monte Cox, sports editor of The Quad City Times, was putting the finishing touches on a 16-page fight supplement for Thursday. Bout posters appeared in stores and hotels in the Quad Cities.
"What this really is," Taylor said, emphasizing rising tourism figures, "is one more activity to draw visitors. Success breeds success."

GRAPHIC: Photo: View from roof of John O'Donnell Stadium on the banks of the Mississippi River in Davenport, Iowa, where championship fight will take place. (John Gaps 3d for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Avery Fisher Mit Schlag

BYLINE: By BRYAN MILLER

 BODY:
Opulent pastries and high-octane coffee are featured at a new Austrian-style coffeehouse that opens today in the lobby of Avery Fisher Hall. The theatrical 90-seat cafe, with hand-painted murals depicting scenes from Mozart's operas as well as displays of costumes from famous Austrian operas, is a gift to Lincoln Center from the Federal Economic Chamber of Austria. The donation honors the center's current Mozart Bicentennial celebration, which continues through August 1992.
Cafe Vienna, which will be operated by Restaurant Associates, is open from 11:30 A.M. to well after evening performances at Lincoln Center. Patrons do not need event tickets to get in. The cafe is expected to remain open at least through August 1992, and perhaps permanently, said Richard Cattani, president of restaurant services for Restaurant Associates.
The cafe features a wide array of pastries, coffees, beer and wine. In the true European cafe tradition, there are wood slat newspaper racks around the dining room. But the newspapers are in German.

HEADLINE: Restaurants

BYLINE: By Bryan Miller

 BODY:
Aureole
With pricey haute cuisine restaurants toppling like power lines in a hurricane, how does one account for a place like Aureole? Opened in 1988, just as the economy was plummeting, it could have been heading into a maelstrom. Yet three years later, it remains one of the most vibrant and popular restaurants in New York City. 
 With a $55 prix fixe dinner, Aureole is on the high end of the price scale. Its unwavering success must be attributed to the top-notch service and the consistently captivating food of Charles Palmer, the chef and owner.
The restaurant is in a dramatic town house with a two-story front window that allows previews of the cream-toned walls adorned with plaster reliefs of wildlife. The downstairs dining room, all beige and accented with eruptions of colorful flowers, occasionally feels cramped when full; upstairs offers more privacy.
We started one evening with an array of savory little giveaways: shrimp tempura, pop-in-the-mouth beef Wellington and seared tuna on top of peppered pineapple. Mr. Palmer's signature appetizer, which remains as good as ever, is called sea scallop sandwich: perfectly seared sea scallops between layers of thin golden potatoes atop a lemony shellfish stock sauce.
Sweetbreads make a dynamic starter when lightly browned and set in a nest of mixed greens and asparagus tips with beignets of morels.
Aureole's Muscovy duck tasting is a varied teaser: lean but well-seasoned rillettes, an earthy pistachio-studded terrine, a silken foie gras terrine, excellent homemade duck sausage moistened with vinaigrette, and creamy (but bitter) duck liver mousse. If you find all this daunting, there is always the superb oak-smoked salmon served with cucumber salad and a dollop of double-cultured cream.
Waiters at Aureole have a professional bearing without being stiff. Like good basketball centers, they know when to float in and when to stay on the perimeter. You won't find many bargains on Aureole's wine list. A few California chardonnays and pinot noirs are worth looking at, though.
The kitchen has a sprightly touch with seafood, from sesame-crusted tuna with mushroom soy sauce and caramelized turnips to buttery sauteed halibut with ravioli of potato and green beans. The big hit at my table was seared salmon coated with three mustards accompanied by basil-braised artichokes and new potatoes.
Wood-grilled lamb chops come atop an earthy lentil cake and are surrounded by a ragout of oyster mushrooms and sweet caramelized onions -- a harmonious combination. Zestily seasoned peppered quails are served deboned over wild mushrooms and sauteed vegetables, along with a sweetish sweetbread pudding. I'd just as soon spend a summer weekend in the Holland Tunnel as eat kidneys, but the exceptionally mild ones served here with roasted pancetta, shallots and wild mushrooms in a Barolo wine reduction were indeed special.
Richard Leach, the pastry chef, should have his hands licensed as deadly weapons, like boxers. One seductive example of his handiwork is called a chocolate timbale, which has a chocolate cylinder filled with bittersweet chocolate mousse, anchored in exceptionally rich chocolate cake. Apple tart is ineffably light with its warm apples in its puff pastry crust with vanilla ice cream. Pear and pistachio layer cake was too sweet for my taste, but the pear sorbet with it was wonderful, as was the warm pear fritter.
In today's economy, Aureole may be a place that is frequented only on special occasions. If you are lucky enough to go there, though, special it should be.
 
Phoenix Garden
 The seedy, trash-strewn arcade off the Bowery in Chinatown hardly piques one's appetite. Those who venture within come across a lightning fast and obstreperous little place called Phoenix Garden, where some of the best Cantonese fare in New York City can be found.
Phoenix Garden is neither the friendliest nor the most comfortable restaurant in Chinatown. Upon entering the packed beige-toned dining room one evening we were ushered -- well, pushed really -- against a glass partition near the cash register by the aggressive hostess. When one woman in our party drifted from her designated spot, the hostess pummeled her on the arm until she returned.
Waiters here make delicatessen countermen look leisurely. "Beer?" "Beer?" "Beer?" asked three different waiters in quick succession. "Ready?" "Ready?" "Ready?" they inquired about two minutes after menus were presented. Finally, after about 10 minutes, the hostess took our orders when she felt we had used up sufficient time. Phoenix Garden is an easy place to despise -- but then there is that food.
We started with a light and wholesome soup of mustard greens and sliced pork that carried a kick of fresh ginger. The house specialty, called pepper and salty shrimp, is as heavenly as ever. Medium-sized shrimp are butterflied and amply seasoned with a yin-yang of salt and pepper, then cooked to light gold. A similar method works extraordinarily well with squid. Thin twirls of seasoned squid are delightfully crisp and tasty.
Crispy roasted squab with a sweet brittle skin and thin layer of fat is as addictive as candy. Another good light starter is stewed eggplant with ground ham served in a casserole.
All entrees come cascading out of the kitchen at once even if you ask for them staggered, so be ready, chopsticks up. Sea scallops smothered in moderately hot black pepper sauce with onions and garlic are tantalizing. So too is tender braised duck with mustard greens. A dish called sizzling chicken was dry because the moisture had evaporated during cooking. Much better was the complex combination of stewed beef flank with sweet turnips, mustard greens, garlic and lots of coriander.
The melange of mai-fun (rice noodles) and shrimp, sweet morsels of pork, green peppers, onions and bean sprouts, is right on target for texture and blending of flavors. Four-mushroom casserole was more impressive looking than it tasted. (It needed seasonings.) A seafood dish called lobster with satee sauce, a piquant blend of black pepper and curry, was an unqualified winner. Cut-up lobster, carefully cooked, came in an earthenware crock over clean cellophane noodles in a sweetish sauce tempered by the oceanic lobster juices.
When the last claw is cracked, out go the plates and in comes a chemical-tasting almond gelatin. Check . . slam . . . dunk . . . goodbye. For the first time, the hostess smiles.

SECTION: Section A; Page 30; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 546 words

HEADLINE: Soak the Rich? No. Help the Poor

 BODY:
Four senior Democrats, led by Senator Albert Gore and Representative Thomas Downey, proposed a bill to lower taxes on poor families with children and raise taxes on the very rich. That's a seductive combination: a way to play Robin Hood without costing the Treasury a dime.
But the proposal is also deceptively dangerous. To reap political favor, the sponsors would also shower tax benefits on a wide swath of the middle class. That's why their proposal requires piling tax hikes on six million rich families. 
 That invites -- begs -- wealthy investors to swarm all over Congress to reinstate the tax break for capital gains and recreate loopholes to protect themselves against the higher taxes.
The likely outcome is a deformed tax code, much like the one that existed before the 1986 tax reform. Tax rates were weighted in favor of the poor. But after taking account of the dodges, loopholes and shelters, rich and poor paid about the same proportion of their income to Washington. And the various deformations pushed investment into wasteful boondoggles.
 The Democratic sponsors make a compelling case for targeting tax relief to poor families. For more than a decade the working poor have suffered as their wages, measured after inflation, went down and their payroll taxes went up. And non-working poor parents have suffered from a 40 percent plunge in after-inflation welfare benefits.
The Downey-Gore bill would eliminate the existing personal deduction for children and substitute a child care tax credit worth $800 to every family, rich and poor. Families in the 15 percent tax bracket would save $455 per child; families in the 28 percent bracket would save $156 per child.
The bill would also boost the earned income tax credit, an income supplement for low-paid workers. The benefits for the poor would be dramatic: it would lift 600,000 families out of poverty; two million more families would owe no taxes.
But because every family would be eligible for the new tax credit, there would also be tax cuts for as many as 135 million Americans -- including families earning up to $75,000 a year. To pay for that, the bill would raise tax rates on upper income families, including a top rate of 38 percent on income above $250,000.
These proposed rates would pose no serious economic threat; they would still be lower than rates prevailing in much of Europe and in the U.S. before the Reagan Administration. But higher rates do pose a serious political threat.
The Democratic leadership has barely beaten back President Bush's attempts to cut the tax on capital gains -- during a period when the tax rate on the highest incomes ranged merely between 28 percent and 32. With a top rate near 40 percent, the opposition to Mr. Bush is quite likely to crumble.
A big boost in the top tax bracket would also push lawyers and accountants back into the business of creating wasteful tax shelters. The crowning glory of the 1986 reform was to eliminate the incentive to create dodges.
Messrs. Gore and Downey can solve the problem by targeting their tax cut. They could, for example, phase out the new child tax credit as family income rises. That way poor families would get an equitable boost and spare society any need to deform tax reform.

SECTION: Section A; Page 30; Column 1; Editorial Desk
