HEADLINE: Courage, Finally, on Gun Control

 BODY:
The customer shows up at the Ohio shop every couple of weeks looking for 9-millimeter semiautomatic handguns. He doesn't look like a local man, but he produces what looks like a valid local ID. So the dealer sells him the guns. He's not sure what the man does with all those 9-millimeters. But that's not his concern.
Eventually the man stops coming in, and the dealer learns that his best customer has been arrested. He's actually a resident of the Bronx who was getting rich selling guns from Ohio on the streets of New York City, where gun laws are strict. 
 The gun control bill that cleared the House of Representatives by a resounding margin on Wednesday would do much to stop such gun running -- and a lot of urban bloodshed as well. The vote was a welcome triumph of common sense over the bullying tactics of special interests. And it challenges the Senate to show similar fortitude.
The legislation would impose a national seven-day waiting period between the purchase and delivery of a handgun. It was introduced by Representative James Feighan, Democrat of Ohio, and named for James Brady, the former press secretary injured in the 1981 assassination attempt on President Reagan.
In addition to the waiting period, the bill requires that documents involved in the sale, including the purchaser's identification, be forwarded to local police. That gives them a chance to prevent illegal sales to felons, drug addicts, mental patients and purchasers from out of state.
The last group may be the most dangerous. Drug gangs and other criminals in cities with strong gun laws are commonly armed by smugglers who buy guns over the counter in other states and bring them home for resale on the black market -- at huge profits. Knowing that such out-of-state purchases will be routinely subjected to police scrutiny could have a powerful chilling effect.
The House vote marked a dramatic defeat for the National Rifle Association, which has for years invested heavily to prevent passage of the Brady bill. This time the gun lobby sought to parry the bill with a proposal for instant background checking at the point of sale. That was a cynical maneuver: the N.R.A. knew better than anyone that such a system would take years to set up and cost millions Washington doesn't have.
For once, enough lawmakers refused to be fooled or intimidated. Angry N.R.A. spokesmen now promise revenge in the 1992 elections. Such crude tactics could backfire. The bill's substantial margin of victory is due in part to representatives like Les AuCoin of Oregon, an N.R.A. supporter who changed his vote and publicly voiced his disgust with the gun lobby's heavy-handed approach.
Now it's the Senate's turn to show that it is capable of similar decency and courage. Senator Howard Metzenbaum of Ohio has introduced the Brady bill, and Senator George Mitchell of Maine, the majority leader, says he wants a stronger version that would combine a waiting period with development of a data base for instant background checking.
There is some reason to suspect Mr. Mitchell, from a state where gun control gets little sympathy, of another cynical scheme for an unworkable substitute. The House vote, however, makes that a highly dubious strategy. Now more than ever, the Brady bill looks like Washington's best response to the deadly spread of illegal guns.

CORRECTION-DATE: May 14, 1991, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
An editorial Friday misidentified the House sponsor of the gun legislation known as the Brady bill. He is Edward Feighan, Democrat of Ohio.

HEADLINE: Jerome P. Pickard, 74, Is Dead; Early Forecaster of Urban Spread

BYLINE: By GLENN FOWLER

 BODY:
Jerome P. Pickard, a geographer and a specialist in economic development who was senior adviser on demographics to the Appalachian Regional Commission for two decades, died on Monday at his summer home in Amagansett, L. I. He was 74 years old and also lived in Somerset, Md.
He died of heart failure, his family said. 
 In 1972, in a much-discussed report to the Federal Commission on Population Growth and the American Future, Dr. Pickard concluded that the urbanization of the United States was proceeding so rapidly that metropolitan governments would eventually have to be superseded by broader regional authorities to cover entities like the Atlantic Seaboard urban region. The Shenandoah National Park in Virginia, he said, would bear the same relationship to the seaboard region as Central Park bore to New York City in the 19th century.
Dr. Pickard, who was reared in Chicago, was a graduate of the University of Chicago and held advanced degrees from the University of Wisconsin and a doctorate from the Maxwell School at Syracuse University. He was a Fulbright scholar at the University of Oslo in Norway.
From 1954 to 1959 he served as research director for economic development at the Washington (D.C.) Board of Trade. Later he held similar posts at the Urban Land Institute and the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development. He joined the Appalachian Regional Commission in 1970 and retired last year.
Dr. Pickard taught regional development at George Washington University and was widely published in scholarly journals.
He is survived by his wife, Mildred; four daughters, Judith Lemieux of Montreal, Ruth Ann Running of St. Francis, S.D., Elizabeth Pickard of Lummi Island, Wash., and Susan Pickard of Madison, Wis., and six grandchldren.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Head of Quaker State Steps Down at Meeting

 BODY:
Quentin E. Wood, who rose during a 43-year career at the Quaker State Corporation from field engineer to chairman, resigned at the motor oil company's annual meeting yesterday. He will be succeeded by Jack W. Corn, who will also retain the title of chief executive.
Under Mr. Wood's leadership, as chief executive from 1975 to 1988 and chairman since 1982, Quaker State undwerwent a sizable expansion. From 1979 to 1986, sales increased from $292.9 million, to about $1 billion, and net income rose from $23.2 million, to $50 million. 
 Mr. Wood, 68 years old, attributed the growth, in part, to the acquisition of a string of assets, including the Valley Camp Coal Company, the Heritage Insurance Group and the Arctic Circle Corporation, which the company converted into a chain of 460 fast-lube service centers now known as Quaker State Minit-Lube.
Since 1986, the company, based in Oil City, Pa., has sold all its shallow crude oil wells, two of its refineries, its wax plant and its restaurant business. By the end of 1990, the company's sales had fallen to $874 million and net income was $19.6 million.
Mr. Wood said one of the most memorable accomplishments of his tenure was fending off an unsolicited $675 million takeover bid from Ardshiel Inc., an investor group, in 1988.
"During that period, when hostile takeovers were so prevalent, Quaker State was on the list of every corporate raider," Mr. Wood said. "I'm very proud of the fact that I was able to keep Quaker State independent."
Mr. Wood, who will remain a director at Quaker State, is leaving the chairman's office at another critical time in the history of the company, as it battles the debilitating effects of the recession, the sluggish automotive market and the operational problems that have plagued two of its coal mines.
The company reported that net income fell 88.4 percent in the first quarter, to $269,000, or 1 cent a share, compared with $2.3 million, or 9 cents a share, in the comparable period of 1990. Sales fell 9.8 percent, to $188.5 million, compared with $209 million.
Mr. Wood joined Quaker State on July 1, 1948, less than a month after he graduated from Pennsylvania State University with a bachelor of science degree in petroleum and natural gas engineering. He rose from field engineer to chief engineer of the product division, to manager, to vice president, to corporate director and then to president, the job he took in 1973. He relinquished the position of chief executive to Mr. Corn in 1988.
He and his wife, Louise, will continue to divide their time between Oil City and Ponte Vedra Beach, Fla. They are avid golfers and tennis players and are planning trips later this year to Ireland and Scotland. "I feel ready to step aside and relax a little bit," Mr. Wood said.

HEADLINE: Brazil's Economy Chief Out; Envoy to U.S. Gets the Post

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, May 9

 BODY:
Pressed by a deep recession, stubborn inflation and restive foreign creditors, President Fernando Collor de Mello today replaced Zelia Cardoso de Mello as Economy Minister, traditionally Brazil's second most powerful Government post, with Brazil's Ambassador to the United States.
As Marcilio Marques Moreira prepared to take office on Friday, Ms. Cardoso's economic team, including the president of the central bank and the nation's foreign debt negotiator, resigned. 
 In making the change, Mr. Collor replaced youth with experience, and radical home-grown solutions with orthodox, internationally acceptable remedies. Business executives here hailed the move.
Ms. Cardoso, Brazilian-trained and 37 years old, was a virtually unknown college professor when Mr. Collor named her Economy Minister, the first woman in Brazil's history to occupy the post.
Ms. Cardoso ordered radical measures, including freezing most bank accounts, and Brazil's economy shrank 6 percent in her first year in office. When inflation returned to 20 percent a month in January, she imposed wage and price controls, Brazil's fourth such experience in four years.
In a demonstration of disaffection with Government policies, shopkeepers increased the supposedly frozen prices by 40 percent in the last three months.
Universally known here as Zelia, Ms. Cardoso disrupted the Government in October when she made public her affair with Bernardo Cabral, then Minister of Justice. Mr. Cabral, who is married, was forced to resign. Ms. Cardoso, who is single, retained her post.
Her replacement, Mr. Moreira, 59, is a discreet former bank director with 34 years of experience with the United States and a penchant for orthodox, negotiated approaches to economic problems.
"Marcilio brings a key ingredient: credibility," Joel Korn, who is head of Bank of America operations in Brazil said today. "He brings maturity. He has developed an extremely good rapport with the international community."
The son of a career diplomat, Mr. Moreira grew up in Europe and Rio de Janeiro, where he studied law. Fluent in English, Mr. Moreira lived in Washington from 1957 to 1963, where he worked as first secretary in Brazil's Embassy and earned a master's degree in political science from Georgetown University.
At the embassy, Mr. Moreira's mentor was Roberto Campos, then-ambassador and later architect of Brazil's economic boom of the late 1960's.
 
Business Experience Stressed
 Speaking today of his former protege, Mr. Campos, now a congressman, said, "Marcilio has what Collor's team has lacked so far: business experience and international negotiating experience."
Before becoming Brazil's Ambassador to the United States in 1986, Mr. Moreira worked for Unibanco, Brazil's fifth-largest private banking group, rising to become a board member.
"Marcilio is well respected, both as a banker and as a diplomat," William R. Rhodes, a Citibank executive who has led the negotiating committee of Brazil's creditor banks, said today. "He has some of the best connections of any ambassador in Washington."
Reacting favorably to his appointment, the trading price of Brazilian debt paper rose 1.25 cents, to 28.25 cents, on London's secondary debt market.
 
Visit to U.S. in June
 In Washington, the appointment is expected to smooth President Collor's state visit to the United States next month. Reknowned for her abrasive personality, Ms. Cardoso tangled in recent weeks with American officials over Brazil's slow progress on renegotiating its $60 billion foreign debt.
Several business people cautioned that Mr. Moreira would have to name a seasoned team in order to make progress against Brazil's entrenched economic problems.
Today, two members of the new team were named: Francisco Gross, nominee for the presidency of the central bank, replacing Ibrahim Eris, and Joao Santana, new Minister of Infrastructure, succeeding Eduardo Teixeira.
Jorio Dauster, special ambassador for foreign debt negotiations, resigned today but was expecterd to complete negotiations in the next few weeks over Brazil's rescheduling of back due interest on its foreign debt.
In late April, the two protagonists of today's drama displayed radically different styles and spirits in separate interviews in Brasilia.
 
Complexity Acknowledged
 Ms. Cardoso, interviewed in her fifth floor office in the Economy Ministry, appeared tense, tired and irritable.
"The problems were more complex than we imagined when we were out of government," acknowledged the minister, whose elegant lime green business suit and cherry red lipstick contrasted with her gray frame of mind.
On the other side of Brasilia's grassy central mall, at the Foreign Ministry building, Mr. Moreira was the picture of a seasoned diplomat. Balding, dressed in a dark blue suit, he outlined in soft tones the agenda of President Collor's visit to Washington.

HEADLINE: Your Money;
School Vacation Tax Advantages

BYLINE: By Jan M. Rosen

 BODY:
With school holidays approaching, single parents and working couples with young children are scrambling to arrange for their care, while many older students are looking for summer jobs. Both situations can offer opportunities for tax savings.
Working people who pay for child care may be able to take a credit that reduces income taxes dollar for dollar. For people with adjusted gross incomes of $28,000 or more, the maximum is $480 for one child and $960 for two or more, but it is higher for lower-income people -- 30 percent of the money spent up to $4,800 for two or more children for people with incomes below $10,000. 
 To qualify, taxpayers must provide the Social Security number or taxpayer identification number of the person or institution providing the care. The children must be under age 13, and the amount spent cannot exceed the earnings of the lower-income spouse. Only day care is eligible, not overnight camp.
"I advise clients that they have to be sure everything is documented with respect to the care given," said Avery E. Neumark, a partner in the accounting firm of Weber, Lipshie & Company in New York. Sometimes, he said, people feel that if the child attends a camp sponsored by a religious organization, the money paid ought to be deductible as a charitable gift, but he points out that it is not. "It's the same principle as tuition," he said.
A dependent care assistance plan may be even better than the tax credit for families with income above $32,000, Mr. Neumark said. It may be either a stand-alone plan provided by the employer or paid through an employee salary-reduction plan -- that is, a flexible spending account or "cafeteria" plan in which up to $5,000 of compensation can be set aside on a pretax basis for child care. Self-employed people may also be able to set up a flexible spending account. People must choose between the credit and the dependent care plan, Mr. Neumark said, adding, "You can't double-dip."
For a family in a 40 percent marginal bracket for combined Federal, state and local taxes, that would provide a direct tax benefit of $2,000. And with personal exemptions and itemized deductions being phased out for upper-income taxpayers, it helps by lowering adjusted gross income.
Companies normally give employees an opportunity once a year to elect to take part in a flexible spending plan. For those with a June 30 fiscal year, elections may be possible now, said Mr. Neumark, who is also an adjunct professor at the Fordham Graduate School of Business.
An important consideration when the person providing the care is a household employee is that employers must pay their share of Social Security and Medicare taxes, which together equal 7.65 percent, and often state unemployment taxes.
For high school and college students, summer work can be rewarding in a number of ways, and parents are often surprised to learn that it may be tax-free.
"There is a misconception that the kiddie tax is all-encompassing," said Julian Block, a Larchmont, N.Y., tax lawyer and author. That tax applies only to unearned income like dividends and interest paid to children under age 14. Amounts above $1,100 this year are taxed at the parents' rate.
But earned income is taxable at the child's rate, he noted, and with the $3,400 standard deduction in 1991, young people may earn that much and owe no taxes. Earnings above that are taxable at 15 percent, up to $19,450. Parents who provide more than half a child's support may still claim the dependency exemption.
William J. Goldberg, partner in KPMG Peat Marwick in Houston, advised students to "give your employer the address where you are going to be in January," when employers mail out W-2's. Taxes will generally be withheld, and the student will have to file a return with the W-2 attached to get a refund, he said. When students are away at school, the matter sometimes slips through the cracks, he said.
Mr. Block said, "A family that has its own business can hire the child for the summer." For example, he hired his daughter, a college student, to file and type letters. "The break is that you can shift some income," he said, and the student can learn about the business or profession and decide whether to enter it after graduation.
Sole proprietors and husband-wife partnerships are not required to withhold Social Security taxes for children under age 18, he said. But it is important to keep thorough records of wages and hours, he added, and "you can pay no more than you would pay an unrelated employee for the same work." Also, it must be legitimate work within the child's competence.
Of course, Mr. Neumark noted, "Summer plans shouldn't be contingent on deductibility of costs." He added: "If children have an opportunity to work on a kibbutz in Israel or study a foreign language in Switzerland, they shouldn't be deterred. The experience may be worth a lot more than a tax deduction."

HEADLINE: Luxury Tax Under Attack

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 10

 BODY:
Repeal of the luxury tax on expensive cars is a top priority of the American International Automobile Dealers Association, the group's president, Walter Huizenga, said today.
"I've yet to find one member of Congress who says this is sound tax policy," Mr. Huizenga said at a news conference as the group prepared to begin its annual legislative meeting here on Monday. The association represents more than 9,700 foreign-car dealers. 
 Members will also lobby against pending legislation requiring significant fuel-economy improvements and allowing the Bush Administration to negotiate a free-trade pact with Mexico, he said.
The luxury tax was imposed last fall as part of the five-year deficit-reduction law. The tax -- 10 percent of a car's purchase price above $30,000 -- was viewed as a way to get more money from the rich, Mr. Huizenga said. Instead, he said, it has combined with the recession to cut luxury car sales 45 percent in the first quarter.
The dealership closings that resulted have have put 3,700 dealers, mechanics and others out of work, he said, and many more people will lose their jobs unless the tax is rescinded.

HEADLINE: Washington Bank Seized

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 10

 BODY:
Federal bank regulators today seized the Madison National Bank, one of the largest in the Washington area, after declaring it insolvent.
Madison is to be sold to Signet Bank for $18 million. 
 Banking officials estimated that the failure of Madison would ultimately cost the fund that insures deposits almost $150 million. All depositors, even those with uninsured accounts of more than $100,000, will be protected. Madison's shareholders will lose their investments.
The move caps three years of problems at the bank, which had an unusually high concentration of loans for real estate and construction and had been unable to comply with regulatory standards.
Trying to keep Madison afloat, regulators last year permitted the bank to borrow heavily from the Federal Reserve. But the borrowing could not offset the mounting losses on loans to real estate developers and to many of the bank's executives, and the losses eventually exceeded the bank's capital.
"The downturn in the local economy contributed to the bank's problems," the office of the Comptroller of the Currency said in a statement released today. "But Madison National Bank's poor underwriting standards, including making unsecured real estate loans, providing 100 percent financing of real estate projects, and lending based on character rather than cash flow, were major causes of the bank's failure."
The banking company is the sixth largest in Washington. It had assets of $529 million as of Dec. 31.

HEADLINE: NWA Has Loss of $62 Million

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: EAGAN, Minn., May 10

 BODY:
NWA Inc., the parent of Northwest Airlines, said today that it lost $62 million in the first quarter of 1991. It attributed the results to higher fuel prices and lower traffic caused by the recession and the Persian Gulf war.
The loss compared with a $39 million loss a year earlier. The privately held company reported its financial results in a filing required by the Department of Transportation. 
 Operating revenues in the quarter were $1.64 billion, compared with $1.63 billion for the first quarter of 1990, a 1 percent increase, Northwest said. But quarterly operating expenses were $1.76 billion, compared with $1.72 billion a year earlier, a 2 percent increase.
John Dasburg, president and chief executive, said the first quarter "typically produces a loss because of traditionally lower travel demand."
The airline, the nation's fourth largest, suffered a $10 million net loss for 1990, compared with a $355 million profit in 1989. The 1990 figure included a $121 million net loss in the fourth quarter, which the airline said resulted from the Persian Gulf crisis.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
The Dollar Is Mostly Down; Gold Prices Show Declines

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar fell yesterday against all leading currencies except the Japanese yen in quiet trading on world currency markets.
Gold prices declined worldwide. On the New York Commodity Exchange, bullion for current delivery settled at $357.10 an ounce, down $1 from Thursday. The Republic National Bank said gold slipped 85 cents an ounce, to $356.75. 
 Currency dealers said activity was uneventful, with the dollar holding to a relatively narrow trading range.
The dollar got a slight lift early in the session following the Labor Department's report that producer prices rose in April for the first time in five months. The report was interpreted favorably as a sign that inflation was being kept at bay. But because the increase was within expectations, traders said it had no more than a brief impact on the dollar.
"I don't think the fundamentals in the United States justify a sustained upward move for the dollar, so we're in a consolidation mode," said Earl Johnson, a vice president at the Harris Trust and Savings Bank in Chicago.
Mr. Johnson said there was some talk about interest rate cuts in Europe next week, possibly in Italy and Spain, which could give the dollar a slight lift. But traders are also awaiting the release of fresh data on the American economy, including figures for industrial production, consumer prices, business inventories and merchandise trade.
In Tokyo, the dollar rose to a closing 138.58 Japanese yen from 138.23 yen at Thursday's close. Later, in London, it rose to 138.70 yen. In New York, the dollar settled at 138.70 yen, up from 138.10 yen on Thursday.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.7195, from $1.7045 late Thursday. In New York, it cost $1.7245 to buy 1, more expensive than Thursday's $1.7175.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Thursday's rates, included: 1.7230 German marks, down from 1.7325; 1.4550 Swiss francs, down from 1.4630; 5.8280 French francs, down from 5.8585; 1,275.00 Italian lire, down from 1,280.25, and 1.1514 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1526.
Gold fell in London to a late bid price of $356.80 a troy ounce, from $356.95 late Thursday. In Zurich, the metal fell to a closing bid of $356.50, from $356.65 on Wednesday. Markets were closed Thursday for the Ascension Day holiday.
Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell 53 cents to close at a bid $357.67.
Silver prices also lost ground. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery settled at $4.024 a troy ounce, down from $4.050 on Thursday. In London the metal slipped to a late bid price of $4.04 an ounce from $4.07.

HEADLINE: Stocks Wilt in Fallout From Treasury Sale

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
Stocks fell sharply late yesterday, more than erasing Thursday's strong gains. Traders attributed the slide to plunging bond prices.
The Dow, relentlessly tumbling minute by minute throughout the day, sank 50.98 points, or 1.7 percent, to 2,920.17. 
 Ironically, Wall Street traced both Thursday's rise and yesterday's fall to the same thing -- the Treasury's $37 billion refinancing. [Page 38.]
"The stock market rose 40 points on Thursday because we were all so relieved the refunding went so well," said Robert T. Falconer, senior vice president and economist of Aubrey G. Lanston & Company, a leading bond dealer.
"Today," he added, "the stock market dropped 50 points because we realized we had one devil of a bad refunding. Investors didn't show up, and dealers were selling unwanted inventories, and prices plunged."
The blue-chip index also lost 18.69 points for the week, but because of a couple of strong gains earlier in the week, the five-day loss was small.
Showing that yesterday's decline was widespread, the broader-based Standard & Poor's index of the top 500 stocks slid almost 2 percent.
Trading volume on the New York Stock Exchange, turning a bit sluggish, dropped to 172.7 million shares, from 180.2 million the day before. Big Board declines, though, led advances by well over 2 to 1.
In one of the wildest computer-driven selling frenzies, Birinyi Associates, which tracks program trading, said that 10 separate waves of program selling chopped slightly more than 68 points off the Dow. Close to 20 points of the decline came in three big waves between 12:45 and 1:04 P.M.
To prevent the selling from feeding on itself and driving the market down further, the Big Board intervened at 3:23 P.M. -- imposing its so-called 50-point rule for the first time since the middle of last month.
Under the rule, program traders are not permitted to sell unless the price of the stock is the same as or more than the previous price. A similar procedure is used to regulate program buying. While it does not eliminate program trading, imposing the rule almost always halts it.
 
 'A Mammoth Mountain of Bonds'

Explaining what happened, Mr. Falconer said: "There's a mammoth mountain of bonds, and the indigestion you're seeing is that dealers have more than they wanted. And to reduce their holdings -- to encourage institutional investors to buy them -- they've had to lower prices."
When the Treasury needs money, it auctions bonds through a network of primary dealers, who, in turn, resell them to the big investors, like insurers and investment funds.
When dealers studied the resale potential Thursday, in advance of yesterday's Producer Price Index data, the figures were expected to be favorable enough for them to unload the bulk of their inventory.
"We got good numbers," Mr. Falconer said. "They showed inflation slowing. But they were not good enough to ignite buying. And in the absence of buying, you have unwanted inventories."
He explained that dealers would not hold on to inventory because of the risk that interest rates could go up, forcing prices down, "so dealers mark them down."
Further complicating an already difficult day, wild rumors -- regarded now as unfounded -- circulated that California insurance regulators were liquidating a bond portfolio owned by First Capital Holdings, a company 28 percent owned by American Express and its Shearson subsidiary.
Other rumors, discounted as ridiculous, circulated that a bond dealer had failed. There appeared to be little doubt, though, that the bond community had sustained big losses on the refinancing.
Declines among the Dow stocks were widespread.
I.B.M.; Walt Disney; Sears, Roebuck; Chevron, and General Electric all dropped 2 points or more.
Coca-Cola, Exxon, Boeing, Du Pont, J. P. Morgan, Texaco, Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing and Philip Morris all slumped more than a point.
Health care and technology stocks, both strong on Thursday, weakened yesterday.

HEADLINE: Dutch Export Violator Barred on Sales to U.S.

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 10

 BODY:
The Defense Department has for the first time banned a company from doing business with any Federal agency because it reportedly exported high-technology products in violation of American export controls.
The Defense Logistics Agency suspended a Dutch company from bidding for Government contracts after the early results from investigations by the Defense, State and Commerce departments indicated that it had shipped American night-vision equipment to Iraq without first obtaining the Government's permission. 
 The company, Delft Instruments N.V., has been a large seller of medical equipment to the Government, and is now barred from these contracts.
 
 Found on Iraqi Troops
 Some of the night-vision equipment sold by Delft was found on dead and captured Iraqi troops after a battle in Khafji, Saudi Arabia. A night attack by Iraqi forces surprised allied forces there, who had underestimated the Iraqi night-fighting capabilities, and resulted in significant casualties among allied Arab forces.
The suspension represents a hardening of Defense Department policy in the debate over whether the United States should try to increase exports with potential military applications now that the Soviet Union represents a dwindling military threat. The debate pits business and Government officials concerned about the nation's waning economic fortunes against military and civilian officials who want the United States to retain the technological advantage that gave it an easy victory in Kuwait.
 
More Caution Seen

The Defense Department's action against Delft "is new, and it is going to put a lot of companies on edge," said Laura A. Gubisch, the export controls expert at the American Association of Exporters and Importers. Businesses that rely heavily on Government contracts may become even more cautious about what they allow any of their subsidiaries to export, she added. Violators of American export control statutes are already subject to civil and criminal sanctions.
The logistics agency justified the suspension by citing its military acquisition regulations, which are normally used to bar companies for fraud or bribery. The regulations technically allow the Defense Department to suspend any company deemed to have behaved irresponsibly, and the logistics agency decided that a violation of export controls qualified as irresponsible behavior.
The logistics agency explicitly banned Delft from Defense Department contracts. But under a little-known law, a company deemed irresponsible by any single Federal agency is automatically barred from doing business with any other agency of the executive branch.
The Defense Logistics Agency took action against Delft at the request of the Defense Technology Security Agency, said a Defense Department official who spoke on condition of anonymity. The security agency, which seeks to prevent the leakage of American military secrets to foreign powers, has not previously tried to bar companies from doing business with the Government.
Vincent Cusack, the president of the Oldelft Corporation of America, the American arm of Delft Industries, did not return telephone calls seeking comment. Oldelft had sales of $30 million last year, its first year of operation.
The Defense Department's move against Delft, which went into effect without announcement on May 2, may make it much more difficult for companies to export militarily sensitive products, said Stephen D. Bryen, who was the Deputy Under Secretary of Defense for trade security policy from 1981 to 1988 and now runs a small computer software company.
 
Tougher on Curbs

"The Defense Department is more likely to impose these constraints than the Commerce Department, which has not been strong on these sanctions," Mr. Bryen said. The promotion of exports is one of the Commerce Department's main tasks.
A Commerce Department official said his agency had no objection to the Defense Department's action because the night-vision equipment involved was intended for military use. The equipment was on a Government list of munitions that are subject to strict export controls and not on the broader list of technologies with both civilian and military applications, he added. "Honest exporters have nothing to worry about," said the official, who insisted on anonymity.

HEADLINE: Mild Rise in Producer Price Index

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 10

 BODY:
Prices of finished goods as they left the factory rose a mild two-tenths of 1 percent in April, the Labor Department reported today. The report was fresh evidence that the recession is taking the steam out of inflation.
The rise in prices that manufacturers charge for goods sold to wholesalers and distributors was the first after four months of declines. But the increase resulted mostly from flukes in two areas -- fresh vegetables and tobacco products -- rather than from strong demand driving up prices, said Craig Howell, chief for producer prices at the department's Bureau of Labor Statistics. 
 "When you analyze all the items, there is no sign yet of a pickup in the general economy," he said.
 
 Effect on the Fed

The report today and the April performance of the Consumer Price Index, to be released on Tuesday, are likely to ratify the Federal Reserve's decision last week to reduce interest rates to fight the recession. A regular meeting of the Fed's policy makers, known as the Federal Open Market Committee, is set for Tuesday, and the inflation numbers are likely to be a prime topic.
Those Fed officials who had pushed within the central bank for the April 30 rate reductions had expressed the hope then that the two April inflation numbers would be weak enough to help justify the rate cuts when all 17 policy makers held their meeting next week. Some economists also suggested that weak April inflation numbers might prompt the policy makers to favor lowering interest rates another notch to stimulate the economy, although there is skepticism on this point on Wall Street.
"We are seeing some inflation dividend out of the recession," said Richard B. Berner, chief economist at Salomon Brothers. "Now the issue is whether we will sustain the apparently lower level of inflation."
 
 The Core Rate

Through April, the Producer Price Index for Finished Goods has risen only 3.2 percent in a year. That is roughly half the annual rate of increase in the final months of last year. Even excluding volatile food and energy prices -- to get at what economists consider the core rate of inflation -- the index has risen a relatively mild 3.7 percent in the last 12 months. The April increase, without food and energy, was also two-tenths of 1 percent.
Consumer prices -- almost always higher than producer prices because they include the cost of health care and other services -- have declined since late last year, but not as sharply as producer prices. The March Consumer Price Index showed a decline of one-tenth of 1 percent, the first monthly drop since 1986. The 12-month rate of increase through March was 4.9 percent.
Among producer goods ready for consumption, three items -- fresh vegetables, tobacco products and prescription drugs -- rose with unexpected sharpness. The increases in vegetable prices -- onions up 83 percent, sweet corn 36 percent and tomatoes 29 percent, for example -- came because spring supplies from California that usually appear in quantity by April failed to do so this year, Mr. Howell said.
Tobacco product prices, usually increased by the industry at the beginning and in the middle of each year, rose 2.7 percent in April, perhaps reflecting concerns arising from various legal actions against tobacco companies, Mr. Howell said. Prescription drugs rose 2.3 percent, an unusual jump for a product category in which the average price has risen 8.6 percent in the last year. The drug companies cited research and development costs, Mr. Howell said.
The prices of nearly all other items either rose only mildly, or fell. Men's, women's and children's apparel, for example, all rose three-tenths of 1 percent or less, the Labor Department reported. Light trucks, cars, books, computers, dies, textile machinery and most other types of capital equipment all fell in price, with light trucks down 2.2 percent and cars two-tenths of 1 percent.
While the Producer Price Index rose, two other indexes fell. One, measuring the prices of intermediate goods like flour, synthetic fibers, leather and car parts, fell four-tenths of 1 percent in April, the fifth monthly decline. The other, measuring crude goods prices for products like wheat, cattle hides, leaf tobacco and logs, dropped five-tenths of 1 percent in April, the third monthly decline.
The indexes say the recession continued in April, said Joel Popkin, a consultant, "but the decline in the prices of things that producers buy is not yet reflected in what retailers charge for consumer goods."

HEADLINE: Detroit's Assault on Mileage Bill

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, May 10

 BODY:
The American auto industry, a perennial straggler in Washington regulatory battles, has been waging an uncharacteristically effective fight against proposed legislation to make cars and trucks much more fuel efficient.
The focus of the campaign is a bill sponsored by Senator Richard H. Bryan, a Nevada Democrat, that would raise the corporate average fuel-economy standard, known as CAFE, to 40 miles a gallon, from the current 27.5, over 10 years. The Bryan bill has cleared the Senate Commerce Committee and awaits action by the full Senate. Similar bills have been proposed in the House. 
 Auto makers contend that if the bill became law, it would shoehorn Americans into tiny cars akin to today's Geo Metro and eliminate production of full-size models. President Bush, whose economic advisers prefer a market approach to reducing fuel consumption, has promised to veto the measure.
 
 Supporters Back Off
 As industry pressure against the bill has grown more intense, even some of the bill's original supporters are beginning to back away. One of its co-sponsors, Senator Dale Bumpers, Democrat of Arkansas, has said he is no longer sure the bill's efficiency goals are feasible.
But even if the Bryan bill fails, auto makers fear that fuel-efficiency initiatives will permanently remain on Congress's agenda.
In the past, Detroit's efforts in Washington have mostly been limited to lobbying, and more often than not, the attempts have fallen flat. But this time, the industry has geared up a grass-roots lobbying and education effort, called the Coalition for Vehicle Choice, to argue against far-reaching fuel-efficiency standards.
Headed by Diane Steed, a former head of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, the lobbying group has attracted constituencies as diverse as tool and die makers, cattlemen and campground owners, who are willing to rally around the comfort and hauling capacity of the large car and truck. "Traditionally, debates like this have been between Congress and the auto industry," said Ron DeFore, a spokesman for the coalition. "We think we are making a tremendous difference."
Environmental and conservation groups disagree with Detroit, producing studies suggesting that technological changes could significantly improve fuel efficiency without sacrificing much of the size or usefulness of vehicles.
"The auto industry has been crying wolf for decades," said Dan Becker, the Sierra Club's director of energy programs. "Back in 1974, when the first CAFE bill was being discussed, Ford said we'd all be driving Pintos and Mavericks if it got passed." The Sierra Club asserts that the Bryan bill will save the country 2.5 million barrels of oil a day and that vehicles will remain about the same size.
The Center for Auto Safety, a nonprofit research foundation that is often critical of auto makers, published a report last month suggesting that safety would not be compromised by strict economy standards. Its findings contradict those of the Department of Transporation, which said the Bryan bill would lead to smaller cars and more highway deaths. The Insurance Institute for Highway Safety, which is supported by the insurance industry, agrees.
The auto industry's grass-roots and special-interest organizing infuriates the opposition, which has used similar tactics in the name of tougher regulation. Clarence M. Ditlow, executive director of the Center for Auto Safety, dismissed the Coalition for Vehicle Choice as "an industry front that only gives the appearance of a broad-based coalition." And Mr. Ditlow accused Ms. Steed of "weakening fuel-efficiency standards when she was in charge of N.H.T.S.A."
 
 Under Study by Experts

Most lawmakers lack the technical expertise to evaluate which side is right, so the Department of Transportation has enlisted a committee of the National Academy of Sciences to determine what standards are technically and economically feasible. The panel hopes to submit its findings by June 30, although the process could drag through the summer.
The crux of the auto makers' brief is that average fuel efficiency has doubled since 1975 and that few technological innovations remain that could bolster efficiency as quickly as the Bryan bill would require. Indeed, the size and weight of the average car has shrunk since 1975, and fuel efficiency has doubled. As cars and engines got smaller, Detroit says, many consumers simply switched to roomier trucks and truck-like vehicles, which conform to more liberal fuel-efficiency standards.
Most cars already have front-wheel drive, which reduces weight and delivers power to the wheels more efficiency, and enhanced aerodynamics, which reduces wind resistance. Adding refinements to those designs and other improvements, like tire innovations, will gradually raise the fleet average, but not by the 40 percent envisioned by the Bryan bill over the next decade, auto makers say.
The politics of CAFE are complex and only partly related to the question of whether imposing fuel efficiency on auto makers effectively promotes conservation. Although the Bush Administration damaged the Bryan bill's chances for passage by promising a veto, the bill's backers hold something the Administration wants: support for expanded oil and gas drilling in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge in Alaska.
Lobbyists and political strategists say the Administration may be willing to trade support for higher fuel-efficiency standards in return for expanded drilling rights in Alaska. Such a swap could be carried out in an energy bill sponsored by Senators J. Bennett Johnston, Democrat of Louisiana, and Malcolm Wallop, Republican of Wyoming. That bill is being debated in the Senate.
Lawmakers, Administration officials and those trying to increase economy standards concede privately that higher gasoline taxes are vital to reducing consumption. But rather than impose a direct tax on constituents, lawmakers like Mr. Bryan prefer that auto makers raise prices to pay for technological breakthroughs.
The auto makers decline to say what increase in CAFE would be technically and economically feasible. They want the power to raise fuel-efficiency standards assigned to the Transportation Department, rather than let Congress decide them. The law, therefore, would force auto makers to improve fuel efficiency continually, but in small increments that the Secretary of Transportation would control. Detroit thinks those rules would be easier to take.

HEADLINE: Focusing on Welfare

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 10

 BODY:
President Bush has struck a partisan blow against critics who accuse him of having no domestic policy: He has denounced Lyndon B. Johnson's Great Society. By doing so he also invigorated a national debate about what type of social welfare programs the nation needs, and how effective other Presidents have been in combating poverty and racial bias.
The heart of the debate is political. Mr. Bush delivered his rebuff in a speech at the University of Michigan in Ann Arbor last Saturday, laying a foundation for domestic policy debate in the 1992 Presidential campaign. He knows that many voters share his opposition to racial quotas, and he knows there are few votes to be had in defending welfare recipients. 
 Mr. Bush's comments on the Great Society came in an address in which he warned that free speech rights were under assault on many college campuses. The President defended both free speech and "freedom of spirit," saying the Great Society had discouraged individuals from performing good works by overemphasizing the role of Government in social policy.
Mr. Bush said Johnson's crusade against poverty had backfired, saying its civil rights programs had "generated animosity" and its welfare programs had made poor people dependent on Government.
 
Embedded in Social Fabric
 In his remarks, Mr. Bush ignored the fact that much of the Great Society has been accepted and embedded in the nation's social fabric: Federal aid for elementary and secondary schools, the Voting Rights Act of 1965, the Fair Housing Act of 1968, Medicare for the elderly, Medicaid for the poor, a nationwide food stamp program, automobile safety and consumer protection laws.
The President's speech pointedly omitted any praise for Great Society programs that Mr. Bush has lauded, like Head Start and a number of environmental laws. Perhaps unintentionally, Mr. Bush's comments revived debate over the merit of those programs. Supporters of the Great Society say it drastically reduced the number of poor people. Critics insist that it fostered a culture of dependency.
The President's criticism of the Great Society was sweeping and unqualified. But Mr. Bush's main speechwriter, Tony Snow, who drafted the address, acknowledged in an interview that the Bush Administration's judgment of the Great Society was actually more complex and nuanced than the speech suggested.
Mr. Snow, 35 years old, a former editor of the editorial page at The Washington Times, said he had been troubled to hear radio reports that Mr. Bush had attacked the Great Society. Mr. Bush conceded that "the ideals behind the Great Society were noble," but he said the programs were not "up to the task," and he concluded that "we need to rethink our approach" to poverty and discrimination.
Mr. Bush, in his speech, sought to lay the groundwork for the Republican domestic agenda in the 1992 Presidential campaign, a campaign in which Republicans will assail Democrats as members of the party of old ideas.
Mr. Bush's indictment of the Great Society surprised some experts. Joseph A. Califano Jr., for instance, who worked for Johnson at the White House from 1965 through 1968, said, "Mr. Bush doesn't know his history."
 
'Redistribute Opportunity'
 In a telephone interview from London, Mr. Califano said, "The goal of the Great Society was to redistribute opportunity and wealth and to empower poor people."
Empowerment is a theme in vogue among Bush appointees like Housing Secretary Jack F. Kemp and James P. Pinkerton, a White House policy planner. And Mr. Bush has often alluded to the notion that poor people should have more control over public housing and other Government benefits.
Mr. Bush delivered his speech at the site where Johnson articulated his vision of the Great Society 27 years ago. Speaking in a time of prosperity and economic growth, Johnson said, "We have the opportunity to move not only toward the rich society and the powerful society, but upward to the Great Society," and he declared his commitment to end poverty and racial injustice "in our time."
What Johnson did not envision was that the Vietnam War would eat up so much of the nation's resources.
Nonetheless, by virtually all accounts, the Great Society helped improve the lives and financial security of the elderly, in part through a big increase in Social Security benefits. By most accounts, Medicare and Medicaid have succeeded in providing health care for the elderly and the poor, though at far greater cost than Johnson could ever have imagined.
 
A Question of Dependency
 But there has been bitter debate over whether the Great Society's main cash welfare program, Aid to Families With Dependent Children, tends to foster dependency. Timothy M. Smeeding, a professor of economics at Syracuse University, is among those who say it does.
But Greg J. Duncan, a professor of economics at the University of Michigan who has followed the income of 7,500 families for two decades, said: "There is no evidence from our data that dependency is any greater problem now than in the early 1970's, when Great Society programs reached their peak. There is no evidence of an increase in the proportion of children dependent on welfare."
In the speech, Mr. Bush proposed to replace the Great Society with a "good society," in which individuals perform private acts of common decency, becoming "points of light." Mr. Bush's speech and his domestic policy indicate that his vision of Government's role in fighting poverty is much more modest than Johnson's; it omits the idea of the Government as helper and savior that inspired Johnson.

HEADLINE: Rates Climb in an Unsettled Market

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
Long-term interest rates soared yesterday as the Treasury securities market was unsettled by fact and rumor. After shrugging off a modest rise in the April Producer Price Index, dealers began shaving prices of Treasury notes and bonds they had bought at this week's quarterly refunding auction.
Given the less than enthusiastic bidding for the 30-year bonds that wrapped up the auctions on Thursday and the tepid response to the note sale the previous day, dealers said they wanted to cut their inventory before the weekend. 
 Also during the morning, the Treasury debt market was buoyed by the residual buying occasioned by the covering of short positions taken by dealers and other prospective bidders as a hedge against a decline in the value of the securities they plan to bid for.
 
 Rumor From California

But the price shaving turned to price slashing late in the session on a rumor that California had ordered the liquidation of the large bond portfolio of the First Capital Life Insurance Company. State officials said later that options being discussed with outside directors of First Capital Holdings, the insurer's parent, included the reduction of the "junk bond" portfolio,
"Normally the rumor would have not had much effect, except that it was Friday afternoon and the market wanted to forget the refunding and go home," said Alan R. Leslie, chief economist at the Discount Corporation of New York. "As for the refunding, it wasn't as terrible as some had predicted before the auction. Even after today's selloff, the long bond's yield is well below the yield of 8.40 that many in the Street had predicted would be needed to draw retail interest."
As it was, late trading found the outstanding Treasury long bonds, the 7 7/8 percent issue maturing in February 2021, being offered at 94 29/32, down 1 6/32, while its yield soared to 8.34 percent, from 8.21 percent the day before and 8.22 percent a week ago.
Treasury bond prices plunged even lower in Chicago's futures market. The spot June Treasury bond futures contract plummeted 1.11, to 94 24/32.
In the cash market, the refunding issues auctioned this week will continue to trade on a when-issued basis until the May 15 settlement date, when the buyers at the auctions pay for their securities.
On this basis, the $13.75 billion of the usually popular three-year Treasury notes auctioned Tuesday and carrying a 7 percent coupon traded late in the day at 99 20/32, off 3/32, for a yield of 7.14 percent. The average at the sale was 7.09 percent.
The $11.75 billion of 8 percent 10-year notes that sold on Wednesday at an average yield of 8.07 percent traded at 99 11/32, to yield 8.09 percent.
But the new 8 1/8 percent 30-year bonds bore the brunt of the late selloff, dropping 1 6/32, to 98, while their yield soared to 8.30 percent from the auction average of 8.21 percent.
At the short end of the Treasury maturity spectrum, discount rates on bills were mixed. The 90-day bill rate fell 4 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 5.44 percent; six-month bills were unchanged at 5.62 percent, and the one-year bills added a basis point, at 5.75 percent.
Normally, the Treasury bill market responds to moves by the Federal Reserve. Yesterday, the Fed moved to drain reserves from the banking system. Mr. Leslie said the Fed's move, which was expected, was prompted by what the central bank thought was excessive liquidity in the banking system.
A key measure of this liquidity is the Federal funds rate, which banks charge one another for temporary loans and from which most other interest rates are scaled up. The funds traded at 5 5/8 percent for most of the day, below the Fed's perceived target of 5 3/4 percent, and closed at 5 1/2 percent. As usual late on Friday, demand shriveled.
 
 Liquidity Explanation

Douglas P. Handler, an economist at the Dun & Bradstreet Corporation, offered a possible explanation for the liquidity in the banking system.
"The biggest source of credit is still the credit that merchants receive from suppliers," Mr. Handler said. "The quality of this credit is closely monitored by bankers and other lenders. In any case, we found that at the end of 1990, $64 billion of the credit extended by suppliers, banks and other credit providers to vendors was delinquent, nonperforming or not being serviced promptly."
At the end of the first quarter of this year, Mr. Handler added, "these nonperforming supplier and other credits had increased by 74 percent."

HEADLINE: A Reckoning For Dinkins

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
In proposing the darkest budget New York City has seen since its brush with bankruptcy 16 years ago, Mayor David N. Dinkins said yesterday, "No one is to blame for this crushing burden." But it is weighted by bundles this Mayor chose to carry.
 "To suggest that we are in this fix because of actions of our own is not accurate," Mr. Dinkins said, noting that recession and punishing cuts in state and Federal aid have robbed his city of resources. 
 But the Mayor is also a prisoner of the competing priorities to which he committed himself in one fateful week last fall: granting raises to city workers and hiring thousands of new police officers.
The cost of those moves would amount to almost $800 million for the coming fiscal year, though Mr. Dinkins argues that he has access to some of that money precisely because he did what he did. And if he did not spend at least some of it, workers would get no raises at all and the Police Department would have shrunk by about 2,000 officers next year.
But even half the $800 million could avert the worst of the $2 billion in spending cuts -- from closing health clinics and libraries to suspending recycling -- that he now says he needs to keep the $28.7 billion budget balanced as required by law.
"The chickens of October have come home to roost in May," said Henry Stern, president of the Citizens Union, one of the city's oldest nonprofit civic groups.
Mr. Dinkins refuses to repudiate the labor settlements, but he effectively retreated from them yesterday, calling for more than 20,000 layoffs to pressure most municipal unions to make wage or benefit concessions that could soften the sharpest service cuts.
Paradoxically, the Mayor would end up rewarding one large union that did not support his candidacy -- the police -- because he refuses to waver from his plan to hire thousands of police officers and expand the justice system, which he undertook after blaring headlines about a spate of frightening crimes last summer combined with criticism of his subdued response to force his hand.
 
'We Have Done Something'
 "I know this audience remembers the summer of '90 when the tabloids headlined 'Dave, Do Something' -- people are dying, so do something," Mr. Dinkins told reporters at City Hall. "We have done something and I modestly say done it damn well, and we are going to stick with that the best we can."
Now the question is whether Mr. Dinkins did too much.
It may be the most poignant conundrum of his progressive platform that the city's first black mayor -- who has been asked over and over by both critics and supporters to prove himself -- is now proposing to prove himself by closing the shelters for the homeless and infant mortality programs he fought for, to hire police officers, which are among the most routine of city expenses.
Mr. Dinkins had vowed in his campaign to be "the toughest mayor on crime that this city has ever seen."
But, as one longtime senior adviser said yesterday, "He couldn't get by on rhetoric, like Koch did," referring to Mr. Dinkins's outspoken precedessor, who failed in 12 years to reach the police hiring goal Mr. Dinkins is now pledged to reach in six. "He wasn't seen as true blue."
First Deputy Mayor Norman Steisel said: "The public wanted security. The Mayor fought hard to put this together and he feels its very important to stick with it. There are people who are questioning that now."
To be sure, shelters are of little help if people feel unsafe on the streets, and Mr. Dinkins would use the new officers to support Police Commissioner Lee P. Brown's expansive vision of "community patrol," which emphasizes a return to neighborhood beats and requires a large staff.
The Mayor is also quick to note that the police hiring plan (which also includes programs for youth) is supported by $168 million in special taxes and a new lottery game reserved for that purpose. He won the money after bruising negotiations with the City Council and the State Legislature, and said he might not have won it for less politically popular programs.
But that is only part of the story. Getting the special taxes locks Mr. Dinkins into spending money from the regular budget, too. That is because the legislation approving the new taxes requires Mr. Dinkins to meet fixed police hiring targets by certain dates or lose the new revenues. And he can only meet those goals by going ahead with the level of police hiring that was already planned for the coming year -- replacing 1,700 retirees and adding 1,200 recruits.
That will cost $40 million -- money he must spend to be assured of getting the $168 million.
The true cost of labor settlements already reached and projected also has two parts. Mr. Dinkins says that the direct cost to the city was for a 1.5 percent raise, or about $320 million in the coming year. But the raises were supplemented by raising the assumptions for how much workers' pension funds will earn, which allows the city to reduce its contributions to the funds by about $250 million in the coming year.
The administration needed the unions' support to make the change in pension earnings assumptions, and Mr. Dinkins has repeatedly said he could not have obtained such support without agreeing to use the money for raises. On the other hand, the administration could have chosen to bargain harder, offering to use the pension money to avoid layoffs.
But mayoral aides contend that would not have been acceptable to the unions last fall, when the depth of the city's slide was less clear and the Mayor's decision to pursue both raises and hiring agendas at once made it hard for union leaders to persuade their members that the city was strapped.
For his part, bound by the tight oversight imposed on the city's finances after the fiscal crisis of the mid-1970's, Mr. Dinkins was defensive yesterday.
"It is important to understand that cuts are forced upon us," he said. "If you wish to argue that which cuts to do are mine, I accept that responsibility with every expectation and every hope that it will be recognized that we ought not have to do any of these things."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Companies
A new Federal law requiring drug makers to cut their prices to Medicaid programs has touched off efforts by virtually every other major purchaser to control the costs of prescription drugs. These efforts represent the most serious challenge yet to the ability of drug makers to keep raising prices far ahead of inflation. [Page 1.] 
 California regulators placed sharp restrictions on First Capital Life, the second time in a month they have moved against a large insurer burdened with a deteriorating portfolio of "junk bonds." [35.] Shearson, which has a 28 percent stake in First Capital, said it would take a charge to earnings of about $144 million. [36.]
Saturn made the unprecedented offer to replace 1,836 cars with faulty engine cooling systems. It was the second setback in three months for G.M.'s bid to make and market a small car that can compete against the Japanese. [35.]
Drexel filed terms of a reorganization plan under which it would emerge from bankruptcy as a new, much smaller company. About $2.1 billion would be distributed. [35.]
The Defense Department has for the first time banned a company, Delft Instruments of the Netherlands, from doing business with any Federal agency because it is said to have exported high-technology products in violation of U.S. export controls. [36.]
Continental and Pirelli said they would resume merger talks. The move by two of Europe's largest tire makers followed the recent resignation of Continental's chairman. [37.]
U.P.S. is leaving Greenwich, Conn., for the same reason it came 16 years ago: housing prices. [1.]
As phone companies blanket the country with offers of new services, many customers are confused. Consumer's World. [48.]
 
The Economy
Prices of finished goods rose a mild 0.2 percent in April, the Labor Department said. The report was fresh evidence that the recession is taking the steam out of inflation. [35.]
Detroit has been waging an unusually effective fight against proposed legislation to make cars and trucks much more fuel-efficient. The focus of the campaign is a bill that would raise average fuel economy to 40 miles a gallon. [35.]
Robert L. Clarke said he would put his investments in a blind trust in an effort to "lay to rest" questions about his financial affairs. The Comptroller of the Currency has been at the center of a controversy over investments in stocks and "junk bonds." [7.]
 
Markets
Stocks fell sharply, more than erasing strong gains on Thursday. Traders attributed the slide to plunging bond prices. The Dow sank 50.98, to 2,920.17. [35.]
Long-term interest rates soared as the Treasury securities market was unsettled by fact and rumor. After shrugging off a modest rise in producer prices, dealers began shaving prices of Treasury notes and bonds they had bought at the refunding auction. [38.]
The dollar fell against all leading currencies except the yen in quiet trading. Gold prices declined. [43.]
Wheat prices bounded higher after the Agriculture Department released a lower-than-expected estimate for the United States winter wheat crop. [43.]

With summer coming, some parents are scrambling to arrange child care, while many older students are looking for summer jobs. Both can offer opportunities for tax savings. Your Money. [36.]
A machine resembling an automated teller that lets customers check out videotapes 24 hours a day has been patented by a small Connecticut company. Patents. [36.]

HEADLINE: U.S. Will Cite Manhattan for Soot Level

BYLINE: By ALLAN R. GOLD

 BODY:
After three years of monitoring bus and truck fumes on Madison Avenue, the Federal Government is preparing to cite New York City for violating health standards for the city's most visible form of pollution: soot.
The finding would give the city -- the diesel-bus capital of the nation -- until Dec. 31, 1997, to reduce soot levels in Manhattan. City and state officials said they would try to meet the standards through a variety of measures, including buying buses that burn cleaner fuels. 
 Another approach would be expanding the use of soot traps on diesel buses. And state officials say the city could also consider restrictions on truck access to mid-Manhattan, although attempts to impose traffic restrictions to comply with Federal health standards for ozone and carbon monoxide -- both of which the city has already been found to violate -- have failed repeatedly. If compliance is not reached, the Government could impose sanctions, such as cutting off Federal highway grants, although such measures are rarely invoked.
 
Madison Ave. at 47th St.
 The soot problem in mid-Manhattan is attributed mainly to emissions from diesel engines on trucks and buses. Toxic particles in the black smoke become trapped between tall buildings lining the streets, causing or aggravating respiratory problems. The Federal Government has identified the particles as a probable cause of cancer.
Air quality monitoring on Madison Avenue at 47th Street, which is one of the busiest bus thoroughfares in Manhattan, has shown annual violations since 1988, environmental officials say.
"While everyone on the street knows the diesel buses and trucks smell bad, this is the first formal Government step to acknowledge this public health problem," said Eric A. Goldstein, a senior lawyer with the Natural Resources Defense Council, a nonprofit environmental group.
Government officials say they will formally designate Manhattan as a violator in July.
State and city environmental officials acknowledge that Federal standards are violated in Manhattan but say that the standards can be attained by the 1997 deadline. "We're not that far out of attainment," said Thomas C. Jorling, the state's Environmental Conservation Commissioner.
The soot levels measured exceeded the standards by 14 percent in 1988, by 32 percent in 1989 and by 10 percent in 1990, according to figures from the Environmental Protection Agency.
The cost of a soot control program is uncertain. But it will be closely related to the price tag for gradually converting the city's bus fleet to fuels that burn more cleanly, said Albert F. Appleton, the city's Environmental Protection Commissioner.
Both Mr. Jorling and Mr. Appleton said the compliance plan would include wider use of buses powered by cleaner-burning fuels like natural gas and methanol. Mr. Jorling also said the plan could require better inspection and maintenance for diesel vehicles, stricter enforcement of vehicle-idling regulations and limits on the hours that trucks may use city streets.
 
Soot Traps on Buses
 One corrective step taken by the Transit Authority involves equipping new buses with pollution-control devices that trap 85 percent of soot particles before they are emitted. But questions have been raised by public and private environmental experts about whether these devices are durable enough to offer a long-term solution to soot and other air pollution problems.
The Transit Authority has responded that it is monitoring developments in alternative-fuels technology but that the emissions traps are the best and most economical technology available for controlling soot.
The Transit Authority operates 3,600 diesel buses while private companies run several thousand more. In addition, 10,000 diesel trucks are registered in the city, and thousands more enter and leave each day.
Diesel engines have been popular because they are more durable than those powered by gasoline, fuel is cheaper and, until recently emissions standards were less stringent. But they are far dirtier, emitting 30 to 70 times as many particles as gasoline engines, the Environmental Protection Agency said.
Soot violations in Manhattan have been recorded only recently because the Federal Government began using a new standard in 1987 that addresses smaller particles. These particles -- less than 10 microns, or one-tenth the width of a human hair -- have been found most likely to produce health problems because they can pass through the body's natural filters in the nose and mouth and lodge in the lungs.
 
Emissions Standards
 Even if the Government did not force new soot control measures, New York City air would probably have still become cleaner through recently passed national and city pollution legislation.
The Federal Clean Air Act Amendments of 1990 calls for much stricter emissions standards on new diesel bus engines beginning in the 1993 model year and another tightening the following year. And Mayor David N. Dinkins signed legislation last January requiring the city to begin purchasing vehicles, including buses, using fuels that burn more cleanly than gasoline.
For now, the Transit Authority has purchased 400 buses, more than 10 percent of the fleet, equipped with the special soot emissions control devices, called trap oxidizers. A Transit Authority maintenance official, John Walsh, said the devices would permit new city buses to comply with the strictest Federal soot emissions standards.

HEADLINE: U.P.S. Is Latest to See Prices Diminish the Lure of Suburbs

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GREENWICH, Conn., May 10

 BODY:
When the United Parcel Service moved its corporate headquarters here in 1975, it was part of an exodus of companies fleeing the high costs of living and working in New York City.
This week, United Parcel Service officials announced that they were moving again, this time to Atlanta. But it was for much the same reason. The company said the chief reason it planned to move 1,000 employees was that the cost of suburban housing that offered a welcome refuge two decades ago had risen so much. 
 "We are right back to facing what we wanted to escape from when we left the city," said the company's chairman, Kent C. Nelson, noting that housing costs in Fairfield County are double those in Atlanta.
The median price of a home in the Atlanta area in the first three months of this year, according to the National Association of Realtors, was $86,000. The median price of a single-family home in southwestern Connecticut was $165,100 and the median price of homes sold in Greenwich during the last year is $480,000, according to the Greenwich Board of Realtors.
Housing prices like those, Mr. Nelson said, force many employees transferred here to lower their standards of living by buying smaller homes than the ones they had given up, or by commuting an hour or more from Danbury, Trumbull and other towns on the outer rim of the metropolitan area.
"The sentiment is that most of the employees are looking forward to it," said Robert Kenney, a spokesman for the company. "The cost of living here is extremely high."
"I'm real positive about it," said Leroy W. Daniel, a computer technician who lives in Yonkers and has been with the company for six years. "Overall, the feelings are mixed. A lot of the younger people without any ties to the area think it's a great opportunity. Some of the others who have ties to the area aren't so sure."
The move comes as the appeal of lower Fairfield County, which is home to more than two dozen Fortune 500 companies, is changing.
The area is still attractive to small-to-medium-sized companies and larger ones with ties to Manhattan. For example, the Morgan Stanley Group, a securities firm with 4,200 employees, has been negotiating for months to move from midtown Manhattan to downtown Stamford. And on Friday, the Macmillan publishing house announced plans to move its headquarters from Third Avenue and 52d Street to downtown Greenwich.
 
Other Companies Slip Out
 But for companies that moved here in the 1970's and 1980's, growing traffic congestion and some of the most expensive housing in the nation have tarnished the county's luster. GTE, for example, has been paring down its presence in Stamford for years, moving employees to Plano, Tex. And at least 10 large corporations, including Conoco, Kennecott, the Continental Group and the Singer Company, have moved their headquarters out of the area or sharply cut their operations because of mergers and takeovers.
In March, the office vacancy rate for Fairfield County was among the highest in the nation: 26.9 percent, largely a result of overbuilding in the 1980's.
"It is always a reason to be glum when a company leaves the area, especially one the size of U.P.S.," said Joseph M. Ercolano, vice president for economic development for the Southwestern Area Commerce and Industry Association, a Stamford-based business-advocacy group.
But the company's departure, which could add hundreds more homes to brokers' "For Sale" listings, is not expected to seriously hurt the glutted Greenwich housing market because only "a handful" of United Parcel Service employees can afford to live in Greenwich, Mr. Kenney said.
Bett McCarthy, executive vice president of the Greenwich Board of Realtors, suggested that it would have a greater impact elsewhere in Fairfield County and in Westchester.
 
Impact May Be Diluted
 But Ormond G. Farris, the head broker at the Century 21 A&B Realty office in Stamford, said the impact even on the region's severely glutted market would be diluted by the wide area in which U.P.S. employees live. He said there are already 1,400 homes and condominiums on the market in Stamford alone. "The homes of U.P.S. people are scattered around," he said. "It is not like there are 500 homes going on the market in Stamford. That would be a disaster."
The loss of the company is more likely to be felt by Greenwich charities. U.P.S. is the city's largest donor and has given as much as $3 million a year to them, including the United Way and the Greenwich Hospital. "They are wonderful corporate citizens, and Greenwich will dearly miss them," Ms. McCarthy said.
The company has not yet picked a site in Atlanta for its headquarters, Mr. Nelson said.
But it must move, Mr. Nelson said, because it is becoming difficult to keep administrators, especially if they were being transferred from the Midwest or South, despite salary differentials and perquisites paid by the company to resettled employees. Worldwide, United Parcel Service employs 245,000 people. It was in New York for 45 years before moving to Greenwich in 1975.
"I was just in Louisville and people there told me they were dreading facing buying a home in Connecticut if they were fortunate enough to be promoted," Mr. Nelson said.
He said other factors, like airports, cultural amenities, similarity of landscape and lifestyle also influenced the decision. But the growing tax burden in Connecticut and the increasing clamor for a state income tax was not a factor. Georgia has a state income tax.
Mr. Nelson said that Dallas, Baltimore and Cincinnati were the runner-ups. Florida, he said, was ruled out because its resort image is not appropriate for the company.
The company, which is owned by its employees, plans to begin moving workers to the Atlanta this fall.
