HEADLINE: DINKINS PRESENTS '92 BUDGET, VOWING TO BAR TAKEOVER

BYLINE: By JOSH BARBANEL

 BODY:
A somber and sometimes angry Mayor David N. Dinkins presented a worst-case New York City budget yesterday filled with sharp tax increases, searing service cuts and more than 20,000 layoffs and declared that he was committed to carrying it all out if necessary to stave off a takeover of city finances by a state oversight agency.
"The nearly eight million people who are privileged to call this great city home must decide whether we shall make our own destiny or have another destiny forced upon us," Mr. Dinkins said at a City Hall news conference. 
 With charts mounted on an easel by his side, he laid out the specter of $1 billion in tax increases and cuts ranging from the shutdown of all municipal swimming pools to the elimination of infant-mortality-prevention programs to close a $3.5 billion budget gap for the fiscal year that begins on July 1.
 
Council Opposition Likely
 The budget presented by Mr. Dinkins, which faces a potential fight in the City Council, would be 2.6 percent larger than this year's, bringing it to $28.7 billion, the smallest increase in years. It is far below the 7 percent growth projected between last year's budget and the current one, even after months of budget-cutting and alarms about a possible deficit.
Property taxes would rise by $776 million next year and by more than $500 million a year in each of the next three years, increases that have sparked a protest movement in the real-estate field. Taxes on a house with a market value of $170,000 would go up by $227 next year, to $1,570.
Personal income tax increases would rise by another $200 million, with the maximum rate going to 4.3 percent from 3.9, costing a family with $100,000 income $260 more next year. A family with a $50,000 income would pay $76 more.
 
New Tax on Autos
 A new 1 percent tax on the value of automobiles would raise $45 million and expanding the sales tax to cover cable television, airline food and the trade-in value of automobiles would raise $45 million.
City officials attributed virtually the entire growth in the budget to an $800 million increase in debt service, mainly a result of bond refinancings and other fiscal sleights of hand that had temporarily cut those costs in the current budget.
Other spending on city services would remain nearly constant, with the cost of an ambitious expansion of the police force, wage increases for city workers and higher welfare costs offset by layoffs and spending cuts, including a 42 percent cut in staffing at the Parks Department.
Some cuts were less heralded. The Board of Education, which avoided a large cut this year, was hit with far deeper cuts next year. Because it is an independent agency, the details of the cuts would be decided by the board.
But with the hiring of police and correction officers continuing next year, the total number of city employees would decline by only 8,357 from the 241,794 on the payroll when Mr. Dinkins took office on Jan. 1, 1990, a roll-back that would reduce the payroll only to the levels of three years ago.
 
Looking for Concessions
 Yesterday Mr. Dinkins, seeking to dampen concern, said the city had successfully closed a $465 million gap calculated under its accounting system for the current fiscal year and would also have enough cash on hand to pay its bills. But he warned that if the State Legislature failed to adopt a long-delayed state budget by May 25, the city could have difficulty selling $600 million in bonds, which in turn could create an immediate cash problem.
After months of concern and complaints that the Mayor had not cut spending enough and with growing urgency over the city's balancing its budget, Mr. Dinkins put out his dire plan with the hope of wresting concessions from union leaders, state aid from Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, and surplus cash and the proceeds of bond refinancings from a state agency, the Municipal Assistance Corporation.
But yesterday Mr. Dinkins angrily insisted that the need for deep cuts was real and that the cuts would begin immediately as part of his commitment to do whatever was necessary to maintain control of the city's finances. A memo to city commissioners ordered them to identify workers to be laid off within a week so that they could be off the payroll by the end of the fiscal year.
Asked if some of the service cuts were merely a ploy, Mr. Dinkins, a touch of anger in his voice, said: "The process begins now. Now is upon us, and those who think this is some kind of exercise are mistaken."
 
Blaming Washington
 Later when a reporter suggested that the Mayor's own policies might be to blame in part for the city's current problems, Mr. Dinkins strenously disagreed and turned a finger of blame to cuts in Federal aid to cities.
"To suggest that we are in this fix because of actions of our own is not accurate," Mr. Dinkins said.
And even as Mr. Dinkins announced his plan, the City Council, which has the power to modify and approve the budget, dissented. The Speaker of the Council, Peter F. Vallone, promised to keep the Central Park Zoo open and street lights on while he reviewed the social service budget.
At a news conference, Mr. Vallone and other council leaders, said Mr. Dinkins's proposed tax increases went too far. They called for deeper, structural changes, rather than across-the-board cuts.
Others offered little praise for the Mayor. Advocates for services urged him to roll back cuts, while others pressed for deeper reforms in the way the city does business.
State Comptroller Edward V. Regan called the plan to close the zoo "only a pressure tactic to get tax increases and concessions" reflecting a failure of the city government to "undertake fundamental reforms."
 
Labor Asks Burden-Sharing
 To head off the worst of the cuts, Mr. Dinkins is seeking hundreds of millions of dollars in help from city unions, the State Legislature and the Municipal Assistance Corporation, and he plans to go to Washington next week as part of a delegation of city officials pressing the Federal Government to step in to help cities battered by the recession.
Yesterday union leaders said they would help, but only if others do their fair share.
Felix Rohaytn, the chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, which was set up in the 1970's to sell bonds on the city's behalf, said his staff was working on a plan to help the city, but he said it would not be easy. He is to report on his progress late next week.
With city revenues sagging because of the recession, and the size of the city work force still above the near-record levels when Mr. Dinkins took office, concern has been mounting that the State Financial Control Board, an agency set up in 1975 during the last fiscal crisis, could assume powers now in reserve to regulate city spending.
Some business and civic leaders have urged the Mayor to invite the Financial Control Board to assume its regulatory powers, as a way to staunch concern in the financial markets, and to help the city drastically curtail services in a single year.
But Mr. Dinkins, leaning on some oratory more in tune with a civil rights rally than a city budget, insisted that the city must prevail on its own, so "our generation and the next will be able to hold our heads high as free men and free women in a free city."
"I advance these proposals with a heavy heart," he said. "If we lose control of our finances, we lose control of our government -- and that is something we cannot and will not allow."

HEADLINE: Woodbridge Schools Pay for Voter Support

BYLINE: By ROBERT HANLEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WOODBRIDGE, N.J., May 9

 BODY:
As scores of communities in northern New Jersey rejected school budgets last week, residents of this sprawling suburb of 93,000 people voted their approval of a budget for the first time in 27 years.
The deeply divided school board had virtually insured the passage of the $103 million budget by first cutting $4.5 million from it, which guaranteed that no new taxes would be needed. 
 Now Woodbridge's Superintendent, Fredric Buonocore, and his staff are grappling with a retrenchment that colleagues elsewhere might consider unthinkable. With enrollment down almost 50 percent from its peak in the baby-boom years, this school system is shrinking in many ways.
Officials have dismissed 79 teachers and administrators and 20 aides out of a staff of 1,600; eliminated 140 courses in Woodbridge's three high schools; increased class sizes; dropped classes in computers, music, driver training and other subjects and ordered delays in repairs at some of the 24 schools.
 
Teachers Feel Betrayed
 Bitterness prevails. Teachers feel betrayed by the three educators on the board who, with two other members, ordered the budget cut. Leaders of parents groups complain that the pro-cut majority is more sensitive to elderly taxpayers than to students, and they helped defeat the only majority member up for re-election last week.
An angry Dr. Buonocore said Gov. Jim Florio and the State Legislature had turned their backs on schools by taking $380 million from the $1.1 billion in increased school aid that Mr. Florio initially wanted and giving it to towns to cut property taxes.
"It's a sick situation," Dr. Buonocore said. "We need more support for education and less is coming."
Authors of the $4.5 million cut disagree, saying Woodbridge's school administrators have spent too much for years. "They waste money," said Warren Larsen, the board member who lost his seat in the voter backlash. "If they were concerned about what's good for children, why don't they work longer hours?
"We're going to make people in the schools work harder and earn their money. That was the message we sent out."
Joseph Karabin, head of the board's finance committee, said, "We felt there were quite a few areas that could be managed more effectively." Before he became a board member two years ago, he ran the science department at Colonia High School for 21 years.
Enrollment has dropped from 21,000 in 1967 to about 11,000 today, Mr. Karabin said. Dozens of classes in the three high schools and five middle schools have fewer than 10 students.
"That's a very sparse number and a very big cost factor," he said.
 
Variety Will Be Lost
 In response, Dr. Buonocore said Woodbridge's hallmark had been a rich variety of courses. "One of the things we prided ourselves on was the many, many offerings to provide for the individual needs of students," he said. "The long-term effect will be that some youngsters will never have the opportunities to experience some of them."
The biggest single budget cut -- $1.5 million -- led to the dismissal of 70 teachers and the elimination of high school courses with fewer than 10 students, officials said. Chinese I and German I were dropped at one school or another, as were current affairs, computer science, architectural drawing, advanced placement physics, carpentry and basic stenography. At one high school, business systems I and II will be merged; in another, French II and III will be.
Separate sociology and economics classes for average and above average students will be merged. Computer instruction will be reduced. Cello and violin instruction will be eliminated in elementary schools. Special arts, music and drama for gifted students in all grades will be scrapped, as will driver training.
 
Bus Routes, Overtime
 Other cuts include $800,000 for 63 of the 275 bus routes in this 23-square mile community; $500,000 for supervisors' salaries; $600,000 in staff health-care benefits, $300,000 in capital programs, including roof repair and playground repaving; $200,000 in overtime, primarily spent for janitors during nighttime use of schools by community groups, and $100,000 for new equipment, Dr. Buonocore said.
In less cost-conscious times, Woodbridge's budget usually increased at least 10 percent a year. Although budgets were defeated 27 times in a row, the votes are nonbinding and mean only that the budget is submitted to the town government, which can order cuts.
This year, state legislators, fretting about taxpayer hostility to last year's $2.8 billion increase in state income and sales taxes, imposed maximum spending increases for all districts. Woodbridge's cap was 7.65 percent.
The proposed 1991-1992 budget met that level. But Mr. Karabin of the finance committee said it required a property tax increase of $364 on a home assessed at $140,000 -- roughly the average assessment in Woodbridge, he said.
To avoid raising taxes, Mr. Karabin and four allies tapped a $4 million surplus from earlier years and cut $4.5 million from the $81 million part of the budget to be raised from property taxes. Toyce Collins, head of Woodbridge's teachers union, said the cut turned a "frugal budget into an irresponsibly low budget."
The union and parent groups failed to persuade the board to restore $2.3 million, but then campaigned intensely for passage, fearing a defeat would lead to even deeper cuts by the Council.
On voting day, a parents' get-out-the-vote campaign prevailed. About 10 percent of the eligible voters voted, and the budget passed 2,281 to 2,103. Among elderly voters, the turnout was sparse, apparently because the flat tax rate for 1991-92 mollified their traditional opposition to school budgets.

HEADLINE: Drug Makers Face Pressure To Restrain Price Increases

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM

 BODY:
A new Federal law requiring drug makers to cut their prices to Medicaid programs has touched off efforts by virtually every other major purchaser to control the costs of prescription drugs.
Taken together, these efforts represent the most serious challenge yet to the ability of drug makers to continue raising prices far more rapidly than the general rate of inflation. Prescription drugs have been one of the fastest-growing but least regulated health-care costs. 
 Under a law passed in December, the Federal Government has ordered drug makers to pay an estimated $3.3 billion in rebates over five years on products provided to the poor by Medicaid. State programs that spend hundreds of millions of dollars on drugs for the elderly are now pressing for similar rebates.
Employers and private insurers are trying to keep the drug companies from shifting the costs of the Medicaid rebates to them. In addition, a growing number of insurers, health maintenance organizations and other cost-containment plans are strengthening incentives for patients to use lower-priced, alternative drugs.
More large purchasers are demanding discounts and rebates. And some public officials are seeking price controls like those in most other industrial countries.
For the time being, the drug companies seem capable of fending off most constraints because most doctors who prescribe drugs still do not worry much about the costs. Even those companies that hold the line on prices of older drugs can increase their profits by introducing new, more expensive medicines.
Pharmaceutical executives say privately that they have never felt such strong pressure to limit their prices. Some fear they will become as closely regulated as public utilities.
The drug companies say that Government price controls would damage the economy by harming one of the nation's strongest industries. Regulation would discourage spending on scientific advances that can save lives, they say.
The new law requires the companies to offer rebates to Medicaid programs matching their deepest discounts -- sometimes as much as 60 percent -- for other large purchasers. Some drug companies have responded by eliminating these discounts and sharply increasing their charges to hospitals, health maintenance organizations and even other Government agencies.
Angered by the increases, David Pryor, chairman of the Senate Aging Committee and the principal author of the Medicaid rebate law, has suggested sharply curtailing the drug industry's benefits from various Government programs.
But the drug makers said they had to raise prices and reduce discounts to make up for lost earnings. The Medicaid rebate law "threw a monkey wrench into the marketplace," said Dr. Charles A. Sanders, chief executive of the American unit of Glaxo Holdings P.L.C. of Britain, one of the largest drug makers. "People are scrambling around trying to figure out what to do."
 
Hospitals Could Be Hurt
 Glaxo is considering whether to abolish all its drug discounts, as several major companies have already done. Hospitals and other large purchasers say that without the discounts, their drug expenses will rise at least $1 billion this year, or more than 12 percent.
Americans spent $34.2 billion for prescription drugs last year, with $15.1 billion, or 44 percent, paid directly by individuals. People older than 65 bought at least one-third of all prescriptions, with only those used in hospitals covered by Medicare, the Federal health program for the elderly.
Although drugs consume only 6 percent to 8 percent of the nation's health-care spending, prices have been rising much faster than general inflation. New drugs can be painfully expensive. Some medicines for high blood pressure or ulcers require decades of use.
Spending for prescriptions for employees and retirees has been increasing by more than 20 percent a year at many companies. Employers and private insurers paid about $12 billion for prescription drugs last year, up from $5 billion in 1980, said Stephen W. Schondelmeyer, director of Purdue University's Pharmaceutical Economics Research Center.
New accounting rules are forcing large companies to deduct from profits the estimated future costs of health benefits for retirees, which may amount to several hundred million dollars. The Aluminum Company of America says it expects drugs to absorb about 28 percent of its $1 billion in estimated retirees' costs.
Ronald Nordmann, an analyst at Paine Webber Inc., said the pharmaceutical industry's greatest fear was that the Medicaid rebate law presaged more Government intervention. Pennsylvania, which uses $220 million a year of state lottery money to provide drugs for the elderly, is already pressing for rebates on these purchases. "Government is saying, 'Hello, we are the market and we are not going to bear this anymore,' " said Linda M. Rhodes, Pennsylvania's Secretary of Aging. Eleven other states have similar drug programs for the elderly.
Senator Pryor, an Arkansas Democrat, has asked Dr. Louis M. Sullivan, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, to review hundreds of millions of dollars in tax credits that the drug companies receive for research and development and at least $1.4 billion in tax credits for operating factories in Puerto Rico.
"I think some of the companies are taking this research and development money and using it for the marketing of me-too drugs," Senator Pryor said.
 
Marketing Costs Noted
 Mr. Pryor also asked Dr. Sullivan to see whether the drug companies were claiming research tax credits for marketing activities. David Wilson, a principal with the Foster Higgins consulting firm, said the industry spends $2.5 billion annually on marketing, or $5,000 for every American physician.
The drug companies deny all of Senator Pryor's accusations, saying that patients benefit from their tax-subsidized research. Administration officials warn that unless drug companies limit price increases voluntarily, they will face more calls from Congress for further cost controls. "Pharmaceuticals is a successful, internationally competitive industry and we want to make sure it stays that way," said Gail R. Wilensky, the Federal Medicare and Medicaid administrator. "There are some individuals who would just as soon see the industry as a regulated public utility. I would hate to see the companies doing anything that would give those groups any encouragement."
American employers and insurers are also demanding better prices. To control medical costs, they are forming health maintenance organizations and other groups that limit patients to certain doctors and hospitals. The groups can then bargain with drug makers and steer patients to products that cost less.
Many health plans are refusing to pay the full cost of a drug when a cheaper alternative is available. Some health plans that will pay the $690 typical annual cost of treating ulcers with SmithKline Beecham's Tagamet require patients to pay all or part of the $910 annual cost of Glaxo's Zantac, a newer remedy.
The companies say their high profit margins -- about triple those of most other large American companies last year -- allowed them to spend $8.2 billion for research and development. But economists at the Congressional Office of Technology Assessment said recently that industry estimates of research costs depend on "arbitrary" numbers that cannot be substantiated.
 
Increases Expected to Continue
 Most analysts say the drug industry will succeed in resisting cost containment pressures for at least the next few years. "In the short run, the vast majority will continue price increases as a way to rachet up growth," said Marsha Fanucci, a consultant with Arthur D. Little.
Merck & Company, the world's largest drug maker, says it will keep its price increases below the general rate of inflation. But analysts said that Merck and other companies reaped some of their largest profits from setting high prices on new drugs that replaced less expensive ones.
Companies like Merck that have many important new products can shrug off demands for discounts, said Paul A. Brooke, an analyst at Morgan Stanley. But companies with weak research and products that already face strong competition could face hard times, he said.
Federal officials and health care administrators say that for all but Medicaid patients, this year is bringing another pile of higher drug bills. Congressional aides said that veterans hospitals face $150 million in higher drug expenses, up 21 percent. Kaiser Permanente, the country's largest health maintenance organization, said its drug costs would rise by $140 million, or 31 percent.
Many drug companies are eliminating discounts, which they would now be required to share with the Medicaid program. Jeffrey Bourret, the pharmacy director at the Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania, cited the Du Pont Merck Pharmaceutical Company, a joint venture, which raised the price of Coumadin, an anticoagulent, from $1.80 for 100 tablets to $37.26. But Roger R. Morris, a joint venture spokesman, said the increase reflected a decision made before the Medicaid law's passage.
Mr. Morris and spokesmen for several other companies said they would continue to offer drug discounts to Federal depots that supply veterans and military hospitals. The law does not require the drug companies to give the Medicaid program the same discounts as the depots receive. The hospitals have found it easier to fill their needs by ordering directly, but many drug producers no longer offer them discounts.
As long as almost half of the nation's drugs are purchased by individuals, analysts say, the drug makers can continue raising their prices. "In our system," said Marc O. Mayer, an analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein & Company, "one person prescribes a drug, another person dispenses it, somebody else takes it and somebody else pays for it."

HEADLINE: Black Frats Step Back

BYLINE: By Bill Maxwell; Bill Maxwell is a columnist for The Gainesville Sun.

DATELINE: GAINESVILLE , Fla.

 BODY:
While verbal and physical attacks against African American students are at an all-time high nationwide, and while battlelines are being drawn over admissions quotas and culturally diverse curriculas, many black students are their own worst enemies.
At the University of Florida, for example, two black fraternities, Kappa Alpha Psi and Phi Beta Sigma, are at each other's throats, not over how to improve exam scores or how best to get more black jocks to earn degrees. No, we're talking about potential fratricide, so to speak, over such weighty issues as which fraternity wears the fanciest outfits or has the most intricate dance steps. 
 Between April 20 and 22, the Kappas and Sigmas hurled profanities, kicked in doors, fought with fists and canes and exchanged gunshots at an off-campus apartment complex. Luckily, no one was killed. The university has suspended both fraternities indefinitely and the police are seeking charges against those who used handguns during the incident.
I'm sad that these violent incidents occurred because black Greek-letter organizations began with noble goals. The 65,000-member Phi Beta Sigma Fraternity, for example, established in 1914, promoted brotherhood, community service and academic excellence through scholarships and tutorial programs. Kappa Alpha Psi was founded in 1911 at the predominantly white Indiana University to encourage black achievement and mutual support; it also runs housing and job placement services.
But these organizations, like others that have forgotten their original purposes, undercut their effectiveness through pettiness, false superiority, unproductive competition, egotism, childish pranks and now open warfare. These faults are not local nor are they recent developments.
When I attended Wiley College in Marshall, Tex., during the early 1960's, I became a pledge to Omega Psi Phi. The silly and sometimes dangerous hazing notwithstanding, I was appalled at the negative remarks made about members of other fraternities -- blacks like me who were struggling to get a college education.
My big brothers tried to make me dislike, if not hate, blacks who belonged to other fraternities. Disgusted, I quit the pledge line.
There's more. I couldn't join one fraternity even if I wanted to. Why? Because my skin is too black. This fraternity was for those with fair skin, curly or straight hair and so-called good breeding; the same was true of some sororities. Even today, several black Greek organizations select their members along skin-color lines.
Such behavior isn't innocuous. After these people graduate, many members select their friends, business partners, churches and even spouses in this shallow manner. I know several who force houseguests to wear society colors. The most bizarre practice is that of fraternity members who brand their group's symbol on their arms.
Sure, I've heard the arguments ad nauseam: These groups need their identity. They need their pride. True enough, but for blacks -- as a group that is generally mired in economic, social and political problems -- such behavior is self-destructive.
Recently, for example, a promising central Florida black chamber of commerce dissolved because its members aligned themselves according to Greek organizations. "The frat I belong to wanted to control all of the executive positions," a chamber member said. "The other frats wouldn't cooperate, so the chamber just fell apart. Black frats need to learn to work together."
Indeed. Imagine the chamber's accomplishments had it been unified; imagine the clout a unified voice could have developed with civic, political and lending institutions.
The Kappas and Sigmas have written letters of apology to their local chapters and national offices, and to university officials. But that's not enough. For the good of all African Americans, black fraternities and sororities should revive their original objectives. After all, their members are at the university to learn, not to play children's games.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Fishing Rights for the Few Is Un-American

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Without fanfare, Washington has begun to turn over to private interests the exclusive rights to the multibillion-dollar harvest of fish off the United States coast" (front page, April 22). 
 I think that turning over the right to fish commercially to a select group is counter to the American spirit of free enterprise. This system of individual transferable catch quotas is the latest experiment in fisheries management, the result of at least 30 years of mismanagement of the fish stocks that live in Federal waters by the National Marine Fisheries Service.
Here is a case where the Federal Government is going to bestow an economic windfall on relatively few people and eliminate the majority's chance to make a living from the sea. This policy is an attempt to end a citizen's right to own and operate a small fishing boat business for the capture and sale of fish.
Can you imagine the government trying to allocate the number of restaurants or supermarkets based on economic efficiency? Who would dare to say that there are too many establishments and that we must set the number that makes every participant a profit regardless of quality? Where is the free market capitalistic spirit that allows us to choose what we want to do?
Fish stocks would be more abundant if Federal laws did not allow fishermen to kill and discard millions of pounds of juvenile fish, just to catch the relatively few adults. Both the Marine Fisheries Service and the so-called Fishery Management Councils -- the eight regional groups dominated by local fishing interests that are being allowed to hand out exclusive rights to the catch -- are trying to avoid the political fallout of mismanagement from influential boat owners by giving them the soon-to-be-limited right to fish.
What about the captains and crews who work the ocean in the hope of making enough money so that they can own their own boats and businesses? What has the Federal Government really done to improve the economic efficiency of fishing?
This policy creates more problems than it attempts to eliminate. The reduction in the number of fishing boats will result in a significant loss of revenue and jobs in the transportation, shipbuilding, marine electronic, fuel, repair and other marine-related industries. There will be problems in the transfer of fishing effort from Federal waters to state waters.
If this Federal policy continues, then the next logical step is for the Federal Government to sell the exclusive rights away from the millions of recreational fishermen to the few wealthy boat owners.
The best idea for the Federal Government is to develop fishery management plans that would facilitate the rebuilding of fish stocks and eliminate bi-catch kills and waste, and that allow the free market system to work.
 
MITCHELL A. ROFFER
President, Roffer's Ocean Fishing Forecasting Service
Miami, April 23, 1991

HEADLINE: Bela A. Balassa, 63, Economics Professor Who Fled Hungary

BYLINE: By ALFONSO A. NARVAEZ

 BODY:
Bela A. Balassa, an economist and a retired professor of political economy at Johns Hopkins University who specialized in trade and development, died yesterday at his home in Washington. He was 63 years old.
He died of complications of throat cancer, said his wife, the former Carol Levy. 
 Dr. Balassa was born in Hungary and educated at the University of Budapest, where he earned a law degree. He taught economics and statistics in Hungary before emigrating to the United States in 1957 after taking part in the anti-Communist revolt.
He was named a Rockefeller Foundation fellow in 1957 and went on to earn a Ph.D. at Yale University. After graduation, he served as an assistant professor at Yale until 1966 and also taught at the University of California at Berkeley and at Columbia University. In 1967 he joined the faculty of Johns Hopkins and was a professor there at his retirement on May 1.
He was a consultant to the World Bank and to public and private international organizations and the author of more than 23 books on trade and development, including "The Hungarian Experience in Economic Planning," "Trade Prospects for Developing Countries," "Toward Renewed Economic Growth in Latin America" and "Adjusting to Success: Balance of Payments Policy in East Asia."
His awards included the Bernhard Harms prize from the Kiel Institute of World Economies in 1984. He was also awarded honorary doctoral degrees from the University of Paris in 1990 and from the University of Budapest in 1991. He was recently elected a fellow of the Hungarian Academy of Sciences.
In addition to his wife, he is survived by a daughter, Mara Balassa of Washington; a son, Gabor, also of Washington; and two sisters, Judith Nagy of San Rafael, Calif., and Charlotte Garvey of Mountain View, Calif.

HEADLINE: C. McKim Norton, 84, Ex-Leader Of Regional Plan Group, Is Dead

BYLINE: By ERIC PACE

 BODY:
C. McKim Norton, former president of the Regional Plan Association, a private nonprofit group working for the development and conservation of the New York metropolitan region, died early yesterday at the Brookhaven Nursing Center in Lexington, Mass. He was 84 years old.
 He died of leukemia, his family said. He was a resident of North Haven, Me., and lived in Princeton, N.J., from 1950 to 1989. 
The association, based in Manhattan, devises long-range public policies on economic development, transportation, land use and other issues. It then recommends the policies to leaders in the public and private sectors in New York, Connecticut and New Jersey.
 Mr. Norton headed the association's staff from 1940 to 1943 and from 1945 until his retirement in 1969.
 
Helped Develop Parks
 Sigurd Grava, professor of urban planning at Columbia University, said Mr. Norton made a "major contribution in assisting the development of parks" in the region.
 Professor Grava, who heads Columbia's urban planning program, said Mr. Norton had been instrumental in bringing about the creation of the Gateway National Recreation Area. The 26,000-acre patchwork of sites in Queens, Staten Island, Brooklyn and New Jersey was established by Congress in 1972 with the intention that it become the first urban national park in the United States. Critics say it has suffered from skimpy Federal support over the years.
 On parks and other questions, Mr. Norton was something of a gadfly. In 1960 he warned, "The New York metropolitan region is falling behind in its response to mounting pressures for more recreational space."
 Admirers of Mr. Norton in the planning world have said that he was ahead of his time in prompting debate on problems in such basic spheres as garbage disposal and sewers.
 
Advocate of Mass Transit
 Under his direction, the association led a campaign to revitalize the region's deteriorating public transportation system. The association's current president, Richard T. Anderson, said the campaign played a substantial role in the creation of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority in 1968.
 With Mr. Norton in charge, the association also worked out a comprehensive regional plan and issued it in the 1960's. It was a package of many detailed recommendations that emphasized the importance of rebuilding older cities and of encouraging satellite commercial and business centers.
 Though the plan had no legal force, Professor Grava said it was influential in focusing attention on those and other questions.
 
Father Was a Planner
 Charles McKim Norton was born Jan. 6, 1907, in Lake Forest, Ill., the son of Charles Dyer Norton and the former Katherine McKim Garrison. The elder Mr. Norton played an important role in drawing up an earlier regional plan for the New York City area.
 The younger Mr. Norton graduated from the Groton School, Harvard College, in 1929, and Harvard Law School. He worked as a lawyer and banker in New York and as a lawyer for the National Resources Planning Board in Washington before joining the association, which he left for Army service in World War II.
 Over the years he was also a member of the National Capital Planning Commission in Washington, vice president of the American Institute of Planners, vice president of the Middlesex-Somerset-Mercer Regional Study Council in New Jersey and chairman of the Borough Planning Board in Princeton.
 He was awarded the gold medal of the American Society of Planning Officials and the Distinguished Service Award of the American Institute of Planners.
 Mr. Norton was married in 1939 to Martha Chipman Hutcheson, a pianist. She died in 1988.
 He is survived by a daughter, Lucia Norton Woodruff of Austin, Tex., a violinist with the Austin Symphony Orchestra; a son, John C. Norton of Watertown, Mass., an art teacher and painter; a brother, Garrison Norton of Washington; a sister, Lucia Norton Valentine of Mercer County, N.J.; and four grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Heavy-Metal Mania: It's More Than Music

BYLINE: By DEANNE STILLMAN; Deanne Stillman frequently writes about American culture. Her work has appeared in The Los Angeles Times, The Village Voice and California magazine. She also writes for television.

 BODY:
"I'm in my mid-30's, I'm a professional, I pay my taxes, I'm a voter, I love heavy metal, and I will until I die." So says Tawn Mastrey, host of the video-magazine Metal Head. Ms. Mastrey built her reputation as "the leather nun" at KNAC, the Los Angeles heavy-metal radio station that features a traffic reporter named Headbangin' Barb, car insurance ads for "dudes" with questionable driving records and a turbo-charged playlist that "will make your ears bleed."
The only thing louder than heavy-metal music are heavy-metal fans. But there are many who choose not to hear this very noisy group, who regard the world of metal as being unrefined beyond redemption. 
 To get air time at the national cocktail party, three hard-core, precision metal bands -- Anthrax, Megadeth and Slayer -- embark on a two-month carpet-bombing beginning Thursday in Dallas (the tour reaches New York on June 28). As the press release for the "Clash of the Titans" tour puts it: "How do three bands with no Top-40 or album-rock airplay and scant video play launch a tour of the same arenas as Billy Joel and U2? Answer: Fans."
Says the Anthrax guitarist Scott Ian: "This tour is a salute to those fans so they can stand up and be counted. It's like we're saying, 'Here we are. Now deal with us.' "
"Us" encompasses a cultural phenomenon that continues to give everyone from fundamentalist preachers to middle-aged drummers a reason to get up in the morning. Heavy-metal fans are not only cranking up the volume in their American-made muscle cars but living the life in every possible way. They get their hair done at beauty parlors that specialize in "rock-and-roll hair." They get jobs through placement agencies that understand their "special needs." They frequently wear the skin of animals, like snake, lizard and cow. Accessorized by chains and other bikeresque hardware, the clothing symbolizes exactly the same thing it did 20 years ago (and probably 20 years before that) -- bad to the bone.
And the subculture shows no signs of extinction. In fact, as latter-20th-century life appears to be getting louder, faster and more crowded, so too does the world of heavy metal, now featuring countless clubs nationwide, myriad journals, fanzines and comic books catering to every conceivable gradation of metal mania, every manner of rude dudeness.
On weekends in Los Angeles, the loud crowd gathers big at clubs like F.M. Station, Gazzari's and the Bordello; in Tampa, Fla., at the Filling Station; in Tempe, Ariz., at the Cat House; at the Scrap Bar in Greenwich Village, and every Tuesday night at Beowulf in Manhattan. When not club-hopping, inquiring dudes keep up to date with journals like Screamer, Rip, Mean Street, East Coast Rocker, Thrust, Metal Machine, Metal Shop, Metal Maniacs and New Underground Magazine, a comic book that predicts that in the year 2060, the world will end and heavy metal, the only music to weather the big blast, will provide survivors with a moral code.
For the watchwords of today, headbangers dial the 24-hour hotline for dozens of bands. ("We might be doing a song for 'Bill and Ted's Excellent Adventure II,' " says the recorded message for the group Faster Pussycat. "We'll know more on that later. . . . Go, Kings.") Fans looking for a vacation spot head for the Cabo Wabo Cantina, a Mexican nightclub co-owned by the guitar-speedster Eddie Van Halen, and fans with a craving for venison subscribe to Ted Nugent's World Bowhunters magazine.
They also keep tattoo parlors in business. Their beverage of choice is Budweiser, according to KNAC demographics, which also reports that most of them are 18- to 34-year-old males, although there's a not-unnoticed over-40 crowd, of which there are occasional sightings at concerts by older bands. Each category of metal has its own following, with some overlap; but for the most part, fans remain true to their respective schools. For instance, those who prefer the lighter fare of Bon Jovi are not at all charmed by the raw energy of Pantera. Nevertheless, these fans share a particular sensibility: many are working class, and their music of choice reflects their alienation. (It is significant that heavy metal, along with its angry black counterpart, rap, is the voice of another group of disenfranchised citizens, teen-agers.)
In the case of Damn Yankees, Ted Nugent's new group, "they're the typical Ted Nugent welding fan," he says. Like Mr. Nugent, his fans work with metal every day of their lives; for them, the streets of America are paved with steel, not gold. "They do a great job on the line, they work their behinds off to fulfill family responsibilities, and they won't follow anyone blindly," says Mr. Nugent.
In a statement issued at a recent heavy-metal convention, Dave Mustaine of Megadeth compared his band to its fans: "We're average. We're not rocket scientists and we're not wino bums. We're not like a bazillion years old and we're not fetuses with headphones."
In other words, the guy whom modern witch-hunters like to think of as being possessed by evil is actually completely dispossessed; he's the welder whose job has suddenly disappeared along with his pension fund, any alienated Joe (or Jane) who needs a mega-blast of electricity to get to work -- or the unemployment line -- in the morning.
Metal heads may not rank very high on the socioeconomic food chain, but they are certainly not embarrassed. "They're the most vocal fans of anyone in the world," says Riki Rachtman, host of "Headbangers' Ball" on MTV and co-owner of the Bordello and the Cat House. "The most frequently requested videos on MTV are heavy metal. Compare those to the Top 10 based on sales, and there's a huge difference."
Says Tawn Mastrey: "Heavy metal fans know what they want, and when they don't get it, they let you know. Someone at KNAC once played 'Helter Skelter,' and we got a lot of listener complaints. Not enough edge." Had they known that Charles Manson evidently took a cue from this song by the Beatles, would fans have approved? If Ms. Mastrey had the answer, she could be running focus groups for the Rand Corporation. Nonetheless, she seems to have an accurate reading of the dude pulse.
"Remember two years ago when Jethro Tull won the first heavy metal Grammy?" she asks. "If I played Jethro Tull, the station would get bombed." Another metal gaffe is the Rolling Stones. "The all-time lowest-selling issue of Rip," according to its editor, Lon Friend, "was the one with the Stone on the cover." As KNAC radio claims, true metal fans "rock harder and longer." Or, as the group Slaughter screams in their anthem: "Up all night, sleep all day."
For fans who are unable to sleep all day, Slaughter's boast translates into any number of things. For some, it means doing whatever it takes to follow the activities of their favorite band. Twenty-eight-year-old Gilda Caserta, for instance, publishes a quarterly fanzine called Kiss Fire, which is all about Kiss, the group that shaped her adolescence. Now a copy editor at Woman's Day, Ms. Caserta no longer plans her life around her favorite group. But she still takes personally the fact that although Kiss continues to play to sell-out crowds around the country, the band has never been appreciated by critics.
"They were doing the hair and the makeup before everyone else," she says (but not before the New York Dolls, upon whom they based their look). "And because of that, they were unfairly singled out by fundamentalists. I don't see why people get so upset about them. In the 40's and 50's there were sex songs like 'Makin' Whoopee.' Heavy metal presents the same thing in a different light."
Other fans announce their taste in wattage via hairstyle. Everyone has seen the balding executive with a ponytail dashing for the 5:43 to Westport. Most likely, this is a follower of Tom Petty. But what about the pool boy with the palm-tree hair? Chances are, he's a Scorpions kind of a guy. "Everyone wants to look like Nikki Sixx," reports Melissa Lopez, a Van Nuys, Calif., hairdresser who specializes in "rock-and-roll hair." Mr. Sixx is the bass player in Motley Crue, the model for a look that is now standard at gas stations and construction sites around the country.
Then there are fans who express team identification simply by playing "air guitar" -- not "air flute" or "air bongos" -- when they want to invoke coolness or power. And finally there are fans who are paid to be fans. Since actual fans are often not reliable enough to answer fan mail, some groups hire a professional service to take care of such chores.
Judith Krain is one such fan. As president of Fan Line, she supervises clubs for groups like Guns 'n' Roses, Skid Row, Great White and Slayer, which generates the most mail. "They get letters from all over the world," says Ms. Krain, "and some fans write every day. The Germans and Scandinavians are the most literate, whereas the Americans sometimes can't even make out an envelope. By far the very best letters come from the Japanese, who include reply cards, and if they get an answer send you gifts."
Slayer records on Def American, home to Andrew Dice Clay (a heavy-metal Don Rickles) as well as to five metal bands. "When rock heroes say don't do drugs and have safe sex," says Rick Rubin, the label president, "and along comes a band like Guns 'n' Roses, which is about aggressively not caring, then that's when rock-and-roll becomes exciting again." Slayer is perhaps one of the most aggressively not-caring rock entities since Sid Vicious. "There is something arty in how not musical it is," Mr. Rubin says. "With other groups you get a sense of history. It's not here." Perhaps ignorance explains why the group's fan club is called the Slaytanic Wehrmacht.
On a recent "KNAC Night" at the Florentine Gardens in Hollywood, several hundred metal heads had gathered for a showcase of new bands. Since hundreds of metal outfits vie for ear-space in Southern California, landing a gig here is a serious rite of passage. The emcee guided the devout in their worship of those two holy grails, the amplifier and the fuzz box (devices that produce the sound that makes people make that funny face when they play air guitar). As the bands thrashed on, the regulation heavy-metal lingerie slides were flashed on the wall.
Blasted by lyrics that invoked the stone age of male-female communication, many women gathered near the stage, hoping for the once-over from the sexiest band members, preferably the guy on bass.
Would it be better if heavy metal sang the praises of a politically correct world?
Hey, it's only rock-and-roll, and I like it.
 
 
 
THE DAWN OF THE IRON AGE
 What is heavy metal, exactly? Once upon a time, heavy metal was simply known as rock-and-roll. This was during the old-world order, when pasta was spaghetti and gay meant merry. No one knows exactly when it happened, or even what it was, but one day everything changed. Suddenly, rock-and-roll was heavy metal.
Some say it happened when Jimi Hendrix set his guitar on fire. Others say no, no, no, that wasn't it at all; it happened when Jerry Lee Lewis set his piano on fire. Then there are those who say heavy metal began the day Mrs. O'Leary's cow set Chicago on fire. While the debate rages, there is widespread agreement on one point: Billy Joel did not start the fire.
Hippie lore places "blame" for heavy metal on Bob Dylan, who "plugged in" his guitar at the Newport Jazz Festival in 1965 and thus perverted the instrument by "going electric." Paradoxically, Guns 'n' Roses, a group that wouldn't exist without electricity, recently recorded "Knockin' on Heaven's Door," one of Dylan's most popular tunes, thus introducing his message to a new generation of metal fans.
Nowadays, the term heavy metal refers to veteran three-alarm bands like Judas Priest, AC/DC, Iron Maiden and many others but also includes so many newer bands that the category has subdivided. There is speed metal (louder and faster, like Metallica and Megadeth), thrash (really loud and fast, no kidding around this time, as in Slayer and Danzig), glam (loud, fast, hair spray, maybe some mascara, very pretty, such as Warrant and Poison), metal-funk (critically acclaimed, no references to Lucifer so far, as in Faith No More and Living Colour), and even bands that are cited as thinking man's metal (Queensryche).
Penelope Spheeris, director of the documentary "The Decline of Western Civilization, Part II: The Metal Years," suggests that "new technology will soon allow musicians to play louder and faster than ever before." But the metal demi-god Ozzy Osbourne, who hates the term heavy metal, sees the future differently. "Pretty soon," he says, "concerts will disappear because bands will just phone in their gigs."

HEADLINE: SUNDAY VIEW;
The Tall Truths of a Yarn Spinner

BYLINE: By DAVID RICHARDS

 BODY:
After all the bad blood stirred up on Broadway by "Miss Saigon," along comes "The Will Rogers Follies" to make things better again.
 More than better. A-O.K. Jim dandy. 
 Preceded by no weekly updates on the advance ticket sales, no protests over its casting, no now-it's-off-now-it's-on-again bulletins, it opened recently at the newly minted Palace Theater with next to no fanfare, unless you regard the 35-foot cowgirls above the marquee to be fanfare. But you can bet a lot of people are going to be talking about it from here on in. This, I suspect, is the musical audiences were really waiting for, all the time the paid drumbeaters told them they were waiting for "Miss Saigon."
 It boasts sumptuous production numbers, exquisite chorus girls, phosphorescent rope tricks in black light, a dog act, songs you actually want to hum, a stairway to paradise (or somewhere thereabouts), close harmony, shapely legs in kaleidoscopic patterns, and a thoroughly engaging star performance by Keith Carradine, as the laconic cowboy-philosopher from Oklahoma.
You do not come away from so much abundance, however, feeling satiated. Astutely built into the extravaganza by its incessantly inventive director-choreographer, Tommy Tune, is a heartfelt acknowledgment of the hard times the country happens to be currently experiencing. Without being maudlin, "The Will Rogers Follies" says we'll get through. Without being jingoistic, it says Americans usually do.
Probably the most widely known advocate of common sense since Tom Paine, Rogers was a vaudeville performer, radio personality, newspaper columnist and motion picture star before his untimely death in an airplane crash in 1935. During the 1920's, he was also one of the regular headliners in the Follies, Florenz Ziegfeld's yearly endorsement of conspicuous consumption and the female anatomy. Hence the basic idea behind the show. Why not make Rogers's own story the stuff of a Ziegfeld production? Rogers could offer running commentary about himself and the passing scene, as he did in his day. The lavish numbers, presumably, could be used to illustrate some of the life's highlights. By subtitling the whole affair "A Life in Revue" -- as indeed the show's creators have done -- you could even underline the connection beforehand and get a pun out of it.
All right, the premise is not foolproof. It is even seriously flawed. Whose existence naturally lends itself to the mindless glitter Ziegfeld splashed across the stage? Before his death, Liberace was already his own Ziegfeld revue, and Zsa Zsa Gabor, alas, seriously jeopardized her prospects by slapping the police. The fit is just not going to be all that exact, whoever the subject may be. That is probably why the book writer Peter Stone has the voice of Ziegfeld (played by the voice of Gregory Peck) intervene periodically to make sure that his time-honored theatrical tenets are being enforced, and to hell with what really happened.
When the moment comes for Rogers to meet his future wife, Betty (Dee Hoty, all fresh, warm and wonderful), Ziegfeld rejects the Oklahoma setting where the meeting actually took place and insists, instead, that it unfold "on the moon." Accordingly, the set designer Tony Walton provides a silvery vision of the planets in a sky of midnight blue, and the costumer Willa Kim drapes Ms. Hoty in moonbeam white. (Erte surely would have turned green.) Still, the transposition is forced -- beyond silly. "You're so down to . . . moon," stammers Betty, struggling to make the necessary adjustment, while she's gazing adoringly into the eyes of her ingenuous beau. Not very clever, that.
And let's face it, an animal act is an animal act. The six canines billed as Brackney's Madcap Mutts (five daredevils, one showoff) are incontestably the best thing I've ever seen on 24 legs. The show manages to work them in under the banner of the St. Louis World's Fair of 1904, at which Rogers proposes to his future wife. But we're still facing the same problem -- one man's biography butting up against another man's format.
If Mr. Tune were not the extraordinary showman he is, and Mr. Carradine were a less affable presence, "The Will Rogers Follies" would probably crack right up the middle. But the union holds. In the second act, it flourishes.
Consider, by way of proof, "Favorite Son," the production number that serves to commemorate Rogers's entrance into Presidential politics in 1928 -- on the not altogether serious "anti-bunk" ticket. To a razzle-dazzle campaign ditty by the composer Cy Coleman, Mr. Tune has devised an ingenious routine for 16 seated chorus girls, who clap their hands, pat their thighs, cross and uncross their legs in crisp patterns that suggest the child's game of pat-a-cake raised to the power of about 20 or so.
The precision is enough to boggle anyone who ever had trouble rubbing his stomach and patting his head at the same time. There, however, dead center in the red-white-and-blue line, grinning like the cat that ate the cream and wouldn't mind seconds, is Mr. Carradine. He's clapping, patting, crossing and uncrossing with the best of them, but there's no sign on his blissful face that any of this is costing him the slightest effort. The more complicated Mr. Tune makes the routine, the easier it seems to be for Mr. Carradine to follow along. The rivalry is certainly good-natured, if you can even call it rivalry. But it's also clearly responsible for the spring in the number.
Whatever its claims, "The Will Rogers Follies" does not find its drama in the events of Rogers's life, although the one-eyed aviator Wiley Post, seated in a box, is on hand to call out periodically, "Let's go flying, Will," and remind us of the inevitable ending. Rogers's private existence has been largely boiled down to two running misunderstandings -- one with his father (Dick Latessa), who disapproves of his son's choice of show business as a career; the other with his wife, who has no quibbles with show business, but wishes her husband devoted less time to it.
The show's real drama has far more to do with the pairing of two diametrically opposed temperaments -- Mr. Tune, exuberant, excitable, always on the lookout for a way to top himself; Mr. Carradine, sly, unflappable, looking just as keenly for a way to undercut himself. Mr. Tune takes the show up. Mr. Carradine takes it down. The one's incipient giddiness is chastened by the other's tongue-in-cheek wryness, just as the wryness is sharpened, vitalized, by the enveloping high spirits. The relationship is not only mutually beneficial, but it lends a continuing dynamic to what otherwise might be just a sequence of numbers hitched to the passing years.
The evening's most opulent indulgence, "Presents for Mrs. Rogers," is, in fact, abruptly stopped in its spangled tracks to make place for Rogers's plainest speaking. In a tribute to rare jewels, the Ziegfeld girls, each spectacularly costumed to represent a different gem, have been parading majestically down the staircase. And the staircase, not to be thought disobliging, has been regularly changing its color -- red, when rubies are being saluted; blue for the onslaught of sapphires; green for the wave of emeralds. Then, the Depression strikes.
The lighting designer Jules Fisher pulls the plug on the bright lights, stagehands dismantle the set, and wardrobe mistresses rush on to reclaim the elegant costumes, forcing the stunned chorus girls to wrap themselves in gray sheets. Cady Huffman, Ziegfeld's favorite, gazes out into the hall, hoping for a reassuring word from her protector. But the panache has gone out of her strut, and Ziegfeld is noticeably silent.
The company's sagging spirits are the country's, too, and for once, Rogers isn't sure he can rally them. Head bowed by the gravity of the assignment, Mr. Carradine steps up to a microphone and admits he's as baffled as the next man by the homeless everywhere, the hunger, the inequity. "We hold the distinction of being the only nation in the history of the world that ever went to the poorhouse in an automobile," he says. The words are Rogers's own and were delivered over the radio in 1931 at the invitation of President Herbert Hoover, who had just addressed the nation on the mounting unemployment. They've not gone out of date. Only the easygoing delivery -- content to let an irony rise or fall on its proper merits -- signals a different era. And when he asks, "Where are all the big men? Lord, we could sure use one now," even irony is temporarily set aside.
No Broadway musical in its right mind would leave things at that. And "The Will Rogers Follies" doesn't. Slowly, steadily, it builds from there to its uplifting finale. The only difference is that the build is undertaken by Mr. Carradine and Mr. Tune working in tandem, coming at matters from the same angle. The occasion is "Never Met a Man I Didn't Like," a catchy country-western-flavored melody with appropriately homespun lyrics by Betty Comden and Adolph Green. Mr. Carradine -- standing center stage, an overcoat thrown over his arm, hat in his hand -- is not about to change his basic manner. The mocking twinkle has been extinguished, however. That's his part of the bargain.
With each refrain, Mr. Tune enlarges the number surrounding him. But he does so without setting off fireworks at the star's feet. That's his concession. Faintly, at first, then with increasing distinctness, the homely faces of common Americans come into focus on the scrim behind Mr. Carradine. And just as faintly, too, the voices of the chorus join in. Before long, the sea of faces stretches off into infinity, and Mr. Carradine's voice is riding the crest of a full choir. But no one's stirring. Mr. Carradine is still center stage -- coat on arm, hat in hand -- standing firmly by his humble credo. Theatrically speaking, however, a reconciliation has been effected. One man's modesty and another man's flair have been triumphantly joined.
All that remains is for Rogers to take up Wiley Post's offer, climb the stairs into the billowing white clouds and go flying. The show, by this point, has long since been airborne.

HEADLINE: Fresh Air Fund Builds Lasting Links

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO

 BODY:
IN July, Lisa Carena of North Stamford will welcome a visitor from the Bronx. For two weeks, 10-year-old Nina Washington will make her third summertime visit to Ms. Carena's home as part of the Fresh Air Fund's program to bring poor city children to the country.
 Ms. Carena, whose family has been visited by Fresh Air Fund children for the past nine summers, said the hosts gain as much from the experience as the city youngsters. 
 The visitors "gave a lot," said Ms. Carena's 10-year-old daughter, Elizabeth. "During the summer, I would be real lonely, and they would give me friendship."
The Fresh Air Fund is an independent, nonprofit organization that gives free summer vacations to poor children. The fund was founded in 1877 by the Rev. Willard Parsons, a minister in Sherman, Pa., who requested that members of his congregation provide rural vacations for 60 children from New York City. Today, families from Maine to Delaware sponsor Fresh Air Fund children. Ms. Carena, who is the fund's chairwoman for Stamford and Greenwich, said 22 families in the area had volunteered as hosts for this summer.
 
Learning to Swim
 Ms. Carena said finding hosts in Fairfield County is difficult, because many families send their children away to camp, and because the recession has made a stay-at-home-parent an unaffordable luxury. She added that hosts can send their Fresh Air guests to day camp along with their own children.
"They don't have to baby-sit all the time," said Ms. Carena, who works part time.
In past summers, Ms. Carena said, Nina has learned skills like swimming.
"We tried to teach her how to ride a two-wheel bicycle," Elizabeth said. "And we will probably try to teach her again this summer."
 Ms. Carena said she had been surprised by the reaction of city children to country life.
"They are so full of fear," she said. "Nina is still not totally confident that there are not big animals hiding out there in the woods."
She added, "These children are never in the dark."
 
'We Don't Hit Anybody'
 Other cultural differences show themselves during the visits, Ms. Carena said. "We tried to explain to Nina not to throw garbage out the car window," she said. "She didn't know why not."
And when Nina was found improperly taking money, she said, the child was stunned to learn that she would not be hit for her misdeed.
"I told her we don't hit anybody," Ms. Carena said. "She was quite taken aback by that."
Some Fresh Air Fund children also have a slang-littered vocabulary that is difficult, if not impossible, for a host parent to alter, especially during such a short period, she said.
"You're not going to change these kids," Ms. Carena said. "What I'm hoping to do is give them a focus and encourage them to do something with a future."
 
Never Met Apartment Dweller
 The Carena family has had other Fresh Air guests over the past nine years. One of their favorites was Siegfredo Traverso of the Bronx, known as Ziggy, who first visited when he was 9 and has kept in touch ever since.
Ms. Carena said the experience has proved especially useful for her own children, who live a sheltered life. Besides Elizabeth, she and her husband, Joseph Carena Jr., have two older children, Alexis, 17, and Joe 3d, 15.
"They had never met someone that even lived in an apartment," Ms. Carena said.
Sending a child to visit a host family costs the fund $314, mainly for transporation and insurance, and it costs $819 to send a child to one of its camps. Tax-deductible contributions may be sent to the Fresh Air Fund, 1040 Avenue of the Americas, New York, N.Y. 10018. Connecticut families who wish to be hosts may volunteer by calling (800) 367-0003.

HEADLINE: DINING OUT;
Second-Story Restaurant, Two-Tier Menu

BYLINE: By PATRICIA BROOKS

 BODY:
STONE HORSE, yet another new restaurant in New Canaan, has totally revamped the spacious second story of a building it shares with the New Canaan Racquet Club.
The restaurant, which is a visual delight, has three dining areas (one smoking, two nonsmoking tiered ones) and well-spaced tables. The lively bar is separated from the nonsmoking sections by and a central divider of white columns, assorted plants and fresh flowers in handsome terra cotta planters and a large gray-white pony-size stone horse. Except for overloud taped music in the early dining hours, the atmosphere is one of comfortable, casual dining. 
 Stone Horse's menu reflects the current mood of economizing: In addition to the regular entrees, there is a category called "Stone Horse specialties." These are 10 entrees -- with a nice range of choices -- at prices from $6.50 to $9.95. Regular entree prices run from $12.95 to $17.75. The considerable price difference means portions that are slightly smaller (though still hefty) and no salad included. But even these smaller entrees are nearly enough to feed a horse. All entrees are served throughout the day, as are the sandwiches and pizzas. Fair warning: entree portions are sufficiently large to eliminate the need of a starter.
In addition to the regular all-purpose menu, there are daily specials (thoughtfully printed and clipped to each menu), including chowder, pot pie and quiche of the day. On the whole, our experiences with the specials proved more consistent than some of the menu standards. Especially rewarding were two soups: a rich cream of broccoli (pureed, with several fresh broccoli flowerets) and a creamy New England clam chowder (good flavor, despite only micro-sized clam bits).
Other specials to savor, when available, are the rainbow trout amandine (lightly sauteed with almonds in lemon butter) and crisp Long Island duck (well prepared and crispy skinned in a minimally sweetened sauce of fresh raspberries). One night, fresh asparagus and ham quiche made a totally satisfying light meal.
Lamb pot pie, also a special, was a huge ramekin full of hearty lamb chunks and carrots, with a crisp, brown puff pastry topper. Not a conventional pie, but tasty. A chicken pot pie with similar topping was a disastrous mush, however, reminiscent of a chicken fricassee that expired en route.
Inconsistency can be a diner's peril at Stone Horse. Examples abound: swordfish "with anchovy bread crumbs" was served with no hint of anchovy; fillet of Norwegian salmon, ordered rare, was cooked dry; Louisiana bouilabaisse was heavily oversalted; the crust surrounding baked ham and brie en croute was rubbery.
Best to order judiciously, concentrating on the menu's simpler items. On the whole, the sandwiches were well made and enormous. Either grilled pastrami or sirloin hamburger (enhanced by a melted cheddar or Swiss cheese topping) was a meal, along with a side order of paper-thin, greaseless, crisp onion rings.
Plump grilled mussels (actually steamed in an herb-enriched tomato broth), clams casino, bruschetta (toasted bread piled high with chopped fresh tomatoes) and crisp zucchini chips all made suitable starters. Among the regular entrees, our wisest choice was roast rack of lamb (four rare, meaty and tender little chops). Seafood crepe made a delicious light entree (a happy combination of scallops and shrimp in a sherry cream sauce). Caesar salad, available as the house salad, was a generous plate full of crisp, egg-coated and cheese-sprinkled romaine leaves, tasty even without the usual anchovies. Piping hot miniature blueberry muffins, served with commercial rolls, were a welcome bonus. The best desserts were a fluffy cheesecake and strawberry mousse cake.
Stone Horse is still new, and its kitchen and serving inconsistencies may shake out as time passes. An on-the-scene manager would help shorten the long waits between courses and other staff forgetfulness. Meanwhile, this handsome new place offers friendly, casual and moderately priced family dining. Before tax, tip and drinks, we spent $41.15 on two three-course dinners (one course too many for normal appetites).
 
Stone Horse
 Good
43 Grove Street (between Cherry and Elm), New Canaan. 966-8077.
Atmosphere: A handsome second-floor space with smoking and nonsmoking sections, separated by a bar, with a large stone horse and greenery.
Service: Cheerful and well-intentioned but sometimes forgetfuland slow.
Recommended dishes: Grilled mussels, Caesar salad, zucchini chips, clams casino, cream of broccoli soup, New England clam chowder, onion rings, lamb pot pie, rack of lamb, seafood crepe, asparagus and ham quiche, rainbow trout amandine, duck with raspberry sauce, grilled pastrami, sirloin hamburger, strawberry mousse cake, cheesecake.
Price range: Entrees $6.50 to $17.75.
Credit cards: American Express, Mastercard, Visa.
Hours: 11:30 A.M. to 10 P.M. Monday through Thursday, 11:30 A.M. to 11 P.M. Friday and Saturday, 4 to 10 P.M. Sunday.
Reservations: Accepted.
Wheelchair accessibility: Full flight of steep stairs from ground-level entrance.

HEADLINE: ALMA MATERS COURT THEIR DAUGHTERS

 BODY:
If Anne Matthews had extended her research to a few women's colleges, she could have discovered how to raise significant funds from alumnae at coed colleges and universities ("Alma Maters Court Their Daughters," April 7).
My alma mater raised more than $163 million between 1984 and 1989 in the Campaign for Smith College. In spite of tax reform and a volatile economy, we were able to surpass our goal of $152 million by informing alumnae of campus needs and by personal solicitation. 
 The secret is to celebrate the generosity of alumnae to other charitable causes, while continuing to ask them to contribute to the institution that, in all likelihood, first made them aware of community needs.
Matthews is right when she says that raising money from women is different from raising money from men. There is less quid pro quo and more need to make connections between the money and the outcomes of the programs involved. This was as true for small donations ($100) as it was for leadership gifts ($100,000 and up) in the campaign for Smith.
 
BARBARA O. TAYLOR
Hobe Sound, Fla.

HEADLINE: WESTCHESTER GUIDE

BYLINE: By Eleanor Charles

 BODY:

 
SKINNER TO SPEAK
 Trains, planes, roadways and seaways in Westchester and nationwide will be discussed Wednesday during the dinner meeting of the Westchester County Association, to be held at the Rye Town Hilton.
 The principal speaker will be Samuel Knox Skinner, United States Secretary of Transportation and the President's chief adviser on transportation issues and the economic problems surrounding them.
 In charge of 100,000 employees and a budget of $28 billion, Mr. Skinner oversees the Federal Aviation Administration, the Coast Guard, and seven other organizations dealing with maritime, highway, railroad, mass-transit, highway-safety and research programs.
 He will touch on actions under way to implement his Statement of National Transportation Policy, setting forth an agenda for the 21st century, some of which relates directly to the Westchester highway and transit systems.
 At 5 P.M. a special report by representatives of Westchester 2000 -- a group of leaders in the county that is looking for ways to improve life by the turn of the century -- , will cover county problems and successes in strategies for housing, education, intergovernmental relations, health and human services. A reception at 6:15 will be followed by dinner and Mr. Skinner's speech. Tickets are $90 and reservations can be made by calling 948-6444.
 
NEW CASTLE BICENTENNIAL
 One of several programs celebrating the town of New Castle's bicentennial is a talk by William McFeely today at 4 P.M. in the Quaker Meeting House, at 420 Quaker Road (Route 120) in Chappaqua. Mr. McFeely's subject will be "Frederick Douglass and the Quaker Radicals," based on his new book, a biography titled "Frederick Douglass."
 Mr. McFeely is a professor of history at the University of Georgia and a Pulitzer Prize winner in 1982 for his book about Ulysses S. Grant , titled "Grant: A Biography." His account of Douglass's extraordinary life, from slave to celebrated anti-slavery orator, was chosen by three book clubs, including the Book of the Month. Both biographies were published by Norton.
 The New Castle Historical Society recently published an oversize illustrated paperback, "A Bicentennial History of the Town of New Castle, 1791-1991." Among the remaining bicentennial events are a strawberry festival Saturday from 11 A.M. to 4 P.M. on the grounds of the historic Episcopal Church of St. Mary the Virgin on South Greeley Avenue in Chappaqua; and a Revolutionary Encampment and Battle in Gedney Park in New Castle, on May 25 from 11 A.M. to 4:30 P.M. Everything is free. For more information, call 238-4771.
 
'DOROTHY PARKER'
 Dorothy Parker, the author and wit, is being portrayed on the stage by Tina Sattin, the actress and director, in "What Fresh Hell Is This? An Evening With Dorothy Parker" at the Schoolhouse Theater in Croton Falls.
 In a series of six short monologues and two lengthier solo pieces -- all written by Parker -- Ms. Sattin at times speaks as the writer, and at times she becomes one of the characters created by Parker.
 "The Telephone Call," one of the longer pieces, concerns a woman who waits for and receives the phone call from Hell -- her lover telling her that it's all over. In "The Waltz," a society woman politely endures the attentions of wearisome dance partners at a soiree, while yearning for one man who is absent.
 Ms. Sattin founded and is the director of the Open Cage, a theatrical troupe housed in a former high school at 60 South Third Avenue in Mount Vernon. She has appeared in "To Be Young, Gifted and Black" and "Member of the Wedding" on television, and in other productions on and off Broadway. Her performance as Billie Holiday in "Lady Day at the Emerson Bar & Grill" by Lanie Robertson, seen last October at the Schoolhouse, will be repeated there next fall.
 Performances of "An Evening with Dorothy Parker" are at 3 P.M. today and 8 P.M. Friday and Saturday. Tickets at $12.50 may be reserved by calling 277-8477.
 
CHILDREN AND ARTS
 Dr. Sirgay Sanger, founder of the Parent Child Center at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in Manhattan and a noted child psychiatrist, will talk about "The Arts and Children: Health Promotion for the 90's" Friday at 8 P.M. in Golden's Bridge.
 Drama, dance, music and the visual arts as means of communicating more profoundly with children, and the attendant benefits to children in terms of self-expression and self-esteem, are strongly advocated by Dr. Sanger and are gaining currency in the education community at a time when funds are being cut in many schools.
 Following the talk, to be given at the Northern Westchester Center for the Arts on Old Bedford Road, there will be an open discussion and the audience can view "Visions of a Better World," an exhibition of children's art.
 Dr. Sanger, a graduate of Harvard College and the Harvard Medical School, has written several books on parents and children and their emotional connections. His latest book, "Baby Talk, Parent Talk," was published this year by Doubleday. Admission to the program is free. Call 232-5740 for more information.
 
ARTFUL CHILDREN
 Young artists from 23 schools in Westchester, Putnam and Fairfield Counties will have their own juried art exhibition at the Katonah Museum of Art Saturday through May 26. One hundred high school students will exhibit more than 100 paintings, sculptures, graphics, photographs and metalworks that were judged by teachers to be the best in their schools.
 The show not only gives budding artists an opportunity for public scrutiny of their work, but provides experience in planning, advertising, hanging and being the hosts for their exhibition.Guided by professionals, the students produced the invitations, posters and program; pondered which works looked best where and how far apart; hammered the nails and set up the sculpture, and now will welcome the guests.
 The museum, on Route 22 at Jay Street in Katonah, is open free of charge Tuesdays through Fridays and on Sundays from 1 to 5 P.M.; and Saturdays from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. For more information, call 232- 9555.
 
BOOKS BY THE POUND
 Bookworms, especially economy-minded ones, should head for Yonkers next weekend, where two used-book sales will be in progress.
The Grinton I. Will Public Library at 1500 Central Park Avenue has scheduled a books-by-the-pound sale Saturday from 11 A.M. to 4 P.M. Books and records will be sold for 50 cents a pound, weighed at the checkout counter, and magazines will go for 10 cents for each magazine. The library has been collecting material for four months and expects to sell several thousand items. The phone number for information is 337-1500.
The public library in the Crestwood section, at 16 Thompson Street, will hold a sale Friday from 10 A.M. to 5:30 P.M. and Saturday from 10 A.M. to 1:30 P.M. Children's books will not go on sale until 3:30 P.M. Friday. For more information, call 337-1500, extension 360 or 361.
