PUB-DATE: May 12, 1991,

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 2; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 2562 words

HEADLINE: An American Wrestles With a Troubled Future

BYLINE: By ERIC N. BERG

DATELINE: OAK BROOK, Ill.

 BODY:
For the McDonald's Corporation whose name, golden arches and Big Mac are American icons -- a reckoning is at hand.
For two years, maybe more, McDonald's restaurants in the United States have been struggling to prevent a decline in their business from snowballing. 
 The reasons for the fall: restaurants that cost far more than many rivals' to build and are a permanent drag on earnings; prices that long ago stretched the budgets of many fast-food customers, and a menu that remains the bane of cardiologists and weight watchers, despite the recent introduction of the low-fat burger, McLean Deluxe. The impact of the decline: financial results that have been a painful disappointment.
While some competitors continue to report strong sales increases, many McDonald's restaurants have had flat to negative numbers since 1988, after adjusting for inflation. In the first quarter of this year, the typical company-owned outlet in the United States saw inflation-adjusted sales fall 3 percent from the same period a year earlier, according to Montgomery Securities Inc. of San Francisco. For the typical franchisee, the decline was even bigger -- 7 percent.
By comparison, the typical Taco Bell's sales in the last quarter were up about 3 percent after adjusting for inflation. Wendy's rose 3.2 percent; and at Cracker Barrel, a mid-priced chain in the Southeast, sales jumped 7 percent.
Most of McDonald's troubles are at home. For the first quarter of 1991, the company's net income rose 6.6 percent, thanks to strong foreign sales. But in the United States alone, operating income fell 2 percent. For all of 1990, the typical company-owned domestic outlet saw its operating income fall 7 percent, to $254,500.
The company's ills underscore just how much the fast-food business has changed in the 36 years since the first McDonald's was built -- and how far behind McDonald's has fallen. As the population has aged, customers have become far more sensitive to the healthfulness of what they eat. And the recession has cut deeply into many family food budgets.
Some chains are growing nicely by taking business from leaders like McDonald's. Mid-priced chains like Baker's Square have surged by offering healthier fare and table service for not much more than what some counter-service outlets charge. And Pepsico Inc.'s Taco Bell has scored big with Mexican meals for about $1.
 
 Heading South
 "McDonald's is still a business in which a guy working hard can earn a six-figure income, but the critical issue is the trend, which has been south for some time," said Michael G. Mueller, the Montgomery Securities restaurant analyst. Added Tiger Warren, chairman of Macheesmo Mouse, a Mexican-restaurant chain based in Portland, Ore.: "The halcyon days are over. McDonald's will always be the biggest, but more and more people are chipping away at its base and its competitors have gotten a lot smarter."
Suddenly, however, McDonald's has decided to tackle its problems head on. It has begun a campaign to cut hundreds of thousands of dollars off the construction cost of its restaurants. It has been slashing prices on everything from cheeseburgers to pancakes. And for those who still consider its food to be one step up from Gummi Bears and Twinkies, it has been adding healthier and reduced-calorie fare -- like oat-bran muffins, low-fat salad dressings and the McLean Deluxe.
McDonald's is at a crossroads. If its reforms are successful, sales and profits at the company's 8,600 domestic restaurants should resume their upward trek, and McDonald's will retain its position as a premier growth companies. But if it cannot right itself, McDonald's will cease being the model of excellence that it has been since 1955, when Ray A. Kroc, a former blender salesman, founded the chain. McDonald's would become just another combatant in the increasingly glutted world of fast food -- far more than a bit player but vastly diminished in importance.
Most fast-food experts will not predict the outcome. They note that McDonald's is only beginning to make some of its changes and that the company has been resilient in the past. But they also say that there will always be fast-food restaurants with lower overhead that can charge less.
For their part, some United States franchisees are already folding rather than risk further declines.
"I would like to stay in the system, but I see no future in it," said Joan Fiore, who recently sold the last of five McDonald's restaurants that she and her husband owned in New York City. "I think if we stayed in the system, eventually our restaurants would be valueless."
That may still be a minority view, however. McDonald's executives, including Michael R. Quinlan, the 46-year-old chief executive, believe investing in a McDonald's franchise remains the closest thing to a sure bet. They point to a long waiting list of people wanting a franchise and to the large number of operators earning six-figure incomes.
"They're in very good shape as a whole," Mr. Quinlan said in a recent interview at McDonald's headquarters here, referring to the 6,900 franchises in the United States. (The company owns 1,600 domestic restaurants, and it owns about a third of the 3,300 restaurants in the hugely successful overseas operation.)
But the chain's results suggest that many of its domestic outlets have been battling to keep even, at least in sales volume. And not just for a few quarters. The deterioration appears to have started in 1985.
That year, the average company-owned domestic outlet had $1.3 million in sales, a gain of only three-tenths of 1 percent over 1984 after adjusting for price increases. Since then, adjusted sales have declined every year except 1987, when they rose a modest 2.7 percent. For the three months ended March 31, sales fell in real terms, by about 3 percent.
One key problem is the cost of new restaurants, which come with top-of-the-line kitchen equipment and amusements for children, like playgrounds. It is simply uneconomical to have a Mercedes-Benz for a building when more rivals than ever are vying for the business, analysts say.
Indeed, since Mr. Kroc stepped down as chief executive in 1973, hundreds of newcomers have streamed into the market. There have been plenty of new burger restaurants, of course, like Rally's, a Louisville, Ky.-based chain that offers drive-through service only. But McDonald's now must also compete with convenience stores like 7-Eleven, with gas stations, with delicatessens -- in short, with anyone selling reheatable food. The last few years have also witnessed an explosion in the number of mid-priced restaurant chains, like Chili's and Baker's Square.
Worse yet, in a desperate attempt to hang on to customers in a maturing market, rivals across the spectrum have been cutting prices. Leading the way has been Taco Bell.
By comparison, McDonald's restaurants have been hobbled by heavy up-front costs, which not only have squeezed profits directly but also indirectly by making it hard for operators to match rivals' price cuts.
 
The Wrong Way
 Until recently, McDonald's was raising prices. Its price increases have matched or exceeded inflation in 9 of the last 17 years, according to Montgomery's Mr. Mueller
The result is that the company that got rich from the 15-cent hamburger now gives Americans a regular case of fast-food sticker shock, routinely handing out checks for $15 or more to families of four. More important, price increases have sent customers streaming to competitors.
While the erosion is hard to gauge because fast-food market-share data are notoriously unreliable, one figure speaks volumes: Many McDonald's operators have reported little increase in traffic in the last two years, a period in which Taco Bell says it attracted 60 percent more volume. Since the fast-food market is barely growing, the conclusion, analysts say, is that many of these customers were former McDonald's devotees.
"The world changed for McDonald's when Pepsico began focusing on its restaurant businesses," said Caroline Levy, Shearson Lehman Brothers' restaurant analyst.
In fact, the world changed for McDonald's years ago, when the public started worrying about cholesterol and calories. The simple fact is that, long after Americans became conscious of the impact of eating on health, McDonald's core menu remains high in fat and calories. The Big Mac has 560 calories, 52 percent of them coming from fat. While McDonald's is withdrawing the item cardiologists most loathe -- the 580-calorie, 57 percent-fat McDLT -- it continues to promote sandwiches as fattening and fatty as ever. To wit: the McJordan, a 520-calorie, 50 percent-fat, quarter-pound burger with cheese, barbecue sauce and smoked bacon.
 
Refining the Menu
 "Long term, McDonald's still does not have a menu that will be in favor," said Robert Brent, a former marketing executive at Taco Bell, whose menu is not as laden with red meat.
Mr. Quinlan, McDonald's chief executive, acknowledges that the menu needs work, but he maintains that the company is addressing the issue. "Our menu will evolve to be more varied from a nutrition and taste standpoint," he said.
 And although McLean Deluxe may have got the most attention, McDonald's has been steadily updating its menu in recent years, albeit not enough to convince all its critics. It converted to cholesterol-free vegetable oil for french fries and introduced lighter fare like low-fat milk and new salads. A grilled-chicken sandwich could be rolled out any time.
McDonald's has also been paring the cost of building a restaurant. By allowing franchisees to use less brick and more windows, for instance, $25,000 has been saved. All told, McDonald's hopes to identify $200,000 in savings on construction per building.
And the company has begun cutting prices in a big way. It recently introduced a "value menu," with hamburgers being sold for as little as 49 cents, down from 89 cents. And some combinations, like a burger, fries and drink, are as much as half off. The move appears to be a direct parry to Taco Bell, whose drive-throughs have been jammed since it began offering 49 cent tacos.
Competitors have responded to the value menu with even more price cuts. Earlier this year, for instance, Burger King began offering mini-hamburgers for as little as 29 cents.
And then there are the worrisome demographics. Older people in particular tend to view burger chains like McDonald's with suspicion. And many are uncomfortable with having to wait in line. As the population ages, more Americans may opt for the Baker's Square format of economical table service and a menu favoring such fare as broiled fish.
"When we were younger, burgers were O.K.," said Emerson Kendall, the president of Matteson, Ill.-based Baker's Square. "With the emphasis on nutrition, people want a much more balanced approach to their diets."
Despite everything, the company's stock has been rallying of late, closing Friday at $34.25, after falling steadily through the second half of 1990, to a low of about $28. The current rebound apparently reflects the prevailing view that McDonald's is simply too strong to be counted out. Sagging sales or not, McDonald's restaurants in this country still manage to serve more than 20 million people a day.
Over the long haul, "they are too damn smart and have too many resources to allow anybody to take their market away from them," said George Rice, an industry consultant.
 
 
WEEDING OUT FRANCHISEES
 Although McDonald's domestic restaurants have been suffering lately, the company still is one of the world's most successful food-service organizations.
A lot of that can be traced to the rigorous admissions and training process for franchisees. By making the process costly and time consuming to the applicants and, most important, highly selective, McDonald's insures that only top candidates become operators.
The recruitment numbers tell the story. Each year 20,000 people contact McDonald's about obtaining a franchise. Only 2,000 reach the interview stage and fewer than 200 get a restaurant.
Some applicants are rejected because they want to own a McDonald's as a sideline; the company requires its operators to work full time at the business. Others are rejected because they insist on exclusive rights to a territory; McDonald's will franchise only one restaurant at a time.
And not everyone has the cash: while McDonald's either owns or rents the land and restaurant, spending on average $1 million for the property and to construct the building's shell, franchisees must come up with $610,000. This covers kitchen equipment, dining-room furniture, signs and an initial franchise fee of $22,500. Only 60 percent of the $610,000 can be borrowed.
But having the cash is just the beginning. Before being awarded a restaurant, applicants must work two years, typically 15 to 20 hours a week, as unpaid apprentices in a McDonald's restaurant.
From there the candidates are off to Hamburger University, McDonald's two-week residential training center at its Oak Brook, Ill., headquarters. Candidates must complete courses on motivation, hiring, customer relations and managing time.
Even then, McDonald's sometimes goes a step further to make sure applicants are dedicated enough. Upon graduating from Hamburger U., many people are awarded a franchise hundreds of miles from their home, with relocation at their expense.
"That's what enables us to open restaurants where our market research tells us makes sense," said Chuck Ebeling, a McDonald's spokesman.
 
GAINING SPEED AT THE DRIVE-THROUGH WINDOW
 WITH competitors chipping away at their sales and profits, increasing numbers of McDonald's franchisees are using technology to try to gain an edge. Nowhere is this more true than in drive-throughs, from which many McDonald's restaurants now derive close to half of their business.
The first drive-throughs -- indeed, the first McDonald's restaurants -- took a "linear" approach. One person would take an order, assemble and bag the order and then take the customer's money. It was a time-consuming process that turned many drive-throughs into parking lots.
Now consider how McDonald's operates today at its single-lane, double-window drive-throughs:
When a customer gives an order through a two-way intercom, the customer is talking to a crew member sitting at an order-entry computer system. The system not only calculates the bill but transmits details of the order to two overhead television monitors -- one in the kitchen and the other at drive-through window No. 2, where the customer's order normally is delivered.
The moment the customer finishes giving the order, the kitchen crew looks at its screen and swings into action, and the attendant at window 2 uses the screen there to start assembling the needed condiments, napkins and coffee stirrers.
The most advanced restaurants equip the crew members with wireless, battery-powered headsets that allow everyone to hear an order arriving over the intercom. That way, the crew members do not even have to wait for a customer to finish speaking.
"Basically, there is something happening all the time," said Chuck Ebeling, a McDonald's spokesman. "Americans don't object to getting in line as long as that line is moving."

HEADLINE: Wall Street;
The Seed Money Flow Slows in Computers

BYLINE: By Diana B. Henriques

 BODY:
The high-technology darlings of tomorrow's stock market are incubating in the venture-capital nurseries today. That's the good news. The bad news is that the nanny may be about to give notice.
For the computer industry, in fact, 1990 may become "the year the Great American Venture Capital Machine began to slow down," said Richard A. Shaffer, savvy editor of the Technologic Partners' Computer Letter. Mr. Shaffer estimates that at least 10 of the 300 firms he surveys left the field last year. And at a recent conference, a session titled "How to Wind Down a Venture Capital Firm" drew a capacity crowd, he said. 
 Where will the pain be felt? In California, mostly. At least half of each year's venture activity since 1986 has occurred there. Meanwhile, Mr. Shaffer looks for a rebound in deal activity in Massachusetts, where the weak economy "has made it far easier to find qualified people and inexpensive space to put them in." One startup in the Boston area is operating rent-free for three years.

LENGTH: 1562 words

HEADLINE: Business Diary/May 5-10

BYLINE: By Joel Kurtzman

 BODY:

COMPANIES
 
An Overloaded Occidental Is Shedding Debt
 
When the late Armand Hammer was chairman of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation, he dismissed at least one would-be successor who dared say the company should pare down its debt. But now that Dr. Hammer is gone, Ray R. Irani, Oxy's new chairman, has a free hand. And last week he started moving toward his stated mission of trimming the company's $8.8 billion of debt by $3 billion this year. He made a deal to sell 50 percent of Trident Energy Inc., a producer of liquefied natural gas, for $600 million to a subsidiary of Hicks, Muse & Company, a Dallas-based investment firm. After taxes and other costs, the deal will yield $432 million for Occidental. Then he sold Oxy's North Sea oil and gas holdings for $1.35 billion to France's Societe Nationale Elf Aquitaine and Enterprise Oil P.L.C. of Britain. Mr. Irani is now more than halfway to his goal. And the market likes it. Occidental shares closed the week at $21.125, up $2.125.

NCR -- Who Is the Real Winner?
 
Who benefits most from A.T.& T's $7.4 billion purchase of the NCR Corporation? The American Telephone & Telegraph Company says it does; the deal puts it back in the computer business. But the real winners may be the Wall Street firms that advised the companies during their five-month fight. The advisers get millions in fees at a time when dealmaking is all but dead. Dillon Read & Company and Goldman Sachs & Company, which advised NCR, will each receive about $18.5 million. Morgan Stanley & Company, which advised A.T.& T., will get $13.28 million. Proxy solicitation firms also did well. Morrow & Company will receive $1.7 million and Georgeson & Company will receive $2 million for trying to sway NCR's stockholders. And then there were the lawyers. Two firms will split $20 million for the paperwork.
 
Metromedia's Mighty Returns
 
John W. Kluge, the billionaire chairman of the Metromedia Company, has been making money even in the money-losing cellular-telephone business. His formula has been simple: unload as much of your holdings as you can. Last week, he sold Metromedia's cellular telephone company in Philadelphia for $1.1 billion. The buyer was the Comcast Corporation, an operator of cable television systems there. Metromedia, based in Secaucus, N.J., is one of the nation's largest private partnerships. Since 1986, when it began selling its cellular systems in New York, Washington, Baltimore, Boston and Chicago, the partnership has received $3 billion. The company invested just $20 million in Philadelphia a decade ago. Not a bad return for Mr. Kluge.
 
Troubles for G.M.'s Saturn
 
The General Motors Corporation spent $3.5 billion just to get the Saturn Corporation off the ground. It was supposed to be "a laboratory for all of G.M.," said Ronald Glantz, an automobile analyst at Dean Witter Reynolds in San Francisco. But last week it announced it would be replacing 1,836 of its 1991 model cars that were filled with the wrong coolant. And another laboratory -- one at the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration -- said Saturn was not as safe as any of the other cars in its class in a front-end collision. Should G.M. and the nation's Saturn owners be worried? "The data bear little relationship to reality," Mr. Glantz said. "Saturn is under a magnifying glass right now. It was a smooth startup and it's a good product."
 
USX Bidding Farewell to Steel
 
Carl C. Icahn wants the USX Corporation to sell its steel business, the nation's largest. Mr. Icahn, the company's biggest shareholder, is finally getting his way. Last week, shareholders approved a plan to separate the company's stock into two groups. One would comprise the steel business; the other, the Marathon Oil Company. With two groups of stock, the steel business would be easier to sell. Charles A. Corry, the company's chairman, is talking to potential buyers.
 
Of Batteries, Beer and Bunnies
 
First there was "Harvey," the six-foot rabbit in the 1954 movie starring Jimmy Stewart. This time around, there are two: one mechanical and one played by Leslie Nielsen, the star of "Naked Gun." And the bunny masters are suing each other. Eveready, the battery-making subsidiary of the Ralston Purina Company, alleged last week in a lawsuit that the Adolph Coors Company was unfairly parodying its mechanical rabbit in a new series of commercials starring Mr. Nielsen. Coors, in a countersuit, is trying to stop Eveready from interfering with its new campaign. The problem, said Eveready, is that it doesn't want people to associate its bunny with beer.
 
In Brief
 
The Justice Department said a subsidiary of Japan's NEC Corporation agreed to pay $34 million in fines to settle charges that it rigged bids on contracts worth $103 million at an American military base in Japan.
 
 
 
THE ECONOMY


Inflation? Forget the Veggies
 
Vegetable prices rose by an astonishing 34.5 percent in April due to a heat wave in Florida. Important, of course, if you like vegetables. But more than that: the jump was enough to throw the entire Producer Price Index out of whack. Prices were up 0.2 percent for the month, according to the Commerce Department. On the other hand, the P.P.I. indicator of inflation showed a 0.4 percent decline in intermediate goods and a 0.5 percent decrease in crude goods. "The trend continues in the right direction," said Mickey Levy, chief economist at C.R.T. Government Securities in New York. "Inflation is coming down."
 
Housing Sales Up, Prices Down
 
The housing slump appears to be bottoming out, even in the Northeast. That is what a survey of bank examiners by the Commerce Department said last week. First-quarter sales were up, but at a cost -- falling prices. In another report, this one by the National Association of Realtors, the median price for a home in the United States slipped 0.5 percent, to $95,400 -- the second quarterly drop in a row.
 
The Productivity Twist and Turn
 
At first it seemed the recession had finally turned the corner -- into depression. American business productivity had fallen nine-tenths of 1 percent during the first quarter, the Labor Department said. But then the department corrected itself. Productivity was not down, it was up -- by a strong 1 percent. Even the revised numbers were perplexing. Productivity, a broad measure of output per hours worked, fell in the manufacturing sector and rose in the service sector, the reverse of a long-running trend. The recession has hurt sales, so manufacturing is down. But why the rise in services? "It may be an anomaly," said said Robert Ortner, former chief economist at the Commerce Department. "Every golden glove winner drops a pop fly now and then."
 
 A Few Fewer Layoffs
 
New claims for unemployment benefits fell 9 percent at the end of April, the Labor Department said. "The layoff rate is diminishing," said Alan Sinai, an economist at the Boston Company. "But we're still in recession."
 
 
 
INTERNATIONAL

 
Iraq Says It Will Pay Later
 
The allies got no spoils from the war with Iraq, only costs. Under the terms of a United Nations Security Council resolution, at least some of those costs -- not yet determined -- are to be paid by Iraq. The resolution calls on United Nations Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar to suggest a maximum percentage of Iraq's oil revenue to be used for rebuilding Kuwait and Saudi Arabia. But in a letter last week to Mr. Perez de Cuellar, Iraq asked for a five-year moratorium on those payments. It needs the time, the letter said, to rebuild its oil exporting capacity to 3 million barrels a day -- its prewar level -- from a current 2 million. It also needs time to repair its infrastructure. After all that is done, the letter said, Iraq will be willing to help rebuild the neighborhood its troops destroyed.
 
Sharing Soviet Power
 
1Boris N. Yeltsin, the popular president of the Russian Republic, is up for election next month. There is little doubt he will win. Even so, Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev gave Mr. Yeltsin's campaign a lift when he agreed to transfer control of most of Siberia's coal industry to Russia. The transfer is important because coal is the Soviet Union's principal energy source. It is also important because Mr. Yeltsin has been complaining that Russia controls just 16 percent of its resourceslike oil. Far too little. Transferring the mines is a clear sign that a deal has been struck between by the two leaders. To avert a civil war, they may be ready to share power.
 
Banned in Arabia
 
Since 1967, much of the Arab world has been boycotting the Coca-Cola Company (and hundreds of others) for doing business with Israel. On hot days, Pepsi Cola was the only soft drink around. But in a gesture of thanks to the United States, the Arab League's Boycott Office removed four American companies from its list after the gulf war. Coca Cola, the J.B. Williams Company, Helene Curtis Inc. and the Home Insurance Company can now do business in the Arab Middle East. The only trouble is, 110 companies have been added to the list, including all those in which Britain's Robert Maxwell, new owner of The New York Daily News, has an interest. Mr. Maxwell is starting a Russian language paper in Israel.

HEADLINE: Making a Difference;
Weighing the Facts for Congress

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
In issuing its report last week on the use of genetically engineered growth hormone to boost milk production in cows, the Office of Technology Assessment didn't shrink from controversy.
The Congressional agency issued a point-blank declaration that the hormone poses no danger to cows or to humans who drink their milk, a view at odds with what some consumer groups and state regulators have argued. By so doing, the agency increased the chances that the Government will approve the new drug for widespread commercial use and that Congress will concur. 
 Armed with a tiny budget of $6 million, the agency's director, John H. Gibbons, has made the office important by taking strong stands.
In February, for example, it issued a toughly worded report arguing that the Department of Energy had "neither the capability nor the credibility" to meet its goal of cleaning up radioactive waste from weapons plants in 30 years. In another report that month, the agency argued that policies for disposing of medical waste remain mired in "confusion and inconsistency."
Mr. Gibbons, a 62-year-old physicist with a longstanding interest in energy conservation, is modest about the impact the agency has had in his 12 years as director. "We don't claim to have a big influence," he said. "We're really catalysts. Our job is to provide the movers and shakers with wisdom that is tough to get."
Yet beyond simply answering technical questions, the agency's reports attempt to address the social and economic implications of a technology. Thus, the report on bovine growth hormone went to great lengths describing how the drug could hurt small dairy farmers by lowering milk prices. Likewise, a report on global warming tried to frame strategies for dealing with the problem that would be economically feasible.
Mr. Gibbons admits the conclusions don't always satisfy everyone, but he says most sides to a debate usually agree with the underlying facts cited in the agency's reports.
"We're trying to give members a sense of where all the parties to a debate can stipulate," he said. "It's a heavy weight."

LENGTH: 1699 words

HEADLINE: All About/Computer Retailers;
Superstores Force PC Chains to Reinvent Themselves

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO

 BODY:
For personal computer sellers looking ahead, the future suddenly offers very few alternatives: get big, get specialized or get out.
The entry of a new breed of warehouse-sized superstores is putting the squeeze on traditional computer retailers. As do their predecessors in home furnishings, consumer electronics and toys, the PC superstores offer selection, discounts and convenience. 
 Unable to compete on price with these behemoths, many traditional resellers are closing their retail outlets to concentrate on direct sales to corporate accounts. Here, they say they can sell their "value added" services, like network installations. But by retreating to this higher ground, chains like Computerland, Businessland and MicroAge are, in effect, conceding the home and small-business market to the warehouse stores.
"There has been an evaporation of the middle ground," said Ed Anderson, president of Computerland U.S.A., in Pleasanton, Calif., the nation's largest franchise chain. "You have to make a choice: either go the superstore route for retail, or to a much smaller operation offering networking and service. If you stay in the middle, you're going to die."
Independent dealers and franchisees used to be able to make a good living in the middle ground by offering service with the sale, for which they were able to charge a premium price over the deep discounters and mail-order houses. But the growing sophistication of the customer and the relentless efforts of personal computer manufacturers to make their machines easier to use have eroded the demand for service.
"All of the changes we're seeing are representative of the fact that the customer has changed," said Seymour Merrin, a Palo Alto, Calif.-based PC retailing consultant. "The customer is no longer intimidated by the technology and is no longer willing to pay a premium for hand-holding."
 
Supermarket Concept
Will Big Inventories Become a Handicap?
 There are only a few dozen superstores scattered across the country, but each one that opens can lead to the closing of several traditional computer stores. Of the 5,000 computer dealers in the country today, experts expect that by 1995, 2,000 will convert to specialized business sales or superstore formats, while an additional 1,000 will probably go out of business.
Retail consultants say the most apt model for the emergence of the PC superstore is the stereo industry. When stereo, or "hifi" as it was then called, was a specialized interest, thousands of independent stores served a mostly hobbyist market. As stereo, and later video, equipment became a must-have for most families, the mass merchandisers moved in. The independents that survived, became boutiques, selling high-end products to a small group.
"The PC industry is undergoing a change that other segments of retailing already have undergone," said Nathan Morton, president and chief executive officer of CompUSA Inc. in Dallas. "All our company really did was to put all these products in one place and behave much like the supermarket," he said. With 17 stores, CompUSA, which recently changed its name from Soft Warehouse, is the largest superstore operator.
"One of the reasons we've had the opportunity is the existing resellers have essentially abandoned the retail business," Mr. Morton said. "All the talk about retail being dead in PC's is very much untrue."
Not everyone agrees that superstores are the best answer, however. With 20,000-square-foot stores in high traffic locations, the superstore operators' fixed costs are high, and they must maintain a large inventory at all times. And most superstores, including CompUSA, are not franchised by I.B.M., Compaq or Apple, so they sell mostly clones, and clones do not build customer loyalty the way name brands do.
"It is going to be a much tougher battle for them than it is running a Circuit City," said Albert Bates, president of the Profit Planning Group, a retail consulting firm based in Boulder, Colo. Personal computers still need active selling, and the technology changes often, which can be disaster for a store sitting on a large inventory, he said.
CompUSA does offer full service, and can configure computers to meet customers' needs. In that respect it is more like the established computer resellers than the mass merchandisers.
And now the real mass merchandisers, warehouse clubs like Price Club, CostCo and Sam's, are getting into PC retailing as well. Mr. Merrin estimates that warehouse clubs, which offer no service or support, nevertheless sold more than $700 million in personal computers in 1990 and will hit $1.5 billion this year. The warehouse clubs can offer a high-powered clone, based on Intel's 486 chip, with a large capacity hard disk for $2,999 -- about 25 percent less than the name brands.
 
End of the Retailer
Instead, Direct Sales To Big Business
 The days when a customer could drive to the neighborhood Businessland or MicroAge store to look at PC's may be gone for good. The established computer resellers are closing expensive storefronts as fast as they can to focus on specialized business sales. With profit margins on PC's razor thin, they see more money to be made on service, support and the systems engineering needed to create complex networks of PC's.
"We closed our last retail store Dec. 31," said Tom Pelandini, a spokesman for Businessland in San Jose, Calif., once the largest company-owned retail computer chain. "You can no longer walk into a Businessland store and buy a computer." He sees Businessland's future in direct sales to major corporate customers. Of the superstores, he said:"We are not going to, nor can we compete with those kinds of places."
Similarly, MicroAge, based in Tempe, Ariz., has replaced its storefronts with "2,000 sales people knocking on doors," said Jeffrey McKeever, president and chief executive officer. "Retail stores got a black eye because as people began looking for more complex solutions, nobody could help them," he said. "It's impossible to clerk a store with highly knowledgeable technical people; the economics don't work."
One company that has successfully managed both ends of the market is the Tandy Corporation, based in Fort Worth, which is both a manufacturer and a retailer. Tandy sells to corporations through its Grid Centers, which are more like sales offices than stores, and sells to home and small- business users through its Radio Shack stores. Tandy computers cost more than the no-name clones, but typically offer more built-in software and other features.
"Our object is to not be just a clone," said John Roach, Tandy's chairman and chief executive officer. In addition, "there is a comfort factor in knowing we're going to be in business."
Another tack the established resellers are taking is to "unbundle" sales and service. They note that 90 percent of the $40 million in personal computer sales is to large corporations, many of which have large internal computer support staffs and are only interested in the lowest price. For businesses without internal computer staffs, they offer a range of services at a fee, from loading software to complete support.
 
Software Sellers
More Competition From Discounters
 Before there were superstores, there were software-only stores, which undercut computer dealers on price by selling in volume.
"Unfortunately for them, the superstore is primarily a software store," said Mr. Anderson. "What's happening to them is what they did to the traditional dealer channel."
But Egghead Discount Software, based in Issaquah, Wash., the largest software-only chain, has been able to return to profitability by increasing its emphasis on outside sales and continuing an emphasis on service and selection, said Matthew Griffin, Egghead's president and chief executive officer. "While we are still significantly discounted from retail we are slightly higher than the warehouses," he said. "We believe our customers will pay slightly more to have our selection and service."
 
BEATING THE CLONES ON PRICE
"The retail channel will never be the same," said Seymour Merrin, a leading PC retail consultant, referring to Compaq's across-the-board price cuts announced April 16. Responding to a raft of clones with similar features and lower price tags, Compaq slashed prices on its entire product line by as much as 34 percent.
Computer resellers have long griped that if I.B.M., Compaq and Apple had lower prices, the clone makers and warehouse stores might never have come to be. Apple introduced a new line of lower-priced Macintosh models last year, which have rapidly become its best-selling products ever. And on April 23, I.B.M. lowered prices on its models.
The result of these price drops should be a leveling of the playing field between traditional computer stores, which mostly sell the big three, and superstores, which mostly sell clones, Mr. Merrin said. Corporate buyers would rather buy from I.B.M., Compaq or Apple, but were no longer willing to pay a 30 percent price premium. Now they won't have to.
"What Compaq did -- and this is the single most conservative and deliberate company in our industry -- was not just to meet the competition but to beat the competition," Mr. Merrin said. "They are literally putting their prices below the clones. It's a guerrilla marketing tactic."
One interesting aspect of the Compaq price cut is that the actual price cut to the dealer was not nearly as large as the drop in the suggested retail price. This means that Compaq's own profit margins will suffer little, but it also means that the gap between what the dealer pays and what the customer pays has narrowed. That should make picking Compaq over a clone an easier choice.
Surprisingly, dealers do not mind the apparent shrinkage of their profit margin; this is because most of them were giving it away in discounts to customers anyway, and they believe the lower suggested retail price will bring in added sales. "It was all vapor margin anyway," said Computerland's Ed Anderson. "The truth is that in most major markets, hardware margins were really only 15 to 18 percent."

HEADLINE: Why Salvadorans Flock to the Island

 BODY:
I must take issue with some of the economic and political implications of the article "Illegal Aliens Say Census Missed Thousands" [March 24, 1991]. The tone of the article suggests that most Salvadorans are here in this country because of political repression back in El Salvador and that they held the U.S. responsible.
One illegal refugee was quoted as saying, "It's hard to reach people on Long Island. . . . North Americans are cold to the suffering of our people."
The fact is, it must be hard to reach Salvadorans about the conditions of their country, too, because in election after election they keep electing the right-wing Arena Party, which is associated with death-squad activity.
In fact the United States has pursued a policy in El Salvador of political moderation that many Salvadoran people find soft on communism. That's why the Christian Democrats and Jose Napoleon Duarte were resoundingly turned out of office several years ago and why the Arena Party won another resounding victory this last month.
I was in El Salvador when Reagan won the election back in '84, and the people were jubilant, so afraid most of them were that Mondale was going to discontinue military aid.
All my Salvadoran in-laws who have come to this country hate communists with a passion that even the staunchest American conservative would admire. They all vote for Arena, and every one of them is here for economic, not political reasons. Their objective in the United States is simple. They want to make money.
Other than one college educated refugee I've spoken with and the people at the Central American Refugee Center, I've never met a Salvadoran who expressed the slightest shred of support for the guerrilla movement. They hold the guerrillas responsible for the social, political and economic turmoil of their country.
The article also suggests that Salvadorans have been exploited on Long Island. Considering their lack of economic resources, marketable skills and, often, the ability to speak English, they've done pretty well. Long Islanders should not be held responsible for the conditions under which poor Salvadorans must live because these people have come on their own. Long Island has enough "home-grown" poverty.
I suggest that liberal theologians and refugee organizations educate the Salvadoran people, not North Americans, about conditions in El Salvador. Most Salvadorans are remarkably misinformed, ignorant or indifferent to the roots of their country's present turmoil.
The fact that Salvadorans overwhelmingly re-elect right-wing leaders linked to death-squad activity underscores this point. And of the many Salvadorans I know who are seeking "political amnesty" or refugee status, not one would support even the moderate Christian Democrats over the conservative Arena Party.
These people use the political-amnesty claim because they know it is often the only way they can gain legal entry into this country. I know Salvadorans who while benefitting from amnesty workers and liberal religious groups here denounce what they call "liberation ideology" back home as meddlesome and sympathetic to Communists.
The massive influx of Salvadorans to the United States -- many of whom are indeed uncounted -- is a result of overpopulation, chronic poverty exacerbated by the revolution of rising expectations wrought by United States influence and, finally, the Civil War of the last 10 years. Most Salvadorans see the Communist-led insurgency and the Civil War as a cause, not as a result of the many problems that beset the country.
Journalists and refugee organizations are right in underscoring the chronic injustices of Salvadoran society, and wrong in leading North Americans to believe that the Salvadoran people at large share this concern. For most Salvadorans the concern is to make a living in a stable economic and political atmosphere.
 
HARRY KATZ
Wading River

HEADLINE: Vietnamese Streaming Into Hong Kong

BYLINE: By BARBARA BASLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HONG KONG, May 11

 BODY:
Ignoring constant warnings carried by Vietnamese radio and television about the bleak reception awaiting them here, Vietnamese boat people are once again sailing to Hong Kong in large numbers.
More than 800 arrived in the first week of May alone, 378 of them in eight boats on Tuesday -- the highest one-day total in nearly two years. Hong Kong Government officials say more than 4,500 Vietnamese have arrived so far this year, compared with only 6,400 who came in all of 1990, prompting fears that this British colony may face a crisis like the one in in 1989, when 34,000 Vietnamese fled here.
 
Officials Are Concerned
 Clinton Leeks, the Government's refugee coordinator, said that even though spring and summer are traditionally the most popular times for the Vietnamese to come, the big jump in arrivals compared with last season is "what is troubling us most." 
 Mr. Leeks said the Government once believed the high numbers of boat people who arrived in 1989 were "an aberration, but now we believe that the low numbers of 1990 were the aberration. We think the whole thing may start up once again."
He attributed the low number of arrivals last year to the forced repatriation of 51 Vietnamese in December 1989. The forced return of the boat people was condemned by countries around the world, including the United States, and an embarrassed Vietnam, desperately seeking foreign aid and investment, has refused to accept any more such returns.
 
Talks With U.S. Officials
 Mr. Leeks said Hong Kong and Britain this month hoped to discuss the Vietnamese problem here with American officials, who have opposed forced repatriation of boat people.
Vietnamese have been locked in detention camps here since 1988, when the Hong Kong Government said it would no longer treat all boat people as refugees, who are accorded special protection under international law, but instead as illegal immigrants.
Since then all new arrivals have been taken to closed camps, where they must wait to be screened by immigration officers who decide whether they are refugees eligible for resettlement, or illegal immigrants who will eventually be sent home.
Government officials here say that most of the Vietnamese have left for economic reasons, an assertion disputed by many humanitarian groups.
Relief workers say conditions in the colony's 10 detention camps, which already house 47,300 Vietnamese -- the largest population of boat people in Southeast Asia -- are tense.
 
'Violence and Unrest'
 "You have thousands of men and women locked up, facing uncertain, almost hopeless futures, and that breeds violence and unrest," said a relief worker.
On Thursday, fighting broke out between rival factions of Vietnamese at the Hei Ling Chau camp, leaving 42 people injured, 2 of them seriously, camp officials said.
About 350 additional correction officers were called in to conduct a weapons search, which yielded 419 homemade weapons. On Friday, the colony's legislative leaders said no matter how large the influx, they would refuse to vote money for any new camps.
One legislator said that Hong Kong's "humanitarian" treatment of the Vietnamese "attracts them to come here." But Suzy Comerford, chairman of Hong Kong Refugee Concern, an umbrella group of relief agencies, said: "Hong Kong has had a harsh system of detention that was supposed to deter the boat people and it hasn't. It ought to be clear by now that deterrence as a policy doesn't work."
"We've been interviewing these arrivals to find out what has triggered this new stream of migrants, and really the reasons they are leaving Vietnam now are no different from the reasons they left in the past," said Mr. Leeks. "They are poor, and they hope to find a better life."
Of the 47,300 in the camps, a government official said, 30,509 are still awaiting screening, while almost 17,000 have already been screened out. An additional 6,700 Vietnamese are classified as refugees and live in open camps while they await resettlement.

HEADLINE: Chief Executives See Recession Lingering to 1992

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOT SPRING, Va., May 11

 BODY:
Differing markedly from the view of most economists, the people who run the nation's biggest companies say the recession is likely to linger for many more months, with a recovery not likely until next year.
"There's no sign of recovery -- none at all," declared Henry B. Schacht, chairman of the Cummins Engine Company, a leading producer of such cyclical bellwethers as diesel engines. "The people who buy industrial equipment are not buying it." 
 One after another, individual corporate chiefs among about 100 members of the Business Council who have been meeting here, expressed skepticism in interviews and discussions over the past two days about the recession's ending this summer, thus staying within the average length of the eight previous post-war recessions.
The lack of optimism among the all-male membership of the Business Council, a club-like organization of America's business elite that gathers at the plush red brick Homestead Hotel each May and October, contrasts with the council's own economic consultants, who are still predicting an end of the recession this summer. "We do not see an upturn in the economy until the fourth quarter," said Walter V. Shipley, chairman of the Chemical Banking Corporation.
 
Top Executives in Accord
 "Flat," said Harold A. Poling of the Ford Motor Company, normally an early participant in business recoveries. Their comments were echoed by the top people at such giants as General Electric, Xerox and TRW.
A 20-member panel of economic advisers to the Business Council, many of whom work for companies whose chief executives were gathered here, continues to hold the common view that the recession will be over by midyear. Of the panel members, 6 contend the economy began to recover in the first quarter, 10 hold that recovery will occur during the April-June period and the remaining 4 predict a recovery by the end of September.
In its formal report, the panel predicted a decline in the gross national product of 1.2 percent from the economy's peak last July, about half the magnitude of post-war recessions.
"Favorable factors in the outlook continue to be the absence of a large and widespread overhang of inventories which sharply depressed production in past recessions, rising demand for exports and, most important, the easing of monetary policy under way since last fall," said the technical advisers, who forged their views at a meeting April 30.
This morning, Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, participated in a closed discussion of the chief executives on the outlook for economy. But he gave little hint as to whether the central bank was inclined to begin another round of interest-rate cuts to help turn the economy around.
A meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee, which sets the central bank's monetary policy, is scheduled for Tuesday.
 
Greenspan Sees Low Point

Business executives made it clear to Mr. Greenspan that they desired further lowering of interest rates. But Mr. Greenspan indicated he thought the economy was already nearing its low point, participants at the meeting said.
 There would be very little inflation risk if the rates were lowered, said John F. Welch Jr., chairman of General Electric.
The divergence of views between the professional economists and the chief executives appeared somewhat ominous since the economists proved overly optimistic last fall when only 5 of 19 thought a recession had begun by Oct. 1. As it turned out, the recession had actually begun in July, the National Bureau of Economic Research determined late last month.
A recovery could come this summer, as the economists predict, suggested George M. C. Fisher, chairman of Motorola Inc. but he added, "I wouldn't want to bet on it. I wouldn't be surprised to see a pickup delayed" to year's end.

LENGTH: 1414 words

HEADLINE: How Best to Teach the Blind: A Growing Battle Over Braille

BYLINE: By KAREN DE WITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 10

 BODY:
Kenneth Silberman was in graduate school when he realized he had to learn to read and write.
Mr. Silberman, who is blind, discovered that the tape recorders and computers he had always used to get through school were little help in the studies required to earn a master's degree. 
 He ended up teaching himself Braille and received the degree, in aerospace engineering, from Cornell University. But he is still bitter that as a child with only limited vision he was not taught Braille and thus found himself illiterate in his mid-20's.
Mr. Silberman's predicament is not unusual. Braille, once taught to all the visually handicapped, has been partly supplanted in the last 40 years by such technological aids as tape recorders, voice-activated computers and machines that translate print into voice. As a result, illiteracy is on the rise among the nation's 13 million people with visual handicaps. The most recent figures available, from the American Printing House for the Blind, show that in 1989, only 12 percent of visually handicapped students read Braille, down from nearly 50 percent in 1965.
 
How Militant an Approach?
 The illiteracy rate is at the center of a battle over whether the best approach is technology and some Braille, or a wholesale return to Braille. The conflict pits advocacy groups dominated by those without visual handicaps against more militant groups dominated by the blind.
Those without visual handicaps want to teach Braille selectively. They say the other aids have a valid place and that the pool of visually handicapped people includes those with other disabilities, like mental retardation or tactile insensitivity, that would preclude them from learning Braille.
But the groups dominated by the blind argue that Braille should be mandatory for any visually handicapped person who is able to learn it.
Both sides agree on the stakes: whether more people with visual handicaps will become independent, productive members of society, or whether they will remain largely on the fringe. Seventy percent of the visually impaired who are of employment age are either unemployed or underemployed, according to Susan Spungin, associate executive director of the American Foundation for the Blind.
 
How the Groups Differ
 Dr. Spungin's group is run generally by people without visual handicaps. By contrast, the more militant National Federation of the Blind is dominated by those with visual handicaps. Still another group, the American Council of the Blind, is similar in philosophy to Dr. Spungin's and is run by both handicapped and non-handicapped people.
The struggle between those who would require Braille to be taught and those who argue that it should be taught only when necessary has gathered force since the passage last year of the Americans with Disabilities Act. The law prohibits discrimination against people with physical and mental impairments. It would, for example, require restaurants to assist blind customers by providing Braille menus or having a waiter read selections.
The tension over the teaching of Braille grows out of changes in education. Historically, all people with vision handicaps have been taught Braille in separate schools for the blind. But in the 1950's and 1960's, there was a shift toward integrating these students into public schools and encouraging them to use whatever vision they had.
 
The Degree of Handicaps
 Mr. Silberman, a 30-year-old administrator at the Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, Md., is among those who entered school in that period, just as technology like tape recorders, computers and machines that translate print into voice were becoming cheap enough for classroom use. The technology was considered a boon to those with visual handicaps, particularly people with "low vision," like Mr. Silberman. The feeling among some was that Braille was obsolete.
A person classified as visually impaired is one who has only limited sight and requires specialized care from an eye doctor. A legally blind person is one whose peripheral vision is reduced to 20 percent or who can see only the top "E" on the optical examination chart with the better corrected eye.
For Mr. Silberman and groups like the National Federation of the Blind, Braille is the solution not only to illiteracy but to dependency.
"There are a lot of blind people who can't take advantage of better employment opportunity simply because they can't use written words with facility," said Marc Maurer, president of the federation. "It isn't that we're oppposed to technology. Technology has enhanced Braille, has made it cheaper, made it more accessible and opened up more jobs for those who are blind."
 
Resistance From Parents
 But Dr. Richard Welsh of the Greater Pittsburgh Guild for the Blind disagreed. "Braille is a good medium for some students, but it's not the answer for every student," said Dr. Welsh, a former superintendent of a school for the blind in Maryland who opposed a bill two years ago that would have required the teaching of Braille.
The federation, whose headquarters are in in Baltimore, is demanding that Braille be taught to every legally blind person and is pushing for passage of Braille bills in state legislatures. Laws requiring that legally blind students be taught Braille are now in force in five states. Similar legislation is being considered in several other states.
Dick Edlung, a Democratic State Represenative, sponsored the Braille law that Kansas recently passed. "There was some resistance from teachers, but the major resistance to mandating that kids learn Braille was from the parents," said Mr. Edlung, who is legally blind. "A lot of parents don't want to have a blind kid."
Adapted in the early 19th century by a blind Frenchman, Louis Braille, from a code invented by another Frenchman, Charles Barbier, Braille is a system of six raised dots in 63 combinations representing letters and words that can be read by touching.
 
Aprons Over the Dots
 Opponents of mandatory Braille argue that it is inappropriate for some visually impaired people. They recall a period earlier in the century when students at schools for the blind who had some vision were forced to wear aprons to cover the Braille on their desks because they could see the dots.
"If you can read white dots on white paper with your eyes, then it is probably not appropriate to learn Braille," said Dr. Spungin of the American Foundation for the Blind.
But Mr. Silberman says even partly sighted people should learn Braille.
By the time he was studying astronomy at the University of Pennsylvania, Mr. Silberman said, "I was doing a lot of stuff with taped material, but have you ever tried to look for a specific piece of information on a cassette?" He said he tried to memorize everything, but "the work was getting steadily more sophisticated and I really struggled."
He won a scholarship from the National Federation of the Blind in 1985 and met other blind professionals who helped restore his self-confidence. As a result, he tackled the study of Braille. Mr. Silberman said that has made the difference between living on Social Security and food stamps and having a good job.
Dr. Spungin said the American Foundation for the Blind and the American Council of the Blind favor the use of Braille but object to legislation requiring it for all visually impaired people.
 
Labels for Disabilities
 She said a 1975 Federal law requires that special education students, including those with reduced vision, be given individual education plans, and that such plans can include Braille if parents and teachers think it necessary.
Like some other experts, she explains part of the increase in blind illiteracy by noting that medical advances have made it possible for more children today to survive with multiple disabilities, including impaired vision. But she said that many children are labeled visually impaired when they actually have multiple handicaps and will never be able to learn Braille.
Noreen Rysticken, a Baltimore speech and language pathologist and the mother of a multiply-impaired daughter, opposed the Maryland Braille bill.
"My daughter, Diane, has some functional vision, but she's also very delayed because of hearing impairments and cystic fibrosis," said Ms. Rysticken. "To force teachers to teach her Braille, would cause emotional problems. Braille is a reading system. She'll never read very much."

HEADLINE: For New Yorkers,Something Is Gone With Budget

BYLINE: By ALESSANDRA STANLEY

 BODY:
To the people who live in New York City, there is nothing abstract about the fiscal crisis anymore. Experts prescribe and politicians spar, but New Yorkers look past them at the city. What they see is loss.
They see the city budget through the prism of their own lives and jobs, fears and urban pleasures. Regardless of what happens in the coming weeks in the corridors and conference rooms of City Hall, many on the outside speak of a shared sense that New York City will never be quite the same again. 
 "I don't think that it will ever come back," said Stephen Bohannon, a 36-year-old video producer who lives with his wife and 5-month-old daughter in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn.
Mr. Bohannon was talking of the services he expected the government to cut. He was also referring to the economic boom, excitement, and confidence that drew him to New York in 1977 from the Midwest. "It's not that glittering place anymore."
The telling sign of a city's deterioration is in the eye of each beholder. To Llewellyn Lennon, 36, a Jamaican-born architectural designer, the crisis is one of unemployment. He has been out of work for 18 months. "If something doesn't break soon," he said, "I will have to drive a cab in a few weeks." A cleaning woman from the Caribbean, who would give her name only as Marre, said she feared walking down darkened streets of Flatbush, certain that the bad crime in her Brooklyn neighborhood would only get worse.
And Jacob Levich, a 31-year-old paralegal who lives in Manhattan and who spent the last four months hunting for his current job, said he saw decline most acutely in the simple luxuries of New York -- the parks he expected to be neglected and the libraries he expected to close. "Parks and libraries," Mr. Levich said, "provide the difference between an acceptable and utterly dismal existence."
Almost all the people who were interviewed last week spoke of danger, predicting that suffering caused by cuts in social services, employment and drug treatment would unleash class rage.
And many who heard the details of Mayor David N. Dinkins's doomsday budget proposals thought they smelled a bluff. They laughed dismissively at the notion that the city would really be forced to drain public swimming pools, turn off street lights or close the recently renovated Central Park Zoo. "It will probably cost just as much to remove the animals from their cages," said Neddi Heller, a painter and art teacher in Brooklyn.
Yet those same New Yorkers who were confident that not all the threatened service cuts would come to pass also gloomily predicted that those that were cut would probably never be restored. "Once services are gone, you can't bring them back," said Michele Krauthamer, 36, a teacher at a private school who is married to Mr. Bohannon. "Once people do without, they just keep doing without."
And few expect that the pain to be meted out by City Hall in the coming weeks will be remotely even. Most say they expect that those who will suffer most in the years of government's doing less will be those who already have little reason to rejoice about conditions in the city.
 
'People Will Be at Odds'
 This time, however, many predicted that even the well-off would not be entirely spared. "The lower down you are on the social scale the more these cuts hurt," Mr. Levich said, "but in the long run, even the well-to-do will be bothered. People will be at odds with each other."
The notion that greater unemployment, poverty, and crime would further pit the poor against the rich was widely shared. Mr. Bohannan put it this way: "The Mayor said that those who receive should also give something back, but for those who had it taken away, they are going to give some grief."
Not everyone was despairing -- but even the optimists worried that others would. "People are getting ready to retire and move," said Curtis Payadue, 66, an electrician from Cambria Heights, Queens. "I wish I could stay until I die, right here in New York, because I love the city."
Mr. Payadue said he was deeply troubled by how less-resilient New Yorkers would respond to higher taxes and service cuts. "You're going to knock the morale down," he said. "They're going to lose the spirit and you're going to lose those people doing things for the city, and we can't just cut our kids out and throw them to the dogs."
 
'I Don't Care How Bad It Is'
 Mr. Payadue had a warning for City Hall. "My advice to the Mayor would be, realize that certain things you cannot cut out," he said. "I don't care how bad it is, we have to have those things. They're talking about cutting the sanitation -- No, we need the streets clean. For appearance, for the morale of the city, you need to do things so that people can feel that you are trying, that you are saying, 'It's rough and tough but we're trying to weather those things.' "
There were those who expected their neighbors to pull together in adversity, and didn't scoff at the Mayor's plea for team spirit and volunteerism.
"I've seen more and more people really reaching out," said Durriyya Abdullah, an administrator at the Hudson Guild, a community center on 26th Street in Chelsea. "Last night I brought more than I could carry from the supermarket. When I came to a traffic light, I put my bags down to rest my arms. A woman I didn't know said, 'How far are you going? I'll walk with you.' "
"We cannot think that our backs are against the wall," Ms. Abdullah added. "True, our basic needs are being threatened. But we can assist in a very direct manner. There are people -- our neighbors, people we see -- who have a need, who we could help."
Her optimism, however, was not shared by Anthony J. Marra, a 48-year old municipal employee and lifelong resident of Staten Island. "There's no sense of community here," Mr. Marra said. "People are afraid to walk the streets. They don't know their neighbors. How can you expect them to want to help each other?"
Frustration over the city's straits quickly turns to anger at its leaders. "If I had been younger, I would have been part of the protest at Hunter over the tuition hike," said Ms. Heller, who is in her 30's. "It's miserable how the politicians have taken this education system and and taken away financial aid from students who really need to finish their education." She added a lament that was echoed by many others. "The wrong people are being taxed: the poor and the middle class."
Ms. Krauthamer worried about what was being done with her tax dollars. "I think there is a lot of corruption and money wasted unnecessarily," she said, adding that she saw it most clearly along the Eastern Parkway, whose restoration was stalled last year after the contractor filed for bankruptcy. "I think the city could be more careful who they do business with."
 
Call Seems Hollow to Some
 The call for sacrifice from City Hall also rang hollow to Mr. Lennon, who said he had seen little on the part of elected officials. "The City Council won't even take a cut in pay for their part-time jobs, which makes me feel like there is money out there and people don't want to do their share." He added, "Management doesn't want to bite the bullet, in my opinion."
Jean Alexander, a single mother from Trinidad, suggested that organized labor could also pitch in. "I think the union people should at least listen to the Mayor and understand and not ask for raises."
Ms. Alexander, who runs a social service agency for Caribbean immigrants in Coney Island, knows first-hand that there are places in far worse shape than New York City.
"Some people only look at the bad sides of things," she said. "If it were only bad, why would people be coming here from the Caribbean and all over the world?"
 
Beacon With Less Luster
 "But," Ms. Alexander added quietly, "now is not a good time to be migrating, because migrants expect that things are going to be better here and they're going to find a job, but that's not happening now. There aren't that many jobs out there now."
Despite all its financial troubles, New York City remains a beacon for the least fortunate of the third world, but it has lost some of its luster for other traditional immigrants. Take the Greenwich Village artist.
John Zinsser, 30, is an abstract painter who lives in the East Village and works in a studio in TriBeCa. He stated, "I do feel that New York is still the important art city, because of the peer group and intellectual support community." But Mr. Zinsser said he could not afford to ignore the city's weakened condition. "I've had a show in L.A." he said, "That eased my thinking, that New York isn't all there is."
