HEADLINE: Mexico City's Toxic Residue Worsens Already Filthy Air

BYLINE: By MARK A. UHLIG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ECATEPEC, Mexico, May 10

 BODY:
Whether the weather is cold or hot, one thing is usually certain in this northern Mexico City suburb: it snows.
Snow, at least, is the word that residents use for the fine white powder that blankets their streets and houses every morning. And it is a fitting description for what scientists say is a lingering cloud of wind-borne chemicals, raised from a giant caustic-soda plant beyond the horizon, that hangs above the working-class neighborhood.
"It even kills the trees," said Pedro Quesadas Herrera, a 40-year-old accountant, pointing to lifeless shrubs on the block where he lives with his wife and four daughters. "There's no way to get away from it."
 
Skin and Respiratory Ailments
 Amid the bare concrete houses and flat, rubble-strewn fields of Ecatepec, many adults and children have developed respiratory problems, and dozens bear large patches of rough, discolored skin on their faces and arms. The neighborhood air is so foul with sharp, industrial odors that it burns a visitor's eyes and throat.
Yet by Mexico City standards, Ecatepec's toxic snowfall is just one symptom of a deepening environmental crisis that has left the Mexican capital with the most polluted air of any major metropolitan area in the world.
Trapped by unfavorable geography and explosive population growth, Mexico City has what scientists say is an unequaled collection of atmospheric poisons. It is overwhelmed by industrial emissions, smoke, vehicle exhaust and human waste.
Saturated with contaminants, the grey-brown blanket of pollution that covers the Mexico City valley now routinely exceeds -- by as much as four times -- the maximum exposure limits established by the World Health Organization. Infectious diseases like salmonella and hepatitis can be contracted simply by inhaling bacteria suspended in the air. And doctors say that even mild outdoor exercise, like jogging, has now become a calculated risk.
As pollution problems have worsened, the Mexican Government, pushed by Mexico City's Mayor, Manuel Camacho Solis, has adopted increasingly stringent measures to force reduction in harmful emissions. Since late 1989, every automobile in the city has been required to remain idle one business day a week. This winter, the authorities banned traffic in 50 square blocks around the central plaza, Zocalo, and have begun shutting down dozens of industries for violating pollution laws.
Those efforts have been redoubled as environmental concerns have become central to the proposed free trade agreement grouping Mexico, the United States and Canada. Last fall, the Mexican Government announced a $2.5-billion, four-year plan to rescue the capital's air quality. In March, President Carlos Salinas de Gortari ordered the shutdown of the city's giant state-run oil refinery.
Despite such measures, daily concentrations of pollutants like ozone and nitrogen dioxide have continued to rise. In 1990, Mexico City exceeded maximum ozone limits four out of every five days of the year -- more than twice the level of Los Angeles.
Until now, renewed economic expansion has canceled out the hard-won gains of mandatory conservation programs, and well-intended decrees have been emasculated by lax or corrupt enforcement. But as Mexico City has labored through the worst season of contaminated air in its history, Government officials and environmental groups agree that the struggle against pollution has become a high-stakes battle for the city's survival.
"The citizen of Mexico City gets up every morning and the first thing he confronts is the pollution," said Homero Aridjis of the Group of 100, a group of writers and artists that has taken a leading role in anti-pollution efforts. "There is a contaminant for every hour, every activity. It has reached the level of an ecological catastrophe."
 
Tons of Foul Dust, A River of Sludge
 It takes just a glance from a high-flying aircraft to understand the causes of Mexico City's pollution crisis, which is defined, like the city itself, by a semicircle of volcano peaks that reach as high as 16,900 feet. "It is like a giant cup or bowl that is open only to the north, where the prevailing winds come from," an American scientist said. "So it acts like a catch basin, collecting every fume."
Carpeting the broad Mexico City valley is a seemingly endless sprawl of urban industries and ramshackle neighborhoods that have pushed the valley's population from 5 million to roughly 16 million in the last 40 years. That growth has made greater Mexico City the largest metropolitan area in the world, filling the valley with 2.8 million vehicles and tens of thousands of poorly regulated businesses -- from cement factories to public baths -- that foul the air with furnaces, incinerators, spray paint, solvents and open-air chemical stockpiles. They release a total of 4.35 million tons of pollutants into the city's atmosphere every year, Government statistics say.
The effect of those emissions is compounded by the city's high elevation, 7,280 feet above sea level. It reduces by 23 percent the oxygen needed for breathing and effective burning of fuel.
In the vast areas covered by urban squatters, where latrines and sewers are often nonexistent, that dust carries with it tons of dried fecal matter. A confidential United Nations study conducted in 1989 said that about 30 percent of Mexico City residents have no sewerage service, and their solid waste, deposited in open areas, contributes about 600 tons of fecal dust to the city's pollution each day.
Even where sewage is channeled into rivers or other means of disposal, it often remains exposed above ground, where it is carried into the air as gases or microscopic particles.
By the time it crosses north-central Mexico City, one such river, the Rio de los Remedios, appears to be less a body of water than a thick, venomous stream of black sludge. On the surface, the foul-smelling river shines with rainbow-colored slicks of oil and industrial discharges. But organic processes from untreated waste causes the river to release bubbles of gas from within, making it appear to boil as it slowly works its way across the city.
Once released into the air, scientists say, the chemical and bacterial pollutants are pressed down by early-morning inversions of hot air. Ground winds and local temperature variations then insure that the pollution becomes an equal opportunity affliction -- choking rich and poor neighbhorhoods alike.
 
Pollution and Illness: The Links Are Clear
 Trying to calm public fear about rising pollution levels, national officials have repeatedly asserted that there is no proven link between pollution and medical problems in otherwise healthy adults.
But years of studies in other polluted cities like Los Angeles and Tokyo have demonstrated the adverse health effects of such individual pollutants as ozone and nitrogen dioxide -- everything from skin reactions and eye irritation to weakness, lung disorders and increased susceptibility to heart attacks.
There is even less doubt about the health implications of the micro-organisms carried in Mexico City's fecal dust. Among the infectious ones identified in the 1989 United Nations study were salmonella, streptococcus, staphylococcus, shigella and amoeba.
Having found no Government answers to their patients' pollution concerns, doctors at one of Mexico City's leading private medical centers, the American British Cowdray Hospital, have pushed ahead with their own studies of lead and other contaminants, and are raising money to construct their own pollution monitoring station on hospital grounds.
Other physicians who deal regularly with large numbers of poor and working class patients have been more outspoken in their assessment of the city's environmental crisis. Dr. Juan Ortiz Feijoo, director of a state-administered hospital that serves more than 400,000 patients in north-central Mexico City, estimated that his staff has seen a doubling of cases of bronchitis and other respiratory ailments this year alone.
Similar increases, he said, have been noted for conjunctivitis and other eye disorders, with the most acute problems among children, the elderly and patients with existing illnesses.
Such statistics have been more than enough to sway many officials of private institutions, particularly those responsible for children. The superintendent of the American School, one of Mexico City's most prestigious preparatory academies, Fred J. Pasquale, explained why parents and teachers decided early in March to cancel all outdoor sports for the school's 2,300 students.
"The question was whether vigorous exercise is beneficial in Mexico City," Mr. Pasquale said. "The conclusion was that it is not." School officials are now studying the possibility of building a new sealed recreation area with filtered air for grade-schoolers.
Embassies and corporations have reached similar judgments about the pollution crisis, renting houses outside the capital for their staffs, and advising diplomats' families not to have babies while stationed here. While applauding the Government's anti-pollution efforts, the United States pays its diplomats a 10 percent hardship premium for enduring the city's air.
Converting medical concerns into free publicity, one small group, the Mexican Ecological Movement, has repeatedly drawn headlines by asserting its intention to install pay-per-breath oxygen booths across the city.
 
Lax Enforcement Obstructs Progress
 When he took office in December 1988, President Salinas declared the job of cleaning up Mexico City's air to be one of his principal objectives.
In 28 months, the Government has pushed through dozens of strict measures, including the nationwide introduction of unleaded gasoline, the replacement of more than 3,500 smoke-belching city buses, and the mandatory changeover of at least 94 major industries to low-sulfur fuels.
Those measures, officials say, have already reversed the growth of the two most dangerous pollutants, lead and sulfur dioxide. But peak measurements of harmful particles suspended in the Mexico City air have reached record levels, and other pollutants like carbon monoxide have, after drastic sacrifices, merely been held constant.
Even efforts like unleaded gasoline, which still accounts for only 3 percent of all gasoline burned in the city, have yet to prove their worth as long-term solutions. Other gains, like sewer-extension projects, have quickly become a perpetual race against the city's continued growth. Since the restrictions on car use were imposed, more than 275,000 additional cars have been registered in the city, as many as 10 percent of them purchased specifically to avoid the restrictions.
Above all, there is no clear indication that the Government has the means or the will to enforce its ambitious pollution standards.
On a recent day in the southeast Mexico City suburb of Iztapaluca, makers of a traditional clay brick known as tabique worked unmolested fueling the crude, house-sized furnaces that they have used for centuries to bake their wares.
A common fuel for the outdoor furnaces, which are designed to produce fierce, sustained heat, is sawdust soaked in fuel oil. But the local preference is for old rubber tires, which are cheaper and generate a powerful, virtually unextinguishable blaze that lasts for days. Both fuels send up billows of acrid black smoke that blanket the neighborhood and are visible for miles.
Asked about such flagrant environmental abuse, Government officials said that the brick factories are difficult to find or close because they operate clandestinely and move frequently from place to place.
But members of some of the 350 families that jointly operate more than a dozen furnaces in Iztapaluca said they have worked and lived in the same spot for at least 30 years. Their location is readily discovered by following the columns of smoke on the horizon.
Whether and how soon the Government can begin to address such glaring problems and improve its enforcement record is unclear. But there is little doubt what the costs of failure will be.
"They have to do something," said Silvia Salmeron Rodriguez, a 33-year-old mother who lives in Ecatepec with her seven children. "The air sticks to you, it chokes you, it burns your children. Nobody can live this way for long."

HEADLINE: States Using Donations to Get Medicaid Money

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR

 BODY:
WASHINGTON, May 11 --
Faced with soaring medical costs, states have devised a way to extract money from the Federal Government to pay for health care of poor people under Medicaid.
Bush Administration officials say the fund-raising technique is a scam that costs the Government more than a billion dollars a year, and they are trying to halt its use. But state officials say it is a legitimate way to finance expanded medical care for millions of women and children in low-income families mandated under recently passed Federal laws -- at no cost to state treasuries. 
 The device works this way: States collect "voluntary donations" from hospitals, count these contributions as part of the state share of Medicaid and then get $2 or $3 of Federal matching money for each dollar donated by the hospitals. Hospitals go along with the arrangement because when the Medicaid funds are paid out, they usually get back more money than they donated.
 
A Way to Pay Rising Costs
 Today, as for the last 25 years, general revenues are the main source of state Medicaid funds. But the hospital contributions have become increasingly important as states try to cope with the program's soaring costs in the midst of a recession that has depleted their revenues.
 Those donations and the related Federal payments finance health care for many pregnant women, new mothers and infants enrolled in Medicaid. Even though the Bush Administration says it wants to reduce infant mortality, it has drafted rules to end Federal matching payments for donations.
"Without these options, there is no doubt that the Medicaid program in Tennessee, after making great progress in recent years, would be forced to reduce benefits and services," said Norman B. Urmy, executive director of the Vanderbilt University Hospital in Nashville. Officials in other states expressed identical concerns.
Although Administration officials describe the hospital donations as a device invented by states to siphon money from the Federal Treasury, Federal courts have upheld the legitimacy of the technique, and Congress has explicitly allowed it to continue.
 
In Lieu of New Taxes
 Senator Wyche Fowler Jr., Democrat of Georgia, said states must be allowed to use "creative methods of financing Medicaid in these tough budget times, when health-care costs are skyrocketing and the Federal Government keeps setting new mandates" for the program. "I would much rather see a system of voluntary contributions from hospitals than the tax increases that might otherwise be needed," he said.
The fiscal condition of states is worse than at any time in the last decade, says the National Governors' Association. But state officials are reluctant to raise taxes, reading last year's election results as an overwhelming vote against new broad-based taxes.
Senator Bob Graham, Democrat of Florida, warned that "states will have to cut already insufficient benefits and reimbursement" if the Administration succeeds in restricting the use of donations and special assessments from hospitals.
A nationwide survey shows that eight states already accept donations from hospitals, for the specific purpose of getting more money from Washington for Medicaid, and 12 other states are considering such programs. A similar device -- a special state assessment on hospitals, used to get more Federal dollars for Medicaid -- has been adopted in nine states and is under consideration in 13 more.
 
Federal Objections
 The Department of Health and Human Services and the White House Office of Management and Budget object to both arrangements, saying they "unfairly increase the Federal share of Medicaid payments," distort the "Federal-state financial partnership" and permit states to finance expansion of Medicaid "with 100 percent Federal monies."
But state officials say the Administration's proposal to stop matching the hospital donations would violate the principle of federalism and usurp their authority to decide how best to raise money.
Nationwide, Medicaid finances health care for 27 million Americans, including 13 million children. States together pay about 45 percent of the program's total cost of more than $90 billion this year. The state share rises with a state's per capita income and ranges from 20 percent in the poorest state, Mississippi, to 50 percent in the most affluent states.
Georgia uses $35.5 million of hospital contributions to get $57 million from the Federal Government. Russell B. Toal, the state Medicaid director, said, "We are using the money for precisely the kinds of services that Congress and the Administration want: expanded eligibility for children, case management of prenatal care, home visits to new mothers and payments to hospitals that carry the burden of indigent care."
 
Helping Themselves by Donating
 While initially skeptical, hospital executives have come to appreciate the value of donating. W. Hoke Kerns, president of the Alabama Hospital Association, said: "Being able to generate additional revenue through voluntary contributions has enabled some of our rural hospitals to remain open. Otherwise they would have to close their doors because there is insufficient revenue to keep them open."
In Alabama this year, 24 hospitals are contributing $108 million to the state, which uses that money to obtain $288 million from the Federal Government. The state distributes the entire sum, $396 million, to hospitals, favoring those with disproportionately large numbers of low-income patients.
"We contribute to our own well-being," said Terry J. Smith, administrator of Bibb Medical Center, a 35-bed hospital in Centreville, Ala., that donates $8,000 a month to the state and gets back $16,000 a month for a net gain of $8,000.
Manly E. White, acting administrator of the Perry County Hospital and Nursing Home in Marion, Ala., said the voluntary contributions program was "a godsend" for many health-care providers. "It makes the difference between surviving and not surviving," he said.
 
How Transactions Work
 When hospitals donate to a state, they typically take the money from their general operating revenues. The donations are not just paper transactions; hospitals make actual cash contributions. While there may be a lag at first, the hospitals are eventually paid by state Medicaid programs at regular monthly or quarterly intervals.
While there is no legal limit on the donation amounts, hospital executives and members of Congress agree that donations should not exceed 10 percent of a hospital's gross revenues or 10 percent of a state's Medicaid spending.
States discovered the value of this fund-raising technique when they found that they had too little money to pay their share of Medicaid costs, creating a backlog of unpaid claims.
Missouri is using $88 million in donated funds to obtain more than $131 million from the Federal Government. "In light of the multiple Federal mandates placed on state Medicaid programs in the last few years, I have every right to be as creative as I can in paying for the program," said Donna E. Checkett, director of Missouri's Medicaid program.
In California, Sally Lee, chief of Medicaid operations, said the state had raised $147 million in voluntary contributions from hospitals and had obtained an equal amount in Federal matching funds. The money, she said, "keeps hospitals in business and improves access to medical care for the indigent."
 
Paying the State's Share
 In some states, hospitals contribute to Medicaid by paying part of the salaries of state or county employees who certify people as eligible for Medicaid. Salaries are considered an administrative cost. The Federal Government normally pays half of such administrative costs, with the expectation that states will pay the remainder.
However, in South Carolina, Missouri, Texas and several other states, hospitals pay the state's share of salary costs for eligibility workers assigned to hospitals to review Medicaid applications. The hospitals benefit because Medicaid pays many hospital bills that would otherwise go unpaid. Medicaid recipients often have neither private insurance nor the means to pay their own bills.
Thus, for example, South Carolina hospitals are contributing $2.3 million to the state's Department of Social Services to pay for 168 state employees who check eligibility for Medicaid. The Federal Government gives the state an equal amount for the salaries of those workers.
The eight states that accept donations to secure Federal matching funds are Alabama, California, Georgia, Massachusetts, Missouri, South Carolina, Tennessee and Texas. States that have been coonsidering such arrangements are Colorado, Florida, Indiana, Maine, Maryland, Michigan, Mississippi, North Carolina, Oregon, Pennsylvania, Utah and West Virginia.

HEADLINE: International Calamities Tax America's Compassion

BYLINE: By CELIA W. DUGGER

 BODY:
Caroline Trinidad, a New York City housewife and mother of four, cringes when she sees the painful images of a Kurdish woman cradling her hollow-eyed child or a Bangladeshi father touching his dead son's head. Then, as quickly as she can, she turns away.
"I want to do something, but I don't do anything. And I feel guilty," Mrs. Trinidad said this week, while she shared a snack at a shopping mall with her daughter and granddaughter. 
 "I get upset watching the babies dying. Who the hell wants to see that? I switch the channel. There's so much going on at once."
Surrounded by horrifying images of war, natural disaster, famine and pestilence in what relief agencies call an unprecedented convergence of international calamities, Americans are showing signs of disaster fatigue.
 
Numbed by So Much Sorrow
 Many of the 50 Americans interviewed this week in cities across the nation said they are moved by the suffering, but overloaded, confused, even numbed by so much sorrow from so many places at once -- the war in Iraq that displaced the Kurds, the cyclone in Bangladesh, the famine in Africa, the cholera epidemic in Peru and earthquakes in Soviet Georgia and Costa Rica.
These sentiments worry international relief agencies working feverishly to aid the millions of people in desolate landscapes dotting the globe. While Americans historically have given generously to such efforts, fund-raisers fear that all the calamities coming together are proving to be too much of a bad thing.
Though many Americans are contributing, the volume of donations has not surged sharply the way it did during the Ethiopian famine of 1984-85, said Peter J. Davies, president of InterAction, an umbrella organization for 132 relief agencies.
Then, the public was able to focus on one catastrophe. British Broadcasting Corporation film footage of children with bloated bellies and wizened faces aired on network television in October 1984, galvanizing public sympathy. And the song "We Are the World," recorded by famous entertainers, made the famine effort famous.
 
'How Do You Choose?'
 But now disasters are piling up like freight cars in a train wreck. "It's so complicated," said Phyllis M. Angelo, a retired teacher from Wakefield, Mass. "Who's going to help who? How? Who first?"
Some who want to help find that they first have to sort through a thicket of moral choices. Do we owe the Kurds more since we got them into that mess, they ask. Or should we help the innocents of Bangladesh, their homes swept away by tidal waves?
"How do you chose?! -- But I do. This is for the Kurds," a man from Pennsylvania wrote on a check for $1,000 he sent to CARE, an international relief organization.
Others find their concern finally moving to action. David Finckel, the cellist in the Emerson Quartet, who lives in Manhattan, said the members of his group want to do a concert for the children of Bangladesh. Phyllis Silverman, a psychotherapist in Manhattan, said she has not given any money yet, but is getting close.
 
'Can't Tune It Out Anymore'
 "When you just see pictures of dead babies, it's over. But when they're alive and suffering, you have to identify with the mother," she said. "I just can't tune it out anymore. I started connecting to what individuals are feeling."
Many other Americans, feeling the squeeze of recession and seeing the outstretched palms of the homeless on their own streets, have let the tragedies hit them in the gut, but not in the pocketbook.
Some expressed doubt that money contributed to international relief gets to the people who need it. Some said they would rather give to causes closer to home. Some have just tuned out. And some said they cannot afford to give.
Debbie Goldberg, who works in a bank in Chicago, tries to tell her three small children why there is hunger, but she does not give money to fight it abroad. She worries most about her family's economic survival.
"I am scared to death of losing my job and my husband is the same way," she said.
 
'Can't Even Get Unemployment'
 Donald Demby, a construction worker in Oakland, Calif., reacted testily to questions about international disasters. A sluggish local economy has wiped out his ability to give to any cause: "A person like me can't even get employment," he said.
Still, many who could give do not. "I know I should give something, and I know even a dollar a week would help a lot," said Casey Nonmacher, who manages a delicatessen in Houston. "But I guess I'm like most people, staying preoccupied with the stuff in my own life."
Bruce McInnes, who owns a tree-care consulting company in Manhattan, said the sheer number of catastrophes left him "confused and unfocused.
"There are so many problems," he said, "that even if you study the reportage, it's hard to tell what one person can do."
 
Gives Tips to Homeless
 The psychic wear-and-tear of life in New York City has left him "enameled" against the pleas of the homeless, though he said he tries to give to a street person at least once a day.
"By the time you get to the office and read the paper," he said, "you may be bereft of emotional capacity sufficient to move you to do something like writing a letter to your congressman saying, 'Do something for the Kurds.' "
Debbie Fleure, a waitress in an Oakland, Calif. pizzeria, said she tries to block out the disasters around the world, but she regularly gives her tips to the homeless.
"I figure somebody just gave it to me, I might as well pass it on," she said. "If Bangladesh had happened awhile ago, people could have helped. Now, with homelessness, problems in the schools, AIDS, crack -- when you start seeing all that here it really affects your ability to give."
Eric P. Davis, a Boston contractor, also sees a need to focus on the homefront. He started an ice-hockey progam for inner-city youth at a local rink, then watched it shut down recently because of state and city budget cuts.
"It's so disheartening to have all these countries get all the attention when we have people lying in the streets here," he said.
Officials in relief organizations, battling public fatigue, apathy and cynicism, rely on the press to get the word out. But while television moves some viewers to act, it numbs others, said Neil Postman, chairman of the Department of Communication Arts at New York University.
"The sheer abundance of images of suffering will tend to make people turn away," he said. "People respond when a little girl falls down a well. But if 70,000 people in Bangladesh are killed, of course people will say, 'Isn't that terrible' but I think the capacity for feeling is if not deadened, at least drugged."
Kay Hamner, an Atlanta executive, and Roux Harding, a Seattle window cleaner, find the images on the evening news strangely unaffecting.
"You can see real true-to-life pictures, but your mind reacts to it almost as if it's just a movie," Ms. Hamner said. Mr. Harding remarked, "It's too surreal when you're watching television."
 
Too Overpowering
 Other Americans find the images and stories all too overpowering. They avoid those items on the news or those articles in newspapers. Tracy Wik, an investment broker in Chicago, says she feels "sensory overload."
And Rob Andropolis, an excercise equipment salesman from Novato, Calif., said the slew of depressing news broadcasts induced him to switch from an all-news radio station to one that plays only classical music.
"I used to listen for the traffic reports and take the side routes," he said. "But now I just don't care if I get caught in traffic. The news was just too much."

HEADLINE: Reporter's Notebook;
Dollars Can Still Get You Scotch and Waterford Crystal in Baghdad

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BAGHDAD, Iraq, May 7

 BODY:
So far, Iraq's dollar-owning bourgeoisie with a taste for foreign living has been hit only selectively by the United Nations trade embargo.
At Baghdad's Duty Free Shopping Center -- a four-story emporium of imported goods for those with dollars -- the cans of pate de foie gras and the Parma hams have all been gone for several months. The only remaining foreign foods are boxes of Blue Diamond smoked almonds from Sacramento, Calif., and some crackers made in the United Arab Emirates. 
 But pretty much everything else is in plentiful supply, including Johnny Walker Black Label -- an Iraqi businessman's favorite tipple -- and wine from Italy and France, all at standard duty-free prices payable in dollars.
Upstairs are French dresses, Italian shoes, Sevres porcelain, Waterford crystal, German dishwashers, General Electric refrigerators, cosmetics and Harris Tweed jackets.
Amer Saleh, the center's manager, whirls his amber worry beads in his huge office complete with four telephones and three air conditioners, none of them working. "The blockade has stopped all imports," he said. "But we have stocks to last a year, perhaps two years."
 
The Money Game

Theoretically, the United Nations embargo bans all financial dealings with Iraq except for humanitarian purposes. But in practice, it has encouraged a flourishing black market in Iraqi dinars as residents try to change their outlawed currency for dollars, while foreign visitors seek to evade a punitive exchange rate.
Officially it takes $3 to buy one Iraqi dinar, although on the black market $1 used to buy six or seven dinars -- until just recently. In the last few days the Iraqi dinar suddenly shot through the ceiling, and the dollar collapsed, dropping in value to five dinars or under. But why?
The black market rate in the Baghdad souk is set by the rate Jordanian money changers pay for the Iraqi dinar in Amman. And one of Baghdad's biggest dealers, a jocular man known as Mr. Tariq, says he thinks that the Iraqi Government has been buying up its own dinars in Amman to increase their value.
A possible reason for doing so is that a stronger dinar makes foreign travel more expensive for those planning to go abroad when the travel ban is lifted May 15, by increasing the cost of acquiring dollars.
Alternatively, President Saddam Hussein may believe that a strong currency is a symbol of a country's national prestige.
 
 Babylon Revisited
 One ofPresident Hussein's favorite prestige projects has been the rebuilding of King Nebuchadnezzar's great southern palace in Babylon according to the designs of German archeologists early this century.
Work continued on the project through the long Iran-Iraq war, even though the Government had to import Sudanese laborers because its own were at the front.
Reconstruction has been more or less complete for a year now. And while archeologists may bicker over details, this immense set of interconnecting chambers and courtyards surrounded by crenelated fortifications is more interesting for visitors than the pile of mud that used to be all there was to see at Babylon.
Today, however, the southern temple is a desolate spot. Power and water have been cut off by the allied bombing, and its shops, museums and restaurants are closed.
But work is under way on a series of three huge viewing platforms just outside the walls of Nebuchadnezzar's Babylon from which visitors will be able to look down at new excavations Iraq is planning.
"This is the personal orders of the President," said Iraq's Director General of Antiquities, Mouyad Said.
Mr. Hussein has always identified with Babylon's most famous ruler. When Nebuchadnezzar built the southern palace in the sixth century B.C., he placed inscribed bricks in the walls telling his successors to repair it. Iraq's current leader has put similar bricks in his reconstruction, declaring that the palace was rebuilt "in the time of the leader Saddam Hussein."
 
 A Feminist Alert

Under the secular rule of President Hussein's Baath Party, women have come to have more freedom in Iraq than almost anywhere else in the Arab world.
Manal al-Lusy, the head of the Iraqi Women's Federation, traces the trends back to Hammurabi, King of Babylon in the 18th century B.C., pointing out that his legal code includes 93 provisions dealing with women's rights.
But now Iraq's feminists are worried by the President's promise to introduce multi-party democracy later this year. They fear that more democracy may lead to the rise of fundamentalist Islamic parties dedicated to putting women back under the veil, as has happened in Algeria and some other Arab countries.
Last month, Mrs. Lusy organized a meeting of women to discuss the danger. They agreed that the answer is for women to play an active role in founding the new parties.
"If we have democracy, I'm not going to believe all parties will support the rights of women like the Baath Party," she said. "Look at Egypt. There are no women in the Parliament there. But we have 15 out of 250."

HEADLINE: The Region;
Dreams Deferred and Payments Due

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
AS he urged New Yorkers to pitch in with sacrifice and courage to endure the city's worst fiscal pains in years, Mayor David N. Dinkins promised last week, "Together, we can ensure that our dreams, though deferred, will never, ever be denied."
The Mayor has been forced to defer dreams so often since he took office 16 months ago that he clings to that comforting phrase from Langston Hughes's poem "Harlem." But he sometimes seems to overlook the poem's final warning about what happens to a dream deferred.
Maybe it just sags
like a heavy load.
Or does it explode? 
 The $28.7 billion doomsday budget that Mr. Dinkins proposed to the City Council on Friday would explode many New Yorkers' fondest hopes for themselves and their city by closing homeless shelters, clinics and the Central Park Zoo, laying off about 20,000 workers and raising $1 billion in new taxes to pay for the privilege of not cutting even more.
The Council, up for re-election this fall, has vowed both to hold down Mr. Dinkins's proposed taxes and restore programs. Just how it can do that before the new fiscal year begins July 1 is unclear. But flexing its muscles under a new City Charter that gives it sole power to approve the budget, the Council is determined to try.
Mr. Dinkins hopes to avoid the very worst of the cuts by pressuring municipal unions -- to whom he recently granted raises -- and state officials to make concessions and give him more aid. But by any measure, the Mayor, squeezed between the recession and his own managerial choices to grant raises and hire thousands of police officers, will sacrifice much of the expansive agenda he campaigned for.
Twice on Thursday, in public at City Hall, he lost his composure, and he was forced to stop speaking. "People who think that this is some process that one engages in as an exercise really don't understand," he said. "Not if you care. This administration cares deeply."
That very tender-heartedness has sometimes tripped Mr. Dinkins as he sought to thread his way through the twisting maze of the city's deepening problems. In a somber televised speech last week, he assured residents, "At each step along the way, we have tried to cushion the blow." He has postponed layoffs as long as possible, losing flexibility and leading his predecessor, Edward I. Koch, to dismiss him as Scarlett O'Hara, content to think about it tomorrow. Actually, Mr. Dinkins seems more like Scarlett's rival, Melanie Hamilton, firm in his belief in the fundamental goodness of others. He often says, "Most people are truly good at heart."
Elected with broad union support, Mr. Dinkins suffered labor's scorn for sending mixed signals by first granting raises, then hiring thousands of police officers, then threatening layoffs. Up to now he has generally asked labor leaders for just what he needed, or even less. That has left the leaders, themselves elected officials, without the ability to follow the classic ritual of excoriating a demand for cuts by the city, then compromising after loud negotiations and finally claiming victory to their members.
The Mayor's latest demands -- more than half a billion dollars in concessions through wage deferrals, early retirements or work-rule changes, his aides say -- have produced conciliatory reactions. "It is not a point of options or cutting a deal," said Stanley Hill, the head of the largest city workers union, District Council 37 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees. "It is a matter of necessity to avoid these massive cuts and layoffs."
Mr. Dinkins has had trouble making austerity sound appetizing to a city whose steady but elusive goal for more than a decade was to restore the perceived quality of life of the days before the fiscal crisis of 1975. From 1982 to the time Mr. Dinkins took office, nearly 50,000 workers were added to the city workforce, many of them in the proud and politically irresistible name of recovery. "Blood, toil, tears and sweat may have worked wonders for Winston Churchill, but it cuts no ice at City Hall in 1991," Felix G. Rohatyn, the head of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, said before Mr. Dinkins's latest proposed cuts.
Now Mr. Dinkins is seeking help from the corporation, which was set up to borrow money on the city's behalf in the last crisis, hoping for $200 million to $300 million through refinancing some of the corporation's bonds. Mr. Rohatyn has agreed to talk, but has made no promises.
Meanwhile, Mr. Dinkins has pressed Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, who is facing even bigger fiscal problems, for more aid, and vowed to do whatever it takes to avoid a takeover of the city's finances by the State Financial Control Board, which Mr. Cuomo heads. The control board could reimpose binding powers over city spending if the city ended the current year with a deficit of $100 million or more or lost access to the bond market.
Mr. Dinkins has declared high noon so many times in his administration that by now it seems like four o'clock at City Hall. New Yorkers who wonder just what is going on might take comfort from some other lines of Langston Hughes:
There's liable
to be confusion
in a dream deferred.
From river to river,
Uptown and down,
There's liable to be confusion
when a dream gets kicked around.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Mayor David N. Dinkins appealing for sacrifices during a speech last week on the city's fiscal crisis. (Chester Higgins Jr./The New York Times)

HEADLINE: African Dilemma: Food Aid May Prolong War and Famine

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ

 BODY:
ONCE again, the reports of starvation are trickling in from parts of Africa. And it is clearly no coincidence that the countries most menaced by famine this season are those that have been mired in long civil wars. Impoverished, warring nations have the worst food problems: peasants cannot plant or harvest during war, armies and rebels confiscate food for themselves, including in some cases well-intentioned Western supplies.
As Western nations gear up yet again to save the starving peoples of Africa they find themselves caught between their humanitarian obligation to feed the hungry and their growing conviction that donated food, far from solving the problem, may in some cases be aggravating rather than alleviating the hunger. In case after case, these officials believe, food from outside helps to subsidize the habits of civil war. 
 This time, too, the relief effort is overshadowed by the immediate needs of people elsewhere -- the Kurds in Iraq, the cyclone-devastated Bangladheshis -- whose disasters came in swift blows.
The United Nations Food and Agricultural Organization says as many as 35 million people are at risk in the six African countries most threatened by famine: the Sudan, Ethiopia, Somalia, Liberia, Mozambique and Angola. These countries have one common thread: civil war. In Angola a peace accord has just been concluded, a positive sign; but because of the intensity of the war and the still-hot suspicions, food supplies for those in need will probably not immediately improve, officials say.
In Ethiopia and the Sudan, where drought as well as drawn-out war have contributed to crop failures, the end of conflict would make it much easier to deliver relief food. In eastern Ethiopia, a relief truck hit a mine last month; in southern Sudan, food convoys are regularly shot at by Taposa tribesmen armed by the Government. In Kopeata, a town under the control of the Sudan People's Liberation Army for more than two years, the marketplace remains barren because the few peasants who might have food to sell are fearful of moving from their villages.
"If peace prevailed there would be no problem in dealing with the shortages -- the commercial systems would work better and so would the relief systems," said Willard J. Pearson, director of the United States Agency for International Development office in Ethiopia.
 
Falling Short of the Need
 But there are shortages, most of all shortages of aid. In the Sudan, where Save the Children says 10 million people are in danger of starving, the United Nations has said that 1.2 million tons of food are needed in 1991. But a Save the Children report said so far only about 72,000 tons have been delivered. The United States has pledged about 300,000 tons of food, and Government figures show spending of $82 million for the Sudan and $53 million for Ethiopia between October 1990 and March. The European Community has pledged $167 million, or 400,000 tons of food, to African nations, but has not yet decided how to raise the money.
As officials of Western governments reassess their past unquestioning efforts to provide relief, they are not, they say, sending less food to places of need. It is not feasible, these officials say, to impose strict "you make peace or we won't give you food" conditions on food aid.
"If you condition the food aid on a certain event such as negotiations taking place and play a game of hardball to see how many people die, the humanitarian providers are going to blink first," said an American official organizing food aid to Africa.
On both humanitarian grounds and for domestic political reasons it would be unacceptable to allow mass deaths by starvation. Americans, even if a little weary of hearing about what seems like constant famine in Africa, do not like seeing starving Africans on their television screens if they believe something can be done to stop the suffering. But, said one official, "we need to organize a strategy in a more hard-minded way."
Humanitarian policies of donating millions of tons of food to warring governments and rebels have helped prop up combatants who care little for the civilians they purport to represent. With the food needs of the starving entirely taken care of by outsiders, the warring parties sometimes partake of the donated food themselves or find themselves left with more resources than they might otherwise have.
Last year, for example, the International Monetary Fund found that the Sudanese Government had sold large stocks of pre-drought grain abroad. Much of the foreign exchange earned by the sales is believed to have been spent on weaponry from China to continue the civil war against the southern part of the country, now in its 20th year.
Now, with the Sudanese Government's reserve food stocks sold, the United States and European donors find themselves struggling to deliver hundreds of thousands of tons of grain to stave off starvation among the Sudanese, against what have been almost insuperable barriers placed by the regime.
In Ethiopia it has been common practice for local government militia members to receive as a form of payment bags of food sent for famine relief. Now, Western donors are trying to weave through war zones to deliver food to hungry Ethiopian civilians as well as Sudanese and Somalian refugees who have sought sanctuary in Ethiopia from their own civil wars.
In southern Sudan, where the Sudan People's Liberation Army controls almost all the territory, Western donors say the leaders behave as though it were the international community's duty to feed the civilians while the rebel forces fight. 
During a visit to Kopeata, the French Minister for Humanitarian Action, Bernard Kouchner, told representatives of the rebel group that sympathy in the West for African people perpetually at war was wearing thin.
"The international community is tired of the mix of war, politics and drought," Mr. Kouchner told representatives of the rebel army and of the Sudan Relief and Rehabilitation Association, its civilian wing.
Mr. Kouchner's anger was sparked in part by the hopeless and virtually unchanged conditions in Kopeata, which the rebel army has controlled for more than two years and to which much aid has been sent. "There is a new hospital ward but that is not good enough," said Mr. Kouchner. "They are asking for white people to pay for everything."
A more hard-minded policy toward food deliveries would involve, among other things, more monitoring of where relief food goes, American officials said. More of an effort has to be made, they said, to insure that food designated for civilians does not end up in the hands of either government or rebel armies.
On the rebel sides of both the Ethiopian and Sudanese conflicts, for example, large quantities of food are provided by Western donors with no precise knowledge of where it goes. For the last several years, the United States has quietly provided food to the relief organizations of the Eritrean People's Liberation Front and the Tigrean People's Liberation Front, rebel groups that appear to be on the verge of defeating the Ethiopian Government. The food is moved from Port Sudan across the Sudanese border but is not accompanied by outside monitors. During their recent successful offensives, the Ethiopian rebels captured the best food-producing areas in Ethiopia -- the provinces of Gojjam and Gondar -- presenting another reason, some Washington officials suggest, for slowing the unmonitored food across the Sudanese border.
Similarly, the United States has been sending food through Kenya to rebel-held southern Sudan. In southern Sudan, there are fewer aid officials from outside agencies than ever before. This is in part because of the increasingly hostile attitude of the Sudanese People's Liberation Army and the Sudan Relief and Rehabilitation Association toward Western relief officials.
Some United Nations food monitors have been expelled by the rebel army in the last year because, according to United Nations officials, they asked too many questions.
And when Mr. Kouchner left southern Sudan he took with him a French volunteer doctor who had been thrown in a pit -- a form of jail -- by the rebels after taking a photograph of a water pump. The doctor, Jean Michel Bouvard of the organization Aide Medicale Internationale, said the rebel group also denied him use of the United Nations radio to contact the outside world.
Mr. Kouchner asked the rebels to allow the doctor to use the radio but when they refused, the doctor cut his stay short and left. Dr. Bouvard said he believed the rebels were hostile toward him because he was not offering tangible goods, like food, that they could use, but rather medical services for civilians.

HEADLINE: The Nation;
As Funds for Welfare Shrink, Ideas Flourish

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
NOBODY likes welfare, and this year it shows. Across the country, officials are unveiling proposals to pay the poor less, work them more and coerce or cajole them into families with fewer children and a father at home. Black and white, liberal and conservative -- everyone seems to have a thirst for change and a six-point plan to boot.
Unease about the dole is an emotion as old as America itself; the nation has spent centuries trying to solve the dilemma of how to supply enough support to help but not so much as to foster dependency. This year, another factor upsets the seesaw: money. Case loads are up, coffers are empty and deficit-ridden state governments are looking for places to tinker and cut. 
But beyond these immediate, budget-driven pressures, something more enduring may be under way. Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the New York Democrat known for his rhetorical sweep, reads into the pattern of a cut here, a work requirement there, the stirrings of a new epoch that he grandly terms "post-industrial social policy."
"What you are seeing is the steady emergence of dependency as the defining issue of American social welfare policy," he said.
In the industrial era of the last 100 years, he argued, the curse was sudden unemployment -- "the Hoovervilles of people accustomed to working, but suddenly without a job." By contrast, he said, "the curse of this era is dependency -- people who aren't in the work force at all." Recent studies show that more than 30 percent of the nation's children will spend a year on welfare before they reach age 18, he said, making welfare, next to public schools, "the most important program we've got."
One category of current proposals would simply cut checks. Another would add work requirements. A third would mix carrots and sticks to guide the poor into smaller and more stable families.
In terms of cutbacks, Michigan has gone farthest and fastest. Facing a $1.1 billion deficit, Gov. John Engler, a Republican, took office in January and reduced welfare checks by 17 percent. Under Aid to Families with Dependent Children, this cut the monthly payment for a family of three to $436, from $525. Smaller, but still substantial cuts have been proposed by the Republican Governor of California, Pete Wilson, and passed last week by the liberal Democrats who govern the City Council in the District of Columbia. These cuts come at a time when the purchasing power of A.F.D.C. payments nationwide has already eroded by 42 percent since 1970.
A second group of proposals has focused on swapping work for welfare. This, of course, is scarcely a new idea; it is essentially what President Franklin D. Roosevelt did in the Depression when he started the Works Progress Administration. But recent experiments have remained small in scale, and forcing poor women to work is a tougher, and potentially more expensive, goal than many people realize. Many mothers would need child-care services. Supervision on the job can be expensive. And sanctions can be difficult to enforce, since cuts in aid to the mother are cuts to the child as well.
Current work proposals include a referendum passed last fall in Oregon seeking Federal permission to start a six-county experiment to replace welfare with a system of guaranteed jobs. Those involved would be paid 90 percent of the minimum wage, a rate intended to maintain the incentive to find regular work.
In New York, the state Social Services Commissioner, Cesar A. Perales, has proposed adding a work provision to the state's Home Relief program, which serves poor people who don't qualify for A.F.D.C.
 
Disintegrating Families
 The third set of proposals takes as its target the dissipating American family, a problem contributing heavily to poverty rates. While 12.8 percent of the population falls below the poverty line, that figure is 35.9 percent for members of female-headed households.
During his unsuccessful campaign for Governor of Massachusetts, John R. Silber, the outspoken conservative Democrat, made headlines when he suggested abolishing welfare for teen-age mothers who have a second child. "If she gets pregnant again, until she is married and capable of taking care of her own children, she will receive no welfare whatsoever," he said. "And if she cannot care for her child, her children will be taken away from her."
Perhaps an even greater controversy erupted in Kansas when state Representative Kerry Patrick, a Republican, proposed financial incentives for welfare mothers to use the contraceptive Norplant. He would pay them a $500 one-time bonus, plus $50 a month, to have the device implanted.
Critics called the proposal an attempt at coercion, and it failed by a 77-to-27 vote. They also said it misdiagnoses the problem, since the average welfare family now has only three members. Mr. Patrick said he hoped to save the state money and help mothers avoid long stays on welfare.
In recent months several elected officials have made other proposals intended to retool the families of the poor. In Wisconsin, Gov. Tommy Thompson, a Republican, would stop paying teen-age mothers extra money for additional children and would provide financial bonuses to those who marry. In New Jersey, a plan put forward by Representative Wayne R. Bryant, the Democratic majority leader of the State Assembly, included similar provisions. Likening the current system to slavery, Mr. Bryant, who is black, said, "We, as African-Americans, know very well that it separates fathers and mothers from their children."
To some degree, these and other proposals are building on principles espoused in the 1988 Family Support Act, the welfare redesign crafted by Senator Moynihan. It requires an increasing percentage of welfare mothers to enroll either in work or training programs as a condition of their aid. But the law is just now taking effect, and many states have little money to get programs off the ground.
Senator Moynihan has pointed to the legislation as the capstone of a career in social policy that attracted attention in 1965, when his explosive Labor Department paper, known as the Moynihan Report, warned that a quarter of black children were being born to single mothers. Now, a quarter of all American children are born to single mothers, and the figure for blacks is 63.5 percent.
"I've been making this case, and feeling a little more confident about it, and a little more articulate, for a quarter century," Senator Moynihan said.
Mickey Kaus, the author of a forthcoming book that includes a history of welfare-policy debates, agrees that eliminating dependency is the biggest challenge. But Mr. Kaus, who wants to abolish welfare and start a huge system of guaranteed Government jobs, says the Family Support Act is "a small improvement" riddled with loopholes.
"Moynihan's great at analyzing the problem," he said. But pointing to the constantly worsening statistics, he added: "Unfortunately, he's consistently failed to come up with the solution."

HEADLINE: The Disasters Multiply And Compassion Falters

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
RELIEF agency officials say there has never been a time in recent history when so many disasters with such different natures have struck so many people.
The exodus of two million Kurds from their homes in Iraq resulted from a political crisis, a brief but bloody civil war that broke out in the aftermath of the allied victory over the Iraqis. 
 That was followed by a natural disaster: a cyclone in Bangladesh -- the 55th since 1900 -- which has killed more than 125,000 people and left 10 million others homeless. The predictions are that as many as 300,000 people may die from starvation, exposure and disease.
Meanwhile, a cholera epidemic is spreading across Peru and other South American countries and earthquakes have recently struck Costa Rica and Soviet Georgia.
And 27 million people in six countries in north Africa face death from starvation and civil war in what the relief agency Save the Children has called "the worst famine in Africa in living memory."
The task of ministering to a world ravaged by disaster has overwhelmed private humanitarian organizations, the United Nations and donor governments. Traditional donors, battered by so many appeals, are weary of pouring money into crises that never seem to go away. The result is a discouragingly contagious compassion fatigue. Even though many relief agencies report that donations have only dipped slightly despite the global recession, they say that the scope of the crisis requires a massive infusion of money and attention from new sources.
"Those of us who have been in the battle for years are tired and battered," said Tom Getman, director of government relations at World Vision, a private relief organization. "It's time for a whole new cadre of donors to emerge from around the world." To educate and encourage potential donors in the United States, Interaction, an umbrella group representing more than 100 relief organizations, will introduce a 900 telephone line next week.
While the world responded, albeit somewhat belatedly, to the Kurdish crisis, it has been more difficult to drum up enthusiasm for Bangladesh, whose history has been cursed by natural disasters. The United States, for example, has given $7 million for cyclone relief and 67,000 tons of food, and has received approval for additional food aid and funds. Bangladesh has pleaded for military helicopters to ferry food and medical supplies that are sitting in warehouses waiting for a delivery system, with little response.
The refugee relief effort in northern Iraq, by contrast, will cost the United States and its allies between $500 million and $700 million for the first six months of its operation.
The response to an evolving, seemingly endless crisis like the famine in the Sudan, a byproduct both of war and the government's refusal to heed the warning signals of famine, is even less enthusiastic.
Helping the victims of African famine was in vogue in the mid-1980's, and there is a reluctance to believe that the problem not only remains unsolved, but will be much worse this time.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Cyclone survivors at a relief camp in Hatiya, Bangladesh, last week. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: The Flutters;
Adding Up Concern For Bush and Doubts About Quayle, the Democrats Get Zero

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
PRESIDENT BUSH'S irregular heartbeat sent a tremor through American politics last week. Suddenly, there was new talk of the "Quayle factor" and a flurry of polls that showed a majority of Americans still queasy at the thought of a Quayle Presidency.
After a spring when Mr. Bush seemed destined for a triumphant, painless stroll to re-election, it was an object lesson in how quickly the political ground might shift. The post-war euphoria is fading, the economy still lags and Mr. Bush's health problem, although soon attributed to a treatable thyroid condition, reminded many people -- including nearly half of the Republicans -- that they would prefer someone else as Vice President, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll. 
 In the midst of all this, the President was forced to crack down on the travels of his chief of staff, John Sununu, in response to embarassing reports about his heavy use of military aircraft.
These may not be huge vulnerabilities, but they should be enough to occupy an opposition party 18 months before a Presidential election. The Democrats, however, are consumed once again with their own problems. In Cleveland, Des Moines and points between, they were thrashing about, fighting over message and strategy and divided over issues. At this point four years ago, they were griping about their Presidential field, often referred to as "the seven dwarves." Now, with just one official candidate in the race, former senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts, Democrats would be grateful for options of whatever size.
What they desperately need is a leader with a unifying vision. The party seems more balkanized than diverse these days; Republicans have the luxury of watching the opposition fight itself. "They can't take advantage of any opportunities," said Mary Matalin, chief of staff of the Republican National Committee.
 
In Search of Themselves
 Throughout the 1980's, as Democrats struggled to adjust to the rise of Reaganism, the party was pulled in two directions: Centrists and conservatives, many of them based in the South, argued that the national party must lose its liberal image and broaden its appeal to the middle class. The liberals, meanwhile, warned of losing the Democratic soul and said that a tough "progressive" message could win with the right messenger. This debate was waged last week with an edge of anger.
In Des Moines, the Coalition for Democratic Values, a group of liberals, railed against what Senator Howard Metzenbaum of Ohio called "shadow Republicans" in their own party. They re-committed themselves to aggressive new government efforts on health care and other domestic needs. They listened to populist stalwarts like Jim Hightower, the former Texas Agriculture Commissioner, inveigh against Wall Street.
In Cleveland, the Democratic Leadership Council, a group of conservatives and centrists, approved a manifesto that declares: "In the minds of too many Americans, the Democratic Party has stood for government programs that don't work, special interests before the interests of ordinary people and a reluctance to assert American values at home and abroad." They disavowed racial hiring quotas, although saying they supported equal opportunity, and endorsed a variety of programs to end welfare dependency. They also broke soundly with organized labor on the free trade issue and endorsed giving the President "fast track" authority in negotiations with Mexico.
 
Lecturing Leaders
 Meanwhile, down the street in Cleveland, the United Auto Workers held a rally against the "fast track" for a Mexican treaty. And across town, the Rev. Jesse Jackson, who was very pointedly not invited to speak at the leadership council meeting, was holding forth in a union hall on "rebuilding America."
Ronald H. Brown, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, went to Cleveland with the attitude of a disgusted hall monitor, sternly lecturing the leadership council that "factions and bickering serve no purpose except to strengthen our opposition." Indeed, on trade and civil rights, the debate was moving onto the most sensitive ground, the Democratic Party's relationship with blacks and organized labor.
But there are many Democrats who argue that the party needs a cathartic debate over what it stands for, that years of muting and avoiding conflict have only made the Democrats a complacent, ill-defined Congressional party. There are Democrats, as well, who say that the generational transition begun by Gary Hart has stalled; Mr. Hart came close to the nomination in 1984 by arguing for "new ideas" and a fresh look at party orthodoxy, while attacking Walter F. Mondale as the captive of interest groups.
There are other tensions: the Congressional wing of the party, accustomed to coalition government and consensus-building politics, often ends up undercutting efforts to create a distinctive Democratic message. For example, many party strategists are convinced that tax cuts for the middle class, such as a cut in the payroll tax for Social Security, are a galvanizing issue. But many Democratic leaders in Congress have been cool to the idea, saying that tinkering with taxes invites trouble.
For all of that, party leaders saw some hopeful signs last week. After months when the 1992 Democratic nomination seemed more a burden than a prize, some politicians began showing interest. Senator John D. Rockefeller 4th of West Virginia, who had ruled out a run for the nomination a few months ago, announced that he was reopening the door. It was not clear, however, whether he is interested in 1992 or simply wanted to draw attention to his proposals for health care and position himself for a race in 1996.
Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa, one of the prime movers in the Coalition for Democratic Values, also indicated a touch of Presidential ambition, while Senator Albert Gore Jr. of Tennesse and Gov. L. Douglas Wilder of Virginia continued to look like likely candidates.
Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, chairman of the leadership council, fared well in the spotlight last week as an articulate spokesman for a tough-minded yet humane approach to social welfare programs. But he shares all governors' glaring resume flaw: a lack of foreign policy experience. Senator Gore is conversant on foreign policy, but his attempt to present a domestic vision to the leadership council last week fell flat.
In the meantime, there is an almost palpable longing within the party for a leader.
Even when a Republican President has an 81 percent approval rating, there is, after all, a Democratic base in this country. No one who watched Michael S. Dukakis march resignedly toward defeat in the final days of 1988 could doubt it: Democrats turned out, dutifully, sometimes almost tearfully, to cheer on a candidate they barely knew. These loyalists wait and remember. In Iowa last week, Representative Dave Nagle brought a hush to a Democratic gathering as he talked about Robert F. Kennedy. "I can still see him, on a platform, the sun setting behind him, quoting Shaw," Mr. Nagle said, and the audience was very still and sad.

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends;
Is Nuclear Winter Giving Way to Nuclear Spring?

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
WITH global warming, research on safer reactors and the need for more energy all converging, advocates of nuclear power see signs that the industry is overcoming years of public criticism and doubt.
On May 2, the Tennessee Valley Authority was granted permission by the Government to restart one of three reactors at the Browns Ferry plant in northern Alabama after the longest shutdown for safety reasons in the history of the industry. With the startup scheduled for sometime before the end of the month, Browns Ferry will be the last of five nuclear plants in the United States to open after extended closures. 
 An even more significant event occurred on April 10, when the National Academy of Sciences urged the Government to quickly develop and test a new generation of reactors. Unlike coal-fired electric plants, the academy noted, nuclear reactors produce none of the carbon compounds that cause global warming. Designs under consideration in the United States, Japan and Europe would have far less likelihood of melting down in an accident than would conventional reactors, according to engineers.
Recently, three environmental groups that have opposed nuclear energy -- the National Audubon Society, the World Resources Institute and the Union of Concerned Scientists -- have guardedly recognized the technology's potential and accepted the need for more research. "Because of the global warming problem these new generation reactors have to be looked into for insurance purposes," said Dr. Jan Beyea, a nuclear physicist with the National Audubon Society in New York.
In the public mind, the accident at Three Mile Island in 1979, followed seven years later by the catastrophe at Chernobyl, seemed to seal the technology's fate as a long-term source of electricity. In 1989 alone, the Long Island Lighting Company pulled the fuel rods from the brand new Shoreham plant, voters in California shut Rancho Seco, a nuclear plant south of Sacramento, and the owners of the Fort St. Vrain nuclear plant in Colorado closed it after years of dismal operation.
Though it is far from clear whether the engineering and political trends of the last few months will persuade utilities to start buying reactors again, the industry is optimistic about making a comeback.
The Department of Energy is spending $160 million this year on research to design a new generation of safer, advanced reactors. The country's major manufacturers -- Westinghouse, General Electric, Combustion Engineering and Babcock and Wilcox -- have entered into joint ventures among themselves and with foreign reactor builders to search for new designs. Legislation sponsored by the Bush Administration to make licensing faster is receiving support in Congress.
 
Weighing Alternatives
 In its National Energy Strategy, made public earlier this year, the Department of Energy estimated that demand for electricity in the year 2010 will rise to 950 billion watts from 700 billion today. Energy conservation could slow the increase but will not eliminate it, the Energy Department said. Other options also present problems. Most of the good hydroelectric sites have already been taken and environmentalists are battling to save the last wild stretches of river from the dam builders. Solar power shows increasing promise, but the Government has been reluctant to provide much financing for research, and the largescale manufacture of photovoltaic panels would produce toxic chemical pollution. Burning and mining coal are an environmental menace.
The future of nuclear power will not be decided, though, until utility boards of directors are convinced the technology will be accepted by the public. "Neither Wall Street nor Main Street seems very supportive of a renewal of nuclear power," said Dan W. Reicher, a lawyer for the Natural Resources Defense Council.
That is true in financial circles. But there are signs that the public is less fearful than it used to be. When a fire and explosion destroyed the electrical transformer of the Maine Yankee plant late last month, citizens of Wiscasset, where the reactor has operated for 19 years, reacted with a giant yawn. The announcement that T.V.A. was close to starting Browns Ferry was greeted with enthusiasm in Alabama.
Still, enduring national acceptance will not come until the nuclear industry solves two problems it has battled since the beginning of the 1950's -- making reactors more reliable and disposing of radioactive wastes.
Billions of dollars spent on new equipment and training since Three Mile Island has resulted in fewer unplanned shutdowns and fewer accidents, according to the Nuclear Regulatory Commission. The country's reactors operated at 68 percent of their capacity last year, a higher rate than in any other year, but still not as good as that of some other sources of power.
The industry is still years away from solving the nuclear waste problem. After spending hundreds of millions of dollars studying a site in Nevada for disposing the most dangerous radioactive wastes, the Department of Energy said last year that its program was a technical failure and that the Government was going to start over.
The industry's problems, though, are not deterring the Tennessee Valley Authority, a Federal agency based in Knoxville, Tenn. Once rebuked by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission and reviled by independent authorities for its inability to operate nuclear reactors safely, the T.V.A. was commended last year by the Government for its operation of the Sequoyah Nuclear power plant in Soddy Daisy, Tenn. Sequoyah, closed from 1985 to 1988 for repairs, was ranked second in the United States and eighth in the world in 1989 for its reliability and the amount of electricity it generated.
Marvin Runyon, the chairman of the T.V.A., believes nuclear power is just as economical as generating electricity from coal and ultimately safer for the environment. In an interview last week, Mr. Runyon said he plans to restart two more reactors at Browns Ferry, and complete four other reactors at two unfinished nuclear plants in Alabama and Tennessee before the end of the decade. He is even considering buying a new reactor, the first ordered in the United States since 1973.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
The C.I.A. in Limbo

BYLINE: By LESLIE H. GELB

 BODY:
The next Director of Central Intelligence will inherit various spying activities totaling $30 billion yearly and a Central Intelligence Agency, the jewel in his crown, on the verge of irrelevance. The successor will step into a universe of a dozen grossly overlapping agencies, of cutthroat bureaucratic competition, of dizzyingly potent and expensive equipment like a spy satellite costing $1.5 billion and of organizations clumsily trying to make the transition from the cold war to a bewilderingly diverse "peace."
 Unless President Bush selects a powerful and experienced new spy chief, two things will surely occur: The C.I.A., already sleepy and isolated, will float into bureaucratic outer space, taking with it the talents of thousands of analysts and agents. And billions of dollars will be wasted in Washington inner space, as rival agencies triplicate tasks and scramble for influence with little sense of mission and excellence. 
 The story of disarray in the U.S. spy world follows a pattern now all too familiar.
 The Agency, as it is known in Washington, provided scant warning of Iraq's attack on Kuwait and raised few alarms about the war's bloody aftermath. Once the fighting began, the Pentagon easily shouldered the gentlemanly C.I.A. aside and ran its own intelligence show. Throughout, White House and State Department officials condemned the Agency for mundane and watered-down analyses and predictions.
 No one wants to blame the outgoing spy chief, Judge William Webster, for the mess. He did not come to the job four years ago as an intelligence or national security expert. His principal duty was to restore the C.I.A.'s integrity after the Iran-contra affair and other illegal activities carried out by his predecessor, William Casey. Judge Webster rebuilt trust brilliantly.
 But the judge had no stomach for bureaucratic in-fighting (particularly with the Pentagon, which controls most of his intelligence budget plus its own) and not much feel for how to fit secret information into policy debates. Top-secret Agency studies quickly became irrelevant to the policy makers. Senior officials became their own intelligence analysts, a disposition well ensconced before the war because of the Agency's lackluster predictions about Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union.
The Agency could not get its act together on the gulf war. On July 20 and 25, a senior C.I.A. analyst predicted that there "may be" war, but not that Iraq would try to conquer all of Kuwait. On the 25th, he was rebutted by the senior agency analyst on the Mideast, and the top C.I.A. brass sided with the Mideast expert -- until 24 hours before the attack.
 The C.I.A., like the military, badly overestimated the number of Iraqi troops in Kuwait and their preparations to use chemical weapons. And compared with military estimates, the Agency was way off in estimating U.S. bomb damage.
 Commendably, the Agency in October predicted widespread rebellions by Kurds and Shiites after the war. But inexplicably, the top brass never pressed these views when victory was in sight.
 War predictions aside, the main task of the intelligence community now is to refocus resources and talents away from the Soviet Union -- and on new threats from economic competition, terrorism, drugs and the environment. The myriad agencies and departments involved in intelligence are making that transition, very slowly and in their usual fashion -- by expensive triplication of effort. Still, more than half the $30 billion spending total goes to countering the badly weakened Soviet war machine. What an incredible waste.
Mr. Bush is seriously considering only one candidate for the daunting task of bringing order and quality to the intelligence bureaucracy. That's Robert Gates, the President's deputy national security adviser. He knows foreign policy, is a tough manager and wily bureaucrat, and has been a career C.I.A. professional.
 Mr. Gates is fully qualified except for a black cloud hovering over his head. Suspicions remain in Congress that he knew more about the illegal Iran-contra caper than he acknowledged in sworn testimony. That cloud has to be cleared away expeditiously before the Director's job is offered, so that Mr. Gates can concentrate not on defending himself but on building a lean, refocused first-class intelligence operation.

HEADLINE: Why Help the Soviet Union?

 BODY:
Sending the Soviet people $1.5 billion in new credits to buy food would be a decent thing to do. It would also serve hard-headed American interests. So it is good to hear that President Bush is looking for a way to provide the aid, despite considerable advice to the contrary.
"When people are hungry," he said last week, "we ought to try to help." It's more than a humanitarian gesture and it's much more than a favor to Mikhail Gorbachev. It's a sign to anxious Soviet citizens that Americans care. 
 By giving aid now, Mr. Bush also lends support to the encouraging spirit of compromise between Mr. Gorbachev and Boris Yeltsin that could revitalize flagging reform. And aid deepens America's economic and political engagement with its former rival. That could consolidate relations as the Soviet Union goes through the travail of transformation. After all, U.S.-Soviet cooperation is the keystone to any new world order Mr. Bush hopes to build.
Supplies of U.S. grain could insure against shortages in a Soviet Union caught between a command economy that's disintegrating and a market economy that's not yet functioning. Moscow wants guarantees of $1.5 billion in commercial bank loans. But it's not creditworthy under U.S. law, so Mr. Bush has to find a way to provide the aid.
Some critics say $1.5 billion of food aid would be a drop in the bucket, if not money down the drain. They fear it would be quickly consumed and yield no lasting economic benefit. But they ignore the political message of aid.
Aid is also being resisted by U.S. hard-liners who don't like that message. They want to accelerate the Soviet Union's economic collapse and political disintegration and undermine Mr. Gorbachev. But that's shortsighted. Washington could reasonably seek assurance that food is going to those who need it most. Getting that assurance opens the way to economic engagement with the restive Soviet republics as well as with Moscow.
Such engagement is essential as the nine core republics move toward federation and the others seem headed for commonwealth status or independence. Whatever shape the Union takes, the U.S. will still have to cooperate with the central government, with its formidable nuclear arsenal.
Mr. Bush sees aid as a reward to Mr. Gorbachev. "Yes, the Soviet Union is fighting difficult times," Mr. Bush said. "But I am not about to forget history." He went on to cite the Soviet leader's "enormous accomplishments" in promoting perestroika and glasnost, allowing Eastern Europe to go its own way and working "in sync" with Washington in the gulf war despite opposition at home.
However much aid might bolster Mr. Gorbachev, it would also yield a more enduring effect. As the last six months of turmoil show, the path of Soviet transformation is long and treacherous -- and stumbles can harm relations with the U.S. To cast bread on Soviet waters will strengthen those relations, and serve America's enduring interests.
