HEADLINE: Political Correctness Besets the Left and Right

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Brent Staples, in commenting on "political correctness" (Editorial Notebook, April 17), does not see the threat to free expression at American universities. The policies to ban allegedly sexist and racist language and eliminate traditional history courses are subject to broad interpretation and may have a chilling effect on academic freedom. 
 The tendency toward left-wing conformism in the academy results in a pressure on independent thinkers to mouth politically correct views. The problem has grown since the 1960's and has not appeared just since the end of the cold war.
As to black enrollment at universities, because of economic inequality and cutbacks in student grants and loans, such enrollment dropped. However, particular universities that have the goal of maintaining or increasing the number of black students were forced to compete with one another for a shrinking pool of applicants. While politically correct admissions teams might be able to change standards to admit X number of blacks at their institutions, they are powerless to eliminate the economic and social trends that shape the national applicant pools.
Although pacifist activism may, as Mr. Staples says, be a prized goal of the politically correct, he is wrong to wonder why there was "no campus peace movement during the war in the Persian Gulf." There was only a small movement, because of the quick United States military victory.
The term "politically correct" does not equate liberalism with intellectual tyranny as Mr. Staples argues. On the contrary, it is the politically correct leftists, not genuine liberals, who are most inclined to be intellectual tyrants. Traditional liberals are more open-minded than the new politically correct left.
A major reason for the politically correct leftist zeal inside the academy is the low state of left-wing politics in the real, nonacademic world. Both the conservative critics of academic political correctness and Mr. Staples have overlooked the attempts of the political right and big business to impose their own kinds of correctness outside the academy.
Since 1980, the conservative Republican domination of American politics has made it politically incorrect to advocate progressive taxation and big, new Federal social programs. Most Democrats have engaged in acts of self-censorship about these subjects. This self-gagging of a once great political party has weakened the quality of debate in our elections. Conservative business interests have also threatened free speech by hitting their critics with lawsuits known as strategic litigation against public participation, or Slapp suits. Corporations use such cases to try intimidating their opponents into silence.
Leftist and conservative forces alike attempt to reduce the level of debate in the spheres they dominate. We must recognize and oppose the threats to freedom posed by the politically correct of both the left and the right.
 
JOSEPH E. RYAN
Resident Scholar, Freedom House
New York, April 25, 1991

HEADLINE: Foreign Peanut Toxins Could Harm Liver

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "Lunch Without Peanut Butter" (editorial, April 21), you support a recommendation to allow peanuts grown outside this country to enter our food chain in order to eliminate the economic inequity of a controlled market. This could have serious health ramifications. 
 Any suspension of the import ban would have to include stringent measures to check for afflatoxins. An afflatoxin is a poison produced by some strains of Aspergillas flavus, which thrive on stored peanuts (and grains). This toxin is known to produce liver cancers in rats, fowl and fish. It is suspected of being a significant contributor to human liver cancer in Africa and Southeast Asia. Although afflatoxins are found in some of our food, the amounts are low and presumably pose no serious health threat. There has been a downward trend in deaths from liver cancer in the United States.
We should be concerned with a decent living for farmers in the third world, and should explore all means to raise their standard of living, but not at the expense of our children's health.
 
JULES M. ELIAS
Lake Grove, L.I., April 24, 1991
 
The writer is an associate professor of immunohistopathology at the State University of New York at Stony Brook.

HEADLINE: A Crisis at Prenatal Clinic in Yonkers

BYLINE: By ROBERTA HERSHENSON

DATELINE: YONKERS

 BODY:
DELIVERY DAY was near for Tawanya Tuck and Ronda Terry, two Yonkers women expecting their first babies this month. The women, who are friends, had come to the prenatal clinic at St. John's Riverside Hospital here for their weekly checkups. After being examined by a doctor, the mothers-to-be met with a registered nurse, Margie Linton, to learn more about what to expect during labor. 
 Although neither woman had been seen here during the critical first trimester of pregnancy -- Ms. Tuck came in her fourth month and Miss Terry in her sixth -- both are part of a system that will insure the best possible care for them and their infants.
 
Treading a Dangerous Line
 Countless other pregnant women in this city, however, tread a dangerous line betwee no prenatal care at all and eventual delivery in a hospital that knows nothing about their medical histories. Their plight, caused by a confluence of social and economic problems, has been termed a crisis by county health administrators.
A shortage of prenatal care is not unique to Yonkers, but the problem is highlighted here. Of the 102 babies countywide who died before their first birthdays in 1988, the latest year for which figures are available, 34 were born to Yonkers residents. Although that is one-third of the deaths, Yonkers residents that year accounted for only about one-fourth of live births, 2,911 out of 12,168. Black babies born to Yonkers mothers died at a much higher rate than white babies: 17 black babies died out of 644 live births; while 15 white babies died out of 2,126 live births. Other ethnic categories are included in the total numbers, but Hispanic births are not calculated separately.
The issue revolves around the refusal of private obstetricians to accept Medicaid patients, thus forcing pregnant women to overflow the city's four prenatal clinics; the growth in the number of the poor in the city, and the reduction of the hospitals that will deliver babies here to one: St. John's Riverside.
The other prenatal clinics here are the Yonkers Community Health Center, a satellite of the Mount Vernon Neighborhood Health Center, whose patients are assigned to deliver at Mount Vernon Hospital; Valentine Lane Family Practice, an outreach branch of the Montefiore Medical Center, whose patients are expected to deliver at the North Central Bronx Hospital, and the clinic at St. Joseph's Hospital, which has a delivery arrangement with St. John's.
In fact, said Isabel Tripodi, a registered nurse and the clinical coordinator at St. John's, many of the women who were supposed to deliver at other hospitals wind up at St. John's. That is because St. John's is nearer to their homes, and because ambulances under contract with the city may travel outside its borders only for emergency treatment. St. John's prenatal clinic and obstretical service are both inundated, she said.
The "drop-ins," Mrs. Tripodi noted, present risks to the hospital as well as to themselves, because doctors often have no access to medical information about them. Dr. Shahram S. Razmzan, an obstetrician at St. John's clinic, said the situation especially created problems for women with conditions like diabetes or high blood pressure, who must be carefully monitored during pregnancy and delivery.
Babies born to diabetics can be very large and suffer neurological damage during birth or die from a rapid drop in blood sugar. The babies of women with high blood pressure can be "growth-retarded" the doctor explained.
For these reasons, Mrs. Tripodi emphasized, all women "should be hooked into a system where they can go to deliver."
 
Material Is Bilingual
 The St. John's clinic accepts all patients who meet the income guidelines established by the State Department of Health's Prenatal Care Assistance Program. Patients, who come by appointment, receive comprehensive services that include family planning and nutritional guidance, as well as postpartum care. Educational material is bilingual because of the large Hispanic population.
Mrs. Tripodi said that about 110 patients are seen in the clinic weekly, and that appointments have been booked until July. This meant, she said, that women who sought care at the appropriate time could not be seen until their pregnancies were well advanced.
David Scarpino, the director of finance at St. John's, said the number of babies delivered at St. John's had been about 1,800 for the last eight years, but that those born to clinic patients had risen to 1,000 from 200. He acknowledged there had been talk about closing the prenatal clinic, which loses $750,000 a year, but said such a move was not imminent. Mr. Scarpino explained that each visit cost the hospital $220, while Medicaid's reimbursement fee to the hospital had been frozen at $60 a visit for many years. The clinic pays the four obstetricians on its staff, because St. John's private attending doctors are no longer required to serve the clinic as part of their obligation to the hospital.
Mr. Scarpino said that none of the attending obstetricians would accept Medicaid patients because of the doctors' high malpractice insurance rates and their fear of suits from "high risk" patients. Clinic patients are considered at high risk of having complicated pregnancies because of problems associated with poverty.
 
Resident Status Not Required
 The finance director said the state's Prenatal Care Assistance Program, which has been administered by Medicaid for a year, offered some hope. Under the program, all pregnant women, infants and young children who meet the financial guidelines, regardless of their resident status in this country, are entitled to a complex of health services that are reimbursed at a higher rate than the standard Medicaid visit. But Mr. Scarpino said the hospital had as yet received no payment under the program.
Louis F. Parker, executive director of St. John's, said that while some trustees had raised questions about the clinic, "the consensus of the board is to do all in our power to continue operating" it. But, Mr. Parker said, "If reimbursements decline according to the Governor's proposals, and costs increase and this affects the rest of our mission to provide services and care to the community, then the clinic would have to close."
"Where these people will go is beyond me," Mr. Parker said. "Our fear is they won't go anywhere and they will appear on our doorstep in the emergency room either very ill or without prenatal care."
It is in the interests of a hospital with an obstetrical service to run a prenatal clinic, Mr. Scarpino pointed out, because "most lawsuits hospitals encounter concern babies." If the clinic were closed, he said, the obstetrical service would have to close, too.
 
Doctor Notes a Paradox
 Mrs. Tripodi and Bea Pilkington, director of social work at St. John's, said they have proposed a county-run prenatal clinic in Yonkers to Dr. Mary E. Lane, director of women and youth services for the county's Department of Health. Dr. Lane said that while she recognized the need for expanded services, the Health Department was "not in a position to set up a prenatal clinc."
Dr. Lane noted the paradox of her department's efforts to promote prenatal education, only to have poor women's attempts to seek care thwarted. "The more proselytizing and outreach you do, the more inadequate the services are," she said. The county subsidizes some prenatal clinics and operates a variety of programs for women and children, but runs no prenatal-care service of its own.
Dr. Mark S. Rapoport, the County Health Commissioner, called the shortage of prenatal care for the poor "a tragedy." He asserted that the county was "trying to expand our role as a coordinator of service," but was under "fiscal siege."
"Even in better financial times, this problem has eluded us," Dr. Rapoport said, because of what he called "the fragmented system of health care in this country." Dr. Rapoport said the county was working with hospitals and medical groups as well as with the state "to try to get the private sector to be part of the system."
Anne E. Wright, a family nurse practitioner at the Valentine Lane family practice, calls for "hospitals with a conscience" to require their attending doctors to serve the needs of poor people, particularly pregnant women. She criticized St. John's for not looking at "how to provide services for the people they are going to be delivering."
 
'Communication About Services'
 Ms. Wright said she was working in the March of Dimes Yonkers Campaign for Healthier Babies to "identify the problems" of pregnant women here and "to provide communication about services so people aren't lost between the cracks."
Dr. Lane said that "anything that can be done institutionally is important to help the doctors hang in there."
"They are leaving obstetrics in droves, and they are not taking care of the poor women."
Another solution was "more emphasis on nurse midwifery and birthing centers," Dr. Lane said.
"We need to promote that partnership between the doctor and nurse midwife," she said, "to give enhanced care with counseling that is sustaining, supporting and nurturing to poor women."

LENGTH: 776 words

HEADLINE: Fresh Air Fund Tells Youths to Study

BYLINE: By ANDREW L. YARROW

 BODY:
Pecuniary interests may have been uppermost in the minds of about 100 poor New York City teen-agers who recently attended the Fresh Air Fund's second-annual Career Day, but all seemed to acknowledge the importance of their counselors' exhortations to stay in school, study hard, stay away from drugs and believe in themselves.
"I'm really interested in I.B.M. because I want to make a lot of money and I like word processing," said Johnny Carey, a 14-year-old from upper Manhattan who had just heard an I.B.M. executive's half-hour introduction to the computer industry. "I like their benefits." 
 Mr. Carey, who said he was applying to Brandeis High School and wanted to go to an Ivy League college, was a member of one of five groups that spent the day in similar sessions learning about careers in health care and art. In addition, the career fair, which was held at Columbia University, included sessions on labor unions and on high schools and colleges.
The day was part of the fund's Career Awareness Program, which was started several years ago "to make a small contribution to the pressing need to do something about youth unemployment," said Jenny Morgenthau, the group's executive director. The initiative also includes a "job shadowing" program, in which teen-agers spend days with architects, lawyers, journalists and other professionals seeing how they work, and a summer Career Awareness Camp, which is scheduled to open in 1993 on the fund's 3,000-acre property near Fishkill, N.Y., about 50 miles north of midtown Manhattan.
 
Free Vacations Since 1877

The fund has provided free summer vacations to more than 1.6 million New York City children and adolescents since 1877, and about 10,000 are expected to attend the fund's bucolic preserve this summer. The group's new $5 million camp will include lodges, an outdoor amphitheater and lakeside playing fields and serve about 300 teen-agers each summer with academic classes and career sessions with professionals.
The key to the program is "to make the link between careers and education, and motivate adolescents to stay in school by letting them explore career options," Ms. Morgenthau said, expressing a sentiment that was echoed many times during the day.
"There's a big difference between a master's degree and working at Wendy's -- and your best offense is education," said Michael Davis, a commercial illustrator who captivated his 12-to-15-year-old audience with his fast-talking, irreverent pitch for the importance of education. Like the other professionals who led the day's career sessions, Mr. Davis described how and why he became an artist and what his working life was like.
"When you think of art, you may think of someone on the street who says, 'I draw what I feel,' " he said mockingly, explaining that his J. C. Penney wardrobe was in keeping with his own philosophy of working hard to maximize his income and minimize his expenses. "It's not about being cool -- it's about business. I don't care if you don't want to be an artist, but you have to learn to read and write."
 
'It Gave Me Real Interest'

Kerensa Smith, a 14-year-old from upper Manhattan, seemed to take Mr. Davis's message to heart. "I've always wanted to draw pictures of people or take pictures," she said. "But when he talked about being an artist, it gave me a real interest in being one."
During a morning session on health care, about 20 teen-agers dressed in their requisite sweatshirts, jeans and sneakers watched a video about the myriad of careers in what was touted as America's fastest growing area of employment. After Carmen Padilla of the nonprofit New York Health Career Center finished extolling the field's virtues, 14-year-old Wilma Vega volunteered: "I want to become an obstetrician, because I like babies. But I learned today that it will be hard, with all the classes I'll have to take."
Many of the teen-agers had done job shadowing and attended the fund's career camp in Fishkill last summer. Ms. Morgenthau said the fund had a commitment "to stay with them for three years to keep encouraging them to stay in school, and then go to college or into the job market."
The practical career advice and the emphasis on education were also repeatedly mixed with a "be all that you can be" message. As Robert Fulton, an official with Local 100 of the Transport Workers Union, told one group: "You have to put it in your mind that you're leaders, not followers."
The fund is a nonprofit agency. Donations may be sent to the Fresh Air fund, 1040 Avenue of the Americas, New York, N.Y. 10018. Information: (212) 221-0900 or (800) 367-0003.

HEADLINE: Scandals Casting Shadows Over Public Life in South Carolina

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: COLUMBIA, S.C.

 BODY:
From its aristocratic beginnings in the great Low Country plantations to the development of what many consider the nation's most powerful state legislature, South Carolina has always been a state accustomed to rule by a few.
Now, after a series of scandals that have touched nearly all the state's power centers -- from the Legislature to its most powerful newspaper, from the former president of the University of South Carolina to the state's most powerful law firm -- South Carolina is looking hard in the mirror and recoiling from what it sees. 
 "Through most of South Carolina's history, the people who set up and ran state government have had two main priorities: Keeping power out of the hands of black people. Keeping power out of the hands of everybody else," began a voluminous package of news articles on May 5 in The State, Columbia's historically docile newspaper.
 
15 Legislators Indicted
 The scandals are diverse. The two most conspicuous ones, a Federal undercover operation that has led to the indictment of 15 state legislators and two indictments against the former state university president, James Holderman, stem from unrelated investigations. But both have helped highlight the degree to which public officials in South Carolina have long been accustomed to extraordinary latitude and minimal oversight in conducting their business. As for the legislators, 10 pleaded guilty, 4 have been found guilty in trials and one is awaiting trial.
"On a scale of democratic institutions, South Carolina is perhaps the least democratic state in the nation," said Charles W. Dunn, a political science professor at Clemson University. "What's happening now is that the old-boy network has been caught in a new-boy vise."
Along with prompting the news articles in The State, the shock waves have given impetus to efforts by Gov. Carroll A. Campbell Jr. to whittle away at the Legislature's power, and have set off a battle over ethics measures in the Legislature.
Skeptics doubt much change will result. But there is little disagreement that South Carolina has been shaken to its political core in the past year.
 
'It Can't Endure Shame'
 "I truly think these are the darkest days for the spirit of South Carolina since the Civil War," said Alex M. Sanders, chief judge of the State Court of Appeals. "For the whole term of its existence, South Carolina has demonstrated that it can endure guilt but it can't endure shame, and shame is where we are today."
South Carolina's culture and politics were shaped by the economics and social structure of its colonial beginnings, when its lordly planters were the richest men in the Colonies. The first English settlers in Charleston set up a rigid class system based on slave labor. What developed was a system that the New Englander Josiah Quincy described as a society divided into "opulent and lordly planters, poor and spiritless peasants and vile slaves."
As the state developed, its beginnings were never wholly forgotten. The Legislature, compared by many to a parliamentary system, is still regarded as the nation's strongest, appointing the state's judges and members of important boards. From the 1930's to the early 1970's the Barnwell Ring, consisting of Edgar A. Brown, the Senate President pro tem, and Solomon Blatt, the House Speaker, both from rural Barnwell County, exercised a degree of power almost unparalleled among the nation's state legislators.
They presided over the state in tandem with the leaders of a relatively monolithic business structure dominated by a few planters, the textile industry and the state's major utilities and banks. As late as 1940 fewer than 100,000 South Carolinians voted in Presidential elections out of nearly one million eligible voters, and the state still has one of the lowest rates of voter participation in the nation.
It was a system that also had some notable achievements. South Carolina integrated more peacefully and with less visible rancor than almost any state in the South. Its relatively placid political environment produced some of the South's most progressive governors, including Ernest F. Hollings, now a United States Senator, Robert McNair, John West and Richard W. Riley.
But it was also a system in which most public policy was made in private, with few brakes on the conduct of those at the top.
"There's a real deference to authority here," said State Senator Michael Rose. "It's like we began with a system of feudal lords who created a hierachical structure, and it's always more or less been that way."
Governor Campbell says the undercover operation, in which legislators took bribes from undercover agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation for support of a parimutuel betting law, reflects the degree to which some of the old ways were dying long before the scandals became public.
 
A Political Transition
 "I think you see a transition in the state," said the Governor, a Republican. "We have gone from a state that, like some others, was dominated by rural barons who operated under their own code and who operated in a nonthreatening society, to a state that now has a competitive two-party system. We had something of an oligarchy down here for a lot of years, and now we're making a transition from it."
Others are less sure how much change is afoot.
"This has always been a state where he who has the gold makes the rules," Mr. Rose said. "That's still the golden rule."
The problems at the state university may be a purer case of how South Carolinahas historically done business.
From his arrival at the university in 1977 to his resignation last May, Mr. Holderman worked the levers of power in South Carolina like a maestro, forging alliances with the state's powers, including the McNair law firm, which is headed by the former Governor. Mr. Holderman's two indictments on charges of tax evasion and use of a public office for private gain stem from a contribution from the firm.
 
Favors and Lavish Gifts
 Mr. Holderman is given credit for drastically upgrading the university. But one way of accomplishing that was by doing favors for and giving lavish gifts to powerful people inside and outside South Carolina.
He personally dispensed $1.6 million in scholarships, many to the children of the state's most prominent residents. He set up an unadvertised student intern program in which some participants, including children of influential South Carolinians, became his personal aides, often joining him on fund-raising expeditions and university-related trips around the country and to Europe and Asia . The program became a steppingstoneto prestigious jobs in the state.
Among his interns were the sons of top executives of The State, which remained an ardent supporter of Mr. Holderman even after other papers, most notably The Charlotte (N.C.) Observer, disclosed his profligate spending. The State, which was purchased from its longtime family ownership by Knight-Ridder Inc. in November 1986, published a long article in March after Mr. Holderman was indicted, taking critical notice of its own ties to the former university president.
"He knew how to utilize the elite structures of the state," said Professor Dunn of Clemson. "He was able to press the right buttons, and there aren't that many to push in an elite, closed system."
Professor Dunn notes that many of the things that once defined South Carolina no longer apply. Once a one-party state, it now has perhaps the strongest Republican Party in the South. Once limited to agriculture and textiles, it has broadened its economic base, with more manufacturing and service concerns. The old rural barons are no longer in control, and the state's news media are more aggressive than they have been in the past.
 
Some Things Remain the Same
 But others say the legacy still plays out in fundamental ways that are more significant then the indictments of legislators. Some blacks contend that the operation was directed disproportionately at black legislators, and some skeptics say legislators on the fringes of power, rather than the center of power, were the ones most affected by the investigation.
Despite economic gains in recent years, South Carolina ranks 42d among the 50 states in per capita income, 49th in life expectancy and near the bottom in many other indices, including infant mortality and illiteracy. It also has one of the nation's largest concentrations of toxic waste dumps, and the economy of the barons' old duchy in Barnwell County is now the preserve of the Savannah River Plant nuclear weapons plant in Aiken.
Tom Turnipseed, a lawyer and former legislator who is active in environmental matters, said the most significant indictment to come out of the F.B.I. investigation did not involve charges of gambling, but rather the indictment of Jack Rogers, a former House Speaker pro tem on charges of taking bribes from Laidlaw Environmental Services Inc., which was seeking a permit for a hazardous waste dump in the state. Laidlow is a major toxic waste collection and disposal company owned by Laidlaw Inc. of Burlington, Ontario. In a plea arrangement Mr. Rogers pleaded guilty to a racketeering charge last Wednesday.
"It's the same old South Carolina story," Mr. Turnipseed said. "There are a few well-situated people who are making a lot of money, and the rest of us are suffering."

CORRECTION-DATE: June 5, 1991, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
An article on May 12 about scandals in South Carolina misstated the link between Laidlaw Environmental Services Inc., a toxic-waste disposal company, and State Representative John I. Rogers 3d. Mr. Rogers was charged with having extorted money from an independent lobbyist who worked on behalf of Laidlaw; Laidlaw was not accused of having paid bribes to Mr. Rogers.

HEADLINE: Making a Difference;
America West's Latest Dogfight

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER

 BODY:
"On this initiative, we've hit the market hard; we are the strongest," said Edward R. Beauvais, founder, chairman and chief executive of America West Airlines, referring to the carrier's announcement last week of steep fare cuts.
Since its founding 10 years ago, America West has built a reputation as one of the last of the scrappy independents, offering full service at precipitous discounts, with such perks as unlimited free drinks. The booze is gone, but last week's move could be the first salvo in a new round of fare wars. 
 The Phoenix-based carrier cut most of its full coach fares by an average of almost 40 percent, touting the discounts in a $20 million ad campaign that casts Jonathan Winters as a Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf lookalike.
Some carriers, like Northwest and Midway, matched the new fares immediately in some markets, but the big three -- American, United and Delta -- said only that they were studying the move.
The guarded response of the giants was just what he expected, Mr. Beauvais said.
"Our cost levels are such that we can make money on these fares," he added, noting that America West has the youngest fleet of fuel-efficient airplanes in the business. In markets where the big three compete only with each other, they maintain high fares, Mr. Beauvais asserted. "It's really important for the industry to have the mavericks to provide a competitive spark," he said.
Though America West accounts for only about 3 percent of the airline industry's capacity, its routes link many major cities, with hubs in both Phoenix and Las Vegas.
Despite its spunk, America West is not immune to the travails of the airline industry as a whole. It reported a first-quarter loss of $49.9 million, compared with a loss of $2.6 million in the comparable period a year ago. Mr. Beauvais said the combination of the gulf war, the recession and soaring fuel prices hurt results, but that business began to recover in March.
A 31-year veteran of the industry, Mr. Beauvais, who is 54, began his career with Frontier Airlines in Colorado as an accountant. Prior to forming America West, he was a principal partner in an air transportation consulting firm from 1970 to 1981.

HEADLINE: New & Noteworthy

BYLINE: By GEORGE JOHNSON

 BODY:
LEBANON: Death of a Nation, by Sandra Mackey. (Anchor/Doubleday, $12.) Carved out of Syria by the French as a haven for Maronite Christians, Lebanon has always teetered on the brink of self-destruction, Sandra Mackey writes. She makes "the story of Lebanon's morass readable for the uninitiated," Robin Wright said here in 1989. THE FLOATING WORLD, by Cynthia Kadohata. (Ballantine, $4.95.) In the 1950's, Olivia, a 12-year-old Japanese girl, and her family live their life on the road, as they travel through the Pacific Northwest looking for work. "Writing in beautiful, clean yet lyrical prose, Ms. Kadohata creates an emotionally precise picture of each member of Olivia's family," Michiko Kakutani said in The Times in 1989. "Ms. Kadohata does not shirk from examining all the sad, painful details of her family's thwarted lives, but she does so with tenderness, compassion and wit. . . . 'The Floating World' marks the debut of a luminous new voice in fiction."
 INSIDE JOB: The Looting of America's Savings and Loans, by Stephen Pizzo, Mary Fricker and Paul Muolo. (Harper Perennial, $10.95.) In the olden days, the Government's willingness to guarantee the deposits in the savings and loan industry was backed by a quid pro quo: there were strict regulations on how the money could be invested. Then the Reagan Administration deregulated the industry. In documenting the disastrous aftermath, the authors "have put together a chilling account, cast almost in cinematic terms, of greed and criminality," Anthony M. Solomon said here in 1989. In THE BIG FIX. Inside the S&L Scandal: How an Unholy Alliance of Politics and Money Destroyed America's Banking System (John Wiley & Sons, $12.95), James Ring Adams shows how the financial industry, the regulators and Congress were all to blame for the mess. He provides "a front-row seat at a three-ring circus," Karen W. Arenson said here in 1989. 
THE MUSIC ROOM, by Dennis McFarland. (Avon, $8.95.) Just as he is trying to adjust to the fact that his wife has left him, Martin Lambert learns that his brother has followed in their father's footsteps and committed suicide. "What is most magical about 'The Music Room' is its fabric: thick, rich, mysterious, true," Josephine Humphreys said here last year. "Constructed like a detective story (an unexplained death, a detective, clues to a buried past) and pressing forward with the detective story's speed, it is nevertheless an opposite of that genre. Instead of narrowing to a solution, it opens onto territory unforeseen, and revelations larger than those that might have been expected."
 CLEOPATRA: Histories, Dreams and Distortions, by Lucy Hughes-Hallett. (Harper Perennial, $10.95.) The myth of Cleopatra as the evil seductress that has come down through the ages began as part of a propaganda campaign by Antony's rival Octavian. Last year The Times's Michiko Kakutani said that in making this argument, Lucy Hughes-Hallett has produced "a well-researched and highly informative volume -- an often fascinating examination of the way history and historical figures are subjected to a continuing process of reimagination." CONSTANCIA: And Other Stories for Virgins, by Carlos Fuentes. Translated by Thomas Christensen. (Harper Perennial, $10.95.) In one of these obscure short stories, a student decides to kill a mannequin because she refuses to return his love. Last year our reviewer, Denis Donoghue, said each of these five fictions is "bizarre, a tale lingered over by the teller to the point at which, if he were to stay with it a moment longer, he would have to explain everything, and ruin it."
 THE SUN ALSO SETS: The Limits to Japan's Economic Power, by Bill Emmott. (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $10.95.) A British journalist says that Japan's economic power can't last forever. In 1989 our reviewer, Joel Dreyfuss, said, "For those who worry about drowning in a sea of yen, 'The Sun Also Sets' is a fragile lifeline, offering hope that Japan will begin to behave like other nations and expose its problems, shortcomings and mistakes."
 MOTHERLAND, by Timothy O'Grady. (Anchor/Dou bleday, $9.) A middle-aged man returns to his flat in Dublin to find that his mother has disappeared, leaving behind a dead turtle, a live monkey and a collection of ancient manuscripts. Last year our reviewer, Annabel Davis-Goff, complimented the author on his "fine sense of image" and the book for its "evocative scenes." FAMILY PORTRAITS: Remembrances by Twenty Distinguished Writers, edited by Carolyn Anthony. (Penguin, $9.95.) Twenty writers, including Walker Percy, Margaret Atwood, Gloria Steinem and Joyce Carol Oates, tell how their lives were shaped by their families. "Every reader will find a favorite family in 'Family Portraits,' " Jill Ker Conway said here in 1989. "Most will ponder the skill with which such complex human relationships are brought to life in prose."
 THE HORSE LATITUDES, by Robert Ferrigno. (Avon, $5.95.) An archeologist and former drug dealer named Danny DiMedici is suspected of murder when his ex-wife disappears from her southern California beach house. "Mr. Ferrigno has concocted a striking if lurid poetry of violence," Christopher Lehmann-Haupt said in The Times last year. Most readers will enjoy "the violent, darkly comic and strangely haunting voyage that Mr. Ferrigno has taken them on."
 STARDUST, by Robert B. Parker. (Berkley, $5.50.) Spenser, the Boston private eye and gourmand, is hired to find out who is stalking Jill Joyce, a beautiful if self-centered television star. Last year our reviewer, Richard Gid Powers, called the novel "classic Spenser, the tough guy who knows his tofu from his tacos."

HEADLINE: Political Talk

BYLINE: By Kevin Sack

 BODY:
New Way to Run
In the old days, candidates announced their plans to run for office and then set about to assemble their staffs. But for today's politicians, who like to act like candidates while remaining coy about their intentions, the old ways no longer suffice. 
 So it is for the New York City Comptroller, Elizabeth Holtzman, who will not yet say that she plans to run for the United States Senate but has already hired a poll taker and a media consultant.
 "If and when she makes a decision, she'll have a strong team," an aide said,
 Perhaps because she was elected to her citywide post less than two years ago, Ms. Holtzman has been reluctant to disclose her ambitions too quickly. But those she has hired -- the poll taker Paul Maslin and the media consulting firm of Squier Eskew Knapp Communications -- think there is only the slightest chance she will not run in next year's Democratic primary.
 Mr. Maslin, who has offices in New York City and Los Angeles, worked for Ms. Holtzman in her 1989 comptroller's race. Robert Squier and Carter Eskew, two of Washington's best-known Democratic consultants, met while working in her 1980 Senate campaign.
 If Ms. Holtzman joins Attorney General Robert Abrams, former Vice Presidential nominee Geraldine A. Ferraro and Representative Robert J. Mrazek, all of whom have said they will run, the 1992 Democratic primary could be one of the most interesting statewide races in years. The Democrats hope to unseat Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, the Long Island Republican being investigated by the Senate Ethics Committee.
 
Decisions a la Jersey
 There was plenty of cynicism when Gov. Jim Florio announced recently that New Jersey would sell a stretch of Interstate 95 to the state's Turnpike Authority for $400 million to help balance its budget. Given that Mr. Florio had recently approved a major turnpike toll increase, which now will finance the interstate purchase, drivers felt they were being asked to shoulder an unfair burden.
 Now the cynicism is growing with the announcement that the Turnpike Authority has hired the law firm that employs the brother of the State Senate President, John A. Lynch, to act as counsel on a $2.5 billion bond refinancing. The refinancing will help generate the $400 million needed for the highway purchase.
 Republican legislators, who hope to wrest control of both houses from the Democrats this year, are charging nepotism.
 The Senate minority leader, John H. Dorsey, who estimates that the refinancing could generate up to $1 million in bond counsel fees, said he would be interested in learning what attracted the authority to the Philadelphia firm of Morgan, Lewis and Bockius. William J. Lynch, the Senator's brother, is a partner in the firm's New York office.
 Mr. Dorsey said that while Morgan, Lewis and Bockius is a prestigious firm, its relative lack of experience in bond work made its selection "extraordinary."
 Senator Lynch has denied knowing anything about the hiring decision. Clive Cummis, the authority's lawyer, said William Lynch's membership in the firm had nothing to do with his decision to recommend it.
 
Little Matilda Sunshine
 Sounding much like Ronald Reagan tweaking the Democrats, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo set out this week to show "the doom and gloom people" that New York City remained strong and would triumph over its fiscal adversities.
 On the same day that Mr. Dinkins, in a televised speech, told of "our difficult journey ahead" and a "grinding financial squeeze," Mr. Cuomo said in a speech that "we ought to provide more energy on the positive side." To that end, he announced -- first to The New York Post gossip columnist Cindy Adams -- that he plans to dispatch his wife, Matilda, as an ambassador of optimism.
 In fact, Mrs. Cuomo has played a similar role for many years, representing her husband on economic development missions to China, Japan, Italy, Spain and Hong Kong. But the Governor seems to feel that the state and city budget problems call for an accelerated campaign against the forces of negativism.
 Mrs. Cuomo's itinerary, which will be coordinated by the State Department of Economic Development, will begin with a daunting challenge. On June 4, she and other state officials will try to sell foreign diplomats, business executives and reporters on investment opportunities in the Bronx.
 
Hot Cakes and Messages
 Stanley Hill, the executive director of District Council 37 of the American Federation of State County and Municipal Employees, is not the only New York City labor leader to emulate the rhetorical style of Yogi Berra. But Mr. Hill does demonstrate a special flair.
 In explaining recently that his members were disturbed by an erroneous news report about contract negotiations, Mr. Hill said, "My members have been calling up like hot cakes."
 With the city's fiscal problems shining a spotlight on the unions, Mr. Hill has retained the Kamber Group, a Washington-based public relations firm, "to help out during the crisis."
 In reacting to Mayor David N. Dinkins's demands for union concessions, Mr. Hill often has been eclipsed by Barry Feinstein, the colorful, quotable and perpetually outraged president of Local 237 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters. With 20,000 members, Mr. Feinstein's union is far smaller than Mr. Hill's 140,000-member group.
 Deborah H. Friedman, who is handling Mr. Hill's account for Kamber, said she hopes to help Mr. Hill press his case. "When you represent so many people, and everybody else is getting their message out, and labor's going to be asked for sacrifices, you want people to know that your members work in the libraries and clean the parks," she said.

HEADLINE: States Using Donations to Get Medicaid Money

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 11 --

 BODY:
Faced with soaring medical costs, states have devised a way to extract money from the Federal Government to pay for health care of poor people under Medicaid.
 Bush Administration officials say the fund-raising technique is a scam that costs the Government more than a billion dollars a year, and they are trying to halt its use. But state officials say it is a legitimate way to finance expanded medical care for millions of women and children in low-income families mandated under recently passed Federal laws -- at no cost to state treasuries. 
 The device works this way: States collect "voluntary donations" from hospitals, count these contributions as part of the state share of Medicaid and then get $2 or $3 of Federal matching money for each dollar donated by the hospitals. Hospitals go along with the arrangement because when the Medicaid funds are paid out, they usually get back more money than they donated.
 
A Way to Pay Rising Costs
 Today, as for the last 25 years, general revenues are the main source of state Medicaid funds. But the hospital contributions have become increasingly important as states try to cope with the program's soaring costs in the midst of a recession that has depleted their revenues.
 Those donations and the related Federal payments finance health care for many pregnant women, new mothers and infants enrolled in Medicaid. Even though the Bush Administration says it wants to reduce infant mortality, it has drafted rules to end Federal matching payments for donations.
 "Without these options, there is no doubt that the Medicaid program in Tennessee, after making great progress in recent years, would be forced to reduce benefits and services," said Norman B. Urmy, executive director of the Vanderbilt University Hospital in Nashville. Officials in other states expressed identical concerns.
Although Administration officials describe the hospital donations as a device invented by states to siphon money from the Federal Treasury, Federal courts have upheld the legitimacy of the technique, and Congress has explicitly allowed it to continue.
 
In Lieu of New Taxes
 Senator Wyche Fowler Jr., Democrat of Georgia, said states must be allowed to use "creative methods of financing Medicaid in these tough budget times, when health-care costs are skyrocketing and the Federal Government keeps setting new mandates" for the program. "I would much rather see a system of voluntary contributions from hospitals than the tax increases that might otherwise be needed," he said.
 The fiscal condition of states is worse than at any time in the last decade, says the National Governors' Association. But state officials are reluctant to raise taxes, reading last year's election results as an overwhelming vote against new broad-based taxes.
 Senator Bob Graham, Democrat of Florida, warned that "states will have to cut already insufficient benefits and reimbursement" if the Administration succeeds in restricting the use of donations and special assessments from hospitals.
 A nationwide survey shows that eight states already accept donations from hospitals, for the specific purpose of getting more money from Washington for Medicaid, and 12 other states are considering such programs. A similar device -- a special state assessment on hospitals, used to get more Federal dollars for Medicaid -- has been adopted in nine states and is under consideration in 13 more.
 
Federal Objections
 The Department of Health and Human Services and the White House Office of Management and Budget object to both arrangements, saying they "unfairly increase the Federal share of Medicaid payments," distort the "Federal-state financial partnership" and permit states to finance expansion of Medicaid "with 100 percent Federal monies."
But state officials say the Administration's proposal to stop matching the hospital donations would violate the principle of federalism and usurp their authority to decide how best to raise money.
 Nationwide, Medicaid finances health care for 27 million Americans, including 13 million children. States together pay about 45 percent of the program's total cost of more than $90 billion this year. The state share rises with a state's per capita income and ranges from 20 percent in the poorest state, Mississippi, to 50 percent in the most affluent states.
 Georgia uses $35.5 million of hospital contributions to get $57 million from the Federal Government. Russell B. Toal, the state Medicaid director, said, "We are using the money for precisely the kinds of services that Congress and the Administration want: expanded eligibility for children, case management of prenatal care, home visits to new mothers and payments to hospitals that carry the burden of indigent care."
 
Helping Themselves by Donating
 While initially skeptical, hospital executives have come to appreciate the value of donating. W. Hoke Kerns, president of the Alabama Hospital Association, said: "Being able to generate additional revenue through voluntary contributions has enabled some of our rural hospitals to remain open. Otherwise they would have to close their doors because there is insufficient revenue to keep them open."
 In Alabama this year, 24 hospitals are contributing $108 million to the state, which uses that money to obtain $288 million from the Federal Government. The state distributes the entire sum, $396 million, to hospitals, favoring those with disproportionately large numbers of low-income patients.
 "We contribute to our own well-being," said Terry J. Smith, administrator of Bibb Medical Center, a 35-bed hospital in Centreville, Ala., that donates $8,000 a month to the state and gets back $16,000 a month for a net gain of $8,000.
 Manly E. White, acting administrator of the Perry County Hospital and Nursing Home in Marion, Ala., said the voluntary contributions program was "a godsend" for many health-care providers. "It makes the difference between surviving and not surviving," he said.
 
How Transactions Work
 When hospitals donate to a state, they typically take the money from their general operating revenues. The donations are not just paper transactions; hospitals make actual cash contributions. While there may be a lag at first, the hospitals are eventually paid by state Medicaid programs at regular monthly or quarterly intervals.
 While there is no legal limit on the donation amounts, hospital executives and members of Congress agree that donations should not exceed 10 percent of a hospital's gross revenues or 10 percent of a state's Medicaid spending.
 States discovered the value of this fund-raising technique when they found that they had too little money to pay their share of Medicaid costs, creating a backlog of unpaid claims.
 Missouri is using $88 million in donated funds to obtain more than $131 million from the Federal Government. "In light of the multiple Federal mandates placed on state Medicaid programs in the last few years, I have every right to be as creative as I can in paying for the program," said Donna E. Checkett, director of Missouri's Medicaid program.
 In California, Sally Lee, chief of Medicaid operations, said the state had raised $147 million in voluntary contributions from hospitals and had obtained an equal amount in Federal matching funds. The money, she said, "keeps hospitals in business and improves access to medical care for the indigent."
 
Paying the State's Share
 In some states, hospitals contribute to Medicaid by paying part of the salaries of state or county employees who certify people as eligible for Medicaid. Salaries are considered an administrative cost. The Federal Government normally pays half of such administrative costs, with the expectation that states will pay the remainder.
 However, in South Carolina, Missouri, Texas and several other states, hospitals pay the state's share of salary costs for eligibility workers assigned to hospitals to review Medicaid applications. The hospitals benefit because Medicaid pays many hospital bills that would otherwise go unpaid. Medicaid recipients often have neither private insurance nor the means to pay their own bills.
 Thus, for example, South Carolina hospitals are contributing $2.3 million to the state's Department of Social Services to pay for 168 state employees who check eligibility for Medicaid. The Federal Government gives the state an equal amount for the salaries of those workers.
 The eight states that accept donations to secure Federal matching funds are Alabama, California, Georgia, Massachusetts, Missouri, South Carolina, Tennessee and Texas. States that have been coonsidering such arrangements are Colorado, Florida, Indiana, Maine, Maryland, Michigan, Mississippi, North Carolina, Oregon, Pennsylvania, Utah and West Virginia.

HEADLINE: Small Businesses Win Growth Awards

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER

 BODY:
WHEN the "white tablecloth" restaurants in Manhattan that flourished during the 1980's started to wither and die in the 90's, the future of the Westchester Restaurant Supply Company in Elmsford was threatened.
"Fifty percent of our business in the 80's came from upscale restaurants in Manhattan," said Richard Ross, owner of the company, which has been supplying restaurant china, glassware, silverware and cookware since 1927. 
 Mr. Ross and his partner, Stephen Birnbaum, who bought the company from its original owners in the late 70's, decided last year to expand their market and seek new customers.
Mainly, the partners turned their sights northeast. Formerly distributing no further east than Fairfield County, they now consider all of New England part of their territory.
"We also expanded our customer base by promoting walk-in trade," Mr. Ross said, "encouraging small restaurant owners, school and church representatives and the public, who want such items as quality cookware, coffee urns and restaurant-quality china."
The company's marketing efforts have been successful, Mr. Ross noted. In late February, sales began to turn up again and have continued to increase. "We've managed to achieve a pattern of growth every year for the past five years," he said.
Such growth is one reason that Westchester Restaurant Supply was recently named a "Westchester Winner" in the sixth yearly event recognizing 18 of Westchester's fastest-growing small companies. In order to qualify, each company had to be an independent business at least five years old, with 1990 sales of $150,000 to $25 million.
Ira Bratt, chairman of the Westchester Small Business Council, an affiliate of the County Chamber of Commerce that sponsors the contest, said this year's awards are particularly signficant.
 
'They Faced All the Problems'
 "These businesses are to be commended," Mr. Bratt said, "because, despite the recession, marked by vacant stores and unrented office space and increased business failures, winners this year have somehow managed to achieve consistent business success. This year, they faced all the problems always inherent in operating a successful company, compounded by the difficult economic climate."
The award winners, several of whose profiles follow, include two limousine concerns, several publishers, engineering firms, interior designers and suppliers of home care.
"Small-business owners create economic opportunities and employ more people than their larger counterparts," Mr. Bratt said. "They also take the biggest risks. But it's the growing small company that provides increased employment in a community. And that is why we like to give them some recognition."
 
'Repeat Business Is the Lifeblood'
 One such example is Excell Limousine Service in Mount Vernon.
Starting with two cars, bought in 1983 with a small stake provided by his grandmother, 32-year-old Richard J. Guberti, Excell's owner, now runs 25 limousines and employs 45 people.
Pointing out that cash flow and marketing are challenges a small service company such as his faces daily, Mr. Guberti said the growth of his company was based on service and a continuing marketing program.
"Repeat business is the lifeblood of our company," he said. "We try to make sure that once we get a customer, we keep him, by providing him with 24-hour-a-day service. I market the company aggressively and go around the country speaking to groups about limousine service."
One such appearance, he noted, resulted in a large order for limousines from the French Government. "They used us last fall to escort French President Mitterrand from the airport to the United Nations," Mr. Guberti said.
 
Publisher Branches Out
 The current challenge facing M. E. Sharpe Publishing in Armonk, publishers of books and social science journals, said its owner, Myron Sharpe, is finding a way the 33-year-old publishing company can grow when its major customers, college and university libraries, are restricted by tight budgets.
"We have been pioneers in translating social science journals from foreign languages, namely Chinese, Japanese and Russian, into English," Mr. Sharpe said. The company's work spans the fields of economics, political science, sociology and history as well as area studies of Europe, the Soviet Union, China and Japan, among others.
In addition to the company's four full-time translators, Mr. Sharpe said, M. E. Sharpe also uses the services of part-time translators and 150 free-lance proofreaders around the world.
The company's solution to the falloff in library orders, Mr. Sharpe said, has been to increase the number of trade books it sells to bookstores. "We're publishing more books, 100 new titles this year, notably in academic fields where we are well known," he said. "And they have generated a lot of new business for us."
 
A Tea Importer Who Adapted
 Despite market changes that mean fewer customers for its products, Kentea Ltd., a tea-importing concern in New Rochelle, founded in 1977, has managed to generate growth.
"Tea importing is a highly specialized business," said Kentea's president, Kentaro Ikeda, who came to this country from his native Japan in 1938. "It's a relatively small business, since Americans use only 187 million pounds of tea a year. But we have been in the business so many years -- I have been in it for 40 -- that we have earned a good reputation, which has helped us."
When Mr. Ikeda began in the tea business, he said, he had hundreds of potential customers in the early 1950's.
"The problem is that now, the number of buyers has dwindled to less than a dozen," he said, "Only the very big companies are left. We have managed because we have established good relationships over the years, and we are able to sell volume amounts at a very competitive price."
But, Mr. Ikeda continued, in order to insure his company's future growth, Kentea plans to import related items, such as speciality coffees, and to explore other products for possible export.
 
Abreast of New Technology
 Robert Schads, president of Signacon Controls in Mamaroneck, a company that designs fire, safety and security systems for industrial and commercial customers, has been in business for 25 years.
"In order to stay on the forefront of the industry, we have expanded over and over again through the years," Mr. Schads said.
"As technology becomes more sophisticated," he said, "the systems we design must integrate a wide variety of state-of-the-art equipment. We are already offering customers such things as fingerprint readers and biometric systems. That's the reason for our growth."
