HEADLINE: Windsor Knot

BYLINE: By Christopher Hitchens; Christopher Hitchens, a columnist for The Nation, is the author of "The Monarchy: A Critique of Britain's Favorite Fetish" and "Blood, Class and Nostalgia: Anglo-American Ironies."

 BODY:
In a 1957 essay, the English novelist and playwright J. B. Priestley lamented Britain's decline into an offshore province of the new American empire. Perhaps surprisingly for such a man-of-the people author, he wrote: "That is why we are so happy and excited when we can send abroad a good-looking young woman in a pretty new dress to represent us, playing the only card we feel can take a trick -- the Queen."
The years have moved on, and the Queen's dressmaker has made very little attempt to keep up with fashion, but the point still holds. No longer a great exporting nation, the British adore sending their sovereign overseas as a symbol of national unity and grandeur. When Her Majesty arrives on a state visit to America this week, she comes not just to set the seal on cooperation between Desert Rats and United States marines in the Persian Gulf and to signal the enduring nature of the "special relationship" between the two English-speaking peoples, but to reassure the "subjects" that she leaves behind. In Washington and in the bloodstock country around Lexington, Ky., she and her husband and retinue will demonstrate the sturdy, enduring qualities of duty and lineage. 
 The visit will also be a holiday from the cares and trials that increasingly beset her court in London, where each week brings rumors of marital stress, of tension over the succession, even of abdication. The essential strength of the House of Windsor reposes in its image as a family: the pattern of order in society and the microcosm of the domestic ideal. Yet it is precisely as a family that the Windsors are beginning to fray. Without even looking for skeletons in the closet, it is possible to find them thrust in one's face in the most alarming way.
Consider, for example, the most popular member of the British royal family -- certainly the most popular after the Queen herself -- Queen Elizabeth the Queen Mother. Born with the century in 1900, she was Queen during the years of the Nazi bombardment of London, when the royal decision to "stay on" through the blitz won so many hearts. And her stoic example also helped the House of Windsor to overcome the deep trauma that was occasioned by the abdication crisis of 1936, when Edward VIII decided that he preferred the company of an American divorcee to the grand responsibility of being King and Emperor.
The usual, if not, indeed, the inevitable word in newspaper descriptions of the Queen Mum, as she is affectionately known to the populace, is "radiant." She fulfils every expectation of a national grandma. Only once has she ever been publicly criticized. This was when, in 1987, a challenge was made to her position as chief patron of the Royal Society for Mentally Handicapped Children and Adults (Mencap). The challenge came when it was disclosed that two of the Queen Mother's nieces -- cousins to the Queen -- had been secretly incarcerated in a mental hospital, listed as dead and written out of the official handbooks of the British nobility.
Katherine and Nerissa Bowes-Lyon were confined in the Royal Earlswood Hospital in 1941, and their deaths announced in Burke's Peerage, the bible of British pedigree and genealogy, in 1963. Nerissa did not, in fact, die until 1986, and Katherine was still alive at the time that the grisly discovery of the forgotten sisters was made. Since Mencap existed partly to prevent ordinary families from "dumping" their retarded members and since the Queen Mother was found to have knowledge of the guilty secret in her own family, there was a row of sorts. But it soon blew over. A picture so much at odds with the prevailing and necessary one -- whereby the royal family is not just a model family in itself but a reinforcement of the idea that the British are a family -- could not be assimilated into the general consciousness. Mention the incarceration and airbrushing of the Bowes-Lyon sisters today, and most British people will look blankly at you. Mention the Queen Mother, however, and the word "radiant" will come easily to the lips as they affirm that she does "a marvelous job."
The history of British monarchy is, of course, replete with wives going to the block, princes smothered in the Tower, inconvenient pretenders spitted and burned. In Britain, reminders of this questionable past are everywhere about. On every coin is a picture of the Queen and the Latin abbreviation F. D., standing for "Fidei Defensor" or "Defender of the Faith." This title, right on the money, makes her head of the Church of England (a state church that does not permit female priests) and descends directly from the lecherous Henry VIII's schism with Rome over his hectic search for a divorce.
The hereditary principle is a peculiar thing. The laws of nature insure that it will throw up reprobates, incompetents, villains and madmen, of the sort that make the works of William Shakespeare imperishable. Yet by some alchemy, a principle so vulnerable to disaster is also the guarantee of tradition, continuity, breeding and other English hallmarks.
Subliminal association with English history and valor can make opposition to the throne seem almost akin to self-hatred. The British do not argue for their monarchy, or attempt to rationalize it. For most of them, it just is, and they affirm it with the same relish as some early church fathers affirmed the Trinity -- "Credo quia absurdum," I believe because it is absurd.
YET ON THE DAY I ARRIVED IN LONDON TO begin my re-examination of this durable absurdity, the front page of Rupert Murdoch's tabloid Sun was consumed by one giant headline. "SEPARATE HOMES," it bellowed, trumpeting the true confessions of Andrew Jacques, a police guard at Prince Charles's country estate of Highgrove. Jacques claimed that a glacial silence had descended upon the home, punctuated only by shouting matches, and that Princess Diana spent almost all her time at Kensington Palace in London. Separate rooms were the rule when the couple did meet, and the Prince spent all his waking time in a walled vegetable garden.
This looked grim. In another newspaper the same morning, I read that Capt. Mark Phillips, the recently separated husband of Charles's sister, Princess Anne, had been served with a paternity suit by a woman living in New Zealand. Princess Anne herself was reported to be having a romance with a young naval officer. And in yet another Fleet Street sheet was a lavish photo spread showing the three recent occasions when the Duchess of York -- nee Sarah Ferguson and known to all as Fergie -- had had her dresses blown above her knees by the wind on state occasions. Things had reached such a pass that Prince Charles complained (and on a French television station at that) about his family being turned into "a soap opera."
For a take on all this, I telephoned my old acquaintance Nigel Dempster, who does the royal-watch column for The Daily Mail and is regarded as the doyen of the Fleet Street society writers. "Take my advice, dear boy," he said. "Get hold of a picture of Prince Andrew" -- Fergie's husband -- "and then one of Lord Porchester at the same age. You'll see that Prince Philip could never have been Andy's father." Lord Porchester is the Queen's racing manager and tends her beloved stable of winners. He is a grandson of the Earl of Carnarvon, who opened King Tutankhamen's tomb with Howard Carter. "If you mention this," said the assiduous Dempster (who first broke the story that Margaret was the second Mrs. Thatcher), "I want full attribution."
The following morning, an angry Buckingham Palace aide, denouncing the Sun story of the previous day, told the rival newspaper Today that Charles and Diana spent at least three nights a week together -- as embarrassing a claim in its way as the earlier public one made by Diana's father, Lord Spencer, that she was "virgo intacta" on her wedding night. The same paper loyally reported that Princess Diana had given Charles a special lamp as a Christmas present, so that he could carry on his gardening after dark. In view of the repeated story that Charles likes to talk to plants and shrubs, how reassuring was this supposed to be?
What, in fact, was going on? Like poor old Tutankhamen, the royal family seemed violated and profaned, prey to every sort of vulgar gaze and speculation. Was nothing sacred? Where was the fabled mystique and reserve? I had left Washington in the clutches of Kitty Kelley fever. Had the virus crossed the Atlantic ahead of me?
SEEKING AN ANSWER, I WENT TO CALL ON Philip Ziegler, the distinguished historian and biographer. Author of "Crown and People," a study of British attitudes to the royal family, he is also one of the very few scholars permitted access to the Royal Archives at Windsor. His acclaimed 1990 biography of King Edward VIII was "authorized" by the present Queen and dealt candidly with the striking and unsettling fact of Edward's open sympathy, before, during and after the Second World War, for Adolf Hitler. (The subject of royalism and fascism is another of those topics considered too awkward for everyday discussion; one of the very few times that the Queen has had to face a political demonstration was in 1963, when she played host to then-Queen Frederika of Greece, the favorite cousin of Prince Philip and a noted pre-war Axis sympathizer.)
Ziegler received me in the ideal surroundings of his gentleman's club in St. James's, just across from the royal palace of that name. We talked about the scandal and sensation that infested royal coverage these days, and I asked him whether he thought that the monarchy, once the symbol of rectitude, had now become a generator of vulgarity. "Look, there's always been a problem with irresponsible behavior on the part of fringe members of the royal family," he said. "And I suppose there always will be. But it's a mistake to confuse public alarm at this with resentment of the monarchy itself. At the time of the abdication, several members of the royal family thought the game was up, for example, and there was a lot of disillusionment. But then along comes a jubilee or a royal marriage or some occasion of national unity and rejoicing, and everybody rallies round again."
Ziegler gave the example of King George V's Silver Jubilee in 1935, when, after a rapturous reception in London's East End slums, the old King remarked: "I'd no idea they felt like that about me. I'm beginning to think they must like me for myself." (This same King George, reading an article in The Times by H. G. Wells that called for a republic and for the end of "an alien and uninspiring court," grunted, "I may be uninspiring, but I'll be damned if I'm alien.")
"Now," Ziegler said, "if She or He showed any signs of vulgarity or irresponsibility, that'd be a very different matter." (I knew before he went on that the mentally capitalized pronouns meant the sovereign herself and the heir to her throne.) "But neither the Queen nor the Prince of Wales appears to be anything but extremely thoughtful and conscientious. In fact, the Queen really embodies the bourgeois virtues rather than the aristocratic ones -- dutiful, family-minded, respectable, hard-working -- and these values appeal to people. Prince Charles also seems a very serious and sober young man -- actually middle-aged man -- and though the press these days is much more efficient and much less scrupulous, it hasn't been able to find more than a few eccentricities in him."
I tried on Ziegler my theory that the hereditary principle is a rather chancy way of selecting a head of state, and that if you're going to claim credit for the sound ones you have to take responsibility for the nutty or corrupt ones as well. He employed the traditional defense: "It's still better than the alternatives. It avoids the ghastliness of finding some superannuated politician to be President every four years or so."
Still, considerable sentiment is generated, especially in times of high unemployment and hardship, by the extravagance of the royal style. The House of Windsor costs the taxpayers $101.5 million each year, almost half of which goes in staffing and maintaining no fewer than five royal palaces. And this hefty sum is a state supplement and subsidy to an astonishing private fortune in land, real estate, stock and art treasures. Fortune magazine recently estimated the private wealth of the Windsors, in everything from picture collections and priceless stamps to shares and jewelry, at $10.73 billion. And on the income of this immense wealth, no income tax is paid: a sore point in a country that very recently saw flaming streets and shattered windows in riots over the hated poll tax.
There's another point, hard to ignore: There are so many of them. Prince Andrew gets $481,000 per annum in expenses for his "official duties." Prince Edward receives $186,000. Princess Margaret, the Queen's divorced socialite sister, pulls in $423,000. Princess Anne, the Queen's daughter, gets $441,000. And it goes on. And all of these, except for the persistently unmarried and rumor-haunted Prince Edward, have children (one ultraloyalist glossy magazine in London deals only with the subject of royal offspring). As a consequence, given the ravenous appetite of the press and the public for royal trivia, England often seems like some princeling-infested Ruritanian theme park.
"Yes, it was all more restrained during the last reign," Philip Zeigler admits. "Then there was just the King and Queen and the two little princesses. Now it's high jinks all over the place, and Viscount Althorp can't even visit a tart in Paris without provoking a storm because he's Princess Diana's brother."
Increasingly, the smooth managers of the Buckingham Palace press office are relying on television to communicate with the public, giving up the press as a bad job (as some of the press is giving up on it: The Independent is said to have a standing order that no more than a dozen "royal stories" a year may appear in its pages). "There is much more control available when it comes to TV," a royal-coverage professional says, "and it is much less easy to spot. The key thing is that the palace can control access and film rights like a tap and can demand editing privileges before anything sees the screen. Ziegler blames the avid press for this state of affairs. But it's also clear that the journalists have more to work with these days.
During the gulf crisis, there was a colossal row over the way the royals fiddled while Kuwait burned. In a huge, indignant editorial on Feb. 10, The Sunday Times intoned piously about the sacrifice of British servicemen in the gulf while, "on the home front, too many of the young royals and their entourages carry on regardless with their peacetime life styles, parading a mixture of upper-class decadence and insensitivity which disgusts the public and demeans the monarchy."
The up-market newspaper, which represents the respectable end of Rupert Murdoch's empire and often editorializes as if it did not share offices with The Sun, is edited by Andrew Neil. Neil once told me that he represents "the new Britain" -- essentially classless or at least meritocratic, with an American approach to politics and business. He makes a practice of ridiculing royal excess and anomaly -- something that no middle-class newspaper would have dared to do until recently, and would still not dare to do unless there were sales in it. On this occasion, he even attacked the heir to the throne, saying: "The Duke of Edinburgh and the Prince of Wales have taken up arms, but only to go hunting birds. Not even war, it seems, can stop the last shoot of the season at Sandringham."
The editorial undoubtedly had the desired effect. Within 24 hours, Prince Charles and Princess Diana were visiting naval families at Plymouth, and "Fergie," the Duchess of York (attacked in the editorial for "playing with her gang, very publicly, at a high-spirited dinner in a London restaurant") was preparing to do the same at a naval air station. In addition to being the head of state and the head of the church, the Queen is also the head of the armed forces -- the only colonel in the British army, in fact, to be married to another colonel -- and on the eve of the ground war a few days later she made a very rare television broadcast to invoke the protection of God on the British troops. Yet in a previous generation, the identification of the monarchy with gut patriotism, empire and the martial virtues was so close as to be unquestionable, and no such hurried or improvised gestures would have been expected or demanded.
There are limits, though, and Neil understands them. Some weeks after his editorial had provoked the storm, The Sunday Times gave its annual literary awards dinner at the Grosvenor House Hotel. Before the ceremonies began, Neil rose, glass in hand, and proposed "The Loyal Toast" to Her Majesty. This toast must be drunk standing up. Joan Smith, the feminist critic and novelist, kept to her seat. "People kept hissing at me to stand up," Smith says, "but I stayed in my chair. And then someone pulled my chair away so I had no choice. It was one of the servants, of course." There will, as people never tire of saying, always be an England.
But is England getting value for its money? Royalists have a threefold reply. First, and usually slightly sotto voce, is the argument that the monarchy isn't like the rest of us and it's silly to pretend that it is or wish that it were or what would be the point of it? Second is the undoubted fact that revenue from the Crown Estate (which, for example, controls all land beneath territorial waters and all mineral rights except hydrocarbons) goes direct to the Treasury. Third is the claim -- put forward with some diffidence because it smacks of tacky commercialism -- that the royals are a magnet for Britain's lucrative tourist industry.
Ziegler disdains to make the tourist-industry defense because he thinks the monarchy is worth every penny. "It's a proven success over many centuries," he argues. "It's a guarantee of political stability. It gives the Prime Minister of the day a chance to talk to at least one adviser and confidante he can be certain isn't after his job. It's very well loved by the British people, who identify their national pride and unity with it. And it costs less than the British Embassy in Washington." Really? "So I've always been told," he says stoutly.
There is a problem with the elegant Ziegler defense: He makes it all somehow appear like a sound business and constitutional proposition, built to human scale. Yet the idea of English monarchy is inextricably linked with the notion of magic and charisma -- something that mortals find it hard to come by. And every revelation of human frailty, from the walled-up cousins of the Queen to the marital difficulties of her progeny, tends to derogate from this aura of majesty and mystery. As Walter Bagehot, one-time editor of The Economist and author of "The English Constitution," wrote on this ticklish subject: "Above all things our royalty is to be reverenced, and if you begin to poke about it you cannot reverence it. . . . Its mystery is its life. We must not let in daylight upon magic."
AS SHE PREPARED for her visit to the United States, during which she will address a joint session of Congress and visit MacDill Air Force Base in Tampa, Fla. (there, according to palace rumor, to meet with and perhaps confer an honorary knighthood on Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf), the Queen was confronted with two reminders of the problem of her symbolic, magical role. The first came with the enthronement of a new Archbishop of Canterbury as steward of the state church that she heads, and the second was her 65th birthday.
At the consecration of the Most Rev. George Carey on April 19, traditionalists were appalled at the evangelical, upbeat, jazzy tone of the event. The Archbishop, who once said publicly that he would gladly change the name of the Church of England to "the Jesus Movement," allowed Canterbury Cathedral to be penetrated by saxophone players and other heralds of "the good news."
The Fidei Defensor had no choice but to attend. But among those pointedly staying away from this trendy outrage to the bones of Thomas a Becket was Prince Charles, who has evolved something of a reputation as a staunch defender of undiluted Anglican orthodoxy. Those who feel that modern liturgy and worship possess none of the magic of the old Book of Common Prayer find a champion in the Prince, so untypical of his baby-boom generation, who has also been very outspoken in his attacks on modern architecture and the sloppy use and teaching of English. His nonattendance, which was explained away by an increasingly busy Buckingham Palace press office as a matter of conflicting engagements and pressure of work, was the sign of his stolidity and seriousness as contrasted to the frivolity of his junior relatives and, indeed, of his wife.
The Queen's birthday, which for magical reasons is actually celebrated on her "official birthday" in June, naturally turned people's thoughts to the increasingly headlined topic of her possible abdication. Sixty-five is the retirement age for most of her subjects, and it has been noticed that she now needs spectacles to read her speech on the state opening of Parliament; that she looks tired at public events, and so on. Meanwhile, Prince Charles has to endure the frustration of playing heir to the throne until well into his 40's.
Taking this touchy subject head on, the novelist and biographer A. N. Wilson wrote an article prominently entitled "The Queen, Abdication and the Question of Charles III." Wilson's fictions and histories qualify him as a conservative with a small c, very much identified with a reverence for what might be called Victorian and traditional standards. He is the only man I know who dines with the Queen Mother and who once even went so far as to write about the experience. He wrote: "It is no longer believed that there is any magic, apparently, about being Queen, and if she feels that she would like to spend more time with her horses in Kentucky, or looking at her father's stamp collection in Sandringham, there is no reason why the Queen should not put her feet up."
Having stated this popular view of the matter, Wilson argued against it: "The Queen did not get her job by mere promotion, as would a bank manager or a Cabinet minister. She was anointed and crowned in a religious ceremony with the clear understanding that being crowned, like being married in church, was something for life. Once an anointed monarch, always an anointed monarch."
There is an inescapable truth to this, despite the increasing demand that the Queen step down and rescue her firstborn son from the waiting room of the "Dynasty" soap opera. On the day of her coronation, the then-Archbishop of Canterbury stated: "This country and Commonwealth . . . were not far from the Kingdom of Heaven." The rituals of anointment, as performed and solemnized, are supposed to be sacred. As The London Times put it on the same occasion: "In her is incarnate on her coronation the whole of society, of which the state is no more than a political manifestation."
Indeed, Parliament itself enacts laws solely in its capacity as the embodiment of the Crown, and one of the Tory and Thatcherite objections to British participation in an increasingly federal Europe is that the primal notion of "the Crown in Parliament" would be diluted. Let no one suppose that the British think that such matters of their history -- with the words "sovereign" and "sovereignty" closely identified -- are mere quaint details. Blood has been shed over them ever since Oliver Cromwell decided that a parliamentary nation should lop off its crowned head. So, having read him making this awkward but essential point, I was surprised when having a drink with A. N. Wilson to hear him say that the monarchy was a vain and foolish business and that he would not mind if it were entirely done away with.
When literary persons of his standing start talking like this -- and the literary world tends to be royalist if only because it is included in the twice-annual distribution of medals and decorations by Buckingham Palace -- then the Crown is in some kind of trouble. If the Queen stays on, as magic says she must, then she will grow antique in the job and her son will become, as Wilson describes him, "morose and tetchy" to an even greater degree. He will be stale before his time.
If she steps down, on the other hand, she breaks the compact with realm and nation that she made on her accession and, on a practical note, becomes a looming dowager presence over the throne held by the new incumbent. Since the country already has a rather colorless Prime Minister dwelling nervously in the shadow of a formidable female predecessor, this might not be the most suitable or dignified outcome. Here is another dilemma that the hereditary system supplies and the much-despised presidential (or democratic) system does not.
"Oh, I'm quite sure she'll never abdicate," Philip Ziegler says confidently. "The British people like their monarchs to be either very old or very young -- Prince Hal or Queen Victoria -- and the Queen knows what's expected of her. It's her duty to provide a very long reign. Prince Charles will be quite happy, using his freedom to comment on matters like architecture and the environment."
LONG-RUN tendencies tell against the primacy of the Crown as it is now constituted. To take one very obvious example, Britain is now (as it was not when Elizabeth II ascended the throne) a conspicuously multiracial and multicultural society. For the Queen to be head of the Church of England is no longer for her to be, in any serious sense, a spiritual figurehead. Not only are there large Roman Catholic and Jewish minorities in the United Kingdom -- the former alone greatly embarrassing the Queen's role as, effectively, and by her own choice, monarch of only just over half of Northern Ireland -- but a large and growing number of Muslems are making their presence visible in everything from education to literary criticism. The fact that members of the royal family are prohibited by law from marrying a Roman Catholic is therefore only the least of the many anomalies for a supposed emblem of national unity.
Add to this the growing debate on constitutional reform. A highly vocal movement named Charter 88 -- composed mainly, but not exclusively, of writers and intellectuals -- has changed the terms of political argument in Britain by pressing for a constitutional bill of rights on the American model, and thus challenging the supreme right of Parliament to make any law that it chooses.
At present, the British people are "subjects," not "citizens." They can be told what to do by what Lord Hailsham, the former Tory Lord Chancellor, once famously called "an elective dictatorship." So the demand for entrenched and inalienable constitutional guarantees strikes at the heart of the political settlement made in 1688 -- the so-called Glorious Revolution" -- whereby the former powers of the deposed King James II were passed to Parliament and a new dynasty founded by the importation of the House of Orange.
On the right, the modernizing monetarists centered at the Institute of Economic Affairs -- think tank for many of Margaret Thatcher's privatizing and marketeering initiatives -- have produced a pamphlet by Frank Vibert that calls for the monarchy to be stripped of all but its ceremonial powers. Thus, to an extent that it would have been impossible to predict even a decade ago, the monarchy has become a political subject as the varying pressures for political libertarianism, for new European institutions and a more modern system come up against the traditions of an ancien regime whose symbolic leadership has internal troubles of its own making.
Once the monarchical apex of the system is challenged, the less popular features of the old order, such as the House of Lords as a nonelected second chamber, become much harder to defend. Indeed, the whole hierarchy of British society would look rather threadbare if it were not for the golden coach, the orb and scepter and the Crown -- known to cynical republicans as "a hat that lets in the rain." Not for nothing is the allegedly apolitical monarchy considered a force for "stability" -- a word that is never quite as apolitical as it seems.
In his story "Russian Hide- and-Seek," the novelist Kingsley Amis (who was created Sir Kingsley by Her Majesty less than a year ago) wrote about a futuristic Britain that had been incorporated into the Soviet Empire. Gradually it becomes evident that the turning point in the Russian subjugation of the conquered Anglo-Saxons has been the execution, disguised clumsily as a suicide, of their Queen. When a Russian officer asks an English doctor his feelings about this, the man becomes all gruff and stiff upper lip: "Please don't let's discuss the matter." When the other assumes a look of theatrical puzzlement, he hurries on: "Because I know from experience that it's quite impossible to explain to a Russian how we feel about that. After what happened . . . there's no point."
This captures quite nicely the indefinable sense that average conservative Britons have of their sovereign as a self-sacrificing, nearly miraculous person; someone only they can understand and who understands them in return -- someone for foreigners to envy and admire but never to comprehend.
Philip Ziegler's book "Crown and People," which contains the results of many surveys of public and street opinion, has as a recurring feature the conviction that Americans are jealous of the monarchy. Typical of many comments is one reported by a Mass Observation polling monitor at the time of the coronation, a man of 60 who said: "I'll say one thing. I think the Americans are a bit jealous. They like it, they think it's wonderful and all that; but they're just a little bit jealous, as if they wished it was theirs." You don't have to spend long in a pub to hear similar sentiments similarly expressed.
This sense that the Queen is all that is left of past imperial splendor must be felt at palace level also, because very particular attention is paid to the deployment of the royal family in the "special relationship" with the former colonies. Visits by one or another royal are frequent and various, with Prince Charles preferring to spend time with Walter Annenberg and Princess Diana choosing the company of John Travolta and Donald Trump.
Some visits are successful -- when the queen made her first visit as Princess Elizabeth, one Washington politician was so overcome on meeting her that he claimed to have met "your father -- Sir Winston." Some are less happy -- as when the then-unmarried Prince Charles thought President Nixon was leaving him too much alone with his daughter Tricia. But in general a royal progress through the United States leads to a good press, some prestige for British exports, a terrific riot over invitations to the reception or garden party in Washington and some enhancement to diplomatic and military relations.
Two honorary knighthoods have recently been conferred on American citizens; one on Caspar W. Weinberger (for services rendered during the Falklands war) and one on Ronald Reagan, and both decisions were taken on the direct prompting of the Foreign Office. The Germans and the Saudis may be able to do many things for their American guests, but one thing they cannot do is take them to Buckingham Palace and lay a ceremonial sword on their shoulders. The present visit is planned as a sort of seal on what was seen throughout Britain as an Anglo-American, rather than an American-led, combined operation. If General Schwarzkopf goes so far as to forget what Jefferson wrote about "the false glare which surrounds kingly government," he will be only the latest in a long line of Democrats and Republicans to do so.
In his acid and crusty memoirs, which are now making the London rounds and causing sharp intake of breath with their caustic reflections, Sir Kingsley Amis speaks quite candidly about his dreams -- some of them rather carnal -- about the Queen. This confession is not as novel as it may appear. A few years ago, there appeared an entire book called "Dreams About H. M. the Queen," in which subjects of every rank and calling confided their fantasies. These were most commonly of embarrassment; of meeting the Queen unprepared or unawares. The book contained a warning. "The dream," it said, "is not about the Queen. It is about you." Some of the British are beginning to notice the difference.

CORRECTION-DATE: June 16, 1991, Sunday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
An article in The Times Magazine on May 12 about the British royal family and a correction in this space on May 19 referred incompletely to the reason the sovereign is called Defender of the Faith. The title was given to King Henry VIII by Pope Leo X in 1521 but was withdrawn by the Roman Catholic Church after Henry broke with it. During Henry's monarchy, an act of Parliament later joined the title to the English crown.

PUB-DATE: May 12, 1991,

HEADLINE: Shore Tries New Tack In Luring Tourists

BYLINE: By LEO H. CARNEY

 BODY:
IN years past, the tourism industry in New Jersey largely relied on the 127-mile stretch of sandy beaches from Sandy Hook to Cape May to sell itself. Now, with many vacationers discouraged by the recession and by the pollution of summers past, and with the state cutting back on promotion money, tourism and local government officials have teamed up with business owners to package and sell the Jersey Shore.
"What we're seeing this year is business people networking among themselves to promote tourism, and cooperation even between chambers of commerce, which you never saw before," said Gordon S. Reinauer, the chairman of the Shore Region Tourism Council, a group of tourism-related businesses and local government agencies in Monmouth and Ocean Counties. 
 He pointed to the marketing of tour packages on Long Beach Island and in Spring Lake as illustrative of local promotional efforts. Among the half-dozen packages on Long Beach Island, for example, are those that include sightseeing at Barnegat Lighthouse, meals at a selection of restaurants, charter-boat deep-sea fishing and a visit to the Fantasy Island amusement park. Businesses and merchants, Mr. Reinauer said, "are being encouraged to work out things like freebies, coupons, transportation and other inducement to amusement parks, restaurants, antique shops, hotels, inns and even malls, where vacationers at the beach can go on a rainy day."
Tourism officials and others say it is too early to judge the results of the new marketing strategy. But preliminary indications, like preseason rentals, they say, give them cause for some optimism. Among the upbeat is Donald O'Rourke, a spokesman for the Ocean County Board of Chosen Freeholders.
"If the weather is good," he said, "I think we'll have a banner year."
The downturn at the Shore in recent seasons is attributable to two largely unrelated phenomena. Widespread reports of ocean pollution and beach closings beginning in 1987 resulted in fewer vacationers and an erosion of tourism revenue. For the Shore, what was a $7 billion a year industry in 1987 is expected to total less than $6 billion this year.
At the same time, many resort towns have seen a falloff in rental properties -- and tourist dollars -- as they have become either year-round communities or enclaves of second homes that are not rented out by the owners. Also undermining the Shore economy are the regional and national recessions, as well as a trend toward shorter vacations caused by socioeconomic changes, like working couples' being unable to coordinate their job schedules.
But with the shorter-vacation trend, at least, tourism officials see an opportunity: as vacationers worry about getting the most for scarce dollars, the officials say, many are opting for the vacation closest to home.
The Shore's promoters, like Mr. Reinauer and Peter Schnell, head of the Ocean County Tourism Advisory Council, pointed out that many businesses in Monmouth and Ocean Counties had decided to market their boardwalk and other beach-related businesses vigorously this year, spending thousands of dollars in hopes of winning back the vacationers. But the marketing efforts also encompass shopping, sightseeing and such rainy-day activities as indoor fashion shows at shopping malls.
 
Municipalities' Efforts
 Meanwhile, county governments and individual municipalities are placing new emphasis on promotional programs, Mr. Reinauer and Mr. Schnell said. Ocean County, for example, will spend $150,000 or more this spring to promote tourism, Mr. Schnell said.
Mr. Reinauer noted that the $350,000 that the state made available in 1989 to Shore communities for special grants to promote local events had dwindled to $200,000 this year because of the budget cuts.
In Belmar, Marie Newbery, the official who oversees beach activities, recited a long list of oceanfront events planned from June 2 to Labor Day that will be financed by the Borough of Belmar and commercial promoters. The events include amateur and professional volleyball tournaments, bicycle and jet-ski races, a jazz festival, surfing contests and a five-mile run.
"There has been a big effort this year to get more people to visit us," she said, adding that much of the organization of these events came from the business community there.
In Asbury Park, Garrett L. Giberson, a spokesman for the city, said the city would hold a boardwalk rock festival this summer, to be broadcast by a New York City radio station, WNEW-FM.
 
Lighthouse to Reopen
 Farther south, in Barnegat Light, the historic Barnegat Lighthouse, known as Old Barney, will reopen on Memorial Day after being closed three years for restoration. And Ocean Grove, in Monmouth County, has a full summer schedule of special events on the boardwalk and at the Great Auditorium, which was built in 1896.
At the Fantasy Island amusement park in Beach Haven, Fern Schoderer, the promotions manager, said she was expecting a banner season, thanks to the various tour packages and a trend toward shorter vacactions and day trips. The park has not yet realized the profits that were expected when it opened in 1985, Miss Schoderer said, but there have been small and steady increases each year since.
"In good times and bad times," Miss Schoderer said, "even when people don't have enough money to take out their family to a restaurant, they won't refuse their children a trip to an amusement park."
 
Encouragement on Rentals
 Preseason rentals along the Shore have, for the most part, provided an encouraging sign. Dolores Szelling, the rental manager for H.C.H. Real Estate in Harvey Cedars, said rentals along the northern half of Long Beach Island were up 20 percent over last year's.
Jeanne DiPaola, a spokesman for the southern Ocean County Chamber of Commerce, said business along the 18-mile Long Beach Island improved last summer over 1989, especially for rentals and the restaurant trade. Vacation packages, with a variety of places to stay and sights to see, had helped, Ms. DiPaola said, as had a brochure that is distributed by the tens of thousands.
And for the coming season "we're seeing some very dramatic increases over 1990 in rentals and motel reservations, too," Ms. DiPaola said.
Eugene Dilbeck, director of the New Jersey Division of Travel and Tourism, said that a promising sign of a successful summer in 1991 was reports the division had received from real-estate agents, who said the renters included families who were returning to the Shore after not vacationing there for five years or so.
But last year, in the spring, the Division of Travel and Tourism had said that preseason shore rentals were running 30 percent above 1989. At summer's end, however, the agency said the actual increase had been only 10 percent.
 
Differences of Opinion
 Others are currently less sanguine in their assessments of preseason rentals.
An innkeeper in Cape May, who insisted on not being identified, for example, said reports by real-estate agents of a 15 to 40 percent increase in preseason rentals were overly optimistic. "They say the same thing every year," he said. "I'll let you know in September if they were right, but our rentals aren't up like that."
Another innkeeper, Carl Conover of Bay Head, said that weekend reservations there for the coming season were merely satisfactory, not exceptional, and that weekday reservations were down, as they had been last year, despite his advertising in national and international directories.
"The preseason reservations and property rentals are generally an accurate barometer of how the summer will be," Mr. Conover said, although he added that "we get a good amount of last-minute rentals, too."
 
Feeling the Budget Pinch
 Mr. Dilbeck, of the Division of Travel and Tourism, acknowledged that budget cuts had hampered the state agency's efforts. The agency's budget has shrunk to $7.6 million this year from $9 million in 1988. As a result, he said, the agency could no longer afford national radio and television advertising that it had sponsored in the past.
He said the $1.9 million that the agency would spend on advertising this spring would be placed in national and regional magazines, like Good Housekeeping, Family Circle and Baltimore Magazine. Roughly a quarter of the ads are specific to the Shore. Others, he said, extol the pleasures of casino gambling in Atlantic City, the state's rich history or the rural splendors of the state's northwest.
"I am dealing the hand I was dealt," Mr. Dilbeck said, referring to the small budget, "and that does not mean I am dealing the hand I wanted." He said $10 million to $12 million a year was need to promote tourism adequately in New Jersey.
With the decline in state support, Mr. Dilbeck said, the agency has adopted the attitude that it is more like a shopping mall operator that advertises the mall itself -- the state -- and the individual communities and businesses are like the mall's retail outlets, which must promote their own specific goods and attractions.
For example, the theme of the division's three-day Governor's conference on tourism in Cherry Hill in March was "Building Partnerships for the 90's." National experts from organizations like the American Express Travel Services Group and Travelers Weekly, a magazine, gave talks and seminars on "Optimizing Marketing Opportunities" and "Developing Tour Packages and Tour Package Partnerships."
"They have to spend their own money now, and also be more creative," Mr. Reinauer said.
 
Uncertainty Over Pollution
 Despite the upbeat talk of tourism officials and merchants, the threat of ocean pollution remains a lingering uncertainty.
State environmental officials note that much has been done to rid the beaches of plastic, wood and other debris; to monitor potential problems from floating waste and garbage in nearby harbors, rivers and offshore waters and to vigorously test bathing waters for bacteria. But the officials say the quality of ocean water this summer will remain anyone's guess.
"We are still vulnerable to easterly storms and driving winds, or to periods of heavy rain that can either force floatables onto beaches or cause bacterial levels to rise in surf waters," said Ed Neafsey, director of enforcement policy and ocean issues for the State Department of Environmental Protection in Trenton.
Acknowledging imponderables like pollution and the tight economy make it impossible to predict accurately how successful the summer season will be. Mr. Dilbeck said the state's advertising campaign could draw an additional 400,000 visitors to the Shore if the weather was good. "We just don't know how deep their pockets will be," he said.

HEADLINE: Metro Matters;
More Thinking About Proposing The Unthinkable

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
In his broadcast call to alms last week, Mayor David N. Dinkins took pains (a word whose variants he invoked seven times) to distinguish the fiscal crisis New York City faced 16 years ago from the great (a word whose derivatives he employed nine times) challenges posed by the current budget crisis.
The 1975 version, the Mayor said, was precipitated by "financial gimmicks and budgetary tricks." In contrast, Mr. Dinkins said, the deepening crisis he inherited last year "is largely the direct result of a failing national economy." 
 But the thrust of his speech was strikingly similar to the refrain sounded in May 1975 by Mayor Abraham D. Beame, a few months before the city was, in effect, placed in receivership. Mr. Beame, too, blamed a national recession. He recounted "unheard of" economies he had already imposed. Unable to muster support for his austerity budget, he proposed an "unthinkable" one. With the help of the public and the assembled officials, he concluded, "I will not fail you."
Mr. Dinkins was somewhat less equivocal last week. "I do not intend to fail," he declared a third of the way through his speech, rousing his invited audience at City Hall to only its third smattering of perfunctory applause.
What does Mr. Dinkins intend to do?
His speech and the budget he formally presented on Friday offered few new clues for dealing with the city's enduring structural deficit. A few high-profile cuts (eliminating lifeguards at public beaches, for one) seemed to have been proposed under the politically correct presumption that the City Council would restore them. Others may become self-fulfilling, though; the deficit is real, even if some of the proposed solutions may not be.
Why did he give the speech?
Mr. Dinkins would rather address the public directly than have his remarks filtered though the media. (He usually prefers to govern in camera.) He appeared earnest and unusually impas sioned, but his nothing- for-everyone speech was heavy on props, platitudes and perspi ration (which, given the one percent of in spiration required by Thomas Edison's defi nition, may qualify the Mayor as a genius).
 The Mayor cautioned againstfinger-point ing. But he took swipes at his predecessor and attributed the city's 10- digit deficit largely to the Federal Government. He has been instrumental in uniting fellow mayors and is to join them again this week in Washington to press their domestic agenda jointly with a new Congressional urban caucus.
Mr. Dinkins defended himself, though, for having lobbied in behalf of his pet spending priorities when he sat on the Board of Estimate as the Manhattan Borough President. ("I did a whole lot with that one damn vote," he said.) He also defended commitments he had made as Mayor -- to expand the police force and raise the pay of city employees -- that now confine him.
Shouldn't he have spoken sooner?
Yes, but would he have been any more believable? By Friday, at least Mr. Dinkins had completed a full week in which his message was consistent, even if he has yet to deliver on most of it. "It is not in words that I should wish my life distinguished but rather in things done," he quoted Sophocles, who also wrote: "That pilot of state who sets no hand to the best policy, but remains tongue-tied through some terror, seems vilest of men."
Has he, indeed, done the unthinkable?
"Without help," Mr. Dinkins said, "the unthinkable will become the unavoidable." Some of the economies he has proposed and imposed were overdue. He even disclosed that a panel he appointed was reviewing the possibility of imposing tolls on the East River bridges. But his conclusion that the recession represents "less an opportunity than a calamity" implies that some things are still unthinkable.
Top-heavy administrations have been pared at the Board of Education and the Health and Hospitals Corporation -- which Budget Director Philip R. Michael said is almost no longer dependent on the city for general support -- but not in the Police Department.
Not until Borough President Howard Golden of Brooklyn pressed was the administration willing to consider a proposal to save millions of dollars in overtime costs by avoiding the heavy use of police officers at nonconfrontational public events.
Mr. Dinkins appealed to New Yorkers to help replace lapsed city services. But he stopped short of suggesting that there are some services the city should no longer provide because it cannot afford to.
What does he consider unthinkable?
Freedom, as the song says, is just another word for nothing left to lose. With so many of his own dreams deferred by the deficit, the Mayor never fully explained why, beyond symbolism, New Yorkers would be that much worse off if the State Financial Control Board or a similar body stepped in to help. Instead, he declared Friday: "Fiscal independence must be maintained at all costs."

HEADLINE: Wary of Expense, Soviets Debate Bill to Ease Travel and Emigration

BYLINE: By ESTHER B. FEIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, May 12

 BODY:
Soviet legislators today discussed the financial and human-rights considerations raised by a long-debated bill that would allow citizens the freedom to travel and emigrate. But they were unable to resolve their conflicting concerns and postponed a vote on the measure.
Although the Soviet Union has considerably eased its once overwhelming obstacles for those seeking to leave the country, on visits or permanently, it still does not have a law that grants its citizens the right to choose whether and when to go abroad. 
 This has created obstacles in the United States to granting most-favored-nation trading status to the Soviet Union, a designation that could help ease the country's critical economic situation by relaxing trade barriers and allowing millions of dollars in credits.
The Supreme Soviet first took up the so-called freedom-of-movement bill two years ago. But fears of a large-scale wave of emigration and of the high costs of putting such a law into effect have continuously pushed the subject back into committee for further discussion. As a result, many Western governments have questioned the country's commitment to guaranteeing travel and migration rights.
 
Support From Gorbachev
 With a recent show of support for the bill by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, supporters of the measure say that it may finally be nearing passage. The debate is scheduled to resume on Monday, and legislators say there is a good chance that there will be a vote.
A presidential spokesman said last week that Mr. Gorbachev was in favor of lifting barriers for those wishing to travel abroad. The spokesman, Vitaly N. Ignatenko, said that "to our regret, the bill has gone through several readings," but added, "It is being fully supported by the President."
In today's debate, and in discussions of the bill that began last week, lawmakers detailed the cost of a law granting across-the-board freedom to travel or emigrate.
They quoted estimates by the official press agency Tass and other Government departments that it would cost the country the equivalent of $20 billion to print passports and new customs forms, increase staff at passport agencies, customs offices and border-control points, and increase the number of outward-bound flights.
That price tag, many of them said, did not include the loss of manpower and intellectual capacity that the country would suffer if all who wished to leave were allowed to go.
 
Hurdles Would Remain
 If the bill is passed, it is not expected to go into effect until July 1992.
And even under the new law, Soviet citizens trying to leave would face substantial hurdles. With low reserves of critically needed hard currency, the Soviet Government strictly limits the amount of rubles a citizen can change into dollars or other convertible currencies, making it difficult for many to pay for a trip or a move abroad.
More important, permission to leave the country does not guarantee that another country would agree to receive potential emigrants. Leaders of Western European nations have already expressed concern that passage of the bill would cause a flood of labor in the European Community, which is already struggling to absorb millions of workers from Eastern Europe.
The immigration issue was long a stumbling block in relations between Moscow and Washington. Tension over the subject has eased in recent years, as the authorities here have relaxed travel restrictions. But Congress has been reluctant to lift remaining trade barriers until the more open policies are enshrined in law.

HEADLINE: Bush Greeted With Silent Protest at Black College

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HAMPTON, Va., May 12

 BODY:
Two-thirds of 1,023 graduating seniors at Hampton University, a historically black institution, remained seated and silent to protest the Bush Administration's civil rights policies today as the President received an honorary degree.
There were a few moans and some laughter as the university's president, William R. Harvey, read the citation recognizing Mr. Bush's "long and steady support for historically black colleges and universities." About 30 students raised their clenched fists into the air. 
 But it was an understated, even polite demonstration as most of the students, who had been standing for the singing of the school song, simply sat down abruptly while Mr. Bush took the stage to the strains of "Hail to the Chief."
There was scattered applause from faculty members, some students and parents for Mr. Bush, whose speech went through a wide range of domestic issues but hardly mentioned civil rights.
 
Sending a Message
 "The students wanted to do something subtle," said Carvel Lewis, the senior class president, who said it was "an honor" to have Mr. Bush at the ceremony. "With the world looking at us, they wanted to act like the educated people that they are, but also do something that would be noticed."
Still, it was a substantial change from the enthusiastic crowds that generally greet Mr. Bush, especially since the Persian Gulf war. And the protest not only demonstrated the unhappiness on one college campus with Mr. Bush's veto of the 1990 Civil Rights Act, but was also a reminder that the President has yet to come to grips with the civil rights issues that have been troubling him since he took office.
Nonetheless, the President stuck to his plans to avoid any discussion of civil rights in the speech, one of a series of commencement addresses that he is delivering this spring on major issues facing the country.
Mr. Bush does plan a speech on civil rights. He will deliver it on June 2, at the United States Military Academy in West Point, N.Y.
 
Promoting Free Trade
 Mr. Lewis said he had not expected Mr. Bush to talk about civil rights, but some of his classmates were disappointed. "One of my friends said he wanted to hear more about what the job market is going to be for us, what the economic prospects are for the country and about the civil rights bill that Bush vetoed," Mr. Lewis said.
Instead, in what had been billed as a major address on "the new world economic order," Mr. Bush gave more of a campaign stump speech extolling his proposals on free trade with Mexico, educational reform and encouraging programs that allow public housing residents to buy their homes.
White House aides argued that simply because Mr. Bush was addressing a largely black audience did not mean he must discuss civil rights. They said it was unfair to criticize the President for not raising the issue.
 
Aware of the Opposition
 Mr. Bush returned to Camp David, Md., after the ceremony and planned to take Monday off at the request of doctors treating a thyroid ailment that has been blamed for an irregular heartbeat. Asked how he would spend the day, Mr. Bush replied, "Jogging." But it was not clear whether he was joking or really intended to resume the exercise that touched off his heart flutter on May 4.
The White House had been aware of the opposition among some Hampton students to Mr. Bush's appearance today; Mr. Lewis said a Presidential aide went to the university last week to discuss Mr. Bush's positions on civil rights with students.
Mr. Bush did not acknowledge the silent demonstration. "The President appreciated the warm welcome and the opportunity to address the students at Hampton," said Judy Smith, the assistant White House press secretary.
Mr. Harvey said the institution was giving Mr. Bush his honorary Doctor of Laws degree "because of your long and steady support for historically black colleges and universities." He also mentioned that Mr. Bush had founded the Yale chapter of the United Negro College Fund as a student.
Mr. Lewis said that many students on campus thought Mr. Bush's actions years ago were not persuasive. "A lot of the students thought, 'Big deal.' "
A document distributed by a group of students said, "We feel that we should only honor any person who has benefited the entire African American community and not just its wealthy and most fortunate."
As he began to speak, Mr. Bush tried a few jokes: "You know, President Harvey is an avid tennis player. Really avid. When I shook his hand he corrected my grip."
But there was little laughter and Mr. Bush launched into his prepared text, which roamed from educational opportunity to free trade, a pitch for his proposed cut in the capital gains tax, affordable housing and general statements about America's role in the post-cold war world.
But there was only one direct reference to domestic civil rights issues. Mr. Bush said: "We must free people who have been held back by barriers of discrimination. This Administration will fight discrimination vigorously because a kinder, gentler nation must not be gentle or kind to those who practice prejudice. We must free people bound by red tape and unnecessary regulation."

HEADLINE: Dinkins and Koch Trade Barbs on Fiscal Performance

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
In a whirlwind round of live and taped television appearances yesterday, Mayor David N. Dinkins defended his handling of New York City's fiscal problems and took some sharp swipes at the stewardship of his predecessor, Edward I. Koch. The former Mayor replied with a few barbed counterpunches reminiscent of the blows he delivered in his own days at City Hall.
"I don't know that it's too fruitful to blame others," Mr. Dinkins said on the WABC-TV "Eyewitness News Conference" after a long week of bad budget news. "I think what people want is resolutions to the problems, as opposed to finger-pointing." 
 The Mayor's resolutions call for, among other things, $1 billion in new taxes and spending cuts that would shut shelters for the homeless and turn off street lights.
But in defending himself and his plans for closing a $3.5 billion gap in the city's $28.7 billion budget for the fiscal year that starts July 1, the Mayor made it clear that he believed there was plenty of blame to go around -- from the Federal and state governments to Mr. Koch.
Noting that the city's work force grew by 50,000 people from the early 80's until he took office, he said: "That was not done by Dinkins. It was done by my predecessor."
 
Prior Planning Criticized
 The Mayor, who has generally avoided pointing a finger at Mr. Koch, also said the city was forced to trim plans for building long-term projects, since it could not afford the interest on bonds issued under "plans made heretofore which may have seemed well and good at the time but were not."
"And mind you," Mr Dinkins added, "while we were doing that in the past, yet we weren't taking care of bridges, and that's why we have our crumbling infrastructure today. So it's significant that many of the actions we take today are to cure the errors of the past."
Asked on the WCBS-TV "Sunday Edition" program whether he, as Manhattan Borough President, had urged Mr. Koch to save money, Mr. Dinkins bristled a bit and said, "What I used to recommend was that we spend money differently."
As Borough President, Mr. Dinkins supported many of the social-service programs that he is now proposing to cut while hiring thousands of new police officers.
Mr. Dinkins was also a member of the Board of Estimate, where he had just one of 11 votes on the budget from 1986 through 1989. Thus, he said, he did not "remotely" bear the same responsibility as Mr. Koch for not spending more carefully.
 
Koch Response: 'Baloney'
 Mr. Koch, in a telephone interview, called the Dinkins criticisms "baloney."
"I never saw David Dinkins ask that we paint the bridges," the former Mayor said, "I only saw him ask for increases in social services. I'm not saying the bridges were not my responsibility, too."
Mr. Koch said the only area in which he had restored the work force to the levels in effect before the fiscal crisis of 1975 was education.
"Did he want me not to?" he asked. "I increased social services for abused children. He wanted even more."
Mr. Koch called Mr. Dinkins, who was elected with strong labor support, a "prisoner of the unions."
"He thought they were his partners," the former Mayor said. "They turned out to be his executioners."
 
Raises Are Defended
 Leland T. Jones, a spokesman for Mr. Dinkins, said the Mayor would not answer Mr. Koch's rebuttal because "he does not respond to columnists."
Mr. Dinkins defended his decision to grant raises to municipal employees, though he is now struggling to get some of that money back through concessions.
"I expect them to make concessions that will be acceptable to us," he said. An 18-month wage deferral, for example, would be unacceptable, the Mayor said, because it would merely postpone the problem. His aides have said he is seeking more than a half-billion dollars in wage, benefit or work-rule changes.
Yesterday the New York City Partnership, a business and civic group, urged Mr. Dinkins to find at least $800 million in labor savings and productivity moves.
Mr. Dinkins has proposed saving hundreds of millions of dollars through various efforts to make the government more efficient.
But the Mayor also said in a live interview on the CBS-TV news program "Face the Nation" that New York was entitled to more help from Washington. He plans to go to the capital on Wednesday with other urban mayors to argue for what he called emergency "anti-recession" aid to cities.

HEADLINE: Fund-Raising on Target for Whopping Victory Parade

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN

 BODY:
With a month to go, New York's salute to the veterans of the Persian Gulf war -- a huge, triumphant ticker-tape parade up lower Broadway's Canyon of Heroes -- is on schedule, planners say, and very likely to meet its twin goals of total private financing and a spectacle rivaling those for Lindbergh or V-J Day.
In an outpouring of support for the hard-pressed city and troops of the American-led coalition, the organizers say, scores of corporations, hundreds of businesses and thousands of individuals have pledged $4.1 million in cash, goods and services, bringing Operation Welcome Home within reach of its $5 million goal for the June 10 extravaganza. 
 If continuing appeals meet expectations, organizers say they will be able to spare the city up to $2.5 million in police, sanitation and other costs; defray all other parade expenses; sponsor an interfaith service and a fireworks display, and have enough left to aid some returning veterans and families of those killed or wounded in the war.
And if all goes as planned, they say, two million people in lower Manhattan and millions more watching television around the world will see 30,000 marchers -- troops and dignitaries from every state, every gulf regiment and all 40 allied nations -- march up Broadway with floats, veterans of other wars, Medal of Honor recipients and a legion of thundering bands under cascades of cheering and a blizzard of confetti and ticker tape.
 
Biggest Parade Planned
 "It's going to be larger than any ticker-tape parade in history," said Joseph H. Flom, co-chairman of Operation Welcome Home, a 30-member private commission named by Mayor David N. Dinkins in March to organize a heroes' welcome that has traditionally been planned and paid for by the city itself.
"It will be wonderful -- a unique experience," said Peter Kohlmann, executive director of the commission. "Imagine yourself in the middle of a big snowstorm with millions of people cheering all around you, people dumping confetti out windows and off the rooftops. It's a form of New York respect and love."
Some 3,000 dignitaries -- ambassadors, cabinet officers, governors, members of Congress, labor and civic leaders -- will join the Mayor in the reviewing stands at City Hall Park, while Secretary of De fense Dick Cheney, Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, the gulf commander, and the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs, Gen. Colin L. Powell, and other military and civilian leaders will ride or march in the parade.
Along the one-mile parade route from the Battery to Worth Street, scores of five-foot yellow-ribbon bows will be painted on the pavement, symbols of the void left on the block by a soldier gone to war.
Although parades on St. Patrick's Day, Puerto Rican Day and other occasions have often mustered larger gatherings or longer marches along Fifth Avenue, ticker-tape parades have usually been short lavish bursts of adoration on lower Broadway for lone heroes or a few world-class athletes, political or military victors, astronauts or foreign leaders.
Those honored have included Charles A. Lindbergh in 1928, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower in 1945, John Glenn in 1962, the world champion New York Mets in 1969 and 1986, the New York Yankees in 1978, Pope John Paul II in 1979, the American hostages returned from Iran in 1981 and, last year, Nelson Mandela, the African National Congress leader.
 
Foreign Troops, Too
 Next month's parade will more closely resemble those that followed the Armistice of World War I and victories in Europe and the Pacific in World War II, when returning American troops marched up the Canyon of Heroes at shoulder arms and were engulfed in ticker-tape and patriotism.
Outlining plans for the parade, Eric Andrus, a spokesman for the organizers, said, "We're going to have 30,000 marchers, troops from all 50 states, a heavy contingent of New York City-area Desert Storm troops and veterans from World War II, the Korean War and the Vietnam War."
Besides American Army, Navy and Marine contingents, he said, troops or other representatives from most of the 40 nations in the coalition that defeated Iraq, and from Israel, which was bombed but did not respond militarily, are expected to take part. Bands, floats, fife and drum corps and many civilian organizations, including labor groups, will also participate, he said.
Among the marchers will be a contingent of at least 87 of the 210 living recipients of the Congressional Medal of Honor, the nation's highest award for valor. The eldest are four 80-year-old veterans of World War II. Those honored are to be flown to New York by American Express, their hosts and a principal contributor to the parade.
 
1,000 Tons of Paper
 The marchers will step off at 11:30 A.M. from Battery Park and move up Broadway in the shadows between the skyscrapers. More than 1,000 tons of ticker tape, shredded paper and confetti, much of it distributed by parade organizers, will flutter down from windows and rooftops.
"It's a blizzard of paper and color and sparkle," Mr. Kohlmann said, conjuring up scenes from ancient newsreels with streamers raining down through the sunlight upon a roaring tumult of humanity.
Most ticker-tape parades end at City Hall, where the Mayor and other officials greet and praise the heroes. But next month's parade will pass the reviewing stand in City Hall Park and continue north to Worth Street, where the marchers will disperse. The parade is expected to end at midafternoon.
The throngs lining Broadway that Monday are expected to be swelled by lunchtime crowds of workers from Manhattan's government-financial complex, and by people in town for the Puerto Rican Day Parade and the Welcome Back to Brooklyn Festival, both scheduled for June 9, and Fleet Week, the annual gathering of American warships in the harbor.
Although many details of news coverage remain to be worked out, the parade organizers say they expect the event to be telecast live by most local stations and by some of the American networks and broadcast in Europe, the Middle East, the Far East and Australia as well.
 
Fireworks at Night
 As part of the welcoming festivities, the organizers are planning to send out 5,000 invitations to an inter-faith service to be held at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, 112th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, at 4 P.M. on Sunday, June 9.
After Monday's parade, at about 9 or 9:30 P.M., the organizers are planning a half-hour fireworks display to be set off from barges in the East River at the South Street Seaport. Mr. Andrus said that Coca-Cola had agreed to sponsor part of the display but that a co-sponsor was still being sought.
Some 450 people, mostly volunteers, have worked on the parade for two months. The Mayor's 30-member commission has set the goals and raised most of the money; Mr. Kohlmann, the executive director, with a small paid staff and 400 volunteers, has coordinated planning, publicity and invitations; Eventures, a company that produces special events, has taken on the huge logistics of the parade without charge.
Deputy Mayor Bill Lynch and other mayoral staff members have met often with the parade organizers. The city, facing a budget crisis, will provide 3,000 police officers, 550 sanitation workers, a battalion of cleanup trucks and hundreds of other municipal employees, but will be reimbursed for all its expenses.
 
Aid for Veterans Planned
 Despite the recession, organizers say, more than 3,000 individuals and 40 corporations have donated $2.5 million in cash and $1.6 million in goods and services. About $300,000 is expected to be raised from the sale of T-shirts and tote bags, but the campaign will continue to provide funds for veterans and their families as well as the parade.
Noncash contributions, the organizers said, have included hotel rooms and airline tickets for visiting dignitaries; meals and gifts for service personnel; office supplies; donations of accounting, legal and advertising services, even tons of used ticker tape from a Connecticut company that still makes old-fashioned ticker-tape machines.
Has support for the troops waned since the war? "People are getting back to their day-to-day lives," Mr. Andrus said. "But there's still enthusiasm for this. I see it in the yellow ribbons people wear, in the calls we receive from people willing to help."
Among the hundreds of letters bearing contributions, he said, was one from Alison Bankes's fourth-grade class at the Todd School in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. The children had raised $800 selling hot dogs.
"We hope this money will make a better parade for the troops of Desert Storm," the children wrote. "They deserve it!"

HEADLINE: U.S. Lawyers Flock to Brussels

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRUSSELS

 BODY:
As Brussels strengthens its hold as the administrative capital of the new Europe, American law firms have rushed to open offices to do everything from lobbying on waste-disposal rules to defending clients charged with antitrust violations.
With business slow at home, more than 20 large American firms have opened offices in the last two years, seeking to cash in on an expected avalanche of rule-making that will inevitably accompany the European Community's plans to form a barrier-free market next year. 
 "It's part of 1992 mania," said Barry E. Hawk, head of the Brussels office of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom, the New York-based firm. "The business community discovered 1992, and then the lawyers discovered it."
The huge influx of American firms has many lawyers already worrying about a shakeout, and those worries are expected to slow the American invasion.
 
Raiding the Law Schools
 Nonetheless, the Americans have already left their fingerprints on this city's more leisurely Old World bar, which includes 3,000 Belgian lawyers and more than 200 non-Belgian firms. The high-paying American firms, for example, are bidding up salaries for young Belgian law school graduates, in some cases tripling their pay. Fearing the American behemoths, many Belgian law firms are scurrying to merge with each other or with Dutch firms to add bulk and breadth.
Working seven-day weeks to impress clients, the American firms are putting pressure on the reluctant Brussels bar to do likewise. Mr. Hawk told the story of a client who one Friday afternoon gave Skadden, Arps research to do.
"They were ecstatic when we had it finished by Monday morning," he said. "They weren't used to that, but, believe me, now they're getting used to it." The Americans are sometimes the target of ridicule, particularly for the reams of documents in which they have buried European Commission officials. In Brussels, politesse and brevity are the rule.
"A lot of people say the Americans are too brash and are dumping too much paper on people's desks," said C. Mark Nicolaides, a partner in the three-lawyer office here of Mayer, Brown & Platt of Chicago.
An example: A loan between two Belgian companies negotiated by two American law firms produced a 110-page document. The American lawyers were proud of the thoroughness of the agreement, but one Belgian client was shocked. Having expected a document of a dozen pages, it worried that the pact was too complicated and could result in excessive fees.
The Americans, along with the many new British firms here, set an aggressive tone. American lawyers think nothing of rushing off to Turkey, South Korea or India to court potential clients threatened by suits from the European Community for their trade practices.
 
Just Like the New Deal
 The new arrivals see huge opportunities as the European Commission, the community's executive branch, adopts rules in areas that had been the preserve of national governments: telecommunications, public procurement, labor relations and environmental protection. In 1970, the community's official journal of new rules was three inches thick; now, each year's edition takes up a yard of shelf space.
Some lawyers say there has not been such an outburst of rule-making since the New Deal in the United States in the 1930's, when Washington assumed broad new powers in regulating the American economy. The current shift is transforming Brussels into Europe's law-firm capital because lawyers flock to power like moths to flame.
Some Americans say Belgian law firms are rushing to wed a foreign partner before they are trampled by the invading hordes. But Carl Bevernage, president of the Flemish-speaking bar in Brussels, said the invasion might help Belgian firms because the greater the number of firms that crowd into Brussels, the more legal work will be created.
 
Ticket for Growth
 As hard times push some American firms to lay off lawyers back home, many firms see Europe as the ticket for growth. Some Belgian lawyers angrily accuse the Americans of dumping excess lawyers in Europe. But Frederick L. Lukoff, a partner in the Brussels office of Oppenheimer, Wolff & Donnelly of St. Paul, disagrees. "The idea that you invest in one place at the same time you restructure in another is not a contradiction," he said.
Many firms are playing what might be called "keeping up with the Jones, Days." Jones, Day, Reavis & Pogue, the big Cleveland-based law firm, opened here 16 months ago and has been aggressive in expanding. Its office has 13 lawyers, including 4 Belgians, 3 Italians, a German, a Frenchman and an Irishman.
Jones, Day has hired two respected antitrust lawyers who had worked at the European Commission. "We sought lawyers who had a long-established presence as opposed to merely plunking down a number of Americans," said Joseph F. Winterscheid, head of the Jones, Day office here.
The initial euphoria that American firms felt here is giving way to fears that there will be a brutal shakeout. There are more than 30 American firms in Brussels, up from 7 before 1987, as well as more than 200 non-Belgian firms, including many British, German and Dutch powerhouses.
"Over the next three years, people will realize there is not enough work to go around," said Mr. Nicolaides of Mayer, Brown.
Several firms say they are making profits, but the general consensus is that it will take most firms at least two years to break even.
The American firms are pursuing specialties. Jones, Day is concentrating on antitrust work; Akin, Gump, Strauss, Hauer & Feld of Dallas and Washington is focusing on lobbying and trade work. Mayer, Brown is specializing in work for banks, but it plans to expand into European Community regulatory law. McGuire, Woods, Battle & Boothe of Richmond opened its office here in January principally to advise one large client, the James River Corporation, also of Richmond, about the European Community's regulatory maze.
Belgian firms often complain about the starting salaries American firms pay to 25-year-old lawyers -- often $65,000 or more, at least twice what many Belgian firms pay. Belgian lawyers also say that some American lawyers acted unprofessionally when they placed advertisements to announce their arrival.
 
Lobbying Efforts Belittled
 The natives also belittle the American attempts at lobbying in Brussels. "Some people think that just because you are good at lobbying in Washington you can be good at lobbying here," said Walter W. Oberreit, a partner with the New York firm of Cleary, Gottlieb, Steen & Hamilton, which has been in Brussels since 1960. "A good Washington lawyer has been around a long time and knows the ins and outs. That person won't necessarily know all the ins and outs and all the faces in Brussels."
The levers of power work differently here than in Washington. While American agencies have a process for formal comment when they introduce new regulations, no such process exists within the community. In Washington, most lobbying is aimed at the Administration and Congress. But to influence community legislation, it might be necessary to lobby officials in the capitals of the 12 community countries and members of the European Parliament in Strasbourg, France, as well as officials from the European Commission in Brussels.
The lobbying style is also vastly different. As one American lawyer put it: "Here in Europe, it's impolite to be direct. If a client has deep concern with a proposal, you should say something like, 'We support the desire of the commission to do this, but we would invite the commission to make the following small changes.' In Washington you would say, 'The agency's action was fundamentally wrongheaded, violates the statutory intent and is wrong for the following 17 reasons.' "
