HEADLINE: A Hard Line From China On Trade

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 12

 BODY:
China faces a difficult battle in Congress this summer to retain its preferential access to the United States market, but you would hardly know it from the unconciliatory remarks being made by Chinese officials.
Ambassador Zhu Qizhen, in a speech last week outlining his Government's position in the coming debate, took a hard and at times menacing line. China has not violated any human rights, he said; it does not have a problem trade surplus with the United States, and it keeps adequate controls over its exports of arms and nuclear technology.
 
Retaliation Is Likely
 China will also use high tariffs to drive American companies out of its markets if the United States does not renew the current trade privileges, Mr. Zhu added. Billions of dollars in contracts and thousands of jobs in industries from aircraft manufacturing to agricultural chemical production would be at risk, he said. 
 Mr. Zhu's remarks were only a little more strident than other policy statements by Chinese officials. For China has pursued a pugnacious four-pronged lobbying strategy here that has dismayed its friends and gladdened its foes.
Mr. Zhu's comments were not what members of Congress had hoped to hear. The massacre at Tiananmen Square in 1989, along with reports in the last month by a human rights group and a Congessman that political prisoners are being forced to produce goods for export, have so stained the reputation of China's leadership that diplomats' assurances carry little credibility.
A growing number of American lawmakers say they want China's "most favored nation" trade status revoked outright. "The Ambassador's threats will strengthen their case," said Representative Nancy Pelosi, a California Democrat who opposes renewal unless it is linked to human rights improvements.
 
Bush Decision Due by June 3
 President Bush must notify Congress by June 3 if he wishes to renew for one year China's most-favored status, which is due to expire on July 3. A motion of disapproval, which seems likely to be introduced, would have to pass both houses of Congress within 90 days, and it probably would provoke a Presidential veto.
When President Bush renewed China's trade status last year, the House voted to disapprove the renewal. The Senate considered similar action but did not take a vote before the 90-day time limit expired, so the renewal stood.
Several lobbyists who favor renewal expect that this year President Bush will recommend a renewal of the special status, that both houses of Congress will disapprove it, and that the President will veto the disapproval. It is possible, though unlikely, that Congress will then override the veto.
Another possibility is that Congress will pair its disapproval of the status for China with approval of a renewal for the Soviet Union, said one lobbyist who favors a renewal for China. In that case, the President would face a particularly difficult dilemma, because the Soviet Union is in desperate need of certain trade subsidies and other credits that indirectly depend on a renewal of its status.
 
Tariff Would Rise to 47.48%
 The U.S.-China Business Council, a Washington-based group of American companies with investments in China, has estimated that the average tariff for the 25 biggest categories of American imports from China will rise to 47.48 percent, from 8.35 percent, if most-favored status is not renewed. With this status, Chinese products enter the United States at the lowest rate available to any American trading partner for each category of goods.
The test of China's strategy will come soon. Congress appeared increasingly likely last week to authorize the Administration to negotiate a free-trade agreement with Mexico and another round of reductions in global trade barriers. At the same time, China's trade status was moving quickly toward the top of the agendas of Washington's economic policy makers.
An eclectic alliance of trade protectionists, anti-Communist conservatives and liberal human rights advocates opposes an unconditional extension.
The strongest of China's four lobbying themes has been that Congress and the Administration should value the United States' strategic relationship with China too highly to risk endangering it for the sake of human rights or trade surpluses. President Bush, a former chief of the American liaison office in Beijing, is widely seen as particularly influenced by this argument.
 
Overestimation by Chinese
 But the Chinese consistently overestimate how much weight is given to such long-term considerations on Capitol Hill, said Warren W. Williams, the president of the American Chamber of Commerce in Hong Kong. Mr. Williams has led a delegation to lobby Washington in support of the Chinese.
"Their fundamental lack of understanding of how things work in Washington, D.C., is a continuing surprise," he said.
Another Chinese lobbying tactic is to insist that China guarantees different human rights, including rights to food and shelter, than the the United States does. American officials, by this argument, should not judge a foreign country by their own standards.
Chinese officials also criticize American trade statistics showing that China shipped $15.1 billion worth of goods to the United States last year while importing products worth only $4.8 billion. Excluding Chinese exports that pass through Hong Kong, the trade is nearly in balance, Mr. Zhu contended. But this argument has not been persuasive in Washington, Mr. Williams said.
 
Attempt to Intimidate U.S.
 The last of China's four approaches to lobbying in Washington has been intimidation. "I have a fondness for the American people," Mr. Zhu said after his speech on Tuesday. "I really don't want to see West German or Japanese people there, taking over."
Business conditions for Americans in China are said to be deteriorating already. For three weeks, Chinese negotiators have been stalling in contract talks with American companies, said an American businessman with extensive contacts there, who spoke on condition that he not be identified. He said the Chinese negotiators were acting on Government instructions.
But in a possible change of tack, the New China News Agency said Saturday that China would send a buying mission to the United States, Reuters reported.
Some people in Washington question the credibility of Chinese threats to exclude American businesses and products. "They may not love capitalism; they may not love human rights, but they love money," Representative Pelosi said.

HEADLINE: Bush Cool to Having Gorbachev at Economic Meeting, Officials Say

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 12

 BODY:
President Bush is reluctant to grant President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's request to observe an economic conference of the seven leading industrial countries in London this summer, but is moving toward agreeing to a visit to Moscow late in June, officials said today.
Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev discussed both questions on Saturday during a 45-minute telephone call that Mr. Bush placed to Moscow from Camp David, Md., the officials said. 
 The call was part of increasingly complicated diplomatic maneuvers as the United States and the Soviet Union try to resolve arms-control disputes, schedule the much-delayed 1991 summit meeting, deal with Moscow's requests for economic assistance and lay the groundwork for moving forward in their overall relationship.
Administration officials said Mr. Bush had been troubled by the disputes over arms control and by what some of his advisers saw as a Soviet drift toward more authoritarian policies.
But they said the President was eager to help Mr. Gorbachev with his political and economic problems, and was especially inclined to find a way to meet with Mr. Gorbachev before the end of June and to grant the Soviet leader's request for $1.5 billion in guaranteed agricultural loans.
During the conversation on Saturday, Mr. Bush told Mr. Gorbachev that he would send a delegation of agricultural and economics expets to Moscow to help the Soviets find ways to alleviate food shortages and to search for ways to give Moscow financial aid.
"We have to find out what the basic problem is," a senior official said today, "and then, would food aid from abroad help?"
 
Seven-Nation Meeting
 Mr. Gorbachev raised the possibility of his going to London in July for the annual meeting of the so-called G-7, the seven most powerful industrial countries -- the United States, Canada, Britain, France, Germany, Italy and Japan. Mr. Bush did not reply, officials said today.
"We have mixed feelings about Gorbachev going to London," the senior official said. "We are very reluctant to agree to having him as an observer to the whole meeting, and I don't think that's in the cards."
But the official said the United States could support a plan under which Mr. Gorbachev would go to London to meet with the seven nations' leaders outside the formal conference framework. "The idea is to get him involved in a way that acquaints him with the international economic system, processes and so on, but doesn't bring him into the G-7," he said.
Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev said last year that they would hold another summit meeting in 1991 in Moscow, and the original date was to have been early in January. Mr. Bush postponed it because of the Persian Gulf crisis, arms-control disputes with Moscow and the Kremlin's crackdown in the Baltic republics.
The arms-control disputes center on American charges that the Soviet Union is cheating on a treaty reducing non-nuclear forces in Central Europe that was signed last November. The two sides are also at odds over the details of another treaty that would reduce long-range nuclear weapons.
For some time, American officials have said both problems must be cleared up before Mr. Bush will agree to the Moscow summit meeting, which was to have centered on the signing of the new nuclear weapons treaty.
But the United States and the Soviet Union have been maneuvering toward a compromise, and officials today said Mr. Bush was increasingly eager to find a way to hold the meeting. One approach, officials said, would be to drop the "arms control" umbrella for the meeting and discuss other issues.
"We're clearly more disposed toward a summit," an official said, "and we'll probably go in the third or fourth week of June. It will be just a summit for the sake of a summit. The President has already made clear that he's willing to meet irrespective of the types of agreements that may or may not be reached."
Officials here said that the United States was counting heavily on the visit this week by Gen. Mikhail Moiseyev, the chief of the Soviet General Staff. American officials are hoping he will bring a new proposal to end the deadlock on the conventional arms treaty.
Sergei Grigoryev, a Gorbachev spokesman, appearing on the ABC News program "This Week," said today, "I don't have a date, but I guess that in summer we will definitely have a summit.
"The feeling is that President Bush is expected in Moscow, to come and sign a treaty," he said.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Long-Term Interest Rates Resist Downward Pressure

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
After 10 months of recession, long-term interest rates remain stubbornly high, and a number of credit market analysts are beginning to wonder whether bond yields may have reached a trough in February, when they briefly dipped below 8 percent.
Persistently high long-term rates must be a source of concern at the Federal Reserve, which has aggressively pushed down short-term rates but has virtually no power to influence the direction of long-term bond yields. And as long as these bond rates remain high, recovery in important sectors like housing and capital spending will be muted or delayed. 
 Historically, bond yields tend to fall roughly one to four months after recessions bottom out, said Alan Sinai, president of Boston Company Economic Advisors Inc.
"It is conceivable that we have seen the lows in long-term rates," Mr. Sinai said, "but bond yields are typically stubborn in response to recession. That is particularly true in the United States, where we tend to be inflation prone."
Bond market participants reaffirmed their fear of inflation on Friday when they generated a fierce sell-off that pushed bond yields above 8.30 percent for the first time since early December.
The rise in long-term rates widened the gap between yields on two-year Treasury notes, which have declined in response to the Fed's moves, and those on 30-year bonds. The gap now is just under 1.50 percentage points. That is the widest difference, or spread, since 1985, analysts at the Wells Fargo Bank said.
The rise in long-term rates came despite a report from the Government showing that producer prices, excluding food and energy, rose by a modest two-tenths of a percent in April, the same rate of increase recorded in March.
The report was in line with market expectations, but was not persuasive enough for traders to want to hold on to huge amounts of Treasury securities accumulated at last week's spring refunding auctions.
"Bond market participants need a lot of information before they can be persuaded that inflation is coming down," Mr. Sinai said. "The history is that even as many as three good monthly reports are generally not enough."
Mr. Sinai and others say that they are convinced that more good inflation numbers are coming and that bond yields will fall in late summer.
Even if inflationary pressures do abate, analysts say that the ever-increasing load of new Treasury debt in coming months may in and of itself be sufficient to prevent long-term rates from falling.
Last week's $37 billion refunding was a record, but analysts said that because of the recession Treasury borrowing needs in the third and fourth quarters were likely to total some $200 billion.
 
'Dominant' Supply Aspect
 "The supply aspect is becoming dominant, and the prospect for the second half of the year is staggering," said Norman Robertson, chief economist at the Mellon National Bank in Pittsburgh. "It is getting harder to see a significant drop in bond yields as long as we experience these demands from the Treasury."
Steven A. Wood, director of financial markets research at the Bank of America, said: "I don't think the market has really focused on the extent of the supply that is coming. But over the next four to five months it will be a real tough chew."
Aside from the bill auctions, credit market participants do not have to worry about placing new Treasury debt this week. Instead, the focus will be on a slew of economic reports for April, beginning with industrial production data that the Fed is expected to release today. Data on retail sales and housing starts are also expected to be released this week.
 
Further Decline Seen
 In general, economists said the figures might dispel the notion that the economy is clawing its way out of recession. "I don't think we have hit bottom yet," said Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst at the Chase Manhattan Corporation. "I think the economy will decline for a few more months. And there is some risk that it could last longer than that."
For the bond market, the week's most important set of statistics is likely to come tomorrow, when consumer price data for April are expected. Few analysts are forecasting a repetition of the March report, when consumer prices declined by one-tenth of a percentage point. But most expect the figures will provide additional evidence that price pressures are moderating.
Mr. Fine and others project that the Consumer Price Index will show a rise of two-tenths of a percentage point for April, and a like amount once food and energy prices are excluded.
Given that the Federal Reserve cut the discount rate and reduced the overnight Federal funds rate another notch late last month, the Fed's policy-making Open Market Committee, which is scheduled to meet tomorrow, is not expected to take any important action, many analyst say.
"If I were advising the Fed, the only thing I would tell them is to keep their powder dry," said Mr. Wood of the Bank of America. "We have already seen that pushing down the funds rate is not going to bring bond yields down with it."

HEADLINE: First U.S. Troops Arrive in Bangladesh to Begin Large-Scale Relief Effort

BYLINE: By DAVID BINDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 12

 BODY:
A team of about 64 marines and Army Special Forces troops flew from Okinawa to Bangladesh today to begin preparing for a large-scale American relief effort in the cyclone-battered country.
The team is the vanguard of a disaster relief force of nearly 8,000 dispatched by the United States military on Saturday to aid survivors, ferry food and clothing by helicopter and set up water-purification centers. 
 A total of 4,660 marines and 3,000 sailors are due off the coast of Bangladesh by Wednesday aboard eight ships of a Navy amphibious group headed by the assault vessel Tarawa, the military said. Among them are Navy construction teams, known as Seabees.
The amphibious force was on its way back to California from the Persian Gulf, where it had been dispatched in early December to take part in the war against Iraq. It was never ordered into combat, said Lieut. Col. Thomas J. Boyd of the Air Force, who is a spokesman of the Pacific Comnmand.
 
Helicopters on the Way
 Colonel Boyd said a C-5 Galaxy transport plane had taken off from Hawaii carrying five Army UH-60 Blackhawk helicopters and 56 crew members and was due in Dhaka, the Bangladeshi capital, on Monday. In addition, several four-member teams of Air Force air-traffic controllers have been sent to Dhaka and members of an Army engineer battalion already working on public works projects in Bangladesh will be incorporated in the operations.
The spokesman said the amphibious vessels carried four types of helicopters for carrying food and medical supplies to people isolated on islands in the Bay of Bengal by the huge tides unleashed during the cyclone on April 30. They range from the CH-53 Sea Stallions and CH-46 Sea Knights to smaller UH-1N Iroquois and AH-1T Cobras.
Al Panico, director of international relief and development for the American Red Cross, said the effort represented a shift in United States Government disaster assistance policy. He said in an interview that in the past aid was usually confined to credits and funds provided to private relief agencies and occasionally included provision of air transport.
"Frankly, they didn't do it before," Mr. Pacino said. "Relief consisted of credits, food supplies, funds and 10 to 20 advisers. Nothing this massive. What is now changing, in northern Iraq and Bangladesh, is sending the military to provide some relief directly. When the military gets a mission, it's awesome. They have orders, command, resources, planes. Others wouldn't do it as fast. I think that's great."
Tom Drahman, director for Asia of CARE in New York, who testified here last week before a House committee on Bangladesh's special need for helicopter transport ships, said of the military relief effort: "We think this is very, very positive. These things can be used. This is a massive problem. It's not going to be solved overnight."
CARE has distributed plastic sheeting for shelter, five days' supplies of rice and molasses, and water supplies together with decontamination tablets to a total of more than 200,000 people in Bangladesh, he said.
Bangladesh officials now estimate that 138,000 people have died as a result of the cyclone and its aftermath.
Mr. Drahman noted that because of the vulnerability of Bangladesh to cyclones, its Government, CARE and relief organizations had positioned emergency supplies "with a very long shelf life" as part of a disaster preparedness strategy at various sites around the country. The problem now, he said, was to move those supplies to people in need.
"Transport, communications and the awful weather -- those are the major problems," he said. "I have been able to speak just twice to Bangladesh on the telephone." It is unclear how much the American military relief effort may cost. The United States has already contributed $7.2 million in assistance and is scheduled to redirect another $2 million already planned for Bangladesh for disaster aid.
 
Officers Plan Campaign
DHAKA, Bangladesh, May 12 (AP) -- A half-dozen American military officers plan to visit Chittagong on Monday to see whether the cyclone-shattered seaport can accommodate their fleet and to start figuring out how best to deploy their troops.
"We've got equipment here to make pure water out of salt water, out of contaminated water," said Maj. Dave Sebastian of the Marines. "We can take almost mud and make it drinkable."
Major Sebastian, a 39-year-old engineer from Orlando, Fla., said the marines would probably set up several water-purification points close to food distribution centers established by foreign and local relief teams along the coutry's badly damaged southeastern coast.
The advance team that arrived today from Okinawa is under the command of Maj. Gen. Henry Stackpole of the Marines. He spent the day conferring with Bangladeshi Government leaders and American Embassy officials.
Another flight from Okinawa was expected to reach Dhaka tonight, carrying about 30 more engineers and communications personnel. Also on the flights were medics who will try to keep the task force from getting sick.
The area where the task force will be working is a nightmare of health hazards. The diarrhea ravaging flood survivors, especially babies and small children, can be fatal because of the rapid dehydration it induces.
Bangladeshi relief workers have already warned of the danger of a cholera epidemic.
 
New Cyclone Is Feared
DHAKA, Bangladesh, May 12 (Reuters) -- Weather officials reported the threat of a new cyclone today. They said a low depression in the Andaman Sea, 800 miles south of Chittagong, could turn into a new storm that might hit the country in the next two days.
"We don't want to take any chances," said Abdur Rub Khan, an official in Chittagong. "We have told people to stay alert."
Finance Minister Saifur Rahman said that the first cyclone cost Bangladesh $3 billion in economic losses and that nearly four million people had been made virtually destitute.
The Dhaka weather office said rivers all over the country were still rising.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Officials in storm-ravaged Bangladesh estimate that eight milion people face serious health problems and food shortages. Survivors on Hatiya Island waited for relief supplies to be distributed. (Agence France-Press)

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 2; National Desk

HEADLINE: Economic Pulse; The Southwest - a special report.;
Far From an Arid Economy, Desert States Thrive

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PHOENIX

 BODY:
The Phoenician Hotel, where there is not much of a waiting list for its $4,000-a-night suites, stands in suburban Scottsdale in all its ostentatious splendor, a glittering monument to the savings and loan debacle, a hangover from the reckless building spree of the 1980's.
In a city that once knew no limits, perhaps 3 of every 10 offices now sit empty. Housing prices are flat. 
 But nothing, it seems, can stop growth in the desert. Indeed, the excesses of the past could seed an even more abundant future as the building glut provides a fast and relatively inexpensive way for more companies and people to claim stakes amid the cactus. In the past year, Arizona, the 24th-largest state, jumped from 35th to 7th in the rate of creating jobs.
The growth here and in Nevada, Utah and New Mexico is a testament to the drawing power of the American desert, a region that thrives as a terminus, and often a turnstile, for people looking for a new start, another roll of the dice. It has become the new California, a place where palm trees and the desert still beckon dreamers.
Even in the depths of the real estate crisis in parts of the region, jobs and people continued to increase. And today, this land of the sun, sand and mesquite has become even more attractive.
The sharpest growth is occurring in Nevada, which has led the nation in employment and population growth for five consecutive years. Utah climbed to sixth in job creation last year, and sees rosier prospects on the horizon. Even New Mexico, one of the poorest states in the country, outpaced the national average in job growth in 1990.
"Businesses today have a lot more freedom about where they want to locate," especially the high-technology companies, said Phillip Burgess, president of the Center for the New West, a research organization. "And employers who need to recruit highly educated technical specialists are going to have a lot more luck convincing somebody to come to the desert. It's simply where people want to be."
But growth does not come without pain, and there are already signs that this region will have to work harder in the 90's to achieve the growth rate of the 80's. In Nevada, there was some slowing in the rate last year, and a shortage of water could be stifling.
Traffic has begun to grow wearisome around Phoenix, and more cars mean more pollution. And the low tax rates throughout the desert, which drew so many migrants, could ultimately prove to be a mirage. With dwindling treasuries and rising costs associated with growth, these states are now considering what had been a taboo: raising taxes.
 
Migration
A Swift Stream Of Californians
For generations, the lifeblood of the desert has been migration, and most of this growth has come from the Midwest and East. But in recent years, a bigger share has come from California, where high costs have been pushing people to bargains in nearby states.
"We think of ourselves very much as an extension of Southern California," said Lee McPhetters, the associate dean in the College of Business at Arizona State University in Tempe. "Ten years ago, there was an aversion to that. But so many of the people in the desert are from somewhere else themselves -- 25 percent of the people in Arizona weren't here a decade ago -- that people don't throw up barriers against 'outsiders' coming in."
Bill Hunter, a regional credit manager for Reynolds Metals, which moved its credit office from Southern California to Scottsdale last August, said: "The noise, the traffic, the crime -- it's just getting to be too much in California. And in Arizona, you can get more house for half the money."
Even places like St. George, a growing city of 28,000 in southwestern Utah, counts about 1,000 new settlers from California in the past year.
Some of the Californians, called "equity migrants," have sold homes for $500,000 or more and find much cheaper replacements in the desert. Ray Jones, the vice president of a civil engineering company in Las Vegas, sold his home in Orange County for $1.3 million and bought a house in Nevada for $400,000.
How do the houses compare? "The one in Las Vegas is much nicer," he said.
 
Haven for the Rich
 More than a generation ago, the artist Georgia O'Keeffe was drawn to New Mexico by its haunting beauty. Now Sante Fe is a haven for the rich, famous and creative. The actor Val Kilmer, the contemporary artist Bruce Naumann and others have recently become residents of Sante Fe.
The state has grown, as well, with the influx of people drawn by the natural beauty who "telecommute" to offices in faraway big cities. Dick Spray, an executive with a golf course design company in California, uses a computer and fax machine to communicate with his office while he works in an adobe house overlooking Taos Valley.
"My office is 10 feet from my bed," said Mr. Spray, who moved to Taos two years ago from the San Francisco area. "The fax machine made this whole adventure viable for me."
Throughout the desert, the population tends to be younger than elsewhere around the country, despite an image of the desert states' being filled with retirees content in the warm, gentle breezes.
In part, the population in desert states has stayed young because many here, among them American Indians, Hispanic people and Mormons, have relatively high birth rates. Arizona, for example, has a median age slightly below the national average of 33.
"In general, people who move tend to be younger, between 25 and 35, because they don't have the established ties," said Steve Happel, a professor of economics at Arizona State University. "And they're more likely to be looking for changes in their lives."
The migration to the desert differs in another important way. In most parts of the country, people follow jobs. In the desert region, with its stunning beauty and sunshine that accommodates tennis players 300 days a year, people often move first and find a job later.
"People in other parts of the country get discouraged and call U-Haul," said Jerry Jordan, chief economist for First Interstate Bancorp, which is based in Los Angeles but has underwritten much of the recent construction in the desert region. "They figure, 'If I've got to live in a tent, I might as well live someplace nice.' "
 
Real Estate
Early to Fall, Early to Rise
The overbuilding boom of the mid-1980's, and the savings and loan collapse that followed, were especially dramatic in Arizona, New Mexico and Utah. Developers built here for the same reason that Willie Sutton robbed banks: This was where the money was.
But the building craze, which was fed by the 1981 Federal tax law that made real estate investment hugely profitable, came to a halt with the Tax Reform Act of 1986 and the evaporation of capital.
The grandiose Phoenician Hotel, built by Charles H. Keating's now-failed Lincoln Savings and Loan of Irvine, Calif., became a symbol of this intoxicating time for builders and, when it was taken over by Government savings and loan regulators, a symbol of the boom going bust.
Since 1987, 10 of 11 savings and loans in Arizona have failed.
 
Seeing the Light
 In some ways, the real estate collapse here in the late 1980's was a harbinger for the slide in New York, Boston and other cities in the Northeast.
"We've already been through what is now occurring in New York, Boston and elsewhere," said Kelly Matthews, an economist at First Security Corporation in Salt Lake City. "We've turned the corner on our real estate problems."
Indeed, the desert states fared much better in construction employment last year than the nation as a whole, which saw a drop of 8.6 percent in building jobs.
Utah had a 6.3 percent increase in construction jobs last year. Construction employment in Nevada slowed a bit, but still grew by 4.6 percent. Arizona and New Mexico lost construction jobs last year, but at a rate of only about 1 percent.
In some important ways, the savings and loan crisis will end up helping the economies of places like Phoenix, where overbuilding has left a surfeit of relatively cheap office space. While that surplus is bad news for landholders -- in many cases, the Federal receivers now running the holdings of bankrupt financial institutions -- it is good news for companies seeking to move.
"When we come out of this recession, and companies start to grow again, these cheaper rents are going to make places like Phoenix very attractive," said Edward Hill, a professor of economics at Cleveland State University. "In a sense, it's the taxpayers' money that will help make Phoenix more competitive."
 
'Cold Water' in Nevada
 Nevada escaped the building glut, in large part, because it grew so fast that builders could scarcely keep pace. While construction foundered elsewhere, many building trades workers and laborers flocked to Las Vegas, drawn by work on the new Mirage and Excalibur casinos and a flurry of home building.
Now some have been idled, as the pace of building in Nevada has slowed. Lenders, wary of the building spree of Arizona, have "thrown cold water" on the real estate market there, said Mr. Jordan, the economist with First Interstate Bancorp.
"We've got some men who are waiting for work," said George Dunckhurst, president of the Laborers Union 872 in Las Vegas. "We've got a waiting list of about nine pages, with about 39 workers to a page."
The lending crunch, as developers call it, has delayed several projects in Las Vegas. "As a consequence, we've got a lot of pent-up demand for homes," said Glenn Barton, manager of the Las Vegas division of the Meyers Group, a real estate consulting company.
That demand has helped pushed up housing prices in Nevada. In Las Vegas, for example, the median price of a home has risen to $123,000, from $105,000, in two years. In Phoenix, meanwhile, the median-price home is about $84,000, and people are fortunate if it has increased in value. In the late 1980's, housing prices fell as much as 30 percent.
"People aren't playing the speculation game here anymore," said Jeff Burt, vice president of the Greater Phoenix Economic Council, a group that recruits new businesses. "They're buying homes because they represent good values, and because they've got some long-term interests here. And that's much healthier for our region."
 
Tourism
Work and Play Under the Sun
The economy of the Southwest, it was once said, rested on the four "C's": copper, cattle, cotton and climate.
Before air-conditioning, the desert sun was a curse. But as more and more Americans choose to work and live where they can also play, the desert climate has generated far more dollars than the other three C's put together.
Few regions can compete with the desert states for sightseeing and recreation, from year-round sunshine to all-night slot machines. It is a factor that already tips the scales in the recruiting efforts of many companies, and it will grow more important.
As members of the baby-boom generation grow older, they are reaching the time of life when their salaries are highest and, with children reaching adulthood, their financial responsibilities are largely satisfied. The result is more money and time for leisure.
The beauty of the Grand Canyon, Carlsbad Caverns and Zion National Park have been drawing tourists, and their money, for generations. More recently, a growing chunk has been spent at the gaming tables in Nevada.
 
The Lure of Las Vegas
 Tourism in the desert region generated $23.3 billion last year, up significantly from the $13.1 billion in 1984. In Nevada, tourism accounts for a whopping 80 percent of revenue. Nationally, tourism accounts for about 6.7 percent of the gross national product; in the desert, tourism represents nearly 19 percent of the economy's revenues.
Some economists once speculated that Las Vegas would suffer if the rest of the country legalized gambling. But people can now gamble in Deadwood, S.D., Atlantic City, on a riverboat on the Mississippi River or stay at home and play the state lottery. The explosion in gambling has only heightened the attraction of Las Vegas.
"It's allowed Las Vegas to say, 'Hey, gambling isn't so bad, you have it in your hometown,' " said Bill Thompson, a professor of management at the University of Nevada-Las Vegas and an expert on the economics of gaming. "It's really stimulated an interest in gambling. And Las Vegas is the capital, the mecca, so people want to come here."
But far from the casinos of Las Vegas, the desert region is profiting on its tourist attractions. Salt Lake City is competing for the 1998 Winter Olympics. And places like Sante Fe, the 17th-fastest growing metropolitan region in the nation, have cashed in on the surrounding beauty and cultural offerings.
 
Limits
Foundations To Be Built
"The great playground of the white American," D. H. Lawrence once called the Southwest.
Not everyone in the desert is pleased that the region has become such a magnet. They see elements of class and race exploitation.
In some cases, the arrival of affluent newcomers has pushed rents beyond the reach of the Indians and Hispanic people who have lived there for generations. And newcomers are not always tolerant of the native ways. In Taos County, for example, affluent newcomers have sought to close a molybdenum mine, fearing that it damages the environment. They were less concerned about the paychecks of the hundreds of Hispanic workers whose ancestors also toiled in the mines.
"The Southwest has become a commodity to be bought and sold," said Joseph C. Wilder, director of the Southwest Center, a research unit at the University of Arizona. "It's a place that's easily romanticized."
During the whirlwind of the 1980's here, planning for the future did not usually mean preparing for the next decade, or even the next year. More often, it meant next Tuesday. But economists say that lack of planning may limit growth in the future.
"We have enough buildings for this millennium," said Mr. Jordan, the economist with First Interstate Bancorp, "but we have neglected the infrastructure, water, sewer, education, and it could put a cap on growth."
 
Dread of New Taxes
 The relatively low level of taxes attracted many people and companies to the desert. But the tax base did not keep up with growth, and now the desert states are struggling to provide services with dwindling coffers.
Every state in the desert region has discussed raising taxes. But since that might discourage newcomers, the governments are groping for more innovative, and less painful, ways to pay the bills. In Arizona, for example, many governmental services have been turned over to private companies in the belief that they can do more with less public money. But it will not be easy.
"If you don't put enough money into schools, for example, some people are going to decide not to move to Arizona," Mr. Jordan said.
In recent years, the desert economy has moved toward greater diversification, but it is still vulnerable.
In New Mexico, about 15 percent of paychecks are drawn on the Federal Government, much of them for military and energy research. While economists there say the research-oriented Government work will probably be spared in military cutbacks, it is by no means a certainty.
And the growth in Las Vegas, which depends on a single industry, has no guarantee of security.
"Las Vegas isn't exactly a one-industry town, but it comes pretty close," said R. Keith Schwer, director of the Center of Business and Economic Research at the University of Nevada-Las Vegas. "If New Orleans or Florida should legalize gambling, then we could be in serious trouble."
But economists generally foresee long and strong growth for the desert states. As Elliot Pollack, president of Epic Enterprises, a real estate consulting company in Phoenix, put it: "If a company is going to pick a city for a new office, do you think they'll pick someplace like Boston, which is fairly staid, or Arizona, which has had 100 years of strong growth, and prospects for more?"

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Special Report

HEADLINE: The Editorial Notebook;
The New Prague Spring

BYLINE: By JACK ROSENTHAL

DATELINE: PRAGUE

 BODY:
The raw new politics of free Czechoslovakia are contained by the magisterial stature of a president who transcends politics. Chalked on a wall on Zatecka Street is a heart, containing the words "Vaclav Havel." Is there another country in the world where a political leader enjoys such popularity? The raw new economic freedoms, meanwhile, seem to be popping out everywhere.
A story told at dinner: How are things going in the former Soviet satellite countries compared with the Soviet Union? Ivan Lamper, editor of Respekt, a leading political journal, answers with a story. Two travelers, one in Paris and one in Moscow, set off by plane for the other capital. Bad weather forces both planes to land in Warsaw. When the travelers get off, they both think they have reached their final destination. 
 Prague, too, may look like Paris to a Soviet traveler; but to a Western visitor, it doesn't look like Moscow at all, most of all because it seems to brim with anxious optimism.
An emigre's view: Jiri Horak left for New York when the Communists took over in 1948 and established himself as a political scientist. In 1989, he came back to help re-establish the Social Democratic Party, which he now chairs. One way that things have changed: "In the past, every Czech wanted to be a musician. Now everyone wants to be an entrepreneur."
A street scene in Prague: "Look at that!" On a busy downtown street, a young American woman who has been teaching in Czechoslovakia since last fall rushes with astonishment to a vendor's stand labeled "Kelly Fruit." Not for months has she seen such produce: Avocados! Artichokes! Mangoes, selling for 150 crowns, or about $5.
Suddenly, a little old lady in a blue hat interrupts. "Oh, no! Too expensive!" she exclaims in German. "Yes, they have these things now, but who can afford them? This is what ordinary people can afford." She presses her thumb over the zero in "150" -- and a dozen passers-by stop and applaud. A small, neat market metaphor. Goods long dreamed of are available but few can pay the price.
Another street scene in Prague: Dozens of electric trams clatter past, all painted drab beige and maroon. Then, with a clang, another one passes in a streak of color. It is painted entirely in shocking pink except for the slash of stylish black script that proclaims "Minolta."
A store scene in Prague: One byproduct of the new freedoms felt since the Velvet Revolution is pornography, long forbidden. Now, a bookstore on smart Pariecka Street displays, next to a "Tom a Jerry" book, a new translation of the old classic: "Fanny Hillova, Memoary Kurtizany." Skin magazines are sold on street corners and lurid pin-ups appear even in shops staffed by women. Don't they object? "Well," says one female clerk with an effort to be understanding, "it was illegal for so long."
A store scene in Bratislava: In the Prior department store, a resident notices two dramatic changes. Where once there were bare pipes and drab lighting now there are posters, plastic flowers and streamers. The other change is on the shelves. They sport, for instance, six feet of "Milford Tea" and three of "Pril," an Austrian dishwashing liquid. The displays probably contain the entire stock -- but that's surely more appealing than shelves that stay empty because there's nothing to put on them.
A street scene in Bratislava: On a main street, whose stores include two fashionable jewelers, pedestrians recoil from two burly men in black uniforms and boots, packing billy clubs and two-way radios and accompanied by a big black dog on a chain. Who are these men? Some sort of secret police?
"Oh, no, they're not political," says a politician. "They're what we call 'black sheriffs.' With the start of private ownership, there's been more crime. So owners hire these people. Like security guards. Like America."

HEADLINE: Chastise China; Don't Isolate It

 BODY:
By June 3, President Bush must tell Congress whether he wants China's "most favored nation" trading privileges extended for another year. Congress has three months to weigh any such request. At stake are billions in commerce, a million jobs in China and thousands in the U.S.
America has nothing to gain from inflicting economic harm on China or reducing its trade. But this yearly decision on trade privileges gives Washington its best opportunity to exert leverage on human rights, arms sales and other issues. The ideal way to use that leverage now would be a conditional renewal, making future trade relations turn on China's willingness to respond to specific U.S. concerns. 
 China has, in fact, responded to some concerns expressed in last year's trade debate. Most of the Chinese imprisoned for taking part in the 1989 Democracy Movement have now been brought to trial, as Americans demanded. Chinese courts imposed long sentences simply for advocating basic freedoms, sentences now being served under extremely harsh conditions. Yet by Chinese standards, punishment was relatively lenient. Recently, a few high-visibility prisoners have been released.
Even so, China's hard-line leaders continue to misread Western attitudes and act in ways that seem calculated to provoke trade retaliation. They export missiles and nuclear technology in violation of their own past pledges. They promote the use of prison labor to produce low-cost exports -- a practice they now promise to cease. They blatantly violate computer software copyrights, asserting that being underdeveloped entitles them to do so. Such methods have helped push the U.S. trade deficit with China to $15 billion.
These provocations might justify revoking the special waiver that allows China to enjoy most-favored-nation privileges despite its failure to qualify as a market economy or as a country permitting free emigration. Alternatively, some in Congress now propose rigid conditions that, realistically, China could not be expected to meet.
Such actions would indeed punish China's leadership. They would also inflict serious economic damage on the Chinese economy, particularly to the special economic zones along the south China coast opposite Hong Kong and Taiwan.
But that's just the problem. Punishing the neo-Stalinist octogenarians now dominant in Beijing won't loosen their grip. But they will, inevitably, pass from the scene, and the last thing the U.S. should do pending a succession crisis is weaken market-oriented regions and personalities by a period of enforced economic isolation.
Mr. Bush and Congress have a better alternative. They can approve renewal -- but attach provisions requiring that when the next 12-month period expires the President report to Congress on Beijing's performance in the areas of trade-law infringements, weapons proliferation, free emigration, prison labor and political imprisonment, and base his 1992 recommendation on this performance.
Even if the President's 1992 report showed disappointing Chinese performance, Mr. Bush could still recommend a further renewal of trade privileges. But he would have to justify that in an election year.
China is flouting U.S. law and values and that warrants a sharp rebuke. But to cut off trade would be to put today's desire for emotional satisfaction ahead of tomorrow's hope for substantive change. Renewal of the agreement, with a reporting requirement, is the better choice.

HEADLINE: HORSE RACING;
Owners Gain an Inside Track

BYLINE: By JOSEPH DURSO

 BODY:
It has been 13 years since a horse won the Triple Crown, with Affirmed prevailing in three stirring duels against Alydar, who lost the Kentucky Derby by a neck, the Preakness by a nose and the Belmont Stakes by an eyebrow.
Now, six months after Alydar died at the age of 15, renowned as the race horse who would not surrender, only one horse in America has a chance to win the Triple Crown in 1991: a son of Alydar named Strike the Gold. 
 To his public, Strike the Gold is the colt who dethroned last year's juvenile champion, Fly So Free. To his trainer, Nick Zito, he is "a horse of destiny."
To his owners, three New York businessmen and golfing partners led by B. Giles Brophy, Strike the Gold is the principal resource in a world that is relatively new to them.
In fact, Strike the Gold's entourage is riding what seems to be the wave of the future in racing: outsiders who invest in horses and also race them. And like Thomas Valando, a music publisher who owns Fly So Free, and Carl Icahn, a financier who owns Meadow Star, Brophy personifies these new horsemen; he is a salesman of Holstein cattle and Government securities who now has a share of the hottest horse in the 3-year-old classics.
Strike the Gold carried his three owners one-third of the way toward their ultimate goal when he won the Kentucky Derby on May 4. He will aim for the second part of the crown next Saturday when he runs in the Preakness at Pimlico Race Course in Maryland.
And, if he is still striding toward the goal that eluded his distinguished sire by inches, he will face the final test three weeks later in the mile-and-a-half Belmont.
"Alydar changed the whole picture as a sire," trainer Scotty Schulhofer said the other day at the Belmont barn of Fly So Free, who twice in the last month lost crucial races to the son of Alydar.
One man who could not agree more is Brophy, who with his partners bought Strike the Gold last year from Calumet Farm about four months before Alydar died. Brophy's partners are William J. Condren, an investor in real estate and oil and a part owner of the sprinter Housebuster, and Joseph M. Cornacchia, a publisher of games like Trivial Pursuit and other blockbusters.
"Everybody has a place in the universe," Brophy said recently. "But they haven't found the spot in the universe for Alydar. You saw him battle Affirmed, stride for stride, without being defeated mentally. And that's what is special about Strike the Gold. They don't make any more Alydars."
When he isn't poring over pedigree charts or performance charts, Brophy is poring over economic charts, either in his office on East 57th Street in Manhattan, in his homes on Fifth Avenue and in Palm Beach, Fla., and Westhampton, L.I., or on his cattle and horse farm in Yorktown Heights in Westchester County.
 
Canyons of Finance
 Brophy is a stocky 53-year-old New Yorker with close wavy hair and blue eyes and a forceful manner, and he gives the distinct impression that not much happens to him by chance. He was raised in Bay Shore, L.I., studied at Hofstra University, earned a graduate degree in business at New York University and headed straight into the canyons of finance.
But Brophy's life changed when he headed into the canyons of raising cattle and buying race horses.
It seems indisputable that Giles Brophy has the golden touch, and some people even suggest he has the flair for executing business coups with the best of them. He laughed at the thought the other day, saying:
"I'm no wheeler-dealer. I'm a pretty conservative guy. If I were scouting myself, I'd say, 'He's persistent, intense about the things he wants to do.' They wrote in my yearbook at Bay Shore High, 'Patience is a virtue not oft deterred.' Was it fair? I have no idea. I didn't know what they were getting at. But let's hope it keeps up."
He is persistent and intense, all right and in business and finance, he has built a track record for dash that even his famous horse might envy.
 
Flip of the Coin
 In 1960, for example, he "decided to go into the securities business," so he flipped a coin to see if he would take a job at Citibank or United States Trust. Citibank won the toss. Later, he founded the securities company of Brophy Gestal Knight & Company and built it into a winner as an institutional bond house. Three years ago, he sold it to the Sanwa Bank of Japan.
"Then I went to Florida and took six or seven months off," he said. "But then I wanted to get back to work. So, I set up another securities firm. I had sold my name along with the firm to the Japanese, so I called the new company Giles Securities.
"This was last year, and by then I was spending a lot of my time with my horses. Animals were always important to me. When I was a kid, I wanted to be a veterinarian. Later, I got into the cattle business, around 1973, registered Holsteins, raised them on my 250-acre farm in Yorktown Heights.
"Horses? I got interested in them once when my wife and I were hunting bear and moose in Alaska. I decided I better learn to ride a horse to mount the hills. So, I bought a jumper for myself and one for my wife. Got into steeplechase riding. And, in 1984, race horses."
But as with his Government bonds and Holstein cattle, the race horses were ones with pedigrees. His first coup was Thirty-Six Red, a son of Slew o' Gold, who won the Gotham and the Wood Memorial in New York last year. But Brophy and Zito were disappointed when the colt ran eighth in the Kentucky Derby, so they promised to take the Blue Grass route to Kentucky next time they had a Derby horse.
They didn't have to wait long. One day last summer, Brophy was approached by Condren, his longtime golfing friend from the Deepdale Club and National Golf Links on Long Island, who proposed pooling their interests with Condren's friend Cornacchio. And while each man kept separate interests in some horses, they formed a partnership to buy and race some others, and naturally struck gold.
Brophy and Zito pored over bloodlines and decided to buy five fillies and one colt from Calumet Farm. Then one day Zito telephoned to warn Brophy that a colt he was training was going to be auctioned in January as part of a dispersal sale by Calumet. The colt was Strike the Gold, a son of Alydar, and Brophy wrote a check "in the low seven-figures" and bought all seven young horses.
So, now he is two races away from making history. Can Strike the Gold go on and win the Triple Crown?
"Very definitely," he said, defending his own unique horse. "Remember who his father was."

HEADLINE: U.S. Sees Trade as Spur

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 13

 BODY:
International trade will continue to stimulate global economic growth, but at a slower rate this year before picking up momentum in 1992, the Bush Administration said today.
"World trade growth should continue to run at its historical rate of just over twice the pace of output growth, or 2.5 percent in 1991 and around 5.5 percent in 1992," it said in its "Annual Trade Projection Report to Congress." 
 "Thus, international trade will remain an important source of stimulus and support for output growth," it added.
The Administration is counting on demand for American goods by overseas nations to help pull the economy out of the recession. Exports accounted for about 40 percent of the economy's growth last year.
The gross national product of the industrialized nations will rise from about 1 percent this year to 2.5 percent to 3 percent in 1992, the report said. The G.N.P. is the total value of a nation's goods and services.
Growth among the lesser-developed countries is expected to increase slightly less than 1 percent this year and about 3.5 percent in 1992.

HEADLINE: Business and Health;
The Drug Makers' Defense on Costs

BYLINE: By Milt Freudenheim

 BODY:
PHARMACEUTICAL executives jousted with Government economists last week over a draft report to Congress that questions the drug industry's main justification for charging thousands of dollars per patient annually for some drugs.
The companies say they have to set high prices to recoup heavy costs of finding and testing a new drug and obtaining Food and Drug Administration approval. The Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association, a trade group, often cites a 1987 estimate of $231 million. 
 Economists at the Office of Technology Assessment, a Congressional advisory bureau, said in the draft report that such numbers were unverifiable, if not meaningless. Critics say the estimates involve guesses about the rates of success and failure in finding new drugs, the time expended, and the cost, in theory, of borrowing money.
At a meeting last week of the technology office's Advisory Panel on Pharmaceutical Research, drug industry spokesmen insisted that the high estimates were basically correct, even if they could not be verified. "You do know the order of magnitude," said Judy C. Lewent, chief financial officer and vice president with Merck & Company, the world's largest drug company.
"Success rates are highly dependent on the state of knowledge about a compound at the start" of a research project, said Jacob Stucki, who retired as vice president for research at the Upjohn Company. He said drug companies often had a "much greater success rate with compounds acquired from outside" laboratories. The up-front costs for such drugs and royalties later are not counted with research in company financial statements.
Ms. Lewent and George B. Rathmann, the retired chairman of Amgen, a biotechnology company in Thousand Oaks, Calif., conceded that not enough was known about the cost of developing a drug. "By the time you get the story right, it's out of date," said Mr. Rathmann, who has moved on to found Icos, a start-up biotechnology company.
Another panel member, Lewis A. Engman, a Washington lawyer and former president of the Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association, said that he had often cited the estimates of research costs, but that even ball park figures were enough to show that the number was large. "Granted that there are many variables and we don't know what they are," he said, "does it matter if the estimate is $250 million, or even $400 million?"
Nancy L. Buc, a Washington lawyer who is a former chief counsel with the F.D.A., identified the political stakes: "If the number is seen as really big, it is less distressing to politicians to allow returns that are seen as perhaps too big." Otherwise, she said, Congress might decide to "tinker with taxes" paid by drug companies.
At a time of rising alarm about health-care costs, these are not idle concerns. Robert B. Helms, a former executive director of the American Pharmaceutical Institute, an industry-sponsored policy group, said there was talk in Washington of adopting European-style controls on drug prices or even subjecting pharmaceuticals to "public utility regulation." To discourage such ideas, he said, the technology office report should cite the savings that drugs permit by taking the place of even more costly hospital care.
Economists say the companies spend heavily for research because the payoffs can be enormous. Ms. Lewent of Merck said increased profits would be "chased by research and development costs" as long as the companies had the money. Merck plans to spend $1 billion this year for research and development. Mr. Rathmann, who recently helped raise $30 million for Icos from investors, said they hoped for a return in 10 years of "42 percent compounded." He added: "If there had not been profitability, there would not be a biotech industry today. The products would not be out there."
Dr. M. Leigh Thompson, a group vice president with Eli Lilly & Company, said medical needs, not economics, were the starting point for drug research. He added that spending on research and development by the drug industry, which was $9.2 billion last year, was less than 2 percent of the $676 billion in national spending on health care.
Ms. Lewent said, "The science opportunities that the industry now sees are orders of magnitude greater than have been seen for a long time." She added, "The hard core issue" is that pharmaceuticals are "an industry that shows itself to be adding to social returns in a competitive environment."
But Jeffrey Levi, a representative of AIDS Action, a patient advocacy group, said the Congressional technology office economists should ask: "Are the companies producing drugs that are accessible to the people who need them?"

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Hunt Transport At a Crossroads

BYLINE: By Agis Salpukas

 BODY:
FOR most of the last 10 years, J. B. Hunt Transport Services Inc. has thrived under the freedoms brought by the deregulation of the trucking industry in 1980.
A nonunion carrier, it benefited from lower costs, an absence of union work rules, and an aggressive management that knew how to exploit the opportunities created when hundreds of older unionized companies failed. Hunt, based in Lowell, Ark., saw its revenues grow to $579 million in 1990 from less than $100 million in the early 1980's. Hunt is the second-largest full-truck-load long-haul carrier, behind Schneider National Inc. of Green Bay, Wis. 
 The company became a favorite of investors and analysts, whose reports helped push the price of the stock up to $33 a share in 1987, from an average in the low teens in 1985. It closed at $19.75 yesterday in over-the-counter trading.
In recent years, Hunt has sustained growth of about 15 percent a year, but it expects to find it more difficult now to meet that target.
When it faced a severe shortage of drivers, the company parked many trucks and then raised its pay rate to 33 cents a mile last year, from 25 cents a mile in 1987. The raises brought a flood of applicants, from which Hunt was able to pick the best, but its cost advantage over union carriers and other nonunion carriers has lessened.
At the same time, its customers, like Ford Motor and Reynolds Metals, have become tougher. They are resisting rate increases and demanding better on-time service, particularly customers that are running their plants on just-in-time inventory deliveries. The recession has also caused many customers to take a sharper look at their haulers.
"They just had open-ended growth opportunities," said Paul R. Schlesinger, the trucking analyst for Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc. "As they could add equipment, they could fill it at decent rates."
But competitors were also adding equipment, which put pressure on prices, making it difficult for truckers to make price increases stick, despite rising labor and fuel costs.
Hunt's operating costs soared from 77 percent of total revenue in 1986 to 90.2 percent in 1990. At the same time, freight rates were steady until last year, when the industry was able to push through a 3 percent rise. "They're at the crossroads," Mr. Schlesinger said. "They've discovered that the growth that they had been counting on will not do the job."
As a result, the management has entered new areas of trucking where Hunt has not shown the expertise it demonstrated in the long-haul, full-truckload market.
Last year the carrier made its first acquisition of a company since 1978. It bought Bulldog Trucking, a short-haul trucking company in the Southeast, based in Carnesville, Ga., to spearhead its drive into the short-haul market.
From 50 to 70 percent of freight is considered short-haul, thus providing a huge market for growth. Hunt is betting that its large size and reputation will enable it to gain market share quickly in a segment that is dominated by small trucking companies.
Hunt also plans to build up its flatbed business, through which it hauls mostly building materials, another highly decentralized business dominated by owner-operators or small companies.
Also, instead of competing in major corridors with railroads, which have made big improvements in the cost of hauling truck containers, Hunt has formed a partnership with the Santa Fe Railway for some of its long-haul business.
Kirk Thompson, president and chief executive of Hunt, said that about one-third of Hunt's business was for hauls of less than 500 miles. "This is not anything particularly new to us," he added.
He said Hunt had been able to persuade some of its Fortune 500 customers, who use it for long hauls, to turn over their short-haul freight to the company, because many prefer limiting the number of vendors they use.
He contended that with its investments in trucks and terminals and with a reputation on which it could now cash in, the company would not have trouble growing in the 90's.
"We took the risk and availed ourselves of the opportunities in the 1980's," he said, "and now we have new opportunity in the 1990's." He added that the industry was resistant to economic slowdowns, commenting, "You can live without frozen yogurt, but you can't live without transportation."
Some analysts suggest that Hunt may even benefit from the recession, because it could lead to the failure of more carriers, giving the stronger companies an opportunity to pick up more customers.
Mr. Thompson also argues that the larger companies have built up such an advantage over smaller truckers that it would be hard to catch up with the efficiencies that a large carrier has.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Dozens of Agencies Pursue Three Japanese Car Makers

BYLINE: By STUART ELLIOTT

 BODY:
ALTHOUGH car and truck sales in the United States remain mired in a slump severe enough to sadden any glad-handing dealer, the appeal of creating vehicle advertising remains strong enough to entice more than two dozen agencies into eagerly pursuing three Japanese auto makers.
Subaru of America is expected to name a short list of finalists sometime this week in the monthlong review of its $60 million account, now handled by Levine, Huntley, Vick & Beaver. American Isuzu Motors is seeking an agency for its car and truck account, valued at $74 million to $100 million, to replace Della Femina, McNamee, which it dismissed Thursday after an 11-year relationship. 
 And in the realm of possibility, agency executives say Mazda Motor of America is continuing to plan a luxury car line code-named Pegasus. If that car, which has involved preliminary discussions with agencies, is introduced, it could mean initial annual ad spending of $60 million to $75 million.
Combined total billings of the three accounts exceed $200 million -- as much as an agency that would rank around 43d among all shops in the United States would have.
Of course, no one agency could serve all three, given the insurmountable competitive conflicts that would ensue. Yet even singly, the billings at issue are magnetic, especially during a recession that has touched off a feeding frenzy among income-starved agencies for whatever sizable pieces of new business become available.
Apart from the financial implications, an added draw makes an automotive account attractive to just about every agency without one. Call it the lure of the open road.
"A car is one of those things that's bigger than life," said Mark Goldstein, president of Earle Palmer Brown Advertising, the Bethesda, Md., agency that is among those identified as being on the long list of Subaru contenders. "It adds a tremendous cachet to your business. You can park a car in front of your building. You can't park a box of Tide in front of your building."
So overwhelming is the desire for auto business that even allied fields bask in a halo effect. When Avis Car Leasing announced the selection yesterday of six finalists on its $30 million-plus account, now being handled by Backer Spielvogel Bates, Robert Cardillo, vice president of sales and marketing, noted that the car-rental company began its review with a list of 120 agencies.
Besides Backer, the finalists, all based in New York, are DDB Needham Worldwide, D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, FCB/Leber Katz Partners, McCann-Erickson and TBWA Advertising. A decision is expected in mid-June.
Servicing a car account is "almost synonymous" with an agency's being regarded by potential clients and its peers as substantial and significant, said Richard Costello, president of TBWA, which is also considered to be among the ranks of Subaru candidates.
"What crystallized it for me was what happened last fall or winter, when we pitched the Nikon account," he continued. "I looked around the room, and there were five of the best agencies: Ammirati & Puris, which has BMW; Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos, which has Infiniti; Della Femina (Isuzu); Levine, Huntley (Subaru), and TBWA, nothing. I thought, 'Man, we're the best agency in America that doesn't have a car account.' " And the winner was a car agency, Ammirati. Mr. Costello added, "With all the nice things that have happened to us over the last few years, the one thing we feel we're missing is the car accunt."
And while the current vehicle sales picture is bleak, automotive accounts remain desirable, Mr. Goldstein said, because, like other marketers, including airlines, restaurant chains, telecommunications outfits and computer makers, "advertising and promotion are critical to them to market their products, whether we're having boom times or we're in a recession."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Sharp Gains At Nordstrom And Dillard

BYLINE: By ISADORE BARMASH

 BODY:
Nordstrom Inc. and Dillard Department Stores, two of the nation's most widely followed retailers, reported sharp increases in quarterly income yesterday.
Considering the "continuing sluggish retail environment," both Nordstrom and Dillard "did quite well for the first quarter," said William N. Smith, retail analyst at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company in New York. He said that Dillard, based in Little Rock, Ark., had primarily benefited from strong growth in same-store sales and had been able to improve sales in the stores it had acquired. He said Dillard had also been helped by not having stores in economically depressed areas like New England, the West and the Middle Atlantic States. 
 "Nordstrom had relatively weak sales results, especially in same stores, which were up in the quarter only six-tenths of 1 percent," Mr. Smith said. But the retail chain had achieved improved gross margins and expense leverage, he added.
"Nordstrom, too, is making a successful transition of appeal to more middle-income consumers, adding more moderately priced goods, without tarnishing its upscale image," Mr. Smith said.
Following are details of the companies' results:
 
Nordstrom
Nordstrom, which operates 64 fashion department stores, said its net jumped 95 percent, to $25.7 milion, or 31 cents a share, in the quarter ended April 30, from $13.2 million, or 16 cents a share, in the 1990 period. Sales rose 10 percent, to $610.6 million, from $555 million. Nordstrom, based in Seattle, operates in eight states and recently opened stores in Paramus, N.J., and Chicago.
"The company benefited from improving sales trends, better management of inventories and steps taken last year to reduce operating expenses," said John Goesling, senior vice president. "These results compare favorably with what we regarded as a disappointing performance during the previous year's first quarter."
Nordstrom, in addition to the release of its quarterly results, also announced that it had settled for $7.5 million both Federal and Washington state securities law class-action suits. Those actions accused the company and six of its officers of failing to disclose that Nordstrom might be liable for additional employee compensation arising from certain past employment practices.
The settlement, which is subject to court approval, calls for the payment to be made to shareholders who bought Nordstrom stock between Feb. 1, 1988, and March 8, 1990. Nordstrom said it had anticipated that most of the settlement would be covered by insurance.
The shareholder settlement followed an earlier settlement with employees who had complained that Nordstrom had failed to pay them for efforts outside their regular work hours, like telephone calls and personal deliveries to customers. Referring to the settlement, Mr. Goesling said that while arrangements with the insurance company were not yet resolved, any payment made by Nordstrom would not have an adverse effect on results for the year.
Nordstrom's stock advanced $2.75 yesterday, to $44, in over-the-counter trading.
 
Dillard
Dillard said that its net income in the quarter ended May 4 rose nearly 30 percent, to $38.1 million, or $1.03 a share, from $29.4 million, or 82 cents a share, in the 1990 quarter. Sales increased 19.3 percent, to $886 million from $742.4 million, while same-store sales -- those from stores opened at least a year -- rose 8.6 percent.
Dillard operates 186 traditional department stores in 18 states, mostly in the South, Southwest and Midwest. Selling primarily branded merchandise in the upper-middle price range, Dillard grew quickly by opening new stores and acquiring many stores from financially pressed retailers.
Dillard's stock rose $4.875 yesterday, closing at $123.25 on the Big Board.

HEADLINE: U.S. Output Up by 0.1% Last Month

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 13

 BODY:
Snapping a six-month decline, the nation's factories, mines and utilities raised production slightly in April as assemblies of trucks and automobiles rebounded, the Federal Reserve reported today.
The increase of one-tenth of 1 percent, while neither large nor unexpected, was seen as indicating that the economy was approaching its low point and that a recovery might be imminent. 
 "We take this number seriously," said James Annable, chief economist at the First National Bank of Chicago. "I think it's good evidence that this recession is indeed bottoming out."
 
Data Intently Scrutinized
 Industrial production data cover only about 25 percent of the economy but are intently scrutinized these days since this is the sector of greatest sensitivity to the business cycle.
But while analysts were encouraged by the first rise in industrial output since September, today's report also showed that output fell twice as much in March as initially estimated and that industry's operating rate, the utilization of capacity, slipped yet again, to 78.3 percent.
It was quite possible, they added, that more months of declining output might lie ahead before the economy was clearly seen to be on the mend. Industrial activity is a "coincident" indicator, typically not turning up before the economy at large but not lagging behind it, either.
 
Gains for Motor Vehicles
 Much of the improvement last month was concentrated in motor vehicles, where output has been held tightly in check during recent months as sales slumped. The April advance was 10.8 percent at a seasonally adjusted annual rate, 24.3 percent for trucks and 2.7 percent for cars.
Production of light trucks surged to an annual rate of 3.1 million from 2.5 million, accounting for the bulk of a 700,000 rate of overall gain for motor vehicles that carried the pace to 8.4 million units.
It appears that demand for light trucks has picked up this spring while car sales remain depressed.
 
Furniture and Textiles Up
 Excluding motor vehicles and parts, industrial production eased two-tenths of 1 percent but several non-automotive industries did post gains, including furniture and textiles. Output of lumber, another product closely tied to the recovering housing industry, has remained about unchanged since February after having dropped an average of almost 2 percent a month between July and February.
On the other hand, production continued to fall last month for primary metals, and weakness was still evident in chemicals and in transportation equipment other than motor vehicles. A drop of eight-tenths of 1 percent in primary metals was its fifth decline in a row.
Over all, factory output rose two-tenths of 1 percent with a rebound of six-tenths in durable goods -- those designed to last at least three years -- more than offsetting a two-tenths decline for nondurables that was paced by a fall in the output of consumer fuels.
 
Mines and Utilities Down
 American mines, meanwhile, produced 1.1 percent less in April than in March and utilities produced one-tenth of 1 percent less.
Production of both consumer goods and construction supplies rose four-tenths of 1 percent last month, construction supplies gaining after tumbling an average of 2.4 percent over the three preceding months. Output of business equipment, meanwhile, rose three-tenths of 1 percent, reversing a March decline of that amount.
The operating rate for manufacturing edged down one-tenth of a point, to 77.1 percent, its lowest level since August 1983, and 2.9 percent below the April 1990 level. The 78.3 percent rate for all industry was two-tenths of a point lower than in March and 2.5 percent lower than the level a year before.
At 105.1 percent of its 1987 average, industrial production last month was down 3.4 percent from April 1990.
April's one-tenth of 1 percent increase in output followed declines of six-tenths in March, eight-tenths in February and five-tenths in January. The March fall had initially been estimated at three-tenths.

GRAPHIC: Graphs: "Industrial Production" shows index of total industrial production from Nov. '89-April '91. (Source: Federal Reserve Board); "Capacity Utilization" shows total output as a percentage of capacity from Nov. '89-April '91. (Source: Federal Reserve Board) (pg. D5)

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Copper at a 15-Month Low As Industrial Need Slumps

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Copper futures sank to a 15-month low yesterday on the Commodity Exchange in New York as weak industrial demand and rising supplies pressed the metal's price toward $1 a pound.
Copper futures settled 1.95 cents to 3.1 cents lower, with the contract for delivery in May at $1.007 a pound, the lowest daily finish for spot copper since Feb. 8, 1990. 
 Copper has been sliding since late in the third quarter of 1990, when slowing industrial production translated into weakening demand. The metal is widely used in the construction, automobile and electronics industries.
"The direction of the market is being determined by the sluggish demand picture we're seeing," said William O'Neill, senior futures strategist with Merrill Lynch.
 
Heavy Japanese Selling
 Yesterday's drop began with heavy Japanese selling early in the session, said Fred Demler, the metals economist at Paine Webber Inc. He said those sales ignited speculative selling, which took the market down sharply.
Traders found little to cheer about in yesterday's Government report of a gain of one-tenth of a percent in industrial production last month after a six-month decline.
The improvement was too slight to offset weak copper demand at a time when industrial consumers of the metal normally were acquiring stocks for summer and fall, analysts said.
Grain and soybean futures ended narrowly mixed in a quiet session on the Chicago Board of Trade as traders awaited a Government update on spring planting progress.
In a weekly report released after the close, the Agriculture Department said corn planting in the 17 largest corn-growing states progressed rapidly last week but remained well behind the normal pace.
 
51% of Corn in Ground
 About 51 percent of the corn crop was planted as of Sunday, compared with a five-year average of 71 percent for that date.
The grain markets were also under pressure. the Agriculture Department said that a decision on whether to grant additional export credit guarantees to the Soviet Union would not be made until around May 24, when a team from the United States returns from studying the Soviet food distribution system.
Moscow has asked for $1.5 billion in United States food credits.
