HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
The Dollar Is Mostly Down While Gold Prices Advance

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar ended lower yesterday against most major currencies except the Japanese yen, which was under pressure fromspeculation about declining interest rates in that country.
Gold prices headed higher after falling in Asia. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $358.60 a troy ounce, up $1.50 from late Friday. The Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid for gold at $358 an ounce, $1.25 higher. 
 Currency dealers said technical factors were largely responsible for the dollar's movement. Most traders, they said, shrugged off the Government's latest economic report showing industrial production increased one-tenth of 1 percent in April against March's six-tenths of 1 percent decline.
The spotlight in foreign exchange centered on the yen.
"There is a perception that the Bank of Japan will lower interest rates," said Ronald H. Holzer, vice president and chief dealer for the Harris Trust and Company in Chicago.
Such speculation intensified after the Bank of Japan intervened by selling dollars for yen, traders said.
In Tokyo, where the global trading day begins, the dollar closed up 139.03 Japanese yen, from 138.58 yen Friday. It traded higher at 139.40 yen in London, and at 139.45 yen in New York, up from 138.70.
The dollar was weaker against the British pound compared with trading on Friday. Sterling bought $1.7320 in London, up from $1.7195, and $1.7385 in New York, up from $1.7245.
The dollar also fell against the German currency, dropping to 1.7140 marks in New York from late Friday's 1.7230.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday's rates, included: 1.4412 Swiss francs, down from 1.4550; 5.8040 French francs, down from 5.8280; 1,272 Italian lire, down from 1,275, and 1.15005 Canadian dollars, down from 1.15135.
Meanwhile, gold gained in London to a late bid of $357 an ounce, from $356.80 Friday. In Zurich, gold rose to $357 an ounce from $356.50.
Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell 23 cents an ounce to close at $357.44.
Silver prices declined.
On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery settled at $3.989 a troy ounce, down from $4.024 late Friday. Silver fell in London to a late bid of $3.99 an ounce from $4.04.

HEADLINE: Historic Hotel Is S.& L. Victim

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: BRETTON WOODS, N.H., May 13

 BODY:
The hotel where the postwar international monetary system was born in the 1940's has fallen victim to the savings and loan debacle of the 1980's.
The Mount Washington, the last of five grand hotels that once graced this resort area, will be put on the auction block on June 26 by Federal banking regulators. 
 The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation acquired a majority stake in the 235-room hotel when it bailed out the Eliot Savings Bank of Boston.
The Mount Washington, an 89-year-old hotel that is on the National Register of Historical Places, was the site of the Bretton Woods conference, where economists and policy makers gathered in 1944 to hammer out rules for the global monetary system.
The meeting created the economic sister organizations of the United Nations: the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices of Treasury Issues Increase

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities rose in moderately active trading yesterday, with dealers reporting that some retail accounts were buying notes and bonds following Friday's big selloff.
Market participants said that most of the buying took place during overnight trading, with foreign accounts buying bonds when the yields on long-term bonds were around the 8.30 percent level reached near the close of business on Friday. 
 There were also some signs of life after market activity shifted to the United States, traders said.
"We are starting to grind back," said Joseph Liro, a senior vice president and money market economist at S. G. Warburg & Company. "But the problem is that since we started so much in the hole, I don't know where we will go if yields get back to 8.21 percent, which is where the new bonds were auctioned last week."
Indeed, analysts said that additional, sustained price improvement was unlikely until inventories of notes and bonds amassed by dealers during last week's quarterly refunding auctions were pared.
"While the long-term outlook for bonds remains bullish, we do not expect solid buying interest to emerge for several sessions, due to the burdensome supply conditions," analysts at MMS International, an economic information service company, said in their daily market commentary.
A report from the Federal Reserve showing that output at the nation's factories rose by one-tenth of a percentage point last month was largely in line with the expectations of analysts and evoked little response in the credit markets.
The gain, the first in six months, was even less than it appeared, however, because the Fed also said that industrial production declined by much more in March than initially reported.
In addition, market participants said, a decline in April in capacity utilization rates, a figure included in the Fed's report, should provide further help in squeezing out inflationary pressures.
"The market has a nice little pop to it, but it doesn't seem particularly inspired," said Mitchell Held, chief financial economist at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company.
Many economic statistics are expected to be released today, and that may help explain why market activity was not more intense yesterday. Among the reports scheduled are consumer price statistics and retail sales data for April.
Most economists expect that the inflation figures will show a modest upturn, and that retail sales sagged again last month.
At the Treasury's weekly bill auction, three-month bills were sold at an average discount rate of 5.50 percent, unchanged from last week's sale. Bids on the new six-month bills produced an average discount rate of 5.63 percent, up slightly from the average rate of 5.61 percent a week ago.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the new 8 1/8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered at a price of 98 1/2 late yesterday, up 18/32, to yield 8.26 percent, down from 8.31 percent late Friday.
Among Treasury note issues, the 8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 99 5/8, up 9/32, to yield 8.05 percent. And the 7 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 11/32, up 2/32, to yield 6.80 percent.
Activity in the investment-grade corporate bond market was slow yesterday, as market participants prepared for an expected offering today of $1.405 billion of new securities from Citicorp backed by credit card receipts. Price talk in advance of the offering put yields on the new five-year securities at between 95 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, and 99 basis points above the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 7 5/8 percent five-year notes.
In the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds, prices of most issues rose by a quarter of a point in quiet trading, dealers said.
In the secondary market for tax-exempt securities, traders said that prices of most widely quoted municipal issues were unchanged to up an eighth of a point.

HEADLINE: Gain in Square D Deal Seen After Slump Ends

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
The agreement by Groupe Schneider S.A. of France to buy the Square D Company for $2.23 billion is one of the largest consolidations in the electrical equipment industry. But that industry is facing some serious challenges because of lower demand in the construction market, which accounts for more than 60 percent of Square D's sales.
The combination of Square D, the North American market leader in low-voltage electrical distribution and industrial control products, and Schneider, with its vast size and financial resources, will result in a stronger competitor for other global giants like Siemens-Nixdorf of Germany, ABB of Sweden, Mitsubishi of Japan and General Electric. The acquisition will also create the world's largest maker of electrical control devices like circuit breakers, switchboards and transformers.
 
Square D Stock Soars
 In response to the agreement announced Sunday night, which calls for Schneider to pay $88 in cash for each Square D share, Square D's stock soared $6.375 yesterday, to $87.375, on the Big Board. 
 "Obviously, the industry has been affected by the economy," said James E. Peirce, an analyst with PNC Financial in Philadelphia. "With construction down, the industry is having some problems, and the outlook for this year is not too good," Mr. Peirce added. "But this will help both companies to be stronger competitors when the economy picks up again."
The combination will be particularly valuable, analysts said, because Schneider will be able to sell its products through Square D's big distribution system in the United States. The companies will have a combined budget of $450 million for research and development, Schneider said. Analysts said that figure would outpace others in the industry.
The combined company will have revenues of about $3 billion from electrical distribution systems, said Schneider, placing it above ABB, which has sales of about $2 billion in that field; Westinghouse, which has $1.6 billion; G.E., $1.5 billion, and Siemens, $1.2 billion.
 
Advantage After Recession
 The larger size will help the company after the recession, Square D officials said. "With the downturn in construction, our industry is deeply affected," said Robert P. Piorani, a Square D spokesman. "The industry is cyclical, and we are at a lower cyclical point. But with the recovery in sight, we expect to come out of this recession on a profitable and strong basis."
For years, Schneider has been trying to move into faster-growing markets overseas.
The industry is considered important because it provides the distribution and control of electrical energy from the point of generation to the outlet on the wall. Square D, based in the Chicago suburb of Palatine, Ill., gets about 80 percent of its profits from electrical distribution, which includes load and circuit breakers, safety switches and connectors. The rest comes from industrial control systems, which include power protection systems, infrared measurement products and automation products.
The size of the industry is difficult to determine, analysts say, because Square D is virtually alone as an independent producer of electrical distribution products. The other giants in the industry, like General Electric and Siemens, make a variety of products, from jet engines to machinery.
The deal follows the 1988 acquisition by Schneider of Telemecanique, another French electrical equipment maker.

HEADLINE: Cash-Strapped Cities Turn to Companies to Do What Government Once Did

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, May 13

 BODY:
Seventy years after Philadelphia helped launch a new era in American politics by having public workers provide most public services, many politicians here are saying the city's survival may depend on bringing that era to a quick close.
To help solve the city's fiscal crisis, say four of the eight politicians who are vying to be Philadelphia's next mayor, the city must put many costly public services, including trash collection and custodial services, out to competitive bid by private companies. 
 The assumption is that private companies are unhampered by union contracts, civil service systems, bloated work forces and other burdens that raise costs and are thus more efficient than governments in performing the same tasks.
A switch to private companies would normally be unthinkable in this overwhelmingly Democratic and highly unionized city. But public policy analysts say the time is ripe for radical change here and in many other cities, particularly older ones in the Northeast and Midwest.
An exception is New York, where there is a fiscal crisis but so little impetus toward shifting public services to private companies that Mayor David N. Dinkins has not even mentioned it in his recent statements on the city's financial problems.
Felix G. Rohatyn, chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, the state agency that monitors New York City's finances. favors contracting out more services and attributed the lack of action to political inertia.
 
Move to Shed Services
 Elsewhere, the trend is clear. "Since the beginning of the 1980's the prevailing political philosophy has been that governments should shed what services they can," said Dr. Anita A. Summers, professor of public policy and management at the Wharton School of Business at the University of Pennsylvania.
The buzzword here, in both Democratic and Republican circles, is privatization. The term, popularized by the Reagan Administration, refers to a process of stripping government to the bones: While public officials continue to regulate and administer the city government, private companies bid to provide public services.
Such arrangements have become relatively common around the nation, though much less so in large older cities like Philadelphia.
Many cities have experimented with privatization, according to the Mercer Group, a management consultant in Atlanta that advises cities on ways to contract out services. A survey last year of 82 municipalities in 34 states chosen to represent cities of different sizes, regions and political organizations found that virtually all had contracted out at least three services.
The savings that result from contracting out services are hard to measure, but numerous studies put the savings at a 10 percent to 40 percent reduction in costs, with the greatest savings coming from contracting out labor-intensive services. Savings also vary depending on how bloated a city's work force is and how out of line city compensation is with the marketplace. But most estimates do not include hidden costs like writing and bidding contracts, monitoring contractors, cost-overruns and employee severance.
State governments have been generally less experimental than local governments, but many states have started to hire private companies to manage prisons, roads, parks, commuter railways and hospitals. Cities in the South and West, where unions are weaker and where growing populations have strained public services, have been the most active in contracting out public services.
Los Angeles County recently contracted out the management of five small airports, and the Los Angeles City Council last month discussed selling the Los Angeles International Airport. Fort Worth is turning the operation of its zoo over to a not-for-profit organization that will seek charitable donations to cover annual deficits.
Chicago is contracting out a string of services and, in some cases, turning money losers like vehicle towing into small profit centers. Lansing, Mich., is looking for companies or not-for-profit organizations to take over the city's ambulance service, cemetery and recreation programs.
And among Northeastern cities, Newark has taken the lead by contracting out a dozen functions, including a third of the city's trash collections. "The hardest part of it is laying off men and women who live in the community," said Mayor Sharpe James.
 
Reversal in Phoenix
 In 1978, Phoenix set up a competitive system in which private contractors bid against the city for trash collection. For several years, the department was underbid and lost contracts to serve half the city. But by 1987, the department had won back all the contracts.
"Competition forces you to improve productivity, develop teamwork and raise morale," said Ron W. Jensen, director of the department. A city audit estimated that competition had saved the city $20 million in the last decade.
Despite the boom in privatization, experts say it is easy to do wrong, because public officials are just learning to write these novel contracts. In March, for example, Los Angeles County officials canceled a five-year contract to maintain city vehicles because of cost overruns.
Labor leaders, facing the prospects of layoffs, say that contracting with private companies to run public services is merely a way for politicians to hide their own management failures. "Philadelphia is not in a mess just because of union work rules," said Linda M. Lampkin, director of research for the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees.
 
Savings Can Be Small
 Even where there are considerable savings in some departments, they can be relatively small compared to the overall budgets of many cities. And Paul Starr, a sociologist at Princeton University, said that in many privatization plans the savings are largely a result of private companies' paying low wages and providing minimal health benefits.
Apart from the individual hardship, he said, the net social result was that one branch of government saved money while social welfare agencies and public health agencies spent more because more city employees were out of work.
Ray F. Ybarra, business manager of the Phoenix sanitation workers' union, said the private contractors were hardly free of problems and added: "The city is wasting money going through the bidding process. It's a myth that competition keeps you on your toes."
In Philadelphia, there are discussions about selling the city-owned gas and water utilities, Veterans Stadium, parking garages and the Philadelphia International Airport, which, like nearly all other airports that receive Federal subsidies, is operated as a not-for-profit entity. But laws, politics and opposition from companies that benefit from current arrangements make it unlikely that major city-owned assets would be sold or leased any time soon.
But the city's labor contracts, which prohibit layoffs, expire next year, and a new mayor could consider contracting out things like trash collection, custodial services, vehicle repairs and building maintenance, said Dianne E. Reed, director of the Pennsylvania Economy League, a not-for-profit research organization.
She said a conservative estimate of savings produced by these contracts was $20 million to $30 million a year; other experts in privatization say the savings would be much higher. The savings would only dent the city's deficit, which is more than $230 million on this year's $2.1 billion budget, but would be "psychologically significant," she said.
Many of the mayoral candidates who are lining up for the May 21 primary have prescribed more state aid and contracting out services as the most powerful remedies for Philadelphia's financial ills. Mayor W. Wilson Goode is prevented by law from running for a third consecutive term.
"Contracting out public services can produce significant savings and restore credibility to the city in Harrisburg and up on Wall Street," said Edward G. Rendell, a former Philadelphia District Attorney and a Democratic candidate for mayor.
The candidates with backing from city unions oppose contracting out services.
Former Mayor Frank L. Rizzo, who is running as a Republican, is one of the staunch opponents to privatization. "I'm pro union, I've been that way all my life," he said at a recent candidates forum the issue.
James S. White, a Democrat and former managing director of the city who just dropped out of the race, said: "We've already privatized the health care in prisons, solid waste disposal, the golf courses, the trolley service in Fairmount Park, certain custodial services in certain buildings and all road resurfacing."
But in New York, Mr. Rohatyn said: "When you begin to talk to politicians about privatization, they look at you with blank stares because they know that kind of process takes years here." He recalled that in the midst of the city's mid-1970's fiscal crisis, the assistance corporation proposed contracting out trash collection but that the proposal died after running "into a brick wall of opposition," mostly from unions and private trash haulers.
Philadelphia's fiscal crisis has turned up the volume in the debate over contracting out services, but it remains to be seen whether a new Mayor could persuade the City Council to lay off city workers. Three years ago, when the city first invited competitive bids for collecting trash, the council rejected a contract that its advocates said would have saved the city $40 million in the first year. It chose to keep sanitation workers on the job and contract out only waste disposal.
To some local history buffs, the debate echoes one that took place more than 70 years ago, when city ordinances required officials to contract out all services. Corruption was rampant. In 1919, Philadelphia repealed those ordinances and developed professionally managed service agencies.
Frederick L. Voight is executive secretary of the Committee of Seventy, a not-for-profit group founded in 1904 after the muckraker Lincoln Steffens wrote that Philadephia was "corrupt and contented."
"We have to be very careful," Mr. Voight said, "about going private in a way that we don't repeat the mistakes of the past under the guise of doing something new and different."

HEADLINE: Daily News Is Rebuilding Circulation But Is Still Below Level Before Strike

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
Eight weeks after the British publisher Robert Maxwell took over The Daily News and ended a bitter five-month strike, the New York newspaper has overcome initial difficulties in production and distribution and has begun to rebuild its circulation.
But whether The News will approach the daily circulation of almost 1.1 million that it had before the strike began last October, when it was the nation's largest daily tabloid, is still in doubt. Newspaper investment analysts and newspaper executives say it will be months before the long-term prospects of The News become more clear. 
 Executives of The News say about 800,000 copies a day are now being sold. The News claimed a circulation of 600,000 during the strike, but labor leaders and executives at other papers said then that perhaps half that many papers were being bought each day.
Some newspaper investment analysts and newspaper executives said that, based on reports from newspaper dealers and distributors, they thought the daily circulation of The News was now about 700,000. They were uncertain how many copies were now being sold on Sunday, a critical day in the newspaper business because as much as half of the advertising revenue for an entire week comes from the Sunday edition. Several newspaper executives said they thought 700,000 to 800,000 copies of The News were being sold on Sundays. Officials of The News did not disclose the current Sunday circulation.
 
Chief Beneficiary
 New York Newsday appears to be the chief beneficiary of the strike at The News and its aftermath. The New York edition of the Long Island paper sold about 225,000 copies a day before October and reached a daily peak of 365,000 during the strike. Its circulation is now slightly less than 300,000 on weekdays, said Chiara Coletti, a Newsday spokeswoman.
New York Newsday is selling 375,000 copies on Sunday, more than double its Sunday circulation of 155,000 before the strike, Ms. Coletti said. On Long Island, Newsday has a daily circulation of about 500,000 and a Sunday circulation of about 560,000, she said.
The New York Post, which reached a peak of more than 1 million in February, is now down to about 550,000 copies a day, a spokesman for The Post, Gary Lewi, said. Several executives at other newspapers did not challenge The Post and Newsday figures.
The major question for all three New York tabloids -- The News, The Post and Newsday -- is how thoroughly The News can rebuild its circulation, many executives and investment analysts said. If The News can reach daily sales of 800,000 to 900,000, they said, it would re-establish its dominance among the tabloids, and significantly increased advertising would likely follow.
 
Buying Patterns
 "I was surprised that the circulation did not come back faster," said John Reidy, a newspaper investment analyst at Smith Barney. "I had thought that the circulation would bounce back to about a million fairly quickly."
Mr. Reidy said the next few months could be crucial for The News. He said it would have to attract more readers before people go on summer vacations. "Buying patterns get established," he said. "If you didn't get them back by the end of June and they're going to go off on a trip or to the shore, are you going to get them back in September?"
Many of The News's traditional advertisers, including Macy's and Alexander's, have been running ads in recent weeks. But its comeback effort is complicated by the recession, with nearly all advertisers cutting back.
 
Introductory Rates
 "They have a lot of loyal advertisers, but their deals are all over the place," said a newspaper executive, who spoke on condition of anonymity. "They are offering some nice introductory rates. You've got to do that so you don't look like you're out of business. They've got to prove their circulation, which will then drive their advertising."
The next semiannual audit of newspapers' circulation will not be reported until the end of September, so until then The News will have to win the confidence of advertisers without independent verification of its circulation.
Executives of The News said they were confident that they could do so. "Mr. Maxwell has guaranteed our advertisers a daily circulation of 800,000 and a Sunday circulation of 1 million for the six months ending with the A.B.C. audit of Sept. 30," said John G. Campi, the paper's vice president of promotion and public relations, referring to the Audit Bureau of Circulation. "Our initial checks suggest that we're right on target."
In the initial weeks after Mr. Maxwell took over The Daily News from the Tribune Company of Chicago on March 21, The News had significant problems with printing and distribution, and the paper was slow to return to many newsstands.
Hundreds of union drivers and pressmen were laid off as a result of the settlement between Mr. Maxwell and the paper's unions, and it took time to reconfigure staffing levels for the reduced work force.
Some union officials said Mr. Maxwell's refusal to pay overtime made it difficult to print the required number of papers and impossible for some drivers to complete their deliveries.
Donald A. Nizen, a former circulation executive at The New York Post and The New York Times, was hired by Mr. Maxwell last month to help straighten out the distribution system. Mr. Nizen said drivers have now selected their new routes and have become familiar with them. In late March and early April, he said, drivers had different routes each night.
He said some overtime has been restored for longer routes. "You can't get from Brooklyn to Montauk on straight time," he said. All overtime must still be approved by Mr. Maxwell.
 
Still the Publisher
 The publisher of The News, James Hoge, has been away while many of these matters have been resolved. In mid-April, officials at the paper said Mr. Hoge had gone on a six-week vacation. That led to speculation by the staff that Mr. Hoge, who had run the newspaper before Mr. Maxwell took over, would not return.
Mr. Campi reiterated yesterday that Mr. Hoge was still the publisher. Last week, Mr. Hoge was said to have been an unsuccessful candidate for chief executive of the American Newspaper Publishers Association.
Under the sale agreement, the Tribune Company would pay severance to about 60 senior executives if Mr. Maxwell should dismiss them during the first 90 days after the sale, an executive involved in the sale said. The executives would get two weeks' pay for every year of service at The News, up to a year's pay. For 10 days after the 90-day period, they could leave voluntarily and still receive the severance.
Now that the paper's post-strike problems have been worked out, The News has begun restoring pre-strike features, like zoned editions in some boroughs and more sections on Sunday, Mr. Nizen said.
One News employee said executives were studying whether to bring back a late-afternoon edition published only during the strike.
But some investment analysts said it would be months before the prospects for The News could be evaluated.
"All the problems that The Daily News had before the strike are still there," said John Morton, a newspaper analyst at Lynch, Jones & Ryan in Washington. "It is a paper that has had profound market problems for a long time. And Maxwell has not come up with a magic formula so far."

HEADLINE: Panel Urges Wider State-City Fiscal Ties

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
New York City and State suffer deep and inseparable fiscal problems that will not be solved by an economic recovery, and should agree on a multiyear plan to shift tax burdens from the city to the state, shrink their work forces and improve management, a major civic group said yesterday.
The report by the Citizens Budget Commission puts it at least partly at odds with Mayor David N. Dinkins, who endorses shifting some of the city's burdens to the state and streamlining government but contends that the city's problems are mostly the result of a cyclical recession that will pass. 
 The commission, a nonprofit watchdog group financed by businesses and for more than half a century a leading Cassandra on local fiscal issues, said the city and the state could face combined deficits totaling $30 billion over the next four years and must begin phasing in fundamental but politically difficult changes.
In making the recommendations, the budget commission, whose chairman is Richard Ravitch, the former mayoral candidate who was chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, sums up and expands on a chorus of warnings that New York's problems are so deep and likely to persist as to require a rethinking of state and local governments' mission.
"I think this is an opportunity to deal with this on a long-term basis," he said. "People need certainty and reasonable predictability to make economic decisions. And it's very damaging to have us lurch from crisis to crisis."
 
Sharing the Costs
 Many of the changes recommended by the commission have been batted around unsuccessfully for years. They include the state's assuming a greater share of the cost of Medicaid and welfare payments, better management of health care for the poor and reshaping employee health benefits, a smaller, more efficient work force in which government could share savings from increased productivity with workers, and higher state income and gasoline taxes to help pay Medicaid and welfare costs and allow reductions in local taxes.
Only in exchange for such major changes, the group's leaders said, should the city and state move to borrow their way out of their current troubles through various proposals now under review to stretch out the problem by refinancing bonds, for example.
The commission's president, Raymond D. Horton, said: "What we're sort of looking for is some sort of compact with all the players. What I'm really afraid of now is that we're getting awfully close to treating this problem very much like we treated the 1975 crisis as just a financing problem."
Mayor Dinkins and Gov. Mario M. Cuomo have said they hope the Municipal Assistance Corporation, which was set up to borrow money on the city's behalf in the 1970's, could now help it with several hundred million dollars from bond refinancings in the coming year.
Yesterday, in a WNYC radio interview, Mr. Cuomo said the assistance corporation might be able to provide more than $1 billion over the next several years if it could do so without damaging its credit ratings. The corporation's chairman, Felix G. Rohatyn, says he could only provide such help on those conditions and as part of a comprehensive plan.
The budget commission, too, has resisted the idea of borrowing to help close the deficit, and its report seemed aimed at buttressing Mr. Rohatyn's views in the face of heavy political pressure to use the money for this.
Of the study, Mr. Cuomo said in Albany: "We're trying to deal with imminent catastrophe in New York City between now and May 25. The Citizens Budget Commission's ideas for the future may be worthwhile. For the moment the important question is how to get the Legislature to produce a budget within the next 10 days or so, and that's what I'm concentrating on."
A spokesman for Mr. Dinkins, Eli Attie, said, "Obviously we're very pleased that the Citizens Budget Commission has embraced a number of proposals we have already made," like having the state bear a bigger share of Medicaid costs. "We hope the C.B.C. will use whatever authority it has to help achieve these goals. At the same time, it's important to recognize that achieving these kinds of reforms isn't as easy as issuing a report or snapping your fingers."
"I think there is no question," Mr. Rohatyn said, "that ultimately there has to be a city-state restructuring of functions and financing."
"This obviously can't be done overnight," he added, "and I think the only way to do it will be for some legislatively created type of commission to make recommendations to the Legislature and to have it voted up or down."

HEADLINE: Mulroney Outlines New Unity Strategy

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: OTTAWA, May 13

 BODY:
Amid indications that Quebec may resolve differences with the rest of Canada without breaking away, Prime Minister Brian Mulroney outlined a strategy of broad public consultation today as the key to national unity.
In his first major address to the nation since the collapse of an effort for constitutional change in June, the embattled Progressive Conservative leader, who is far down in the polls, promised economic and social changes as the constitutional issues are worked on. 
 "Prosperity is enhanced by a united country," Mr. Mulroney declared. "But disunity in the face of global economic challenge invites decline."
His remarks, which signal the path the Government will take in elections that have to be called in two years, were delivered in the Senate of Parliament in the Speech From the Throne, a rough equivalent of the American State of the Union Message. Canada recognizes Queen Elizabeth II as its formal head of state.
 
Truckers and Other Protesters
 The text of the speech, prepared by Mr. Mulroney, was read by the Queen's representative, Governor General Ramon J. Hnatyshyn, in a traditional ceremony in the Parliament Building. On the lawns, demonstrators carried placards referring to "brain-dead Tories" and calling for the impeachment of Mr. Mulroney. Truckers protested high fuel and insurance costs.
The speech kicking off the third session of the 34th Parliament in 124 years of nationhood was intended to lift morale -- and Tory political hopes -- at a time when Canada is not only going through a constitutional crisis, but also a recession that is already deeper and longer than the one in the United States.
Although there have been signs that the recession may have bottomed out here, unemployment is still at 10.2 percent of the work force, about 4 points higher than in the United States, and home-mortgage interest rates have not fallen under 10 percent.
Mr. Mulroney, whose seven years in power have been dominated by efforts to win free trade with the United States, and now Mexico, and fend off Quebec separatists, is hoping to capitalize on the more subdued feelings about independence in Quebec. Polls show the number of voters supporting sovereignty has sharply dropped since last year, apparently reflecting effects of the recession and warnings of Quebec business leaders that more belt-tightening would follow independence.
Although the Quebec legislature is expected this week to outline plans for a separatism referendum by the end of next year, Premier Robert Bourassa has said he may delay the vote if the other nine provinces are close to making commitments on revising the Federal system.
 
New Ideas for Changes
 Against this backdrop, Mr. Mulroney sketched out a more broadly based process for changes to replace the failed Meech Lake Accord of June. That proposal would have enshrined Quebec's status as a "distinct society." The effort failed to carry two provinces, Newfoundland and Manitoba.
Mr. Mulroney said his Government would formulate plans to change Federal and provincial powers by September and refer the proposals to a joint parliamentary committee that would consult Canadians at all levels of life. The committee is to report in five months, and the Government would propose a plan for "a renewed Canada for consideration by the people of Canada."
Although the speech did not spell it out, officials said the Prime Minister was leaving the door open to a referendum or a constituent assembly for final votes on the proposals. He said he would follow the principles that Quebec's "unique character must be affirmed" and that "particular interests of the west, the Atlantic provinces, Ontario, the north and aboriginal Canadians must be recognized as well."
Mr. Mulroney said the two-and-a-half-year-old free-trade agreement with the United States, which is seen by opposition members as costing jobs, had "helped to secure the Canadian economy in difficult times." For the first time in 16 years, he noted, Canada is attracting more job-creating direct investment than had been going abroad.

HEADLINE: Stock Prices Edge Upward on a Quiet Day

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
Stocks edged higher yesterday in quiet trading as investors tried to figure out where the economy was heading.
The Dow Jones industrial index of 30 blue chips tacked on 4.25 points to close at 2,924.42. 
 Trading on the New York Stock Exchange slumped from more than 170 million shares on Friday to 129.6 million shares, the slowest in a week.
Birinyi Associates, which tracks program trading, said five big waves of computer-driven selling cut close to 23 points off the Dow throughout the day. Selling was particularly heavy early in the day and again between 1 P.M. and 2 P.M.
Asked why the Dow was not doing better, Allen Sinai, chief economist for the Boston Company, said: "The market's overvalued. The economy has to recover soon and by a lot to justify these prices."
The market, he argued, "is way ahead of itself and has discounted good earnings long before we're likely to see them."
Alan M. Newman, technical market analyst for H. D. Brous & Company, in Great Neck, L.I., said he thought the S.&P. 500, the Value Line index and the New York Stock Exchange's composite index would "continue to outperform" the Dow "because of the way the Dow's constructed."
"When I look at the charts of the smaller stocks," he said, "I see much more potential than I see in the Dow stocks. The smaller stocks overwhelmingly have been under selling pressure for years, and the market is telling us the economy will recover eventually -- although that could still be a year away -- and that these small companies will remain attractive."
As he explained it, "The problem with the Dow is that it's 30 stocks; all you've gotta do is throw in a couple of rotten apples and you really spoil the performance compared to the other indexes."
Union Carbide, Sears Roebuck and American Express, he maintained, "have basically gone nowhere in a long time."
And as for what he called "the worst reason why the Dow can underperform in the near future," he mentioned Merck and Disney, two of the most highly regarded investment stocks.
"God forbid these stocks split," Mr. Newman said. "Their impact will be severely reduced."
He noted that Merck ended yesterday up 1/8 at 118 1/2 and that Disney, which just joined the Dow index a week ago, ended ahead 5/8 at 121 1/2.
"The best-performing Dow stocks are generally the highest-priced ones," he said, "and the highest-priced ones are generally the ones that split."
Of course, companies like to split their stock so that more people can afford to buy it. Moreover, stocks that split often continue to rise.
Mr. Sinai noted that while the Fed "is a friend to the stock market," it was not easing interest rates any more right now -- "and that's negative."
Asked why the Fed would not ease for the present, he replied, "It's expecting a recovery."
He said Wall Street would be watching for clues in such forward-looking figures as retail sales, expected today, and housing starts, due on Thursday.
Technology stocks, often viewed as a market leader, were fairly strong yesterday. I.B.M. rose 2 1/2, to 105 7/8; Digital Equipment 1 7/8, to 67 7/8; Apple Computer 1 1/2, to 52 3/4, and Motorola 1 5/8, to 65 3/8.
Dillard rose 4 7/8, to 123 1/4, and Nordstrom 2 3/4, to 44, after both store chains reported higher-than-expected profits.
Square D jumped 6 3/8, to 87 3/8, after the electrical equipment producer accepted $88 a share from Schneider of France when the Justice Department said it would not block the deal on antitrust grounds.

HEADLINE: Census Finds Households Are Growing In New York

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN

 BODY:
After declining steadily for most of this century, the average number of people living in a household in New York City began to rise again in the last decade, according to an analysis of 1990 census data by New York City planners.
The reversal of the longstanding trend toward smaller households appeared to signal a return to an old phenomenon for a new generation in this city of immigrants -- one in which families with many children and older members had to live together. 
 Richard L. Schaffer, the Director of City Planning, said yesterday that the average size of New York households increased to 2.54 people in 1990 from 2.49 in 1980. Despite the citywide increase, Manhattan -- with fewer than two people in each living unit -- retained its distinction as the county with the smallest household size in the nation.
"This modest increase in household size reflects recent changes in the composition of our population," Mr. Schaffer said of the citywide figures. "For example, we have many new immigrant groups with extended families and multigenerational households."
 
Living With Relatives
 And in a city that gained at least 250,000 people in the 1980's, and perhaps many more if census figures are adjusted upward, a declining economy and a shortage of affordable housing may also have contributed to the rise in the average household size, Mr. Schaffer said. Both factors make it harder for immigrants and young people to establish their own households.
While experts say hundreds of thousands of New Yorkers are living with relatives or friends in overcrowded apartments, Evelyn Mann, the Planning Department's population division director, cautioned against interpreting the figures as confirmation that families are doubled up.
"It doesn't necessarily mean that people are being squeezed in," she said. "It only means that more housing in certain areas of the city is being used at their designed levels. I don't think the census actually counted many people who were doubled up. If such arrangements were illegal, it would not have been reported."
Average household size is figured by dividing the number of people in households in a given area by the number of occupied units in that area. New York City contends that both the population and the housing count were seriously flawed in the 1990 census, partly because residents in illegally overcrowded housing were not reported.
If people were undercounted, Mr. Schaffer noted, the average number of people in New York households might well be higher than 2.54.
In any case, he said, the 1990 census showed a reversal in trends toward smaller households that had been noted since 1900.
The average size of New York households at the turn of the century -- in an era of heavy immigration by ethnic groups that tended to have many children and lived in large, multigenerational families -- was 4.51 people, according to figures supplied by the Planning Department.
But as increasing prosperity and a growing housing stock in New York allowed for more privacy and greater choice in living arrangements, the extended families broke up, young people increasingly established their own homes. Household size declined to 3.89 people in 1930, to 3.2 in 1950 and to 2.74 in 1970.
 
Immigrant Pattern Cited
 Mrs. Mann said the 1990 census figures for average household size suggested a return in some neighborhoods "to the family structure at the turn of the century" by new immigrants who had many children and lived in multigenerational households.
For example, she said, an apartment in Flatbush that once was the home of a large extended immigrant family was occupied down through the decades by fewer people as the family prospered and children moved out, until finally the apartment was occupied by a lone widowed grandmother.
When that woman dies or goes to a nursing home, the apartment again becomes occupied by a new large extended immigrant family. This has the effect of raising the size of the household and using the housing stock more efficiently, Mrs. Mann said.
"It's turning back the clock in some neighborhoods," she said of the reversal of the long decline in household size.
Moreover economic hard times and an inadequate stock of affordable housing have prompted many young people to remain longer at home with their parents. People who are doubled up with relatives or friends have also postponed establishing their own households.
Mr. Schaffer said that while all five boroughs gained population in the 1990 census, the Bronx and Brooklyn experienced declines in housing units and occupied housing units. In the Bronx, average household size rose from 2.66 to 2.74, while Brooklyn's increased from 2.66 to 2.73.
Thus, he said "more people lived in fewer housing units in these two boroughs than in the past."
Manhattan and Queens gained in total and occupied housing units and the number of people in each household. Manhattan's increase, to 1.99 people from 1.92 in each household, did not jeopardize its national standing as the county with the lowest average household size. Queens showed an increase from 2.62 to 2.67 over the decade.
Staten Island had the highest percentage increase among the boroughs in both housing units and people in each household, but nonetheless it experienced a decrease in average household size from 2.99 to 2.85.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
Industrial production rose 0.1 percent, snapping a six-month decline, as assemblies of trucks and automobiles rebounded, the Fed reported. The rise was seen as indicating that the economy was nearing its low point and a recovery might be imminent. [Page D1.] 
 The Supreme Court agreed to decide whether corporations can take Federal income tax deductions for expenses incurred in arranging to be acquired in a friendly takeover. [D5.]
The last decade has brought chief information officers into the upper corporate ranks. But their prominence has a price. [D1.]
Companies have expanded the number of products that carry "800" numbers, and have found a side benefit in the information they can gather. [D4.]
Philadelphia must put many public services out to competitive bid by private companies, many city politicians say. [A12.]
 
Companies
G.M. said it planned to raise as much as $600 million by selling an unusual type of stock that will save money for the company if the price of its common stock rises, but cost it money if the common stock falls. [D1.]
Drexel Burnham Lambert, as part of its reorganization plan, agreed to join the Government in lawsuits against some of the people who once worked for it. [D1.]
Nordstrom and Dillard reported sharp increases in quarterly income. Nordstrom's net jumped 95 percent, while Dillard's rose nearly 30 percent. [D3.]
The agreement by Schneider to buy Square D is one of the largest consolidations in electrical equipment, an industry facing serious challenges. [D6.]
Dell Computer said it would lower prices by $100 to $900 on nine of its desktop and laptop personal computers. [D7.]
Intelligent Electronics said it would buy Bizmart in a deal valued at $192 million. [D3.]
Nine years after seven Tylenol deaths, Johnson & Johnson has agreed to pay an undisclosed sum to the survivors. [A15.]
Eight weeks after Maxwell took over, The Daily News has begun to rebuild circulation. [B4.]
Rival designers from Lockheed and Northrop spearheaded the development of stealth warplanes. Science Times. [C1.]
 
International
Karl Otto Pohl will resign later this year as Bundesbank president, two West German newspapers reported. [D1.]
U.S. and Japanese negotiators failed to arrive at a new semiconductor trade agreement after meeting in Washington. [D7.]

HEADLINE: Nursing Homes Drain Connecticut Budget

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: FAIRFIELD, Conn., May 8

 BODY:
Grete Struch, blind but barely slowed down, marches the hallways at the Jewish Home for the Elderly with a Braille copy of a Danielle Steel novel under her arm and a fistful of raffle tickets to sell. She also has the Sweetheart's Ball coming up, plus an afternoon sing-along, a cocktail party, and the next crafts sale.
Her ebullience shatters the stereotype of nursing homes as bleak and sterile warehouses. The cultivated grounds here, the hallways lined with stained glass, the buoyant good humor of the patients and the constant activities attest to the high level of care. 
 And that is the problem. Connecticut spends about 17 cents out of every general fund tax dollar, or about $1.2 billion, on medical assistance, with a good part of that going to nursing-home care in places just like this one. With a fiscal crisis and an aging population bearing down from two sides, the Medicaid budget, intended to help the poor, has emerged as a middle-class entitlement program that state officials say can no longer be maintained in the style to which it has become accustomed.
The Jewish Home, for example, charges $194 a day for skilled full-time nursing care, or $70,810 a year. Of its 240 patients needing that level of care, 83 percent are legally destitute and have most of their bills paid by Medicaid, the Federal and state reimbursement program. Even at the reduced Medicaid rate of $163 a day, and with patients contributing Social Security payments and other income, a year here can still cost taxpayers $50,000 or more per patient, state officials say.
When times were good and Medicaid patients were rare, few questioned the priorities of a system that created expensive nursing centers like the Jewish Home, with its 12-member recreation staff, music-therapy sessions and entertainment programs to stimulate the minds of its residents.
It is formal state policy, for example, that no one should have to drive more than 10 miles to visit relatives in a nursing home, an almost unheard-of courtesy that national health experts say has led to clusters of small homes, each costing far more per bed to operate than one large home.
Even at the median statewide rate of $109 a day, Connecticut nursing-home care is the fourth most expensive in the nation, after Alaska, Hawaii and New York.
But in the harsher light of recession and budget crisis, state officials have declared war on a system they say is too costly to withstand Connecticut's newly straitened economic circumstances. Armed with con sultants' studies and anecdotes about patients' limousine rides to hospitals at state expense, they have proposed an overhaul that would separate for the first time those costs that are strictly related to medical care. So-called nonessential care would be sharply restricted.
Total Medicaid expenditures would be reduced by about $78 million in the year beginning July 1, with the bulk of the immediate cuts -- and the even more restrictive growth limits set for futures years -- aimed at pushing the most expensive homes down toward the median.
State welfare officials have also attacked their clients, the patients, arguing that growing numbers of middle-class people who transfer all their assets to their children are unfairly expropriating Medicaid, which was intended for the poor.
These newly minted poor, having given away their wealth, enter the nursing-home system at state expense, fueling part of the sharp increase in Medicaid cases that began in the mid-1980's. Another factor is that the highest Medicaid enrollment rates are also found in the most expensive homes.
"The taxpayer has been there with the checkbook, with no limits," said Lorraine M. Aronson, the deputy secretary at the Office of Policy and Management. "Now we have to say, 'what is care?' " she added. "What do we believe is a reasonable contribution on the part of the taxpayer?"
 
Highest in the Nation
 Nursing home operators and advocates for the elderly blame the state for creating the spiral. Connecticut is one of only a handful of states that regulate private-pay nursing home rates, and those regulated prices are the highest in the nation, reaching a peak of nearly $200 a day at the most costly centers.
State laws also mandate that patients receive exactly the same care regardless of how their bills are paid, a provision that nursing home operators say removes any incentive to pay one's own way. Why give up a lifetime of savings if it makes no difference in care?
They also attack the system as being riddled with inefficiencies that have nothing to do with care. Medicaid rules require, for example, the use of $5,000 customized wheelchairs for certain patients, and has refused to reimburse the modification of a standard wheelchair at about half the cost, according to administrators of St. Joseph's Manor, a nursing home in Trumbull.
On a moral landscape where the painful issues of aging bump up hard against the realities of public finance and nursing-home profits, all sides ask the same question: can a state with growing numbers of elderly, a clouded economic future, and festering problems of poverty and infant mortality cut back on spending for the elderly without betraying its own vision?
 
Immediate Layoffs
 "For years they've said, 'we don't care what you spend, we want everybody to get a Cadillac level of care,' " said Louis Halpryn, executive vice president of the Connecticut Association of Health Care Facilities, a trade group that represents most nursing homes. "They can't change all that in one year -- it's Draconian," he added.
"All the things that soothe the soul -- goodbye," said Rebecca Baker, the Jewish Home's director of community relations and special projects. "These are the things that make life worth living."
At the Jewish Home, a nonprofit center, administrators say the reimbursement overhaul plan could result in immediate layoffs for 10 percent of the 550 employees if the proposal is approved by the State Legislature. Statewide, nursing home lobbyists say that between 1,200 to 1,500 jobs could be lost.
At the backdrop of the debate are numbers that cannot be changed by anyone: Connecticut's population is aging, and the elderly of today are living longer. That portends a future with more nursing-home patients who will require more and more expensive care as they live on into their 90's.
In the 1980's, people aged 85 and over made up the single fastest growing segment of the state's population, up 31.5 percent, according to figures from the Federal Bureau of the Census. The percent of the population aged 65 or over rose to 13.6 percent in 1990 from 11.7 percent in 1980.
Other numbers are so foggy as to be almost meaningless. The overhaul package, for example, would impose a three-year moratorium on the approval of any new nursing-home beds on the theory that the state has a surplus of beds and that any bed, once created, will be filled whether it is really needed or not. Yet many homes also have waiting lists. The Jewish Home has more than 300 people waiting for an available space.
And some of the most desirable homes already have the upper hand. One woman who insisted that her name not be used said she looked at eight nursing homes for her 82-year-old mother, and three of the homes wanted illegal deposits to guarantee admission. One insisted that all of the patient's assets be turned over to the home, to be "spent down" to the point at which Medicaid could take over.
The woman said she finally paid a $4,000 deposit, and is still on a waiting list to get into the home she really wanted.

HEADLINE: Health Insurance Gaps Laid to Racial Bias

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 13

 BODY:
The editor of a medical journal said today that longstanding racial discrimination was one reason black and Hispanic people were slipping through ever-widening cracks of the nation's health care system.
In an editorial in The Journal of the American Medical Association this week, the editor, Dr. George Lundberg, said it was no coincidence that the United States and South Africa were the only developed countries that lack a national health policy insuring access to basic care for all. 
 The United States and South Africa "also are the only two countries that have within their borders substantial numbers of under-served people who are different ethnically from the controlling group," Dr. Lundberg said.
Inequity in access to health care in the United States, he said, is due in part to "longstanding, systematic, institutionalized racial discrimination."
Such characterizations of American health care have been expressed before, but Dr. Lundberg's statement was considered remarkable for a medical association official. Dr. Lundberg is editor in chief of all the association's publications.
 
Disparity in Medical Care
 Black and Hispanic people have higher rates of unemployment than whites, and more often have low-level jobs. So, Dr. Lundberg said, they have less employment-related health insurance and are less likely to receive medical care.
And the public sector has not filled the gaps, he said, adding that Medicaid coverage for the poor is often harder to get in states that have large populations of blacks.
Nationwide, an estimated 31 million to 37 million Americans lack any health insurance, and millions of others who are insured lack adequate coverage. The rising number of uninsured Americans and the steeply rising costs of health care have recently emerged as a major preoccupation of government, business and many citizens. But there is little consensus on solutions.
"An aura of inevitability is upon us," Dr. Lundberg said in his editorial. "It is no longer acceptable morally, ethically or economically for so many of our people to be medically uninsured or seriously underinsured."
 
A.M.A.'s Call for Reform

The A.M.A. devoted the entire issue of its journal this week to proposals for restructuring the nation's health care system. From among 80 individuals and groups that answered the association's call last year for reform proposals, editors selected 13 for publication in the journal.
The proposals fall into four broad categories. Some, put forth by the A.M.A. and other groups, would expand access to all by requiring employers to provide health insurance for all full-time workers and their families. Government would insure nonworkers and the poor. A second group of proposals, variants on the first, would require employers either to provide health insurance or pay a tax, and the Government would use the tax proceeds to help cover uninsured workers.
A third approach, put forth by market-oriented conservatives, would provide income-related tax credits for individuals and families to help them buy insurance directly, while eliminating current tax incentives that promote job-based insurance.
A fourth approach would establish a single, comprehensive public insurance program without co-payments or deductibles. It would allow everyone to choose his or her own provider and would be financed with health care taxes. The higher taxes required to finance national insurance would be offset in large part by the elimination of employer payments for health insurance.

HEADLINE: Continental's New Face Is Red

 BODY:
Some women like to wear the kind of makeup that shouts. Some women like to wear the kind of makeup that whispers. And some women like to wear no makeup at all. For very few of them does not using cosmetics mean the difference between a job and the unemployment line. Teresa Fischette is one of those few.
Is Teresa Fischette a performer, who must be visible from the balcony? No. Is she a sales representative for Elizabeth Arden? No. 
 Teresa Fischette is, or was until last week, a ticket-counter agent at Boston's Logan International Airport for Continental Airlines. The airline, now operating under the supervision of a bankruptcy court, wants a new image. Female ground workers, the airline says, must wear makeup. Told, in other words, that she had to get a new face, Ms. Fischette demurred -- and was fired.
Since then she has been offered a job with no customer contact, thereby sparing potential passengers a glimpse of a naked female face. She has refused; the Massachusetts Civil Liberties Union has taken her case, and Continental is sticking to its paint and powder rule. Which, the airline points out, was suggested by a group of 16 employees, seven of whom were women, who devised a new appearance code to go with the airline's new image.
New code? Old tradition is more like it. There was the airline that wouldn't let its flight attendants wear eyeglasses . . . the airline that wouldn't trust female employees in non-uniformed jobs to wear normal business attire and made them wear smocks . . . the airline that monitored female flight attendants' weight far more carefully than that of males. All were found by the courts to have discriminated against women.
There's nothing wrong with reasonable dress and appearance codes. But before those Continental code-writers decreed a bit of blush, a puff of powder and a lick of lipstick, they would have done well to ask themselves just what it is a female ticket agent is supposed to be selling.

HEADLINE: New York's Pain: Deeper, Longer

 BODY:
The more one studies Mayor David Dinkins's new budget proposal the worse New York's fiscal crisis looks. The budget confirms that, even assuming some exaggeration for bargaining purposes, the crisis is real and it is deep. What's worse is how long it is projected to last.
Even if New Yorkers learn to do without services like clean streets and libraries while paying higher taxes for the privilege, the problems will not disappear. Unless the economy makes a startling comeback, and nobody can responsibly predict that, the pain will last. 
 Retrenchment, service cuts and tax increases are necessary in the crisis budget for the fiscal year that begins in July. But all this will be perpetuated in future years as well, unless the city and state, itself burdened, can promptly join in deep, difficult reforms that would benefit both.
The Mayor's proposed cuts will hurt just about every aspect of city life. Thanks to the Safe City, Safe Streets plan, law enforcement is the only area for which Mr. Dinkins proposes real growth. The city would hire 1,800 new police officers. Meanwhile, it would eliminate 500,000 vision and hearing screenings for schoolchildren . . . add to the garbage mountain at the Staten Island landfill by suspending recycling for a year . . . cut library funding so much that some branches would probably close . . . cut cultural affairs by 44 percent . . . and cut education so deeply that school officials anticipate losing perhaps 6,500 teachers and 3,500 aides.
The mix of cuts and taxes will change as the Mayor negotiates with the City Council, and the gap may be narrowed if the city gets more revenue from the state and the Municipal Assistance Corporation. But the recession, magnified by policy mistakes the Mayor made in the fall, leaves so serious a problem that deep cuts cannot be avoided in the fiscal year beginning July 1.
So much pain does not have to endure, however, if the city and state will join in fundamental fiscal, tax and management reforms. The Dinkins administration is already pursuing some of those changes and the Citizens Budget Commission urges even more far-reaching reforms. But the city cannot do it without its unofficial partner, the state -- particularly Gov. Mario Cuomo, who has yet to involve himself energetically.
The Mayor supports state takeover of local Medicaid costs, for instance, which would be more equitable for all cities and counties because it would spread the tax burden more evenly. The same is true of welfare. If city and state could work together to lift some forms of rent control, most New Yorkers would benefit, as they would if the city conceded that it undertaxes residential properties and pursued reform legislation.
Those are just a few potential reforms. They would not substitute for a thriving economy, but would at least ease the long-term burden. New Yorkers will have to tighten their belts in the coming year. Joint action now to make the city better run and more competitive can spare them municipal starvation in the future.

HEADLINE: Keep the Heat on Gorbachev

BYLINE: By Hedrick Smith; Hedrick Smith, a fellow of the Johns Hopkins Foreign Policy Institute, is author of "The New Russians."

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
To sort out Soviet politics, Americans need a seasonally adjusted method for interpreting the zigzags of Mikhail Gorbachev. In fall and winter, he typically aligns himself with reactionary forces. But in spring and summer, he turns toward reform and compromise with progressive forces.
He has done it again. After five months of alliance with Communist and military reactionaries, Mr. Gorbachev rebuffed the hard-liners last month, and is now operating in a partnership with his rival, Boris Yeltsin, the Russian Republic leader and champion of the reformers. 
 Mr. Gorbachev's shift reflects a pragmatic concession to the power of republican governments, one that opens an opportunity for American policy. The West can widen its official dealings with republican and local governments to promote long-term democratic and market reforms. Mr. Gorbachev himself offered the means for doing so, asking Washington for a new agricultural credit of $1.5 billion.
Clearly President Bush wants to say yes, but Washington should also spread its bets among the contending forces -- not abandoning President Gorbachev but moving to expand parallel connections at all levels of the fragmented Soviet power structure. Here are some steps that should be taken:
* Amend the 1990 legislation establishing the Support East European Democracy program to include the Soviet Union, so that the U.S. can help train elected legislators, mayors and city council members in the art of democracy. Those reformers confront the hard-line party apparatus and lack experience in governing.
* Invest in building democratic institutions in the Russian Republic and other republics. With only $300,000, the National Endowment for Democracy through the National Democratic Institute has run seminars for Soviet officials on budgets, taxes, services and coalition-building. Some 200 city officials have begun this training, but 20 times that number need help. Multiply the budget tenfold, using Federal money, and it would still pale beside the cost of aid to the Kurds.
* Take advantage of glasnost's daring spirits like the TV journalists of the popular program "Vzglyad" who were thrown off the air last December. They are trying to organize alternative TV and radio outlets to compete with the censored state media. Seed money and secondhand equipment are desperately needed.
* Extend economic advice to republics, regions and city governments that want market reforms. Until now, the Bush Administration has been so worried about offending Mr. Gorbachev that it has only advised the central Government, where the will to create a market is weak.
By contrast, leaders in Moscow, Leningrad and some other cities are eager to promote privatization, free trade zones and wholesale markets, rewrite tax laws and ease customs restrictions and other conditions for joint ventures. Low-cost technical advice offers potentially large returns.
* Channel U.S. aid, especially food and other humanitarian aid, to republican governments rather than to the Kremlin. Let the local reformers get the bonus for delivering food. Last winter, when Mr. Bush granted $1 billion in farm credits, the grain went to Moscow and was distributed by the K.G.B. The leader of Moldavia complained that Mr. Gorbachev was demanding that republic leaders accept his version of a new union treaty as a price for obtaining grain.
* Use this summer's summit meeting of the seven industrialized nations to coordinate aid to Moscow; distribute it in phases, continuing so long as Mr. Gorbachev pursues progressive politics and market economics.
* Insist that the Interior Ministry's black-beret troops stop taking over banks, customs posts, airstrips and other facilities in Lithuania and Latvia. Require as a price of outside help that seized Baltic institutions be returned to local authorities.
* Gradually expand official relations with Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia, leading to establishment of what Zbigniew Brzezinski calls "institutes," or veiled U.S. embassies, and get the Baltic states accepted as full members at Helsinki II conference.
In sum, the moment has come for bolder American actions. The object should be to encourage Mr. Gorbachev to stay on a progressive track, -- and to strengthen democratic institutions in case he follows his seasonal pattern and swerves back toward a hard line next fall.

HEADLINE: ON MY MIND;
For China: Action Now

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
Jimmy Carter went to Communist China. He made a speech to Beijing's diplomatic trainees. He spoke privately to China's leaders.
Always, he says, he made a point of supporting amnesty for some political prisoners and the right of Chinese students abroad to visit their country and leave again. 
 Then Mr. Carter returned to Atlanta, and promptly advised the United States to continue the special privilege of minimum tariffs that allows Communist China to sell $15 billion of goods to us annually, about three times more than it buys.
Of course, under various laws and regulations the U.S. is not supposed to give those privileges to countries that do not allow its citizens to come and go freely or which generally act like beasts from hell. Law or not, most Americans would hardly favor giving those privileges to a country that specializes in slave labor, or which occupies and tortures another nation, as China does Tibet.
 The lowest-tariff privileges, known as most-favored-nation status, are supposed to be for friends, not operators of countrywide gulags.
Oh, we get around that, we do. The President just waives the whole thing every year and Beijing goes on selling us the goods it needs to preserve the Communist dictatorship.
But Mr. Bush has to make up his mind any day now on whether he will waive again or state the simple truth that Beijing is in violation of American trading laws and every international human rights agreement.
What with additional disclosures of Communist brutality coming in from China and Tibet every day, and with Beijing shipping nuclear weapon ingredients and technology or missiles to countries all over the world, waiving is becoming more awkward.
China clearly intends to become a major nuclear and missile supplier, which would give it political as well as economic clout. So far it has supplied nuclear material or missiles to Pakistan, Algeria, India, Brazil, Argentina, Syria and South Africa.
Beijing's taste for murder, aggression and death-trade profits is a hot political issue in Congress. The majority wants to grab Beijing's attention by attacking the tariff privileges.
But Mr. Carter advises us not to be so "self-satisfied" about such rights as freedom of speech, press and religion. After all, the former President says, the Communist Chinese and leaders of other "socialist" countries point out "correctly" that in their countries certain rights are respected that the U.S. neglects -- like the right "to have a decent home, a job and adequate health care."
Naturally, neither Mr. Carter's speech nor his advice to the butchers of Beijing were carried by the Chinese press, radio or TV. The outside world knew about it only because of the reports of foreign correspondents in Beijing, printed by the free American press about which we are so unbecomingly self-satisfied.
More embarrassing: Two days after Mr. Carter's Op-Ed comments about human rights in the "socialist countries" were carried in The New York Times, The Wall Street Journal reported from China that not all Chinese have jobs, houses or medical care and in fact between 30 and 50 million of them are wandering the countryside at the moment, searching for any of the three.
So despite Mr. Carter's advice, many members of Congress are demanding that tariff breaks end next year unless the President testifies that Beijing is granting full human rights in China and Tibet and is getting out of the death trade.
 But in separate bills, Senators Daniel P. Moynihan of New York and Jesse Helms of North Carolina are calling for immediate cancellation of the tariff privileges.
Some journalists and Americans in the China trade say that action at once would isolate China. That's a tired argument, historically false. Refusing those privileges to the governments of countries like the Soviet Union or Nicaragua isolated not the people, only the rulers they hated.
There would be a majority for certain action now, not possible action next year, except for fear of a Presidential veto. But human rights advocates in Congress think they could override a veto on a milder bill, to delay action another year but still leave the waiver with the President.
Maybe that is simply human rights politics. But the Communist lords of China have failed for almost a half-century to give their people real human rights, "socialist" or otherwise. It is past time for the United States to refuse to subsidize political tyranny any longer. That is simply human rights truth.

HEADLINE: More Health Care for Less Money

BYLINE: By Joseph A. Califano Jr.; Joseph A. Califano Jr., a lawyer, was Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare from 1977 to 1979.

 BODY:
The $750 billion Americans will spend on health care this year -- and the trillion dollars in 1994 -- should be an opportunity to release the poor from rationing and give all Americans all the health and long-term care they need. Instead, to stem rocketing costs, Richard Darman, Director of the Office of Management and Budget, some legislators and the General Accounting Office suggest rationing health care for all of us.
No politician or bureaucrat has the wisdom to decide who should suffer how much pain for how long, who should walk and who should limp, who will live and who will die -- and when. Here are some ways to free up resources to provide all Americans with the care they need for what we are now spending, or less. 
 Revamp the medical malpractice system. The Bush Administration is right to use Federal programs to prod state malpractice reform. We should develop standards of care to establish under what circumstances which medical procedures work. Any doctor who follows those standards should have a defense to any charge of malpractice. Where providers are negligent, states should limit recovery for pain and suffering and sharply reduce contingent legal fees.
Relax the doctors' monopoly over the practice of medicine. Once essential to protect patients from quacks and charlatans, the doctors' monopoly is now an economic hammerlock that keeps costs high and denies us the savings and efficiencies of modern technology. Today, trained nurses can perform all sorts diagnoses and treatments of common ailments like respiratory diseases, sprains and breaks, just as competently and far less expensively than doctors. Midwives can handle normal deliveries. These physican assistants earn less than half the income of doctors.
Require that insurers and managed care plans compete on the basis of service and price, not on the basis of who can attract the most low cost patients. Now most insurers and managed care plans vie for the healthiest beneficiaries. If all plans were community based -- with rates determined by the needs of the entire community -- and were required to cover anyone who could pay, they would be forced to compete on the basis of price, service and efficiency.
Medicare, Medicaid and private insurers should refuse to reimburse (or at least reduce payments to) hospitals operating at less than 60 percent capacity. We've got to eliminate the inexcusable level of excess capacity in our hospitals. Residents of towns with hospitals where doctors and nurses don't perform operations enough to maintain proficiency, much less attain excellence, would be better off investing in a first-class primary care clinic and a helicopter. Insurers would save money by paying for of such transportation rather than to keep the hospital open.
Eliminate the pharmacists' monopoly over dispensing drugs. The era of doctors writing in Latin and pharmacists mixing powders and potions is long gone. Today, virtually all prescriptions can be filled by anyone who can read and count. Mail order houses do it and some provide prescriptions for as little as 50 cents an order. The cost at retail pharmacies is three to 10 times higher. Pharmacists can help counsel about potential drug interactions, but their monopoly over filling more than a billion prescriptions a year is rooted in self-interest, not consumer protection.
Change the way we pay doctors. It's time to pay doctors to talk with us, not just to do something to us. Fees for such consultation are better spent, particularly when physicians are talking about health promotion and life style changes. It's also time to pay family practitioners more and some specialists less. Medicare is moving in this direction; private insurers should follow.
There are other things we can do to reduce costs. Insurers and the Government should promote disease prevention with financial incentives to take care of ourselves. And everyone involved in the health care industry should sign a paperwork nonproliferation treaty. Electronic processing, standardizing and simplifying claims and audit procedures could save a quarter of the more than $100 billion we will spend this year to administer the system.
Before politicians and bureaucrats resort to rationing for everyone, they should stop tinkering and make fundamental changes in the way we deliver care. Then we can provide high quality care to all -- rather than a declining quality of care to some.
