HEADLINE: South Africa Needs Loans for Democratization

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The imminent elimination of repressive racial laws in South Africa is, as you state in "The Last Days of Apartheid" (editorial, April 24), only a part of the job of establishing a truly democratic society. Few can be more aware than South Africans of the tremendous challenges ahead.
As has been recognized internationally, the successful transformation of South African society is vitally dependent on the country's rebuilding its economy. I therefore welcome your view that the United States should not defer lifting sanctions when South Africa has complied with the minimum conditions of the Comprehensive Anti-Apartheid Act. 
 However, I am astonished by your suggestion that, to preserve some leverage after sanctions have been phased out, Washington use its voting veto at the International Monetary Fund to deprive South Africa of I.M.F. loans until a true democracy has come about.
Decades of apartheid and years of destructive international sanction measures have left South Africa with a zero-growth economy incapable of meeting the demands of high population growth, let alone the aspirations of the black population. It has resulted in growing unemployment and insufficient capital for the huge backlog in housing, education and job creation. The increasingly difficult economic situation contributes to the wave of violence and crime being experienced and seriously threatens democratization.
Immediate access to international finance is the crux for successful transition in South Africa. The recent warning by Chris Stals, governor of the South African Reserve Bank, that if poor economic performance continues, South Africa will be ungovernable by 1995, should not be taken lightly. For you to propose delay of South Africa's access to I.M.F. loans condemns South Africa to being a country unable to borrow extensively for growth. Linked to I.M.F. borrowings, of course, are the opportunities to raise funds from the international capital market and commercial banks around the world.
Your proposal would jeopardize the future financing of the democratic option for which so many of us are striving.
 
C. G. KNOBBS
President, Chamber of
Mines of South Africa
Johannesburg, April 29, 1991

HEADLINE: South Africa Needs Loans for Democratization;
Enriched by Apartheid

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The statement by South Africa's Foreign Minister, P. W. Botha, that he hopes the United States and other countries will offer economic aid to apartheid's black victims, creates an interesting picture: that of wealthy white South Africans with their often lavish life style expecting the American taxpayer to subsidize these white foreigners, who are responsible for apartheid's misery in the first place.
Such a picture is not entirely uncharitable to white South Africa, for its whites have shown a strong reluctance to make any reparations to the blacks for apartheid's shameful exploitations. Development Minister Gerritt Viljoen, for instance, has insisted that there will be "no expropriation of land without compensation" to its legal (under apartheid's laws) owners. Apartheid -- especially including the historically false "homelands" system -- apportions 35 times more land to whites, per person, than to blacks. Blacks made poor by apartheid will be expected to buy back their own land from whites made rich by apartheid. 
 And the blacks are poor indeed through apartheid. Last October it was disclosed that on a large fruit farm, one of whose trustees is President F. W. de Klerk, black workers were being paid barely $40 a month for a 60-hour week and were fined $15 if they ate any of the fruit they picked.
It is rarely realized outside South Africa that by corralling, with racist laws, nearly all South Africa's good farmland and most of its vast mineral riches for themselves, the white South Africans' debt to the blacks runs into dozens of billions of dollars. (Example: some years ago The Financial Mail of South Africa reported that each year, whites profited by $2 billion from land transactions and rent, while five times as many blacks had effectively no income from land at all.)
Apartheid has made its white creators enormously rich. They should be made to pay their own debts, at last. To pay the blacks a proper wage for a hard day's work might be a good start.
 
LEN CLARKE
Uxbridge, England, April 19, 1991

HEADLINE: Arizona Catacombs Yield Clues to a Vanished People

BYLINE: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD

DATELINE: SPRINGERVILLE, Ariz.

 BODY:
FROM the rim of the broad mesa, as a dust devil whistled its way across dry grassland like a whirling apparition, John W. Hohmann looked down the slope on the stone ruins of a prehistoric pueblo. Some 700 years ago this was a village of the Mogollon, a hunting and farming people. Now it was his archeological domain.
Few sites of pre-Columbian life in North America explored in recent years have aroused so much curiosity and excitement, even extravagant expectations and simmering controversy. Archeologists expect the ruins, called Casa Malpais, to cast new light on the mysterious Mogollon (pronounced MUG-gy-own), who seemingly vanished by the year 1450.
But here they lived for more than a century, hunting deer and antelope on the mesa and growing corn and beans in the green valley of the Little Colorado River below. On natural terraces, formed of collapsed basalt from an ancient volcano, they built a housing complex of stone, clay, timbers and brush. They erected an unusually large kiva, or ceremonial building, whose size marks it as a possible religious center. 
 "We don't know where these people went or what happened to them," said Mr. Hohmann, an archeologist with the private consulting company of Louis Berger and Associates in Phoenix. "That's a mystery we hope to solve."
Deep beneath the dwellings and kiva lay the most astonishing surprise, which Mr. Hohmann and two other archeologists discovered last summer. Crawling and squeezing through natural fissures in the dull reddish basalt, they came upon sacred chambers where the Mogollon had interred their dead.
In an announcement to the Society of American Archeology two weeks ago, Mr. Hohmann described the burial chambers as catacombs and said these were the first known to have been used by prehistoric people north of Mexico. Other archeologists agree that catacombs had not been found before in the United States.
"We've seen that Indians used caves for burials," Mr. Hohmann said. "But we've never heard about these types of fissures being so culturally modified. All that labor and community effort to seal up the chambers, conceal entrances and make other architectural changes is truly remarkable."
Except for the discoverers, visitors are not allowed in the catacombs, out of respect for the dead. Yet the magnitude of the discovery can be sensed by climbing down a ladder into a nearby cavern that was presumably never used for burials. One narrow chamber opened into a larger one, some 20 feet high, 30 feet long and no more than 12 feet wide, flanked by walls of basalt smooth and cool to the touch.
Mr. Hohmann said that he and his colleagues, Diane E. White and Christopher D. Adams, had explored three to four acres of intricate catacombs similar to this cavern. A few of the rooms were 50 feet high and 100 feet long. The Mogollon had carefully laid stones in the terrain above to close cracks in the ceilings.
Several hundred graves were found -- bones arranged under stone cairns, in stone cribs and in wall niches. Once there may have been even more human remains, and possibly ceramics, tools and other artifacts. But no such grave goods have been uncovered. The archeologists suspect looters got there first.
 Nevertheless, the find is seen as an economic godsend in Springerville, a town of fewer than 2,000 people about two miles from the ruins.
Officials of Springerville estimate that if Casa Malpais could become a national park or monument, it would bring in $3 million to $5 million annually from tourism. People have opened a small museum on Main Street, offering tours of the ruins. In addition to the usual rodeo on the Fourth of July, a promotion of local archeology will feature an Indiana Jones look-alike contest for children.
 
Tough Time in Rural America
 State archeologists are apprehensive that modern Indians, sensitive to any appearance of desecration of ancestral remains and sacred places, will be angry. Other archeologists have begun to quibble over the use of the word "catacombs" to characterize the burial site.
Mr. Hohmann winces at comparisons with the fictional archeological swashbuckler that find their way into many news reports. He is a young archeologist completing his doctoral dissertation at Arizona State University, not on lost arks, but on the social complexity of ancient Americans.
The dig was commissioned and partly financed by Springerville and the neighboring town of Eagar to lay the groundwork for a recreational park that would capitalize on the ruins, long known to local people but never fully explored by scientists. In compliance with the National Historic Preservation Act of 1966, the site had to be investigated for archeological treasures before development.
Mr. Hohmann said the plan he was drawing up was for the conservation of the ruins, along with some continuing scientific research, within a park setting. Local people hope this will attract tourists to this out-of-the-way place near the New Mexico border, four to five hours' drive from any major city.
Brandee Snyder, a volunteer working at the museum, said: "This is rural America, and we're having a tough time economically. The lumber mill is closed. We see this as a chance that people won't have to leave our community."
But the hoopla puts Mr. Hohmann in an embarrassing position because it came swiftly before he could inform modern Native Americans of the discovery.
 
Amicable Pacts With Tribes
 Lynn Teague, a curator at the Arizona State Museum in Tucson, said that some of the tribes "are very distressed by all the publicity," though their representatives have yet to make any public comments about the catacombs. Under a new state law, archeologists are supposed to notify officials of all 20 Indian tribes in Arizona when any human remains are excavated. Even though the law was not in effect when the catacombs were found, Mrs. Teague said the museum was inviting the tribes to send representatives to inspect Casa Malpais and discuss their concerns.
As many as 40 states now have similar laws, and Federal legislation went into effect last year regulating the handling of human remains found on Government lands and by federally financed institutions. Indian skeletons and grave goods already in museums must be returned to tribes for reburial, if requested.
Dr. Dennis Stanford, an anthropologist at the Smithsonian Institution who specializes in prehistoric America, said that so far negotiations with tribes have ended amicably. Cave burials found recently in the Aleutian Islands were being investigated with the cooperation of the Aleuts, he said.
Mr. Hohmann's dealings with fellow archeologists could also turn bumpy. Several researchers have expressed doubts that the discovery qualifies as true catacombs, a subterranean cemetery consisting of galleries with recesses for tombs.
"I have mixed feelings about calling them catacombs," said Dr. Charles A. Hoffman, professor of archeology at Northern Arizona University in Flagstaff. "When we say catacombs, we think of Rome and the early Christians and their elaborate underground burial chambers."
Miss White, one of the discoverers, stands by the designation. "There's always debate in archeology over definitions," she said. "What else would you call underground features with human remains that have clearly been modified by people to serve as a burial place?"
But no one is disputing the potential significance of the ruins of Casa Malpais.
Dr. Stanford said the pueblo, kiva and catacombs "might give us a whole new look at Mogollon society, its organization and structure and rituals, none of which is well known."
"In terms of ethnohistory," Dr. Hoffman said, "the discoveries are important because they will be filling a gap in our knowledge between the historic Indians, like the Zuni, and the earlier prehistoric people."
Three distinctive prehistoric cultures dominated the American Southwest between the years 300 and 1450. In southern Arizona and northern Mexico lived the Hohokam, whose descendants may include the modern Papagos. Across northern Arizona and New Mexico and into Utah and Colorado, the Anasazi were the master builders of pueblos on the sides of canyon walls. The Mogollon were a mountain people living mainly in central Arizona and New Mexico. The Zuni and Tarhuamar Indians are thought to be their descendants.
Dr. Edward B. Danson, director of the Museum of Northern Arizona at Flagstaff, surveyed the Casa Malpais site in 1948 as part of the Harvard Peabody Museum's Upper Gila expedition. Told of the ruins by local people, he climbed there and found the stone walls of the kiva still standing, the foundations of several dwellings and a staircase leading to the mesa above.
But busy archeologists never gave it a second thought, until the people of Springerville decided they wanted to turn it into a park. Mr. Hohmann's team began systematic excavations at Casa Malpais last summer and expects to continue another year or two. The archeologists have found the stone outlines of as many as 100 rooms in a kind of apartment-building complex where the people lived. Some of the rooms are small, no more than 6 feet by 9, with some others much larger. In one room being excavated, a fireplace is visible in the center and fragments of pottery have been collected.
 
Too Early for Conclusions
 Mr. Hohmann said the typical dwelling had walls of boulders and clay mortar and roofs of poles and brush. Wood fragments buried there have enabled scientists at the University of Arizona, examining tree rings, to date the construction to as early as 1265. Ceramics indicate that the village must have been abandoned soon after 1380.
Most of the dwellings are on the same terrace with the great kiva. Remains of its stone walls stand 6 feet high and reveal that the building was about 50 feet square, an impressive size for such ceremonial centers. A bench of stone and clay bordered the interior wall on all sides, and in the center is a depression where the fireplace had been.
Among the pottery uncovered are reddish-brown jars and bowls typical of Mogollon culture. But others have black and white geometric designs that archeologists believe indicate the Mogollon had considerable contact with the Anasazi to the north. The pueblo architecture also appears to show an Anasazi influence.
On the lower terraces, Mr. Hohmann said, areas cleared of stone are thought to have been gardens. But the people probably did most of their farming along the river, their one reliable source of water.
 
Drought May Be the Culprit
 A rift in one of the higher terraces provides a protected area where, as grinding stones indicate, the people must have prepared their corn meal and made stone tools. On the walls are drawings of animals, including a huge centipede, and human footprints and "stick men" figures. Also, vandals have left graffiti.
Archeologists suspect that devastating drought, not defeat by intruders, eventually drove the Mogollon from Casa Malpais.
Mr. Hohmann climbed over huge chunks of basalt toward the rear of the pueblo and the face of the cliff. He reached the hidden staircase Dr. Danson had described. It spiraled upward between walls of rock. The Mogollon had laid smooth stepping stones and chipped out handholds right where they were indispensable.
At the top of the mesa, Mr. Hohmann could watch the archeologists bent at their digging in the baking sun. Beyond was the valley of the White Mountains where the Apache, a nomadic hunting people, came to replace the Mogollon, and then Spanish sheepherders replaced the Apache and finally the pioneer Henry Springer established his trading post in 1879 -- one broad vista of prehistory and history.

HEADLINE: Heads That Roll if Computers Fail

BYLINE: By GLENN RIFKIN

 BODY:
The last decade has brought chief information officers, the executives who manage corporate computer systems, into the upper ranks of their companies. But their prominence has come with a price: When something with the computers goes wrong, they often get the blame and the dismissal notices.
Martin Stein arrived at the BankAmerica Corporation 10 months ago as the fourth chief information officer in six years. Mr. Stein professes to be unafraid. "At Paine Webber, there were eight C.I.O.'s in six years," he said, referring to his previous post. "I consider this job low risk." 
 Mr. Stein's experience is hardly unusual. More than a third of 600 chief information officers said in a survey that their predecessors had been dismissed or demoted, according to Deloitte & Touche, the consulting and accounting firm.
The chief information officers, who go by a variety of formal titles, have become vulnerable as computer networks grow more sophisticated and companies' demands on them multiply. Cost-conscious companies whose systems fail to meet their sometimes extravagant expectations often hold their chief information officers responsible.
More top executives are learning enough about computers to become dangerous to those directly responsible for the machines. "The mystique is coming out of information technology," said DuWayne Peterson, the chief information officer at Merrill Lynch. "This puts some C.I.O.'s at risk because they once had a niche that no one else understood."
But some computer managers themselves say the turnover results as much from their own failings as from scapegoating. Trained as technicians, they must think more like other business people to survive.
"There is a fundamental change happening in the profession," said Michael Simmons, group vice president in charge of technology and operations at the Bank of Boston. "Technology is changing so fast that we haven't learned how to manage it. C.I.O.'s have to become managers rather than tech nerds and a lot just don't make that transition."
More chief executives are asking the question many computer managers dread: What is the company getting for all that money? Though corporations continue to spend billions of dollars on technology, white-collar productivity has stagnated. No longer are chief executives confident that throwing computers at their office staffs will result in greater efficiency, said Stephen Roach, an economist at Morgan Stanley. Major computer suppliers, including the International Business Machines Corporation, are facing declining sales, especially for their largest systems.
"If the C.I.O. cannot reduce his own cost structure, then he is destined to extinction," Mr. Roach said. "Information technology has to be directed, bottom line, to productivity enhancement."
The current recession is causing many chief executives to take a harder look at technology spending. Computer managers have to justify every dollar of what, for many companies, is the single largest capital expense. In a recent survey of 200 chief executives and chief financial officers by Computerworld newspaper and Andersen Consulting, more than half doubted that their companies were getting the full benefit of their computer investments.
 
'Serious Technology Bets'
 Chief information officers are often buried under an avalanche of technological change. New computer architectures, networking, open systems, and powerful desktop computers linked to even more powerful, specialized machines called servers confound anyone trying to make decisions as simply as they did a decade ago. "There are serious technology bets that have to be placed in most corporations now," said Bill Laberis, editor of Computerworld, a leading industry publication. "Is the profession up to handling this change? In many cases, the answer is no."
In the 1980's, the failure of many companies to achieve major advantages over their competitors after investing heavily in computers damaged the reputations of many computer managers. As professional information systems people, "we have just about lost it," said Henry Spencer, assistant vice president of Cigna Systems, the computer operations of the Cigna Corporation. "There are countless examples in most major corporations of late or never-completed projects and cost overruns."
H. Ross Perot, chairman of Perot Data Systems, said many major computer projects were ill conceived. "They went from massive funding to massive implementation to failure," Mr. Perot said.
Many new computer managers find they have to clean up messes left behind by predecessors or consultants. Mr. Simmons -- who preceded Mr. Stein at BankAmerica before joining the Bank of Boston a year ago -- found the Boston company using 11 different brands of large computers. "They were shell-shocked," Mr. Simmons said. "They had listened to a consultant in the mid-1980's who told them to decentralize everything, and they didn't realize they would have to put everything back together eventually." He has already cut back to seven computer makers, and plans to end up with four.
Mr. Simmons is used to inheriting snarled systems. At BankAmerica, he stepped in after management had scuttled an $80 million system designed to automate the employee benefits and trust departments.
The most savvy technology managers now speak of re-engineering company operations, not just computerizing antiquated processes. For 25 years, the old data processing departments focused on automating backroom procedures. "We automated everything just because it was there," Mr. Simmons said. "We were taking the same bandy-legged horse and putting him in a faster race."
Now, computer managers try to introduce new, streamlined techniques. The Ford Motor Company was able to cut its 500-member accounts payable department by 75 percent. Rather than having rows of clerks manually match suppliers' invoices with Ford's purchase orders and receipt records, then authorize payment, a constantly updated computer data base matches purchase orders and receipts automatically -- with no invoices required -- and the computer authorizes payment.
Not that such thorough changes are easy to bring about. As F. Warren McFarlan, a Harvard Business School expert in information technology, said, "People look at glitzy examples of technology implementation and they overlook how complex it is to drive these processes through."
Many large companies, searching for ways to cut costs, have turned their computer operations over to outsiders like I.B.M., Electronic Data Systems or Perot Data Systems. Earlier this month, Continental Airlines signed a 10-year agreement handing over its computer reservation system to E.D.S. Such "outsourcing" has many chief information officers worried about the future of their departments.
Proponents of outsourcing point to potential savings. Kathy Hudson, chief information officer at the Eastman Kodak Company, said the company's agreement in late 1989 for I.B.M. to run its data center has cut annual capital spending on technology to $3 million from nearly $60 million. The collaboration has succeeded beyond all expectations, she said, although she would not disclose I.B.M.'s fee.
But some managers point to companies whose own computer staffs have scored major victories. John Hammitt, the chief information officer of the United Technologies Corporation, mentions American Airlines' Sabre reservation system and American Hospital Supply's ASAP system for delivering orders. "Technology can be a powerful weapon and still bring competitive advantage," he said. "We'll have a few more surprises in the next few years."
Many in the industry, however, have grown tired of hearing about these same few examples over and over. Max Hopper, the chief information officer of American Airlines responsible for much of Sabre's success, says that the era when large new computer systems can bring insurmountable advantages is over. "Hitting the big home runs has become almost impossible," because computer technology has become so pervasive, he said.
 
In the Middle
 Competitive pressures are squeezing computer systems managers as never before, he said. "Introducing change is tough," Mr. Hopper said. "If the C.I.O. drives it too fast, the C.E.O. hears complaints that systems is buying technology just for technology's sake. But if he doesn't move fast enough, he hears how Company X down the street just put in a new whiz-bang system and why don't we have it here."
Consultants say that instead of blaming chief information officers for every glitch, senior managers ought to become more involved in their computer departments.
But the top executives most likely to stay involved and support their computer managers are those who once managed computer operations themselves. "The best systems are in companies where the C.E.O. once had responsibility for technology and understood what systems could do," Mr. Perot said. "When a C.E.O. wants something new, he should spend time with the systems people rather than send it through three levels of command."

HEADLINE: Despite Rights Issue, Chinese Hope U.S. Trade Status Stays

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIJING

 BODY:
As a battle looms in Washington over whether to end normal trade relations with China, many Chinese are finding themselves reluctantly siding with their hard-line rulers in hoping that the status is maintained.
While they appreciate the concern for human rights in their country and hope that the debate will force the Government to become less repressive, some worry that a cutoff of so-called most-favored-nation status would hurt their standard of living, harm the most reformist segments of the economy and prompt the hard-liners to restrict contacts with the United States. 
 It is impossible to be sure of public opinion in so vast and tightly controlled a country as China. But in informal conversations with dozens of Chinese in several parts of the country over recent months, most of those who were aware of the issue did not favor American economic sanctions and hoped that most-favored-nations benefits would be extended.
President Bush's annual recommendation on whether to renew the preferential trade status for China is required by June 3. He is expected to favor renewal, and opponents in Congress are expected to introduce legislation to overturn the decision.
In their first breath, urban Chinese intellectuals typically tell their trusted American friends how much they detest their leadership. In their second breath, they express affection for the United States and inquire about getting visas. And in their third breath, they worry that harsh American sanctions would hurt the Chinese people rather than their leaders.
"If I were President Bush, I would extend most-favored-nation status to China," said Zhang Weiguo, a Shanghai dissident who was unusual only in that he was willing to have his name published. "The U.S. should support China's economic development and social exchanges."
Mr. Zhang's anti-Government credentials are not in doubt. He was arrested after the 1989 Tiananmen crackdown and spent 20 months in prison before being released earlier this year, still unrepentant and fuming at the Government.
Mr. Zhang said the best result would be for a tough battle over Chinese trade in Washington, ending in an extension for another year. Such a close call would encourage China to make concessions on human rights and would leave the issue open for another fight next year, he said.
"Every year it's discussed, and that's very good," Mr. Zhang said. "It puts new pressure on China each year."
A downgrading of American trade links with China would mean a large rise in the tariffs imposed on Chinese goods shipped to the United States, and would hurt its thriving export sector. The south of China, which has the most developed private economy in the country, would be particularly affected, as would Hong Kong, through which Chinese goods usually pass for packaging or transshipment.
Many dissidents say they would like the United States and other countries to be even more outspoken in supporting Chinese human rights. Above all, they would like Prime Minister Li Peng and other hard-liners to lose "face."But they worry that economic sanctions are the wrong method.
"People are very torn inside," said a university student in Beijing. "They want pressure on the Government to change its policies, and they want the leadership to eat bitterness. But on the other hand, they're afraid that if sanctions are imposed, it's the ordinary people who would suffer. So we want America to threaten sanctions to pressure China, but we don't want sanctions themselves."
 
Peasants Seem Less Aware
 Among Chinese peasants and workers, especially outside the capital, there seems to be much less awareness of the issue of sanctions, as well as less anger at the Government. Consequently, many people do not have clearly formed ideas on the subject, but frequently seem vaguely opposed to any sanctions that might compound the economic difficulties of the last couple of years. And some wealthier people fear that sanctions would make it more difficult to buy foreign products.
"The fear is that if M.F.N. were cut off, the price of a pack of Marlboros would go up," said an entrepreneur.

Bush Picks Envoy to China
 WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP) -- President Bush said today that he would nominate J. Stapleton Roy, a State Department officials, as Ambassador to China, succeeding James Rodrick Lilley.
Mr. Roy, 55 years old, of Bethesda, Md., is special assistant to Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and executive secretary of the State Department. A former Ambassador to Singapore, he was deputy chief of the United States liaison office and later the American mission in China from 1978 to 1981.
He was born in Nanjing of missionary parents.

HEADLINE: Port Newark: Busy Corner Of Commerce And Worries

BYLINE: By PETER KERR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEWARK, May 14

 BODY:
Everything seems outsized in the Port of New York and New Jersey, the docks around New York Harbor that have dominated the Atlantic maritime trade since the 1600's.
Here at Port Newark, the larger port's heart, an ship carrying orange juice arrives every month, brimming with enough concentrate to fill 40 million glasses. A Toyota ship disgorges 900 vehicles in a matter of hours. On other nearby docks, workers move mountains of salt, piles of Portuguese paving stones, hills of cars that have been flattened, cubed or diced into scrap. 
 "The port is an entire world of its own," said the Rev. Jean R. Smith of the Seaman's Institute Church, one of two churches that minister to the thousands of sailors who dock at the major slips in Newark and Elizabeth, just across the New Jersey Turnpike from Newark International Airport. "Most people drive by and only see planes landing at the airport. They have no idea of what goes on here."
 
Half-Billion Dollars
 Each day more than 15,000 trucks enter the main cargo areas here through gates that look much like highway toll booths. A computer system directs each of the truck cabs to one of the thousands of spaces where freight containers are parked. The 40-by-8-foot containers can hold 15 tons or more of cargo, anything from M & M's to VCR's.
In recent years there the level of activity has been stable in the sprawling warehouses and docks that line not only the shorefront at Newark and Elizabeth but also smaller docks in Brooklyn and on Staten Island.
But in other ports, new trade patterns have increased the flow of cargo.
In 1981, New York handled cargo worth $11 billion more than Los Angeles and Long Beach combined. In 1989, the latest year for which figures are available, New York's $49 billion in goods was $6 billion less than in Los Angeles and only $7 billion more than in Long Beach. And on the East Coast, ports with less expensive operations for loading and unloading containerized cargo, like Halifax, Nova Scotia; Baltimore and Norfolk, Va., have cut heavily into New York's position as the premier port in the trans-Atlantic trade.
As a result, the agency that manages the port, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, plans to spend a half-billion dollars in the next five years to improve the harbor and its docks.
"We are in a real fight," said Stanley Brezenoff, the Port Authority's executive director. "We used to be the de facto port for the Eastern Seaboard. Now we have to fight for market share. But we believe with increased trade from the European Community after 1992 and the opening of Eastern Europe, we can greatly increase our role."
For most New Yorkers, consciousness of New York Harbor as a sea cargo hub disappeared when cargo piers vanished from the West Side of Manhattan. They were replaced largely by new containerized operations in Newark and Elizabeth. In fact, the port seethes with activity year round and provides the metropolitan region with what the Port Authority estimates as more than 200,000 jobs.
 
Danglng From Ropes
 At dockside here in Newark, cranes 18 stories tall lower devices that look like giant four-legged spiders, which hook onto the corners of containers to raise or lower them off ships where they are stacked seven stories high.
Men known as lashers dangle from ropes as they secure the containers with rods, chains or cables in an occupation that is highly dangerous, particularly on winter days when all metal surfaces are coated with ice.
One section of the docks here is devoted to foodstuffs, including a pier that handles only bananas. At least once a month, a Brazilian freighter ties up at the orange juice dock, where hissing hoses suck out 400,000 gallons of cold concentrate, bright orange and thick as jam. Silver refrigerator trucks then carry the concentrate to factories around the region where every gallon is mixed with five gallons of water.
At another warehouse on the Newark docks, a factory melts, casts, rolls and coils 90,000 tons of copper tubing a year, enough copper, port officials estimate, to construct several hundred Statues of Liberty.
A short distance away ships built like floating parking lots discharge fleets of Japanese and European cars. Similar ships load American automobiles that have been shipped by train from factories across the United States for export.
Not everything here takes on gargantuan dimensions. Next to the offices of the Foreign Auto Preparation Service, a family-owned business that prepares 100,000 imported cars each year for delivery to dealers, John LoBue, the company's president, maintains a tiny garden with strawberry and tomato plants, an apple tree and a small waterfall.
 
Floating Parking Lots
 "After years of looking at automobiles," Mr. LoBue said as he stood in front of a shipment of Chevrolet Caprices being prepared for shipment to Kuwait, "I wanted to see something more than automobiles."
Although New York has remained the largest port on the Atlantic, receiving more than 5,200 ships a year, high labor costs have put it at an economic disadvantage in competing for the imports and exports of America's industries.
The port's labor costs date back to the 1960's when the system of shipping cargo loose in a ship's hold, or break bulk, was replaced by shipping in containers. Although far fewer dockworkers were required to load and unload containerized cargo, the surplus unionized workers continued through an assessment on all containers passing through the port.
In the agreement with the International Longshoremen's Association, more than 20,000 dockworkers were guaranteed employment although far fewer workers were needed -- the largest ship requires 60 to 80 workers. Through deaths and retirements, the port now employs about 5,200 longshoremen although, James Malone, the general manager of the port's New Jersey Marine Terminals, said the port needs only about 4,000.
 
New York as Target
 The ports' labor costs have now begun to decline, officials say. But in recent years the quality of services at competing ports has been vastly improved.
"Ports like Halifax, Norfolk and Baltimore were making hundreds of million of dollars in investments in facilities," said Lillian Liburdi, the director of the agency's port department. "New York has been the target."
The Port Authority's plans call for the dredging of a 40-foot channel to accommodate new cargo vessels with deeper drafts. It also plans to improve warehouses, add new rail lines that will take trains onto the docks and establish a new computer system that will give customers instant information on where their cargo is and when it is expected to arrive.
Such expansions are expected to strain further the two churches that minister to the thousands of sailors passing through, a Catholic Stella Maris Chapel, a church in a trailer with a steeple, and the Seaman's Institute Church, which provides Protestant ministers, a restaurant and a gift shop.
Ms. Smith, an Episcopal minister, said many sailors arrive at her church racked by loneliness, often desperate to phone home to learn of births, deaths and the health of family members. The church provides telephones for sailors to call home, and when ships remain in port for only several hours, church members go on board to take cellular phones to the seamen.
The church has also married sailors, counseled stowaways and helped seamen quickly obtain everything from perfume to a prosthesis.
"We are," she said, "a full-service ministry."

HEADLINE: Consumer Prices Up A Modest 0.2% in April

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 14

 BODY:
The prices that consumers pay for goods and services rose a modest two-tenths of 1 percent in April despite a sharp jump in food costs and the first increase in gasoline prices since November, the Government reported today.
The Labor Department said the small increase in its Consumer Price Index came after a rare drop of one-tenth of 1 percent in March and left consumer inflation rising at an annual rate of 2.5 percent through the first four months of the year. 
 The underlying "core" rate of inflation -- taking out the volatile food and energy sectors -- rose the same two-tenths of 1 percent in April after a rise of one-tenth in March.
 
Constrained by Weak Demand
 Analysts said producers had largely been unable to raise prices because of weak demand during the recession.
"Inflation is under control," said Sandra Shaber, an economist with the Futures Group. "The biggest worry is the recession and jobs."
The 2.5 percent annual rate of inflation in the first four months of this year compares with a 6.1 percent jump in prices during 1990, a time when the oil shock following Iraq's invasion of Kuwait sent energy prices spiraling.
In April, the Government said energy prices fell seven-tenths of 1 percent. But the decline was just one-third of the March drop. While declines were posted for home heating oil and natural gas, the cost of gasoline went up by two-tenths. Analysts said pump prices were rising even faster in May as oil companies raised prices at the start of the vacation driving season.
 
Vegetables and Fruits Higher
 Food prices rose seven-tenths of 1 percent in April, the biggest jump since a winter freeze sent prices shooting up in January. Nearly 95 percent of the April increase was attributed to higher vegetable and fruit prices. Vegetable costs were up 15.4 percent, the biggest rise in 15 months, with the increase attributed to adverse weather and insect problems harming tomato and corn crops in Florida.
Fruit costs were pushed higher by another increase in orange prices, which have risen 64.4 percent since the start of the year.
Analysts said that the moderation in the "core" inflation rate was particularly good news after a sharp jump in earlier months caused by increases in such things as women's clothing, postage stamps and alcoholic beverages.
For April, women's clothing prices fell by 1.4 percent although men's and children's clothing posted increases.
Costs for health care rose five-tenths of 1 percent, the smallest increase in two years.
Other categories showing major shifts included airline fares, down 6.2 percent, and entertainment costs, up seven-tenths of 1 percent, a price rise attributed to higher ticket costs for sporting events and movies. Tobacco prices were up 1.2 percent while school tuition costs rose 1.1 percent last month, reflecting higher costs for day care.
The various changes left the Consumer Price Index, before adjusting for seasonal factors, at 135.2 in April, up from 128.9 a year ago. That means that a market basket of goods costing $100 in the 1982-84 base period would have cost $135.20 last month, up from $128.90 in April 1990.

HEADLINE: C.D.'s and Bank Funds Down 11th Week

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields on certificates of deposit and money market accounts were down for the week ended yesterday, the 11th consecutive decline.
The size of the weekly drop was smaller than the week before, which followed a cut in bank prime rates. 
 Analysts at The Bank Rate Monitor said that at the current rate of decline, yields on bank money market accounts would be bumping against those offered on regular passbook accounts sometime in July.
The odds favor interest rates remaining flat for a long time when the bottom is finally reached, said Robert K. Heady, publisher of the interest-rate publication.
At the Treasury Department's weekly auction held Monday, the average discount rates were only slightly different from a week ago, but still at their lowest levels in three years. The results of these bill auctions often indicate what many banks may eventually pay on money market accounts and certificates of deposit.
The three-month bill was unchanged at 5.5 percent, while the six-month bill increased a couple of basis points, to 5.63 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
In The Bank Rate Monitor's weekly survey of banks in the New York area, declines reported at the commercial banks and savings insitutions were moderate in size.
The largest yield changes for banks in the New York area were recorded at the People's Bank of Connecticut, which cut 16 basis points off both the money market account and six-month certificate, to 5.38 percent and 5.92 percent, respectively. Goldome lowered the yield of its three-month certificate by a similar same amount, to 5.92 percent.
Commercial banks cut deposit yields slightly, compared with the cuts made by savings institutions. Money market accounts and three-month C.D.'s were lowered by 2 basis points, to 5.25 percent and 5.66 percent, respectively, while a six-month certificate slipped 3 basis points, to 5.79 percent.

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC SCENE;
Second Thoughts On Mexico Trade

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
THE campaign for "fast track" authority to negotiate a trade agreement with Mexico is nearly over, and the Administration seems headed for a lopsided victory. The President's strategy, a mix of high-minded talk about global competitiveness and coolly calculated concessions to interests ranging from anti-pesticide lobbyists to brewers, has apparently succeeded in isolating hard-core protectionists from the what's-in-it-for-my-district pragmatists.
But not every defender of free trade is breaking out the margaritas. One of the most articulate, Jagdish Bhagwati, an economist at Columbia University and the author of "The World Trading System at Risk" (Princeton University Press), is downright glum. The fight to open the border with Mexico is a diversion from the more important issue of global trade liberalization, he argues, "encouraging sloppy thinking that all trade is good." 
 Intractable opposition to the free-trade pact can be traced to the usual suspects: unions that fear competition from low-wage Mexican workers and a handful of industries that believe they can prosper only in a protectionist hothouse.
Mr. Bush did not challenge them head-on, preferring to rally the uncommitted with rosy visions of increased exports and decreased illegal immigration while quietly assuaging more parochial qualms. The Administration's 80-page "action plan" promises to hold Mexico to tough standards on pollution, child labor and worker safety. It also promises adequate financing for displaced worker programs. And it tosses a bouquet to agribusiness, which is promised quick relief if the competition grows too fierce, too fast. Mr. Bhagwati's objections are not so easily finessed. The point of open trade, he notes, is to increase the total value of output by allowing specialization in the goods that countries produce relatively cheaply. Opening one border in a world riddled with restrictions may actually reduce efficiency by diverting natural trade flows.
Without a free-trade agreement with the United States, Mexico might buy machine tools from Switzerland because they are cheaper than equivalent American equipment. But once the border is open, the higher tariff on Swiss tools would tip the competitive balance to American manufacturers.
This "trade diversion" argument has not been heard much since the 1960's, when economists tangled over the consequences of a European Common Market. And in the Mexican context, it has been dismissed as academic hairsplitting: The barriers scheduled for lowering, it is said, are simply not high enough to divert much trade.
But if that is indeed the case, Mr. Bhagwati wonders, why make a fuss about lowering the barriers a bit more? One answer is that the deal is more a symbol of solidarity with Mexico's President Carlos Salinas de Gortari than an economic imperative. President Salinas, it is argued, is opening Mexico's parochial economic culture to new ideas. He deserves every bit of help he can get.
But Mr. Bhagwati has a less attractive view on the symbolic consequences of blurring the distinction between the creation of a regional common market in the Americas and continuing efforts to liberalize global trading.
To build a winning coalition for the Mexican agreement, the Bush Administration accepted the premise that everything from air quality in Mexican cities to working conditions in Mexican factories were grist for bilateral negotiations. Such interference makes sense if the long-term goal is creating a single economy, Mr. Bhagwati acknowledges. But making economic harmonization a precondition of liberalized trade with one country would be a dangerous precedent for the more important Uruguay Round world trade negotiations.
As a practical matter, giving environmentalists or workplace safety advocates seats at the table would make it more difficult to cut a deal acceptable to dozens of countries. But Mr. Bhagwati's objections go beyond the mechanics of negotiation: Economic diversity, he argues, is the force that drives mutually beneficial trade. Eliminate the diversity, and the gains from trade diminish.
Diversity is a slippery notion. Someone, after all, must draw the line between, say, the outrage of slave labor and the disappointing failure to encourage collective bargaining. Someone must distinguish between the wholesale slaughter of elephants and timber policies that endanger a species of owl.
But no matter where one comes out, Mr. Bhagwati has a point. If free trade with Mexico means a lot more commerce, trade diversion ought to be taken seriously. If the gains are largely symbolic, the President may have a tough time explaining why the Mexican negotiations should not be a precedent for global talks.

HEADLINE: CONGRESS PANELS VOTE TO ADVANCE FREE-TRADE PLAN

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 14

 BODY:
House and Senate committees voted overwhelmingly today to endorse negotiations for a free-trade agreement with Mexico and a new round of lowering of international trade barriers, opening the way for passage by both houses before the end of next week.
Members of Congress on both sides of the issue described the Administration's authority to negotiate trade agreements as probably the most important and contentious economic problem facing policy makers this year. 
 Appearances by Administration officials across the country have been picketed by union and environmental advocates opposed mainly to the free-trade agreement with Mexico. But today's votes gave the Administration unexpectedly wide margins, making passage very likely, although not guaranteed. The House Ways and Means Committee voted 27 to 9, and the Senate Finance Committee voted 15 to 3.
 
Pressure by White House
 The Administration had arranged hundreds of interviews for the President and his top aides to meet members of Congress, and had sent groups of Cabinet officials to appear before several Congressional hearings each day in seeking renewal of the President's "fast track authority," which expires on June 1.
Today's votes supported the Administration by rejecting resolutions to cancel the President's fast-track authority to negotiate trade agreements over the next two years and submit each agreement to a single vote in Congress with no amendments allowed. If neither chamber of Congress passes such a resolution by end of this month, the fast-track authority is renewed automatically.
One factor that helped the Administration today is that fast-track authority calls for the Administration to consult extensively with members of both committees before submitting any trade agreement to Congress. But given the continuous rivalry among House and Senate committees, some lawmakers who are not on those committees may be less enthusiastic about renewing the authority.
Nevertheless, support for renewing the Administration's fast-track authority has broadened considerably in the last two weeks for other reasons, as well. One is the continued wide acceptance of free-trade principles among economists and other intellectuals, which has put constant pressure on opponents of the negotiating authority.
"You're almost unpatriotic," said Representative Byron L. Dorgan, Democrat of North Dakota, an opponent. "You're not looking out for this country's interest, it's almost a shameful thing to be labeled a protectionist."
Also, Democrats grew worried about offending the fast-growing Hispanic vote, particularly in border states where trade with Mexico is important, The Administration has tried to exploit that issue. And after a slow start, corporations that depend on exports organized a lobbying blitz to counter a similar effort that organized labor began late last year.
On the other side, unions and environmental groups have argued that an agreement with Mexico might result in many United States companies moving their factories south of the border to take advantage of lower wages and less vigorous enforcement of environmental protection statutes. Textile interests have opposed fast-track authority because negotiations on international reductions in trade barriers have led to a tentative agreement eliminating many United States restrictions on textile imports.
The Administration has contended that free trade will allow the continued expansion of American exports, which accounted for five-sixths of last year's growth in the United States economy.
Senator Lloyd Bentsen, the Texas Democrat who is chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, said President Carlos Salinas de Gortari of Mexico was committed to closer ties with the United States, "That's an opportunity we must seize," he said. "If we don't, we'll regret it well into the next century."
The margins in today's committee votes were "pretty solid," said Victoria Clarke, a spokeswoman for the United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, whose office negotiates trade accords. But Administration officials will maintain their intensive effort to win Congressional support, she added.
 
Floor Vote Cited
 Rex Hardesty, a spokesman for the A.F.L.-C.I.O., contended that the committee votes were relatively meaningless. "It's what comes next on the floor of either chamber that really matters," he said.
Indeed, Representatives and Senators who do not belong to these committees are jealous of the special role of the panels, and may vote against fast-track authority on the floor of both houses, Administration officials and their allies in Congress conceded.
A vote in the committee for fast-track authority "protects the jurisdictional exclusivity of the Finance Committee," said Senator Donald W. Riegle Jr., Democrat of Michigan, who cast one of the three votes against fast-track authority in the finance committee.
Senator Riegle, who represents a state in which the United Automobile Workers have rallied strong opposition to a trade agreement with Mexico, has contended that Congress should retain the right to amend a free-trade agreement with Mexico in five key areas. they are labor standards, environmental protection, assistance for displaced workers, the resolution of transborder disputes and provisions to prevent third countries from evading United States import duties by shipping goods through Mexico.
 
Full Debate Backed
 The Senate majority leader, George J. Mitchell, Democrat of Maine, introduced a new element of uncertainty into the legislative future of the issue today when he indicated an interest in allowing Senator Riegle to present his proposal for debate on the floor of the full Senate.
The Administration won over several key legislators by staging a tactical retreat two weeks ago. After insisting repeatedly that any conditions for the renewal of fast-track authority would tie the hands of United States negotiators, the Administration announced on May 1 that it would pursue certain goals in talks with Mexico.
President Bush said in a letter then that the Administration would seek cooperation in improving the environment along the border and would provide some assistance to workers displaced by a trade agreement. Several key legislators, notably the House majority leader, Representative Richard A. Gephardt, Democrat of Missouri, have since lent their support to the renewal of fast-track authority.
 
Slurs Are Charged
 Issues of racism have given a bitter tinge in the last few days to the debate. In a speech on Sunday, the President criticized the use of slurs against Mexicans. At a U.A.W. rally protesting the agreement in Cleveland early last week, the hall was decorated with a large banner showing President Bush in a sombrero and other traditional Mexican garb. "Put Bush on the fast track -- to Mexico," the banner said.
Two New York Democrats on the Ways and Means Committee, Representatives Thomas J. Downey and Charles B. Rangel, criticized the President's remarks today as inappropriately highlighting racial issues. Representative Gephardt made a similar complaint on Monday.
After voting down the resolution to cancel the President's fast-track authority, the House Ways and Means Committee passed on a voice vote a resolution calling on the Administration to consult with Congress during the negotiations and to follow the negotiation plan it presented on May 1. Representative Gephardt and Representative Dan Rostenkowski, Democrat of Illinois and chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, co-sponsored the resolution, which is widely perceived as a sop to organized labor.

HEADLINE: Retail Sales Data Viewed as Sign That Economic Decline Is Halting

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 14

 BODY:
Evidence mounted today that the economy has halted its slide and that the improvement already under way in housing may have begun to spread.
The Government revised its retail sales figures for March to show a rise of four-tenths of 1 percent instead of an eight-tenths drop and it said sales essentially held this gain in April. 
 "It certainly is going in the direction of an upturn," said Rosanne M. Cahn, an economist at the First Boston Corporation, citing recent increases in industrial production, consumer sentiment and corporate purchasing as well as housing. "Perhaps the economy bottomed in April, but, if not, it will probably be May or June."
The relative strength in retail sales disclosed today by the Commerce Department appeared to touch off declines in both the bond and stock markets, reflecting diminished chances that the Federal Reserve will need to cut interest rates again to arrest the economic decline and spur a recovery. Stocks, which have been anticipating a recovery since early in the year, are now taking their cue from interest rates. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 37.57 points to end at 2,886.85.
Some analysts, however, contended that today's bond market selloff was more the result of excess supplies of bonds than fears of an economic rebound that might heat up inflation.
The Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee, its chief policy-setting body, met privately today to fix the course of monetary policy for the next seven weeks. It did so against the background of a separate report today showing that consumer prices rose a modest two-tenths of 1 percent in April, both over all and excluding the frequently wide-swinging food and energy components. [Page D6.]
The inflation figures suggested that the Fed had some maneuvering room if it wanted to push rates down, but the figures on retail sales, which account for one-third of all economic activity, suggested the economy was pulling out of the recession without the need for more rate cuts.
On the other hand, another report today showed that the sales of North American-made cars and trucks during the first 10 days of May fell 18.3 percent from levels a year earlier as the automobile industry continued to see only sporadic signs of a turnaround.
Some of the forces currently weighing on the auto sector seem likely to hold back the recovery, which nearly all analysts -- whether they expect the recession to end in the spring, summer or even later -- believe will be far less robust than has typified postwar contractions. Among other things, debts are burdensome, baby-boom spenders are entering middle age and incomes are squeezed.
 
Sales at $151.5 Billion
 Nonetheless, the retail report showed that sales in April totaled $151.5 billion, only a slight one-tenth of 1 percent below the $151.7 billion to which March was raised from an initial estimate of $149.6 billion. Sales for February were also lifted by a revision, to $151.1 billion from $150.8 billion.
Excluding the automotive sector, which showed a small upturn in the April report, sales last month were down two-tenths of 1 percent, while March sales were unchanged after being estimated initially at a decline of eight-tenths.
Sales of durable goods, those expected to last a minimum of three years, climbed six-tenths of 1 percent last month, paced by items related to housing. Merchants selling building materials, hardware, garden supplies and mobile homes posted a 3.5 percent gain and those selling furniture and other home equipment showed an increase of 1.8 percent.
The increase for automotive dealers was three-tenths of 1 percent. That is less than the 1.8 percent jump now reported for March, but much better than the drop of nine-tenths of a percent originally reported for that month.
Sales of nondurables, however, fell five-tenths of 1 percent, roughly offsetting the advance in durable goods. Most of this drop reflected a 1 percent decline for food stores and a 2.8 percent fall at gasoline service stations.
 
'Trading Down' Seen
 A Commerce Department analyst could not account for the lower food and gasoline sales but speculated that some of the decline might reflect consumers "trading down" during the recession by buying, say, cheaper cuts of meat or lower-octane gasoline. The Labor Department's report showed gasoline prices rose slightly last month.
Adding to the mystery was the fact that food-store sales in April were 1.4 percent above those of April 1990, down sharply from a 3.4 percent year-over-year increase in March.
Sales at drugstores eased three-tenths of 1 percent but there were gains of 2.1 percent at stores selling apparel and accessories and five-tenths at eating and drinking establishments. Stores selling general merchandise showed no change from March levels.
 
Revision Broadly Based
 The upward revision for March was broadly based, with durable goods now showing a 1.3 percent gain for the month instead of a nine-tenths of 1 percent decline and nondurables, a one-tenth drop instead of eight-tenths.
For February through April, sales were 1.1 percent higher than in the comparable 1990 period, but this does not allow for inflation that raised prices 4.9 percent over the last 12 months.
The upward revisions for February and March will also affect the gross national product, which was estimated last month to have fallen at a rate of 2.8 percent in the first quarter. According to Kathleen M. Camilli, an economist at Maria Ramirez Capital Consultants, the G.N.P. is now likely to be down only about half as much.
In a report related to the Consumer Price Index, the Labor Department calculated today that real average weekly earnings fell one-tenth of 1 percent in April as declines in hours worked and increases in prices were not fully offset by an increase in average hourly earnings.

HEADLINE: First Capital Unit Seized In California

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, May 14

 BODY:
State regulators today seized the California insurance subsidiary of the First Capital Holdings Corporation after an attempt by Citibank, the troubled company's main lender, to force it into involuntary bankruptcy.
The California Insurance Commissioner, John Garamendi, said he had taken the action to keep Citibank's claim from endangering the ability of the subsidiary, the First Capital Life Insurance Company, to pay policyholders. First Capital Holdings and its insurance units have been stung in recent months by defaults in their portfolios of "junk bonds" and by consumers' fears about the insurers' ability to honor their commitments. 
 Mr. Garamendi had put First Capital Life under harsh operating restrictions last week after a wave of requests by customers to cash in policies. On Monday, regulators in Virginia seized First Capital Holdings' other subsidiary, the Fidelity Bankers Life Insurance Company, after a similar surge in policy surrenders.
Citibank is the lead bank in a syndicate that lent $275 million to First Capital Holdings. It filed a petition with the Federal Bankruptcy Court in Los Angeles late Monday seeking to have First Capital Holdings placed under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code. Under Chapter 11, a company operates under court supervision and is shielded from claims while it develops a plan to pay creditors. The petition could be opposed by the company and has not been acted on by the court.
Citibank said in a statement that it took the action along with other lenders "in an attempt to protect the bank group's rights." By trying to force First Capital Holdings into bankruptcy, the bank hoped to bolster its claim for repayment.
First Capital Holdings said in a statement that it was "now considering all of its options," but would not elaborate.
At a news conference in Sacramento, Mr. Garamendi said he seized the insurer "to protect the assets of First Capital Life and the savings and benefits of hundreds of thousands of policyholders from being ensnared in Citibank's attempt to place First Capital Holdings in involuntary bankruptcy."
First Capital Life has assets of $4.5 billion. It has 190,000 life insurance policyholders and 62,000 annuity holders in 49 states. Fidelity Bankers has $4.1 billion in assets, 213,000 life insurance policyholders and 97,000 annuity holders nationwide.
 
Insurer 'Walled Off'
 In a telephone interview, Mr. Garamendi said the bankruptcy petition "required us to wall off the insurance company from the holding company."
First Capital Life will continue to pay all death benefits and other policy claims and will make regular payments to annuity holders, Mr. Garamendi said. The freeze on policy surrenders imposed last week will remain in effect, he said.
Mr. Garamendi said negotiations were continuing with the American Express Company and its Shearson Lehman brokerage subsidiary on a plan to restore First Capital to health. Shearson owns a 28 percent stake in First Capital Holdings and sold many First Capital Life policies to its customers. Mr. Garamendi said the negotiations also included Citibank.
 
Shearson Resists Demands
 Shearson said last week that it would take a $144 million charge to write off its investment in First Capital Holdings. Shearson and American Express have so far resisted Mr. Garamendi's demands that they help to bail out First Capital Life.
Mr. Garamendi said today that American Express and Shearson "have been very cooperative in the process of restructuring the financial foundation" of First Capital Life. But he said they may not inject additional capital into the insurer as part of the restructuring.
People who have been briefed on the discussions said Shearson had proposed alternative plans to replace two that Mr. Garamendi rejected last week. But those plans were said to be intended only to protect Shearson customers, a fact that led to the rejection of the original initiatives.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
First Executive Filing
 LOS ANGELES, May 14 (Reuters) -- The First Executive Corporation, the insurance holding company whose operations were seized by state regulators last month, has filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection.
The company announced the filing late Monday, but gave no details. The papers were filed with the Federal Bankruptcy Court in Los Angeles.
On April 11, California's Insurance Commissioner put the Executive Life Insurance Company under control of an outside conservator, hoping to fashion a rescue plan for the unit, which has assets of $10.2 billion. New York State regulators, meanwhile, seized another First Executive unit, the Executive Life Insurance Company of New York.
The failure of the insurance subsidiaries was the biggest in United States history.
The bankruptcy filing by the parent will have no effect on policyholders of either unit. The financial ties between First Executive and the operating units have been frozen under the seizures.
First Executive had suffered huge losses on its "junk bond" holdings, weakening its financial condition. The company was a large customer of Drexel Burnham Lambert, the investment firm that was forced into liquidation by legal problems surrounding its junk bond activities.
First Executive lost $466 million in the fourth quarter, largely because of junk bond defaults. As the economy soared in the 1980's, insurance companies and other investors took on the high-yielding bonds, which in previous decades had largely been shunned by mainstream investors as too risky.
Executive Life of California had $6.4 billion in junk bonds out of total assets of $10.1 billion.
Separately, the California Insurance Department said it would soon begin a competitive bidding process for the sale of Executive Life. John Garamendi, the insurance commissioner, said he had authorized the Blackstone Group, a New York investment bank, to begin contacting prospective buyers.
The most likely buyer continues to be a European consortium headed by Altus Finance, an arm of Credit Lyonnais, a French banking company. Mr. Garamendi said negotiations with Altus were proceeding and that the consortium had agreed to provide at leat $3 billion in new financing should a deal be completed.
Mr. Garamendi said any deal with Altus would include a "restructuring of liabilities," presumably meaning a cut in the rate paid to holders of Executive Life annuities and other investment agreements.

HEADLINE: Icahn Sale Of USX Stock Seen

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA

 BODY:
Carl C. Icahn apparently sold his entire stake in the USX Corporation yesterday for more than $1 billion and a profit of about $200 million.
The sale, in what may have been a move to assist his ailing Trans World Airlines, ends an often stormy relationship between the New York-based takeover strategist and the Pittsburgh-based energy and steel company. It comes a week after USX shareholders agreed to split the company's stock into two classes to reflect the separate values of the energy and steel business, something Mr. Icahn had urged for years. 
 Yesterday blocks of stock representing 13.3 percent of each issue were sold on the New York Stock Exchange. Mr. Icahn did not respond to calls to his office, but news agencies quoted USX spokesmen as saying he was almost certainly the seller since no one else held so many shares.
 
Proceeds May Aid Airline
 Meanwhile, T.W.A., where he is chairman and chief executive, has been pinched by a decline in air traffic and higher fuel prices and has announced its intention to restructure its finances. Some of Mr. Icahn's investment in USX was done through T.W.A., so some of the proceeds may be used to help the cash-short carrier.
Mr. Icahn has been accused by T.W.A.'s unions of not investing enough in the airline to make it competitive under current conditions.
Because of Mr. Icahn's pressure, USX stock now trades as USX-Marathon and USX-U.S. Steel. Brokers bought and then resold 33.9 million shares of USX-Marathon and nearly 6.8 million shares of USX-Steel, both at $25 a share, for just over $1 billion in proceeds.
 
Paid About $800 Million
 Since he is believed to have paid about $800 million for the shares, he apparently recorded a profit of $200 million before interest and other costs.
The Marathon shares declined by $1.125 yesterday, to $25.125, while the Steel shares fell 75 cents, to $25. Marathon was the most active stock of the day while Steel was the third most active.
Analysts said the sale was not surprising in light of an agreement Mr. Icahn had made with the company not to acquire any more shares for seven years. They added that there was little he could do to lift the prices of the stock.
"People were waiting for him to sell his position," Reuters quoted Richard Cohen of Baird, Patrick as saying. "He was not going to do anything to add value at this point."
Mr. Icahn has long argued that USX's steel business has dragged down the performance of its energy operations, which includes the Marathon Oil Company, and held down the price of USX stock.
He began battling the company shortly after investing in its shares in 1986 and threatened a takeover effort. Rebuffed by management, he held on to his shares but took little action for two years. But in 1989 he bought more USX stock and again pressed management to restructure.
Last year, Mr. Icahn threatened a proxy fight to win control of the board. He dropped that effort when management agreed to submit to shareholders a nonbinding plan to spin off 80 percent of U.S. Steel and pay a special dividend with the proceeds.
The measure lost, but the 43 percent of the vote won by Mr. Icahn put pressure on management to do some form of reshuffle. Early this year the company announced that it would issue a new series of stock representing the steel business.
USX officials have said recently that they have held informal talks about selling the steel units, but that no deals are close.
If the steel unit is sold it would be the ultimate breakup for a company that was founded in 1901 by the combination of an Andrew Carnegie steel company and J. P. Morgan's steel holding and was known until 1986 as the United States Steel Corporation. It remains the nation's largest maker of steel, but has had trouble making money in the steel business.
Last month the company reported a net loss of $237 million in the first quarter, primarily as a result of a recession-dampened demand for steel and the cost of closing steel plants. Steel sales in the period were down 27 percent, to $943 million.
Meanwhile, the energy side of the company reported an operating income of $229 million, down only slightly from the previous year.

HEADLINE: House Panel Bars Proposal To Limit Deposit Insurance

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 14

 BODY:
The Bush Administration's attempt to rewrite the banking laws suffered a political setback today when a House panel rejected its proposals to limit coverage of deposit insurance.
A House banking subcommittee removed from the Treasury Department's legislation a provision that would have restricted deposit insurance coverage to $200,000 per individual per bank. 
 The subcommittee also voted against attempts supported by the Treasury to eliminate insurance coverage of some types of deferred compensation plans and of brokered deposits sold by investment houses to investors seeking high interest rates.
The votes came on the first day that Congress began formally considering the Administration's plan to restructure the banking industry by limiting deposit insurance and expanding the ability of banks to enter into new businesses.
Today's votes do not kill the Administration's proposal because once a banking package is approved by the subcommittee it must still go to the full banking committee, where it can be amended again, before proceeding to the floor of the House. Parts of it may also be taken up by another committee, which has jurisdiction over the regulation of investment banks; under the Treasury proposal, investment banks would be permitted to merge with commercial banks.
The Senate Banking Committee is expected to begin drafting banking legislation this summer but it has not set a date yet.
Even though the rejected measures in the Administration's proposal could yet be revived, the votes today by the House Banking Committee's Subcommittee on Financial Institutions Supervision, Regulation and Insurance provided the first indication that Congress may not be willing to substantially reduce deposit insurance protection, a key component of the Administration's plan to repair the banking industry. Thirty-six of the 52 members of the banking committee serve on the subcommittee that rejected the Administration's proposals today.
Subcommittee members said the legislation being crafted was clearly bearing more of a mark of banking groups and other interested lobbyists than of the Bush Administration.
"Treasury has been out-lobbied by the banking industry," said Representative Barney Frank, Democrat of Massachusetts, after the daylong subcommittee voting.
Representative Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of Brooklyn and another member of the subcommittee, who has been courted by the Administration to lend support to its legislation, called the day's action "hardly an irremediable setback, but a setback nonetheless."
"The consensus that is emerging is to not limit deposit insurance, but to limit bank powers," Mr. Schumer said. "The Administration is going to have to come in and offer some compromises."
By a vote of 18 to 17, the subcommittee adopted a provision that basically retains the present insurance coverage for individuals. Although the coverage now technically only protects a depositor for up to $100,000, the law also permits families to open up multiple joint accounts, which effectively extends coverage.
The Administration had proposed limiting coverage to $100,000, plus retirement savings of $100,000, per depositor per institution in an attempt to eliminate the extra protection afforded through the use of multiple accounts. The federally backed fund that insures deposits is at its lowest level since its creation and, by some estimates, could become insolvent within the next year or two.
The Treasury proposal was already watered down from an original plan supported by some senior Administration officials to limit coverage to $100,000 systemwide. Instead, the Treasury proposal recommended that an individual with more than $100,000 be permitted to obtain complete insurance protection by opening accounts at more than one bank.
The vote followed a well-orchestrated campaign led by the Independent Bankers Association of America, a trade group representing small and middle-sized banks that fear any limitations could lead to heavy withdrawals from depositors.
The Independent Bankers Association enlisted the support of 23 other lobbying groups, from home builders and the National Farmers Union to the American Association of Retired Persons, in its attempt to maintain existing coverage.
The subcommittee also decided by voice vote today to permit the stronger banks to continue to provide deposit insurance for brokered deposits. Such deposits, which include certificates of deposit, are sold to investors by investment firms that often move them around the nation in search of the highest available interest rates. The Treasury Department had proposed eliminating insurance coverage for brokered deposits, a recommendation that has precipitated an intense lobbying campaign by the large Wall Street firms that sell such deposits, notably Merrill Lynch.
 
Deferred Compensation Plans
 By a vote of 22 to 14, the subcommittee decided to reject the Administration's recommendation on insurance coverage of deferred compensation plans structured under section 457 of the Federal income tax code.
The Treasury's only major victory of the day came when the subcommittee by voice vote rejected an attempt to retain the existing law that protects deposits in so-called pass-through accounts, typically pension plans that break down their funds to receive insurance coverage.
The initial test for most of the Administration's other significant recommendations to change the banking landscape will begin later this week or next week, when the subcommittee begins examining the Treasury's proposals to expand the power of banks to enter new fields of business and eliminate barriers that now restrict banks from opening branches across state lines. Many of these changes are also opposed by the coalition formed by the Independent Bankers Association.
Last week the subcommittee approved a measure to increase to $30 billion from $5 billion the authority of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation to borrow from the Treasury.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

INTERNATIONAL

THE ECONOMY
Retail sales rose 0.4 percent in March, the Commerce Dept. said, revising figures that had shown an 0.8 percent drop. The gain was viewed as a sign that the economic slide is halting. [A1.]
