HEADLINE: New York Is Pressed to Pare Welfare as Home-Relief Rolls Grow

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, May 14

 BODY:
As the recession robs hundreds of thousands of New Yorkers of work, the state's welfare program for the employable poor is growing at an astounding rate.
But paradoxically, the immense growth in the cost of the home-relief program is creating political pressure to shrink the state's social safety net precisely when it is most needed to break the fall of the recently unemployed. 
 The need to make cuts in the $2 billion program stems largely from the struggle to fill a state budget gap that is estimated at more than $6 billion by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo.
The movement has been reinforced by the fact that New York spends more per person on the program than any other state and by the traditional perception of home relief as a dole for those who prefer a life of dependency to a life of work.
 
Fruitless Search for Work
 But the stereotype of the able-bodied malingerer does not fit many of the new home-relief applicants at the Soundview Income Maintenance Center, at 1365 Jerome Avenue in the South Bronx.
They are men like Christopher Askew, a 38-year-old laborer who has spent his life flinging newspapers, shining shoes, loading boxcars and, most recently, operating a jackhammer. After being laid off from his construction job in July, and spending 10 months in a fruitless search for work, Mr. Askew applied for home relief for the first time in late April.
"I'm behind in my rent since November, and they're threatening to toss me out," said Mr. Askew, whose unemployment benefits ran out in January. "Working is all I know. But now I sit around and can't feed my family."
New York, unlike many states, provides welfare support not only to mothers with dependent children and the handicapped, but also has home relief, a general welfare program that provides a monthly grant and Medicaid coverage to able-bodied people who cannot find work and those who are too ill, addicted or incapacitated to hold a job.
For a person with no income in New York City, the home-relief grant is $352 a month, an amount that leaves the recipient living far below the poverty level and sometimes without shelter.
But in Albany, where the program has become the fastest growing component of the state's $5.7 billion welfare system, home relief is viewed as the most conspicuous symbol of the state's growing inability to provide for its poor.
Between January 1989 and January 1991, the number of home-relief recipients in New York grew by 38 percent, to 315,000 from 229,000. In 1990 the average monthly expenditure on home relief, including the cost of welfare grants and Medicaid, rose by 28 percent over the previous year, to $168 million from $131 million. The cost is split by the state and local governments, with no Federal assistance.
As in other states, most of the growth in the home-relief caseload has been among those who were considered employable, and the growth generally has followed increases in unemployment. In New York, the number of employable home-relief recipients grew by 51 percent between January 1989 and January 1991, a period when the jobless rate rose to 7.1 percent from 5.6 percent and when the number of people who exhausted their unemployment benefits increased by 42 percent to almost 217,000.
By contrast, the caseload for the Aid to Families With Dependent Children program, which has only a marginal connection to the job market, grew by 6 percent in the same period, to slightly more than one million.
While the Federal Government requires that welfare benefits be paid to the elderly, the disabled and poor mothers with children, New York is one of only 13 states that chooses to finance welfare for the employable poor.
Governors in many of those states, including California, Ohio and Illinois, have proposed deep cuts in their versions of home relief. The proposals are rooted in a philosophy of welfare triage, in which programs that provide benefits for children and the disabled are being salvaged by sacrificing those that assist employable adults.
Home relief has long been susceptible to political attack because it is financed without help from Washington, unlike Aid to Families with Dependent Children, the primary welfare program for poor mothers and children. But the growing caseload and cost, which now accounts for one of every $29 in New York State's general fund budget, is posing the most severe threat to the program since its creation in 1931 by Gov. Franklin D. Roosevelt.
The Republicans who control the State Senate have proposed a broad array of cuts. Among the most severe would be a 90-day limit on benefits for employable recipients and requirements that recipients pay premiums for their Medicaid coverage and a fee of up to $3 for each doctor visit.
"We have a limited pot of dollars and we've said that our priorities will be mothers and children," said Paul F. Macielak, counsel to the Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino.
Supporters of home relief fear that the need to fill a $6 billion budget gap will weaken resistance to the cuts in the Assembly. But Assembly officials vow that the Democratic majority in that house will maintain its traditional protection of the program. Seventy-one percent of the home-relief caseload, and 81 percent of the growth in the caseload in the last two years, comes from New York City, the power base of the Assembly Democrats.
Welfare advocates are also discouraged that Governor Cuomo has shown a willingness in the last two years to scale back the program. Last year, Mr. Cuomo proposed a six-month limit on benefits for employable home-relief recipients. The proposal died in the Legislature last year and the Governor killed it this year in response to the deteriorating economy.
Although the Cuomo administration wants to protect home relief from major cuts, it hopes to glean savings from more modest eligibility restrictions. It has also been forced to suggest innovative measures to fend off Republican attacks.
Last month, the State Social Services Commissioner, Cesar A. Perales, suggested that the home-relief grant could be used to subsidize salaries paid by employers willing to create new jobs for welfare recipients.
Advocates for the poor argue that the Senate proposals will ultimately drive up social-services costs for the state and local governments. It would be "penny wise and pound foolish" to scale back home relief, said Pablo Ruiz Salomon, an analyst with the Community Service Society of New York.
"Where do you think these people are going to go?" he said. "They're going to go to the Health and Hospitals Corporation if they don't have Medicaid. They're going to go to the shelter system if they don't have a grant." At $1,215 a month, the cost of housing a person in a New York City homeless shelter is more than three times the cost of the home-relief grant in the city.
The chairman of the Senate Social Services Committee, Joseph R. Holland, Republican of Rockland County, said his party viewed home relief as a major contributor to the problem of welfare dependency.
 
Stereotypes as Drawbacks
 "If people have a real problem, whether it's drugs, alcohol, mental or physical, we don't think the public minds taking care of them," Mr. Holland said. "But if they're physically able and are unused to working or don't work, we want them to struggle, just like I would want my kids to do."
State social services officials and advocates for the poor concede that the program is stigmatized by a pervasive stereotype.
"In the rural areas, it's the guy sitting on a porch swigging a beer and tossing the cans into the backyard and watching them pile up," said Mr. Perales, the State Social Services Commissioner. "In the city, it's the young men hanging around fires in barrels. There's a sense that these people just don't like to work, that they're lazy."
Like most stereotypes, Mr. Perales said, that profile of home relief is based on a nugget of truth that obscures a greater reality. Few legislators, he maintains, realize that half of all home-relief recipients are women and that only 23 percent are men under the age of 40. He also pointed out that almost 60 percent of the growth in the home relief population in the last two years has been composed of families. Benefits increase depending on the number of people in a family.
"It's a potpourri, without a doubt, and you have a percentage of the population that justifiably inspires people's anger," said Russell Sykes, a policy analyst with the State Communities Aid Association. "But policy should not be made for a larger group based on the perception about a minority."
For the victims of the recession who are making their first trips to Soundview's drab waiting rooms, the fear that their safety net may soon shrink is particularly disheartening.

HEADLINE: AFTER THE WAR;
U.N. Plan Could Have Iraq Yield 25% of Oil Revenue

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, May 14

 BODY:
The United States and the four other permanent members of the Security Council have drawn up a plan under which Iraq could be compelled to pay 25 to 30 percent of its $20 billion annual oil revenue as reparations for the invasion and looting of Kuwait and as repayment of its debts to foreign governments.
Such a limit on reparations would mean that the most Iraq could be asked to pay in any year would be roughly equivalent to the $5 billion or so it spent annually buying foreign weapons before the Persian Gulf war. And the Security Council might set the payment at a lower level than the maximum. The total reparations to be demanded of Iraq could run as high as $50 billion. 
 A major question is when the Baghdad Government will be permitted to resume selling its oil on the world market. This is dependent on Iraq's compliance with previous orders to turn over and destroy its missiles and chemical weapons, and submit its nuclear material to inspection.
 
Approval Thought Likely
 The proposal on reparations, which has the backing of Britain, France, the Soviet Union and China as well as the United States -- is expected to be adopted by the entire Council later this week without major changes, diplomats say.
The proposal itself does not set any figures for the level of Iraqi payments, saying it is up to the United Nations Secretary General, Javier Perez de Cuellar, to propose a maximum figure to the Council for approval.
Despite the wide expectation of a 25 to 30 percent ceiling, the American Assistant Secretary of State in charge of United Nations affairs, John R. Bolton, recently proposed a ceiling up to 50 percent of Iraq's oil revenue. Other permanent members of the Council, the five nations with veto power, regard this as unrealistic.
 
Way of Increasing Oil Flow
 Some countries friendly to Iraq have suggested that the Government of President Saddam Hussein be asked to allocate no more than 10 percent of its oil revenue for reparations.
Earlier, Iraq had asked for a five-year delay on reparations payments to allow it to rebuild its shattered economy.
The purpose of establishing an annual ceiling on payments, diplomats say, is to encourage Baghdad to produce maximum quantities of oil after sanctions are lifted by insuring that it will always get a portion of any increase in its market share.
In calling for a ceiling, diplomats say the Council also wanted to avoid a disastrous mistake like the Treaty of Versailles of 1919, when the victorious Allies imposed draconian compensation payments on a defeated Germany, threatening it with impoverishment and contributing to the rise of Nazism.
Under previous resolutions, the Security Council has declared Baghdad liable for "any direct loss, damage, including environmental damage and the depletion of natural resources, or injury to foreign governments, nationals and corporations as a result of Iraq's unlawful invasion and occupation of Kuwait."
 
How Iraqis Can Help Themselves
 Diplomats say the payment level demanded may also be influenced by political factors, like the composition of the government in power in Baghdad, and by Saudi Arabia's and Kuwait's demands for repayment of the roughly $50 billion they are believed to have lent Iraq during its eight-year war against Iran.
If Mr. Hussein's Government falls and is replaced by a more acceptable leadership, these diplomats believe that Kuwait and other gulf nations would urge the Council to treat Iraq more leniently and offer to forgive some debts. Iraq also owes $25 billion to the Western industrial nations and the Soviet Union.
In deciding how much Iraq should pay in reparations, the Security Council, working through a new subsidiary to be called the United Nations Compensation Fund, is required to take into account the cost of repaying its foreign debts as well as its economic-development needs.
Security Council approval of the proposed resolution setting up the reparations-payment mechanism fulfills one of two conditions the Council has established for lifting its worldwide ban on the Iraqi oil trade.
The other condition will be met when the Council is satisfied that Iraq has complied with a plan the Secretary General will present on May 18 -- for a special commission to take possession of Iraq's chemical and other weapons of mass destruction within 45 days and start destroying them.

Poland to Represent U.S.
 WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP) -- The Polish Embassy in Baghdad will serve as a diplomatic intermediary between the United States and Iraq, the State Department said today. Iraq has a diplomatic presence in Washington through the Algerian Embassy.

HEADLINE: Wine Talk

BYLINE: By Frank J. Prial

 BODY:
WINE people, people who make a living from it, that is, can make somber companions these days. They sigh, they shrug their shoulders and the roll their eyes. Can't blame them. The recession and the strong wave of anti-alcohol sentiment in the United States have combined to deliver the trade a one-two punch. Not fatal, but not pleasant, either.
Which is why it is pleasant to run into someone like Jeff Prather, wine director at Ray's Boathouse, a popular restaurant in Seattle. Unlike many others in the industry, Mr. Prather is optimistic about the future of wine, and is doing something about it. 
 Restaurants are the front line of wine appreciation. People who would never dream of drinking wine at home drink it in restaurants. And unless their parents were wine drinkers, most people who do drink wine at home first tasted it in restaurants.
The restaurant is wine's natural habitat because in a restaurant, wine is invariably paired with food. And let's face it, without food, most wine doesn't make sense. Which is where Mr. Prather comes in.
Most restaurants' wine lists group wines by country -- all the French wines in one section, all the Americans in another -- or by variety -- cabernets here, chardonnays there. Mr. Prather groups wines that might go well with certain foods: four reds that go with steak and chops, or five whites that go with lighter fish.
Mr. Prather talked about his system the other day in New York, where he was visiting Windows on the World, interestingly one of the first major restaurants to promote wine as an integral part of a meal.
Most people don't know the difference between a sauvignon blanc and a chenin blanc. Or a cabernet and a merlot, a barbera and a barbaresco, a pouilly fume and a pouilly fuisse. So why, if they are ready to order wine with their dinner, should they be penalized for not being wine experts?
Like many ambitious wine managers, Mr. Prather offers wine courses at Ray's and at a newer restaurant in the Seattle area, the Yarrow Bay Grill. Courses are excellent for people interested in them, but it should not be necessary to take a course to enjoy wine in a restaurant. Or anywhere else.
The Ray's Boathouse wine list sees to that. The restaurant's main list includes more than 700 items. Recently, Mr. Prather devised a short list, called Ray's Recommends. It lists a few sparkling wines and six categories based on food: whites to go with oysters and shellfish; whites for light fish; richer selections for salmon and such; Boathouse blush, roses; red wines that can go with fish, and meaty reds, for people who persist in eating steak in fish restaurants.
The 27-wine short list is overwhelmingly American, but it includes a few French wines. The seven wines recommended for oysters and shellfish, for example, are three sauvignon blancs -- Ray's private label, from Washington ($13); a Paul Thomas, also from Washington ($16); and a Groth, from Napa Valley ($15) -- a Snoqualmie semillon, from Washington ($13); an Eyrie pinot gris, from Oregon ($17); a grand cru Chablis, Les Bougros by Joseph Drouhin, ($45), and a white Bordeaux, Chateau La Louviere, from Graves ($17).
With light fish, Mr. Prather recommends several Washington rieslings, a Washington chenin blanc and an Oregon gewurztraminer, all of which are dry, he said. With salmon, he wisely suggests chardonnay. Salmon and lobster are two of the few seafoods that can stand up to chardonnay; the wine is too alcoholic and has too pronounced a flavor for most species. The Drouhin Chablis is 100 percent chardonnay, but without the heaviness and the over-oaked taste of so many American chardonnays.
In recommending some reds to go with fish, Mr. Prather is following Bordeaux tradition. The Bordelais find themselves in a peculiar position: they make some of the great red wines of the world, much of it a stone's throw from the ocean and some very fine fish. Of course, they match them up. Not always, but often.
If the fish -- salmon or bluefish, say -- is not delicate and the wine is, why not. Accordingly, Mr. Prather offers two pinot noirs, a Knudsen-Erath Vintage Select from Oregon and a Saintsbury, from the Carneros region of Napa Valley, and a gamay, Georges Duboeuf's Beaujolais Villages.
This kind of wine list works two ways. Someone in the mood for chardonnay is gently steered away from fish that need a lighter wine and toward the salmon that will make a good match.
And an oyster fan, if he follows the list, will get something sharp to counter the salinity of the oyster, and not a fruity riesling or a bland chenin blanc.
For patrons who want all the work done for them, Mr. Prather and Ray's chef, Wayne Ludvigsen, put together menus of complete dinners, which they call Matchmaker.
One such menu, recently reprinted in The Restaurant Wine Newsletter, was steamed clams and mussels, and a tossed salad with Dijon mustard and Oregon blue cheese, served with a Manzanilla sherry; then grilled coho salmon, in a chanterelle and chardonnay cream sauce, with a Chalone chardonnay from California bottled for the restaurant; and dessert served with a naturally sweet, late harvest riesling from Stewart Vineyards in Washington. Price for the works: $33.
This kind of menu, including wines, remains the best way to begin learning about the subject. Nor is it an idea limited to this country. Almost every French restaurant with three stars from Michelin offers a menu degustation -- a tasting menu -- that includes wines. Many food lovers planning a dinner at, for example, Lucas-Carton in Paris, look forward to the wines the chef and owner, Alain Senderens, will pick for them, almost as much as the meal itself.
 
TASTINGS
Taylor California Cellars Diet Chablis; about $6 for a magnum.
 If ever there was a wine whose time has come, this is it. The concept is not new and the name isn't exactly felicitous. Connoisseurs are not likely to give it a second thought. But there are probably a few dozen million consumers out there who will see nothing untoward about the idea of a low-alcohol, low-calorie white wine. They, and anyone else who tries it, are in for a surprise. Diet Chablis resembles nothing so much as the fresh young wines served in the Vienna Woods in springtime and directly from the cask in the vine-covered cafes along the Rhine and Moselle: fresh, flowery and with just the right acid bite. Wine doesn't have to be high in alcohol to taste good. In Germany, light wines at 7 or 9 percent alcohol were once common, and Beaujolais at 10 percent was not unusual. Diet Chablis comes in at an astonishingly low 3.4 percent -- astonishing because it still tastes like fresh young wine. Alcohol-free wines continue to be dreadful stuff for the most part, tasting flat and bland. This is nothing like them. There is a bit of residual sugar, but not the sticky sweetness of most wine coolers. The process of making Diet Chablis involves adding grape juice to regular wine. Whatever it is, it works; this is a delightful summer drink, especially for parties and receptions, and with just 30 percent of the calories of regular wine. Widely available now, Diet Chablis should be in all large markets in a month.

HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
Steel Stories: A U.S. Success and a Soviet Failure

BYLINE: By HERBERT MITGANG

 BODY:

American Steel
Hot Metal Men and the Resurrection of the Rust Belt
By Richard Preston
278 pages. Prentice Hall Press. $19.95.
 
Steeltown, U.S.S.R.
Soviet Society in the Gorbachev Era
By Stephen Kotkin
Illustrated. 269 pages. University of California Press. $24.95. 
 With American business on the skids and the Soviet economy on the ropes, it's enlightening to pair two books about the steel industry, which is about as basic as you can get, in each country. Reading the books side by side -- both happen to be well researched and fairly well written -- is a lesson in the larger matter of how the free market and a controlled system succeed or stumble.
"American Steel," by Richard Preston, and "Steeltown, U.S.S.R.," by Stephen Kotkin, are generally apolitical. They are mainly concerned with the efforts and shortcomings, the difficulties and the dreams of people working in a sector of the economy in tough times. Neither of these American authors has an evil empire in mind.
In the midst of all the unemployment in Midwestern industrial areas. Mr. Preston has written an upbeat story about the creation of a new steel mill in an old cornfield in Crawfordsville, Ind. (An excerpt from "American Steel" ran in The New Yorker this year.) The author observed the building of a large sheet mill by the Nucor Corporation, using German technology, from a hole in the ground to the first pouring of molten steel.
Nucor, a Fortune 500 company with manufacturing plants around the country, makes steel from melted automobiles -- literally. Right at the start, F. Kenneth Iverson, Nucor's chairman, told the author that his new plant was going to scare the big American steel companies by invading their market for flat-rolled sheet steel; furthermore, he was going to beat the Japanese steelmakers by using machinery that was more labor efficient.
"American Steel" takes the reader from the chairman's modest office down to the Hades-like heat and danger of the new steel plant. We meet a half-dozen dedicated individuals, the subtitle's "hot metal men," who love their business and find it professionally satisfying and even glamorous. Without interpretation and all too briefly, the author notes that Nucor's plants are nonunion and that Mr. Iverson is not popular with the United Steelworkers of America. He says that Nucor built mills and product factories in small rural towns among farm people who were comfortable with machinery and disliked labor organizers.
Mr. Preston uses dramatic terms that occasionally overreach when straightforward language would be less distracting and possibly more accurate. He writes that steel rushes into a mold, "which shivers around the nozzle in a sexual-industrial climax, and water jets roar inside the machine." Still, "American Steel" conveys the excitement of a comparatively small company going up against the big boys.
In the end, the new machinery and the daring hot metal men turn the self-contained plant into a pioneering enterprise: "Iverson's machine carries the river and the river shines like the sun, flowing from the mountains of the Rust Belt to the arc furnaces of Crawfordsville, down the cataracts of the casting tower, through the narrows of the rolling mill, and into the Midwest."
"Steeltown, U.S.S.R." is a more ambitious work by a Princeton historian who went to the model steel city of Magnitogorsk in the southern Urals in 1987 and became the first American to live there in 45 years. His book provides realistic insights into life and industry in the Soviet Union during the Gorbachev era. For both the people and the plant, it's a struggle for survival.
By contrast, "American Steel" illustrates that a new mill in onetime farm country in Indiana -- even though an exception to the poor conditions prevailing elsewhere in the American Rust Belt -- could become a competitor internationally. In fairness, the author points out that workers in the steel city of Gary, Ind., are also burdened with problems, including unemployment, inadequate housing and racism.
Magnitogorsk is presented as a symbol of the difficulties facing any Moscow leaders trying to improve production, let alone change to a market economy. The city was founded in 1929 as part of Stalin's forced industrialization. It was once a showcase of production and was especially effective during World War II. But built into the system was forced labor and in some cases purges and executions. One of the propaganda photographs reproduced in the book is a 1932 picture of a so-called "new man" and his wife; the author's caption says the former peasant turned literate skilled worker was arrested and shot in 1937.
The Soviet system brought certain benefits to the steel town: basic education, considered a right, was provided free; higher education, also free, afforded a chance to move up in society. But alongside these advantages, the author writes, the people still face "entrenched alcoholism, recurrent shortages of consumer goods, a severe housing crisis extending well into the future, a ubiquitous black market." From its peak as a great steel plant, Magnitogorsk became what it is today, a dinosaur spewing pollution.
"In Magnitogorsk the newspaper expertly conducted the campaign to expose the fatal flaws of the existing system but did not offer any suggestions about how to put the pieces back together again, other than to pursue the truth and to support Mikhail Gorbachev, whatever he might be up to," Mr. Kotkin writes. "Steeltown, U.S.S.R." leaves a clear impression that glasnost is working but perestroika is still hobbled by the spoor of Stalinism.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Richard Preston (Michelle Preston/Prentice Hall Press); Stephen Kotkin (Jurii Popov/University of California Press)

HEADLINE: FOREIGN AFFAIRS;
A Thunderclap . . .

BYLINE: By LESLIE H. GELB

 BODY:
Secretary of State Baker has gotten no Mideast conference and no coonskin, no peace process and no one to blame. He and President Bush have squandered American prestige and power in vain attempts to squeeze micro-mini procedural concessions from the warring parties.
 To jump-start the bargaining process requires not small steps, but a clap of thunder from Mr. Bush -- the one leader to emerge from the Iraq war holding a fistful of huge i.o.u.'s and wish lists. Officials say that is just what he is thinking about.
 
 The idea is for Mr. Bush to announce the convening of a Mideast peace conference in Washington at a date soon and certain. He himself would set fair rules to govern the proceedings. And he would spell out in unmistakable terms the consequences -- realistic ones with sharp teeth -- for failing to participate.
 Mr. Baker has been slyly executing a variant of this approach for several weeks, but it was grossly misdirected at either establishing a conference or isolating Israel. The essence of the approach was to gain the agreement of key Arab states to a regional gathering and then present Prime Minister Shamir with a virtual ultimatum: Either join in or face the prospect of a Mideast peace parley with an empty seat for Israel.
 Behind that ultimatum, Mr. Baker hinted to his interlocutors, stood a second threat: If Israel refused to attend a "friendly" conference sponsored by Moscow and Washington, it might be confronted with an "unfriendly" U.N.-sponsored meeting and with sanctions against the Jewish state for not complying with U.N. resolutions.
 Syria's rejection of Mr. Baker's compromise terms for the regional conference knocked that strategy off the rails. Israel could no longer be isolated, despite the Shamir Government's intransigence.
 Administration officials are suggesting that they will turn next to a small-bore strategy, probably the old one of prompting talks between Israel and a joint Jordanian-Palestinian team to discuss the West Bank and Gaza Strip. But like past efforts, this will take many months to play out -- only to stumble eventually over tiny procedural hurdles.
 The alternative is a thunderclap proposal that Mr. Bush and Mikhail Gorbachev could package as follows:
 1. A Washington conference. The two leaders invite Israel, Egypt, Syria, Lebanon, Saudi Arabia representing the Persian Gulf states and a joint Jordanian-Palestinian delegation. Without consultation, the conveners decide on the Palestinian members, while offering Israel assurances that Jerusalem cannot even be discussed until all other matters are resolved. The U.N. and the European Community are given observer status to meet Arab concerns. No party is required to accept substantive preconditions such as land for peace.
 2. Rules and procedures. These must be handed down by the conveners without negotiations.
All parties will meet for one or two days. After that and for three months, they will divide into three parts: Israel with the Jordanian-Palestinian team on the occupied territories. Syria and Israel on the Golan Heights; and Lebanon with Israel. All parties on regional arms control, economic development and water-sharing.
 After a three-month interval, the full conference will reconvene solely to hear reports and comment before the three-tiered talks are resumed.
 3. Consequences for no-shows. Mr. Bush will have to lay bare the costs of not participating. For Saudi Arabia, no U.S. arms or security blanket. For Syria, no U.S. economic support bilaterally or multilaterally plus diplomatic isolation. For Jordan, no U.S. aid. For the Palestinians, no further U.S. efforts in their behalf. For Israel, no aid for resettling Soviet immigrants and aid cuts if further Jewish settlements are erected on the West Bank.
 These measures are draconian. They have to be. Nothing less can shake up these enemies whose peoples desperately need peace to discuss peace.
 If the conference flops, the U.S. can always go back to selling more arms and making occasional diplomatic forays, and regional leaders to hating and killing. But Mr. Bush has the chance to rewrite this endless, murderous tragedy if he would pursue peace as skillfully and boldly as he waged war.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

HEADLINE: Rohatyn Ties Aid to New York City To Greater Role for a State Board

BYLINE: By JOSH BARBANEL

 BODY:
Felix G. Rohatyn, the chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, says his agency will give New York City $1 billion over four years to avoid layoffs and service cuts if a state board's role in overseeing the city's finances is expanded.
Mr. Rohatyn has told city and state officials in the last few days that the corporation, set up to sell bonds for the city during its fiscal troubles in the 1970's, could raise the $1 billion by refinancing the city's bonds. 
 In effect, the plan would help reduce city deficits for the next four years but increase debt repayment costs in subsequent years. While the money involved is only a small portion of the $3.5 billion budget gap the city faces in the next fiscal year, it could help the city avert the worst of the $1.5 billion in cuts proposed by Mayor David N. Dinkins.
 
String Is Attached
 But according to the officials who were briefed, Mr. Rohatyn said he was prepared to raise the money only if the State Financial Control Board certifies that the Dinkins administration has a plan to achieve a permanent balance between recurring revenues and spending by 1995.
The M.A.C. money's leverage would indirectly give the Control Board new power to pressure the Mayor to reshape his spending priorities. The board was set up in 1975 to control city spending, but it officially gave up that power in 1986, when the city was in an economic boom. It now monitors the city's finances.
The new role for the board would be a challenge to Mr. Dinkins; he has made maintaining firm control over the city's finances a cornerstone of his fiscal policy and has viewed any suggestion that he give up any of his authority to the Control Board as a personal affront.
Mr. Rohatyn, who had a central role in the city's efforts to stave off bankruptcy in the 1970's and who has been a major figure in its finances ever since, was appointed by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and is an adviser to him. Both he and Mr. Cuomo have occasionally expressed displeasure with the spending decisions of the Dinkins administration. But it is not clear to what extent, if any, Mr. Cuomo has endorsed the terms proposed by Mr. Rohatyn.
The Financial Control Board has seven members: the Governor, the Mayor, the City and State Comptrollers and three members appointed by the Governor.
City officials said yesterday that if Mr. Rohatyn insisted on having the board certify a long-range budget-balancing plan, his offer could amount to a "pseudo control period" that would severely distress Mr. Dinkins. The officials also said that it could violate assurances given by Mr. Cuomo that the state would help the city without conditions.
But the officials said that they had not been fully briefed on the plan and that they preferred to assume that Mr. Rohatyn wanted a more limited role for the Control Board. The board now issues reports analyzing financial plans submitted by the city every quarter.
"The Control Board has always had the ability to review our plan and comment on it," said Norman Steisel, the First Deputy Mayor. "We assume that the current rules will continue to be the rules."
Asked for comment, Anne Crowley, a spokeswoman for Governor Cuomo, said, "Felix Rohatyn hasn't finished his work on this."
She added that the Control Board would in due course comment on the city's financial plan "in any event" and that "both the Governor and the Mayor understood this."
 
'All Very Touchy'
 Mr. Rohatyn is scheduled to present his plan tomorrow at a meeting of the M.A.C. board. He declined to comment on the plan, saying that the corporation's lawyers were still reviewing it and that it was subject to change. "I'm not confirming or denying anything," he said. "This is all very touchy."
In the last two days, however, he has sketched much of it out for city officials, bond-rating agencies, union leaders and the Control Board's private members. Some said that without the details it was unclear how much authority the Mayor would, in practice, cede to the Control Board.
On the one hand, they said, the Control Board may have the practical, if not the legal, power to hold up hundreds of millions of dollars in funds unless the Mayor complies with the Control Board's wishes.
On the other hand, they said, the Governor and the Mayor might be able to simply use the board as a means of reassuring the bond-rating agencies and financial markets that the Mayor was serious about shrinking the size of city government.
 
Union Leader Is Optimistic
 Barry Feinstein, president of Local 237 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, which represents thousands of city workers, said he was awaiting an analysis from his fiscal staff before commenting.
"We are cautiously optimistic that the efforts of Felix Rohatyn are clearly meant to help in this very difficult time," Mr. Feinstein said.
City Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman confirmed that she had been briefed on the plan but declined to discuss it, except to say that she would oppose any effort to diminish the authority of elected city officials.
Ms. Holtzman noted that the city was still paying $300 million a year to erase debts left over from the city's fiscal crisis in the 1970's. She said she did not want to burden future generations with the city's current problems.
Bond-rating agencies have said that the M.A.C. help would amount to "deficit financing" by the city -- the selling of bonds or notes to cover a budget deficit. The agencies have warned that such an action could prompt them to lower the city's rating. .
Hyman Grossman, a managing director at Standard & Poor's, the rating agency, said that even if the Financial Control Board certified that the city's plan would achieve a permanent balance, that would not "necessarily wash if our opinion is different than the Control Board's."

CORRECTION-DATE: May 16, 1991, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a proposal to reduce New York City's budget deficit with the help of the Municipal Assistance Corporation referred incorrectly in some copies to the bonds that would be refinanced to provide the money. They were the corporation's bonds, not the city's.

HEADLINE: Washington Talk;
Return of a Lawmaker, Dusting Off an Old Idea

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 14

 BODY:
At a time when most Democrats have modest legislative agendas, it would be normal to dismiss as an idealistic neophyte any newly elected Congressman who wants to spend $110 billion or so on education and roads and the environment and that sort of thing.
But Ray Thornton represents not only the Second Congressional District of Arkansas, but also a more optimistic time in Congress. When he calls for a domestic Marshall Plan to rebuild the United States economy, the reaction of his colleagues may be skeptical, but it is hardly dismissive. 
 Mr. Thornton was here for three terms in the mid-1970's, in the thick of successful efforts to expand power for the House rank and file and to make decisions about issues like energy conservation and research into recombinant DNA. Most telling of all, he served on the House Judiciary Committee and cast reluctant but critical votes to recommend the impeachment of President Richard M. Nixon in 1974.
Some of Mr. Thornton's current optimism may also be a consequence of not being around Washington in the 1980's, a depressing time for Democrats here. He left in 1978 after losing a tight Senate primary to then Gov. David Pryor and fellow Representative Jim Guy Tucker. Mr. Thornton spent the decade as president of Arkansas State University and then the larger University of Arkansas.
Twelve years is a long time to be away from the House. Fred Schwengel, president of the Capitol Historical Society who is a former Representative from Iowa, said he could not think of anyone in this century who had returned after a longer interval except Jeanette Rankin, the Montana pacifist and Republican who in 1917 voted against the United States entering World War I, was out of Congress for 22 years and returned in 1941 in time to cast the only vote in Congress against declaring war on Japan.
Mr. Thornton jokes that he decided to leave university life because "I got tired of all the politics." But he really ran again, at the age of 62, because he had this Marshall Plan idea.
As he put it to the House last month, "The United States should formulate and pursue new strategies to insure that it remains the mightiest nation in the world militarily, while developing its human and material resources to advance its position as the dominant economic power in the world."
He said weaknesses were developing in the economy, from abandoning energy conservation to letting the physical, commercial and technological infrastructure deteriorate while support for education eroded.
"We need to develop strategies for America as appropriate for our needs as those we employed with such success in rebuilding Europe and Japan," he said. "In short, we need a Marshall Plan for America."
The original Marshall Plan, in which the United States spent $13 billion to aid European recovery from 1948 to 1952, cost about 2 percent of the gross national product at that time. Mr. Thornton maintains that spending 2 percent of the current G.N.P., or about $110 billion, will not be as costly as failing to make the investment. He has offered only modest suggestions for raising revenue, including an import fee on crude oil.
The Thornton proposal is more of an idea than a plan, and he makes his way around Washington trying to enlist interest or, as he says, "trying to give it away" to leaders or officials who have more influence than he.
On his return to Congress this year Mr. Thornton found the House a friendly place, not greatly changed in its methods since he left. "The era of extremely strong committee chairmen has ended," he said, "and that's not necessarily positive."
But there are some differences in spirit. "In the 70's Congress was a functioning organization that was setting out to meet challenges," he said. That spirit can be found in the country today, he added, the "can-do" idea "that we can accomplish American goals," though it is sometimes harder to find at the Capitol than it used to be.
This is a less drastic, more diffuse challenge than he faced in his first term, as a freshman from Arkansas voting to impeach a President who two years earlier had carried Mr. Thornton's district, which includes Little Rock, with 69 percent of the vote. But those tense days taught an inspiring lesson.
When Mr. Nixon resigned a few days after the committee's impeachment vote, the watchword of the capital was, "The system worked."

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 6; National Desk

LENGTH: 1737 words

HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHOOSES NO. 2 SECURITY AIDE FOR C.I.A. DIRECTOR

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 14

 BODY:
President Bush today gave Robert M. Gates an unusual second chance to become Director of Central Intelligence. The President chose the career intelligence analyst for a job he was denied four years ago in the face of intensive questioning about the Iran-contra affair.
In selecting Mr. Gates, a veteran of 25 years in Government bureaucracy with no political profile or base of his own, Mr. Bush reiterated his view that the espionage agencies should devote themselves to intelligence gathering and remain aloof from both politics and policymaking. Mr. Bush said that was the way he ran the intelligence services when he was Director himself in 1976, although he moved into the position after serving as chairman of the Republican National Committee, as well as a Congressman from Texas from 1966 to 1970.
 
'He Will Do a Superb Job'
 "I will keep it the way it was when I was there," Mr. Bush said today. "And it will be -- he will be at the table when matters of -- or when we need the intelligence to make critical decisions on foreign affairs. He will not be a political -- trying to shape policy. But he will do a superb job as a professional intelligence officer, heading the intelligence agency. That's the way it's going to be." 
 That often-repeated mandate seems to reflect Mr. Bush's desire to avoid the experiences of the Reagan Administration, when William J. Casey, the intelligence chief, not only was heavily involved in policymaking but embarked on an ambitious covert operation, the Iran-contra affair. That secret effort to sell arms to Iran and divert some of the profits to the Nicaraguan rebels crippled Mr. Reagan's final years in office.
White House aides took pains today to say that if Mr. Gates is confirmed by the Senate he would abide by Mr. Bush's wishes to stick to intelligence gathering and analysis.
 
Man of Strong Opinions
 The 47-year-old Mr. Gates has a reputation for loyally defending official policy. But he also has strong opinions and clashed with Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d in 1989 over Mr. Gates's intention to give a speech expressing skepticism about whether the Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev could deliver on his promises of reform. The speech was shelved after Mr. Baker objected to its pessimistic tone.
Although Mr. Gates, who is now deputy national security adviser, was forced to withdraw from nomination to the intelligence post in 1987 because of questions about his actions during the Iran-contra affair, Mr. Bush today brushed aside concerns that the Gates confirmation hearing would revive that debate and put his own role in the affair under renewed scrutiny.
The President said he had "no qualms at all" about that prospect and was "very, very pleased" by consultations between his aides and influential senators who have told the White House that they believed Mr. Gates could be confirmed to replace William H. Webster, who announced his resignation last week.
Generally, members of the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence, which will review Mr. Gates's nomination first, reacted positively to the choice. They included the Democratic chairman of the panel, David L. Boren of Oklahoma, and Alan Cranston, Democrat of California, who opposed Mr. Gates in 1987.
 
Time Expected to Help
 The Administration is counting on the passage of time, and Mr. Gates's enhanced prestige as a result of his work at the White House, especially during the Persian Gulf crisis, to smooth the nomination proceedings. But it was clear that lawmakers would focus hard on Mr. Gates's involvement in the Iran-contra affair, which could prove embarrassing for Mr. Bush politically even if it did not derail the nomination.
"I would expect extended hearings to probe those questions," said Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum, Democrat of Ohio, the only committee member who directly criticized the naming of Mr. Gates. "I am surprised and disappointed that President Bush has made such a controversial choice."
Mr. Boren said confirmation hearings would probably not begin until June and that the Senate would probably not vote on the nomination until August or September.
Administration officials said the President's selection of Mr. Gates reflected a balancing of Mr. Bush's concerns about the Iran-contra scandal with his desire to reward a loyal aide and appoint an intelligence director who Mr. Bush believes is likely to run the Central Intelligence Agency the way he wants.
 
Shift in Lines of Power
 The move also promises to produce an important shift in the makeup of the Administration's national security team and the lines of power within the White House.
The White House had been seeking to ease Mr. Webster out of office in hopes of finding an intelligence chief who would be more engaged in day-to-day operations.
Officials said Mr. Gates was expected to fill that gap, even though the intelligence agencies are trying to shift their resources away from his primary area of expertise, the Soviet Union, and focus more on economic issues, as well as social unrest and political tensions, in the developing countries.
Mr. Bush said Mr. Gates would not be made a member of the Cabinet, as Mr. Casey was under Mr. Reagan. Mr. Webster also did not hold Cabinet rank.
"But he will do a superb job as a professional intelligence officer, heading the intelligence agency," Mr. Bush said. "That's the way it's going to be."
Taking the new job will cost Mr. Gates his coveted position in the core group that made all the decisions during the Persian Gulf crisis, a group that included Mr. Baker, Brent Scowcroft, the national security adviser, and Defense Secretary Dick Cheney. But officials said Mr. Gates was not fighting that.
 
'Got Lifelong Ambition'
 "Bush is going to keep the C.I.A. just as it was when he headed it and Bob Gates fits perfectly into that," one official said. "He's a bureaucrat. He's got his lifelong ambition, head of the agency. He's happy."
The White House said no successor had been selected for Mr. Gates, a choice in which Mr. Scowcroft is expected to have a strong say.
But Administration officials said that the White House was likely to look for someone roughly Mr. Gates's age who will, as one put it, "be young and aggressive but know he's No. 2."
Mr. Scowcroft, who zealously protects his close relationship with Mr. Bush, focused on long-range policy planning and gave Mr. Gates the day-to-day responsibility for running the staff of the National Security Council.
Mr. Gates also played a major role in forming the committee of department deputies that supervises the day-to-day execution of military and foreign policy and was chairman of the panel.
"His replacement is going to need to know the National Security Council, State and Defense and not require a long learning curve," one official said. "Having a track record with Brent is also going to help, since the deputy is going to have to work in tandem with Scowcroft the way Bob has."
Of the officials currently available within the Administration, at least three seem to fit these requirements: Robert Kimmitt, Under Secretary of State for political affairs; Robert Zoellick, the State Department counsellor, and Paul Wolfowitz, Under Secretary of Defense for policy.
James Lilley, the Ambassador to China whose name was mentioned for the intelligence director's job, appears to be under consideration for a new post. He is an old friend of Mr. Bush, is friendly with Mr. Scowcroft and has an intelligence background.
Some Senators were strongly supportive of Mr. Gates's nomination. "Mr. Gates has demonstrated by his service in many capacities that he is an extremely able and non-partisan professional in the intelligence field," said Mr. Boren.
Senator Slade Gorton, Republican of Washington, who is a panel member, said through a spokesman that there were "valid questions that deserve answers" about the Iran-contra period. But he said he supported the nomination and that Mr. Gates was "extremely qualified and has tremendous experience in the intelligence community."
Senator William S. Cohen, Republican of Maine, who served as vice chairman of the committee during the Iran-contra scandal, said he believed Mr. Gates would be confirmed although "there will be a hard look at some of the issues" from that period.
Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York, said: "It would be premature to take a position on Mr. Gates's confirmation until the hearing process is over. But I believe he is fully qualified for the job and unless disqualifying information should be revealed during the hearing, the President's choice should be honored."
Mr. Cranston said: "I am favorably disposed toward the nomination. I will, of course, wait until his confirmation hearing is completed before making a final decision."
But Senator Bill Bradley, Democrat of New Jersey, who also opposed Mr. Gates in 1987, has said he still had reservations about Mr. Gates. Today, he said, "I intend to pursue the most important unresolved questions about Mr. Gates's record, his view on the future challenges and direction of the intelligence community and its role in protecting U.S. interests."
 
Bush on Foreign Affairs
 During the news conference today at which he named Mr. Gates for the intelligence job, Mr. Bush also said that he did not consider Mr. Baker's current mission to the Middle East a failure because of Syria's refusal to join peace talks with Israel.
"There are ups and downs in this process," Mr. Bush said, and speaking of President Hafez al-Assad, he added, "I would like to see President Assad do what the Secretary of State has asked. But we'll just keep working on this."
Mr. Bush said there had been no agreement on a date for a delayed Soviet-American summit that was supposed to be held in Moscow this year. Asked whether he would support Mr. Gorbachev's request to attend a meeting in London in July of the leaders of the seven most powerful industrial democracies, Mr. Bush said he would discuss the idea with his allies.
"I think it's important that if he go there, something positive will happen," Mr. Bush said.
Senior Administration officials have said Mr. Bush did not favor giving Mr. Gorbachev full observer status at the conference but would support a plan under which Mr. Gorbachev met with the other leaders in London either before or after their talks.

HEADLINE: Man in the News: Robert Michael Gates;
Analyst With Strong Views

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 14

 BODY:
Though President Bush said today that he did not want the Central Intelligence Agency involved in policy making, by nominating Robert M. Gates as the agency's new director Mr. Bush has picked a man with strong opinions about the Soviet Union and a strong belief in aggressively packaging intelligence to serve the Administration's foreign policy agenda.
Mr. Gates, 47 years old, would be the first former director of the C.I.A.'s analytical arm, or Directorate of Intelligence, to move up to the agency's top post. This reflects the growing interest in the Bush Administration in understanding fast-changing events in the Soviet Union, Europe and the third world, as opposed to trying to shape them through covert action, Administration officials said. 
 In his 25 years in Government, Mr. Gates has served a number of Presidents from both political parties, but despite his image as a low-profile and cautious bureaucrat, he is known at the C.I.A. as a tough and blunt-spoken task master who rose through the ranks by making well-researched judgments and predictions for his bosses, who often complained that agency analysts were writing history instead of predicting it.
His reputation is that of a scholarly professional who believes that policy makers need timely guidance on potential crises and trouble spots. But he is also known as a man who has not been afraid to use his analytical skills to promote his own policy views, particularly his tough, pessimistic attitude toward the Soviets.
In contrast with the departing Director, William H. Webster, Mr. Gates advocates detailed involvement by the director in the substance of daily intelligence issues and a close relationship with the White House, both to convey important developments quickly and to take Presidential responses back to agency analysts so they better know the views of the decision makers.
"It tells you a change in the world we live in," said a former C.I.A. Deputy Director, Bobby Inman, who took himself out of the running for the director's post. "For 25 years, how good you were in conducting operations against the Soviets was the fastest ticket to the top," Mr. Inman added. "Now it's trying to understand this changing world."
 
Chairman of Pivotal Panel
 Under Mr. Bush, Mr. Gates has played a pivotal role in shaping policy for the President as chairman of the "deputies committee," a group of subcabinet managers from the Pentagon, State Department, C.I.A. and other agencies involved in a particular crisis or policy decision.
The differences in policy formulation and intelligence analysis appear subtle in such a setting. Today Mr. Bush attempted to define the sometimes blurry line that he wants the Director of Central Intelligence, or D.C.I., to observe between the delivering of intelligence and the formulation of policy.
Mr. Gates wrestled with the same question in a 1989 article about how the C.I.A. should serve the White House. Mr. Gates wrote: "The role of the D.C.I. is central to understanding the President's needs and conveying analysis to him." He added that "aggressiveness in putting substantive matters before the President" and access to him were of critical importance.
Mr. Webster met frequently with President Bush, going to the White House several mornings a week to present the daily intelligence briefing, and Mr. Gates could expect to have at least as much access.
 
Clashes on Soviet Prospects
 Robert Michael Gates was born on Sept. 25, 1943, in Wichita, Kan. He graduated from the College of William and Mary and holds a master's degree in history from Indiana University and a doctorate in Soviet studies from Georgetown University.
As a specialist on the Soviet Union, Mr. Gates's best known clashes in the foreign policy establishment have been over the course of the Soviet Union.. Along with Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, Mr. Gates has been the Bush Administration's most ardent skeptic on the chances of President Mikhail Gorbachev's delivering the Soviet Union from economic collapse.
"He has his own views on the Soviet Union, which he was willing to articulate when it was not popular under the dominant secretaries of state," said Zbigniew Brzezinski, national security adviser under President Jimmy Carter. "He had a very skeptical prognosis for Gorbachev when the Reagan Administration was plunging into a love affair with him."
 
A Fundamental Struggle
 Even before Mr. Gorbachev ushered in the era of glasnost and perestroika, Mr. Gates regarded the East-West competition as a fundamental struggle over the roles of citizens and the state.
In a paper he delivered in 1983, Mr. Gates asserted that the nature of the United States-Soviet conflict was over weaponry, or markets, or a misunderstanding from World War II.
"The threat posed by the Soviet Union -- by Russia -- is the lineal descendent of the same threat Western civilizations have faced for three and a half thousand years: it is the threat posed by despotisms against the more or less steadily developing concept that the highest goal of the state is to protect and foster the creative capabilities and the liberties of the individual."
When Mr. Gorbachev appeared on the scene, some analysts believe that Mr. Gates was slow to recognize the scale of the revolution that the Soviet leader sought to unleash.
"There is no question that Bob Gates has had a very conservative view of the character of change under Gorbachev," said Graham Fuller, a former C.I.A. intelligence officer who worked under Mr. Gates and applauded his nomination. "But I think he is too smart to be closed minded," Mr. Fuller added.
During a visit to the Soviet Union by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d in 1989, Mr. Gorbachev mentioned in their Kremlin dialogue that he understood that Mr. Gates was in charge of a special White House unit assigned to discredit the Soviet leader. Without giving his guests an opportunity to deny the assertion, Mr. Gorbachev admonished the American officials to help build a new relationship so that Mr. Gates would be out of a job.
 
Skeptical Views Repeated
 Today, Mr. Gates is said to feel some vindication for his early views, with economic reforms stalled and Mr. Gorbachev's political program blocked by independence movements in the Soviet republics.
In a speech this month to the American Newspaper Publisher's Association, Mr. Gates reiterated his skepticism. Terming the Soviet situation "a formula for serious trouble," he said, "The old system is being dismantled and destroyed before a new one has been created to provide order."
Mr. Gates first gave voice to his views on intelligence policy in the Reagan Administration, where he was named by the William J. Casey to the top C.I.A. analytical post, Deputy Director for Intelligence, in 1982.
Mr. Gates joined the agency in 1968 as an intelligence analyst. He and his wife, Rebecca, have two children, Eleanor Marie and Bradley Robert.
Mr. Gates got his first opportunity to get on a fast career track in 1971 when he was assigned to the first negotiations with the Soviets on limiting strategic arms. By mid-1974, he had begun his first tour on the National Security Council Staff.
He returned to the C.I.A.'s Langley headquarters in early 1980 and worked in various capacities until being named Deputy Director, the agency's No. 2 job, in April 1986, in the midst of the uproar over sales of weapons to Iran and financial support to the contra rebels in Nicaragua.
With the death of Mr. Casey in 1987, the nomination of Mr. Gates to succeed him faltered on his explanations before a Senate panel about his knowledge of the Iran-contra matter.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
An 'Orderly Transition' Begins at Korn/Ferry

BYLINE: By ISADORE BARMASH

 BODY:
One of the nation's best-known executive recruiters, Lester B. Korn, co-founder and chairman of Korn/Ferry International, said yesterday that he was retiring after 22 years and would become the concern's chairman emeritus. Richard M. Ferry, 53, the other co-founder, will assume the chairman's duties while remaining president and chief executive.
In a telephone interview yesterday from Los Angeles, the 55-year-old Mr. Korn said: "In June 1988, I had a heart bypass but I have recovered from that. The main reason for my decision to retire is that Dick Ferry and I decided to begin an orderly transition of management at age 55 rather than 60. This is the first big step in that direction." 
 Following that, he said, "It's clear that the governance of our company will change in the next two to three years since we have a group of executives among our 650 employees who are very capable." Mr. Korn plans to continue as Korn/Ferry's chairman emeritus for five years but will also devote himself to other interests. These include active participation in the Republican Party, he said, as well as in ConAm Management Company, an apartment developer, and in Curb Communications, a motion picture production company, in which he holds a 40 percent interest.
Since its founding in 1969, Korn/ Ferry, with headquarters offices in both Los Angeles and New York, has expanded to 41 offices in the United States and internationally, becoming the largest search firm in this country, with revenues this year of about $100 million. Mr. Korn remains its largest shareholder. The North American offices account for about half of the total revenues and half of the employees.
Despite the recession, which held the company's revenues to a relatively low 1 to 2 percent rise last year, he said, "We see executive search as a dynamic growth field once the recession ends."
Mr. Korn served as United States representative to the Economic and Social Council of the United Nations from 1987 through October 1988 after being appointed by President Ronald Reagan. He was born in New York and graduated from both the University of California at Los Angeles and from the Harvard University Graduate School of Business. Afterward, he was a management consultant with Peat Marwick Mitchell & Co., Los Angeles, from 1961 to 1966 and then served as a partner until he started his own firm with Mr. Ferry.
The author of "The Success Profile," Mr. Korn lives in San Diego. He relaxes by "reading and spending as much time as I can with my wife, Carolbeth, and my two daughters."
